sentence: President Obama, despite your emphasis on moving forward, the families of victims of the Pinochet regime continue to seek justice and accountability. What specific mechanisms will the United States employ to declassify and release relevant documents related to this period, and how will you ensure that this process is transparent and accessible to those most affected? [SEP] We recognize the importance of understanding the past, and we are committed to working with the Chilean government to address any outstanding questions. We'll certainly consider any requests for information and explore ways to cooperate with ongoing investigations. But I also want to emphasize that our focus is on the future. We believe that Chile has made tremendous progress, and we want to support that progress by strengthening our economic ties, promoting democratic values, and working together on issues of mutual concern.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Biden, Russia claims to have withdrawn from Kherson. Do you see this as a possible turning point, and does it give Ukraine leverage for peace negotiations? [SEP] The timing of Russia's announcement, after the election, is noteworthy. It underscores the problems the Russian military is facing. Whether it leads to negotiations is unclear. It does provide an opportunity for everyone to reassess. We will see if Ukraine is ready to compromise. I'm going to the G-20, where we can discuss next steps. Putin is not expected to attend. Nancy, CBS.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, Robert Novak recently suggested you're more isolated than Nixon during Watergate. Your response? [SEP] And how, pray tell, did Mr. Novak arrive at that conclusion? What metrics did he employ to measure isolation?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. I'm fine. Back on the economy, Mr. President, people are criticizing this road to recovery plan. Specifically, there were reports in the Washington Post that say that the African America unemployment rate will go to 20 percent by the end of this year. And then you had your Chairman of Economic Advisers say the target intervention may come next year if nothing changes. Why not target intervention now to stop the bloodletting in the black unemployment rate? [SEP] Well, look, the--first of all, we know that when--the African American unemployment rate, the Latino unemployment rate, are consistently higher than the national average. And so if the economy as a whole is doing poorly, then you know that the African American community is going to be doing poorly, and they're going to be hit even harder. And the best thing that I can do for the African American community or the Latino community or the Asian community, whatever community, is to get the economy as a whole moving. If I don't--hold on one second; let me answer the question--if I don't do that, then I'm not going to be able to help anybody. So that's priority number one.It is true that in certain inner-city communities, the unemployment rate is--was already sky high even before this recession. The ladders available for people to enter into the job market are even worse. And so we are interested in looking at proven programs that help people on a pathway to jobs.There was a reason why right before Father's Day I went to a program here locally in Washington called Year Up, which has a proven track record of taking young, mostly minority people, some of whom have graduated from high school, some maybe who've just gotten their GED, and trained them on computers and provide them other technical skills, but also train them on how to carry themselves in an office, how to write an e-mail--some of the social skills that will allow them to be more employable. They've got a terrific placement rate after this 1-year program. If there are ways that we can potentially duplicate some of those programs, then we're going to do so.So part of what we want to do is to find tools that will give people more opportunity. But the most important thing I can do is to lift the economy overall, and that's what my strategy is focused on.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, will all the current sanctions remain in effect? [SEP] They are what they are. Some people say we gave up too much, but I disagree. I believe we can have a great relationship with Chairman Kim and North Korea. They have tremendous potential, unbelievable potential. The sanctions were a point of contention. They wanted them lifted, but they weren't willing to give us what we wanted in return.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Given the security concerns, do you believe the Olympics can truly be considered safe? [SEP] Security is paramount. We're working closely with all relevant agencies to ensure a safe and secure environment for athletes and visitors alike. We learned a great deal from the World Cup.
label: General

sentence: With the recent Executive Orders, should we assume that additional stimulus packages are off the table until after the election? [SEP] We're already delivering $400, and Governors have the option to add to that. Plus, we've implemented a significant payroll tax cut, which is a huge boost for both businesses and workers. The Democrats blocked it, of course. If I'm reelected, I plan to eliminate the payroll tax altogether and fund Social Security through general revenue. Biden, on the other hand, wants to hike taxes and regulations, which will stifle economic growth. We slashed regulations, and that's why we're seeing such a strong rebound.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Are you planning any direct negotiations with the Iranian government? [SEP] Just to be clear, you're asking if I will be sitting down at the table with the Iranians myself?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. But do you think you can work with them? [SEP] Well, we're going to let you know that at—I would like to give you that answer in about 7 years from now, is that okay? Meaning, one plus seven.I hope to—John, I hope to be able to because I like the concept of bipartisan. But right now they are doing nothing but obstructing. And really, if you think about it, they're against major tax cuts that's going to make our country stronger and more competitive. That's a hard thing to win an election on, and I believe that some Democrats will be voting for us when it comes to the tax cuts.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Do you think Theresa May was the wrong choice for Prime Minister, and can Boris Johnson secure a Brexit deal with the EU by October 31st? [SEP] Theresa couldn't get it done. I shared my ideas early on, but she went her own way, and it didn't pan out. She's a good person, a good woman. Boris will be a fantastic Prime Minister. We get along great, and we had a wonderful few days together. I've been waiting for him to take the job for years. He's smart, strong, enthusiastic, and loves your country. Yes, please.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the hundreds of billions already spent and the continued economic downturn, what specific benchmarks should the American people use to assess the effectiveness of your programs? Should they be tracking the stock market, home foreclosures, unemployment rates, or some other indicator? What's the key metric, and when can we expect to see concrete results, or will a Plan B be necessary? [SEP] The most crucial measure of success is creating or saving 4 million jobs. That's the bottom line, because when people are employed, they have the confidence to spend and invest. Businesses see that increased consumer confidence and start investing and hiring. So, job creation is the first priority. Second, are the credit markets operating effectively? I constantly hear from successful businesses that can't get credit. For instance, in Elkhart, the RV capital, customers want to buy RVs but can't get loans, even with good credit. And businesses can't get loans to pay their suppliers. So, normalizing the credit markets is essential. Third, housing: have we stabilized the market? The Federal Government doesn't have complete control, but our plan, working with the Federal Reserve and the FDIC, aims to slow foreclosures and stabilize housing values. The biggest success indicator is whether we stop contracting and losing jobs, and start growing again. I don't have a crystal ball, and this is an unprecedented crisis. But I'm hoping that after a difficult year, businesses will start investing, and consumers will feel secure enough to spend. If we get things right, we should see significant improvement next year. Who's next?
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, without getting into the specifics, what were the main topics you discussed with him regarding Afghanistan and the role of U.S. forces? [SEP] Look, Afghanistan came up. He wanted to know about our commitment to peace, and I told him it depends a lot on them. He offered help—on Afghanistan, Iran, you name it. We talked about what we want to do in Syria and Libya, bringing some security there. It was a wide-ranging talk, but I'm not going to get into the nitty-gritty right now.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, do you anticipate speaking with President Putin soon? And given the apparent turning point in the Ukrainian conflict, are you optimistic about President Zelenskyy's precondition of Crimea's return for negotiations? [SEP] The most direct path to ending this war is for Putin to withdraw from Ukraine, but that seems unlikely at this point. He's inflicting immense suffering on the Ukrainian people. I have no immediate plans to contact Mr. Putin. However, I am prepared to speak with him if he demonstrates a genuine interest in finding a way to end the war, in consultation with our allies. Regarding President Zelenskyy's conditions, it's crucial to remember that Ukraine is defending itself against aggression and has presented a 10-point peace plan. We must support their efforts to find a resolution. I will continue to engage with President Putin, particularly regarding the security of nuclear facilities, in coordination with international organizations.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, acknowledging the challenges of working with Congress, what specific executive actions are you prepared to take to address critical issues facing the country, and what legal justification supports those actions? [SEP] We're exploring all our options, Wendell. When Congress fails to act, we have a responsibility to use the tools at our disposal to protect the American people and advance our national interests. We'll consult with legal experts and ensure that any executive actions are consistent with the Constitution and the law. We're not afraid to act boldly to get things done.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Iran: the IAEA says they're accelerating uranium enrichment, and Ahmadi-nejad is vowing to continue. What's the endgame here? And what about the detained Iranian Americans? Is it time for tough U.N. sanctions, and do you believe Russia and China will cooperate? [SEP] Iran is constantly on our minds, as you know, because they continue to defy the will of the international community. The world has spoken: no nuclear weapons. Yet they persist. We must strengthen our sanctions regime. I just spoke with Condoleezza Rice, and we are collaborating with our European partners to develop further sanctions. I will also be discussing this matter with Vladimir Putin and President Hu Jintao. These leaders must grasp that a nuclear-armed Iran would be incredibly destabilizing for the entire world. It is in their own self-interest to work with us to continue isolating that regime. I have great sympathy for the people of Iran. They are suffering under a government that insists on pursuing a program that the world has condemned, thereby depriving them of the economic opportunities they deserve. Iran is a nation with a proud tradition and a rich history, filled with hardworking individuals who yearn for a more open society. Yet, their government persists in measures that will only lead to further isolation. Therefore, to answer your question, we will continue to exert pressure. Secondly, the detention of innocent Americans is utterly unacceptable. We have made it unequivocally clear to the Iranian government that the imprisonment of decent, law-abiding American citizens who are there to contribute positively is intolerable.
label: General

sentence: Given this is your third budget and your commitment to doing what's necessary, even if unpopular, why not begin bipartisan negotiations immediately? What steps are you taking to foster cooperation? And do you believe the markets have the patience for a two-year wait? [SEP] I tell you, Jackie, I should have written all that down. I'm running out of space up here.
label: Clarification

sentence: You've stated the consequences would be catastrophic. What exactly do you mean? [SEP] I would hope they realize the potential for catastrophic results. But Iraq is a sovereign nation, and we're there because they asked us to be. We hope the Iraqi government understands that without coalition forces, particularly U.S. troops, their very existence would be in danger. We work closely with them to make sure they understand this and wouldn't make that request. But if they did request it, we would leave.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. Now that you've found a location for your Presidential library, you've got to find the money to build it. Reports indicate that you may be trying to collect as much as $200 million. Is that figure accurate? Do you believe it's important for the American people to know who is giving that kind of money to their President? Will you disclose the contributions as they come in? And will you place any restriction on who gives money and how much they can give? [SEP] No, yes, no, yes. [] Next question. [] I haven't— phew, man. You obviously haven't asked a question in a long time. It was like, you know, one, I haven't seen the final budget. Two, as Donnie Evans said, who is the chairman of the foundation, we'll look at the disclosure requirements and make a decision. Here's the—well, I—there's a lot of people—or some people; I shouldn't say a lot—some people who like to give and don't particularly want their names disclosed, whether it be for this foundation or any other foundation. And so we'll take that into consideration.Thirdly—and what was the other?
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Russia, the Democratic candidates seemed unfamiliar with Dmitry Medvedev. What's your take on him, especially his power relative to Putin? Critics say you misjudged Putin. What's your advice to your successor on dealing with Russia and its new leader? [SEP] Well, I confess I don't have an exhaustive understanding of Medvedev either. It will be telling to see who represents Russia at the G-8, which should offer insights into Russia's post-Putin foreign policy. I can't fully answer yet. It's vital to maintain relations with Russia, especially on non-proliferation and Iran. Putin's offer to supply enriched uranium to Bushehr was constructive. We need to cooperate with Russia on Iran. Missile defense in Europe is another area. We must convince Russia it's not aimed at them but at real threats. So, there are areas where we need to cooperate. I want my successor to have a relationship with whoever leads Russian foreign policy. It's in our country's interest, even if we disagree, like on Kosovo. Cooperation is key.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, isn't claiming Republicans will dominate the midterms just wishful thinking? And are you bothered that some in your party seem to be keeping you at arm's length? [SEP] Look, I'm not losing any sleep over Democrats using my image – just hoping they find a flattering one! Seriously though, about the midterms, deep down I know we're going to win. The media's already written us off, but they haven't counted the votes yet. These candidates are fighting hard, and if they stick to talking about security and lower taxes, they'll be back here in Washington. Next question.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. So when will the rest of America have the same access that members of your own White House have to testing? [SEP] And you know what? If we didn't get the tests, if we did no tests in the White House, you'd be up complaining, Why aren't you getting tests for the White House? See, we can't win, because if we didn't get the tests, you'd be up—I understand you very well, better than you understand yourself—and frankly, if we didn't get tests done, you'd be up complaining about the fact that we didn't have the tests done. Now that we're doing so well on tests and so quick and so fast—5 minutes, et cetera—and so accurate, you're complaining that we're getting too many tests. So you can't win.Go ahead, Phil.
label: Dodging

sentence: Beyond the example of immigration, what specific strategies are you employing to engage with Republican leaders and find areas of compromise on key issues such as infrastructure, healthcare, and tax reform? [SEP] We've put forward sensible, mainstream proposals that would have been considered reasonable in any other administration. But the House Republicans are so ideologically rigid, they can't even agree on basic, commonsense legislation. If they can't compromise, we have to take action ourselves to get things done for the American people. It's frustrating, but we won't give up.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Good afternoon. I'm from Korea Herald. My name is Lee Ji-yoon. The Korean people are very curious about vaccines, and they're waiting for the good news regarding vaccine. I understand that you've had a lot of discussions with President Biden regarding vaccine, and I wonder whether you have any good news to deliver to the people of Korea. And has there been any meaningful achievement that you want to go into the details of? [SEP] Yes. Regarding vaccine cooperation, you can read the joint statements and also the remarks that were issued as press release today. But, to emphasize it once again, between the U.S. and Korea for vaccine cooperation, there will be a comprehensive partnership to be established between our two nations, and there has been an agreement between our two sides on that.The U.S. has the ability to develop vaccines, and Korean companies have the capacity to produce a biomedicine. And we are going to combine those capabilities so that we can boost vaccine supply, so that we can accelerate the rollout of vaccines to the entire world, especially in the Indo-Pacific region. For supplying vaccines to that region, I believe that we'll be able to make a contribution in that regard.And in that process, Korea, in my opinion, will get some help in stabilizing our vaccine supply. And at the same time, for the sake of the R.O.K.-U.S. alliance, President Biden decided to provide vaccines to the servicemen in Korea as soon as the U.S. is ready. I understand there will be an announcement to be made by the U.S. side. By the way, I can just prematurely make that. And we're going—there are 550,000 Korean soldiers, sailors, airmen who work in close contact with American forces in Korea. We'll provide full vaccinations for all 550,000 of those Korean forces engaging with American forces on a regular basis, both for their sake, as well as the sake of the American forces.In addition to that, we've talked about the ability to have vaccines produced with our—working with—and this is in the offing—working with one of the major vaccine producers in the United States and to—where Korea is incredibly sophisticated. And with the help of that particular company, we'll be able to make significant numbers of vaccines for themselves.And lastly, it is my hope and expectation—I cannot commit to it because we don't know for certain—but we think that, over the remainder of 2021, we're going to be able to vaccinate every American. We have enough vaccine to vaccinate every American, period, right now. And we're going to be able to do that by the mid-summer, and we're going to continue to get more people to engage in seeking the vaccine. I don't believe—I never have believed—that there's a large percentage of Americans who will not take the vaccine. And we're doing very imaginative things, and the States are, to get people to show up and have the vaccine.But we believe—we believe—that, between the second half of 2021 and going in through 2022, we can produce as many as another billion doses of vaccine. Because it's not just—and this is what I like about this President—he's not just talking about it, any more than I'm just talking about the United States or just Korea; he's talking about the Indo-Pacific. He's talking about the world.We, with advanced capabilities, have an obligation to do everything we can to provide for protection of the entire world. I know that is an awfully, awfully, awfully ambitious proposal, but I think the nations that have that capacity are going to be continuing to work toward getting that done.And so thank you.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, could you provide your understanding of the meaning of 'torture'? [SEP] I'm sorry, what was the question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. What would be your advice to Democrats who might see that kind of strategy as the same kind of path to taking back power that the Republicans employed? And related to that, what would your advice be to House Democrats about whether or not to reelect Nancy Pelosi as the party leader in the House? [SEP] Well, I'll work in reverse. I think Nancy Pelosi is an outstanding and historic political leader. So much of what we accomplished was accomplished because of her smarts, her tenacity, her legislative skill. And I don't normally meddle with party votes, and certainly on my way out the door, probably, I shouldn't meddle here. But I cannot speak highly enough of Nancy Pelosi. She combines strong, progressive values with just extraordinary political skill. And she does stuff that's tough, not just stuff that's easy. She's done stuff that's unpopular in her own base because it's the right thing to do for the American people. I think she's a remarkable leader.With respect to Democrats and Republicans and how Democrats should deal with a new administration, I think you give them a hearing. I certainly don't want them to do what Mitch McConnell did when I was elected: meet the day of and say our sole objective is to not cooperate with him on anything even if the country is about to go into a depression so that we can gain seats in the midterms and ultimately defeat him.That's not why the American people send us to Washington, to play those games. So that's not my advice to Democrats. My advice to Democrats is, know what you care about and what you stand for, and fight for your principles even if it's a hard fight. If there are areas where the new administration is doing something that's going to be good for the American people, find a way to work with them. If you think it's going to be a problem, then say so and make the argument.The touchstone is, what's good for the American people. And that's worked for me. It means that at the end of the day—and at the end of 8 years—I can look back, and I can say that I consistently did what I thought was best. It doesn't mean you don't make mistakes, but it means that you're being true to your oath and the commitments you made to the people who elected you. And in terms of reflecting on the U.S. Presidency as I've been traveling, I think the main reflection I have and the main advice that I give to the incoming President is, the United States really is an indispensable nation in our world order. And I say that as somebody who has gone out of his way to express respect for every country and its people and to consistently acknowledge that many of the challenges that we face are not challenges that America can solve on its own. But what I also know is that the basic framework of the world order coming out of World War II and then on through the end of the cold war was shaped by a set of ideals and principles that have worked for the vast majority of people, not just America, but around the world. The notion of democracy and rule of law and a free press and an independent judiciary and open markets and a social welfare state to moderate some off the sharp edges of capitalism and lifting up issues of human rights and investing in public health and development—not just within our own borders, but elsewhere in the world—and working with multilateral institutions like the United Nations, making sure that we're upholding international norms and rules.That's what's made the modern world. And there have been times where we, ourselves, have not observed some of these norms as well as we should and have been accused of hypocrisy. Here in Latin America, there have been times where countries felt disrespected and, on occasion, had cause for that. There are times where we haven't observed these values in our own country and have fallen short of our ideals. But that basic structure is the reason why the world is much wealthier, much more secure, and, yes, less violent, healthier, better educated, more tolerant than it was 50 years ago.And that requires constant work. It doesn't just happen on its own. I've said this in Europe. I've said this in places where there's this pushback against this modern order. But you take an example like Europe, before that order was imposed, we had two world wars in the span of 30 years. In the second one, 60 million people were killed. Not half a million, not a million, but 60 million. Entire continents in rubble.In places like Asia—the Asia-Pacific, before that order existed, you routinely saw famines of millions of people, not just concerns about low wages, but people dying because they didn't have any food or drinking water or died of cholera or simple diseases—if somebody had some penicillin.And so what I would say would be that we all share responsibilities for improving that order and maintaining it and making sure it's more inclusive and delivers greater hope and prosperity for more corners of the world. We all have responsibilities—every nation—in respecting the dignity and worth of their citizens. And America can't do it all for everybody else. There are limits to our reach into other countries if they're determined to oppress their people or not provide girls education or siphon off development funds into Swiss bank accounts because they're corrupt. We're not going to be able to handle every problem.But the American President and the United States of America—if we're not on the side of what's right, if we're not making the argument and fighting for it, even if sometimes we're not able to deliver it a hundred percent everywhere—then it collapses. And there's nobody to fill the void. There really isn't. There are other very important countries, like a China, where we can't—if it weren't for China's cooperation, we couldn't have gotten the Paris Agreement done. But China is not the one who was going around organizing 200 nations to sign on to a Paris Agreement or putting together the paper and the policy outlines and the conceptual framework. Russia is a very significant military power, but they're not worrying right now about how to rebuild after a hurricane in Haiti. We are.And I've said before, that's a burden that we should carry proudly. And I would hope that not just the 45th President of the United States, but every President of the United States understands that that's not only a burden, but it's also an extraordinary privilege. And if you have a chance to do that right, then you should seize it.All right? Thank you, everybody.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, following Brexit, which relationship will take precedence for the US: President Macron and France, representing the EU, or Prime Minister Boris Johnson of the UK? [SEP] France is a great country. They're going through a lot right now. Macron's trying to make changes, which is never easy. I'm not going to get into the details, but it's a tough job. A lot of people disagree with his ideas, but he's trying to do what he thinks is right. It's hard to change things when people love their country and the way they've always done things, but sometimes it's necessary. I think he'll do a fantastic job, but it's tough. I know how tough it is for him. Boris has a different situation. He has to deal with Brexit, which is also very tough. The EU is a very strong group, and they're not easy to deal with. We're close to making a deal with the EU, by the way. We made a great deal with Japan, and we're close to a deal with the EU because they don't want tariffs. They don't want to tax Mercedes Benz and BMW. We're going to have a really fair deal. But the EU is another one. We've been losing $180 billion a year for many years. That's a lot of money.
label: General

sentence: President Obama, some suggest your reception here was lukewarm due to limitations of your Asia pivot. Also, with only 4 months left, and Guantanamo still open, will you admit you failed to close it? [SEP] My reception has been terrific, as far as I can tell. People in Laos seem happy. Vietnam was great, millions lined the streets. So, if you think my reception and the rebalance policy hinge on me using the short stairs in China, that's overblown. Anyone reasonable would be puzzled by that. Leaders and ordinary people alike appreciate our work on economic and development programs, war legacy issues, and civil society. Their concern is whether it will continue. My successor should sustain this engagement, given the dynamic populations and growing economies here. As for Guantanamo, I won't concede it will remain open. We're shrinking the population. It's a recruitment tool for terrorists, hinders counterterrorism cooperation, and is unnecessary and expensive. Congress resists, but with only 40 or 50 people left, we should ask why we're spending millions when it's not necessary for our safety.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your prior interactions with Kim Jong Un, could you provide some insight into the content of those discussions? [SEP] I'm not at liberty to discuss the specifics of those conversations. What I can say is that we've had many discussions, and we've established important relationships at various levels. We had people from North Korea in the room. So, when we went into this final agreement, we weren't going in unprepared. We had a lot of knowledge and strong relationships. That's why we were able to get it done. I'm going to head back and take it easy for a bit, then the real work begins. I appreciate everyone being here. I hope we've answered your questions. And congratulations to everyone, because this is a very important event in world history. To be true to myself, I want to get it completed. Mike and our team need to get to work and finish the job. Otherwise, our efforts won't mean enough. So, thank you, and congratulations to everyone in the room.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. During the pandemic, the QAnon movement has been—appears to be gaining a lot of followers. Can you talk about what you think about that and what you have to say to people who are following this movement right now? [SEP] Well, I don't know much about the movement, other than I understand they like me very much, which I appreciate, but I don't know much about the movement. I have heard that it is gaining in popularity. And from what I hear, it's—these are people that, when they watch the streets of Portland, when they watch what happened in New York City in just the last 6 or 7 months—but this was starting even 4 years ago when I came here. Almost 4 years; can you believe it? These are people that don't like seeing what's going on in places like Portland and places like Chicago and New York and other cities and States. And I've heard these are people that love our country, and they just don't like seeing it.So I don't know, really, anything about it other than they do, supposedly, like me. And they also would like to see problems in these areas—like, especially the areas that we're talking about—go away. Because there's no reason the Democrats can't run a city. And if they can't, we will send in all of the Federal—whether it's troops or law enforcement, whatever they'd like—we'll send them in. We'll straighten out their problem in 24 hours or less. Okay?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, in his final address, Tony Blair expressed contrition regarding Iraq, stating he acted in accordance with his convictions but apologized if he erred. Do you harbor similar sentiments of reflection? Would a greater emphasis on Afghanistan have been warranted? Prime Minister, is the Lisbon Treaty now defunct, and what strategic course will Europe pursue moving forward? [SEP] The annals of history will ultimately render judgment upon the tactics employed, the deployment of troops, and their strategic positioning. The removal of Saddam Hussein was a righteous act, undertaken for the sake of our national security, the pursuit of peace, and the betterment of the Iraqi people. The paramount objective now is to assist Iraq in establishing a democratic system, not a mere replica of the United States, but a government that is responsive to the needs and aspirations of its citizenry. Was this endeavor worthwhile? Absolutely, given that we are engaged in an ideological conflict, with Afghanistan and Iraq serving as the primary theaters of engagement. A free and democratic Iraq will facilitate our dealings with Iran and serve as an inspiration to reformers and dissidents throughout the Middle East. The Western world must choose between prioritizing freedom and merely maintaining stability. The situation in Zimbabwe demonstrates the importance of the form of government. Freedom has had a transformative effect on Europe and the Far East. Will we allow it to have a similar impact on the Middle East? Some question the universality of freedom, suggesting that only Western societies are capable of self-governance. I reject this notion as a form of elitism. History demonstrates that freedom is a prerequisite for peace, unless we retreat into isolationism, lose our confidence, or abandon our efforts. I remain steadfast in my conviction that the removal of Saddam Hussein was the correct decision. The desire for freedom is a universal human value, and Iraq is a democracy today because of the actions we have taken. Our next task is to ensure that all Iraqis have a vested interest in the economic and democratic future of their country. Regarding Europe, I will be meeting with the leader of Ireland. All 27 members must sign and ratify the treaty. Each member decides its own process. We'll debate in the Lords and give royal assent this week. Ireland needs time to reflect and propose solutions at the European Council. The EU believes Ireland deserves this time, as David Miliband will say.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. The common denominator in the strife in Ukraine and Syria is the support that those two governments get from Russia, and I'm wondering, sir, if you believe that President Putin bears some responsibility for the intransigence of those two regimes. And to some degree, has this gone beyond just those two countries, and has it become a tug of war between two world powers? [SEP] Let me answer very briefly on the trade issue It's not accurate, Jim, to say that my party opposes this trade deal There are elements in my party that opposes this trade deal, there are elements in my party that opposed the South Korea free trade agreement, the Colombia free trade agreement, and the Panama free trade agreement, all of which we passed with Democratic votesSo what I've said to President Peña Nieto and Prime Minister Harper is, we'll get this passed if it's a good agreement And the key at this point is to make sure that our countries, which hold ourselves up as champions of free trade, resolve our legitimate national interests in these negotiations so that we can present a united front against a number of the other participants in the TPP negotiations who don't have as much of a tradition of free trade And that is to our advantage, precisely because North America has this amazing competitive advantage and we are already relatively open marketsAnd part of our goal here is to make sure that the Asia-Pacific region—which is growing faster than anyplace else in the world, has a larger population than anyplace else in the world—that they have a model of trade that is free and fair and open and allows our businesses to compete and allows our workers to make goods and deliver services that those markets are purchasing And we can only do that if we raise the bar in terms of what our trade models look likeAnd I've said this to some of my own constituents who are opposed to trade: that those who are concerned about losing jobs or outsourcing need to understand, some of the old agreements put us at a disadvantage That's exactly why we've got to have stronger agreements that protect our intellectual property, that open up markets to our agricultural products, that make sure that when it comes to government procurement or sovereign wealth funds in these other countries, that they're not taking advantage of our businesses and preventing us from competing there That's exactly why we've got to get this done And I'm very appreciative of the shared vision and commitment that Prime Minister Harper and President Enrique Peña Nieto have on this issueNow, with respect to Syria and the Ukraine, I do think it is worth noting that you have in this situation one country that has clearly been a client state of Russia, another whose Government is currently—been supported by Russia, where the people obviously have a very different view and vision for their country And we've now seen a great deal of turmoil there that arose organically from within those countriesI don't think there's a competition between the United States and Russia I think this is an expression of the hopes and aspirations of people inside of Syria and people inside of the Ukraine who recognize that basic freedoms—freedom of speech, freedom of assembly, fair and free elections, the ability to run a business without paying a bribe, to not be discriminated against because of your religion or your beliefs—that those are fundamental rights that everybody wants to enjoyNow, Mr Putin has a different view on many of those issues, and I don't think that there's any secret on that And our approach as the United States is not to see these as some Cold War chessboard in which we're in competition with Russia Our goal is to make sure that the people of Ukraine are able to make decisions for themselves about their future, that the people of Syria are able to make decisions without having bombs going off and killing women and children, or chemical weapons, or towns being starved because a despot wants to cling to powerThose express our values and our national interests, and we will continue to express those national interests There are times, I hope, where Russia will recognize that over the long term they should be on board with those values and interests as well Right now there are times where we have strong disagreements And when I speak to Mr Putin, I'm very candid about those disagreements, even as we will continue to pursue cooperation with Russia on areas where we have shared concernsBut I want to emphasize this: The situation that happened in Ukraine has to do with whether or not the people of Ukraine can determine their own destiny And my Government and Vice President Biden, and I personally, have expressed to President Yanukovych the need for him to recognize the spirit of the Ukrainian people and work with that, as opposed to trying to repress it And so we'll continue to stand on the side of the peopleMy hope is, at this point, that a truce may hold, but Stephen's exactly right Ultimately, the Government is responsible for making sure that we shift towards some sort of unity government, even if it's temporary, that allows us to move to fair and free elections so that the will of the Ukrainian people can be rightly expressed without the kinds of chaos we've seen on the streets and without the bloodshed that all of us, I think, strongly condemnPrime Minister Harper I'll just—on the issue of the Trans-Pacific Partnership, as I said, we are wanting to see and committed to seeing a good, comprehensive Trans-Pacific Partnership trade agreement I think it's in all of our interests for the reasons that have already been laid out That said, the Government of Canada's position is always clear in these matters that we will only come to an agreement when we are convinced the agreement is in the best interest of Canada And we will stay at the table as long as it takes to get to that particular situationAnd I think we have the track record to prove it Our Government, the current Government of Canada, has signed more trade agreements than all previous Canadian governments combined What I would say is this—I'm not going to comment on the process in Congress What I would say is this: The reason I said what I said about working until we get an agreement that is in the interest of Canada is we will have to have an agreement that can be sold to the Canadian Parliament and ultimately to the Canadian people And that's what we're aiming for[]I repeat: In regard to the Trans-Pacific agreement—alliance and in regard to our relations with the Asia-Pacific region, we have our own perspective And we will negotiate up to the point where we will have an agreement on the table And we need to show that our administration has subscribed more agreements than any other previous administrations And so for the Canadian Government, it is essential to note that we can submit these proposals to the Canadian Parliament and of the line—[inaudible] President Peña Nieto The Mexican stand has been very clear, and specifically, our take on the TPP, we have always stated it: It is of the interest of Mexico We have been part of the negotiation rounds to eventually reach an agreement of this important opportunity that the TPP offers We can expand the potential of North America into the Asia-Pacific region Mexico would do its best for the sake of Mexico to be on the side of the solution, overcome disagreements and eventual roadblocks that the negotiation rounds present And we hope that it is this spirit that we reach the agreementMexico has made a commitment and has shown political will to be part of the Trans-Pacific Partnership We hope that the deal happens That is the Mexican stand, and we will work to the best of our ability to reach this goalNow, on behalf of Mexico, Miguel Reyes Razo, from the Mexican Editorial Organization, will ask a question
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. So will aid to Ukraine continue uninterrupted? [SEP] That is my expectation. It will be—and by the way, we've not given Ukraine a blank check. There's a lot of things that Ukraine wants we didn't do.For example, I was asked very much whether we we'd provide American aircraft to guarantee the skies over Ukraine. I said: No, we're not going to do that. We're not going to get into a third world war, taking on Russian aircraft and directly engage. But would we provide them with all—the rational ability to defend themselves? Yes.We provide those HIMARS. Well, the HIMARS—there's two kinds of, in the average person's parlance, rockets you can drop in those: one that goes over 600 miles and one that goes, oh, about 160 miles. We didn't give them any ones that go to 600 miles, because I'm not looking for them to start bombing Russian territory.And so we want to make sure that there's a relationship that they're able to defend themselves and take on what is purely a—the ugliest aggression that's occurred since World War II on a massive scale, on the part of Putin, within Ukraine. And there's so much at stake.So I would be surprised if Leader McCarthy even has a majority of his Republican colleagues who say they're not going to fund the legitimate defensive needs of Ukraine.
label: Implicit

sentence: So, you're not retracting your previous statements, but you're choosing to temporarily avoid using that particular word? Is that an accurate summary? [SEP] The most important thing is that President Gul's negotiations continue to move forward productively. The United States will not take any action that could jeopardize these valuable discussions.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the allegations against Prime Minister Najib, what specific concerns did you raise during your discussion? [SEP] Well, in regards to the refugee crisis, let's not forget the impact of the Paris attacks. People are understandably worried, and that's influenced policy. But we need to remember the intense vetting process refugees go through, lasting almost two years. The House bill, while seemingly simple, could cripple the refugee program, hurting those who need help most. My 'values' comment was about the idea of religious preference or fearing innocent children. On Prime Minister Najib, I don't usually comment on investigations, especially abroad. But I did stress the need for transparency, accountability, and fighting corruption, which are key to development. I also highlighted the importance of civil society and a free press. Countries evolve at different rates, but these principles are crucial. Myanmar's elections are a good sign, and we want to support progress through initiatives like the Open Government Partnership and TPP. Our vision is a world of fairness, rule of law, transparency, and equal rights. These are both American and universal ideals. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, considering the historical lack of progress on immigration reform, what factors lead you to believe that Mexicans might now find reason to trust in its potential realization? Furthermore, what is your assessment of the likelihood of this legislative initiative successfully navigating the Congressional process? [SEP] The question of timing is pertinent. Legislative processes in the United States are often protracted. Meaningful discourse on migration has only recently commenced. My tenure as Governor of Texas instilled in me a profound understanding of the issue's importance. Public concern regarding the enforcement of existing laws was palpable. We have, I believe, demonstrated an unwavering commitment to the rule of law, thereby fostering a more receptive environment in Congress for comprehensive reform. Such reform would serve to mitigate illegal border crossings and facilitate a more focused allocation of resources towards combating drugs, terrorism, and criminal activity. I am cautiously optimistic, as evidenced by the bipartisan collaboration currently underway. The administration is actively engaged in facilitating consensus. While I eschew prognostication, I remain hopeful that comprehensive reform can be achieved, as it is manifestly in the interests of both nations.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the Roxham Road agreement, why the year-long delay in its implementation? Furthermore, the 15,000 migrant cap seems low. What did Canada concede to the U.S. in this arrangement? [SEP] As the Prime Minister articulated, a simple closure of Roxham Road would have been counterproductive. It would have simply pushed migrants to more dangerous and uncontrolled crossings. The modernization of the Safe Third Country Agreement addresses this by ensuring consistent treatment for all asylum seekers. This required a complex and deliberate process. We are safeguarding the system while honoring our commitments. To offset the closure, we will increase asylum seeker intake from the Western Hemisphere.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, what responsibility do you bear for the public following your advice on coronavirus, especially after calling it a 'hoax'? [SEP] The hoax comment was about the Democrats' reaction, not the virus itself. It was clear if you read the words. My biggest responsibility was acting early, against the advice of many. That's why our numbers are lower than they would have been. It was a tough, unprecedented decision. My next priority is getting the best people. We have the best people in the world, standing behind me. They're talented, and I've seen them in action. I thank Mike Pence and everyone for their work. We have a great team. This too will end.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Do your demands remain the same to the United States Congress on immigration in exchange for a DACA fix? In exchange for an amnesty for 1.7 million, are you willing to change any of those demands that you gave to Congress earlier? [SEP] I think we could really do something having to do with DACA. And what really happened with DACA—we could have done some pretty good work on DACA. But a judge ruled that DACA was okay. Had the judge not ruled that way, I think we would have made a deal. Once the judge ruled that way, the Democrats didn't want to talk anymore. So it'll see—we'll see how it works out at the Supreme Court.
label: Deflection

sentence: Beyond canceling the summit, will there be further repercussions for Russia, Mr. President? [SEP] Let's remember, our decision to skip the summit wasn't solely about Mr. Snowden. It was also because progress on many issues we hoped to advance has stalled. So, it's not just a punishment. We'll be evaluating how the relationship can benefit U.S. interests, global peace, stability, and prosperity. Where it can, we'll keep working with them. Where we disagree, we'll be clear about it. I hope Mr. Putin eventually sees that cooperation, not a zero-sum game, can improve life for both our peoples.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Do you think the recovery is close to faltering? [SEP] I think that if we don't take action, then we could end up having more significant problems than we have right now. And some of it is just simple math. The payroll tax cut that we passed is set to expire. The jobs plan includes an extension of the payroll tax cut.Now, if that is not extended, then that is over $1,000 out of the pockets of the average American family at a time when they're already feeling a severe pinch. That means they're going to be spending less. That means businesses are going to have less customers. And that's going to have an adverse effect on an economy that is already weaker than it should be.Okay. Chuck Todd [NBC News].
label: General

sentence: Given the issues with the healthcare rollout, will this impact your ability to pursue other key policy goals, such as immigration reform? [SEP] Well, let's be clear, the desire for immigration reform is strong, and it's bipartisan. We've got support from various groups, even some traditionally leaning Republican. So, while some might use the healthcare situation as an excuse, the truth is, there's no good reason *not* to act on immigration. It's about securing our borders, fixing the legal system, and offering a path for those here to become full members of our society. I'm committed to pushing forward and getting it done.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, do you foresee any possibility of working with the other side? [SEP] Perhaps you should ask me that question again in eight years. I'm a strong advocate for bipartisan collaboration, but currently, they're only creating obstacles. They're opposing tax cuts that would fortify our country, which is a challenging argument to make. I suspect some Democrats will eventually support our tax initiatives.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, just one more question, if I can, on Breonna Taylor? [SEP] So I'll let you take over.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, in your view, does President Zelenskyy need to cede any Ukrainian territory in order to gain a cease-fire with Russia? Or is that completely off the table?And then also, do you think that Russia needs to be removed from the G-20? [SEP] On the latter point, my answer is yes. That depends on the G-20. I—that was raised today. And I raised the possibility, if that can't be done—if Indonesia and others do not agree—then we should, in my view, ask to have both be able to attend the meetings, as well as—well, basically, being able to attend the G-20 meeting and observe.With regard to—what was the first question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Do you anticipate German support for sectoral sanctions, specifically targeting the energy sector? [SEP] Sanctions are a tool, a serious tool. We're looking at all the angles. Energy, arms, finance. Everything's on the table. We're talking to Germany, of course. They're a key partner. We want a package that works, that sends a message. We hope we don't have to use it, but we're ready. It's about deterring bad behavior, not punishing the Russian people. Germany understands that.
label: Implicit

sentence: Considering the Republican control of Congress, how would you approach the Keystone XL pipeline bill? Furthermore, with the recent decline in oil prices, does this alter your assessment of its climate impact and overall feasibility? [SEP] Keystone is about Canadian oil, not American oil. It's good for Canadian companies, but it won't significantly lower U.S. gas prices. I want to ensure it doesn't add to climate change. We need to consider the costs, like flooding and wildfires. The State Department will make its decision after the Nebraska judge resolves the path issue. It's not a magic bullet for the U.S. economy.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning rockets and settlements, what steps should Israel take to address the increasing threat from Gaza? And regarding settlements, did the Prime Minister offer any new guarantees about removing illegal outposts? Do you think they'll actually follow through this time? Is this something you're concerned about? [SEP] Yes.
label: General

sentence: Sir, regarding Afghanistan, what is the timeline for troop withdrawal, and will you allow media coverage of returning soldiers? [SEP] Let me begin by acknowledging the recent loss of American lives in Iraq. My thoughts are with their families. Signing those condolence letters is the most sobering part of this job. Regarding the media policy, we're reviewing it with the Defense Department, so I can't comment definitively. Afghanistan presents a significant challenge. Unlike Iraq, where we've seen progress, Afghanistan's government is struggling, and the Taliban and Al Qaida persist. We need a coordinated effort to eliminate their safe havens. General Petraeus and Special Envoy Holbrooke are assessing the situation and developing a regional strategy. We must coordinate our military, diplomatic, and development efforts with our allies. Ultimately, we cannot allow Afghanistan to become a base for attacks against the United States. While I cannot provide a specific timetable, I assure you we will not allow Al Qaida to operate with impunity.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the situation in Iraq, the proposed security agreement is facing backlash, with Iraqi officials calling for a significant decrease in the U.S. presence. Does this worry you, and how might it influence your strategy moving forward? [SEP] Let me be clear: we will achieve a strategic agreement with Iraq. There's always going to be noise in their system and ours. The truth will prevail. For example, you read stories that the U.S. is planning permanent bases in Iraq. That's false. The Iraqis know it's false. We're there at the invitation of the sovereign Government of Iraq. The agreement sends a clear message to the people of Iraq that the security they're seeing will continue. Democracy and economic development require security. This will not involve permanent bases, nor will it bind any future President to troop levels. You can find any voice you want in the Iraqi political scene and quote them. I deal with Prime Minister Maliki. He appreciates our presence, and he understands that we're returning on success. As the situation improves, we're bringing our troops home. The progress in Iraq is substantial, and it's going to help change the Middle East for the better. I believe freedom is universal, and freedom yields peace.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, have you received concrete intelligence suggesting Putin is deploying or considering the use of chemical weapons, as you've warned? And if such weapons were used, what military response would the U.S. or NATO undertake? [SEP] I'm unable to comment on specific intelligence matters. However, let me be absolutely clear: we would respond decisively if chemical weapons are used. The exact nature of our response would depend on the specifics of the situation. Moving on...
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Considering the Vatican's stance on Palestine, what implications does this have for the two-state solution you're pursuing? [SEP] Look, the most important thing right now is lowering prescription drug costs for seniors. We're talking about allowing Medicare to negotiate prices, just like the VA does. This is a game-changer for millions of Americans who are struggling to afford their medications. Now, some folks in Congress are trying to block this, protecting the profits of big pharmaceutical companies. But I'm fighting for the American people, and I'm confident that we can get this done. What was the first part of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Regarding the executive action, how will you ensure its effectiveness against Republican opposition, particularly concerning funding? Also, are you now considering a figure of two million or more? [SEP] Jeff, the specifics, the nitty-gritty, will all be laid out when we announce the executive action. Trust me, it will be comprehensive. And I'm sure you'll all have plenty of questions afterward.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, to be clear, are you now advocating for the elimination of the filibuster? [SEP] I've spoken extensively on this topic./National Security/Trade Agreements/Budget Priorities
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Would you ever consider removing the sanctions without significant improvement in the human rights situation? [SEP] No. I want significant improvement. I want to know that it won't be happening. And again, once you start that process, there will be a point at which, even though you won't be finished for a while because it can't happen scientifically or mechanically, but you're not going to be able to go back. You know, once we reach that point, I'll start to give that very serious thought.Yes. Go ahead. Go ahead. Go ahead. You first.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, what's your take on a second round of direct payments to Americans, as proposed in the House Democratic bill? [SEP] Well, we're discussing that with many people. I want a payroll tax cut. I want various things. I want the workers taken care of. But we're negotiating with the Democrats. We'll see what happens. It's a transition to greatness, starting next year. I think we're going to do fantastically well. The third quarter is a transition quarter, maybe pretty good. The fourth quarter will have tremendous numbers, I think. Next year, you'll see numbers like before, maybe even better, because of pent-up demand. People want to do things, but they've held back because of the virus. So, next year will be phenomenal, unless someone messes it up by raising taxes, like the Democrats want to do. We had the greatest economy ever, and we'll do it again quickly and easily. Yes, ma'am.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, could you give us some specific examples of mail-in ballot fraud in Nevada or other states? What evidence do you have? [SEP] Well, you know, a lot of people are saying it's a problem. I've heard stories, terrible stories, about what's going on with mail-in ballots. And in Nevada, they don't even check the signatures. It's a very unfair system, very unfair.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, some critics suggest that your focus on Ukraine and ISIL is a convenient way to avoid addressing more pressing domestic issues. How do you respond to these claims? [SEP] These are not distractions; they are critical challenges that demand our attention. Ukraine is on the brink, and ISIL continues to pose a serious threat. I'm committed to addressing these issues head-on, while also working to improve the lives of Americans at home.
label: Dodging

sentence: Specifically, are you prepared to comment on the situation in Syria? [SEP] I'm not going to be baited into commenting on specific situations. I'm sure you can appreciate that.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: The public is confused about the coronavirus response. Why haven't you made changes at the CDC or other agencies given the confusing messages? [SEP] The messages have been confusing because the scientists are learning more. It's an unfolding story. Think about how astounding it was to come up with a vaccine so quickly. Did everything get done perfectly? No. Anyway, I'm talking too much.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, the reporter from Sputnik News is asking about North Korea's nuclear sites. Did you discuss inspections during your meetings? [SEP] I'm having trouble hearing. Could you repeat that and tell me where you're from?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, following up on that, can you elaborate on what 'yes' means in this context? Did the Prime Minister commit to specific actions regarding either Gaza or the outposts? [SEP] Look, Israel is a strong ally, and they have the right to defend themselves. We support them in that right. As for the other issues, we're working on them. It's a complex situation, but we're making progress.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, you campaigned on your policies, but the election results were a clear setback for your party. Do you accept any responsibility to adjust your agenda for the remaining two years? What specific changes will you make in your White House and your approach to Republicans to address voter concerns? [SEP] Well, look, the American people want Washington to work. They want me to get things done. I'm the President, so I'm responsible for making that happen. We'll find areas where we can agree with Republicans, like infrastructure. We'll keep pushing for things like a minimum wage increase, which voters support. It's about finding common ground and getting things done.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You came to Asia talking about the deep frustration that Americans feel about the slow pace of recovery in the economy, and over your travels in the past 10 days, you've been talking a lot about sustainable growth. But the American people don't seem as interested in gradual growth as much as they want real, noticeable help right now. Can you promise them that there will be, in fact, noticeable job growth during your 4-year term? And do you think that the unemployment rate will still be north of 9 percent when you run for reelection? [SEP] Well, I don't have a crystal ball, Ben, but I will say this. First of all, we've grown the economy by a million jobs over the last year. So that's pretty noticeable. I think those million people who've been hired notice those paychecks. And that's 10 consecutive months of private sector job growth.In order to speed up job growth, we've put forward a range of proposals that I hope to discuss with Democratic and Republican leaders, because I don't think we can just stand pat. I continue to believe that we need to invest in a creaky infrastructure back home. And I think as you travel around Asia, you start seeing other countries investing in infrastructure. That's what the United States has done in the past, but we've been living off the investments that we made back in the thirties, forties, fifties, and sixties. And it's time for us to make sure that we've upgraded our roads and our railways and our airports. That will make us more productive and will put people back to work right now.I continue to believe that it is important for us to work with businesses to see if we can incentivize them to invest now rather than holding cash waiting for the future. They've got cash to spend. And so we've put forward a series of tax proposals that historically Republicans have supported. And my expectation would be, there's no reason for them not to support it just because I'm supporting it. And so that's a conversation that I hope to have next week.But we have a recovery. It needs to be speeded up. Government can't hire back the 8 million people who lost their jobs. Ultimately, that's up to the private sector. But I think we can set the conditions whereby we're seeing significant improvement during the course of the next year, the next 2 years, and we can chip away at the unemployment rate so that we get back to the kinds of levels that reflect a growing middle class and increased opportunity for all people.Jake Tapper [ABC News].
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, some might interpret your meetings with both the current and former Italian leaders as a calculated move, perhaps signaling a lack of unwavering support for the current administration. How do you reassure our allies, and the American public, that your foreign policy remains consistent and focused? [SEP] Look, it's simple. I'm seeing Berlusconi because he's a friend and a significant political figure. Romano understands. There's no hidden agenda here. We talked about important issues like Afghanistan and Iran, and we're aligned on the dangers of nuclear proliferation. We'll continue to work together. We also discussed climate change and how we can harmonize our approaches. It's about collaboration and finding common ground. It's not about undermining anyone.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Rick Ledgett's comments on Snowden, were you aware he was going to raise the possibility of amnesty? Under what circumstances would you consider a plea deal or amnesty? And what do you say to Americans who believe Snowden acted justly? [SEP] Major, I have to be careful. Snowden's indicted. It's up to the Attorney General and the courts. I can't comment directly on the case. But I will say this: the debate was important. But the way he did it damaged our country. There was a way to have this conversation without causing so much harm. We're a nation of laws, but because of Snowden, countries that are far worse than us are now criticizing us. So, yes, the debate was necessary, but it did unnecessary damage. I'll leave the specifics to the courts.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Are you rattled by this at all, Mr. President? [SEP] I don't know; do I seem rattled? It's unfortunate that this is a world—but the world has always been a dangerous place. It's not something that's unique. The world has been—you look back over the centuries, the world has been a dangerous place, a very dangerous place. And it will continue, I guess, for a period of time.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, a simple yes or no: Is Sergeant Bergdahl subject to any disciplinary measures, or is that not even being considered at this time? [SEP] The situation with Sergeant Bergdahl is complex, and frankly, disciplinary action is not our immediate concern. Our focus is on his well-being and providing him with the necessary support. On another note, Poland's proactive stance on NATO presence is appreciated, and we are in constant communication with them.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, can you confirm whether the recent leaks about U.S. spying on South Korea were discussed during your meetings with President Biden, and if so, did he offer any assurances regarding this matter? [SEP] We are in communication with the United States on this issue, sharing relevant information. The U.S. is conducting an investigation, and there are many factors at play. We need to allow time for the investigation to conclude. We will continue to communicate on this matter.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Has the American President provided reassurance regarding his successor's stance on climate change and Russia, thereby easing your concerns? Are you concerned that the common European policy towards Russia might disintegrate? And following Mr. Trump's election, wouldn't you be compelled to announce your candidacy again as a matter of courtesy? [SEP] I generally avoid interfering in other countries' internal affairs. All I can say is that Chancellor Merkel has been an exceptional partner. She's perhaps the only leader among our closest allies who was there when I first arrived, making us veterans of many challenges over the past 8 years. While we haven't always agreed on every issue, her core values, integrity, truthfulness, thoughtfulness, diligence, knowledge, and commitment to the interests of the German people, while recognizing the importance of global engagement and multilateral institutions, have been outstanding. It's her decision whether to run again, and ultimately, the German people will decide. If I were German, I might support her. As for Russia, my approach has been consistent since I took office. Russia is an important country, a military superpower with global influence. Cooperation with Russia is in our interest to solve many global problems. We should hope for a successful Russia with a growing economy and good relations with its neighbors. I've sought a constructive relationship with Russia, but I'm realistic about our differences. We can't set aside our values of democracy, free speech, international norms, and the rule of law. We've had significant differences on issues like Ukraine and Syria. I hope the President-elect will take a similar approach, finding areas for cooperation while standing up to Russia when it deviates from our values. I'm encouraged by the President-elect's commitment to NATO. Regarding my conversations with President Putin, they occurred before the election. There's clear proof of their cyber attacks, which isn't new. We've delivered a clear message that meddling with elections or targeting private organizations is unacceptable, and we'll respond appropriately. We need international frameworks to prevent a cyber arms race. We've started working on principles at the G-20, G-7, and U.N. levels, but more work is needed. The transition period in the United States is proceeding smoothly, with the outgoing administration sharing its knowledge with the incoming one. This encourages us to continue the good cooperation between the United States and Germany. I'll approach this with an open mind and a deep conviction with President-elect Donald Trump. On Russia, it's about respecting certain principles. From a European perspective, peace depends on respecting territorial integrity and sovereignty. The reverse would be a dangerous path. We're pinning our hopes on political efforts like the Normandy process. Russia is our neighbor, and we have an interest in a good relationship. We must raise our differences with political means and work for political settlements. I'll continue to work on this with all my heart. I'll decide on my candidacy at the appropriate time.
label: General

sentence: Given the gravity of the situation in Afghanistan, and the incoming Obama administration, will the Republican party offer bipartisan support for his strategies, particularly concerning troop deployment and dealing with Pakistan regarding terrorist activities? [SEP] Well, let me say this: President-elect Obama is about to face some serious challenges. As a Republican, my party wants him to succeed. We've been working to ensure a smooth transition. Secretary Gates, staying on as Secretary of Defense, signals continuity to Afghanistan. We'll likely see more U.S. troops where the Taliban is causing trouble. I recall discussing this with Presidents Karzai and Musharraf – the threat of extremists using violence for political goals is a problem for all of us. A collaborative strategy is essential, working with Pakistan to address those who harm their citizens and Afghans. I recently met with President Zardari, reminding him that my priority is defending our people. He understands the threat personally. We're consulting with him, and I believe he is meeting with President Obama soon. It's a collaborative effort.
label: Implicit

sentence: On Iran, Mr. President: Are they serious about talks? What about the attacks? [SEP] Two issues. JCPOA depends on them and our friends. Attacks? We'll respond.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Regarding potential boycotts against companies stifling political expression, what specific strategies would you suggest to those wishing to participate? [SEP] Oh, I don't get involved in that sort of thing. People can do what they want. I'm just saying, it's a shame when companies try to shut down free speech. It's not right. But I'm not going to tell people how to protest. That's their business.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the recent energy bill you signed with Speaker Pelosi and Senator Reid, aimed at reducing greenhouse gases, there's been some confusion. Your administration simultaneously prevented California from enforcing its own stricter emission standards. Could you please clarify how important fighting greenhouse gases is to you, why states are being blocked from doing more, and whether you've discussed climate change with Vice President Gore lately? [SEP] Look, it's about having the *right* strategy. The question isn't whether we care about greenhouse gases – of course we do. The question is, what's the *most effective* way to tackle this? Is it 50 different states doing their own thing, or a unified national approach? Director Johnson made a decision based on the new law, which gives us a national plan. We're talking about raising CAFE standards and using more alternative fuels. That's a national solution. I spoke with Vice President Gore, and I assured him I'm taking this seriously. We're developing a strategy, and this bill is part of it. Replacing gasoline with alternatives will make a big difference. The bill I signed was a bit weaker than I wanted, but it's still a good step. We need to invest in cellulosic ethanol, not just corn. That's a real national plan. But let's be clear: this is a global problem. That's why I was against Kyoto – China wasn't included. We need major emitters at the table. We're working on that, as I said at the G-8 and in Bali. I take this seriously, but we can't wreck our economy in the process. We need to be prosperous to invest in new technologies. And if you're serious about greenhouse gases, you should support nuclear power. It's the best way to generate electricity without emissions. So, we have a strategy: higher CAFE standards, alternative fuels, nuclear power. And we have tons of coal, so we need to find ways to use it cleanly. Our strategy is to bring others to the table, develop a national plan, and meet international goals. That's the plan.
label: General

sentence: Q. With Netanyahu now public about the Syria bombing, what's your take? Did we know about it? Did we support it? And are we walking into a bigger mess in the Middle East? [SEP] I'm going to pass on that one. It's a sensitive situation, and I don't want to say anything that could make it worse.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I'd like to switch to Afghanistan. There was another attempt on President Karzai's life. There are operations going on there right now. Is the strategy succeeding? Are we winning in Afghanistan? [SEP] Yes, I think we're making progress in Afghanistan, but there's a very resilient enemy that obviously wants to kill people that stand in the way of their reimposition of a state that is—which vision is incredibly dark. I mean, it's very important for the American people to remember what life was like in Afghanistan prior to the liberation of the country. We had a government in place that abused people's human rights. They didn't believe in women's rights, they didn't let little girls go to school, and they provided safe haven to Al Qaida. In the liberation of this country, we've achieved some very important strategic objectives: denying Al Qaida safe haven from which to plot and plan attacks and replacing this repressive group with a young democracy.And it's difficult in Afghanistan. I mean, it's—if you know the history of the country, you understand it's hard to go from the kind of society in which they had been living to one in which people are now responsible for their own behavior. But I am pleased with a lot of things. One, I'm pleased with the number of roads that have been built. I'm pleased with the number of schools that have opened up. I'm pleased a lot of girls, young girls, are going to school. I'm pleased health clinics are now being distributed around the country. I'm pleased with the Afghan Army, that when they're in the fight, they're good.I wish we had completely eliminated the radicals who kill innocent people to achieve objectives, but that hasn't happened yet. And so I think it's very much in our interests to continue helping the young democracy, and we will.Yes. Obviously, you've got a follow-up.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, are you considering altering any of the immigration stipulations you presented to Congress, particularly concerning the DACA program and the potential amnesty for 1.7 million individuals? [SEP] Look, DACA is a situation we could have resolved beautifully. We were on the verge of a fantastic deal, a really good deal for everyone. But then a judge stepped in and said DACA was fine as it was. That ruling, frankly, took the wind out of the Democrats' sails. They lost interest in negotiating. So, we'll see what happens with the Supreme Court. It's in their hands now.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, concerning North Korea, you've said the crisis will be resolved. Can you highlight any specific successes in your diplomatic approach? And do you still believe direct talks are a waste of time? [SEP] You know me well enough to know I don't like to talk about successes in a case like this. We like to keep our cards close. But I will say this: it makes sense for to do the right thing, not only for , but for humanity. There is a lot of good reason behind it. With that, yes, I think we're making progress. We're showing strength. They understand we have unparalleled strength. We sent three of the largest aircraft carriers, and they're positioned. We have a nuclear submarine. We hope we never have to use it. I believe it makes sense for to come to the table and make a deal that's good for the people of and the world. I see certain movement, yes. But let's see what happens.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, under what specific circumstances would you consider a meeting with President Castro in Havana? Are there preconditions that must be met before such a meeting could occur? And regarding the cyberattack, while you've stated you won't announce your response, can you confirm whether additional economic or financial sanctions on North Korea are being considered? Can you definitively rule out the use of military force or a retaliatory cyberattack?
