[SEP] I'm going to reiterate my previous statement: we have confirmed North Korea's involvement and are formulating a range of options. These options will be presented to me, and I will make a decision based on what I deem proportional and appropriate to the nature of this crime. Regarding Cuba, a visit to Cuba by myself or a visit to the United States by President Castro is not currently under consideration. I am uncertain how this relationship will evolve in the coming years. I am relatively young, and I anticipate having the opportunity to visit Cuba and engage with the Cuban people at some point in my life. However, there are no specific plans for a visit at this time.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Ukraine, do you believe President Zelenskyy should consider ceding territory to Russia in exchange for a cease-fire, or is that a non-starter? And secondly, what's your stance on removing Russia from the G-20? [SEP] On the G-20, my answer is yes, but it's up to the G-20. I brought it up earlier. If Indonesia and others aren't on board, then we should push for allowing both Ukraine and Russia to attend as observers. Remind me of the first question?
label: Clarification

sentence: So, about Ukraine, Mr. President. Does Zelenskyy have to give up land to get a deal with Russia? And should we kick Russia out of the G-20? [SEP] On the G-20 thing, yeah, probably. But it depends on what everyone else thinks. I talked about it today. If Indonesia and the others don't agree, maybe we just let them both come as observers. What was the first thing you asked?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, could you elaborate on your wider agenda and the progress you're making? [SEP] Schumer and the Democrats are holding up every single nomination. It's pure obstructionism. They may not be skilled politicians, but they excel at obstruction. Look at Bush, Obama, Clinton—their approval rates were much higher. Mitch will begin to prioritize these nominations, particularly the judicial ones.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. I just wanted to follow up on my colleague's question about Russian interference. Can you pledge to the American people that you will not accept any foreign assistance in the upcoming election?And on this idea of a purge in your administration, there was recently the departure of your Acting DNI, Joseph Maguire. You replaced him with your Ambassador to Germany, Rick Grenell. Some of your critics have pointed out that Ambassador Grenell has no intelligence experience. How can you justify to the American people having an Acting DNI with no intelligence experience? [SEP] Okay, first of all, I want no help from any country. And I haven't been given help from any country.And if you see what CNN, your wonderful network, said—[]—I guess they apologized, in a way, for—didn't they apologize for the fact that they said certain things that weren't true? Tell me, what was their apology yesterday? What did they say?
label: Deflection

sentence: Given the complexities of the Syrian conflict and the divergent interests of the international actors involved, what specific steps are being taken to ensure that any coalition against ISIS is truly unified and effective? [SEP] We are actively engaged in diplomatic efforts to build a broad-based coalition that is united in its commitment to defeating ISIS. This requires open communication, a clear understanding of shared goals, and a willingness to compromise. We are confident that we can overcome these challenges and forge a strong and effective alliance.
label: General

sentence: Q. President Trump, do you agree with Senate Republicans discussing the possibility of extending short-term unemployment insurance today so that they prevent benefits from expiring? [SEP] Well, I think a lot of politicians are discussing that: Republicans, Democrats. And right now a lot of my representatives are on the Hill. They're discussing CARES Act or phase four, whatever you want to call it. And I think, ultimately, something good will come out of it.The economy is starting to really come back strongly, when you look at the numbers—even with the fact that—like California is still closed up and many big States. I think the numbers are even more impressive, considering that some States like California—big ones—are pretty well shut down.So we expect to have something over a period of time—over the appropriate period of time.Please, go ahead.
label: Implicit

sentence: Last May, you surpassed your predecessor, George W. Bush, in time served as President during wartime. If you complete your presidency with troops in Afghanistan, Syria, and Iraq, you'll be the only two-term President to have served with the country at war. How do you feel about this reality, given your campaign promises? And should Americans resign themselves to perpetual war, even if it's not the all-out war of the 20th century? [SEP] Okay, interesting question. First, about the State Department, I am concerned. The problem is the sheer volume of information. Email, texts, smartphones – it's generating a data deluge. It's convenient, I get info in real-time my predecessors waited weeks for. But it's overwhelming the Department, sorting, classifying, securing it from cyber-attacks. Over-classify, and the information's useless. Secretary Kerry's working on it. It's a government-wide problem. FOIA requests are up, the information is massive. It's worse for national security. We're trying to fix it. As for war, when I took office, we had 180,000 troops in Iraq and Afghanistan. Now it's a fraction of that. They're not in active combat, but training and advising, except for strikes against ISIS with Iraqi and Syrian partners. Our operations are different now. But you're right, dealing with non-state actors in weak countries means partnering to secure borders and eliminate threats. Afghanistan takes time. They're fighting, more capable now, but need support. We could pull out, let the country collapse, and go back in later. Or we can maintain a limited partnership. We can't get a MacArthur-Emperor moment with non-state actors. We defeated al-Qaeda in Iraq, transitioned to a democracy, but Sunni resentment allowed it to rebuild in Syria and return. Some say we should have stayed. But the Iraqi government didn't want us, unlike Afghanistan. I can't risk our troops without protection. So, I'm trying to build a structure emphasizing partnerships, fragile states, conflict resolution, local partners, and targeted strikes. It's a hybrid approach. The good news is fewer wars between states, almost none between great powers. But this low-grade threat can do real damage and create fear. We need to do better. I put out data on civilian drone casualties to hold ourselves accountable. It's imperfect, but we're improving. Whether it's the NSA, drone strikes, or Guantanamo, I'm confident my efforts will be on firmer legal footing, more consistent with our values. But there's more to do. I spend a lot of time on this. It's better than when I started. Thank you.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Bush, regarding the scandal involving politicians and drug trafficking, particularly their connections to paramilitary groups, what is your assessment of the government's handling of the situation? To what extent do you support President Uribe, considering the involvement of paramilitary leaders in drug trafficking? Will the U.S. insist on extraditing these individuals? [SEP] I believe in a system where justice is blind, where the courts are independent, and where those found guilty are held accountable. That's the kind of system President Uribe supports, and it's the kind of system the United States supports. We want to see a fair and transparent process, free from political interference. That's the best way to ensure that justice is served and that the people of Colombia can have confidence in their government.
label: Implicit

sentence: Given your statement that you don't know when the North Korean leader will be willing to negotiate, would the U.S. consider strengthening sanctions and increasing pressure on North Korea? [SEP] I don't want to comment on that. We have very strong sanctions. I don't want to talk about increasing sanctions. They're strong. They have a lot of great people in North Korea that have to live also. My whole attitude changed a lot because I got to know Chairman Kim very well. And they have a point of view also. I just think that, hopefully, for the sake of , for the sake of Japan, and frankly, for the sake of —I was talking to President Xi, who really is a man that gets the respect of a lot of people—I say, You can't love having a nuclear state right next to . And he doesn't. He really doesn't. I will tell you, he would like to see that problem solved too.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. As you know, the Chinese Government recently ejected several Wall Street Journal reporters. What is your administration considering to do in retaliation to that move? Are you considering banning or restricting the access the Chinese journalists, for example, have in the United States? [SEP] So I haven't really been given a full briefing on that. We're going to look at it. We will look at it. It's something that I don't like to see. I don't think it's fair, because we give very good access. Maybe some people would say we give too good. I don't think—I don't believe in that. I think we give very good access, so I don't think it's fair. But we'll have a decision made on that relatively soon. Okay? Thank you. Good question.Please, go ahead. Go ahead. Go ahead.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Two quick questions. Thank you, Mr. President. First of all, you said that voting by mail is an invitation to fraud. Could you lay out and tell us exactly where the evidence is right now that mail-in ballots in Nevada and other States will lead to widespread fraud? [SEP] Well, if you read, even the Washington Post had a terrible story on mail-in and the New York Times. And many, many newspapers have had terrible stories. You see them all over the internet. They've had some just horrible stories on mail-in ballots.You look at Arizona [Nevada]*, you don't even have to have—as you know, they have a provision where they don't have to check signatures. So you sign it, and you could have a totally different signature. It's okay. It won't be approved. They have the right to go 7 days after the election for approval, so you're not even going to know who won the State of Nevada.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. During the conventions, Kimberly and Don Jr. had the outreach—the Indian American community—with a video called Four More Years for you, which has gone viral among the Indian Americans in the battleground States.So my question is: Would Kimberly, Don Jr., and Ivanka Trump, who are very popular among Indian Americans—would be campaigning on your behalf around the Indian Americans with your views on the India and U.S. relationship? [SEP] Well, I didn't understand everything you said. I know India, and I understood—those young people that you mentioned. They're very good, young people. And I know their relationship to India is very good, and so is mine.And Prime Minister Modi is a friend of mine, and he's doing a very good job. Nothing easy—nothing easy, but he's doing a very good job.We're talking—I mean, while we're at it, we're talking about China and India. They're pretty—going at a pretty good on the border, as you know. It's been very nasty. It's been a very nasty situation, and we stand ready to help, with respect to China and India. If we can do anything, we would love to get involved and help, and we are talking to both countries about that.But I appreciate your nice sentiments. They think a lot of India, and so do I. And I think a lot of your Prime Minister. Thank you.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Demetri Sevastopulo, Financial Times. Can I just ask, first, one clarification? [SEP] Sure.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, this aid package for Puerto Rico is substantial. Why wasn't it approved earlier, before the election neared? Some see it as politically motivated. [SEP] Well, it's been a long process, a very long process. We've been working hard to get this package passed, but you know how it is with the Democrats. They don't always see eye-to-eye with us, especially when it comes to these kinds of things. But it's a great package, a really great package. And the best part, I think, is what we're going to do with the pharmaceutical industry. We're bringing them back to Puerto Rico. They used to be there, but the tax situation changed, and they left. So we're going to bring them back, and that's going to be a huge boost for the island.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, your nominee for Veterans Affairs, Dr. Ronny Jackson, faces serious allegations. What is your understanding of these allegations, and do you intend to support his nomination? [SEP] I'm not familiar with the specifics of these allegations, but I can tell you he's a remarkable individual. Melania would agree. He served as physician to Presidents Obama, Bush, and myself. He's an excellent doctor. It was just a suggestion, and I know there are concerns about his experience. The VA is crucial to me, and we've made great strides with the Accountability Act and other initiatives. We're also working on choice. We'll take care of our veterans. I even told Admiral Jackson, 'Why do you want this?' It's a tough environment. But he's an admiral, a great leader. They scrutinize everything. Look at Pompeo's confirmation; everyone was surprised. I heard he wouldn't be approved, but Rand Paul came through. Rand is a good man. I knew things others didn't. Rand changed his vote, and he was approved.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your upcoming meeting with Kim Jong Un, considering your CIA Director's recent visit to Pyongyang failed to secure the release of detained Americans or any visible concessions from North Korea, are you still willing to meet with Kim Jong Un if Americans remain imprisoned? Will you demand tangible concessions from North Korea in exchange for gestures like sending a potential future Secretary of State? [SEP] Well, the fact is, they *do* have three prisoners. We're talking about them. We're negotiating. We're doing our best. They've been there a long time, and it's harsh treatment. We fought hard to get Otto Warmbier back, and he was in very bad condition. It was a very sad event. We're fighting diligently to get the three American citizens back. I think there's a good chance. We're having very good dialogue. We'll keep you informed. We're in there, working hard. We've come a long way with North Korea. For years, they've been talking and nothing happened. Past administrations should have taken care of this when they weren't so far along. But we put unbelievably powerful sanctions on, and many other things. I want to thank President Xi of China, who has done more for us than he's done for any other administration. He's clogged up the border, very powerfully. He never thought he'd go to this extent, and I appreciate that. It's put a lot of pressure on. 93 percent of the goods into North Korea come from China. President Xi understands this is a very important set of months. He doesn't want a Korea with nuclear weapons. He's also fighting for China. He's been terrific. Can he be better? Always. But he's been very good, and it's had a big impact. We've never been in this position with that regime. I hope to have a very successful meeting. If we don't think it'll be successful, we won't have it. If the meeting isn't fruitful, I'll respectfully leave, and we'll continue what we're doing. Something will happen. I like remaining flexible. I've gotten it to this point. President Moon of South Korea said if it weren't for Donald Trump, the Olympics would have been a total failure. It was my involvement that made them successful. If you look at ticket sales before, it was going to be a big problem. We've gotten us here, and I think we'll be successful. But if I feel we're not, we end. Okay?
label: General

sentence: Given the UK's pursuit of Gary McKinnon's extradition, do you believe leniency should be considered due to his Asperger's and the potential disproportionality of the punishment? And Prime Minister Cameron, could you reiterate your views on this matter, particularly whether you discussed it with the President today? [SEP] David and I discussed this. There's an ongoing discussion between our countries, and I don't want to interfere. We understand the seriousness of the hacking charges against Gary McKinnon. Cybersecurity is a growing challenge, and we need to cooperate extensively on it. While traditional espionage is still a concern, the greatest vulnerabilities now lie in breaches of our information systems. We take this very seriously, as does the British Government. The President doesn't typically get involved in prosecution or extradition decisions. My team will follow the law but will coordinate closely with our unparalleled ally. I trust this will be resolved in a way that underscores the seriousness of the issue and our cooperative relationship. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to the Meng Wanzhou case, should we anticipate a similar deferral as with other matters, or is there a conceivable scenario in which the U.S. might withdraw its extradition proceedings? [SEP] Come again? You're asking about what, exactly? And in what context?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, considering the potential damage caused by the leak of the Hadley memo, what specific measures are being taken to prevent future leaks of classified information? And are you confident that you have identified all individuals within your administration who may be responsible for such breaches of security? [SEP] I'm trying to think back if I ordered an investigation. I don't recall ordering an investigation. I do recall expressing some angst about ongoing leaks. You all work hard to find information and, of course, put it out for public consumption, and I understand that. But I don't appreciate those who leak classified documents. And it's an ongoing problem here, it really is. You know, there may be an ongoing investigation of this; I just don't know. If there is, if I knew about it, it's not fresh in my mind.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. ——nomination speech. Senator John Thune questioned whether or not that's actually legal, given the Hatch Act. Is this something that you would get clearance for before proceeding? [SEP] John Thune did, right?
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Just to follow up on Zeke's [Zeke Miller, Associated Press] question, can you clarify: Are you considering restricting travel to and from South Korea, Italy, and other countries that have been affected by this? [SEP] At a right time, we may do that. Right now it's not the right time. But at a right time—and we are checking people as they come through, specifically for the problem, the problem that we're dealing with. So we're checking a lot of people if they're coming from—South Korea has been hit pretty hard; Italy has been hit pretty hard. China is obvious—what's happened in China.But again, the numbers seem to be leveling off and going down in China, which is very good news. So we'll see what happens./White House Messaging on Coronavirus/U.S. Cases of Coronavirus
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, the agreement relies on voluntary cooperation. With so much past conflict, how likely is it that countries will actually cooperate, and what enforcement mechanisms are in place? [SEP] Let's look at Ukraine. We've been encouraging them for a decade to ship out its highly enriched uranium. Because of this conference, Ukraine took that step. All the commitments we talked about are ones that we've already booked. That indicates the degree to which there's actually strong unanimity about the importance of this issue. We also have a number of international conventions. The United States needs to work on a couple of these conventions dealing with the issues of nuclear terrorism. This sets out a bold plan. What I'm encouraged about is the fact that we've already seen efforts that had been delayed for years actually finally coming to fruition here at this summit.
label: Deflection

sentence: Given the concerns about China's human rights record and trade practices, how can we ensure a level playing field and protect American interests while engaging with them economically? [SEP] We're committed to a relationship with China that is both competitive and cooperative. We'll continue to press them on human rights, challenge their unfair trade practices, and work with our allies to promote a more open and rules-based international order.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, isn't the Special Counsel still determining whether there was collusion? [SEP] Thank you very much.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, concerning the nuclear—the dispute about missile defense, the missile defense with Moscow, what concrete steps are you planning to convince President Putin that this is a good idea of NATO and the U.S.? And can the German Chancellor help you on this issue? [SEP] As you know, I'm having a regular conversation with the German Chancellor. We have a secure video that is beamed in the White House and her office, and so we consult regularly. And she expressed her concerns that the U.S. position wasn't very clear about the missile defense systems and that there were some people concerned in Germany, as well as Europe, about our intentions. And she also suggested that it might make sense for me to share my intentions more clearly with President Putin. And I took her advice very seriously.Our intention, of course, is to have a defense system that prevents rogue regimes from holding Western Europe and/or America to hostage. Evidently, the Russians view it differently. And so upon the advice of the Chancellor, I asked Secretary Gates to go to Moscow, where he had a very constructive meeting with President Putin. I called President Putin and asked him to see Secretary Gates, and that we would put forth an interesting information-sharing proposal.Our intention is to say to Russia that the system is something you ought to think about participating in. It's in your interests to have a system that would—could prevent a future Iranian regime, for example, from launching a weapon—it's in Russia's security interests. And therefore, we have started a dialog that, as a result of Secretary Gates's visit, that, hopefully, will make explicit our intentions and, hopefully, present the—an opportunity to share with the Russians, so that they don't see us as an antagonistic force, but see us as a friendly force.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. I am surprised. Could I ask you about race? [SEP] You may.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, China claims your recent agreements with nations in its vicinity are a 'cold war mentality.' Are they correct? Is a cold war brewing? And when will you meet with President Xi? [SEP] I hope to see Xi soon; we've spent a lot of time together. But this isn't about a cold war. Look at the India deal: new infrastructure saving money, boosting the Global South's growth with railroads to the Mediterranean, shipping lanes to Europe. It's about economic growth, not hurting or helping China. It's about investing in people, giving them a chance. If everyone had a job they loved and could provide for their families, the world would be better. That's the idea. We're building a railroad across Africa too. How else do you get food from one side to the other? We're investing billions in solar in Angola. It helps the whole region. It's not cold war thinking; it's about global economic stability.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, to be blunt, are you prepared to publicly condemn Prime Minister Netanyahu's stance on Palestinian statehood, and what specific actions will the U.S. take to demonstrate its commitment to a two-state solution, even if it means disagreeing with a close ally? [SEP] As a rule, I don't comment on intelligence matters in a big room full of reporters. We have briefed Congress and our partners about the progress or lack thereof. If an agreement is arrived at that we feel confident will prevent Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon, it's going to be there for everybody to see. I have confidence that if there's an agreement, it's going to be a good agreement that's good for American security and Israeli security and the region's security. With respect to Israel's relations with the Palestinians, I think it's important to understand that the issue here is not what I believe, but it's what the Palestinians and the parties in the negotiations and the Israeli people believe is possible. That's the most important issue.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Obama, can you elaborate on the rationale behind moving the G-8 summit from Chicago to Camp David? [SEP] Well, Lynn, as you know, we're also hosting the NATO summit. We usually try to coordinate the two to avoid unnecessary travel for world leaders. The idea to move the G-8 to Camp David came later. I realized I hadn't yet hosted my counterparts there. The G-8 is a more informal setting for intimate discussions. I thought it would be a good opportunity for us to connect in a relaxed atmosphere, and it'll give me a chance to meet with President Putin. And I have full confidence in Chicago's ability to handle security for the NATO summit. Mayor Emanuel will ensure everything runs smoothly.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. ——the supply/demand equation would improve. Why have you not sort of called on Americans to drive less and to turn down the thermostat? [SEP] They're smart enough to figure out whether they're going to drive less or not. I mean, you know, it's interesting what the price of gasoline has done—is it caused people to drive less. That's why they want smaller cars, they want to conserve. But the consumer is plenty bright, Mark. The marketplace works.Secondly, we have worked with Congress to change CAFE standards and had a mandatory alternative fuel requirement.So no question about it, what you just said is right. One way to correct the imbalance is to save, is to conserve. And as you noticed in my statement yesterday, I talked about good conservation. And people can figure out whether they need to drive more or less; they can balance their own checkbooks.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, when you use the word 'torture,' what exactly do you mean? [SEP] Torture in what context?
label: Clarification

sentence: To be clear, are we heading towards a hard Brexit? [SEP] Are we heading towards a difficult situation?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with respect, wouldn't a limited incursion still be a violation of sovereignty? Are you suggesting that only a full-scale invasion warrants a full response? [SEP] I've addressed this matter previously. We're focused on de-escalation.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Obama, what's your take on the TPP's congressional hurdles and the criticism surrounding Mullah Mansur's death in Pakistan? [SEP] Well, on TPP, these trade deals always stir up debate. Everyone wants a better deal, especially with multiple countries involved. And in an election year? Expect political posturing. But I'm confident we'll get it done. It's good for America, good for the region, good for the world. This is the fastest-growing part of the world, a huge market for us. They sell to us with low tariffs, but ours are higher there. This deal eliminates 18,000 taxes on U.S. goods. It's a win for American businesses and workers. Historically, trade deals faced complaints about lower wages and labor practices. TPP addresses that with enforceable commitments to raise labor standards and tackle environmental issues. I haven't seen a credible argument that TPP makes us worse off. We're demonstrably better off. The politics will be noisy, like with the Korean and Colombian deals. But we got those done, and we'll get this done too. Currency manipulation? We have transparency and reporting provisions. Some wanted enforceable tariffs, but it's hard to determine manipulation. Binding others' monetary policy would mean binding our Federal Reserve, which we won't do. We've strengthened provisions to monitor competitive devaluations. On Mullah Mansur, his death is confirmed. He targeted U.S. personnel in Afghanistan. This isn't a shift in approach. We're not re-entering combat. Our job is to help Afghanistan secure itself. But when a high-profile leader consistently plans to harm our people and resists peace talks, I have a responsibility to act. We're sending a clear signal to the Taliban.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Erdogan, regarding President Trump's October 9th letter, with its... directness... why did you proceed with military action in northern Syria despite his explicit warning? [SEP] The letter, shall we say, was brought up again with President Trump this afternoon. I also made it clear that a terrorist like Ferhat Abdi Sahin, responsible for the deaths of hundreds of Turkish civilians and a protégé of Abdullah Öcalan, should not be considered an interlocutor by the United States. It's hard to understand why a country fighting terrorism would welcome such a person, as Russia has also done. To fight terrorism effectively, we need more sensitivity. We provided information, including a CIA document identifying him as a terrorist, to the White House and Mr. President. We gave the letter back.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, Valentinovna from Sputnik News Agency asks: During your negotiations, did you discuss the possibility of inspections at North Korea's nuclear facilities? [SEP] I'm having trouble hearing you. Where are you reporting from?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Bush, with respect to China, many feel your approach is too soft. Critics argue that simply expressing concerns isn't enough to effect real change. What specific leverage are you willing to use to pressure China on human rights? Furthermore, President Lee, concerning North Korea, given their history of broken promises, what guarantees can you offer that this time will be different? [SEP] I've consistently communicated to Chinese leaders the importance of respecting religious freedom and freedom of expression. These values are essential for a thriving society. I've made this clear in every meeting. My presence at the Olympics is a dual purpose: to honor the Chinese people and to support our athletes. I hope our team excels, but it's also a chance to reinforce our principles. I don't need the Olympics to express my views on religious freedom, as I've been doing it throughout my presidency. Regarding the six-party talks, skepticism is understandable given North Korea's past actions. However, I commend President Bush's leadership in dealing with this difficult situation. Denuclearization is paramount. We will remain patient, consistent, and committed to verification. We must all work together to ensure North Korea fulfills its obligations. Despite their intentions, the other members of the six-party talks must persevere. There may be challenges, but our commitment remains steadfast.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, with respect, the situation in Pakistan is evolving rapidly. Is the United States prepared to reassess its relationship with President Musharraf, given the outcome of the elections and the potential for instability in the region? [SEP] The important thing is, Pakistan had an election, and it was judged fair. That's a win for freedom. Musharraf kept his word. Now, we'll see what the new government does. Pakistan's an important ally. We share interests. We both want to stop terrorists. And as for Africa, America is a generous nation. We can help them and ourselves at the same time. The world's getting smaller. If we ignore Africa's problems, they'll come knocking on our door. We need to work together to fight terrorism everywhere.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, some say your rhetoric is only inflaming the situation and making things worse. [SEP] That's fake news. I'm telling the truth. I'm calling it like it is. These are radical leftists, anarchists. They want to destroy our country. I'm the only one standing in their way. I'm the only one who can protect you.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, isn't this 'rush to judgment' a bit premature given the gravity of the allegations? [SEP] He's a top student, a fantastic lawyer, everyone knows it. I've been hearing his name for a decade as a potential Supreme Court Justice. But let's be clear, I want to hear her side too. A very fair process is what we want.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Very quickly: You didn't want to get involved in the Ukraine conflict militarily for obvious reasons. Are you willing to get involved militarily to defend Taiwan, if it comes to that? [SEP] Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: So, Mr. President, concerning the future vision for this region that we've been discussing, did the talks today lead to a shared understanding between Romania and the U.S., especially concerning NATO's involvement? [SEP] *inaudible*
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, did Putin show any sign of wanting Assad out? And did you get anywhere with him or President Hu on stopping the Syrian violence? [SEP] Those were big topics in both meetings, absolutely. Syria's a mess, right? Civilians getting hammered, Assad's lost it. You can't have a peaceful change with him still calling the shots after all that. But it's not easy. Russia and China, they've been tougher to get on board with the pressure thing. We had a real talk. We're not exactly seeing eye-to-eye with them, but they know civil war's bad news and they don't like the killings. They get that a new government would be better for everyone. I told them we need to work with the UN and Kofi Annan on a plan. Hopefully, we can show the world, especially the Syrian people, a way out of this. Russia and China aren't totally on board yet, but they know things are bad and it's not helping them. We all agree that helping the Syrians find peace is the way to go. But I just don't see Assad staying and things getting better. He blew his chance with the Annan plan. The monitors had to leave. The opposition's done some bad stuff too, but those awful pictures from Homs? That's on Assad.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, are you taking this as a personal threat? [SEP] The situation is still unfolding. We're waiting for the results of the investigation.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Regarding Vice President Biden's statement about a 30% failure rate, can you clarify the context of that conversation and whether you concur with that percentage? [SEP] To be perfectly honest, I can't quite recall the specific instance Joe was talking about. But, I believe his underlying point – and I wouldn't necessarily put a precise figure on it – is that the challenges before us are so substantial that any individual measure will only contribute to the overall solution. As I've stated previously, not every initiative we undertake will yield the exact results we anticipate. We're navigating uncharted territory, and while there's a broad consensus among economists regarding the need for a recovery package, we still have to tackle the financial system, the housing market, and the regulatory framework. These are all significant and intricate tasks. So, I believe that's the general idea Joe was trying to communicate.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, concerning the NHS, will it be part of any potential trade agreement? [SEP] Could you repeat that? I'm having trouble hearing.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, some critics argue that your administration's response to the potential food crisis has been inadequate. They point to long lines at food banks and empty shelves in some stores as evidence that more needs to be done. How do you respond to these criticisms? [SEP] We're doing everything we can to address this challenge. We're working with our partners in the private sector and the non-profit world to ensure that food is getting to those who need it most. We're also investing in programs that will help to strengthen our food supply chain and prevent future disruptions.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, you've spoken about a shift toward decency. Do you believe this election marks a true break from the feverish political climate of recent years? [SEP] The super-mega-MAGA Republicans? I doubt we'll ever reach them. But they're a minority. The vast majority of Republicans are decent, honorable people, even if we disagree on policy. I've worked with many of them in the Senate and House, and they're honest and straightforward. The world is watching us. At the first G-7 meeting, I declared, 'America is back.' One leader asked, 'For how long?' Another asked what I'd say if thousands stormed the British Parliament to stop an election confirmation. It's not the same, but it would signal a democracy in crisis. People want to know if the U.S. is stable, if we still uphold our values and institutions. That's the key question.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Considering the bipartisan resistance to comprehensive immigration reform, could you detail your plan to overcome congressional obstacles and address the current stalemate in the Senate? [SEP] Well, the reason a consensus bill hasn't emerged in the Senate is because this is a complex issue requiring bipartisan cooperation. It's crucial to first establish a coherent Republican position in the Senate, which is where we're currently focusing our efforts. Senator Kennedy will lead the bill on the Democrat side. Once we achieve a unified Republican stance, one that most Republicans support, we'll collaborate with the Senator. Without sufficient consensus, nothing will pass the Senate, and consequently, nothing will happen in the House. Therefore, the initial stages of crafting a bill that addresses concerns are time-consuming but essential to address the issues raised during the last immigration reform debate. I'm optimistic that we can achieve something, and we're beginning to find common ground. There's broad agreement on a temporary-worker plan allowing individuals to legally come to the U.S. for jobs Americans aren't doing. This would greatly benefit Guatemalan citizens, eliminating the need to enter the country illegally, pay smugglers, or live in hiding. They'd be able to enter legally. Secondly, they'd be able to return home to their families legally, without fear. There would be a time limit, which is part of the negotiations. The difficult issue is what to do with those who've been in our country for an extended period. This is a sensitive issue with significant political implications. Automatic citizenship is unacceptable to many in our country. The challenge is to design a system that alleviates these concerns.
label: General

sentence: Q. Are you concerned about all that just like giving Kim the meeting, that he's getting a win as a deal—[inaudible]? [SEP] No, no, no, no. That's only—only the fake news says that. You know, this—look, we just three hostages back. We paid nothing. They came back. They're happily in ensconced in their homes with their families. They're the happiest people in the world right now.We have gotten—you know, we haven't done anything. Everyone said—you know, the haters, they say, Oh, you're giving him a meeting, you're—give me a break, okay? There's nothing. I think if I didn't do this, it would be—and it's never been done before, you know. It's never been done before. And obviously, what has been done before hasn't worked.And this is something—I can't stress this strong enough. You know, I talked about tariffs that previous people—and I'm not looking to criticize people that were preceding me—but on tariffs, it should have never happened.Well, the same thing on . We shouldn't be in this position. We shouldn't be in this position on tariffs, where we're hundreds of billions of dollars down to other countries that, frankly, were never even negotiated with. They never even got spoken to. I asked a top person in China, how did it get so bad? He looked at me, he said, Nobody ever talked to us. They were missing in action, our leaders.Well, a very similar thing, if you think about it, took place with . This should not be done now. This should have been done 5 years ago and 10 years ago and 25 years ago. It shouldn't be done now.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, following General Pace's controversial remarks on homosexuality, what is your personal view on whether homosexuality is immoral? [SEP] I'm not going to offer a personal judgment on individual orientations. I continue to believe that the 'don't ask, don't tell' policy serves us well. Next question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the challenges facing the nation, what specific areas of collaboration do you envision with Mr. McCarthy and the Republican Party? [SEP] I think he's the Republican leader, and I haven't had much of occasion to talk to him. But I will be talking to him. I think I'm talking to him later today.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, about Afghanistan, when can Americans expect our troops to come home, and will you make the media ban on covering the return of our fallen soldiers a thing of the past? [SEP] First, let me say that we just learned of more American soldiers lost in Iraq today. Our hearts go out to their families. Being President, signing those letters to the fallen, that's when it really hits you. As for the media policy, we're looking at it with the Pentagon, so I can't say for sure yet. Afghanistan is a tough one. Iraq had a pretty smooth election, thanks to our troops and Ambassador Crocker. Afghanistan isn't there yet. The government seems disconnected. Plus, you've got the Taliban and Al Qaida in the border areas. We need a real effort to get rid of those safe havens. General Petraeus and Richard Holbrooke are on it, figuring out a regional plan. We need better teamwork between our military, diplomats, and allies. The important thing to remember is that this region was where the 9/11 attacks came from. I met with the families of the victims this week. We can't let Al Qaida operate there. So, no timetable yet, but we won't let them plan attacks on us.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, are you confident this legislation will pass within your first year? [SEP] We're moving forward with the process this year, as quickly as possible. Some say I'm doing too much at once. We're giving it our all on every front. Ultimately, the legislative calendar isn't in my hands. We'll be working with congressional leaders to see what we can accomplish.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the intelligence community's assessment of Russian interference in the 2020 election, can you clearly and directly state whether you believe Russia attempted to influence the outcome and what specific steps your administration has taken to prevent future interference? [SEP] Well, let me be clear. We are aware of the reports, and we are taking them very seriously. We have the best people in the world working on this, the absolute best. But you know, the Democrats, they always want to blame Russia for everything. It's their excuse for losing. We're going to make sure our elections are secure, very secure. We're doing a great job, the best job.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, setting aside Donald Trump's candidacy, would you have still pursued a second term? [SEP] Yes, I would still be running if he wasn't. I know him well. He's not hard to know, as you know. You know him well, too. The question is whether or not we can finish the job. We have an opportunity to put ourselves in a position where we are economically and politically secure for a long time. There's still a contest between autocracies and democracies, and we're the leading democracy in the world. It's something I know a fair amount about, something I care about, and something that I have found a willingness of an awful lot of our allies and friends to follow. So I think that we have to finish the job and nail it down.
label: Deflection

sentence: Regarding Chinese tech firms, are there any others besides Huawei that you are considering prohibiting from operating within the United States? [SEP] Well, the big one is Huawei, isn't it? Huawei's not here, and I'm not letting them in. I've told European countries and others – Australia's been great, for example – that Huawei's not coming here. We even told some countries considering Huawei that they could use them, but we wouldn't share intelligence. They all backed away. Look at the UK, they seemed to be going that way, but now they've backed out – Scotland Yard.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, the public is frankly bewildered by the shifting guidelines and mixed messages coming from your administration regarding the coronavirus response. From mask mandates to testing protocols, there's a pervasive sense of confusion. Given this, why haven't you considered making personnel changes at agencies like the CDC to ensure clearer and more consistent communication? [SEP] Look, the evolving nature of the virus itself is the primary source of any perceived confusion. Our scientists are constantly learning and adapting their recommendations based on the latest data. It's a dynamic situation. Furthermore, the CDC has faced challenges in its communication strategies, but they are working diligently to improve. Think back to the early days of polio. The initial guidance on treatment and prevention evolved as we gained a better understanding of the disease. This is simply the reality of dealing with a novel virus. The speed at which we developed a vaccine is a testament to the dedication and expertise of our scientific community. While we haven't gotten everything right, we are committed to learning from our mistakes and providing the public with the most accurate and up-to-date information possible.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Are you confident it will happen before the deadline? [SEP] I think that everybody wants to make it happen, and they're working hard to get it done.Nedra [Nedra Pickler, Associated Press].
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Last week, you told us that Secretary Rumsfeld will be staying on. Why is the timing right now for this, and how much does it have to do with the election results? [SEP] Right. No, you and Hunt and Keil [Richard Keil, Bloomberg News] came in the Oval Office, and Hunt asked me the question one week before the campaign, and basically it was, Are you going to do something about Rumsfeld and the Vice President? And my answer was, they're going to stay on. And the reason why is, I didn't want to inject a major decision about this war in the final days of a campaign. And so the only way to answer that question and to get you on to another question was to give you that answer.The truth of the matter is, as well— I mean, that's one reason I gave the answer, but the other reason why is, I hadn't had a chance to visit with Bob Gates yet, and I hadn't had my final conversation with Don Rumsfeld yet at that point.I had been talking with Don Rumsfeld over a period of time about fresh perspective. He likes to call it fresh eyes. He himself understands that Iraq is not working well enough, fast enough. And he and I are constantly assessing. And I'm assessing, as well, all the time, by myself about, do we have the right people in the right place, or do we got the right strategy? As you know, we're constantly changing tactics, and that requires constant assessment.And so he and I both agreed in our meeting yesterday that it was appropriate that I accept his resignation. And so the decision was made. Actually, I thought we were going to do fine yesterday. Shows what I know. But I thought we were going to be fine in the election. My point to you is, is that, win or lose, Bob Gates was going to become the nominee.Let's see here. Bret [Bret Baier, FOX News].
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. ——confidence in Secretary Azar? [SEP] Wish him good luck. In who?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, can we expect this legislation to be passed within the next twelve months? [SEP] We're making progress on the process this year, as rapidly as we can. Some might argue I'm overextending myself. We're proceeding at full speed on all fronts. However, I don't dictate the legislative agenda. We'll be working with congressional leaders to determine what's achievable.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. ——in place right now. When can we expect that announcement? And how do you see the overall progress that Asian countries made? [SEP] Well, some are making progress; some are not, as you know. But some are making progress. And as they make progress, as they get down to the number that we all think is right—that they know is right, we know is right—we'll be opening it up. And some are really moving along rapidly. We hope to be able to open things up as quickly as possible.Go ahead, please. Go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Rick Ledgett's suggestion on 60 Minutes to grant Edward Snowden amnesty, what was your initial reaction? Are there any conceivable conditions under which you might consider a plea agreement or amnesty for Snowden? And what do you say to those Americans who believe Snowden's actions were justified in light of the surveillance revelations? [SEP] Look, I have to be careful here because Snowden's under indictment, and the Attorney General and the courts are handling it. I can't comment directly on the specifics. But I will say this: the conversation he started was important and needed to happen. However, the way he went about it caused real damage to our intelligence capabilities. There could have been a better way to have this discussion. The U.S., despite its flaws, respects the rule of law and privacy. Now, countries that actually *do* the things Snowden accused us of are using this to deflect criticism. So, while the conversation was important, the leaks hurt us. The courts will decide Snowden's fate.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Don't Americans have a right to know about who is proliferating, especially when you're negotiating with North Korea? [SEP] No, you have a right to know this, that when it comes to the six-party talks, proliferation—the issue of proliferation is—has equal importance with the issue of weaponry, and that North Korea has said that they will stop proliferating, just like they have said they will fully disclose and disable any weapons programs.Step one of that has been dealing with shuttering Pyongyang. Step two will be full declaration of any plutonium that has been manufactured and/or the construction of bombs, along with a full declaration of any proliferation activities. And in my judgment, the best way to solve this issue with North Korea peacefully is to put it in the— keep it in the context of the six-party talks. And the reason why is that diplomacy only works if there are consequences when diplomacy breaks down. And it makes sense for there to be other people at the table so that if North Korea were to have said to all of us, We're going to do x, y, or z, and they don't, that we have other— people other than the United States being consequential.There's a lot of aid that goes on with— between North Korea and China, or North Korea and South Korea, and therefore, if they renege on their promises—and they have said—they have declared that they will show us weapons and get rid of the weapons programs as well as stop proliferation— if they don't fulfill that which they've said, we are now in a position to make sure that they understand that there will be consequences.And I'm pleased with the progress we're making. There's still work to be done? You bet there's work to be done. Do I go into this thing saying, well, you know, gosh, the process is more important than results? I don't. What matters most to me are whether or not we can achieve the results that I've said we're hoping to achieve. And if not, there will be consequences to the North Koreans.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. That doesn't seem to resonate with a lot of House Republicans who represent overwhelmingly White districts. What other political leverage can you bring to bear to help move a bill in the House? [SEP] Well, we've got an economic report that shows that our economy would be a trillion dollars stronger if we get immigration reform done. We've got evidence that our housing market would be stronger if immigrants are in a situation in which, having paid a fine, having paid back taxes, that they now have the ability to actually enter into the housing market. We've got strong evidence that our technological and research edge would be better if we get immigration reform done.We know that the Senate bill strengthens border security, puts unprecedented resources on top of the unprecedented resources I've already put into border security. So if your main priority is border security, I'd think you'd want to vote for this bill. We know that the Senate bill creates a system in which employers are held accountable for when they hire undocumented workers. This is something that people say is a bad thing. I agree. Let's make sure that that system for holding employers accountable is in place.So when I hear the opposition to immigration reform, I just run through the list of things they're concerned about, I look at what the Senate bill does, and I say to myself, you know what, the Senate bill actually improves the situation on every issue that they say they're concerned about.Now, what they may argue is, it doesn't solve the problem 100 percent. I don't know a law that solves a problem 100 percent. Social Security lifted millions of seniors out of poverty, but there are still some poor seniors. The Civil Rights Act and the Voting Rights Act drastically reduced discrimination in America, but there's still discrimination. That doesn't make them bad laws; it just means that there are very few human problems that are 100 percent solvable.So what I see right now is a strong bipartisan vote coming out of the Senate. I think that the Speaker and others have said they need to do something, and I'd urge, when they get back, to do something, put forward a bill that has an opportunity to actually pass. It may not be precisely what's in the Senate bill. My preference would be for them to go ahead and call the Senate bill. But if they've got some additional ideas, I think the Senate is happy to consider them. And get that bill on the floor, put it up for a vote.I am absolutely certain that the votes for the Senate bill, which strengthens border security, demands responsibility from undocumented workers to pay a fine—pay a penalty and get to the back of the line, reforms our legal immigration system, holds employers accountable, I am absolutely confident that if that bill was on the floor of the House, it would pass.So the challenge right now is not that there aren't a majority of House Members, just like a majority of Senate Members, who aren't prepared to support this bill. The problem is internal Republican caucus politics. And that's what the American people don't want us to be worrying about. Don't worry about your Washington politics, solve problems.And this is one where you've actually got some pretty broad consensus. I don't know an issue where you've got labor, the Chamber of Commerce, evangelicals, student groups, you name it, supportive of a bill. Let's get it done, all right?Thank you very much, everybody.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, critics suggest that your close relationship with Prime Minister Blair has unduly influenced American foreign policy, particularly regarding the Iraq War. How do you respond to concerns that your administration has prioritized British interests over those of the United States? [SEP] Tony's a friend, a good friend. And he's a strong leader, a smart leader. We see eye to eye on a lot of things, and that's a good thing. But I make my own decisions. I do what's best for America. And sometimes that aligns with what's best for Great Britain, and sometimes it doesn't. But I always put America first. Always. And as far as the Iraq War, that was a tough decision, a very tough decision. But I believe it was the right decision. We had to remove Saddam Hussein, he was a threat to the world. And we're better off without him. And I know that Tony feels the same way. He's a strong ally, a loyal ally. And I appreciate his support. But I make my own decisions. I always have, and I always will.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your vision for a free and open Indo-Pacific, and your upcoming trip to China, a country lacking both qualities, how do you reconcile promoting freedom in the region without inevitable conflict with China? And Prime Minister, concerning President Trump's desire for Japan to strengthen its defense, including purchasing U.S. military equipment, and reports of his disappointment regarding the North Korean missile incident, did this topic arise, and what is your message regarding Japan's defense role? [SEP] Thank you. If I may address a portion of the Prime Minister's response, he will indeed intercept those missiles once he finalizes the acquisition of substantial military equipment from the United States. It will be a straightforward matter, much like our successful interception in Saudi Arabia. A rapidly moving missile neutralized with precision and without collateral damage. The Prime Minister of Japan will be procuring significant quantities of military equipment, as he should. We manufacture the finest military equipment globally. Whether it's the F-35 fighter, unparalleled in its stealth capabilities, or a variety of missiles, this translates to jobs for us and enhanced security for Japan and other nations purchasing our equipment, something that was not happening a year or two ago. As for China, my relationship with President Xi is excellent. I consider him a friend, and he reciprocates. However, he represents China, and I represent the United States. Our perspectives may differ, but we share common ground on trade. The issue with China is that for decades, the trade situation has been, to put it mildly, unfair. Our trade deficit is enormous, ranging from $350 billion to $504 billion annually, excluding intellectual property. We have initiated discussions with China to rectify this imbalance. It must be addressed through fair and reciprocal trade practices. I prefer the term 'reciprocal' because it resonates with people. When you explain that tariffs will be imposed to level the playing field, some may not grasp the concept. But when you frame it as 'reciprocal,' where we charge the same rates they charge us, it becomes more palatable, even if it's 100 percent. Reciprocal trade is paramount. We have numerous countries, not just China or Japan, that engage in such practices. One country, for instance, levies a 100 percent tax on our exports while charging us nothing on theirs. I have long opposed this, and we will take action. This process takes time due to statutory limitations. Notices must be issued, and waiting periods observed. However, much of this has already been addressed. You will witness the United States taking decisive action against countries that have treated our companies, workers, and nation unfairly. This has already commenced, and the legal groundwork is complete. Significant changes are imminent. The United States has been treated unfairly in trade for far too long. Regarding Japan's defense equipment, we procure a significant portion from the United States. Given the challenging North Korean situation and the Asia-Pacific security environment, we must enhance our defense capabilities both qualitatively and quantitatively. The F-35A and SM-3 Block IIA are prime examples of planned purchases from the United States. Aegis vessels will also be enhanced in both quality and quantity. In this process, we will be increasing our purchases from the United States. Concerning North Korea's missile launches, we immediately tracked their trajectory. Missile defense is a collaborative effort between Japan and the United States. If interception and shooting down become necessary, we will certainly do so, in close coordination with the United States.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, isn't this 'fix' simply a political maneuver designed to mitigate the damage from the disastrous rollout? Are you prioritizing short-term political gains over the long-term stability and integrity of the Affordable Care Act? [SEP] That's a cynical view, and it's simply not accurate. This is about people. It's about ensuring that people who are facing uncertainty and anxiety have options. We're listening to the concerns of the American people and responding in a responsible way. The ACA is a complex piece of legislation, and we're constantly working to improve it. This is just one step in that process. We're committed to ensuring that everyone has access to affordable, quality healthcare, and we're going to continue to work towards that goal, regardless of the political implications.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, Americans are feeling the pinch of rising prices. How long should they expect to endure these high costs at the grocery store and gas pump? And given the Fed's role, are your options limited in addressing inflation? [SEP] Well, look, the issue is the supply chain. That's what's driving inflation. We're making progress on that. The chip shortage is a big part of the problem, especially for cars. We're working to become self-reliant on those chips. As for energy prices, that's more complicated. We convinced countries to release oil reserves, which helped a bit. But it's going to be hard. We need more competition in the meat industry, too. And Build Back Better would actually lower inflation, according to experts.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, the QAnon conspiracy alleges you're secretly fighting a deep state of child-trafficking elites. Do you endorse this theory, and what's your message to those who believe in it? [SEP] Well, I don't know about the specifics of that. But I can tell you, we're fighting for the American people. We're fighting against the radical left who want to destroy our country. We're fighting for law and order. That's what we're doing.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Mayor Bowser's order in DC, while it exempts federal properties, would you consider encouraging federal entities, including the White House and military bases, to voluntarily adhere to it? [SEP] That's a matter under active consideration. We're evaluating the situation and expect to have a definitive course of action within the next day. Stay tuned.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Bush, the invasion of Iraq was predicated on the belief that Saddam Hussein possessed weapons of mass destruction. Given that no such weapons were found, do you believe the war was justified, and what lessons have you learned from that experience about the use of intelligence in making decisions about military intervention? [SEP] I made the decision to remove Saddam Hussein because I believed he posed a threat to the United States and the world. We acted on the best intelligence available at the time. While no weapons of mass destruction were found, Saddam Hussein was a brutal dictator who had a history of using chemical weapons. The world is better off without him.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. I was wondering, do you think that North Korea has fundamentally changed from being a member of the axis of evil a few years ago? [SEP] That's to be determined. The human rights abuses inside the country still exist and persist. The n leader has yet to fully verify the extent to which he has had a highly enriched uranium program. There's still more steps to be done on the plutonium program. So in order to get off the list, the axis of evil list, then the n leader is going to have to make certain decisions. And that's all part of the six-party talks.And again, I can't predict the n leader's decisionmaking. I don't know what he's going to do. But I do know that the best way to solve this issue is for five other nations to be saying the exact same thing.And there has been progress. I mean, one thing is for certain, that he did blow up the cooling tower. That was—that's verifiable because we all saw it. And it's— that was a positive step. And I—you know, I think all of us appreciated that positive step, but there's more steps to be taken. And my hope is that the axis of evil list no longer exists. That's my hope, for the sake of peace. And it's my hope for—you know, for the sake of our children.Thank you very much for your attention. Thank you for your questions. Why don't you go find a shade tree to stand under? []
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Did you agree that Huawei can sell to the U.S. or that U.S. companies can sell to Huawei? The President. U.S. companies can sell their equipment to Huawei. We're talking about equipment where there is no great national emergency problem with it. But the U.S. companies can sell their equipment. So we have a lot of the great companies in Silicon Valley and based in different parts of the country that make extremely complex equipment. We're letting them sell to Huawei.Turkey/Turkey's Purchase of Russian S-400 Antiaircraft System  Q. And then, on Turkey, sir, will Turkey face sanctions if it goes ahead with the S-400 purchases? [SEP] Okay so Turkey is an interesting case—because there's another one Jim that I get along with very well and he's a tough cookie okay? Right? President Erdogan. He's tough but I get along with him. And maybe that's a bad thing but I think it's a really good thing. Because frankly he wanted to wipe out—he has a big problem with the Kurds as everyone knows. And he had a 65000-man army at the border and he was going to wipe out the Kurds who helped us with ISIS. We took out the caliphate. We have a hundred percent of the caliphate.And I called him and I asked him not to do it. They are I guess natural enemies of his or Turkey's. And he hasn't done it. He had—they were lined up to go out and wipe out the people that we just defeated the ISIS caliphate with and I said You can't do that. You can't do it. And he didn't do it.So I have a relationship. But let me tell you—so he goes out during the Obama administration; he wants to buy our Patriot missile. Right? They wouldn't sell it to him. He wants to buy—even though he's a member of NATO and in theory he could be an ally if he respected the President. He—and he's got a big army and he's—you know they're fighters. Turkey is—big fighters. And we're working on Idlib Province together because he doesn't want to see 3 million people killed and neither do I—in Syria. But—and I mentioned that. That was another thing I mentioned folks to President Putin. I said Please take it easy with Idlib. Because you know they've been encircling that.I think if I didn't put out a statement 6 months ago that would've been catastrophic. But they have 30000 terrorists in Idlib Province. You have 3 million people. And you know getting terrorists is okay but you don't want to kill 3 million people or a million people to get the terrorists.So anyway—so we get along great. But what happened with Turkey—and I will tell you when it's fair and when it's not fair. He wanted to buy the Patriot missile. President Obama's group said no. He kept wanting to buy it. They kept saying no no no. Couldn't buy it. Now he needed it for defense. He needed it. So he then went to Russia and he bought the S-400. Made a deal to buy it because he couldn't get it. They wouldn't allow him to buy it. They wouldn't allow it. This administration meaning this administration previous to mine would not let him buy it.So he goes out he goes to Russia and he makes a deal for the S-400. And let's assume it's not nearly as good but he made a deal. He paid them money a lot of money. Put up a lot of money. And he bought it. As soon as he bought it people went back to him from our country and they said Listen we don't want you to use that system because it's not the NATO system et cetera et cetera—you know all the reasons: We don't want you to use that system. Do us a favor we'll sell you the Patriot. He said It's too late. I already bought it. There was nothing he could do; he already bought it.In the meantime he bought over a hundred F-35s the greatest fighter jet in the world. It's stealth. You can't see it. It's real hard to beat something when you can't see it. But he bought over a hundred. I think he bought 116. But he bought over a hundred. A lot. And he has options for more. And now he wants delivery. He's paid a tremendous amount of money up front to Lockheed our company our jobs everything. And now they're saying he's using the S-400 system which is incompatible with our system and if you use the S-400 system Russia and other people can gain access into the genius of the F-35.But honestly I'm all for our country but he got treated very unfairly. He was told you can't buy it you can't buy it. You know it's the old secret when you can't have something all of a sudden he ends up going and getting something else and then they were—they said—first they said: We'll sell it to you. You can have it in 4 years. Then they said We'll get it to you immediately. But he said: I can't do it. I bought. I've spent a fortune on buying another system—similar system—from Russia. The problem is he already bought the planes. And the planes aren't compatible from our standpoint. Not from the standpoint of compatibility but from our standpoint national security wise.So it's a mess. It's a mess. And honestly it's not really Erdogan's fault. So now we have breaking news.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, some critics argue that your policies have exacerbated political divisions in the country. How do you respond to these concerns, and what steps are you taking to bridge the divide? [SEP] Look, I'm trying to bring people together.
