sentence: Q. Tajiri, Kyodo News. At Camp David with history. I do have a question to each of the leaders.Mr. President Biden—President Biden, it was mentioned at this summit meeting that Russia's aggression of Ukraine is continuing. So what role do you expect of Japan?Prime Minister Kishida has mentioned that as China's threat in Asia is rising, Ukraine may be East Asia tomorrow. What do you think about this comment, President Biden?And the situation in Asia, where China's threat is rising, what is the meaning and significance of the trilateral relationship with Japan, U.S., R.O.K. becoming stronger in multiple layers? [SEP] North Korea's nuclear missile development is a major security threat to Japan, South Korea, and the U.S. As North Korea's provocations continue to escalate, what is the meaning and significance of the three countries declaring a new era of partnership?Regarding the release of treated water at Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, did Prime Minister Kishida explain the matter at the trilateral or the bilateral summit today?To the recent Japan-R.O.K. summit meeting, Your Excellency, you expressed your intent to respect the IAEA report despite the strong domestic opposition. Why do you demonstrate your understanding for the policy of Kishida administration? I ask for that reason.And to Prime Minister Kishida, this is the first time that a trilateral summit is held on a stand-alone basis rather than on the sidelines of international meetings. You have said that the trilateral cooperation will be raised to new heights for the security environment in East Asia. And without the resolution of abduction, North Korea is continuing nuclear missile development. What is the meaning for North Korea?And in East and South Seas, by maritime advancement, is continuing unilateral attempts to change the status quo. What is the meaning for ? And you have a great imagination. One question ends up being six. But thank you. [] I'll try to answer all of it. [] I'm glad I didn't have you as my law professor when he said one question. [] At any rate, they're all legitimate questions.Look, on Ukraine, I and my country and the leadership of my country in both parties are very grateful for everything Japan is helping to deal with in Ukraine. And I mean that sincerely. You've showed strong leadership through the G-7 as well and contributed to a significant amount of financial and humanitarian assistance to Ukraine, as well as nonlethal military equipment.And you know—and they joined so many other nations in holding Russia accountable through their international sanctions.If my memory serves me well—and I think it does, Mr. Prime Minister—we found ourselves in a circumstance where, when I called you about Ukraine, I didn't have to convince you of anything. I started off to make the case that Ukraine was a circumstance where—to think, in the first quarter of the 20th century, another country would amass over 150,000 forces on the border of another country—or 150,000 forces and invade that country—invade that country without any rationale other than—if you read Putin's speech after he invaded, he talked about Kyiv being the motherland.You know, I mean, it just was ridiculous, I think. And he talked about being Peter the Great. It was—just imagine if we had done nothing. Imagine if we had done nothing.And the point was immediately recognized, if I'm not mistaken, by you, Mr. Prime Minister, that we're in a situation where it could happen anywhere. If we stand—if we had stood still, what signal would that send to about Taiwan? What signal would that send around the world if nations weren't powerful on borders?But here's the deal. You contributed significantly to what, I think, is already the—let me put it this way. Russia has already lost. It cannot meet its original objective which it stated. It's not possible.But—and they've joined so many other nations in holding Russia accountable for international sanctions. But Japan's leadership, from day one, that has been critical for making it clear that the consequences for war extend well beyond Europe—well beyond Europe.I say it in reverse. What would happen if an Asian country with 150,000 troops invaded another? You think that would not affect the interests, the economy, and the foreign policy of nations in Europe and Latin America all across the world? It would have profound impact.And with Japan's leadership, from day one, it has been critical to making clear the consequences of this will extend well beyond Europe—well beyond Europe. It's a global issue that has impacts everywhere. And the Prime Minister's comments at Shangri-La capture that.And by the way, you know, we talked about this being an inflection point. The world is changing. The world is changing. And about every six or seven generations, it makes significant change. And there's a lot happening.And the idea that we're going to sit down, the rest of the world, and say, Well, that's only a European problem. There hasn't been that kind of invasion since World War II.And so—as for peace, we all want that, of course. Ukrainians want it most of all. And my team has been working very closely with the—President Zelenskyy's team and further peace formula, noting that nothing about Ukraine without Ukraine. But nonetheless, we're meeting with them constantly—constantly.And your other two questions about —I'll just say this: This summit was not about . That was not the purpose of the meeting. But it did come— obviously came up. Not to say we don't share concerns about the economic coercion or heightened tensions caused by , but this summit was really about our relationship with each other and deepening cooperation across an entire range of issues that went well beyond just the immediate issues we raised.It was about more peaceful and prosperous Indo-Pacific, a region, quite frankly, that would benefit everyone living there and around the world if we get it right. It's not just here. It has a phenomenal impact.Think about what's going—at any rate, I won't get going. I'll take too long. []But as you've seen from the initiatives we're announcing here, today is just how committed we are to see this vision take place. And I think this relationship that we've put together and I think we're going to—you're going to see it expand. It's not merely what we did today. This is a historic meeting.But we're about to—we've laid in place a long-term structure for a relationship that will last and have a phenomenal impact not just in Asia, but around the world.Someone once said in a different context that—about a health care provision in my country a while ago: This is a big deal. [] This is a big deal.Thank you. President Xi Jinping of
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Repeatedly now, Donald Trump has said that this election will be rigged against him, challenging really the core foundation of our democratic system. Can you promise the American people that this election will be conducted in a fair way? And are you worried that comments like his could erode the public's faith in the outcome of the election? And if he does win, given that you have just declared him unfit, what will you say to the American people? [SEP] Well, at the end of the day, it's the American people's decision. I have one vote. I have the same vote you do. I have the vote that all the voters who are eligible all across the country have. I've offered my opinion, but ultimately, it's the American people's decision to make collectively. And if somebody wins the election and they are President, then my constitutional responsibility is to peacefully transfer power to that individual and do everything I can to help them succeed.It is—I don't even really know where to start on answering this question. [] Of course, the elections will not be rigged. What does that mean? [] The Federal Government doesn't run the election process. States and cities and communities all across the country, they are the ones who set up the voting systems and the voting booths. And if Mr. Trump is suggesting that there is a conspiracy theory that is being propagated across the country, including in places like Texas, where typically it's not Democrats who are in charge of voting booths, that's ridiculous. That doesn't make any sense. And I don't think anybody would take that seriously.Now, we do take seriously—as we always do—our responsibilities to monitor and preserve the integrity of the voting process. If we see signs that a voting machine or system is vulnerable to hacking, then we inform those local authorities who are running the elections that they need to be careful. If we see jurisdictions that are violating Federal laws in terms of equal access and aren't providing ramps for disabled voters or are discriminating in some fashion or are otherwise violating civil rights laws, then the Justice Department will come in and take care of that.But this will be an election like every other election. And I think all of us at some points in our lives have played sports or maybe just played in a schoolyard or a sandbox. And sometimes, folks, if they lose, they start complaining that they got cheated. But I've never heard of somebody complaining about being cheated before the game was over or before the score is even tallied. So my suggestion would be go out there and try to win the election.If Mr. Trump is up 10 or 15 points on election day and ends up losing, then maybe he can raise some questions. [] That doesn't seem to be the case at the moment.Barbara Starr [CNN].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, do you believe the Justice Department's seizure of phone records from Associated Press journalists was an overreach? Do you still have confidence in your Attorney General? Is the renewed White House interest in a media shield law a response? And what about comparisons to the Nixon era? [SEP] I'll let you all make those comparisons and draw your own conclusions. My concern is fixing problems in the Government. That's my responsibility. That's true for the IRS and the security of our diplomats. Regarding the Justice Department, I won't comment on a specific, pending case. But leaks related to national security can endanger people, especially those in uniform or intelligence officers. U.S. national security depends on their confidence. I make no apologies for protecting them. However, we also live in a democracy with a free press. The media shield law aimed to strike a balance. This case has prompted renewed interest, so it's time to revisit that legislation. It's important to recognize that I have troops in Afghanistan and intelligence officers in risky situations. Part of my job is to protect them while still accommodating the need for information.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: On the topic of energy, are US oil producers maximizing all available resources, including offshore? And concerning Iraq, will you conclude an interim agreement with Prime Minister Maliki regarding the American military presence, or will you defer the negotiation of a permanent agreement to your successor? [SEP] We are in the process of developing a comprehensive strategic framework agreement with the Iraqi government, which will address cooperation across multiple sectors, including diplomacy, economics, and justice. This framework includes a security agreement, and the Iraqi government has indicated its preference for a timeline for transitioning to an 'overwatch' role for US forces, which would involve training, logistical support, and specialized operations. To maintain our troop presence in Iraq, we require a clear understanding with the Iraqi government, including the necessary operational authorities and protections for our personnel. We are actively engaged in negotiating these details, and we intend to finalize the agreement before the end of the year, unless the UN mandate is extended.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. So if he wants the sanctions completely off, and you want more on denuclearization, how can you bridge that gap between now and the next time you might sit down with him? [SEP] With time. It will be bridged, I think, at a certain point. But there is a gap. We have to have sanctions. And he wants to denuke, but he wants to just do areas that are less important than the areas that we want. We know that—we know the country very well, believe it or not. We know every inch of that country. And we have to get what we have to get, because that's a big give.Yes, Sean. Please.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding voting access, many citizens are expressing concerns about potential barriers. But honestly, that's a question for the state governments, not for me. Next question, please.

sentence: Sir, if you don't mind, before he gets a word in, can I, representing the New York Times, ask my question first? [SEP] Say again? You're with who?

sentence: Mr. President, after pushing a $447 billion jobs bill for months, you've achieved very little beyond a veterans jobs bill and some executive orders. Are you resigned to the fact that Congress won't pass any significant jobs legislation, leaving you to face the voters in 2012 with high unemployment and questions about your leadership? [SEP] Well, frankly, people are questioning Congress's leadership for failing to pass a jobs bill that most Americans, including many Republicans, support. That's why Congress isn't popular right now. Usually, when people dislike what you're doing, you change course. But Republicans in Congress don't seem to feel the same urgency about creating jobs. I'll keep pushing. We'll get some of it done now, and I'll keep pushing until we get all of it done. Maybe that takes till November, maybe it takes a new Congress. Cutting taxes for the middle class, small businesses hiring veterans, teachers—Hawaii has kids in school four days a week due to budget problems. How do we compete globally with that? The jobs bill would help. Rebuilding infrastructure—every world leader talks about needing top-notch infrastructure. Look at Asia—better airports, better ports. That hurts our capacity to trade. And we could put people back to work. So, I'll keep pushing. I don't expect Republicans to suddenly agree with me, but I hope they realize doing nothing isn't an option. If not, we might have different leaders in Congress.
label: Deflection

sentence: So, regarding the Afghanistan deal, what role do you envision for India and Pakistan in the region moving forward? [SEP] Well, India's keen to see things work out, and I had a good chat with Prime Minister Modi about it today. We're getting there, you know? Two days without major violence – that's something. Everyone seems to be on board, even the usual naysayers. It's been 19 years, folks, time to bring our troops home. We'll keep an eye on things, of course, and if anything goes sideways, we'll hit them hard. But we're not a police force. They gotta handle their own backyard.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Biden and Harris's first campaign rally, did you happen to catch any of it, and what are your initial thoughts? [SEP] Didn't have time to watch the whole thing, just snippets. Enough to see it's the same old song and dance. He chose her, and frankly, that's his problem. Remember her poll numbers? They tanked! She attacked him relentlessly during the primaries, even echoing those accusations, and now she's suddenly his biggest cheerleader? It's a bit much, even for politics. And her policies? No fracking? Good luck with that in Pennsylvania. It's the same playbook as 2016, but we're stronger now. Bigger tax cuts, fewer regulations, a booming economy. They want to raise taxes, defund the police, weaken the military. It's a disaster waiting to happen. We're getting endorsements from law enforcement, the military, everyone who wants a strong America. So, no, I wasn't impressed. Not at all.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, regarding those comments suggesting Iran doesn't want a nuclear weapon, are you concerned, and does it signal weakening international pressure? [SEP] If that's what he said, I'd like him to clarify. When I spoke with him, he understood the world needs to keep Iran from getting a nuclear weapon. That's why we worked together at the UN. If he wasn't worried, why did we make so much progress there? I'll talk to him about it. I haven't been briefed on Condi and Bob Gates' meeting with Putin yet.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning energy independence, why haven't you directly addressed the role of major oil corporations? Are you satisfied that domestic producers are fully exploiting available resources, including offshore reserves? Also, on Iraq, will you conclude an interim operational agreement with Prime Minister Maliki, or leave a permanent accord to the next administration? [SEP] Let's be clear about Iraq. We are currently developing a strategic framework agreement with the Iraqi government. This will cover cooperation on multiple fronts – diplomacy, economics, and the rule of law. Integral to this is a security agreement. They naturally desire a clear timeline for transitioning to what we call 'overwatch.' 'Overwatch' means the U.S. will maintain a training mission, logistical support, and special operations capabilities. For our forces to be stationed in any foreign country, a mutual understanding with its government is paramount. This includes the authority to operate and protections for our personnel. We are negotiating this diligently, aiming to finalize it before the end of the year, barring an extension of the UN mandate. There are two distinct aspects to this agreement – often confused, it seems – and we're addressing both simultaneously. Now, about those oil companies...
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, you mentioned reaching out to Republicans. Some Republicans, like Mitt Romney, who might be open to voting rights changes, say they haven't even received a call from the White House. Why is that? [SEP] Look, I like Mitt. He's a straight shooter. I was focused on getting everyone in my own party on board first. I didn't call many Republicans at all. But Mitt's a serious guy, and I think we can get things done. I predict we'll see progress on electoral reform. Instead of judging what will or won't happen, I'll keep making the case for why it's crucial not to hand over the electoral process to political operatives deliberately trying to change election outcomes. Next question, please.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, to be precise, are you actively exploring methods to remove him as part of that political transition? And regarding the continuing resolution expiring on December 11, what are the odds of a government shutdown, and how much does that influence your decision on immigration and executive action? [SEP] I trust Mitch McConnell's word that the government won't shut down. There's no reason for it. We've been down that road before, and it was bad for everyone. It'll be resolved the same way it would have been without a shutdown. So, it's not productive. This goes to a broader point: In a democracy, parties disagree. In our system, with divided government, disagreement is inevitable. The sensible approach is to fight for your position on issues you disagree on, and work together on issues you agree on. That's how it was with Ronald Reagan and a Democratic Congress. They didn't say they couldn't work with him on Social Security or tax reform because they disagreed on other issues. I expect the same now. Some Republicans disagree with me on immigration reform, but that doesn't mean we should shut down the government. That makes as much sense as me shutting down the government if they vote to repeal healthcare for the 55th time. Let's do the people's business.
label: Deflection

sentence: Given the recent attack on the Inter-Continental Hotel, are you worried about the Afghan forces' ability to secure the country? [SEP] It's crucial to remember that the troop drawdown hasn't even started yet. We've always known it's a dangerous region, the Taliban remains active, and incidents like this will, unfortunately, occur. The key question is whether Afghan capacity is improving overall. Kabul, with a large part of the population, has been policed by Afghan forces for a long time, and they've done a pretty good job. Kabul is safer than it was, and Afghan forces are more capable. That doesn't mean these attacks won't happen; they probably will for a while. Our work isn't finished. But, as I said, the tide of war is receding. We're in a transition phase, like in Iraq, where we drew down troops, and Iraq maintained a democratic government and reduced violence. We think a similar approach makes sense here. Even in Iraq, attacks still happen. These countries are recovering from war and conflict; they're dangerous. They won't be perfectly safe even if we were there. But we can improve the chances for the Afghan people to defend themselves.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. But did you hear from other world leaders and business leaders who said that they think that she has a message that you should listen to? [SEP] No, I didn't, actually. But I would have loved to have seen her speak. I did not.

sentence: Madam President, while Brazil sees itself as a global leader, the U.S. views it as a regional player. How do you reconcile these differing perspectives? [SEP] I'd like to thank for partially answering that. Countries face crises. Overcoming them makes a country great. This applies to relations with the U.S. We have much in common: a history of slavery, large Black populations, and multiculturalism. We're strong democracies. Brazil will overcome its current crisis, continue its growth, and preserve its gains. We want a predominantly middle-class country and will fight to reduce inequality.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. So, there's no official record of this conversation? [SEP] Well, as far as I'm aware, no recording exists. I don't believe it was recorded. If only there were a recording! It would certainly make things... clearer.

sentence: With the incoming administration's differing stances on climate change and Russia, are you concerned about the future of European unity? And, purely hypothetically, would you consider a return to politics as a gesture of stability? [SEP] I maintain a policy of non-interference in other nations' politics. Chancellor Merkel has been an exceptional colleague, a leader of unwavering integrity. Our alliance is rooted in common values and a dedication to global cooperation. My stance on Russia has been constant: pursue collaboration where feasible, but resolutely defend our principles. We aspire to a successful Russia that respects international norms, but we must not compromise on democracy, sovereignty, and the rule of law. I am optimistic that the new administration will strike a balance between engagement and upholding these principles. The President-elect's commitment to NATO is reassuring. On cyber security, we must collaborate to establish international standards and prevent a digital arms race. The smooth transition of power in the US underscores its democratic strength, and I am confident that the strong bonds between the US and Germany will persist. We must protect territorial integrity in Europe, and we will continue to seek diplomatic resolutions. Regarding my own future, I will announce my decision at the appropriate time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Cuba, considering their history of antagonism, what's your assessment of Fidel Castro's influence on the current negotiations with Raul? Did you inquire about Fidel's health, and will you actively engage with Congress to secure funding for the embassy amidst Republican opposition? sentence: Q. With respect, Mr. President, can you at least confirm whether the assailant was male or female, and the type of weapon utilized? [SEP] I'm afraid I'm unable to provide any insight on those matters.

sentence: Q. ——a booster. Why hasn't this White House changed the definition of fully vaccinated to include that third booster shot? Is it because the numbers of fully vaccinated Americans would suddenly look a lot less impressive? [SEP] No, it's not that at all. It's just, this has become clearer and clearer, and every time I speak of it, I say: If you've been vaccinated, get your booster shot. Everybody get the booster shot. It's the optimum protection you could have. You're protected very well with two shots, if it's the Pfizer—anyway, you're protected. But you are better protected with the booster shot.

sentence: Q. But how quickly, sir, do they need to move out? [SEP] You know, as quickly as possible.

sentence: Are all sanctions currently in place going to stay in place? [SEP] They're there. The sanctions are there. We didn't give anything up. Nobody seems to realize that. I think we're going to be great friends with Kim Jong Un. He's a tough cookie, but he's smart. And North Korea, they have so much potential. But the sanctions? They wanted them gone, but they wouldn't give us what we wanted. So, they're staying right where they are.

sentence: Mr. President, following your Geneva meeting where you said President Putin didn't want a cold war, considering the troop deployments, cyber attacks, and demands for a sphere of influence, do you still hold that view? Has your opinion of him evolved, and if an invasion occurs, would you revert to a containment strategy? [SEP] My assessment is that he still doesn't want a full-blown war. However, I anticipate he will test the resolve of the West, the United States, and NATO to the fullest extent possible. He will face significant consequences that he doesn't currently anticipate. He will come to regret his actions. He perceives the collapse of the Berlin Wall and the dissolution of the Soviet empire as a profound loss for Russia. He possesses immense territory, but is struggling to define his position between China and the West. I'm uncertain if he has a clear plan. My expectation is that he will intervene. He feels compelled to take action. He seeks assurances that Ukraine will not join NATO and that strategic weapons will not be deployed there. We can potentially find common ground on the latter, contingent on his behavior. The former presents a greater challenge, as international agreements uphold the right of nations to choose their affiliations. Nevertheless, Ukraine's accession to NATO in the immediate future is improbable. There's an opportunity for negotiation if he's willing. But I suspect, as always, he's going to—well, I probably shouldn't go any further. But I think it will hurt him badly.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, Mayor Bloomberg cited climate change as a key reason for endorsing you, particularly after Hurricane Sandy's devastation. What specific climate change initiatives will you pursue in a second term? And do you believe there's sufficient political will in Washington for carbon tax legislation? [SEP] Mark, we can't definitively link any single weather event to climate change. However, global temperatures are rising faster than predicted, and Arctic ice is melting at an alarming rate. Severe weather events are increasingly frequent. I firmly believe climate change is real and driven by human emissions. We have a responsibility to future generations. In my first term, we doubled fuel efficiency and clean energy production, reducing carbon emissions. But we need to do more. I'll consult with scientists, engineers, and politicians to identify short-term carbon reduction strategies and foster a national conversation on long-term solutions. I'm unsure what Democrats or Republicans will support, as regional differences exist. Addressing climate change seriously requires tough choices. Americans are focused on jobs and growth, so we can't ignore those. If we can create jobs, advance growth, and tackle climate change, that's something the public will support. Expect to hear more from me on this in the coming months.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding potential inspections of North Korea's nuclear sites, as reported by Sputnik News Agency, can you confirm whether this topic was discussed during your negotiations? [SEP] I didn't quite catch that. Could you speak up and tell me where you're reporting from?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, can you offer a concrete plan for how a second round of direct payments would be distributed, and what specific economic indicators are you monitoring to determine the necessity and scale of such payments? [SEP] We're in discussions with various parties, exploring different avenues. I'm keen on a payroll tax cut and ensuring the well-being of our workers. We're negotiating with the Democrats, and we'll see where it leads. This is a transition, a transition to greatness. Next year will be exceptional, truly special. The third quarter is a transition, but the fourth quarter will show tremendous numbers. Next year, we'll see the kind of numbers we had before, perhaps even better, driven by pent-up demand.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, and Prime Minister, a question for you both. First, Mr. President, did you discuss the possibility of Canada boosting its stimulus spending? Second, looking ahead, how do you both see the future of the Canada-U.S. relationship in four years? What about the auto industry, border crossings, and environmental policies? [SEP] That's quite a few questions all at once! Were you speaking with someone else? Is that--[]?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the current situation, do you wish to revise your previous assessment of China's transparency concerning the coronavirus? [SEP] I consistently show deference to China.
label: General

sentence: President Niinistö, with Finland sharing a border with Russia, what are your current concerns, and what further steps do you think are needed to deter Putin's actions? [SEP] We have been very careful in considering all possibilities. We want to be ready for anything. The situation is calm, and we hope it remains so. The Finnish people feel safer, and we are committed to defending our allies.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, the Vice President specifically mentioned a conversation the two of you had. Surely you have some recollection of the topic? [SEP] Look, Joe and I have countless conversations. I can't recall every single detail of every discussion. But the underlying point, and I think this is what Joe was trying to convey, is that when you're dealing with challenges of this scale, there's always a degree of uncertainty. I wouldn't put a number on it, but the reality is, no single action is going to solve everything. We're in uncharted waters. Economists generally agree on the path forward, the need for a substantial recovery package, a combination of tax cuts and investments. But even if we do all that perfectly, we still have to fix the financial system, get the banks lending again, address the housing crisis, and establish a regulatory system to prevent future crises. These are all massive, complex undertakings. So, I'm not sure if that's what Joe was referring to, but it's a good opportunity to talk about the bigger picture.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, on the matter of the potential bill granting voting rights to DC and another seat to Utah, are you saying this is the first you're hearing about it? [SEP] Honestly, yes. It hasn't crossed my desk. I'm focused on other priorities right now.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. And—you did, during the virtual summit? [SEP] Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, given Prime Minister Netanyahu's recent backtracking on the two-state solution, what concrete actions could he take to convince you of his sincerity in pursuing peace? Also, what's your response to allegations of Israeli spying on the Iran talks? And President Ghani, what makes you hopeful about reconciliation talks with the Taliban, and do you want the U.S. involved? [SEP] Regarding the spying allegations, I won't comment on intelligence matters publicly. On the Iran deal, we've briefed Congress and our allies, including Israel. Any agreement will be transparent. If it prevents Iran from getting a nuclear weapon, it's good for everyone. If not, no deal. On Israeli-Palestinian relations, it's about what both sides believe is possible. Prime Minister Netanyahu said no Palestinian state under his watch. He later added conditions, but they seem impossible. It's not about instant statehood, but a framework for hope. His words make that hard to see. My evaluation is about the future of Israeli-Palestinian relations, not our commitment to Israel's security. We must be honest about the slim chances of a two-state solution. This isn't personal; it's a policy difference with big consequences. We want two states; Prime Minister Netanyahu doesn't. We need to work through this.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your economic package, why introduce it now during a heated campaign? Critics say it's purely political. And why avoid the word 'stimulus' for the infrastructure spending, given the original stimulus's unpopularity? [SEP] When I took office, we faced an economy on the brink. We implemented a plan that economists say averted a depression. A third of that plan was tax cuts. We haven't waited until now. We've cut taxes for small businesses eight times in 18 months. These actions have made a difference. Three million people have jobs that wouldn't exist otherwise. The economy would be worse. But we're not where we need to be. So, what else can we do? Our proposals have historically had bipartisan support: R&D tax credit, accelerated business depreciation. On infrastructure, we're ramping up the highway bill. We're rebuilding America. We'll pay for it by ending tax breaks for companies shipping jobs overseas. These are commonsense approaches. Historically, Republicans and Democrats agree on infrastructure and R&D. Let's get it done. It's not that the previous stimulus didn't work. It did. It just hasn't done enough. We have a long way to go.
label: Deflection

sentence: Given the support the Kurds provided in defeating ISIS, what specific steps will your administration take to assist them beyond the Syrian border? [SEP] Let me just reiterate, we are actively engaged in assessing the situation. Discussions are ongoing, have been ongoing. The crucial point is the Kurds were instrumental in the fight against ISIS, a fact we acknowledge.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Obama, with President Hollande visiting Moscow soon, what concrete outcomes are you hoping for regarding military coordination with Russia, especially given the current tensions? What assurances are you seeking to prevent similar incidents in the future? [SEP] My hope is that President Hollande can convey the urgency of the situation to President Putin. We need Russia to understand that its actions in Syria are not helping the fight against ISIS. We need a political solution in Syria, and Russia needs to be part of that solution, not an obstacle. We're looking for assurances that Russia will focus its efforts on ISIS and that it will respect the airspace of its neighbors. Only then can we have real military coordination.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, some argue that focusing on economic issues alone ignores the broader social and cultural concerns that are important to many women. How do you address those concerns? [SEP] Well, we're not just focused on economics. We're focused on creating a society where everyone has the opportunity to succeed, regardless of their background or circumstances. That includes addressing issues like equal pay, access to healthcare, and protection from discrimination. We believe that when women are empowered, families are stronger, and communities are more vibrant.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. And if I may, could I ask the other question, because I think it might get an interesting response. You, last May, passed a milestone in that you are now were President longer when the country was at war than your predecessor, George W. Bush. And if you complete your Presidency, as you will, with troops in Afghanistan, Syria, and Iraq, you will be the only two-term President in American history to have served with the country at war. And I wonder, given the way that you ran for office and the aspirations you brought into office, how you feel about that reality? And then, a second follow-up on that: Should the American people simply resign themselves to living in a state of perpetual war, even if that war is not the all-out war that we think of in the 20th century? [SEP] Okay. That was an interesting question so—first of all, with respect to the State Department, I am concerned. And the challenge that we've got is primarily driven by the changing nature of how information flows. Look, the advent of e-mail and texts and smartphones is just generating enormous amounts of data. Now, it is hugely convenient. It means that in real time I'm getting information that some of my predecessors might not have gotten for weeks.But what it also is doing is creating this massive influx of information on a daily basis, putting enormous pressure on the Department to sort through it, classify it properly, figure out what are the various points of entry because of the cyber-attack risks that these systems have, knowing that our adversaries are constantly trying to hack into these various systems. If you overclassify, then all the advantages of this new information suddenly go away because it's taking too long to process. And so we've been trying to think about this in a smart way. And I think Secretary Kerry has got a range of initiatives to try to get our arms around this. It reflects a larger problem in Government. We just recently, for example—I just recently signed a bill about FOIA requests, Freedom of Information Act requests, that built on a number of reforms that we've put in place. We're processing more Freedom of Information Act requests and doing so faster than ever before. The problem is the volume of requests has skyrocketed. The amount of information that answers the request has multiplied exponentially.So, across Government, you're seeing this problem. And it's a problem in terms of domestic affairs. It becomes an even bigger problem when you're talking about national security issues. So it is something that we're going to have to take care of.With respect to reflections on war, when I came into office, we had 180,000 troops in Iraq and Afghanistan. Today, we have a fraction of that. They are not involved in active combat situations, but are involved in train, advise, and assist situations, other than the direct attacks that we launch against ISIL in conjunction with the Iraq Government and the Syrian Government [partners on the ground in Syria; White House correction.].So, in some ways, Mark, I think you'd recognize that our military operations today in Iraq and Afghanistan are fundamentally different than the wars that we were engaged in when I came into office. But I think you are making an important point, which is when we are dealing with nonstate actors, and those nonstate actors are located in countries with limited capacity, our ultimate goal is to partner with those countries so that they can secure their borders and, themselves, eliminate these terrorist threats.But as we've seen in Afghanistan, for example, that takes some time. The Afghans are fighting. They are much more capable now than they were when I came into office. But they still need support, because it's really tough territory, and it's a really poor country with really low literacy rates and not much experience in things that we take for granted like logistics.And so we have an option of going in, taking out Al aida, pulling out, potentially then seeing a country crumble under the strains of continued terrorist activity or insurgency, and then going back in. Or we can try to maintain a limited partnership that allows them to continue to build their capacity over time and selectively take our own actions against those organizations that we know are trying to attack us or our allies.Because they're nonstate actors, it's very hard for us ever to get the satisfaction of McArthur and the Emperor meeting and a war officially being over. AI was defeated in the sense that we were able to execute a transition to a democratically elected Iraqi Government. But for all of our efforts and the incredible courage and bravery and sacrifice of our troops, the political structure there was still uneven. You had continued Sunni resentments, continued de-Baathification, and as a consequence, those vestiges of AI were able to reconstitute themselves, move into Syria as Syria began to engage in civil war, rebuild, and then come back in.Some have argued that this is the reason why we should have never pulled out of Iraq, or at least, we should have left some larger presence there. Of course, the problem was that we didn't have an Iraqi Government that wanted them, unlike Afghanistan, where we've been invited. And it's very difficult for us to—for me, as Commander in Chief, to want to put our troops in a precarious situation where they're not protected. So I think what we've been trying to do, what I've been trying to do, is to create an architecture, a structure—and it's not there yet—that emphasizes partnerships with countries, emphasizes building up fragile states, resolving internal conflicts wherever we can, trying to do as much as we can through our local partners, preserving the possibility, the necessity to take strikes ourselves against organizations or individuals that we know are trying to kill Americans or Belgians or French or Germans, combine that with much more effective intelligence gathering. But it becomes more of a hybrid approach to national security. And that I do think is probably going to be something that we have to continue to grapple with for years to come.The good news is that there are fewer wars between states than ever before and almost no wars between great powers. And that's a great legacy of leaders in the United States and Europe and Asia, after the cold war—or after the end of World War II that built this international architecture. That's worked. And we should be proud of that and preserve it.But this different kind of low-grade threat, one that's not an existential threat, but can do real damage and real harm to our societies and creates the kind of fear that can cause division and political reactions—we have to do that better. We have to continually refine it.So, for example, the reason that I put out our announcement about the civilian casualties resulting from drone attacks—understanding that there are those who dispute the numbers—what I'm trying to do there is to institutionalize a system where we begin to hold ourselves accountable for this different kind of national security threat and these different kinds of operations.And it's imperfect, still. But I think we can get there. And what I can say honestly is, whether we're talking about how the NSA operates or how drone strikes operate or how we're partnering with other countries or my efforts to close Guantanamo, that by the end of my Presidency—or banning torture—by the end of my Presidency, I feel confident that these efforts will be on a firmer legal footing, more consistent with international law and norms, more reflective of our values and our ethics. But we're going to have more work to do. It's not perfect, and we have to wrestle with these issues all the time.And as Commander in Chief of the most powerful military in the world, I spend a lot of time brooding over these issues. And I'm not satisfied that we've got it perfect yet. I can say honestly, it's better than it was when I came into office.Thank you very much, everybody. Thank you, Poland.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the fight against ISIL, some suggest a strategy of containment. Do you believe containment is sufficient, or is complete annihilation the only acceptable outcome? Furthermore, considering the limitations of airstrikes, what role do you envision for ground forces, particularly the Free Syrian Army, in achieving the complete destruction of ISIL in Syria? [SEP] Containment is simply not an option when dealing with an organization that disregards borders, spreads chaos, displaces populations, commits atrocities, and enslaves women. Our objective must be to dismantle them entirely. Think back to Al Qaeda in the FATA; we pushed them back, systematically degraded their capabilities, limited their operational scope, reduced their territory, and eliminated their leadership. Over time, their ability to conduct large-scale attacks diminished. Now, will remnants still exist, hiding and plotting? Of course. We'll hunt them down, just as we do with Al Qaeda remnants in the FATA, al-Shabaab elements in Somalia, or any terrorist worldwide. But we aim to dismantle this network, this force controlling vast territory, so they can no longer threaten us. That's our goal, and I'm encouraged by the unanimous support from our allies. Regarding Syria, we won't deploy U.S. ground troops to control conflict zones. It's unnecessary. We need effective partners on the ground to push back against ISIL. The moderate coalition is a viable option; we have experience with them. They've been outgunned, so we'll support them more effectively. Remember, when U.S. forces put ISIL on the defensive, ground forces can achieve remarkable results, even if initially outmatched. This strategy is evolving, and we'll consult with allies and regional partners. Ultimately, we'll do what's necessary to ensure ISIL doesn't threaten the U.S. or our allies. Next question.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. And then, my final question. [Laughter] Republicans have made it clear that if they do take control of the House, that they want to launch a raft of investigations on day one into your handling of Afghanistan, the border. They want to look into some of your Cabinet officials. They want to investigate you. They may even want to investigate your son. What's your message to Republicans who are considering investigating your family and, particularly, your son Hunter's business dealings? [SEP] Lots of luck in your senior year, as my coach used to say. []Look, I think the American public want us to move on and get things done for them. And, you know, I heard that there were—it was reported—whether it's accurate or not, I'm not sure—but it was reported many times that Republicans were saying, and the former President said, How many times are you going to impeach Biden? You know, impeachment proceedings against Biden—I mean, I think the American people will look at all of that for what it is. It's just almost comedy. I mean, it's—but you know, look, I can't control what they're going to do. All I can do is continue to try to make life better for the American people.Okay. Phil. Phil Mattingly, CNN.
label: Implicit

sentence: In what context are we measuring 'equality'? [SEP] Elaborate on your premise.
label: Clarification

sentence: Are you optimistic that this law will be approved in your first year in office? [SEP] We're doing everything we can to move this forward quickly. I'm being very proactive on all fronts. Ultimately, the legislative schedule is not my decision. We'll be working closely with congressional leaders to see what we can achieve.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, the NSA task force head on Edward Snowden suggested a conversation about amnesty. Given the sensitivity, what's your take on this 'trial balloon,' and what specific circumstances might lead to a plea deal or amnesty? Many Americans feel Snowden exposed surveillance overreach and shouldn't be deemed a criminal. [SEP] Look, it's a tricky situation. Snowden's got an indictment hanging over his head, and that puts it squarely in the AG's and the courts' ballpark. I can't really get into the nitty-gritty of the case itself. But, I will say this: we needed to have a serious conversation about surveillance, no doubt. But the way Snowden did it? Big mistake. It hurt our intelligence big time. We're talking about a country that actually respects the rule of law and privacy, unlike some others. Now, these other countries, they're using Snowden's stuff to deflect from their own shady practices. So, yeah, the debate's important, but let's not forget the damage done. The courts will sort out the Snowden thing.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. So is that a yes, sir? You're willing to sign a budget that doesn't have those two provisions? [SEP] No, I--what I said was I haven't seen yet what provisions are in there. The bottom line is, is that I want to see health care, energy, education, and serious efforts to reduce our deficit--our budget deficit. And there are going to be a lot of details that are still being worked out, but I have confidence that we're going to be able to get a budget done that's reflective of what needs to happen in order to make sure that America grows.Chip Reid [CBS News].Federal Deficit/Balancing the
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, can you estimate the percentage of asylum seekers who you believe legitimately qualify for asylum in the United States? [SEP] I won't get into percentages. We are a nation of laws, and we must have borders. Without borders, we don't have a country. I've been watching the caravan for weeks. Mexico has very strict immigration laws. It started with over a thousand people, now down to around a hundred, traveling through Mexico. Mexico is a large country. We're dealing with the border with terrible laws. We need changes in Congress and a wall. Even a less-than-perfect wall makes a difference. We're sending National Guard troops to the border, which is making a difference. We need legal changes. Catch-and-release is absurd. We need a change in the law.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Senator McConnell suggests minimal communication between you since your inauguration, alleging a significant shift to the left on your part. Do you share this perspective? Has your administration abandoned bipartisan efforts? [SEP] Well, I wouldn't say that. I've reached out to Republicans on numerous occasions. We're collaborating on various initiatives, like boosting our domestic computer chip production. Of course, I'd prefer to have Republican backing, but the fact is, Republican voters are on board with my agenda. If Senator McConnell believes my policies are excessively liberal, perhaps he should re-evaluate his own party's position, given the widespread support for my initiatives.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. ——in order to get a deal done? What do you need to see at this point to get that deal past the finish line? [SEP] We're looking for a complete deal. I'm not looking for a partial deal. China has been starting to buy our agricultural product—if you noticed over the last week—and actually some very big purchases.But that's not what I'm looking for; we're looking for the big deal. We've taken it to this level. We're taking in billions and billions of dollars of tariffs. China has devalued their currency and they're putting out a lot of money into their economy. And they have a very bad economy right now and I don't want them to have a bad economy. But it's the worst in they say 57 years. Two weeks ago it was the worst in 22 years. Now it's 57 years and it's only going to get worse. Their supply chain is being broken up very badly.And companies are leaving because they can't pay the 25—soon to go to 30—percent tariff. And we have 30 percent very shortly on $250 billion. We have another tariff at a slightly smaller number as you know on other—on about 300 billion dollars' worth of goods and products.So they would like to do something. As you know we're talking a little bit this week talking a lot next week. And then top people are going to be speaking the week following. But I'm not looking for a partial deal; I'm looking for a complete deal.
label: Explicit

sentence: Is their position truly at risk? [SEP] They're doing a tremendous job, really tremendous. We're looking into it very closely, the closest. We'll have a definitive answer, the most definitive, in approximately one week.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. First a quick follow-up. You've made this very public invitation to Kim Jong Un. Will it be a bad sign if he doesn't show up? [SEP] No. Of course I thought of that because I know if he didn't everybody is going to say Oh he was stood up by Chairman Kim. No I understood that. It's very hard to—he follows my Twitter.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. This is on, right? [SEP] Yes, it's on. I can hear you.
label: Explicit

sentence: In your first year, why such a strong push to move the country so far to the left? [SEP] I reject that characterization. I don't see my policies as being 'far to the left.' Investing in COVID relief, infrastructure, and working families – how is that radical? These are common-sense measures to help people and grow the economy. You guys have been trying to label me as a socialist, a Bernie Sanders type. I'm a mainstream Democrat, and my record shows it. The overwhelming support I get from Democrats in the Senate confirms that.
label: Dodging

sentence: Senator Leahy is pushing for a truth and reconciliation committee to investigate the Bush administration's actions, saying we need to 'read the page' before turning it. Do you support this idea, and will you rule out prosecuting Bush administration officials? [SEP] I haven't seen the details of Senator Leahy's proposal, so I can't give you a firm opinion. I've said that my administration will operate with the understanding that we do not torture, that we respect the Geneva Conventions, and that we uphold the rule of law while aggressively pursuing terrorists who threaten us. I believe these principles can coexist. My view is that nobody is above the law, and if there are clear instances of wrongdoing, people should be prosecuted like any other citizen. But, generally speaking, I'm more interested in looking ahead than looking back. I want to unite everyone, including all the members of the intelligence community who have done things the right way and have been working hard to protect America. I'll review Senator Leahy's proposal, but my overall goal is to ensure we move forward in the right direction.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, you've been associated with QAnon by some of your supporters. Do you disavow this conspiracy theory, which claims you're secretly battling a satanic cult? [SEP] I don't know much about it, but I can say this: We're fighting for the American people. We're fighting against the radical left who want to destroy our country. We're fighting for freedom and democracy. That's what we're all about.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: So, you're saying he wasn't invited, sir? [SEP] I haven't a clue. I'm not the one who puts together the invite list. I do know they are a well-oiled machine, and they have a very strong relationship, and that is what is important.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, beyond condemning the ad, what specific actions will your administration take to counter what you perceive as unfair or inaccurate portrayals of military leaders in the media or political discourse? [SEP] We'll continue to highlight the incredible work and dedication of our military personnel. We'll use every opportunity to share their stories and ensure their voices are heard. We'll also call out instances of unfair or inaccurate reporting and challenge those who seek to undermine their service. Ultimately, it's about ensuring that the public has a clear and accurate understanding of the sacrifices they make.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, should the American public be concerned about the August 2nd deadline? [SEP] Listen, I'm trying not to engage in fear-mongering here. I'm the President. August 2nd is a significant date, but there's no reason we can't resolve this. The options are clear: spending cuts, defense adjustments, healthcare reforms, tax loophole closures. Congress needs to act. This isn't a technical issue; it's a matter of political will. And, you know, my kids are always on top of their schoolwork.
label: General

sentence: Q. Dr. Fauci. Okay? [SEP] Right. Better.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Good afternoon, President Bush and Prime Minister. And I thought that this summit would be the—would—actually Plan Mexico would come out of this, the combination of three governments to combat the effects of drug trafficking. What is the obstacle? What is it causing the delay? Why don't the societies of each country know what this plan is about? And can you actually confirm the support of the United States to Mexico? Apparently, it will increase tenfold, and the levels will be similar to Colombia. We hear very often that the United States wants to take part in this situation against drugs, this war on drugs, and we see it very clearly in Mexico. Now, what is it all about? Could you tell us? [SEP] Man! [] ! [] We discussed a common strategy to deal with a common problem, and that is narcotrafficking and violence on our border. First, let me say that in order to develop an effective, common strategy requires—there needs to be serious consultations between our respective governments. It's one thing to say, we're interested in working together, it's another thing to develop a package on both sides of the border that will be effective in dealing with the problem. That's what our people expect us to do. They expect us to see a problem and to develop an effective strategy to deal with that problem. President Calderon and I met in Mexico, and we had a serious discussion to get this initiative on the table. This is an interim meeting, a meeting for us to make sure that the strategy that's being developed is— will be effective. And so we reviewed where we are in the process.The United States is committed to this joint strategy to deal with a joint problem. I would not be committed to dealing with this if I wasn't convinced that President Calderon had the will and the desire to protect his people from narcotraffickers. He has shown great leadership and great strength of character, which gives me good confidence that the plan we'll develop will be effective. And the fundamental question is, what can we do together to make sure that the common strategy works? And that's where we are in the discussions right now.There's all kinds of speculation about the size of the package, this, that, and the other. All I can tell you is, the package, when it's developed, will be robust enough to achieve a common objective, which is less violence on both sides of the border and to deal with narcotrafficking. And we both have responsibilities. And that's what the package is entailed to develop. It's to develop how do we share our joint responsibilities.It's in our interests that this program go forward. You mentioned Plan Colombia; this is not like Plan Colombia. This is different from Plan Colombia. This is a plan that says, we've got an issue on our own border. We share a border, and therefore, it's a joint program that will mean—that won't mean U.S. armed presence in your country. Mexico is plenty capable of handling the problem. And the question is, is there any way for us to help strengthen the effort? And so that's what we're studying.And I can't give you a definitive moment when the plan will be ready, but we're working hard to get a plan ready. And it's a plan that, once it's proposed and out there, I strongly urge the United States Congress to support. It's in our interests, it's in the U.S. interests that we get this issue solved. Thank you, President Bush, for your comments and also for the question, because this allows us to emphasize the fact that—well, the President has already said, it's a common strategy to combat, in a coordinated way, a common problem. Drug trafficking and violence that's associated to drug trafficking, which is particularly evident on the border between the U.S. and Mexico, cannot be dealt with in an isolated way. It has to be confronted by, dealt with by the people and by the governments that are directly affected by this scourge. And it requires a variety, a multiplicity of actions carried out by society, by governments, in other words, enforcement activities against criminals, preventive activities, protective activities, prevention and treatment of addictions with the young.Now, I agree with President Bush; it's very important to reduce—well, to have clear policies to reduce the consumption patterns in terms of drugs, including Mexico, because this is a main cause of the problem that we're facing.Now, last week, for example, last week, three Federal policemen were murdered in Mexico—Mexican policemen, that is—and they were tortured in a very cowardly way. And those Mexican policemen are fully committed towards the Government to free the young Mexicans from drugs and to free Mexican society from slavery on the part of organized crime based on money and technology. And I don't want any—not one single Mexican policeman to have a logistical disadvantage when facing these criminals. I don't want my Government to be responsible for any omission, any legal omission within a legal framework that would have been directed towards defeating these criminals.So this is a common strategy because it means that the U.S. will do its part and Mexico will do its part. Now, what do we want the U.S. to do—to carry out—have greater surveillance along the border. We are seeing high-powered weapons into Mexico, and we know that we can do much more than we're doing at this point in time. I know that drugs go from Mexico to the U.S. Both of us have to agree so that there is surveillance, efficient surveillance, that is, on both sides of the border. We are facing mafias that are working on both sides of the border. That is quite clear to us. And I think that we will not be acting in an efficient way as long as they have a coordinated strategy and we don't. In other words, they're coordinated on both sides of the border; we are not.So I would like to introduce into the— well, we have to be respectful of our legislation, our respective legislations. I would want to create a strategy in order to defeat this scourge. And that requires a variety of instruments, strategies, exchange of intelligence, exchange of technology. It also means that we have to keep in mind issues of sovereignty. I told President Bush, though, we did not want to have U.S. soldiers working in our country, as has happened in other countries. I know that that's typical, of course. But we've said this very clearly, we put forth this very clearly, and in the framework of our own legislations, we will find a way out.And I would also wonder what the men and women are thinking now, those who are suffering from crime, how scared are they, what's the degree of their fear that has led these groups to be so powerful, to grow so much. And they've essentially taken power in their area of operation. We have developed an aggressive policy to combat organized crime, and I haven't hesitated to use our forces to recover the areas. We've taken about 10,000 drug traffickers to jail, many weapons, 50-millimeter cannons, grenades capable of bringing down aircraft.And I think—so I cannot send the Mexican policemen to combat this situation with their hands tied. So I have to answer to the Mexican people in order to preserve their security, and I will do so without abusing human rights and without distorting Mexican legislation. I will respect Mexican legislation fully. But I am calling upon my neighbor in order to act in a coordinated way, because it's a situation we both have to face. It's a problem that affects two countries, and only together will we be able to solve it.There are several causes. It involves several joint responsibilities. And the action, therefore, has to be shared, within the legal framework. What's the scope of this strategy? I cannot tell you now; we cannot tell you now. We're just exchanging assessments, needs, assessing the situation and making it clear what the rules are for each country.We will have a strategy—I think it's possible—but we will not be able to come up with it until we finish our discussions and negotiations, which, by nature, are very complex. But in the end, that is what we're trying to combat. And it's a problem that's affecting Mexican citizens as well as U.S. nationals. This is an example. We are all sovereign nations, that is quite true, but we are not isolated problems according to our own sovereignty. We have shared problems—for example, drug trafficking. This is a good example. It begins in a country in the Americas or in the Caribbean, but the consequences are seen in the streets in Canada. And we have to discuss these problems. We have to compare our strategies, and sometimes we have to work hand in hand.[.]Once again, this is a perfect example of why we meet. We're sovereign countries, but problems are not—problems don't limit themselves to the boundaries of our countries. Drug trafficking is a perfect example. These problems may originate in some of the countries of Latin America or the Caribbean, but the problems are felt on the streets and the communities of Canada. And that's why we meet to discuss; that's why we meet to compare strategies; that's why we, from time to time, have to engage in shared action.Let me just say one other thing, if I can, about the drug trade, because indirect reference was made to Colombia. Canada has undertaken negotiations of a trade agreement with Colombia. We have a Government in Colombia that wants to share in the benefits of free and open markets. We don't need to have a trade agreement to have a drug trade with Colombia. The drug traffickers aren't going to wait for our parliaments or our congresses to pass a trade agreement in order to have a drug trade. But if we want to have other opportunities for the people of Colombia and mutual development and shared prosperity, we've got to move forward on these kinds of initiatives. And that's why the Government of Canada is committed to working with Colombia and getting a trade deal.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President—[inaudible]—Times. Thank you, Mr. President. For the phase two China trade deal, we expect—do you expect human rights in Hong Kong to be a part of the discussion? [SEP] We are discussing that already, yes. We would like to see if we can do something. But again, we're doing a trade deal, and it's a very big deal. Phase one is done. Phase two is being discussed.We are discussing aspects of your question, yes.

sentence: Mr. President, given the complexities of the Syrian conflict, with multiple actors and competing interests, how confident are you that a unified coalition against ISIL is even possible? Are there irreconcilable differences that will prevent effective cooperation? [SEP] It's certainly a challenge, but we're committed to working with all parties who share our goal of defeating ISIL. We're engaged in intensive diplomatic efforts to bridge the divides and find common ground. We believe that a unified front is essential to defeating this barbaric organization.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Well, I should actually know what— how to hold a microphone, but thank you. President—to you, Mr. Sarkozy, it would appear that the building and shaping of Europe has been seriously shaken yesterday by the Irish no. In fact, some have called for the ratification procedure to be suspended. Can this not be the case? And secondly, do you want your Presidency, the French Presidency to be one which, as you called for, continues to push Europe forward? And do you not think that the Irish no is going to hinder this? [SEP] Well, it's going to make things more difficult, but when you're a head of state and when the bubble— you take over the Presidency of the Union, if you like easy jobs, then you should step down straightaway.Now, the Irish no is a political reality. It's a fact; it's happened. But the issue is not whether we like or not. It's a fact; we have to live with it. The Irish people said what they had to say, and we have to accept that. Now, having said that, we, with Angela Merkel, believe that we have to continue with the ratification process, because at this stage, 18 European states have ratified the treaty. We have to continue doing so, and that is Gordon Brown's intention, as he explained to me yesterday over the telephone, so that this Irish hiccup not become a major crisis.So, despite that, let's continue to ratify. But at the same time, we have to put our heads together, all of us. It is no coincidence, it is no surprise to a certain extent— in fact, I spoke yesterday with the Irish , the Irish Prime Minister. A lot of Europeans do not understand how we are shaping Europe right now and building Europe, and we have to take account of that. And we have to do so very fast. We have to change our way of building Europe.The idea of a European construct, it was one of the most wonderful ideas that the founding fathers had some half a century ago. We are not allow—we shouldn't sabotage it. But perhaps we should do it differently. Europe was set up to protect, and yet it worries so many Europeans. We can't not take account of this. We have to do so, and we have to do so now. So I have every intention of taking initiatives. I'm thinking, for instance, of a European immigration policy. I'm thinking of a European response to this endless increase in oil prices. It seems to me that we have a duty to be more effective and look at what the daily lives of our citizens—fellow citizens— look like. And I take the Irish no as a call for us to do things differently and do things better.Now, of course, it's not going to simplify the work and the task of the French President—Presidency of the European Union, but—— Olivier [Olivier Knox, Agence France-Presse]. Tossing a bone to somebody who's got a French name. [] Might want to use the mike, Olivier.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Are we talking about a hard Brexit scenario here? [SEP] Or a heartbreaking one, perhaps?

sentence: Mr. President, considering the demise of cap-and-trade, will you now empower the EPA to regulate carbon emissions, and do you have any second thoughts about the compromises you made to pass the Affordable Care Act, even if they weakened the legislation? [SEP] Well, let me be clear: Providing healthcare for families is essential. But the legislative process was challenging, and I regret that it wasn't more transparent. As for the EPA, we need to find bipartisan solutions on energy and climate. Cap-and-trade was just one option. We're exploring all possibilities to address this issue without damaging our economy.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. President Obama, could you confirm whether the blind Chinese dissident Chen Guangcheng is under U.S. protection in Beijing? And how do you foresee that situation being resolved? Would the United States grant him asylum if he asked for it?And, Prime Minister Noda, how likely do you think it is that North Korea will carry out a third nuclear test? How would Japan respond to such a test? And what would you like the U.S. to do to respond? [SEP] Obviously, I'm aware of the press reports on the situation in , but I'm not going to make a statement on the issue. What I would like to emphasize is that every time we meet with , the issue of human rights comes up. It is our belief that not only is that the right thing to do because it comports with our principles and our belief in freedom and human rights, but also because we actually think will be stronger as it opens up and liberalizes its own system.We want to be strong, and we want it to be prosperous. And we're very pleased with all the areas of cooperation that we've been able to engage in. But we also believe that that relationship will be that much stronger and will be that much more prosperous and strong as you see improvements on human rights issues in that country.I know it wasn't directed at me, but I'll just make a quick statement around North Korea. This was a topic of extensive discussion between myself and Our consultation throughout the failed missile launch was, I think, reflective of how important our alliance is not just to our two countries, but to the region as a whole. And what I've tried to do since I came into office is to make sure that the North Koreans understand that the old pattern of provocation that then gets attention and somehow insists on the world purchasing good behavior from them, that that pattern is broken.And what we've said is, is that the more you engage in provocative acts, the more isolated you will become, the stronger sanctions will be in place, the more isolated you will be diplomatically, politically, and commercially. And so although we can't anticipate--and I don't want to hypothesize on what might happen in the coming months--I think Pyongyang is very clear that the United States, Japan, South Korea, other countries in the region are unified in insisting that it abide by its responsibilities, abide by international norms, and that they will not be able to purchase anything from further provocative acts. With regard to North Korea, between myself and President Obama earlier we--with regard to the so-called launch of satellite--the missile launch--we share the view that it undermines the efforts of the various countries concerned to achieve resolution through dialogue.Now, in the latest round of missile launch, they also conducted a nuclear test, which means that there is a great possibility they will conduct a nuclear test. And I believe the international community as a whole, together, will need to call for restraint on the part of D.P.R.K. And more specifically, I believe the measures incorporated in the recent U.N. Security Council chairman's statement need to be complied with. And among Japan, the U.S., and Korea, as well as and Russia, we need to communicate with each other fully and also call--stress that 's role continues to be very important and cooperate with while also maintaining close coordination with the United States. And we shared this view with And let me ask Mr. Imaichi of TBS, from Japan, to ask a question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. But surely you have some internal projections, Mr. President? [SEP] We have various models, yes. But releasing those publicly would only fuel speculation and anxiety. It's more important to focus on the steps we're taking to get people back to work.
