sentence:
Given the recent election results, what message do you believe the American people were sending? And do you see an opportunity to adjust course before similar decisions are made in Europe? [SEP] I believe Americans understand the interconnectedness of the world and that there's no going back. They recognize the need for dynamic careers, potentially involving career changes, further education, or retraining.

Americans are ready for this, but they want fair rules. Surveys show that most Americans still support trade but are concerned about its fairness and equal access to markets. They worry about a race to the bottom in wages.

I argued, unsuccessfully, that the TPP trade deal strengthened workers' and environmental rights, leveling the playing field for American workers and businesses. However, it's a complex argument when people remember plant closures and offshoring.

This election reflected a desire for the course correction you mentioned. Messages about stopping immigration surges and avoiding unfair trade deals resonated. As we govern, we need orderly and lawful immigration, which benefits our economy by keeping it young and dynamic. Entrepreneurs and risk-takers contribute to America's success.

Eliminating trade deals with Mexico, for example, isn't simple due to global supply chains. Auto plants rely on parts from Mexico. Progressives need to address concerns by advocating for a higher minimum wage, stronger worker protections, and financial regulations.

We need to support trade that ensures fair labor practices and addresses inequality. This strategy will help people feel part of the global economy, not by isolating ourselves but by working together more effectively.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, you've neglected to address oil companies. Are you satisfied that American oil producers are exploiting all possible resources, including offshore? And concerning Iraq, will you finalize an interim agreement with Prime Minister Maliki regarding American operations, leaving a more comprehensive agreement to your successor? [SEP] Let's address Iraq first. We're currently negotiating a strategic framework agreement with the Iraqi government, encompassing diplomacy, economics, and justice. A key component is a security agreement outlining the transition to an overwatch mission, which includes training, logistical support, and special operations. To maintain our troop presence in Iraq, we require an agreement with the Iraqi government that grants operational authority and protects our personnel. This agreement must be in place before the year's end, unless the UN mandate is renewed. These are two distinct elements of the agreement, and we're pursuing both concurrently. Now, where were we?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. But do you have new specific proposals to get them off the sidelines and start hiring? [SEP] Well, I already discussed a couple with Chip that haven't been acted on yet. You're right that I made these proposals 2 months ago, but--or 3 months ago--but it was in the midst of a campaign season where it was doubtful that they were going to get a full hearing just because there was so much political noise going on.I think as we move forward, sitting down and talking to businesses, figuring out what exactly would help you make more investments that could create more jobs here in the United States, and listening hard to them--in a context where, maybe, Democrats and Republicans are together so we're receiving the same message at the same time--and then acting on that agenda could make a big difference.Matt Spetalnick of Reuters.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. And then, on—on one other note, on bipartisanship: Your old friend, Mitch McConnell, says you have only spoken to each other once since you took office and that you have moved far left since taking office. Do you see it the same way he does? Have you rejected bipartisanship? [SEP] No, I haven't at all. I've been meeting—when is the last time a President invited the opposite party down at least a half a dozen times to talk about issues? Everything from how we work—we're working with a group of 20 Members of the Senate right now and House on how we reestablish our ability to make computer chips and how we get ahead of the game, how we can work together. And we're working together on a bunch of things.But look, I know Mitch well; Mitch knows me well. I would expect Mitch to say exactly what he said. But this is a matter of making sure that—I would like Republican—elected Republican support, but what I know I have now is that I have electoral support from Republican voters. Republican voters agree with what I'm doing.And so, unless Mitch says the last thing I did is—the last piece of legislation is so far left—well, then he ought to a look at his party. Over 50 percent of them must be over that edge as well because they support what I did.Okay. Where am I here? Let me see.Kaitlan [Kaitlan Collins, CNN News].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the approaching conclusion of the war in Afghanistan, can you honestly say that the substantial human and financial investments have been worthwhile, considering the perceived shortcomings in achieving the original aims of reconstruction and democratization? And President Karzai, given the widespread concerns about corruption and governance in Afghanistan, do you still assert that foreign interference is the main cause, and are you fully committed to resigning from your position after the next elections? [SEP] We went into Afghanistan to get the people who attacked us on 9/11. We did that. We weakened Al-Qaeda. That was the mission. Now, Afghanistan is a tough place. But we've made progress. We're working with them to build a better future. As for Karzai, he's a strong leader, and we support him.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Madam Chancellor, Mr. President. First, a question addressed to you, Mr. President. There are—were a number of hopes in the world that were in a way shattered as regards your legislative term, for example, the closing down of Guantanamo or scrapping the death penalty throughout the whole of the United States, in all of the States. And now, as regards Asia and—are you singling out Germany because there's a big risk here? Or——And, Madam Chancellor, the Nobel Prize winner, Obama is waging a drone war also via Germany. And is he allowed to do that, according to German law? [SEP] Let me see if I understood your question properly. First question was related to policies back home, related to Guantanamo or the death penalty. And then you wanted to talk about drones, or did you just want to focus on the drone question? I just want to make sure that I'm responsive to your question. I guess I ought to answer on the drones. And Guantanamo, that was a question, I believe, addressed to you. . Okay. Well, it continues to be my policy that I want to close Guantanamo. It has been more difficult than I had hoped, in part because there's been significant resistance from Congress on this, and on some issues, I need congressional authorization.But about a month ago I gave a speech in which I said that I would redouble my efforts to do so. Because 9/11 happened, and we now have been involved in one form or another in a war for over a decade. One war, I think, in Afghanistan, was necessary. One war I disagreed with strongly. But in either case, there are dangers if we get on a perpetual war footing.The threat of terrorism remains real, and we have to be vigilant, and we have to take steps to protect ourselves, consistent with our values and consistent with international law. But we also have to guard against being so driven by fear that we are not changing the fabric of our society in ways that we don't intend and do not want for the future. I think closing Guantanamo is an example of us getting out of that perpetual war mentality.Some of thepeople at Guantanamo are dangerous. Some of them did bad things. But we cannot have a permanent outpost in which they're being held even as we're ending a war in Afghanistan that triggered some of these—the capture of some of these detainees in the first place.So I'm confident that we can continue to make progress on this front, although, you're right, it has not been as fast as I would have liked. One of the things you discover as a politician is, is that people don't always do exactly what you want. It's shocking. And then you have to keep on working at it.One thing with respect to drone policy: In that speech that I gave, I also addressed that issue of—that, the lethal targeting of identified terrorists. This also is a source of controversy. We have constrained it tightly. And as we defeat Al Qaida, we have to, I think, very carefully examine how these technologies are used. I can say, though, that we do not use Germany as a launching point for unmanned drones to go after counter—as part of our counterterrorism activities. And so I know that there have been some reports here in Germany that that might be the case. That is not. Let me complement by saying that the United States of America have bases here, they have soldiers here. They fulfill a very important function, particularly in the fight against terrorism. If I think of Ramstein, for example—and also supplies to soldiers, but also caring for wounded soldiers.We as allies, as members of NATO, stand shoulder to shoulder here. And we provide bases for our activities, and our work is based also on shared values. As I said, we exchange on—have exchanges on values. But I think it's good. I think it's the right thing to do for the United States of America to be present here with military bases in Germany. It's a normal thing within an alliance, and this is as it should be and as it will be and continue to be.
label: Implicit

sentence: Many argue that excessive consumer spending fueled the recent economic crisis. If your plan succeeds in boosting consumer spending, aren't we simply perpetuating the problem? Shouldn't we prioritize saving and debt reduction? [SEP] The root cause of the crisis wasn't simply consumer spending. It was reckless behavior by banks, taking on excessive risk with shaky assets. This led to a credit crunch, impacting businesses and creating widespread economic uncertainty. While I agree that our savings rate needs to improve, the immediate priority is to break the downward spiral. We need to stimulate demand and invest in long-term growth. This is crucial for stabilizing the budget and preventing further strain on social safety nets. Once the economy recovers, we can then focus on promoting more prudent financial habits.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you very much, Prime Minister and Mr. President. Laura Kuenssberg, BBC News. Mr. President, you seem rather to have changed your tune from what you said earlier this week, when you said that, on the current Brexit plan, that would probably kill the possibility of a trade deal with the U.K. Our countries are meant to have a special relationship, yet you publicly criticized the Prime Minister's policy and her personally for not listening to you this week. Is that really the behavior of a friend?And, Prime Minister, is it a problem for you that some of the things Mr. Trump has said about your Brexit plan are right? It will limit the possibilities of doing trade deals easily in the future. Can you also tell us how it felt for him to criticize you in the way he did in that interview? [SEP] Well, maybe I'll go first, because I didn't criticize the I have a lot of respect for the And unfortunately, there was a story that was done, which was generally fine, but it didn't put in what I said about the And I said tremendous things. And fortunately, we tend to record stories now, so we have it for your enjoyment if you'd like it. But we record when we deal with reporters. It's called fake news. You know, we solve a lot of problems with the good, old recording instrument.But what happens is that—look, the Prime Minister, as I really just said, she's going to make a decision as to what she's going to do. The only thing I ask of Theresa is that we make sure we can trade, that we don't have any restrictions, because we want to trade with the U.K., and the U.K. wants to trade with us. We're, by far, their biggest trading partner. And we have just a tremendous opportunity to double, triple, quadruple that.So if they're going a slightly different route—and I know they do want independence. It's going to be independence; it's just your definition. But if they're going to go a certain route, I just said that I hope you're going to be able to trade with the United States. I read reports where that won't be possible, but I believe after speaking with the Prime Minister's people and representatives and trade experts, it will absolutely be possible.So, based on that, I—and based on just trade in general, and our other relationship—which will be fine—but the trade is a little bit tricky. We want to be able to trade, and they want to be able to trade, and I think we'll be able to do that. Okay? And I think she's doing a terrific job, by the way.. Thank you, Mr. President. And just to confirm what the President just said, Laura, there will be no limit to the possibility of us doing trade deals around the rest of the world once we leave the European Union, on the basis of the agreement that was made here at Chequers and that I've put forward to the European Union. And just to be clear, that is an agreement that delivers on the Brexit vote that we had in 2016 here in the U.K., that delivers what I believe is at the forefront of people's mind when they were voting to leave the European Union.So at the end of these negotiations, we will ensure that free movement will come to an end. The jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice here in the U.K. will come to an end. The sending of vast sums of money every year to the EU will come to an end. We will come out of the Common Agricultural Policy. We will come out of the Common Fisheries Policy. And we will ensure, by not being in the Customs Union, that we are able to have an independent trade policy and do those trade deals around the world. And as you've heard from the President, the United States is keen for us. We're keen to work with them. And we will do a trade deal with them and with others around the rest of the world.Mr. President, would you like to select a person? Jonathan Swan, go ahead. /North Atlantic Treaty Organization
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, considering my affiliation with the New York Times, would it be possible for me to ask a question before my colleagues? [SEP] You're from... where exactly?
label: Clarification

sentence: So, Mr. President, if the court doesn't uphold your plan, do you have a backup plan? [SEP] Let me be clear: we have complete faith in the legal soundness of our position. We are confident that this will be over--that this will be upheld. Our legal team has meticulously reviewed every aspect, and we are prepared to vigorously defend it. That's not just my opinion, that's the opinion of a whole lot of constitutional law professors and academics and judges and lawyers who have examined this law, even if they're not particularly sympathetic to this particular piece of legislation or my Presidency.
label: Dodging

sentence: So, are you leaning towards withdrawing the troops, then? [SEP] Could you repeat that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Did you get any distance toward, sort of, what Kim's vision of denuclearization is? [SEP] Yes, we did. We did.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, you tweeted that Dr. Birx was taking bait from Speaker Pelosi. Could you elaborate, especially considering she was presenting factual data on the pandemic's current state? [SEP] We're handling things incredibly well, better than most nations, frankly. Look at the flare-ups happening in other countries – China, India, you name it. The media conveniently ignores that. I think Dr. Birx is a fine person, and I respect her, but Pelosi has been nasty to her. We've done an amazing job on ventilators, testing – over 60 million tests! Nobody else is even close. So, I think we're doing great.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with the 2020 election already on the horizon, can you confirm that Vice President Pence will be your running mate? [SEP] Well, I haven't actually popped the question yet, but I certainly hope so! Hey Mike, you gonna be my running mate? Stand up, Mike! Raise your right hand! Just kidding! Will you? Great! The answer is a resounding yes!
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Two questions. One, shifting back to your trip to the—to Asia. When you meet with President Xi Jinping of China, will you tell him that you're committed to defending Taiwan militarily? And what are you hoping to get out of this meeting that will make it a success? Are you willing to make any concessions to him? [SEP] Well, look, I'm not making—I'm not willing to make any fundamental concessions because what I—what I've told him in the beginning—and this is—we've—I've spent over 78, I think they told me, hours with him so far—67 in person, when I was Vice President. President Obama knew he couldn't spend time with the Vice President of another country, so I traveled 17,000 miles with them in China and around—and the United States. I've met with him many times.And I've told him: I'm looking for competition, not conflict. And so what I want to do with him when we talk is lay out what the—what kind of—what each of our red lines are, understand what he believes to be in the critical national interests of China, what I know to be the critical interests of the United States, and to determine whether or not they conflict with one another. And if they do, how to resolve it and how to work it out.And so—and the Taiwan doctrine has not changed at all from the very beginning—the very beginning. So I'm sure we'll discuss China, the—excuse me, Taiwan. And I'm sure we'll discuss a number of other issues, including fair trade and relationships relating to his relationship with other countries in the region.And so, at any rate—so there's a lot we're going to have to discuss.Do you want another question?
label: Implicit

sentence: Do we have any details on the perpetrator, specifically their sex and the weapon they employed? [SEP] I'm afraid I haven't been briefed on those specifics.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, are you suggesting that this alleged hacking is not surprising, given the current relationship with China? [SEP] Let's just say I'm not shocked. China has a long history of questionable behavior. We're watching them very closely, and we're taking steps to protect our intellectual property and our national security. But frankly, this is just par for the course with China.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, can you explain the anger many Democrats felt when the tax cut bill extended tax cuts for the wealthy? Are you contributing to this divide when you call these tax cuts 'morally inappropriate'? [SEP] I understand the frustration. I've said before, and I'll say it again: I don't think we can afford tax breaks for people who are already doing well. They were doing well when Bill Clinton was president. This will be a debate over the next few years. As soon as the new Congress is sworn in, we'll have to discuss how to balance our budget. That means cutting programs that don't work, but also being honest about paying for what's important. If we want to care for our veterans, we need to fund the doctors and facilities they need. If we want our children to succeed, we need to invest in education. If we want to stay competitive, we need to invest in basic research. We have to compare maintaining tax cuts for the wealthy versus spending on these priorities. I understand why some Democrats and even some Republicans think we could have done without that part of the tax package. But compromise means taking some things you don't like. The overall package was the right one to grow the economy and create jobs. There's no better antipoverty program than a growing economy, and no better deficit-reduction program either. If the economy had contracted, the choices would have been even tougher.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. ——got the Cleveland connection, so I appreciate that. You cited the Mayo Clinic and the Cleveland Clinics as models for the delivery of health care in the past. The Mayo Clinic, though, has some problems with the House proposal, saying they're not focused enough on patients and on results. What do you expect to achieve tomorrow by going to the Cleveland Clinic, which hasn't stated an opinion, and are you expecting some form of endorsement from the Cleveland Clinic? [SEP] I am not expecting an endorsement. The Cleveland Clinic is simply a role model for some of the kind of changes that we want to see. I think it's important to note that the Mayo Clinic was initially critical and concerned about whether there were enough changes in the delivery system and cost-saving measures in the original House bill. After they found out that we had put forward very specific mechanisms for this MedPAC idea, this idea of experts getting the politics out of health care and making decisions based on the best evidence out there, they wrote in their blog the very next day that, We actually think this would make a difference. Okay?All right, I tried to make that short so that Lynn Sweet would get her last question in.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with health officials expressing concerns about the inadequacy of testing for the coronavirus, why hasn't your administration implemented a more comprehensive testing program, similar to those in other countries? [SEP] Look, we're not going to overreact. We're testing those who need to be tested. We're not going to test everyone. That's just not necessary. This is not the end of the world. It's like the flu. People get sick, they get better. We're working on a vaccine. We're doing a great job. The media is trying to make this into a bigger deal than it is. We have it totally under control. We're the best at this. Nobody does it better than us.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, to be specific, what is the administration's target amount for these direct payments, and what assurances can you provide that these payments will not contribute to inflation or increase the national debt? [SEP] We're in discussions with various parties, exploring different avenues. I'm keen on a payroll tax cut and ensuring the well-being of our workers. We're negotiating with the Democrats, and we'll see where it leads. This is a transition, a transition to greatness. Next year will be exceptional, truly special. The third quarter is a transition, but the fourth quarter will show tremendous numbers. Next year, we'll see the kind of numbers we had before, perhaps even better, driven by pent-up demand.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Trump, given your commitment to a free and open Indo-Pacific, how do you reconcile that with your upcoming visit to China, a country that doesn't share those values? And Prime Minister Abe, did President Trump voice concerns about Japan's response to North Korean missile launches, and what assurances did you provide regarding Japan's defense posture? [SEP] Look, China's China, and we're the United States. We have a relationship, a business relationship. We're working on trade, making it much better for our country. As for Japan, they're a great ally. They're buying a lot of our equipment, the best equipment. They'll be ready. We're working together to keep the region safe. It's all about strength, and nobody's stronger than us.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Did you have contacts with other leaders in the Middle East? And when you appraised them for reforms, are you looking at other options where other leaders in the region can be supported to stay in power in the Middle East? [SEP] I'm in constant contact with leaders throughout the Middle East, and I've had a fairly consistent message to all of them: Number one, the United States believes in the right of peaceful protests and the ability of ordinary people to express their grievances to their government. And we oppose the use of violence in response to peaceful protests. So that's one clear message that we tried to send.The second message we've try to send is that it is in the interest of the entire region to reform itself: to reform itself both politically and economically so that the incredible talents of young people throughout that region can be tapped; so that the young man, whether he is in Sanaa or he's in Tripoli or she's in Cairo or Amman, that they know that if they work hard, if they are getting an education, that they have an opportunity to live a better life, that they can get a job that pays a good wage and supports their family, and that they can have the basic necessities of life, and that they have personal security and they have personal freedom.Now, each country is different, and so the evolution, the process towards that vision is going to differ in each country. But my consistent message to leaders in the region is that this process of change can be a great opportunity for the Middle East, because if you can tap into the talents of those young people, then you can start seeing the kind of economic growth in that region that you've started to see in other places in the world.And there's no reason why countries in the Middle East shouldn't have the same kind of growth rates that you're seeing in China and India. There's nothing inherent about the people in those countries that would prevent that. What's preventing it is the fact that for many decades you've seen a lack of opening up that allows you to take advantage of the global economy.And I think that, as I said, each country is going to be different, and it's going to ultimately be up to the people in those countries to determine the best form for them to seize this opportunity, but we should be on the side of those who want to seize this opportunity.Okay?
label: Explicit

sentence: Considering Cuba's claims that US intervention has hindered political progress, will your administration definitively end regime change efforts? And, given potential policy shifts, do you believe Hillary Clinton's nomination is still uncertain? [SEP] I'm retired from running elections, and I won't speculate on future races. That's your domain. Regarding Cuba, we aim to empower the Cuban people with freedom and self-determination, supporting civil society. Change within Cuba is inevitable, driven partly by generational shifts. While we still have serious concerns about the Cuban government's human rights record and regional activities, there are also areas for cooperation, such as healthcare. My message to President Castro was consistent: we will advocate for our values through persuasion. Cuba is not a direct threat to the US, and our priorities lie elsewhere, including combating ISIL, preventing Iranian nuclear proliferation, addressing conflicts in Yemen and Libya, countering Boko Haram, and addressing Russian aggression in Ukraine. Our approach is to partner with the region, promoting opportunity, prosperity, and security. Overly aggressive intervention often backfires, providing excuses for governance failures. Let's remove those excuses and engage constructively. Major Garrett.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you very much. We are the real Wall Street Journal.Mr. President, you tweeted earlier asking Virginia and New Jersey residents to vote. Democrat Terry McAuliffe is struggling in a State that you won by 10 points. Do you see—do you see his problems as a rebuke of your Presidency? And could this signal your real losses for Democrats in the midterms? [SEP] We're going to win. I think we're going to win in Virginia.And you know—you're reporting it being close—the race is very close. It's about who shows up, who turns out.And granted, I did win by a large margin, but the point of the matter is that I think that this is—this is going to be what we all knew from the beginning: This is going to be a tight race. And it is tight. And it's going to get down to turnout, and it's going to—my guess is that I'm going to be landing at 1 o'clock in the morning, East Coast time. That's probably about the time we'll be hearing what the final results are. I think we're going to win New Jersey as well.But look, you know, the off year is always unpredictable, especially when we don't have a general election going on at the same time. That's been the case all the—up and down, you know, for a long time, especially as Virginia has turned more and more blue.But having said that, I don't believe—and I've not seen any evidence that whether or not I am doing well or poorly, whether or not I've got my agenda passed or not is going to have any real impact on winning or losing.Even if we had passed my agenda, I wouldn't claim, We won because Biden's agenda passed. So—but I think it's a—I think it's going to be very close. I think it's going to get down to, as you all know, turnout. And I think that, based on what I have heard so far, it's awful hard for me to be prognosticating, which I don't like doing as President anyway, from overseas.But I think—I hope that every eligible voter in Virginia and New Jersey shows up and votes. And the more of them that do, the better off I think our chances are. And I think we're going—I think we're going to win. Okay?All right. NPR, Scott [Scott Horsley, NPR].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, after calling the 2010 midterms a 'shellacking,' what's your take on this election? Also, any updates on your immigration executive order? Will the election change your plans, will it be out before the lame duck session ends, and has its scope been reduced? [SEP] Well, as I said before, the Republicans had a good night. We're going to reach out to Mitch McConnell and John Boehner to see what their agenda is. Hopefully, we can find some common ground. The big message from this election, and from others recently, is: get things done. Focus on the concerns of regular Americans. Think about the single mom struggling with bills, the young person worried about college debt, the construction worker needing a job. If we focus on them, we can get things done. On immigration, I've always said I prefer Congress to act on comprehensive reform. We need to secure our borders, streamline legal immigration, and give those here illegally a chance to earn legal status. The Senate passed a bipartisan bill, which wasn't perfect but would improve things. I asked John Boehner to pass it in the House, but he couldn't. So, I'll use my executive authority to fix what I can, but I'll replace those actions with a bill from Congress if they pass one. That's a promise I made to the American people and to John Boehner. Before the end of the year, I'll take lawful executive actions to improve our immigration system and boost border security. I'll also talk to Republican and Democratic leaders about how to move forward. If they want to pass a bill, I'm ready to work with them. But I won't just wait. I've been patient and tried to work together, and I'll keep doing that. But in the meantime, let's improve things through executive action.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, American troops are dying, sectarian violence is escalating, and you foresee more casualties. Realistically, how much longer can this Iraq policy continue without tangible results? And are you optimistic about finding the missing soldiers? [SEP] We are doing everything possible to find the missing soldiers. General Petraeus and Secretary Gates are fully informed, and we are utilizing all available intelligence and troops. It is a top priority. The loss of life is devastating, but I sent more troops to stabilize the capital. We haven't even fully deployed them yet. General Petraeus presented a plan to Congress aimed at helping the Iraqi government secure its capital and reconcile. All troops will be in place by mid-June. The increased fighting is due to our troops entering new areas with the Iraqis. General Petraeus has requested until September to report back on progress. I want to see a different configuration in Iraq, but that requires securing the capital, which is why I followed General Petraeus's recommendations. I favor the Baker-Hamilton approach of embedding, training, guarding territorial integrity, and using Special Forces against Al Qaida. But we needed to increase troop levels to secure the capital, as I feared violence would spiral out of control. The timing of our actions will be decided by commanders on the ground, not politicians in Washington.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, despite your efforts to reverse the policies of the previous administration, many remain skeptical about the long-term sustainability of your agenda. What assurances can you offer to the international community that America's commitment to global leadership is enduring? [SEP] We're building something great here, something that will last. We're putting America first, but that doesn't mean we're abandoning the world. We're going to be a strong partner, but on our terms. Believe me, this is here to stay.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, the public is confused about the government's response to the coronavirus, from mask guidance to testing protocols. Why did you tell Jeff Zeleny you were satisfied with your team? Why aren't you making changes at the CDC or other agencies, given the confusing messaging? [SEP] The messages have been confusing because the scientists are learning more. They're evolving their understanding of what's needed. The CDC's communication capacity has been a focus. But the scientists are learning to communicate what they've observed. It's like polio – the guidance changed over time. This is a brand new virus, a new phenomenon. It's an unfolding story. But think about the speed with which we developed a vaccine. It saved lives. Did we get everything right? No.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, what advice would you give to young men in America today? [SEP] Well, it's a complicated situation, isn't it? It's a very big moment for our country, because you have a man who is very outstanding, but he's got very strong charges against him—probably charges that nobody is going to be able be—to prove. It's tough out there, folks. It's tough.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, given that this is your Postal Service, isn't it your responsibility to address its critical needs? [SEP] Look, we've got a great guy, Louis DeJoy, running the Postal Service. He's only been there a couple of months, but he's a brilliant businessman, very talented. He's working hard to fix the problems. But the Democrats are blocking funding for the Postal Service because they want to push this ridiculous all mail-in voting scheme. Absentee voting is fine, but universal mail-in voting is a disaster waiting to happen. Ballots are being lost, discarded, found in piles. It's going to be a catastrophe. Louis DeJoy is doing his best, but the Democrats are making it impossible. The Post Office has been losing billions for decades. And now they want to flood it with millions of ballots. Look at what happened in New York, Virginia, New Jersey – it's a mess. So, we'll see what happens. But universal mail-in voting is going to be a laughingstock. They're off by 20, 30 percent. And they want money to bail out poorly run, radical-left Democrat states. Look at Portland. We could fix it in an hour if they asked us. But they won't. So, if they can't get the money for universal mail-in voting, I don't see how they can do it.
label: Deflection

sentence: President López Obrador, you mentioned the dangers faced by migrants crossing Mexico. Beyond providing shelters and healthcare, what specific measures are being taken to combat human trafficking and protect migrants from criminal organizations, and how are you coordinating with the U.S. to address this issue? [SEP] We are working closely with the U.S. administration to combat human trafficking and protect migrants. We have increased our law enforcement presence in key areas and are working to dismantle criminal organizations. We are also providing support to victims of human trafficking and working to raise awareness about the dangers of migration. We are committed to ensuring the safety and well-being of all migrants in Mexico.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President—[inaudible]—Valentinovna, Sputnik News Agency. Have you discussed the issue of possible inspections to North Korea's nuclear sites during your negotiations? [SEP] I didn't catch that. Can you repeat it louder? And remind me of your affiliation?
label: Clarification

sentence: Regarding Iran, Mr. President, what criteria will you use to determine if they're serious about re-engaging in nuclear negotiations, and what repercussions await them if they persist in attacking U.S. forces? [SEP] We'll be looking for concrete steps demonstrating their commitment to a peaceful resolution. And we will defend our interests and respond decisively to any aggression.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. And one more back to—a quick one. Quick follow-up: Which loss last night surprised you the most? And which of these unsuccessful candidates are you most likely to consider for a future administration? [SEP] Nothing surprises me in politics.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, the Red Cross has issued a report alleging torture in CIA detention facilities. What is your reaction to these findings? And regarding Guantanamo Bay, despite your promise to close it, it remains open. Given reported resistance from within your administration, can you assure the American people that Guantanamo will be closed before you leave office? [SEP] I've consistently stated that closing Guantanamo is a goal for this nation. A major hurdle is the reluctance of other countries to take back detainees. We need a place for these individuals to go. The Senate recently voted overwhelmingly against bringing these prisoners into the country. So, the practical issue is: what do we do with these people? To say nothing has been done is inaccurate. We are actively working with other nations to facilitate the return of detainees. Many of these individuals are dangerous, and countries are hesitant to accept them. We also want to ensure humane treatment upon their return. Another challenge is holding trials. I'm eager to see these trials commence. The courts are involved in determining the process, and the Defense Department is working to establish mechanisms for these trials. The sooner we can get this underway, the better. I can't predict whether Guantanamo will be closed. It's a complex issue. I've set an aspiration. Whether we achieve it remains to be seen. It's not as simple as some believe. Again, consider the Senate vote. There's little support for closing Guantanamo and accepting prisoners in their home states. What was your other question?
label: General

sentence: Sir, concerning Afghanistan, what's the exit strategy? What's the timeline for bringing our troops home? And will you allow the media to cover the return of our fallen soldiers, a practice that was once deemed 'shameful'? [SEP] The loss of any American life is a tragedy. We are examining the media policy. With respect to Afghanistan, we are reassessing our approach. We will not allow Al Qaeda to regain a foothold. A timeline will be determined after the review.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your recent fundraiser comments, do you believe calling President Xi a dictator has damaged your administration's attempts to foster a working relationship with China? And secondly, concerning India, what is your response to those who claim your administration is ignoring the targeting of religious minorities in Prime Minister Modi's country? [SEP] The answer to your first question is unequivocally no. When engaging with our allies and partners globally, including India, the suggestion that I would refrain from expressing what I believe to be the truth about China is simply not an option. I firmly believe that the panic surrounding the relationship with China is unwarranted. We experienced an incident that caused some… let's say… confusion. However, Secretary Blinken's trip to China was highly productive, and I anticipate meeting with President Xi in the near future. I don't believe my remarks have had any significant impact. And could you please remind me of your second question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, can you elaborate on your knowledge regarding any acceleration of the Iranian nuclear program based on the intelligence you've reviewed? [SEP] I'm not at liberty to discuss specific intelligence assessments, either confirming or denying anything. But what I can tell you is that we're extremely vigilant about the Iranian nuclear situation. It's a key focus of our foreign policy, and we're working closely with our partners to send a clear message to Iran that there's a better future available to them. Our concern isn't with the Iranian people, whose heritage and culture we admire, but with their government's decisions that continue to isolate them and prevent them from achieving economic prosperity. We're taking this issue very seriously.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. So, you're not convinced that the climate is warming? [SEP] Well, I'm waiting to hear Putin's perspective after their meeting, to see if he still shares my concerns. He previously assured me in Australia that he understands the dangers of nuclear weapons proliferation. Russia has been supportive in the UN, and we're collaborating on a possible resolution. My focus is on preventing nuclear proliferation, not the weather. I'll continue working with Russia and other nations to isolate those pursuing nuclear ambitions.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: And what about the payment? [SEP] Sorry, could you repeat the question?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Do you believe that a deal could have been reached without Israel's agreement to temporarily suspend annexation? [SEP] Say it again. Could you make it louder?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. With the news this morning that the U.S. and its allies are returning to the table, are taking up Iran's offer to talk again, more than a year after those talks broke up in frustration, is this Israel's--Iran's last chance to negotiate an end to this nuclear question?And you said 3 years ago--nearly 3 years ago, in a similar one-on-one meeting with Prime Minister Netanyahu, that the time for talk--by the end of that year, 2009, you would be considering whether Iran was negotiating in good faith. And you said at that time that we're not going to have talks forever. So here we are nearly 3 years later. Is this it? And did you think you would be here 3 years after those first talks? [SEP] You know, there is no doubt that over the last 3 years, when Iran has engaged in negotiations, there has been hemming and hawing and stalling and avoiding the issues in ways that the international community has concluded were not serious. And my expectations, given the consequences of inaction for them, the severe sanctions that are now being applied, the huge toll it's taking on their economy, the degree of isolation that they're feeling right now, which is unprecedented, they understand that the world community means business.To resolve this issue will require Iran to come to the table and discuss in a clear and forthright way how to prove to the international community that the intentions of their nuclear program are peaceful. They know how to do that. This is not a mystery. And so it's going to be very important to make sure that on an issue like this--there are complexities; it obviously has to be methodical. I don't expect a breakthrough in a first meeting, but I think we will have a pretty good sense fairly quickly as to how serious they are about resolving the issue.And there are steps that they can take that would send a signal to the international community and that are verifiable, that would allow them to be in compliance with international norms, in compliance with international mandates, abiding by the nonproliferation treaty, and provide the world an assurance that they're not pursuing a nuclear weapon. They know how to do it, and the question is going to be whether in these discussions they show themselves moving clearly in that direction.Ed Henry [FOX News].
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, with Americans still losing their lives and cases on the rise, why is this a global contest? [SEP] People are dying everywhere. Maybe you should ask China that question. Not me, ask them. You might get a very interesting answer. Yes, you in the back.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Concerning Kamala Harris's eligibility, are you prepared to state unequivocally that her birth in Oakland, California, satisfies the requirements for holding the office of Vice President or President? [SEP] Honestly, it's not something I've spent any time on. I saw a brief mention of it somewhere, involving some lawyer, but I'm not really concerned about it. It's just not on my radar.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Well, no, I'm asking the question about whether you're concerned. But isn't there something you took away and that you can offer to your successor about how it's risky in the process of sizing up your Russian counterpart? Don't you think that you learned something from your time with Putin? [SEP] Here's what I learned, here's what I learned. I learned that it's important to establish a personal relations with leaders even though you may not agree with them—certain leaders. I'm not going to have a personal relationship with Kim Jong Il, and our relationships are such that that's impossible.But U.S.-Russian relations are important. It's important for stability. It's important for our relations in Europe. And therefore, my advice is to establish a personal relationship with whoever is in charge of foreign policy in Russia. It's in our country's interest to do so.Now, it makes it easier, by the way, when there's a trustworthy relationship to be able to disagree and yet maintain common interests in other areas. And so we've had our disagreements. As you know, Putin is a straightforward, pretty tough character when it comes to his interests. Well, so am I. And we've had some headbutts, diplomatic headbutts. You might remember the trip to Slovakia. I think you were there at the famous press conference. But—and yet, in spite of that, our differences of opinion, we still have got a cordial enough relationship to be able to deal with common threats and opportunities. And that's going to be important for the next President to maintain.Yes, Jonathan [Jonathan Karl, ABC News].
label: Explicit

sentence: So, Mr. President, in concrete terms, what are the next steps? [SEP] Well, the immediate need is to get more people back into their homes, to ensure they have a place to live. The systems are in place for the ongoing reconstruction of New Orleans. Some have criticized the Federal response as slow, but I must point out that 30,000 people were rescued from rooftops immediately after the storm. I personally thanked the helicopter pilots and Coast Guard for their heroic efforts. While improvements could always be made, to call the response slow is to disregard the efforts of those who saved so many lives. Furthermore, I was deeply moved by the reactions after the election, seeing people with tears in their eyes expressing disbelief at the election of a Black president. It highlights the progress we've made as a nation regarding race relations, but there is still work to be done to address the prejudices that remain in people's hearts. I am optimistic about the future and the historic moment this represents for our country.
label: Deflection

sentence: Can you elaborate on the conditions under which these individual conversations would occur? [SEP] I'm not at liberty to discuss the intricacies of the negotiations. Suffice it to say, we are determined to achieve a resolution and won't be bound by rigid diplomatic procedures. If Iran is genuinely interested in resolving this, they'll find a way.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, in your estimation, what are the key factors contributing to the success of this particular approach? [SEP] Here's the bottom line: People are saying, 'Just make a deal!' But they lack the spine and the understanding to grasp that we can't keep losing $500 billion every year. It's simply not sustainable. Someone had to step up and do something. Obama should have done it. Biden, Sleepy Joe, should have done it. Bush, Clinton, they all should have done it! But I'm doing it. And let me tell you something else: North Korea should have been dealt with a long time ago. I'm doing it. I'm doing a lot of things that should have been done by others.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. When you first saw this, weren't you angry? You didn't know about Syria. In 2005, you had the same assessment, with high confidence that Iran currently is determined to develop nuclear weapons. And now, quite the opposite. How can you possibly think the rest of the world is going to continue—to the degree it did—to rally around you and your intelligence? [SEP] Because many in the world understand that if developed a nuclear weapon, the world would be a very dangerous place. Secondly, many of the world are going to take heart in noting that it's diplomatic pressure that caused them to change their mind. And plenty of people understand that if they learn how to enrich, that knowledge can be transferred to a weapons program, if so chooses.And I think this is a—it's a—to me, it's a way for us to continue to rally our partners. That's why I'm working the phones, and Condi Rice is working the phones. All of us are calling our partners. And I appreciate many of the comments that have come out of the capitals.One thing is for certain: The NIE talks about how a carrot-and-stick approach can work. And this is heartening news to people who believe that, on the one hand, we should exert pressure, and on the other hand, we should provide the ians a way forward. And it was working until Ahmadi-nejad came in. And our hope is that the ians will get diplomacy back on track.Yes, ma'am.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Sir, what exactly did you say to the Pakistani government about this? [SEP] Those conversations are privileged, and I'm not going to disclose them publicly. But rest assured, we've made it abundantly clear that this is a critical issue, and we expect their full cooperation. The stakes are high.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. How are you going to push forward your prolife agenda? [SEP] Just going to push. I've been pushing. I've done a very good job too. They're very happy with me. But it's a tough issue for the two sides. There's no question about it.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, can you confirm or deny the reported deployment of 15,000 troops to the southern border? [SEP] You seem to be quite familiar with the situation. You've seen the reports, you know the details. What else do you want to know?
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. President Obama and President Xi, I'd like to talk to you about cyber. If I am an American business and I'm being hacked by Chinese pirates who are trying to steal my intellectual property, what firm assurances can you give us today that things are going to get better and when? [SEP] S. did sanction anyone in China, would you respond with sanctions?Also, everyone will kill me if I don't ask: What is your reaction to House Speaker John Boehner's decision to resign? [] Will this make life better or worse for you? Are you concerned it will make it more difficult to avoid a Government shutdown or raise the debt limit? And do you think Boehner could just waive the rules and get immigration reform through before he leaves? Thank you. I'll take them in order. With respect to cyber, this has been a serious discussion between myself and President Xi since we first met in Sunnyland. And the good news, from my perspective, is, is that in the lead-up to and then finalized during our meetings here today, we have, I think, made significant progress in agreeing to how our law enforcement and investigators are going to work together, how we're going to exchange information, how we are going to go after individuals or entities who are engaging in cyber crimes or cyber attacks. And we have jointly affirmed the principle that governments don't engage in cyber espionage for commercial gain against companies. That all I consider to be progress.What I've said to President Xi and what I'd say to the American people is, the question now is, are words followed by actions? And we will be watching carefully to make an assessment as to whether progress has been made in this area.With respect to the various tools that we have to go after those who are attacking our companies or trying to extract trade secrets or data, we have traditional law enforcement tools, but, as I indicated a while back, through executive action, I've also instituted the ability to impose sanctions on individuals or entities where we have proof that they've gone after U.S. companies or U.S. persons.And we did not, at our level, have specific discussions of specific cases. But I did indicate to President Xi that we will apply those and whatever other tools we have in our toolkit to go after cyber criminals, either retrospectively or prospectively. Those are tools generally that were—that are not directed at governments; they are directed at entities or individuals that we can identify. And they're not unique to China. Those are tools that we're going to be using for cyber criminals around the world.And President Xi, during these discussions, indicated to me that, with 1.3 billion people, he can't guarantee the behavior of every single person on Chinese soil, which I completely understand. I can't guarantee the actions of every single American. What I can guarantee, though, and what I'm hoping President Xi will show me, is that we are not sponsoring these activities, and that when it comes to our attention that nongovernmental entities or individuals are engaging in this stuff, that we take it seriously and we're cooperating to enforce the law.The last point I'll make on the cyber issue: Because this is a global problem and because, unlike some of the other areas of international cooperation, the rules in this area are not well developed, I think it's going to very important for the United States and China, working with other nations and the United Nations and other—and the private sector, to start developing an architecture to govern behavior in cyberspace that is enforceable and clear. It doesn't mean that we're going to prevent every cyber crime, but it does start to serve as a template whereby countries know what the rules are, they're held accountable, and we're able to jointly go after nonstate actors in this area.On John Boehner, I just heard the news as I was coming out of the meeting here, so it took me by surprise. And I took the time prior to this press conference to call John directly and talk to him.John Boehner is a good man. He is a patriot. He cares deeply about the House, an institution in which he served for a long time. He cares about his constituents, and he cares about America. We have obviously had a lot of disagreements, and politically, we're at different ends of the spectrum. But I will tell you, he has always conducted himself with courtesy and civility with me. He has kept his word when he made a commitment. He is somebody who has been gracious.And I think maybe most importantly, he's somebody who understands that in government, in governance, you don't get a hundred percent of what you want, but you have to work with people who you disagree with—sometimes strongly—in order to do the people's business.I'm not going to prejudge who the next Speaker will be. That's something that will have to be worked through in the House. And I will certainly reach out immediately to whoever is the new Speaker to see what his or her ideas are and how we can make progress in the important issues that America faces.The one thing I will say is that my hope is, there's a recognition on the part of the next Speaker—something I think John understood, even though at times, it was challenging to bring his caucus along—that we can have significant differences on issues, but that doesn't mean you shut down the Government. That doesn't mean you risk the full faith and credit of the United States. You don't invite potential financial crises. You build roads and pass transportation bills. And you do the basic work of governance that ensures that our military is operating and that our national parks are open and that our kids are learning.And there's no weakness in that. There's—that's what government is in our democracy. You don't get what you want a hundred percent of the time. And so sometimes, you take half a loaf; sometimes, you take a quarter loaf. And that's certainly something that I've learned here in this office.So I'm looking forward to working with the next Speaker. In the meantime, John is not going to leave for another 30 days, so hopefully, he feels like getting as much stuff done as he possibly can. And I'll certainly be looking forward to working with him on that. All right? Madam reporter has raised the cybersecurity issue. Indeed, at current, for the international community and for China and the United States, this is an issue all attach great importance to. With President Obama and I have on many occasions—and this is a long history—have exchange of views on this. I think it's fair to say we've reached a lot of consensus on cybersecurity, including some new consensus.Overall, the United States is the strongest country in terms of cyberstrength. China is the world's biggest cyber country in terms of the number of web users. We have more than 600 million of netizens. Our two sides should cooperate because cooperation will benefit both and confrontation will lead to losses on both sides. We are entirely able to carry out government department and expert levels of dialogue and exchanges to strengthen our cooperation in many respects and turn the cybersecurity between the two countries into a new growth source, rather than a point of confrontation between the two sides.China strongly opposes and combats the theft of commercial secrets and other kinds of hacking attacks. The U.S. side, if has concerns in this respect, we can, through the existing channels, express those concerns. The Chinese side will take seriously the U.S. provision of any information. Now, we have already, and in the future, we will still, through the law enforcement authorities, maintain communication and coordination on this matter and appropriately address them.So, all in all, we have broad, common interests in the field of the cyber. But we need to strengthen cooperation and avoid leading to confrontation. And nor should we politicize this issue. During my current visit, I think it's fair to say that the two sides, concerning combating cyber crimes, have reached a lot of consensus. Going forward, we need to, at an early date, reach further agreement on them and further put them on the ground.Thank you.Now I would like to propose for China's Central Television reporter—[inaudible]—to raise a question.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, just a quick question——Russia-U.S. Relations  Q. But on the military—military response, sir? [SEP] No, we didn't talk about military response.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. So, the $600 a week, it's definitely on the table, right? [SEP] We're looking at a lot of different numbers, a lot of different options. It's all part of the negotiation. We'll see what happens.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, Germany is pushing for a new initiative within the Middle East Quartet. Some believe that European nations lack the ability to influence a superpower like the US. Can you cite an instance where a discussion with a European leader led you to alter your stance? And Mrs. Merkel, considering the Quartet's limited achievements, were the efforts insufficient, or are the challenges insurmountable? What are the implications for future attempts? [SEP] Look, I always listen to my European allies. They're important partners. I may not always agree with them, but I value their perspectives. They've helped me see things in a different light. And Angela Merkel is a great leader. I respect her a lot.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. But if you think that Secretary Azar is doing such a great job, why did you feel the need to make a change and put Vice President Mike Pence in charge of the Federal response to this virus? [SEP] Because—and I think Secretary Azar is doing a fantastic job, but he also has many other things. I mean, we're working on many, many things together. If you look at his schedule of what he's doing, including drug prices and—I think it's perhaps the most complicated job that we have in Government. And I want him to be able to focus on that.And Mike is really good at it. They're going to work together. They're going to work very closely together. And they're both in the administration. I see them all the time, so it really works. This isn't a czar. This isn't going out and getting somebody that's never been in the administration. I have two people that are very talented. And it's something I feel good about.I don't want to spare the horses. I have very talented people. I want to use them on this, because I want it to stay low or as low as possible.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with Brazil pursuing closer economic relations with China, how will the United States adapt its foreign policy to ensure its continued relevance and influence in South America? [SEP] We have a lot of friends in South America. We're going to continue to work with them to promote our shared values and interests. We're not going to let China dictate the terms. We're going to stand up for what we believe in.
label: Dodging

sentence: How did those experiences shape your perspective on the allegations against Judge Kavanaugh? [SEP] It definitely affects my view. I've faced many false accusations myself, being a well-known person. People seek fame or money. So, I see it differently than someone watching TV. I know friends who've been falsely accused. I had a woman claim I attacked her on a plane, a complete fabrication. So, when considering Judge Kavanaugh, it resonates because I've experienced it. The news about the four individuals caught was significant.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, the QAnon movement seems to be gaining traction. What are your thoughts on this, and what message do you have for its followers? [SEP] Look, I'm not deeply familiar with QAnon, but I'm told they're big fans, which is great. They see what's happening in cities like Portland and Chicago, the chaos and the crime, and they're fed up. These are patriots who love America, and they're just tired of watching it go to hell. So, while I don't know the specifics, I appreciate their support and their desire to clean up these Democrat-run messes. If the Democrats can't handle it, we'll step in and fix it, plain and simple.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Tom Marino's nomination as drug czar and your recent criticism of Mitch McConnell's healthcare efforts, can you clarify your current confidence levels in both individuals? [SEP] Look, about Mitch, we've been at this healthcare thing for, what, six, seven months tops? Others had years and couldn't crack it. This guy will get it done, believe me. As for Tom, early supporter, great guy from Pennsylvania. Saw the report, we'll check it out, serious stuff. Big announcement next week on the opioid crisis, gotta get it right. This country, the world, has a drug problem, and we're gonna fix it. So, we're looking into Tom.
label: General

sentence:
Mr. President, regarding Libya, you've stated your desire for Qadhafi to relinquish power. Are you prepared to authorize any and all actions by the U.S. government to achieve this? If not, what are the specific limitations, considering the apparent shift in policy compared to other regional uprisings? [SEP] Well, let's be clear about our actions thus far. My immediate concern was the safety of American citizens and embassy staff in Libya, which we successfully addressed. Subsequently, we implemented the most substantial financial asset seizure in our nation's history. Following that, we imposed sanctions and rallied the international community through the UN, progressively tightening the pressure on Qadhafi. He faces increasing international isolation through sanctions and an arms embargo.

Furthermore, we've extended significant humanitarian aid to assist those crossing into Tunisia and Egypt, and we will continue this support. Within NATO, we've initiated discussions on a range of options, from continuous surveillance to monitor the situation and respond swiftly to potential deterioration, to further actions regarding the arms embargo, additional humanitarian assistance, and potential military options, including a no-fly zone.

NATO will convene on Tuesday to consider a no-fly zone, and we've consulted with Arab and African nations to assess their support for such a measure. Additionally, Secretary Clinton will meet with the opposition in the coming days, and we've decided to appoint a representative specifically to engage with the opposition and explore ways to further assist them. We will maintain close communication with them.

In essence, I haven't ruled out any options at this stage. It's crucial to recognize that we've acted with unprecedented speed in imposing sanctions on Qadhafi through an international coalition. I am unequivocally committed to the notion that Mr. Qadhafi's departure is in the best interest of the United States and, more importantly, the Libyan people. I haven't dismissed any of these options.

However, I take seriously the responsibility of ensuring that any decisions involving U.S. military force are carefully considered and made in close consultation with Secretary Gates, Chairman Mullen, and all relevant personnel. Deploying U.S. forces into potentially hostile situations carries inherent risks and consequences, and it is my duty as President to thoroughly assess those risks.

Politically, it's also vital to maintain the strong international coalition we've established.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. And on the domestic question, sir: What further specific executive actions are you considering in response to the Roe ruling? And would you declare a public health emergency as several Democrats are calling on you to do? [SEP] I'll be happy to go in detail with you on that, on the—I'm having a meeting with a group of Governors when I get home on Friday. And I'll have announcements to make then.But the first and foremost thing we should do is make it clear how outrageous this decision was and how much it impacts not just on a woman's right to choose—which is a critical, critical piece—but on privacy generally. On privacy generally.And so I'm going to be talking to the Governors as to what actions they think I should be taking as well. And—but the most important thing to be clear about is, we have to change—I believe we have to codify v. into law. And the way to do that is to make sure that Congress votes to do that. And if the filibuster gets in the way—it's like voting rights—it should be, we provide an exception for this—the—require an exception to the filibuster for this action to deal with the Supreme Court decision.Abortion Rights/Codification of v. /U.S. Supreme Court
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, to clarify, can American companies now sell to Huawei without restrictions, and what specific consequences will Turkey face if they proceed with the S-400 purchase? [SEP] Look, Turkey's a complicated situation. Erdogan, I get along with him great. He's a tough guy. He was going to wipe out the Kurds, who helped us with ISIS. I told him not to, and he didn't. So, Obama wouldn't sell him the Patriot missile, even though he's a NATO ally. So, he went to Russia and bought the S-400. Then, we wanted to sell him the Patriot, but he already bought the S-400. He also bought over a hundred F-35s, paid a fortune. Now, they're saying he can't use the S-400 because it's not compatible and Russia could get into the F-35. Frankly, he was treated very unfairly. They wouldn't sell him the Patriot in the first place. It's a mess, and it's not really his fault.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, there are many questions regarding the situation in Syria, particularly concerning Russia's involvement. Following your meeting with President Putin, do you believe he was honest about his intentions in Syria? If Russian forces target groups aligned with the U.S. alongside ISIS, will the U.S. military intervene to protect them? Furthermore, considering the setbacks in the U.S. train-and-equip program, can it be salvaged, or should alternative strategies be considered? Specifically, would you entertain the idea of a no-fly zone, as advocated by several presidential hopefuls, including your former Secretary of State? [SEP] Let's be clear, Syria is a complex situation that requires a comprehensive understanding. What began as peaceful protests against Assad transformed into a civil war due to his brutal response. This is not a conflict between the U.S. and any party in Syria; it is a conflict between the Syrian people and a ruthless dictator. Assad remains in power because Russia and Iran have supported him throughout this process. Putin's actions now are not particularly different from what they have been doing in the past; they are just more overt about it. They are propping up a regime that is rejected by the Syrian population because Assad has been willing to bomb his own people to stay in power. I told Putin that the only way to solve the problem in Syria is through a political transition that is inclusive, keeps the state and military intact, but gets rid of Assad. He is too toxic for Syrians to accept. I offered to work with Putin if he can convince Assad and Iran to agree to this transition. A military solution will not work; it will just get them stuck in a quagmire. We all want to destroy ISIS, but Putin does not distinguish between ISIS and the moderate Sunni opposition. He thinks they are all terrorists, which is wrong. We are talking to Russia to avoid accidental clashes. We still believe Assad is the problem and his brutality must end. We are ready to work with anyone to achieve that, but we will not help Russia crush Assad's opposition. The moderate opposition is key to Syria's future. Russia's actions are weakening them and strengthening ISIS. Our train-and-equip program has not worked as planned, partly because the opposition is too busy fighting Assad to focus on ISIS. We are looking at what has worked, like our work with the Kurds, and building on that. We will also keep working with the opposition because without a change in government, the civil war will continue, fueling ISIS. Putin went into Syria because Assad was crumbling. Sending arms and money was not enough; he had to send in his own forces. Nobody is buying his plan. Iran and Assad are his only allies. We have a coalition of 60 nations. Putin might realize it is in his interest to broker a political settlement. We are ready to work with Russia and Iran on that. It will not be easy, but it is possible. We need to talk, but only if there is a recognition that Assad has to go. We cannot go back to the way things were. Russia's attacks on the moderate opposition are making things worse.
label: General

sentence: Q. Has Netanyahu made concessions? [SEP] Yes, go ahead. Please. Sir./Japan-U.S. Trade
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Again, Mr. President, would you be willing to go so far as to normalize relations with North Korea? And what about the idea of signing some sort of an agreement on the 12th to end the war? [SEP] Well, it could be. We could sign an agreement. As you know, that would be a first step. It's what happens after the agreement that really is the big point.But, yes, we could absolutely sign an agreement. We're looking at it. We're talking about it with them. We're talking about it with a lot of other people. But that could happen. But that's really the beginning. Sounds a little bit strange, but that's probably the easy part; the hard part remains after that./Japan/China

But I did speak with the pastor of the family, who is a fine man, a wonderful man. And I think we had a great talk.And I may, at some point, you know, do that. But they did have a lawyer that wanted to be on the phone, and I said, No, that's inappropriate, but I just gave my best regards. But, again, I spoke with the pastor.Yes, please.

sentence: Q. Do you see any path to a deal if they don't budge on taxes? [SEP] I do not see a path to a deal if they don't budge, period. I mean, if the basic proposition is, It's my way or the highway, then we're probably not going to get something done because we've got divided Government. We've got Democrats controlling the Senate; we probably are going to need Democratic votes in the House for any package that could possibly pass. And so if in fact Mitch McConnell and John Boehner are sincere--and I believe they are--that they don't want to see the U.S. Government default, then they're going to have to compromise just like Democrats are going to have to compromise, just like I have shown myself willing to compromise.Chip Reid [CBS News].

sentence: Mr. President, Rick Ledgett's amnesty suggestion for Edward Snowden has stirred the pot. How pleased were you with him floating that idea? What conditions would warrant a plea agreement or amnesty? And what do you say to Americans who think Snowden did the right thing, exposing surveillance overreach? [SEP] I have to tread carefully here. Snowden's under indictment, and that's for the Attorney General and the courts to handle. I can't comment on the specifics. But I'll say this: we needed to have this conversation. However, the way the disclosures happened damaged the US and our intelligence capabilities. There was a way to have this discussion without that damage. The US abides by the rule of law, cares about privacy, and our Constitution. Because of these disclosures, countries that engage in surveillance of their own citizens, targeting political dissidents, and suppressing the press are acting as if the US has problems when it comes to surveillance and intelligence operations. This has done unnecessary damage to US intelligence capabilities and US diplomacy. I'll leave the specifics of Snowden's case to the courts and the Attorney General.
label: Declining to answer

Given your extensive interactions with President Xi, will you reach out to him, as an old friend, to urge him to allow WHO investigators access to China to investigate the origins of COVID-19?
