sentence: Q. Now, you—I'm sure you're not surprised that some in the military are not supportive of that deal. Some European allies think it would be a deal with the devil. What makes you so confident that you can trust the Russians and Vladimir Putin? [SEP] I'm not confident that we can trust the Russians and Vladimir Putin, which is why we have to test whether or not we can get an actual cessation of hostilities that includes an end to the kinds of aerial bombing and civilian death and destruction that we've seen carried out by the Asad regime. And Russia may not be able to get there either because they don't want to or because they don't have sufficient influence over Asad. And that's what we're going to test.So we go into this without any blinders on. We're very clear that Russia has been willing to support a murderous regime that has—and an individual, in Asad, who has destroyed his country just to cling on to power. What started with peaceful protests has led to a shattering of an entire and pretty advanced society. And so whenever you're trying to broker any kind of deal with an individual like that or a country like that, you've got to go in there with some skepticism.On the other hand, if we are able to get a genuine cessation of hostilities that prevents indiscriminate bombing, that protects civilians, that allows humanitarian access and creates some sort of pathway to begin the hard work of political negotiations inside of Syria, then we have to try, because the alternative is a perpetuation of civil war.I've been wrestling with this now for a lot of years. I am pretty confident that a big chunk of my gray hair comes out of my Syria meetings. [] And there is not a meeting that I don't end by saying, is there something else we could be doing that we haven't thought of. Is there a plan F, G, H that we think would lead to a resolution of this issue so that the Syrian people can put their lives back together again and we can bring peace and relieve the refugee crisis that's taken place? And the options are limited when you have a civil war like this, when you have a ruler who doesn't care about his people, when you've got terrorist organizations that are brutal and would impose their own kind of dictatorship on people, and you have a moderate opposition and ordinary civilians who are often outgunned and outmanned. And that's a very difficult situation to deal with. But we've got to give it a chance.There are going to be some bottom lines that we expect for us to cooperate with Russia beyond the sort of deconfliction that we're currently doing. And that means restraint on the part of the regime that so far has not been forthcoming.Early on in this version of the cessation of hostilities, we probably saw some lives saved and some lessening of violence. The violations of this cessation have grown to the point where it just barely exists, particularly up in the northwestern part of the country. So we're going to test and see if we can get something that sticks. And if not, then Russia will have shown itself very clearly to be an irresponsible actor on the world stage that is supporting a murderous regime and will have to be—will have to answer to that on the international stage.All right? Thank you very much, everybody.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with so many politically sensitive items potentially on the chopping block, where exactly are you planning to cut spending in the Defense and Veterans Affairs budgets? [SEP] Forgive me, you said 'so many' what, exactly?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Vice President Biden's comment about a 30% chance of failure despite best efforts, could you shed light on the context of that discussion and whether it pertained to the stimulus or bank rescue plan? [SEP] With all due respect, I can't recall every single conversation I have. However, I believe the Vice President was alluding to the inherent risks associated with implementing large-scale economic policies during times of crisis. There are no guarantees, but we are committed to making the best decisions possible for the American people.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, are you concerned about your safety given the recent incident? [SEP] My safety is always a concern, but I have faith in the Secret Service and law enforcement to protect me. We need to let them do their job and determine what happened.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Today is Super Tuesday, so I wonder if you might weigh in on some of your potential Republican opponents. Mitt Romney has criticized you on Iran and said, Hope is not a foreign policy. He also said that you are America's most feckless President since Carter. What would you like to say to Mr. Romney? [SEP] Good luck tonight. []
label: Deflection

sentence: President Obama, while acknowledging improved cooperation with Russia post-Boston, can you assure the American public that all necessary resources and protocols are in place to guarantee their safety at large public gatherings, considering the historical context of intelligence relations between our countries? [SEP] Since the Boston bombing, the Russians have been cooperative. Naturally, old habits die hard; there's still some lingering suspicion from the Cold War era. However, President Putin and I have discussed this directly, and he's committed to ensuring full cooperation on counterterrorism efforts. Regarding the American people, I believe their response in Boston demonstrated their resilience. We will not be intimidated. We will continue to live our lives, go to work, raise our families, and attend public events. We will remain vigilant and do everything possible to prevent future attacks, but we will not let fear dictate our actions.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, this communique mentions refraining from competitive currency devaluations. What does that practically mean regarding China's actions, and what do you expect from them? Also, do you believe the Democratic Party would benefit from fresh leadership in Congress? [SEP] From day one, I've been clear that we welcome China's rise. Their remarkable growth has lifted millions out of poverty, which benefits the world and America, as it allows China to be a responsible partner and a vast market for us, Korea, and other nations. It's good to see people escape poverty and gain opportunity. However, China's success demands responsible international behavior. The RMB issue is a source of friction, not just for the US, but for many of China's trading partners who compete globally. It's undervalued, and China intervenes heavily to keep it that way. We've urged China to gradually transition to a market-based system, something they've done before. They also need to shift to a more balanced growth strategy, focusing on their domestic market and empowering their people to consume, boosting their growth and reducing global imbalances. This communique, I believe, signals to China and others that allowing currencies to reflect market fundamentals is the best way to ensure everyone benefits from trade. I expect China to make progress on this. President Hu's visit in January offers an opportunity to continue this progress. This requires adjustments for China, and we understand it won't happen overnight, but it needs addressing, and I'm confident it can be. As for Congress, I believe we'll see talented individuals rise to the top with good ideas on jobs, investment, economic growth, and addressing our challenges. Speaker Pelosi has been an excellent partner, as has Harry Reid in advancing difficult legislation. I look forward to collaborating with the entire leadership team to address the issues that matter to the American people.
label: General

sentence: What are your thoughts on the Pope recognizing Palestine? Will it aid or impede a two-state solution? [SEP] Well, let me first commend the Senate for granting me the power to negotiate and enforce a progressive trade agreement with nations in the Asia-Pacific and Europe. My gratitude to the Senators who supported the debate's commencement. I will continue to persuade those who dissented. Despite prior issues with trade agreements, my strategy benefits businesses of all sizes and, most importantly, American workers. I would not advocate for any agreement that did not generate employment and enhance wages. My disagreement with Elizabeth is not personal; it is a policy divergence. Many of my allies in the Senate and House disagree with me, and I comprehend their worries about factory closures and overseas job migration. They are concerned about labor and environmental standards, as well as equitable trade practices. They are also concerned about inequality and the consequences of automation and globalization. They share my ideals, save for trade. It is a policy disagreement on what is optimal for our citizens. I contend that we are better off establishing stringent regulations with robust safeguards against child labor, deforestation, and other issues for the world's largest and fastest-growing market. If we do not, China will. Regarding outsourcing, enterprises can already engage in it. We have an opportunity to attract businesses back. Nike is repatriating 10,000 jobs due to technological advancements. We must sell our products there. We require a robust minimum wage, job training, infrastructure investments, collective bargaining, overtime compensation, paid sick leave, and transparent budgets. Impeding a trade agreement will not assist. Current trade regulations are detrimental to workers. I support enforcement. I have reservations about the currency language. I must confer with Schumer and Brown about language that does not jeopardize our monetary policy. What was your other query?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. ——or mentioned your name, anything like that? [SEP] We don't know that yet.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, your administration has been calling for Assad to leave power for years. When can we expect to see tangible results in Syria? [SEP] The situation in Syria is, as you know, incredibly complex. We're pursuing a multi-faceted approach, including diplomatic pressure, support for the opposition, and humanitarian aid. However, predicting the exact timeline for Assad's departure is impossible. There are too many variables at play.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, could you provide details regarding your conversation with the newly elected French President and the goals of Vice President Cheney's current trip to the Middle East? [SEP] Let's be clear, we don't 'recruit' presidents. The people decide, and I'll work with whoever they choose. I did speak with President-elect Sarkozy soon after he won – around 8:03 Paris time, I think. I'm glad he took my call. I met him before and found him to be smart and energetic. We'll have our differences, but also things we agree on, and I look forward to working with him. As for Cheney's trip, his main point to the Iraqis is that they need to hurry up, especially on passing laws that bring people together. There's a clock ticking here in Washington, and they need to get that. He'll also be talking to other friends in the region about Iran. We know what it would mean if Iran got nuclear weapons, and we're working to build a united front against that. We've already got the EU-3, Russia, and China on board diplomatically, and we need to keep it that way. Cheney will also remind everyone that success in Iraq is key to dealing with Iran. If we pull out too soon, it would encourage Iran. So, his trip is very important, and I appreciate him doing it.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. But what is your thinking about improving relations with Russia while they continue to illegally occupy another country? [SEP] Well, that was—yes, they do. And if you're talking about Crimea primarily, yes. But again, President Obama failed very badly with Crimea. I don't think he would have done that if I were President. He took over Crimea, and he actually took it over during the Obama administration, I think you will admit.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the COVID-19 death toll, figures show the U.S. ranking among the highest globally in deaths per capita. How do you reconcile this with your administration's response? [SEP] Look, a lot of those numbers came out of New York, right? New York and New Jersey were hit hard. If you take them out of the equation, and look at a state like Florida, for example, our numbers are much lower. Not that there's anything wrong with New York, it's just a densely populated area, very crowded. But even with New York included, I'll get back to you on the exact figures, but we're among the lowest. They've done a fantastic job. Next question.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding oil companies, you've been noticeably silent. Are you confident American oil producers are maximizing domestic resources, including offshore drilling? Furthermore, concerning Iraq, will you finalize an interim agreement with Prime Minister Maliki regarding American operations, or defer a comprehensive agreement to your successor? [SEP] Well, let's address the situation in Iraq first. We're actively engaged in crafting a strategic framework agreement with the Iraqi government. This encompasses various areas of cooperation: diplomatic, economic, and judicial. A key component is a security agreement, and naturally, they're keen on establishing a timeline for the transition to what we term 'overwatch.' Overwatch entails a U.S. presence focused on training, logistical support, and special operations. Crucially, for our troops to operate in a foreign nation, a clear understanding with the host government is essential, including operational authorities and protections for our personnel. We're diligently negotiating these aspects, aiming for completion before year-end, unless the U.N. mandate is extended. So, there are indeed two facets to this agreement – and they're often conflated, I've noticed – and we're tackling them concurrently. Now, where were we?
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the growing trend of what you've described as a crude form of nationalism, would you encourage those protesting against Mr. Trump's rhetoric to cease their demonstrations? Furthermore, have you offered advice to your successor regarding the selection of his staff? And lastly, do you believe you possess any remaining influence to halt the ongoing bombardment of Aleppo? [SEP] Protest is a fundamental aspect of our democratic system. I have been the target of protests throughout my presidency, as have countless presidents before me. I would not discourage those who feel strongly about the issues raised during the campaign from expressing their views. However, I would emphasize the importance of voting, organizing, and staying informed. We must not take our system of government for granted. Democracy requires constant effort. When a significant portion of eligible voters fail to participate, our democracy is weakened. If we are unable to distinguish between facts and propaganda, we face serious challenges. If individuals are unwilling to compromise and engage in the democratic process, our democracy will erode. It is crucial to understand the foundations of a healthy democracy and to actively participate in citizenship. There is a tendency towards complacency, particularly among younger generations who may not fully appreciate the challenges of the Cold War. It is important to remember the values that underpin our society and to actively defend them against misinformation and extremism. The United States has played a positive role in the world, particularly in supporting and defending our allies. We must not take these achievements for granted.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, if the allegations against Postmaster General DeJoy are substantiated, regarding the reimbursement of GOP donations, will you call for his resignation? [SEP] Well, I just heard about it this morning. I don't know the details. He's a respected man, approved by both parties. I'll have to look into it further.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Your response to the fact that that happened and that Schiff may have learned some of what the whistleblower knew prior to the complaint being filed? [SEP] Well, I think it's a scandal that he knew before. I'd go a step further: I think he's probably helped write it. Okay? That's what the word is. And I think it's—I give a lot of respect for the New York Times for putting it out.It just happened. As I'm walking up here, they handed it to me. And I said to Mike—I said: Whoa, that's something. That's big stuff. That's a big story. He knew long before, and he helped write it too. It's a scam. It's a scam.Just to finish on this—I appreciate it. I love that second question, by the way. Should have asked it first. [] But let me just tell you: The whole thing is a scam. The Mueller deal was a scam. The Russian collusion was a scam. You can ask Putin. Nobody has been rougher on Russia than Donald Trump, okay?Now, with that being said, it would be great to get along with Russia. And we will get along with Russia, because it's smart. But nobody has been tougher on Russia than Donald Trump.Okay. Ask one, please.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. If you do run, will Vice President Harris be on your ticket? [SEP] I would fully expect that to be the case. She's doing a great job. She's a great partner. She's a great partner.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, critics suggest the timing of the Puerto Rico aid package is suspect, coming so close to the election. What took so long, and why now? [SEP] Getting things done in Washington is never easy, especially when you're dealing with the other side. We've been pushing for this aid package for a while now, but the Democrats, they have their own agenda. But the important thing is, we got it done. And it's a fantastic package for Puerto Rico. It's going to help them rebuild and recover. And, frankly, I'm most excited about bringing the pharmaceutical industry back to the island. That's going to create jobs and boost the economy.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, to follow up on the previous question regarding Putin, did you explicitly state the consequences for cyberattacks on critical infrastructure, or was the threat implied? And what was Putin's demeanor during this exchange? [SEP] I'll say this: we have tools at our disposal, sophisticated tools. Putin is no fool; he understands the implications of crossing certain lines. We prefer not to telegraph our exact responses, but he knows we're prepared to act decisively.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Sir, might he have inferred that you discussed it with him—was a need for him to take action? [SEP] You're going to have to ask Al that question, but as I say, I discuss with my Cabinet officials complaints I hear. I mean, when Members of the Senate come up and say to me, I've got a complaint, I think it's entirely appropriate and necessary for me to pass those complaints on. Now, I don't every single time, but people view their moment with the President, sometimes, as an opportunity to unload their frustrations about how things may be working in their State—or Congresspersons, how things may be working in their district. And whether it be the Attorney General or the Secretary of State or other members of my Cabinet, I pass those complaints on at times.What Al did was, and what the Justice Department did was appropriate—U.S. attorneys serve at the pleasure of the President. In other words, they're appointed by the President; they can be removed by the President. What was mishandled was the explanation of the cases to the Congress. And Al has got work to do up there. And the thing I appreciate about the Attorney General was, he said publicly that he could have handled it better—mistakes were made—and took action. And obviously, more action needs to be taken. That's what I discussed with him on the phone today.
label: Explicit

sentence: Specifically, was the future of Syria a topic of conversation? [SEP] We discussed various challenges facing the Middle East.
label: Deflection

sentence: So, Mr. President, the White House is pushing the NIH and FDA to expedite this process, correct? [SEP] Well, I'm hearing some really encouraging things about the numbers – over 50 percent, which is fantastic. We've also got some approvals at 31 percent, which is still pretty good. It's all making a big difference. But what you're saying about the White House encouraging this – that's news to me. I'll definitely look into it.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning your discussions with President Duterte, can you confirm whether he apologized for any past remarks? And did you pledge ongoing US support for the Philippines in the face of Chinese expansionism? Finally, Donald Trump has asserted that Vladimir Putin is a more effective leader and that you have weakened the US military. Care to comment? [SEP] So, defend... fine.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, if you do meet with President Putin, what specific issues will you raise, and what outcomes are you hoping to achieve? [SEP] We'll discuss whatever is on the table. We are always looking for ways to improve relations, but we will also stand up for our interests.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, do you think that Pakistan are maintaining the safe havens in Afghanistan for these so-called terrorists? And also, do you know of any country in the Middle East that has nuclear weapons? [SEP] Well, I think that Pakistan--there is no doubt that in the FATA region of Pakistan, in the mountainous regions along the border of Afghanistan, that there are safe havens where terrorists are operating. And one of the goals of Ambassador Holbrooke, as he is traveling throughout the region, is to deliver a message to Pakistan that they are endangered as much as we are by the continuation of those operations. And that we've got to work in a regional fashion to root out those safe havens. It's not acceptable for Pakistan or for us to have folks who, with impunity, will kill innocent men, women, and children. And I believe that the new Government of Pakistan and Mr. Zardari cares deeply about getting control of this situation. And we want to be effective partners with them on that issue.
label: Explicit

sentence: If the Republicans gain control of the House, what impact will that have on your agenda? [SEP] Well, if they do, things will definitely be tighter. The polls were saying, and I'm not knocking anyone for their predictions, that we were looking at a red wave, a loss of 30 to 50 seats. That's clearly not happening. So, there are always folks on the other side, be they Democrats or Republicans, that you can try to work with, maybe peel off a few votes. We'll have to see. But, you know, all this talk… I'll ask a question, not expecting an answer: Do you really think Senator Johnson is going to try to cut Medicare and Social Security? And if he does, how many Republicans will actually vote for it? So, it really all depends.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Sir, about the coronavirus bill, is it true the White House is demanding language concerning the FBI building be included, as reported by the Washington Post? [SEP] I'm not sure about this particular bill, but let's be clear: the FBI *desperately* needs a new building. The existing one is a disaster – old, poorly built, pieces falling off. They looked at locations way outside DC, which I vetoed. They need to be close to Justice. The current site is the best. So, I've been encouraging them to build it. Renovation is a waste; we need a brand-new, top-of-the-line building for the next 100 years, maybe even with a running track on top! It's a huge area. Building new is the only way to go. So, whether it's in this bill or another, we'll get it done. Thank you!
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the vaccine for children under five, what's the latest, and why the delay? [SEP] The science isn't quite there yet. They're running the tests, doing the studies. I'm not a scientist, so I can't give you the specifics. But they're being thorough. We got the older kids vaccinated, and we'll get to the younger ones when the time is right.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, back in 1981, when Israel bombed that Iraqi reactor, did you agree with the decision? [SEP] You know, thinking back that far is tough. I can't say I have a clear memory of exactly what I thought about that situation back then. My focus was elsewhere at the time.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Pakistan's nuclear program, given the conference's focus on nuclear policy and your administration's goals, why does it appear Pakistan operates under different standards, especially considering their nuclear expansion and proximity to Al Qaeda? Shouldn't there be increased international pressure? [SEP] Well, let me just say, we're engaging with Pakistan. We've made it clear they should join the NPT. I've seen progress on their nuclear security. We want lower tensions in South Asia. Prime Minister Gilani's visit and commitments are positive steps in preventing proliferation. More work to do? Absolutely. But his presence here was crucial for regional nuclear stability. Next question.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. [Inaudible]—what do you say to him? [SEP] Well, I don't know Jeremy Corbyn. Never met him. Never spoke to him. He wanted to meet today or tomorrow, and I decided that I would not do that. I think that he is—from where I come from—somewhat of a negative force. I think that the people should look to do things correctly as opposed to criticize. I really don't like critics as much as I like and respect people that get things done. So I've decided not to meet.As far as the protests, I have to tell you, because I commented on it yesterday: We left the Prime Minister, the Queen, the Royal Family; there were thousands of people on the streets cheering. And even coming over today, there were thousands of people cheering. And then, I heard that there were protests. I said: Where are the protests? I don't see any protests. I did see a small protest today when I came, very small. So a lot of it is fake news, I hate to say. But you saw the people waving the American flag, waving your flag; it was tremendous spirit and love. There was great love. It was an alliance. And I didn't see the protesters until just a little while ago, and it was a very, very small group of people, put in for political reasons. So it was fake news. Thank you.. And I would say to both the mayor of London and to Jeremy Corbyn: The discussions that we have had today are about the future of this most important relationship between the U.S. and the U.K.As the President described it: the greatest alliance the world has seen. It is this deep, special relationship and partnership between the United States and the United Kingdom that ensures our safety and security, and the safety and security of others around the world too. And it is this relationship that helps to ensure there are jobs that employ people here in the U.K. and in the United States that underpins our prosperity and our future. That is a relationship we should cherish. It is a relationship we should build on. It is a relationship we should be proud of.Mr. President, would you like to—— It's very big, and this really is a very big and important alliance. And I think people should act positively toward it, because it means so much for both countries. It means so much and it's been so good.Steve Holland [Steve A. Holland, Reuters], yes. Go ahead, Steve.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, with all due respect, the Democrats are saying that you are out of touch with the American people. They say that your policies are hurting minorities. What is your response? [SEP] Well, that question—I can only say this: If you look at the employment and unemployment numbers for African Americans, for Asian Americans, for Hispanic Americans, they're at a historic high. A poll came out recently where my numbers with Hispanics and with African Americans are the highest—the best they've ever been. That had—that took place 2 or 3 days ago, the poll. I have the best numbers with African American and Hispanic American that I've ever had before. And you saw the same poll. So I can say that. I can say this: You look at median income, you look at all of the employment and unemployment numbers, they're doing the best they've ever done. And it reflects—it really is very reflective in the polls.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Niinistö, considering the border fortification efforts, are there specific, recent events that trigger heightened vigilance? And, representing a nation bordering Russia, what additional measures do you propose to effectively dissuade Putin? [SEP] As we initiated our application, we prioritized identifying potential adverse scenarios and formulating corresponding countermeasures. This thorough approach has yielded a reasonably tranquil environment. We trust this stability will endure. However, I wish to underscore the enhanced feeling of security among Finnish citizens. Presently, 80% of our populace endorses NATO membership, and over 80% affirm their readiness to safeguard our allies. That encapsulates Finland's position.
label: General

sentence: Regarding a hypothetical U.S. military intervention in Venezuela, what is Brazil's position, as Bloomberg is asking? [SEP] That's a strategic matter that we're not prepared to discuss publicly. Disclosing our intentions would be unwise. We're proceeding cautiously.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Regarding Charlotte, sir, any updates on a potential visit? [SEP] Got any suggestions? We're finalizing the details, folks. Stay tuned for a big announcement, soon!
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Cuba, does your new policy mean the end of U.S. regime change efforts? And on Hillary Clinton, does Vice President Biden's view that the Democratic race is wide open align with your assessment? [SEP] I've run my last race, and I'm not in the prediction business. That's your domain. Plenty of folks are happy to speculate; I won't be one of them. On Cuba, we're not about regime change. We're about empowering the Cuban people with freedom and the ability to shape their future, supporting civil society. Cuba will evolve regardless. President Castro referenced pre-my-birth actions; the Cold War is over. We still face challenges with Cuba, including their government's approach to its people and regional issues. But we can cooperate. Cuban doctors helped during Ebola; their work in Haiti after the earthquake was impactful. I told President Castro we'll voice our views, but persuasion is key, especially on issues not directly impacting our national security. Cuba isn't a threat. My concerns are ISIL, Iran's nuclear ambitions, Yemen, Libya, Boko Haram, Russian aggression in Ukraine, climate change – a long list. We'll work with the region, be clear about our values, and partner to lift opportunity, prosperity, and security. Overreach is often counterproductive, giving countries excuses for their failures. Let's remove the excuse.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Hypothetically, if a foreign nation were to offer assistance in our electoral process, would you accept it? [SEP] Look, I'm not going to speculate on hypotheticals. My focus is on ensuring free and fair elections. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you. Your administration has laid out four different dates by which you've said that the debt ceiling must be raised or the U.S. would face potential dire consequences. Three of those dates have come and gone, and we haven't faced financial calamity. Some of your critics have argued that these are then scare tactics to force a deal. So why should the American people believe that the August 2 deadline is the final deadline by which a deal must be raised? And would you also spell out for us what you believe will happen if the debt ceiling is not raised by that date? [SEP] Jessica, let's be clear. We haven't given out four different dates. We have given out dates that are markers for us getting into trouble. It's the equivalent of you're driving down the street and the red--the yellow light starts flashing. The yellow light is flashing. Now, it hasn't been a red light yet. So what Tim Geithner has said is, technically speaking, we're in a position now where we're having to do a whole bunch of things to make sure that our bills are paid.By August 2, we run out of tools to make sure that all our bills are paid. So that is a hard deadline. And I want everybody to understand that this is a jobs issue. This is not an abstraction. If the United States Government, for the first time, cannot pay its bills, if it defaults, then the consequences for the U.S. economy will be significant and unpredictable. And that is not a good thing.We don't know how capital markets will react. But if capital markets suddenly decide, you know what, the U.S. Government doesn't pay its bills, so we're going to start pulling our money out, and the U.S. Treasury has to start to raise interest rates in order to attract more money to pay off our bills, that means higher interest rates for businesses; that means higher interest rates for consumers. So all the headwinds that we're already experiencing in terms of the recovery will get worse.That's not my opinion. I think that's a consensus opinion. And that means that job growth will be further stymied, it will be further hampered, as a consequence of that decision. So that's point number one.Point number two, I want to address what I've been hearing from some quarters, which is, well, maybe this debt limit thing is not really that serious; we can just pay interest on the debt. This idea has been floating around in some Republican circles.This is the equivalent of me saying, you know what, I will choose to pay my mortgage, but I'm not going to pay my car note. Or I'm going to pay my car note, but I'm not going to pay my student loan. Now, a lot of people in really tough situations are having to make those tough decisions. But for the U.S. Government to start picking and choosing like that is not going to inspire a lot of confidence.Moreover, which bills are we going to decide to pay? These guys have said, well, maybe we just pay the interest on--for bondholders. So are we really going to start paying interest to Chinese who hold Treasurys, and we're not going to pay folks their Social Security checks? Or we're not going to pay to veterans for their disability checks? I mean, which bills, which obligations, are we going to say we don't have to pay?And last point I want to make about this. These are bills that Congress ran up. The money has been spent. The obligations have been made. So this isn't a situation--I think the American people have to understand this--this is not a situation where Congress is going to say, okay, we won't buy this car or we won't take this vacation. They took the vacation. They bought the car. And now they're saying maybe we don't have to pay or we don't have to pay as fast as we said we were going to or--that's not how responsible families act. And we're the greatest nation on Earth, and we can't act that way.So this is urgent, and it needs to get settled.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President Bush, regarding missile defense, will you ensure transparency with Poland and the Czech Republic? [SEP] We haven't solved all missile defense issues. But our U.S. partners understand our concerns and try to address them. I'm cautiously optimistic about agreements. The devil's in the details; experts must agree on confidence-building measures and their implementation. Cooperation on a global missile defense system is desirable. If we can cooperate regionally and then globally, that's in our interest. Russia worries the system targets them, so they'll react. I see it as defensive, not offensive. We must convince experts it's not aimed at Russia, but to address common threats. Regarding the Czech Republic and Poland, their leaders must see Russia as a partner, not an enemy. We'll work through differences. Transparency means openness, not just briefings. I'll share technologies and information to show it's for single/dual-launch regimes, not Russia's capacity. We've come far since our first talks. This vision benefits America and Russia.
label: General

sentence: President Bush, despite your efforts, have you secured commitments from France and Germany regarding Ukraine's NATO bid, and what tangible impact did your visit have on their stance? [SEP] Well, thank you. We've been working diligently with all NATO members to achieve a favorable result, because I firmly believe that NATO membership for Ukraine and Georgia serves the best interests of our alliance. I've personally engaged with numerous leaders, Secretary Rice has been in contact with her counterparts, and Mr. Hadley has also been involved in these discussions. These conversations are ongoing, and I wouldn't want to predict the final outcome. The vote will take place in Bucharest. My presence here should send a clear message that I am serious about this issue, that I truly believe it's in our interest for Ukraine to join NATO. But I hope you'll see more in my visit than just a statement on NATO. I was deeply impressed, as were many Americans, by the Orange Revolution. Many Americans were genuinely moved and encouraged by what transpired here. I conveyed to the President that Ukraine has captured the hearts and minds of many of our citizens over the past decade, and that you will find strong allies in us. The most important thing is to have a government that is open, transparent, free from corruption, and responsive to the needs of its people. This has been a productive trip, and I'm delighted to be here. As the President noted, it took me too long to arrive, but as they say, better late than never. I'm grateful to be here, and I want to express my appreciation for your hospitality.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the Khashoggi murder, are you personally convinced that Saudi Arabia is responsible, and if so, what specific punitive measures are you considering? [SEP] We're looking into it very, very carefully. I'm working with some great people in Congress. We're talking to everyone involved. I'll have more to say very soon. Very soon.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, now that Netanyahu has publicly acknowledged the Israeli air raid in Syria, can you disclose the target, the U.S.'s support for the action, and its potential consequences for the already volatile situation involving Syria, Iran, and Israel? Is there a risk of U.S. entanglement? [SEP] I'm going to have to pass on that one. What's next?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, the rise in anti-Semitism and hate crimes is alarming. Anti-Semitic incidents are up 57 percent since 2016, and hate crimes are increasing. What do you think is causing this, and what will you do about it? [SEP] It's terrible to see. I hate it. And, as you know, I've done more for Israel than any other President. Prime Minister Netanyahu said that himself. Jerusalem, protection, working together – so many things. But the big thing is Jerusalem. Presidents have talked about building the Embassy in Jerusalem, but it never happened. Making it the capital – never happened. But I did it, and quickly. And we built the Embassy. It would have taken years and cost billions, but we did it for very little money. It's already done. Nobody has done more for Israel than Donald Trump. And that's not just me saying it; it's Prime Minister Netanyahu.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Putin's statement that he sees no evidence Iran wants a nuclear bomb, were you disappointed? Does this suggest international pressure on Iran is waning? [SEP] I need to hear Putin clarify those remarks directly. When we spoke, he understood the global imperative to prevent Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons. He supported UN resolutions on this matter. If he wasn't concerned, why did we achieve such significant progress at the UN? I'll discuss this with him after Condi and Bob Gates brief me on their visit with Putin.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Concerning the middle-class tax cuts you proposed, what specific outreach will you undertake to gain the necessary Democratic votes for passage? [SEP] We've made our position very clear. The ball is in their court.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, you've consistently emphasized the importance of measurable success and accountability when the federal government invests resources. You've outlined benchmarks for the Maliki Government. Could you clarify for the American public precisely how you intend to gauge their progress in achieving these benchmarks, and what consequences will ensue if they fall short? [SEP] Look, the crucial thing is to establish benchmarks that both our government and the Iraqi government can agree on and deem significant. It's imperative for the American people to understand that simply dictating benchmarks to a sovereign nation isn't the most effective approach. We need buy-in from the Iraqi government itself. Our strategy involves collaborating closely with the Maliki Government to develop a series of benchmarks aimed at achieving specific objectives. This is to reassure the Iraqi people that their unity government is committed to improving their lives. It's beneficial for the Iraqi government to demonstrate their intentions and timelines to their people. Similarly, it's beneficial for the American people to see that the Iraqi government is making the difficult decisions necessary for progress. These benchmarks are about fostering collaboration and mutual respect. We respect Iraq's sovereignty, but they must also recognize that our patience, while considerable, is not unlimited.
label: General

sentence: Q. ——defense firms in China? [SEP] Yes, and you'll see more coming. This was a very important bill that we signed. But you're going to see more coming over the next short period of time. But yes, we don't want them investing in Chinese military companies. Okay?
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the recent strikes on Saudi Arabia and your response, what specific actions is Robert O'Brien recommending? And have we truly exhausted all possible sanctions against Iran? [SEP] These are the toughest sanctions ever imposed on any country. We've reached an unprecedented level with Iran. We sanctioned their Central Bank today. We'll see what happens. They're facing internal issues and self-inflicted problems. We possess the world's strongest military. Deciding to engage Iran would be simple, the easiest decision. However, I'm exercising significant restraint, which some appreciate, while others urge immediate action. I prioritize the interests of the United States and our allies. It's progressing exceptionally well. Robert O'Brien has excelled in hostage negotiations, achieving unparalleled success. We've swiftly brought numerous individuals home. Speed is crucial in hostage situations. Recently, I dined with the Warmbier family, a remarkable group, honoring Otto's memory. The First Lady and I found it deeply touching. We discussed Otto, emphasizing the need for quicker action. Robert and I agree on this point. With hostages, swift action is paramount. Otherwise, intervention becomes challenging, sometimes too late, as in Otto's case. We secured his return, but his condition was dire. What he endured was horrific. Robert and I have achieved considerable success. I actively engage in hostage situations, unlike many presidents. These are exceptional American lives, and we assist other nations too. We've secured releases from North Korea, Egypt, Turkey, with President Erdogan's cooperation, including a beloved pastor. Robert's appointment was widely supported, a testament to his capabilities. He's been actively involved since his selection. He's fully engaged in our current endeavors.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, given the seriousness of the allegations against Judge Kavanaugh, wouldn't an additional FBI investigation be warranted? [SEP] The FBI doesn't usually do that, Jon. They've done six background checks already. He's an incredible person, brilliant, with a perfect record. I feel terrible for him. This should have been brought up earlier, during the hearings. Why didn't Senator Feinstein bring it up then? The Democrats are just obstructing. He's a great man. We should have a process, there shouldn't be any doubt. They should have done this months ago. Hopefully, the woman will come forward. He will state his case. Then they'll vote. I feel terrible for him, his wife, and his daughters.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, with so many Americans suffering and the case count still climbing, why frame this as a global competition? What's the rationale? [SEP] These losses are happening everywhere, not just here. And frankly, a better question to ask would be: what is China doing? Go ahead, ask them. I think you'll find the answer quite telling. Yes, next question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President Bush, John Howard has prioritized climate change at this APEC summit. Haven't you undermined his efforts by scheduling your own meeting in Washington? And how important is the Kyoto Protocol to addressing climate change? [SEP] Well, let's start with Kyoto. And remind me of the first part of that question again, I'm getting old. Kyoto might be right for some, but it wasn't for us. I was honest about that. And before I even got to Washington, the Senate voted 95-0 against it. So, it wasn't just me. We went a different way, focusing on new technologies and energy efficiency. And guess what? We cut greenhouse gases while our economy grew. Not many countries can say that. We also want to be less reliant on foreign oil. That might scare some exporters, but we've got a plan to cut gasoline use by 20% in 10 years using ethanol and new tech. Batteries are getting better too. The key is getting these technologies out there. Kyoto didn't do that for us. If you look at who's meeting the Kyoto targets, you might see our approach makes more sense. We rejected it because we wanted to grow our economy, be energy independent, and protect the environment. John and I agree on climate change being important. I also told the G-8 we need everyone at the table, including China and India. If they feel forced into something, they'll walk away, and we can't solve this without them. The Prime Minister is smart to cut tariffs on clean coal tech for China. We support that. The big questions are: How fast can we get these technologies out there, and can we help developing nations get them too? Otherwise, it won't work. I think our plan is the best way to deal with this seriously. And I appreciate John bringing this up and talking about energy efficiency. He's showing leadership, and I'm glad to be here talking about it. Thanks.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, acknowledging the ongoing debate surrounding Edward Snowden, what specific criteria would you consider when evaluating a potential plea agreement or amnesty, balancing national security concerns with the importance of transparency and accountability? [SEP] Well, it's a tough situation, Major. He's been charged with crimes, and that's up to the Attorney General and the courts. I can't really comment on the specifics of his case. But I do think it's important to have a conversation about these issues, about privacy and security. It's a complex balance.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Considering the media's eagerness for progress, your three budgets, and your one-term president statement, why not engage Republicans now? What steps are you taking to encourage collaboration, and will the markets tolerate further delays? [SEP] I needed to write that down, I am running out of mental space.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Do you think that we are actually far from that point right now? And is it realistic to try to broker a cease-fire right now when there are still tunnel operations allowed to continue? Is that going to cause a change of approach from this point forward? [SEP] Well, keep in mind that the cease-fire that had been agreed to would have given Israel the capability to continue to dismantle these tunnel networks, but the Israelis can dismantle these tunnel networks without going into major population centers in Gaza. So I think the Israelis are entirely right that these tunnel networks need to be dismantled. There is a way of doing that while still reducing the bloodshed. You are right that in past conflicts, sometimes, people have to feel deeply the costs. Anybody who has been watching some of these images, I'd like to think, should recognize the costs. You have children who are getting killed. You have women, defenseless, who are getting killed. You have Israelis whose lives are disrupted constantly and living in fear. And those are costs that are avoidable if we're able to get a cease-fire that preserves Israel's ability to defend itself and gives it the capacity to have an assurance that they're not going to be constantly threatened by rocket fire in the future and, conversely, an agreement that recognizes the Palestinian need to be able to make a living and the average Palestinian's capacity to live a decent life.But it's hard. It's going to be hard to get there. I think that there's a lot of anger and there's a lot of despair, and that's a volatile mix. But we have to keep trying.And it is—Bill asked earlier about American leadership. Part of the reason why America remains indispensable, part of the essential ingredient in American leadership is that we're willing to plunge in and try, where other countries don't bother trying. I mean, the fact of the matter is, is that in all these crises that have been mentioned, there may be some tangential risks to the United States. In some cases, as in Iraq and ISIS, those are dangers that have to be addressed right now, and we have to take them very seriously. But for the most part, these are not—the rockets aren't being fired into the United States. The reason we are concerned is because we recognize we've got some special responsibilities.We have to be—have some humility about what we can and can't accomplish. We have to recognize that our resources are finite, and we're coming out of a decade of war and our military has been stretched very hard, as has our budget. Nevertheless, we try. We go in there, and we make an effort.And when I see John Kerry going out there and trying to broker a cease-fire, we should all be supporting him. There shouldn't be a bunch of complaints and second-guessing about, well, it hasn't happened yet, or nitpicking before he's had a chance to complete his efforts. Because, I tell you what, there isn't any other country that's going in there and making those efforts.And more often than not, as a consequence of our involvement, we get better outcomes: not perfect outcomes, not immediate outcomes, but we get better outcomes. And that's going to be true with respect to the Middle East. That's going to be true with respect to Ukraine. That's going to be certainly true with respect to Iraq.And I think it's useful for me to end by just reminding folks that, in my first term, if I had a press conference like this, typically, everybody would want to ask about the economy and how come jobs weren't being created? And how come the housing market is still bad? And why isn't it working? Well, you know what, what we did worked. And the economy is better. And when I say that we've just had 6 months of more than 200,000 jobs that hasn't happened in 17 years, that shows you the power of persistence. It shows you that if you stay at it, eventually, we make some progress. All right?
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, the Chinese officials are expressing some tones of discontent with how— where the source of this virus has come from, and they're spinning some odd narratives. What are your response to the Chinese officials who are doing that? And have they signaled any kind of resistance to upcoming trade talks in response to how we're handling this virus? [SEP] No, we have our deal with China. They're going to be buying $250 billion worth of goods and $50 billion from our farmers. And that's a great deal for our country; it's about time somebody did that. And frankly, phase two, we'll start negotiating.I did read one article, but I don't think that article was representative, certainly not of my conversations with President Xi. And they know where it came from. We all know where it came from.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. So you would sign something that does include funding? [SEP] Sure. A separate thing, I would do it. But one of the reasons the Post Office needs that much money is they have all of these millions of ballots coming in from nowhere, and nobody knows from where and where they're going. You saw what happened in—Kaitlan—in Virginia. It was, you know, 500,000 applications coming in, going all over the State; nobody even knows where they came from. You saw what happened in New York, which was a disaster with Congresswoman Carolyn Maloney. It was a basic disaster. And you see Paterson, New Jersey, what's going on there. And we can give you many other locations and sites.What has happened is that's part of a big negotiation. That's a—actually small part of a big negotiation to get more money to people that it wasn't their fault; it was China's fault. And Post Office is part of it. Another part of it is, they want $3½ billion just for the ballots themselves. Why it's so much, I don't know. But that's what the Democrats want. But if the bill isn't going to get done, that would mean the Post Office isn't going to get funded, and that would also mean that the $3½ billion dollars isn't going to be taken care of. So I don't know how you can possibly use these ballots, these mail-in ballots.Absentee ballots, by the way, are fine. But the universal mail-ins that are just sent all over the place, where people can grab them and grab stacks of them and sign them and do whatever you want, that's the thing we're against.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, you've spoken about state sovereignty, but how does that fit with the 'responsibility to protect' concept, which was central to helping those in need? [SEP] I'm sorry, could you repeat that? How do I reconcile state sovereignty with the 'responsibility to protect,' which was... what exactly was it?
label: Clarification

sentence: Just to be absolutely clear, your question pertains to a potential direct meeting between myself and Iranian counterparts? [SEP] The core of your inquiry is whether I intend to have direct discussions with Iranian officials, correct?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. Are you concerned, Mr. President, that commuting Chelsea Manning's sentence will send a message that leaking classified material will not generate a tough sentence to groups like WikiLeaks? How do you reconcile that in light of WikiLeaks' connection to Russia's hacking in last year's election? And related to that, Julian Assange has now offered to come to the United States. Are you seeking that? And would he be charged or arrested if he came here? [SEP] Let's be clear, Chelsea Manning served a significant prison sentence. It's not as if leaking classified information goes unpunished. The sentence she received was very disproportionate to what other leakers have received. She went to trial, due process was carried out, and she took responsibility for her crime. I felt it made sense to commute her sentence, not pardon it. Justice has been served, and a message has been sent that national security is paramount. People with concerns about government actions should use established channels and whistleblower protections. I recognize some think these aren't enough, but we need to balance accountability with the safety of those in the field. With respect to WikiLeaks, I don't see a contradiction. I haven't commented on WikiLeaks generally. The intelligence community's conclusions on Russian hacking and WikiLeaks were not conclusive. I don't pay attention to Assange's tweets. I'd refer you to the Justice Department for any criminal investigations. In this cyber age, we need to balance accountability, openness, and transparency with national security. We need to protect our democracy while allowing our agencies to function effectively. I looked at the particulars of this case and felt commuting her sentence was appropriate.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, given your emphasis on the necessity of addressing both Afghanistan and Pakistan, why has Pakistan's contribution to resolving the conflict been largely overlooked at this summit? Did your conversations with President Zardari result in any advancement regarding the reopening of supply routes? And if the broader issues with Pakistan are not resolved, will NATO's achievements in Afghanistan be at risk? [SEP] Look, my discussion with President Zardari was brief, but I reiterated our public and private stance: Pakistan is part of the solution in Afghanistan. A democratic, prosperous, and stable Pakistan is in our national interest. We share a common enemy in extremists in both countries, and we must address the tensions arising from our decade-long military presence. President Zardari believes these issues can be resolved. We didn't expect the supply line issue to be resolved here, but we're making progress. Everyone in the alliance and Afghanistan understands that security, stability, and prosperity require resolving these issues and joining the international community to prevent extremism. There are real challenges and tensions between ISAF, the US, and Pakistan, but they are being addressed through military and diplomatic channels. Ultimately, a successful, stable Pakistan is in our interest, and it's in Pakistan's interest to work with us to prevent extremism. We're committed to this, and every NATO/ISAF member is too.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, a year from now, do you believe Assad will still be in power in Syria? [SEP] For Syria to move forward and stop the bloodshed, Assad needs to go. He's lost legitimacy with most of the country. But, how do we build a bridge for a political transition that protects the interests of Assad's allies, like Russia and Iran, and ensures minorities like the Alawites aren't crushed? That's the tough part. If Assad had put his country first, this would be easier. Now, it's harder. But John Kerry is doing great work. And the Russians are starting to see that their actions aren't really changing things, despite their deployment. That's what I thought would happen, because bombing can only do so much when the whole country is against their ruler.
label: General

sentence:
Mr. President, the election results suggest a desire for a different direction. What concrete steps will you take to address the concerns about trade and immigration that seem to have resonated with voters? [SEP] Look, people are worried, and I get it. They see the world changing, and they want to make sure they're not left behind. They know they might need to adapt, but they want a fair shake.

Most Americans still support trade, but they want to know it's fair, that we're not getting taken advantage of. They don't want to see wages go down.

I tried to explain that TPP would help with that, but it's a tough sell when people have seen jobs disappear. So, this election was about wanting a change. People want to control immigration and avoid unfair trade deals. But we need to make sure immigration is legal and orderly, because it's good for our economy. It keeps us young and dynamic.

And when it comes to trade, it's not as simple as just cutting things off. We have global supply chains. Auto plants rely on parts from Mexico. So, we need to address people's concerns with things like a higher minimum wage, stronger worker protections, and financial regulations. We need trade that ensures fair labor practices and addresses inequality. That's how we make sure everyone benefits.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Will do, sir. Iran says that it will be on the verge of violating the threshold for uranium enrichment in the JCPOA as soon as, potentially, next week. What will be your response when that happens? [SEP] You'll see.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, will the problems with the healthcare rollout impact your ability to achieve other policy goals, such as immigration reform? [SEP] Look, there's no reason not to do immigration reform. We already have bipartisan support in the Senate. Even conservative clergy are committed to it. The business community is fully on board. So, there are many constituencies, traditionally Republican-leaning, who support this. If people want an excuse not to do the right thing, they'll find one. But I assume people want to do what's right. This would strengthen borders, improve the legal system, penalize employers who hire undocumented workers, and allow those here illegally to get right with the law – pay a fine, learn English, and get to the back of the line. It's a sensible law, so we shouldn't look for excuses not to pass it. I'll keep pushing. Will I have to rebuild confidence? Yes. But that's part of the job. Good things don't get attention; bad things do. That's always been the case. I'm up to the challenge. We'll get it done.
label: General

sentence: Ms. President, from Bloomberg, Simone Iglesias. In the event of a U.S. military intervention in Venezuela, what would be Brazil's official response? [SEP] Well, you see, some matters are best kept under wraps for strategic reasons. Revealing them would undermine our position. As I recall, during a debate here, one candidate wisely refused to divulge their strategy against ISIS, saying it would compromise their ability to succeed. We will honor our discussions, but certain information cannot be made public.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, the intelligence community has reported potential election interference from Russia aimed at discrediting Mr. Biden and consideration of similar actions by China targeting you. What is your assessment of these reports, and what steps will your administration take to address this threat? [SEP] It's possible. It's always possible. But let's be honest, Russia knows that I'm the only one who can stand up to them, and China is afraid of my trade policies. So, if they're interfering, it's a sign that they know I'm the only one who can make America great again.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Biden and Harris's recent joint appearance, could you share your immediate thoughts and overall assessment of their campaign strategy? [SEP] Didn't bother watching much. Saw enough. He made his choice, and it's a doozy. Her numbers? They tanked, folks, just cratered. And the things she said about him? Unbelievable! Now she's all smiles and sunshine? It's a joke. Pennsylvania? Forget about it with her fracking stance. Texas? They said the same thing about Crooked Hillary, and look what happened. We won, bigly. And this tax hike of hers? A disaster. The military? We rebuilt it, made it strong, the best ever. She wants to cut funding? Crazy! I was shocked, frankly, that he picked her. Shocked! She went down in flames, said terrible things. How does that work? It doesn't. Next question.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. So, if I understand correctly, the business sector benefits, and the climate is addressed, but your direct involvement isn't essential? Is that a fair summary? [SEP] Pardon me, could you repeat that? I didn't quite catch the connection you were making.
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, regarding the Hadley memo incident, did you or your Chief of Staff authorize an investigation into the leak prior to your meeting with Prime Minister al-Maliki? Furthermore, assuming the leak was unauthorized, do you suspect a deliberate attempt within your administration to undermine your Iraq policy or disrupt your discussions with the Prime Minister? [SEP] I'm racking my brain trying to recall if I specifically ordered an investigation. I don't immediately recall doing so. However, I do recall expressing some frustration regarding the persistent leaks. While I acknowledge the media's role in disseminating information, the unauthorized disclosure of classified documents is unacceptable. It's a recurring issue, not just for this administration, but for any administration attempting to implement policy. We've experienced numerous leaks, and pinpointing the source is often elusive. There might be an ongoing investigation; I'm simply not aware of it at this moment. However, it's imperative that individuals who leak classified materials are held accountable. Perhaps consequences would deter such actions in the future.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Is there anything else you can do about it besides passing legislation? [SEP] The answer is yes, but I'm not going to lay out a strategy in front of the whole world and you now.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, would you strongly advise Israel against taking military action against Iran? And do you believe Iran will be pursuing nuclear weapons when you leave office? [SEP] I've made it abundantly clear to everyone involved that diplomacy should always be the first resort. And the most effective way to achieve a diplomatic solution is for the United States to collaborate with other nations to send a unified message: continued enrichment will lead to isolation and economic hardship. As you may recall, I worked closely with Vladimir Putin on this matter. When asked at a press conference whether Iran should have a civilian nuclear program, I said, 'Of course, but they can't be trusted to enrich.' Therefore, I agreed with Russia's offer to provide enriched uranium for a civilian nuclear power program and then collect the spent uranium, eliminating the need for the Iranian regime to enrich at all. So, we will continue to pursue diplomatic avenues. Thank you very much. It's been a pleasure. I hope you've enjoyed this as well.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Bush, beyond diplomatic pleasantries, what tangible results emerged from the Baghdad conference, and what are your specific expectations for subsequent meetings, especially concerning Iran and Syria's stated desire to contribute to Iraq's stability? [SEP] I'm a results-oriented person. Words are cheap. If Iran and Syria are serious about helping Iraq, they need to take concrete steps, like stopping the flow of weapons and foreign fighters. The conference was a positive step. It brought regional players together to discuss Iraq's future. It also boosted the confidence of the Iraqi government. And Secretary Rice will be attending the next meeting, which demonstrates our commitment.
label: Deflection

sentence: So, Mr. President, with Shanghai Media Group asking, any idea when the next meeting might be? Soon, or are we talking a longer wait? [SEP] I honestly couldn't say for sure. It could be in the near future, or it might take quite some time. I really can't give you a definitive answer. Naturally, I'm hoping for it to be soon, but realistically, it might not happen for a while.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, you pledged to alter the climate in Washington, but you previously accused Democrats of aiding terrorists. What has prompted this change? Furthermore, is your administration ready for potential investigations from Congress? [SEP] The election is done, the Democrats won, and now we're going to work together. The Democrats will need to figure out how they want to proceed. I'll be speaking with their leadership soon about these issues.
label: Deflection

sentence: Concerning the COVID-19 vaccine, who will be at the front of the line to receive it? And what are your thoughts on the vaccine being developed in Russia? [SEP] Our focus is on getting the vaccine to those who need it most, as quickly and safely as possible. We're aware of the Russian efforts, but we're confident in our own vaccine development process and the rigorous standards we're adhering to.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, can you provide more details regarding your proposed tax cuts for the middle class? [SEP] Do you know what my plan is? Do you know what my plan is? I'll ask them. If they agree, I'm on board. If they disagree, there's nothing I can do, because their votes are essential. Moving on.
label: Clarification

sentence: So, are you asking if I'm planning to engage directly with Iranian officials? [SEP] Are you asking whether I will meet face-to-face with Iranian representatives?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Do you think he'll come back to the $4 trillion deal? [SEP] I think Speaker Boehner has been very sincere about trying to do something big. I think he'd like to do something big. His politics within his caucus are very difficult, you're right. And this is part of the problem with a political process where folks are rewarded for saying irresponsible things to win elections or obtain short-term political gain, when we actually are in a position to try to do something hard we haven't always laid the groundwork for. And I think that it's going to take some work on his side, but look, it's also going to take some work on our side, in order to get this thing done.I mean, the vast majority of Democrats on Capitol Hill would prefer not to have to do anything on entitlements, would prefer frankly not to have to do anything on some of these debt and deficit problems. And I'm sympathetic to their concerns, because they're looking after folks who are already hurting and already vulnerable, and there are a lot of families out there and seniors who are dependant on some of these programs.And what I've tried to explain to them is, number one, if you look at the numbers, then Medicare in particular will run out of money, and we will not be able to sustain that program no matter how much taxes go up. I mean, it's not an option for us to just sit by and do nothing. And if you're a progressive who cares about the integrity of Social Security and Medicare and Medicaid and believes that it is part of what makes our country great that we look after our seniors and we look after the most vulnerable, then we have an obligation to make sure that we make those changes that are required to make it sustainable over the long term.And if you're a progressive that cares about investments in Head Start and student loan programs and medical research and infrastructure, we're not going to be able to make progress on those areas if we haven't gotten our fiscal house in order.So the argument I'm making to my party is, the values we care about--making sure that everybody in this country has a shot at the American Dream and everybody is out there with the opportunity to succeed if they work hard and live a responsible life, and that Government has a role to play in providing some of that opportunity through things like student loans and making sure that our roads and highways and airports are functioning, and making sure that we're investing in research and development for the high-tech jobs of the future--if you care about those things, then you've got to be interested in figuring out how do we pay for that in a responsible way.And so yes, we're going to have a sales job; this is not pleasant. It is hard to persuade people to do hard stuff that entails trimming benefits and increasing revenues. But the reason we've got a problem right now is people keep on avoiding hard things, and I think now is the time for us to go ahead and take it on.Rich Wolf [USA Today].
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, a U.S. General recently warned marines in Norway about an impending 'big-ass fight.' How imminent is this war, and where do you anticipate it occurring? [SEP] A 'big war,' huh? What exactly are you referring to?
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, if I could just ask you: You said the other day, in the Cabinet Room with African American leaders, you've got to get away from politics. You were down in Charleston last night, using the word hoax when talking about Democrats. Somebody now is dead from this. Do you regret that kind of talk? [SEP] No, no, no. Hoax referring to the action that they take to try and pin this on somebody, because we've done such a good job. The hoax is on them, not—I'm not talking about what's happening here; I'm talking what they're doing. That's the hoax. That's just a continuation of the hoax, whether it's the impeachment hoax or the Russia, Russia, Russia hoax. This is what I'm talking about. Certainly not referring to this. How could anybody refer to this? This is very serious stuff.But the way they refer to it—because these people have done such an incredible job, and I don't like it when they are criticizing these people. And that's the hoax. That's what I'm talking about.
label: Implicit

sentence: Is there any way to narrow down the location of this imminent announcement? [SEP] I'm afraid I must remain tight-lipped on that front. Prematurely revealing such details would be akin to tipping our hand before the game has even begun.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, a year ago, after the Democrats took control of Congress, you expressed a desire for bipartisan cooperation. However, your assessment of the Democrats today was quite critical. How do you evaluate your own performance in working with the Democrats over the past year? How effective have you been in finding common ground, and do you believe you've succeeded in fostering cooperation? [SEP] We're finding common ground on Iraq. I realize some in Congress believe we shouldn't have been there, but the debate seems to have shifted. General Petraeus and Ambassador Crocker's testimony resonated with many members. I hope we continue to find common ground by ensuring our troops are funded. We found common ground on FISA. My only question is, why change a good law? The current law works for national security, which is what the American people want. This law allows our intelligence professionals to understand Al Qaeda's intentions. The law needs to be enhanced by providing liability protection to phone companies that allegedly assisted us. So, we found common ground there. Hopefully, we can find common ground as Congress moves forward with legislation. The reason I spoke as I did today is that there's much to be done. As you know, I'm not a legislator, but as head of the executive branch, it makes sense to urge Congress to show progress and achieve results. It's hard to find common ground when important bills aren't moving. Not even one appropriations bill has reached my desk. How can you find common ground without an appropriations process? We found common ground on trade bills, which are very important. Exports helped us overcome the weakness in the housing market last quarter. If that's the case, it makes sense to continue opening up markets to goods and services. Yet, no trade bills have been moving. Veterans Affairs is another area for common ground. I asked Bob Dole and Donna Shalala to lead a commission to ensure our veterans receive the benefits they deserve. I was concerned about bureaucratic delays and a system that didn't recognize the nature of the war we're fighting. I don't like meeting wives at their husbands' bedsides in Walter Reed who aren't being supported by the government. I'm concerned about PTSD and want people to focus on it. So, we sent up a bill, and I hope they move on it quickly. There's a place where we can find common ground.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You met with President Xi, and you met with him face to face after he had unquestionably consolidated his power at home. So now that you've met with him face to face, how do you assess his sort of posture towards the United States now? And did you find him personally to be more confrontational or more conciliatory and willing to compromise? [SEP] Neither. And yes.

sentence: Are you planning a trip? [SEP] I beg your pardon?

sentence: Q. Reflecting on the situation, is there anything you would have done differently? [SEP] With respect to what are you asking?

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your willingness to collaborate with Governor Romney signals a shift in your own policy positions. How do you respond to those who fear a compromise of your core principles? [SEP] My principles are unwavering. My commitment to the American people is absolute. Talking to someone with different ideas doesn't mean I'm abandoning my own. It means I'm exploring all options to find the best solutions. That's what the American people expect.

sentence: Q. And what is your administration going to do about it? [SEP] I believe all hate is a problem, but I do believe that is a problem.

sentence: Q. Mr. President, given the oil price cap initiative, are you confident American drivers will see lower gas prices soon, and how long should they expect to bear the burden of this war's impact? [SEP] The second part of your question concerned the price, correct?

sentence: So, any chance of cooperation? [SEP] Ask me again in roughly eight years. That's one plus seven, just to be clear. In theory, yes, because bipartisanship is a lovely concept. But currently, it's a wall of obstruction. They oppose tax cuts that would strengthen our country. That's a tough sell, and I suspect some Democrats will eventually support the tax cuts.

sentence: Mr. President, given the ongoing tensions with Iran, would you consider prisoner swaps as a means of de-escalating the situation and securing the release of detained individuals? However, we will not compromise our principles or reward bad behavior. We will continue to hold Iran accountable for its actions and demand the immediate and unconditional release of all wrongfully detained individuals.

sentence: Q. [Laughter] So, is it safe to say you're considering both possibilities? [SEP] Did you say both? What was the question?
