sentence: Without revealing classified information, can you give us a general overview of the requests made regarding Afghanistan and the presence of U.S. troops? [SEP] The conversation centered on mutual concerns regarding Afghanistan. He voiced his hopes for sustained peace, and I emphasized the importance of their role in achieving that. He signaled a willingness to assist, and we discussed our priorities for regional stability, including Syria and Libya. A productive exchange, though details remain confidential.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. And Mr. President—— The President. We want our country safe. We don't—unlike Biden, we don't want to have criminals pouring into our country. We don't want to have open borders. We're not going to have that. And we want to take care of our police. We want to actually fund our police, not defund them. And we're not going to abolish our police. And we're not going to make our military small and weak, because probably—or, at least, at top of the level, we need our military right now.Yes, go ahead. Please.Trade  Q. Mr. President, so how do you think that America first policy can work during a pandemic? Aren't you concerned that this could actually damage the U.S. and make China more influence around the world? [SEP] Okay, look, my policy is America first. We've lost hundreds of billions of dollars a year with China and many other countries. And what we're doing is just handing everybody everything. It's just a sad—I've watched it, I've looked at it.We did the U.S.-Mexico—you saw that, USMCA. We made a very fair deal on trade. We had the worst deal ever, right? You know that. We had the worst deal ever, and it replaced that; it replaced that horrible NAFTA deal. That was one of the worst trade deals ever made.I'll tell you, the only deal that might be worse is the WTO, World Organization. May be worse.OAN, please.
label: General

sentence: So, a specific timeline is not available at this time? [SEP] It's happening very quickly. The private sector has been incredible. These tests are fast, accurate. It's truly remarkable what's been achieved.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, Seattle City Council recently voted to defund their police department, leading to the resignation of Police Chief Carmen Best. What does this situation reflect about the current state of our country and the 'defund the police' movement? [SEP] Well, Seattle, despite everything, with the embarrassment of Antifa and other radical left groups taking over a large part of the city—a major city—that they allowed that to happen is incredible. That it took so long to fix is incredible. And they only went in because they knew we were going in the next day, and they didn't want to be embarrassed. The people just gave up, they were exhausted from having their city taken over for so long. The police commissioner seems like a very good woman. They were going to slash her salary by 40 or 50 percent. And they cut a tremendous amount from the police department, really, to the point where people are saying it's not sustainable as a good police department. And, again, those police are good also, but they're not allowed to do their job. So I think it's a shame. I hate to see her go, because she did, in her own way, a very good job, but she wasn't effective in convincing the mayor and the city council to give the funds that were needed or just leave the funds the way they are. They've done a big defund, a big part of it. And it will probably get worse before people realize this is a tragic error, before people start dying and getting hurt very badly. So I think Seattle has made a tragic mistake. I think Portland has no clue as to what they're doing. They have no clue. And hopefully, they'll be asking for help, because we can solve their problem very, very quickly.
label: Implicit

sentence: Congresswoman Greene has expressed views widely considered to be conspiracy theories. By calling her a 'future Republican star,' aren't you implicitly endorsing those beliefs? [SEP] She's a very popular person, and she's got a lot of good ideas. She's very strong on borders, very strong on the military, and she loves our country. People are tired of the fake news trying to make her look bad.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you. Nearly 2 years have passed since the beginning of the global coronavirus outbreak. And you again today acknowledged that Americans are frustrated and they're tired. Based on your conversations with your health advisers, what type of restrictions do you imagine being on Americans this time next year? And what does the new normal look like for social gatherings and travel to you? [SEP] Well, the answer is, I hope the new normal will be that we don't have—still have 30-some million people not vaccinated. I hope the new normal is, people have seen—and what their own interest is and have taken advantage of what we have available to us.Number two, with the pill that is probably—that appears to be as efficacious as it seems to be—that you're going to be able to deal with this virus in a way that, after the fact, you have the ability to make sure you don't get so—you don't get very sick.Number three, I would hope that what happens is, the rest of the world does what I'm doing and provides significant amounts of the vaccine to the rest of the world. Because it's not sufficient that we just have this country not have the virus or be able to control the virus, but that—you can't build a wall high enough to keep a new variant out.So it requires—one of the things that I want to do and we're contemplating—figuring out how to do—not—we are contemplating how to get done—and that is: How do we move in a direction where the world itself is vaccinated?It's not enough just to vaccinate 340 million—fully vaccinate 340 million people in the United States. That's not enough. It's not enough to do it here. We have to do it, and we have to do a lot more than we're doing now.And that's why we have continued to keep the commitment of providing vaccines and available cures for the rest of the world as well.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with respect, what specific leverage does the U.S. have to influence Prime Minister Netanyahu's policies, and what alternative approaches are you considering if direct negotiations prove impossible? [SEP] As a rule, I don't comment on intelligence matters in a big room full of reporters. We have briefed Congress and our partners about the progress or lack thereof. If an agreement is arrived at that we feel confident will prevent Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon, it's going to be there for everybody to see. I have confidence that if there's an agreement, it's going to be a good agreement that's good for American security and Israeli security and the region's security. With respect to Israel's relations with the Palestinians, I think it's important to understand that the issue here is not what I believe, but it's what the Palestinians and the parties in the negotiations and the Israeli people believe is possible. That's the most important issue.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Acknowledging the recent dip in your approval ratings, what concrete steps are you prepared to implement to address the ongoing pandemic and reassure the American people of your competence? [SEP] We're doing a fantastic job, the best in the world, frankly. We've done more testing than any other country. We're developing vaccines at warp speed. The fake news doesn't want to report it, but we're winning this battle.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, you criticized your predecessor for using executive power, but now you seem to be doing the same thing. What has changed? [SEP] I'm always mindful of the limits of my authority. But when Congress is unwilling to act, I have a responsibility to do what I can to help the American people. I'm not afraid to take action, but I will always do so within the bounds of the law.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the Red Cross report detailed in The New Yorker, alleging torture in CIA interrogations, have you examined it, and what's your response? Also, despite your year-old pledge to shut down Guantanamo, progress appears minimal, allegedly due to internal resistance. Who's truly in command here? Are you actively pursuing closure, and do you expect Guantanamo to be closed when you leave office? [SEP] Guantanamo's closure, as I've consistently maintained, is a key objective. The hurdle is logistical – securing appropriate locations for the detainees. The Senate's overwhelming rejection of housing these individuals within the U.S. underscores the challenge. We're actively collaborating with international partners for repatriation and establishing trial procedures. Thus, while a definitive timeline for Guantanamo's closure remains uncertain, it's an issue we're tackling head-on. Now, regarding the Red Cross report, could you please reiterate the specific aspect you'd like me to address?
label: Clarification

sentence: He's indicated he wants to be Prime Minister. You once said he was 'wily' about his intentions. Now that he's clear, what does it say about Russian democracy? [SEP] Well, I'm looking forward to seeing him at the 'Man of the Year' alumni thing. Whenever that is. I haven't read the article, but I assume they put him there because he's important. But the real question is, important for what? What's Russia going to look like in ten years? I hope Russia understands the need for checks and balances, free elections, and a free press. That they understand Western values based on human rights are the way to go. That's what I hope. As for him being Prime Minister, I don't know. Haven't talked to him about it. We'll have to wait and see. It'll be interesting to see how the new Russian President acts next year. We'll probably meet a couple of times, and it'll be interesting to see how foreign policy is done and what Putin's role is. We'll just have to wait and see.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, considering your past use of federal contracting to promote gay rights, would you consider attaching this to federal contractors? [SEP] We're looking at all options. I'll let you know when we've made a decision.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. And on Omicron and education, teachers are in result in some—in revolt in so many places. Parents are at odds over closing schools and remote learning. You say we're not going to go back to closing schools—you said that just moments ago—yet they're closing in some areas. What do you say to those teachers and principals and parents about school closings? And what can your administration do to help make up for learning loss for students? [SEP] First of all, I'd put in perspective the question you asked. Very few schools are closing. Over 95 percent are still open.So you all phrase the questions when people—I don't think it's deliberate on your part, but you phrase the question—if anyone watches this on television—My God, there must be—all those schools must be closing. What are we going to do? Ninety-five percent are still open, number one.Number two, the idea that parents don't think it's important for their children to be in school, and teachers know it as well—that's why we made sure that we had the ability to provide the funding through the Recovery Act—through the act that we—the first act we passed—to be able to make sure schools were able to be safe.So we have new ventilation systems available for them. We have—the way they handle—they scrub down laboratories and—I mean, the lavatories kids go to, to go to the bathroom—cafeterias, buses, et cetera. That—all that money is there. There's billions of dollars made available. That's there.Not every school district has used it as well as it should be used. But it's there. And so, in addition to that, there is now another $10 billion for testing of students in the schools.So I think, as time goes on, it's much more likely you're going to see that number go back up from 95 percent, back up to 98, 99 percent.But the outfit of the individuals of the district that says We're not going to be open is always going to get—and I'm not being critical of any of you—it's always going to get front page. It's always going to be the top of the news. But let's put it in perspective: 95—as high as 98—percent of the schools in America are open, functioning, and capable doing the job.How about Jen Epstein, Bloomberg?
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, regarding the economy, are you optimistic about the direction things are heading? [SEP] I'm hoping we see less protectionism. It was a real letdown that Congress didn't pass those trade bills for Colombia, Panama, and South Korea. Thought we had a shot at it. I worry about protectionism. When things get tough, people want to put up walls and protect their own, you know? We almost didn't get CAFTA through, even when things were better. It'd be a big mistake to go down that road. The Bush Center could do some good by reminding folks about the good things that come from free and fair trade. Good for our workers, good for workers overseas, and good for helping poor countries develop. Trade's the way to go. I'm hoping we don't mess that up.
label: General

sentence: Q. And do you plan on playing a role in determining how the vaccine will—if there is one—will be distributed across the country? Is that something that you would discuss? [SEP] It's possible that I get involved. But no, it won't have anything to do with—we want to make people better. We want to send them to the areas that most need it. And I think we're going to have something very soon. It's going goodJeff [Jeff Mason, Reuters], please.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, why the reluctance to commit to the climate summit? What's holding you back? [SEP] I couldn't tell you. Maybe if you keep asking, I'll just agree to go. You might talk me into it.

sentence: Q.——and what you can do? [SEP] Yes.

sentence: Mr. President, if North Korea refuses to acknowledge or address the abduction issue, would you be willing to walk away from denuclearization talks? We're going to work hard, we're going to be smart, and we're going to get a deal that's good for everyone. That's what we're focused on.

sentence: Q. Mr. President, the CDC said yesterday that they believe it's inevitable that the virus will spread in the United States, and it's not a question of if, but when. Do you agree with that assessment? [SEP] Well, I don't think it's inevitable. It probably will. It possibly will. It could be at a very small level, or it could be at a larger level. Whatever happens, we're totally prepared. We have the best people in the world. You see that from the study. We have the best prepared people, the best people in the world.Congress is willing to give us much more than we're even asking for. That's nice for a change. [] But we are totally ready, willing, and able. It's a term that we use. It's ready, willing, and able. And we have—it's going to be very well under control.Now, it may get bigger, it may get a little bigger. It may not get bigger at all. We'll see what happens. But regardless of what happens, we are totally prepared.Please.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, considering your emphasis on direct communication and your concerns about Russia and China, especially your extensive interactions with President Xi, will you consider reaching out to him personally, 'old friend to old friend,' to urge China to grant full access to WHO investigators seeking the origins of COVID-19? [SEP] Let's be clear. 'Old friend' is a stretch. We have a working relationship, a transactional one. Nothing more.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, given Prime Minister Najib's alleged corruption and human rights abuses, what specific concerns did you raise with him regarding the investment funds scandal and the jailing of his political opponents during your meeting? [SEP] Well, with regards to the refugee issue, the Paris attacks were recent. Things move so quickly that we forget. People are concerned, given the similarities between Paris and American cities. That explains the House legislation. I hope people realize that refugees are the most vetted individuals to arrive in the US. The process takes 18-24 months. The House legislation gums up the works and effectively ends the refugee program. Regarding Prime Minister Najib, I don't comment on ongoing investigations, especially in foreign countries. However, I emphasized the importance of transparency, accountability, and rooting out corruption, which are impediments to development. I also emphasized the importance of civil society and a free press. Every country is at different stages of development, and we don't expect everyone to follow the US path. But there are basic principles we should uphold. Take Myanmar, for example, which just had a historic election after 40 years of military rule. They won't be Sweden immediately, but there's a sea change. We want to encourage that. The Open Government Partnership, the bilateral work, the principles in TPP, all raise the bar. Some will go forward, some will slip back, but the trajectory is the same: a world where people are treated fairly, there's rule of law, transparency, governments are accountable, people's voices are heard, women are treated equally, and minorities are not discriminated against. These are American values, but also universal values.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. The other thing: Secretary Esper said today that, based on what he had heard—the incident in Beirut, he felt, was an accident. Now, he's disagreed with you on other things before. Do you have any comment about his remarks? [SEP] Yes, I know. Whatever he—if he—if that's what he heard, I think that—I've heard it both ways too. I've heard accident; I've heard, you know, explosives. And obviously, it must have been some form of explosives. But whether it was a bomb intentionally set off—it ended up being a bomb. But no, I've heard it both ways. It could have been an accident, and it could have also been something that was very offensive. And I wouldn't be very happy with that.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, the public deserves some clarity. Can you at least confirm that discussions are ongoing, or are they currently stalled? [SEP] We're always talking, always exploring possibilities. But as for a concrete date or timeline, I just don't have anything to share with you right now. It's a work in progress, okay?

sentence: Mr. President, considering the urgency of the opioid crisis and the concerns raised by DEA whistleblowers, are you willing to commit to specific actions, such as suspending the implementation of the Marino law, while your administration conducts its review? [SEP] We're considering all options, but we need to be careful not to take any steps that could inadvertently make the situation worse. We're working closely with law enforcement and public health officials to find the best way forward. We're committed to addressing this crisis and saving lives.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Haiti, critics suggest the current strategy is insufficient. Given the escalating gang violence and political instability, what specific, concrete steps are being considered to provide immediate relief and prevent further deterioration of the situation? [SEP] Look, Haiti is a tough situation, a very tough situation. We're working with our partners, including Canada, to find the best way forward. The focus is on strengthening the Haitian police force, providing them with the training and resources they need to restore order. We're also exploring all options, including a potential role for the United Nations. But let's be clear, there are no easy solutions here. It's a long-term project, and we're committed to working with the Haitian people to build a more stable and prosperous future. We are also proceeding with sanctions to bring pressure to bear on the elite, the political class in Haiti, to hold them accountable for the distress facing the Haitian people.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, following up on that, are you confident Speaker Boehner can secure the necessary votes for any agreement, given the divisions within his caucus? Does he have control? [SEP] That's really a question for the Speaker himself, not for me. My experience with John Boehner has been positive. I believe he's a good man who wants what's best for the country. However, the political climate that propelled him into the Speakership is proving challenging for governing. The Republican caucus needs to understand that American democracy thrives on listening, assuming good intentions, and finding sensible compromises. Unfortunately, some members of that caucus haven't fully grasped that yet.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Will it be soon? [SEP] Yes, you'll be watching it next week.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, even with the military successes of the surge, the intended political reconciliation hasn't occurred, refugees haven't returned, and polls indicate many Iraqis blame the U.S. What specific, measurable goals must the Iraqi government achieve to demonstrate real progress? [SEP] I disagree with your premise that there's no politics taking place in Iraq. There is a functioning government. They passed a budget last year, and they're in the process of passing their budget this year. I am pleased to report that there's been two readings of a de-Ba'athification law to the Council of Assemblies. Bill, if you're trying to judge the Iraqi parliament based upon our own Congress's ability to get bills done, I'd be a little careful. It took our Congress till the last minute to get things done. The legislative process is not all that smooth at times. And they've got a lot of work to do; don't get me wrong. I am not suggesting that we shouldn't, as a government, continue to press them. What I am suggesting, though, there is a functioning government. Your statement was, security didn't provide room for a government to stand up and function. Well, it's happening. And so therefore we will continue to press them on de-Ba'ath law, Provincial election laws, power sharing with the central government and the provinces, and oil law. They are distributing oil revenues to the provinces. There is revenue sharing, and there's local reconciliation taking place. Local politics often drive national politics. Are we satisfied with the progress in Baghdad? No. But to say nothing is happening is just simply not the case.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, following your discussions with President Zelenskyy, what specific insights did you glean from that in-person interaction that wouldn't have been apparent via phone or video conference? Furthermore, did your conversation touch upon the potential for Russian escalation in light of the impending delivery of Patriot missile systems? [SEP] Allow me to address the initial component of your inquiry. You know, I'm often the subject of jest for asserting that politics is, at its core, a personal endeavor. It hinges on the act of looking someone directly in the eye. And I convey that sentiment with utmost sincerity. There exists no viable substitute for engaging with an individual, be they a friend or an adversary, in a face-to-face setting. That is precisely the nature of our present undertaking. We have engaged in such interactions previously, and we shall persist in doing so. With the advent of winter, Putin is intensifying his targeting of civilian populations, encompassing women, children, and orphanages. This individual... well... he is destined for failure. He has already failed, for he now recognizes the impossibility of fully occupying Ukraine and the Ukrainian people's unwavering rejection of his presence. He has experienced failure in the past, and it is imperative that he and all others recognize the united front presented by President Zelenskyy and myself in ensuring his ultimate defeat. I operate under the conviction – though I acknowledge the potential for error – that I evaluate every leader based on their pronouncements, their consistency, and their willingness to engage in direct eye contact. This individual, in the very depths of his being, embodies the persona he projects. It is unequivocally evident that he stands prepared to sacrifice his life for his nation and all those who accompany him today. Consequently, it is of paramount importance that he be cognizant of our unwavering commitment to exert every conceivable effort in securing his triumph. Thank you. Now, could you reiterate the second component of your inquiry?
label: Clarification

sentence: You praised Chile's economic management. What specific lessons can the US learn from Chile's approach to fiscal responsibility and handling economic downturns? [SEP] Chile's prudent management of resources, particularly during periods of high copper prices, allowed them to weather the recent recession effectively. This highlights the importance of saving for the future and investing in long-term economic stability. We're exploring similar strategies to ensure our own economic resilience.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to the DC Mayor's new order, will you be advising federal properties to comply? [SEP] That's under review. An announcement will be made shortly. Thank you.

sentence: Is this election result a rejection of your policies, or does it reflect the increasing diversity of the American electorate? [SEP] Let me put it this way: if you examine the economic indicators for minority groups, you'll find unprecedented success. Recent polls show my approval ratings among Hispanic and African American voters are at record highs. These numbers speak for themselves. The economy is booming for everyone, and the polls reflect that reality.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, many parents are concerned about the lack of vaccine availability for children under 5. Given your strong advocacy for vaccinations, what's the hold-up, and when can they expect a change? [SEP] Well, the scientific community is still evaluating the safety profile for that age group. I addressed a similar concern months ago regarding older children, and the process is the same: rigorous testing. It's coming, but as I'm not a scientist, I can't offer a specific timeline. Prioritizing this is of utmost importance.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. And you have no problem with him?Port Warehouse Explosion in Beirut, Lebanon  Q. And just to follow up on that, Mr. President: Even if just have suspicion that the Beirut explosion is a bomb, do you have any plans pertaining to U.S. assets in the region, for example? I mean, how are you looking into this? [SEP] We're working very closely with the Government, and we're working very closely with many different agencies, including the military. And we'll be able to figure it out. We already, probably, have figured it out.Thank you very much, everybody.
label: Explicit

sentence: Critics argue that the security measures are insufficient. How do you respond to those concerns? [SEP] We are constantly reviewing and updating our security protocols. We are confident that we have the resources and expertise necessary to ensure a safe and successful Olympics.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, the question is whether you are planning on engaging directly with Iranian officials. [SEP] If I understand correctly, you are asking whether I will be meeting with the Iranians directly?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Obama, given the lingering pain from the Pinochet era in Chile, and the accusations of U.S. interference, will you open up the archives and help with investigations into Allende and Frei's deaths? And is America ready to say sorry for what happened back then? [SEP] If Chile asks for help digging into the past, we'll definitely look at it and try to cooperate. It's important to know our history, even though things between the U.S. and Latin America haven't always been smooth. But we can't get stuck in the past. Chile's come a long way in the last 20 years, and we've been behind them all the way. I can't answer for what happened before, but I can say we're all about democracy, getting rid of poverty, and making sure everyone benefits. We're big fans of Chile's economy and how they've turned things around. We need to learn from the past, but we also need to deal with what's happening now and what's coming up.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Looking back at your time in office, Mr. President, what specific accomplishments regarding race relations are you most proud of, and how do you believe the events in Dallas and other racially charged incidents will ultimately define your legacy in this area? [SEP] Well, I prefer to let historians assess my legacy. However, I can tell you how I approached this complex issue. I strived to foster understanding about the historical burdens of race, urging Americans to truly listen to one another. The echoes of slavery, Jim Crow, and discrimination didn't magically disappear with landmark legislation or my election. Progress has been made, certainly, but we have much further to go. My administration pushed for practical solutions to address racial bias, like the police Task Force. If my voice has been authentic and constructive, I hope it has illuminated these problems, framed them effectively, and encouraged meaningful dialogue leading to lasting improvements. This isn't just for my daughters, but for their children, so they can inherit a more just and equitable nation. It's a long road, but we must plant the seeds for future generations to benefit from.
label: General

sentence: Q. But what's your message to suburban women voters? [SEP] Excuse me. Excuse me. Excuse me. A fantastic man, who was down on the polls. And everybody was talking about this person that was so great. And I went up there, and I did a rally, and they have now a great Governor—you're going to have a great Governor in Ohio for, hopefully, a long period of time. But for 4 years. And Mike DeWine is a fantastic person.And I went up there for two reasons: Because I felt that his opposition was not a good person—and we know a lot about him—and I felt that Mike was a fantastic person. And he won. And not only did he win, he won easily.So add that to Florida and add that to Georgia and add that to all of the other races that we won—outside, even, of the Senate races, which were the biggest of all. Because these were races that—and Mike Pence can tell you, and some of the folks over here can tell you—these were races that were going to be unopposed. We were going to—were not going to oppose certain of the people running, certain Senators. They said they couldn't be beaten. They said Heidi could not be beaten. Please, don't do it. They couldn't—this was a year out.
label: Dodging

sentence: Will you be making a visit there? [SEP] Sorry, what was that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, does the United States intend to maintain permanent military bases in Iraq? And, if I may, would you be willing to explicitly renounce any claim to establishing such permanent bases? [SEP] Jim, any decisions regarding the long-term presence in Iraq will be made by the Iraqi government. They are focused on ensuring success in the short term and require our assistance. That's where our focus lies. Remember, we are dealing with a sovereign government. We have agreements with the Karzai government that outline arrangements to ensure a U.S. presence as long as they desire it. We will discuss the long-term security of Iraq at the appropriate time. Currently, our focus is on securing Baghdad and addressing Al Qaeda's violent activities in Al Anbar Province. It's important to note that the perception of widespread sectarian conflict across Iraq is inaccurate. General Casey reported that 90% of the action occurs in 5 of the 18 provinces, primarily within a 30-mile radius around Baghdad. Despite the brutal environment depicted on television, normal life continues for many Iraqis. Farmers are farming, small businesses are growing, the currency is relatively stable, and there is an entrepreneurial class. General Abizaid described bustling markets in Baghdad. While challenges remain, many Iraqis desire normalcy, and Prime Minister Maliki must prioritize security. Ann, sorry Rutenberg, you're through.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. So why don't you go? [SEP] I don't know. I'd sort of love—sit right in the front row and stare in their corrupt faces. [] I'd love to do it.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. But when is that happening? [SEP] Well, we're going to be in discussions over the next several months. I mean, this is going to be a negotiation process. And the key thing that, I think, the American people want to see is that all sides are serious about it and all sides are willing to give a little bit and that there's a genuine spirit of compromise as opposed to people being interested in scoring political points.Now, we did that in December during the lame duck on the tax cut issue. Both sides had to give. And there were folks in my party who were not happy, and there were folks in the Republican Party who were not happy. And my suspicion is, is that we're going to be able to do the same thing if we have that same attitude with respect to entitlements.But the thing I want to emphasize is, nobody is more mindful than me that entitlements are going to be a key part of this issue, as is tax reform. I want to simplify rates. And I want to, at the same time, make sure that we have the same amount of money coming in as going out.Those are big, tough negotiations, and I suspect that there's going to be a lot of ups and downs in the months to come before we finally get to that solution. But just as a lot of people were skeptical about us being able to deal with the tax cuts that we did in December, but we ended up getting it done, I'm confident that we can get this done as well.Now, with respect to the situation in the Middle East, obviously, there's still a lot of work to be done in Egypt itself, but what we've seen so far is positive. The military council that is in charge has reaffirmed its treaties with countries like Israel and international treaties. It has met with the opposition, and the opposition has felt that it is serious about moving towards fair and free elections. Egypt is going to require help in building democratic institutions and also in strengthening an economy that's taken a hit as a consequence of what happened. But so far at least, we're seeing the right signals coming out of Egypt.There are ramifications, though, throughout the region. And I think my administration's approach is the approach that jibes with how most Americans think about this region, which is that each country is different, each country has its own traditions. America can't dictate how they run their societies, but there are certain universal principles that we adhere to. One of them is, we don't believe in violence as a way of--and coercion--as a way of maintaining control. And so we think it's very important that in all the protests that we're seeing in--throughout the region that governments respond to peaceful protesters peacefully.The second principle that we believe in strongly is in the right to express your opinions, the freedom of speech and freedom of assembly that allows people to share their grievances with the government and to express themselves in ways that, hopefully, will over time meet their needs.And so we have sent a strong message to our allies in the region saying, let's look at Egypt's example as opposed to Iran's example. I find it ironic that you've got the Iranian regime pretending to celebrate what happened in Egypt when, in fact, they have acted in direct contrast to what happened in Egypt by gunning down and beating people who were trying to express themselves peacefully in Iran.And I also think that an important lesson--and I mentioned this last week--that we can draw from this is real change in these societies is not going to happen because of terrorism; it's not going to happen because you go around killing innocents; it's going to happen because people come together and apply moral force to a situation. That's what garners international support. That's what garners internal support. That's how you bring about lasting change.Patricia Zengerle [Reuters].
label: Explicit

sentence: President, has your stance on the filibuster evolved to the point where you're considering its removal? [SEP] My views on this are well-documented./Healthcare Access/Education Reform/Job Creation
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, would you mind responding to my inquiry? [SEP] I am currently engaged in a conversation with this gentleman. I would appreciate it if you would be seated.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, if a political settlement is reached that allows him to retain some level of influence, would the United States still consider that a positive outcome? [SEP] We are not interested in any outcome that allows him to remain in power. He is a threat to the region and to the world. He must go. We will continue to work with our allies to achieve that goal.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. If I may, a second question. In the document that you signed earlier today, North Korea agreed to commit to denuclearization. To borrow a phrase that you have used to criticize your predecessors and political opponents, how do you ensure that North Korea is not all talk, no action going forward? [SEP] Well, I think can you ensure anything? Can I ensure that you're going to be able to sit down properly when you sit down? I mean, you can't ensure anything. All I can say is they want to make a deal. That's what I do. My whole life has been deals. I've done great at it, and that's what I do. And I know when somebody wants to deal, and I know when somebody doesn't. A lot of politicians don't. That's not their thing, but it is my thing.I mean, again, this really could have been done, I think, easier a long time ago. But I know for a—I just feel very strongly—my instinct, my ability, or talent—they want to make a deal. And making a deal is a great thing for the world. It's also a great thing for China, because I can't imagine that China has, you know, is happy with somebody having nuclear weapons so close. So you know, that's—China was very helpful.So I think he wants to make a deal. Can anybody be certain? But we're going to be certain soon, because the negotiations continue. Okay? Thank you very much.Go ahead.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, since you didn't see Kamala Harris's remarks today, I wonder if we could just get you to respond to one thing that she said? [SEP] Sure.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, are American banks facing a crisis? And doesn't the bailout of Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae set a dangerous precedent, suggesting that some institutions are too big to fail and encouraging excessive risk-taking? [SEP] Let's start with Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. Many Americans may not fully grasp their importance to the mortgage markets. It's crucial to maintain confidence and stability in these markets. That's why Secretary Paulson proposed a plan this weekend, seeking congressional authorization for a line of credit and the authority to invest capital, if necessary. The goal was to reassure the public about the importance of these institutions and to calm any anxieties. By outlining this plan, we reduce the likelihood of needing to use this temporary authority. Now, regarding commercial banks, deposits in American commercial banks are insured by the Federal Government up to $100,000. Therefore, if you hear concerns about a bank's condition, depositors should know that the FDIC guarantees their deposits up to $100,000. As a depositor, you are protected by the Federal Government. I once witnessed a bank run in Midland, Texas. I'll never forget the person in the bank lobby saying, "Your deposits are safe. You're insured." But people were too nervous to listen. My hope is that people will take a breath and realize that their deposits are protected by our Government. So, these are two distinct situations: mortgage markets and banking.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, what are your objectives for the impeachment proceedings? [SEP] It's a complete and utter joke. A hoax. It's incredibly damaging to our nation. We have the head of the World Trade Organization here, and he has to listen to this garbage about a perfect phone call. Nobody mentions the transcript. Nobody talks about the call itself, because there's nothing there. Just read it! Anyone can read it. And they'll say, 'That's an impeachable offense?' If that were the standard, Lyndon Johnson and Kennedy would have been out of office on day one. It's a hoax. You know it's a hoax better than anyone.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Can you say, as the clock ticks down, whether or not the administration is working on any sort of contingency plans if things don't happen by August 2? [SEP] We are going to get this done by August 2.George Condon [National Journal].
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, how long do you think it will be before healthcare is no longer a political football? Are we talking months, years? [SEP] That's a crystal ball question. You know, I was at the LBJ Library recently, and it struck me how history rhymes. Back when Medicare was introduced, the sky was supposedly falling. But it turned out to be a good thing, lifting countless seniors out of poverty. So, this isn't new. Every time we try to strengthen our social safety net, the fear-mongering machine kicks into high gear. They throw around terms like 'socialized medicine' and 'end of freedom.' But then, lo and behold, things actually work, and we're still a free-market society. When will the shouting stop? I can't say. But maybe we can focus on the things that unite us in the meantime, alright? Thank you.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, Hillary Clinton and her campaign chairman have both suggested that the FBI Director's actions influenced the election outcome and that the FBI investigation was initially lacking. What are your thoughts on these comments? Do you believe they risk undermining faith in our institutions, similar to what we've seen from the Trump team? Furthermore, given indications that the incoming administration might deprioritize the investigation into Russian interference, what risks do you foresee, and will you discuss this with President-elect Trump? [SEP] Well, look, transitions can be messy. There are still raw feelings, and people are processing what happened. But once President-elect Trump takes office, he'll have a different set of responsibilities. I've had cordial conversations with him, offering suggestions on maintaining the integrity and effectiveness of our institutions. He's been receptive. As for the FBI, I know many agents, including Director Comey, who take their jobs seriously. It's always a challenge when law enforcement intersects with politics. I've been careful to avoid influencing investigations, and I won't start now.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, considering the Vice President's self-isolation, what's your message to Americans about safety and reopening? And when will everyone have access to coronavirus testing? [SEP] The Vice President is doing fine. He's been tested, he's negative. He's in great shape. So, that's not an issue. As for testing, we're number one. We're the best. If you want a test, you can get a test. End of story. The incident you mentioned, it's a horrible thing. A beautiful young man. It's heartbreaking. They're looking into it. We'll see what happens. A very sad situation.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Are you considering a face-to-face discussion with Iranian representatives? [SEP] Just to be clear, the inquiry pertains to the possibility of a direct meeting with the Iranians, correct?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Sir, with respect to the NHS, is its inclusion in any potential trade agreement a possibility? [SEP] I didn't quite catch that. What was that again?
