And so with this in mind, I thought that it would be helpful to set up a permanent liaison office in both Seoul and Pyongyang.As for the summit meeting between myself and Chairman Kim, I will agree to it when the need is real. And I already said publicly that I am willing to meet with him—not just once, but many times—but if the meeting will yield substantial and real results. I believe only when that is possible, I am ready to meet with him and have sincere dialogue, because that will help to bring about peace and stability of the peninsula.So basically, I do hold that thought, but I'm not suggesting that—to have a meeting with Chairman Kim anytime soon. If the need arises, again, I'm ready to meet with him. Steven Lee [Steven Lee Myers, New York Times].
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, you've discussed the debt ceiling with economists. Have you been collaborating with prominent U.S. business figures to lobby Congress for an increase? If so, could you name some of the individuals you've consulted? [SEP] I've had numerous discussions with business leaders, and they generally acknowledge the necessity of finding a resolution. However, they often hesitate to publicly advocate for specific measures due to their ongoing business dealings with Congress. It's a reflection of the political climate. While some, like Warren Buffett, have been outspoken, many are reluctant to be as forthright as I would prefer regarding the need for both spending cuts and revenue increases.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, in light of the midterm results, could you share your current perspective on the job security of your Attorney General and Deputy Attorney General? [SEP] I'd prefer to defer that discussion to a more appropriate juncture. We are currently assessing a multitude of factors, including the composition of the Cabinet. While I am generally content with my Cabinet, we are exploring potential candidates for various positions, a common practice following midterm elections. I deliberately refrained from initiating any changes prior to the election. However, I must emphasize that, for the most part, I am exceptionally satisfied with my Cabinet. Mike Pompeo, for instance, has seamlessly integrated into his role and has performed admirably.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, the continuing resolution deadline is fast approaching. Given the linked funding for Iraq, Syria, Ebola, and general government functions, what's your level of concern about a potential shutdown? How does this influence your immigration decisions? [SEP] I have faith in Senator McConnell's word that we will not see a government shutdown. There's no reason for one. We've been there, done that, and it hurt the country and everyone in Washington. It always resolves itself the same way, so it's unproductive. I believe Senator McConnell and Speaker Boehner understand this. More broadly, democracy means disagreement. Our system allows for a Congress and President from different parties with differing views. The key is how we handle it. The right way is to fight for our positions on disagreements, then work together where we agree. That's how it was with Reagan and the Democratic Congress. They didn't let disagreements stop them from working together. I expect the same here. Some Republicans disagree with me on immigration reform, and that's their right. But shutting down the government over it makes no sense, just like me shutting it down every time they try to repeal healthcare. Let's focus on governing.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding voting rights, Republican legislatures are passing restrictive bills impacting minority and young voters, the very people who helped elect you. Are you worried that if you don't pass voting rights legislation, your party will lose seats in 2022? [SEP] What worries me is the sheer un-American nature of these actions. It's appalling. States banning water for voters in line, ending voting at 5 PM when people get off work, restricting absentee ballots under strict conditions. It's all designed to suppress the vote. I'm focused on three things: passing the House legislation, educating the public, and rallying Republican voters who find this behavior despicable. These aren't the elected officials; these are the voters outside this White House. I believe we can stop this because it's a blatant attack on democracy. It makes Jim Crow look like child's play. I'll do everything I can with my allies in Congress to prevent this from becoming law.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the Republican nominee's recent statements regarding the Khan family and his openness to recognizing Russia's annexation of Crimea, do you question his suitability for the presidency? Secondly, concerning Libya, you've previously stated that your biggest mistake was the lack of planning following the 2011 NATO intervention. Is your recent decision to bomb ISIS in Libya a direct consequence of that oversight? [SEP] Look, I've already stated my concerns about the Republican nominee's fitness for office, and frankly, he continues to validate those concerns. Attacking a Gold Star family who have sacrificed so much for our country is beyond the pale. His apparent lack of understanding of critical issues in Europe, the Middle East, and Asia demonstrates a profound lack of preparedness for this job. And it's not just my opinion; leading Republicans, including the Speaker of the House, the Senate Majority Leader, and figures like John McCain, have repeatedly denounced his statements. The question they need to ask themselves is this: If you consistently and strongly condemn his words, why do you continue to endorse him? What does it say about your party that he is your standard-bearer? This isn't a matter of occasional missteps; it's a daily and weekly occurrence where they distance themselves from his pronouncements. There must come a point where they say, 'This is not someone I can support for President,' even if he claims to be a member of my party. Their failure to do so renders their denunciations hollow. I don't doubt their sincerity, but there must be a point where they recognize that someone who makes such statements lacks the judgment, temperament, and understanding required for the most powerful position in the world. Many people rely on the White House to get things right, and this goes beyond mere policy disagreements. I understand that they profoundly disagree with me or Hillary Clinton on tax policy or foreign policy, but I never doubted the competence of previous Republican Presidents. I disagreed with Mitt Romney and John McCain on certain issues, but I never questioned their ability to do the job. Had they won, I would have been disappointed, but I would have assured Americans that they would uphold norms, rules, common sense, decency, and possess sufficient knowledge of economic policy, foreign policy, and our constitutional traditions to govern effectively. This situation is different, and it's not just my opinion. Many prominent Republicans share this view. There must come a point where they say, 'Enough.' Otherwise, the entire Republican Party effectively endorses and validates Mr. Trump's positions, which I believe do not represent the views of many Republicans. Regarding Libya, I've consistently stated that we did the right thing in preventing a potential massacre under a U.N. mandate. However, we collectively failed to adequately plan for the aftermath to ensure security and peace. The good news is that we now have the beginnings of a Government of National Accord committed to uniting factions and establishing security. At their request, and after significant progress against ISIS, we are working in partnership to prevent ISIS from gaining a foothold in Libya. They recognize ISIS as a threat to their national interests, and we hope that after defeating ISIS, they can unite the country. The Europeans and other nations also have a vested interest in Libyan stability, which is crucial for addressing migration crises and humanitarian tragedies.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Russia's asserted withdrawal from Kherson, do you view this as a possible pivot in the conflict? And do you think Ukraine is now in a position to begin peace talks with Moscow? [SEP] First off, isn't it interesting that they waited until after the election to make that announcement? We've known for some time that they were going to do that. And it's evidence of the fact that they have some real problems—the Russian military. Number two, whether or not that leads to, at a minimum, it will lead to time for everyone to recalibrate their positions over the winter's period. And it remains to be seen whether or not there'll be a judgment made as to whether or not Ukraine is prepared to compromise with Russia. I'm going to be going to the G-20. I'm told that President Putin is not likely to be there, but other world leaders are going to be there in Indonesia. And we're going to have an opportunity to see what the next steps may be.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Yes, thank you, sir. What is your reaction to Alex Rodriguez's admission that he used steroids as a member of the Texas Rangers? [SEP] I think it's depressing news on top of what's been a flurry of depressing items when it comes to Major League Baseball. And if you're a fan of Major League Baseball, I think it tarnishes an entire era to some degree. And it's unfortunate, because I think there are a lot of ballplayers who played it straight. And the thing I'm probably most concerned about is the message that it sends to our kids.What I'm pleased about is Major League Baseball seems to finally be taking this seriously, to recognize how big of a problem this is for the sport. And that our kids, hopefully, are watching and saying, you know what, there are no shortcuts; that when you try to take shortcuts, you may end up tarnishing your entire career, and that your integrity is not worth it. That's the message I hope is communicated.All right, Helen [Helen Thomas, Hearst Newspapers]. This is my inaugural moment here. [] I'm really excited.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. A question on climate and energy. Can the world and others be confident that you will be able to follow or do—make good on the promises on climate change that you will—that you have made, when you're at Glasgow, without a vote having taken place on your bill?And on the same topic, climate: Some NGOs are already saying that the G-20 commitments today were underwhelming. How do you respond to their criticism that the G-20 response is not a good sign for COP26? [SEP] I'll answer both questions.Number one, I believe we will pass my Build Back Better plan, and I believe we will pass the infrastructure bill. Combined, they have $900 billion in climate resistance—in dealing with climate and resilience. And it's the largest investment in the history of the world that's ever occurred, and it's going to pass, in my view. But we'll see. We'll see.You know, you've all believed it wouldn't happen from the very beginning, the moment I announced it, and you always seem amazed when it's alive again. Well, you may turn out to be right; maybe it won't work. But I believe we'll see by the end of next week, at home, that it's passed.With regard to the—and by the way, that infrastructure bill delivers an awful lot of things in terms of everything from tax credits for electric vehicles, to making sure we are able to invest, literally, billions of dollars in everything from highways, roads, bridges, public transit, airports, et cetera. But we'll see.The—and with regard to the disappointment: The disappointment relates to the fact that Russia and—and including not only Russia, but China, basically didn't show up in terms of any commitments to deal with climate change. And there's a reason why people should be disappointed in that. I found it disappointing myself.But what we did do—we passed a number of things here to end the subsidization of coal. We made commitments here from across the board, all of us, in terms of what we're going to bring to the G26 [COP26].*And, I think, you know, as that old bad—that old trite saying goes, The proof of the pudding will be in the eating. I think you're going to see we've made significant progress, and more has to be done. But it's going to require us to continue to focus on what China is not doing, what Russia is not doing, and what Saudi Arabia is not doing.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, Robert Novak recently penned an article suggesting you're more isolated than Nixon during Watergate. How do you respond? [SEP] Isolated, you say? I'm curious, what's his definition of 'isolated' in this context? What benchmarks is he using?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, given the difficulties your administration is encountering in passing stimulus measures, some critics argue that you lack the credibility to advise European leaders on economic recovery. How do you respond to these criticisms, and what specific strategies are you employing to overcome the obstacles to your economic agenda? [SEP] We're focused on doing what's right for the American people. We believe that our economic agenda is the best way to create jobs, grow the economy, and strengthen the middle class. We're working with Congress to pass our proposals, and we're confident that we'll be successful. We're also working with our partners around the world to promote global economic stability. We're all in this together, and we need to work together to find solutions. We're not going to let the critics distract us from our goals. We're going to stay focused on doing what's right for the American people.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, one of the reasons Anthem said--Anthem BlueCross says that it's raising its premiums is because so many people are dropping out of individual coverage because the economy is so bad, and that leaves the people in the pool who are people who need medical care driving up costs. One of the reasons why businesses are not expanding right now, in addition to some of the credit issues you've talked about, at least according to business leaders, is they say there's an uncertainty of what they need to plan for because of the energy bill, because of health care. That's what they say. I'm not saying it's true or not, but that's what they say. What do you say when you hear that? [SEP] Well, I think that the biggest uncertainty has been we just went through the worst recession since the Great Depression, and people weren't sure whether the financial system was going to melt down and whether we were going to tip into a endless recession. So let's be clear about the sources of uncertainty in terms of business investment over the last several years: a huge contraction, trillions of dollars of losses in people's 401(k)s, people have a lot of debt coming out of the previous decade that they still haven't worked out, the housing market losing a whole bunch of value.So the good news is that where we were contracting by 6 percent, the economy is now growing by 6 percent. The CEOs I talked to are saying they are now making investments, and I anticipate that they're going to start hiring at a more rapid clip. What I've also heard is them saying that we would like to feel like Washington is working and able to get some things done.There are two ways of interpreting the issue of uncertainty. One way would be to say, well, you know what, we'll just go back to what we were doing before on, let's say, the financial markets. We won't have the regulations that we need; we won't make any changes in terms of too big to fail. That will provide certainty, until the next financial crisis.That's not the kind of certainty, I think, that the financial markets need. The kind of certainty they need is for us to go ahead and agree on a bipartisan effort to put some rules of the road in place so that consumers are protected in the financial markets, so that we don't have banks that are too big to fail, that we have ways of winding them down and protecting the overall system without taxpayer bailouts. That requires legislation. The sooner we can get that done, the better.The same would be true when it comes to health care. A lot of CEOs I hear from will say, Boy, we'd like you to get health care settled one way or another, but they will acknowledge that when they open up their latest invoice for their premiums, and they find out that those premiums have gone up 20 percent or 25 percent, that's the kind of uncertainty that also tamps down business investment.So I guess my answer would be this: The sooner the business community has a sense that we've got our act together here in Washington and can move forward on big, serious issues in a substantive way without a lot of posturing and partisan wrangling, I think the better off the entire country is going to be. I absolutely agree on that.What I think is important is not to buy into this notion that is perpetrated by some of the business interests that got a stake in this who are fighting financial reform, for example, to say, boy, we'd be doing fine if we just didn't try to regulate the banks. That, I think, would be a mistake. All right?
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President Bush, given America's global influence and your actions in Iraq following UN resolutions, why not insist Israel adhere to UN resolutions regarding Palestine, ending the occupation and enabling a Palestinian-Israeli solution? And President Abbas, did you request President Bush to urge Israel to halt settlements for successful negotiations? [SEP] Hold on, back up. What exactly did you say about the UN?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Libya, are you prepared to use any means necessary to ensure Gaddafi's departure from power? If not, why the apparent shift from the hands-off approach taken in other similar uprisings? [SEP] First thing's first, we got our people out. Then, boom, biggest financial seizure ever. Sanctions, UN, the whole deal. We're squeezing Gaddafi, isolating him. Humanitarian aid's flowing. NATO's talking about everything – watching him 24/7, arms embargo, maybe even a no-fly zone. Hillary's meeting with the opposition, and we're sending someone to help them out. Everything's on the table. We moved fast on the sanctions. Gaddafi's gotta go, for our sake and theirs. I'm talking to the generals about the military stuff, gotta be careful. Gotta keep the world on our side.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the agreement with Iraq, what specific benchmarks must be met before the transition to 'overwatch' can be completed, and what assurances can you provide regarding the safety of American troops during this transition? [SEP] Look, we're working hand-in-glove with the Iraqi government to establish a framework that addresses a multitude of concerns. The transition to 'overwatch,' as you call it, is contingent on a number of factors, including the capabilities of the Iraqi security forces and the overall security environment. We're aiming for a situation where U.S. forces are primarily focused on training, logistics, and special operations. Now, as for the safety of our troops, that's always paramount. We're negotiating the necessary authorities and protections to ensure their well-being. These discussions are ongoing, and we expect to have a finalized agreement soon. It's a complex situation, but we're committed to finding a solution that works for both countries. What else is on your mind?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Can you provide any insight into how long Israel intends to postpone the West Bank annexation? [SEP] The situation is fluid. We're prioritizing peace. The agreement with the Emirates is a major achievement. We're working on the specifics. The annexation is something we'll revisit later. We're giving peace a chance.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the looming fiscal cliff, is there any conceivable scenario where we fail to reach a resolution by year's end? And regarding Iran, are you planning a final diplomatic effort to address their nuclear program, potentially involving direct talks? [SEP] Well, let's be frank, a fiscal cliff outcome is imaginable. If Congressional gridlock persists, even after the election's clear message, and we can't even agree on tax cuts for the middle class, then those families will face a significant tax increase. That's going to sting, impacting holiday spending and, consequently, business investment and hiring, potentially triggering another recession. It's avoidable and unnecessary. My priority is immediate certainty for middle-class families, ensuring 98% of those earning under $250,000 and 97% of small businesses don't see a tax hike. That's doable. Then, we can tackle tax reform, close loopholes, simplify the system, and address entitlements. I'm prepared to make substantial commitments to deficit reduction. I've been immersed in this for years; the math is straightforward. Tough choices are necessary, but we can protect middle-class families, seniors, and those with disabilities while investing in growth areas like research and education. As some Republicans have acknowledged, a modest tax increase on the wealthy won't cripple them. It won't deter business investment. So, we know the path forward. It hinges on bipartisan cooperation, putting the American people first. I hope that prevails. On Iran, I remain committed to a diplomatic solution. My stance hasn't wavered: we won't allow Iran to acquire a nuclear weapon. But a diplomatic window remains open. We've implemented the most stringent sanctions ever, impacting Iran's economy. They should be able to access peaceful nuclear power while adhering to international obligations and assuring the world they're not pursuing a nuclear weapon. I will intensify efforts in the coming months to foster dialogue between Iran and the international community. Whether Iran seizes this opportunity remains to be seen, but it's the preferred course.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, you tweeted that Dr. Birx was taking bait from Speaker Pelosi. Could you elaborate on that, considering she was simply presenting factual data about the pandemic's current state? [SEP] I think we're doing very well, and I think that we have done as well as any nation. If you really look—if you take a look at what's going on, especially now with all these flareups in nations that they were talking about—and don't forget: We're much bigger, other than India and China. China is having a massive flareup right now. India has a tremendous problem. Other countries have problems.And I notice that in the news, in the evening news, I never read about that. In any of the news, I don't read about the other countries. You're starting to see that other countries are having very big flareups, countries that thought they were over it. Like, we thought we might be over it in Florida, and then, all of a sudden, it comes back. They do come back.But I think we're doing very well. I told Dr. Birx I think we're doing very well. She was in my office a little while ago. She's a person I have a lot of respect for. I think Nancy Pelosi has treated her very badly—very, very badly. Very nasty. And I'm just referring to the fact that I thought that, really, they should say the job we've done, whether it's on ventilators or testing—we've tested now over 60 million people. No other country is even close to that. We've tested 60 million people with great—in many cases, about 50 percent now rapid fire, meaning 5- to 15- to 20-minute test, where you get the result almost immediately. Nobody has anything like that. Nobody. And I think we're just doing very well.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, to clarify your earlier statement regarding the Senkaku Islands and the mutual defense treaty with Japan, are you explicitly stating that the United States would intervene militarily if China were to engage in military action against those islands? Furthermore, given the past situation in Syria, where a perceived lack of enforcement of red lines damaged U.S. credibility, how do you ensure that this commitment is perceived as credible? Finally, concerning North Korea, are you signaling a firm warning against further nuclear tests? And Prime Minister Abe, do you still trust President Obama's security guarantees, considering the West's inability to prevent Russian actions in Ukraine? Thank you. President Obama. [SEP] Let me just make sure I understand the core of your question. You're asking if our treaty obligations to Japan regarding the Senkaku Islands are rock solid, if we've learned from the Syria situation, and if we're sending a clear message to North Korea, correct?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, Build Back Better, pandemic, 'big chunks,' individual portions, Supreme Court, domestic flights – your thoughts? [SEP] Look, the Supreme Court ruling was unfortunate, but businesses are stepping up. That's point one. What was point zero?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, why the resistance to teaching this history accurately in schools, and do you believe slavery itself should be taught? [SEP] Look, I want everyone to know our history, good and bad. I'm not into this cancel culture nonsense. If you don't learn from the bad stuff, it could happen again. So, yeah, study it carefully and accurately. But they're trying to rewrite our history, revisionist history. That's why they're tearing down monuments. I saw something the other day about renaming the Washington Monument. This is crazy stuff. We're not doing that. Never going to happen. Anyway, happy Labor Day. We're doing great on vaccines and the pandemic, the plague that came in from China, which they should have never let happen.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, before I ask about Russia, can you quickly clarify something? Is the Meng Wanzhou situation going to be put on hold indefinitely as well, or could the U.S. potentially withdraw the extradition? [SEP] Concerning what? On what subject?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, critics point to your frequent golfing trips as evidence that you're not focused on more pressing matters. When will you make time to personally meet with Gold Star families? [SEP] Indeed.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. What assurances can you give that this executive action won't be neutered by Republican opposition, and is the target still around 2 million people? [SEP] We're prepared for all contingencies. The details will be clear when we announce it. Stay tuned.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Mayor Bowser's recent mandate in DC, what factors are influencing the decision-making process regarding its implementation on federal properties, including the White House and military bases? Can you provide a timeline for when a final determination will be made? [SEP] We're taking a comprehensive approach to this issue and will share our decision with the public in the near future. Next question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with respect, if it's such a drain on resources and detrimental to the nation, what's preventing you from ending it immediately? [SEP] I've answered that question. Move on.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding access for journalists to the facilities housing migrant children, when can we expect full transparency and access to these locations, particularly those where children are being housed in close quarters? Will you commit to a firm timeline? [SEP] Look, transparency is paramount, and it's something we're absolutely committed to. The situation is dynamic, and we're working diligently to ensure everything is in place before opening the doors fully. My team has been on the ground, and I've intentionally avoided visiting myself to prevent becoming a distraction. Rest assured, comprehensive access will be granted as soon as we've finalized the necessary arrangements. We want to get this right.
label: General

sentence: Q. We do all we can. [Laughter]Sir, was the Government too slow in this case to recognize the subprime mortgage problem? And what specific expects—do you expect to see with the economy on the proposals that will be coming later this week? [SEP] We've been working on this since August, Ed. And ours is a belief that, one, we shouldn't bail out lenders. And so, in other words, we shouldn't be using taxpayers' money to say, okay, you made a lousy loan; therefore, we're going to subsidize you.Secondly, that we recognize there's—this is a—the home mortgage industry is a little more complex than in the past. The old days, you'd go to your local savings and loans, say, or your bank, get your home mortgage, and if you had a problem, you go back to the banker that loaned you the money and renegotiate if possible. Now what has happened, as you know, people have taken those mortgages and bundled them up as securities. And somebody else owns the mortgage; it's not the originating bank; it's somebody else owns the mortgage.And so Secretary Paulson is working with a more complex industry than we've had in the past. And that's why it's taken a while, Ed, because not only do you have the lender, you now have a whole service industry that has arisen that will, hopefully, help people stay in their homes—that's their job—but you've also got people all around the world who now own U.S. mortgages, invest—and assets that are U.S. mortgage—bundles of U.S. mortgages.And so it's a complex assignment. I'm pleased with the work that the Secretary is doing—both Secretaries are doing. I think they're making pretty good progress.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, with your third budget and year in office approaching, and your stated willingness to be a one-term president for the sake of doing what's right, why not invite Republicans to negotiate now? What steps are you taking to foster the cooperation needed for bipartisanship? And, will the markets remain patient for two more years? [SEP] Hold on, Jackie, that's a lot to unpack! [] My brain's getting full here.
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, would you allow me to proceed with an additional inquiry? [SEP] So, you're wondering if you can ask another question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, your critics argue that your proposed tax cuts disproportionately benefit the wealthy. How do you respond to these concerns about economic inequality? [SEP] These tax cuts are for everyone. They're going to create jobs, boost the economy, and help the middle class. The rising tide lifts all boats, believe me.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, the intelligence community says Russia is meddling in the election to hurt Joe Biden, and China is considering meddling to hurt you. Do you believe that? And what's your plan to address it? [SEP] Could be. Very much so. I think the last person Russia wants to see in office is Donald Trump because nobody has been tougher on Russia than I have, ever.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, considering the global interconnectedness of technology, how do you balance the need for national security with the potential for economic disruption and the impact on international relations when considering banning Chinese tech companies? [SEP] We're always looking at the big picture, but national security comes first. We have to protect our country. If that means making some tough decisions, we're going to do it. We're not going to let anyone take advantage of us, not China, not anyone.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. The Iraqi Prime Minister is coming in tomorrow to meet with you. And how do you feel about this notion that Iraq can once again become the buffer between Iranian influence and Russian influence in the Middle East? Do you feel that under this Prime Minister that that's possible once again? What are your thoughts on it? [SEP] Well, this is a man that I get along with very well. We're largely out of Iraq. We're down to a very few soldiers. I said we're getting out of these endless wars, these ridiculous, endless wars. We should have never been there in the first place. I think it was the worst decision made in the history of our country. Should have never been there. In the Middle East, we should have never been. But we're getting out rapidly, out of—you know, over the course of 3 years. And getting out—it's very sticky getting out. And some people agree, and many people don't agree, but I think most people very much agree.We're doing very well in our negotiations with Afghanistan. We're getting out. We're down to a much smaller number of people left there. And you know, I greet men and women coming home, and coming home after they've been hit. I've also greeted many, many at Dover, greeted many bodies coming back in.And we've been there 19 years, and we're basically policemen. We're acting as police, as opposed to soldiers. And they're going to have to police their own states, and they've been doing that for thousands of years. But it's time, after 19 years, that our soldiers come home.They've done an incredible job, but you know, they don't—they're not allowed to fight to win. And maybe they shouldn't be, because a lot of the people—it's not their fault. But with the Taliban and with going to Iraq—again, we're down in Afghanistan; very low numbers. And that'll be taking place.And I let them know, Do anything, and you'll be hit like you've never hit—be hit—been hit before. So we're doing very well. Syria, the same thing. Remember when I took all of the soldiers off of the border between Syria and Turkey. Right? And everybody said, Oh, this is—that was 2 years ago. It was a long time ago. They said: Oh, this is terrible, terrible, terrible. We're going to leave.Why do we have our soldiers between Syria and Turkey? Turkey can definitely take care of itself. I have a very good relationship with President Erdogan. And Syria has been fighting forever. And I say, Why are we guarding their border? And I brought our soldiers back home. I got them out. And guess what? Nothing's happened. They've been fighting like they have been for a thousand years. Okay? Nothing's happened. And nobody mentions that.Everybody said, This is going to be a disaster. There's no disaster; nothing's happened. And so we're getting out of the endless wars. And we are building a military, the likes of which the world has never seen: $2½ trillion we have spent. And we, hopefully, don't ever have to use it. But we want to focus on a much bigger picture, because we have a much bigger picture.It's—when you look at what China is doing, when you look at what Russia is doing, when you look at what some other countries are doing, we want to be ready just in case there is a catastrophe. We don't want to see that; we don't want to ever use it. We've rebuilt our military: new missiles and new rockets and new tanks and new everything. New everything—$2½ trillion—all made in the U.S.A.And we've upgraded incredibly our nuclear capability. And some of our nuclear needed nourishment. It needed new strength. And we've upgraded it very, very significantly. I mean, to a level that nobody would even believe. And hopefully, we don't—you pray to God we never have to use it. Okay? But we've never been in a position where we've been this strong.Please.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. If I could just ask you about foreign policy, Mr. President. Overnight, we learned that North Korea tested two ballistic missiles. What, if any, actions will you take? And what is your red line on North Korea? [SEP] Let me say that, number one, U.N. Resolution 1718 was violated by those particular missiles that were tested—number one. We're consulting with our allies and partners. And there will be responses—if they choose to escalate, we will respond accordingly.But I'm also prepared for some form of diplomacy, but it has to be conditioned upon the end result of denuclearization. So that's what we're doing right now: consulting with our allies.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Biden, following up on the security situation in Asia, what concrete agreements were reached with Prime Minister Kishida regarding a potential conflict in the Taiwan Strait? Did the U.S. request specific actions from Japan, and how did Prime Minister Kishida respond regarding Japan's defense capabilities? [SEP] No.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: If Americans are dying daily, why are you focused on a global competition? [SEP] The world is suffering, not just us. Perhaps you should ask the originators of this pandemic about their role. They might have a different take. Next.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Syria and North Korea, could you provide a more concrete timeline for troop withdrawal and clarify your assessment of Kim Jong-un's behavior? [SEP] Let's start with North Korea. Everyone thought I was wrong, but after 25 years of nothing, a lot is happening. It's going to be positive for everyone. I started at a level I shouldn't have had to start at. As for Syria, I'd love to get out. We've obliterated ISIS. But we don't want to give Iran open season to the Mediterranean. We'll be coming home relatively soon. We want to leave a strong and lasting footprint.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, are you implying that I should be directing my questions to China instead? [SEP] I'm not implying anything about you specifically. I'm saying that to anyone who would ask a question like that.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, North Korea agreed to denuclearize. How do you make sure this isn't just another empty promise? [SEP] Can you guarantee anything in life? No. But they want a deal. I know deals. I'm good at deals. And I know when someone's serious. This could have been done a long time ago, but they want to make a deal. It's good for the world, good for China. We'll know soon enough as negotiations continue.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, do you recall whether you supported Israel's 1981 strike on the Iraqi nuclear reactor near Baghdad? [SEP] That was a long time ago. I honestly don't have a specific recollection of my position on that particular event. My focus at the time was on other matters.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. President Obama, regarding Chile, despite your praise for its economic growth and democratic shift, the wounds of the Pinochet dictatorship remain. Many believe the U.S. bears responsibility for its role in those difficult years. Will your administration support investigations into the deaths of Allende and Frei Montalva, and consider apologizing for past U.S. actions in Chile? [SEP] We're certainly willing to consider any requests from the Chilean government for information about the past, and we're committed to cooperation. Understanding our history is essential. The U.S.-Latin America relationship has had its share of challenges. However, while we learn from the past, we shouldn't be held back by it. Chile's progress in recent decades has been remarkable, and the U.S. has been a strong supporter. I can't speak to all past policies, but I can speak to the present and future. The U.S. is dedicated to democracy, eradicating poverty, and promoting inclusive development. We support Chile's open markets and the economic advancements made by and President Bachelet. So, let's learn from history, but not be limited by it. We have present and future challenges to address.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning al-Libi, critics suggest that the method of his capture raises concerns about due process. How do you respond to those concerns? [SEP] Look, the bottom line is this: we brought a dangerous terrorist to justice. We followed all appropriate procedures. I'm not going to get into the specifics of intelligence operations. But I can assure you that we acted within the bounds of the law, and with the safety and security of the American people as our top priority.
label: General

sentence: Q. Just to follow up on that, sir, real quick? The President. Go ahead, Jon.School Reopening Efforts/National Economy/Coronavirus Transmission Among Children  Q. Mr. President, do you plan to do a national strategy to help schools reopen and reopen safely? And regarding the children in your family—your son, your grandchildren—are you comfortable—do you plan to have them back in person, in school this fall? [SEP] Yes. Well, I am comfortable with that. And we do have a national strategy, but, as you know, ultimately, it's up to the Governors of the States. I think most Governors, many Governors want these schools to open. I would like to see the schools open, especially when you see statistics like this. We have great statistics on young people and on safety. So we would like to see schools open. We want to see the economy open.We just had a report, literally as I walked in, that we set an alltime record on housing price increases, up, I think they said, 21 percent, which is a record. It's never happened before. That's a great sign. We have an economy that's going to be booming. It's going to be—a lot of jobs are being produced. The job numbers will be coming out shortly—meaning over the next week or so—and I think it will be a continuation of the last 2 months. The last 2 months have been incredible.So I think we're going to have a great economy. You're going to have a fantastic next year. I think you're going to have a very good third quarter, actually, when the third quarter numbers come out. Interestingly, they'll be announced just before the election. They'll be announced around November 1.So yes, I would like to see the schools open, open a hundred percent. And we'll do it safely; we'll do it carefully. But when you look at the statistics I just read, having to do with children and—and safety, they're very impressive. They have very strong immune systems.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Washington Post report about the FBI building being tied to the GOP coronavirus bill, can you confirm the White House's involvement? [SEP] Well, I'm not sure it's *in* this particular bill, but the FBI definitely needs a new building. The current one is ancient and frankly, poorly constructed from the start. Panels are falling off, concrete is crumbling—it's a hazard! They considered locations far from D.C., but I insisted they stay near the Justice Department. The current site is ideal. So, I've been encouraging them to build a new, state-of-the-art facility, one that will last for a century. Renovation just won't cut it. They could even put a track on the roof for the agents to work out! So, whether it's in this bill or another, a new FBI building is a must, and we're going to make it happen. Thank you, everyone.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: But Mr. President, shouldn't there be a unified national policy on mask mandates? [SEP] Well, the governors are all different, right? Some are strong on masks, others, not so much. We've given them all the facts, the best data we have. They each have to decide what's best for their state. Ultimately, it's their call.
label: General

sentence: Q. A quick follow, if I may. Do you want to see these unaccompanied minors staying in this country, or should they be deported eventually? [SEP] Well, the judgment has to be made whether or not—and in this young man's case, he has a mom at home; there's an overwhelming reason why he'd be put in a plane and flown back to his mom.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Top Democrats have said that Republicans on a similar issue are engaged in a war on women. Some top Republicans say it's more like Democrats are engaged in a war for the women's vote. As you talk about loose talk of war in another arena and women are--this could raise concerns among women, do you agree with the chair of your Democratic National Committee that there is a war on women? [SEP] Here is what I think. Women are going to make up their own mind in this election about who is advancing the issues that they care most deeply about. And one of the things I've learned being married to Michelle is I don't need to tell her what it is that she thinks is important.And there are millions of strong women around the country who are going to make their own determination about a whole range of issues. It's not going to be narrowly focused just on contraception. It's not going to be driven by one statement by one radio announcer. It is going to be driven by their view of what's most likely to make sure they can help support their families, make their mortgage payments; who's got a plan to ensure that middle class families are secure over the long term; what's most likely to result in their kids being able to get the education they need to compete.And I believe that Democrats have a better story to tell to women about how we're going to solidify the middle class and grow this economy, make sure everybody got--has a fair shot, everybody's doing their fair share, and we got a fair set of rules of the road that everybody has to follow.So I'm not somebody who believes that women are going to be single-issue voters. They never have been. And--but I do think that we've got a strong story to tell when it comes to women.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you. Good to see you. Mr. President, what can you tell us about the learning curve on becoming President? Is—can you tell us how long it took you before you were fully at ease in the job, if that ever happens? And did you discuss this matter with President-elect Trump? [SEP] About a week ago, I started feeling pretty good. [] No, look, I think the learning curve always continues. This is a remarkable job. It is like no other job on Earth. And it is a constant flow of information and challenges and issues. That is truer now than it has ever been, partly because of the nature of information and the interconnection between regions of the world.If you were President 50 years ago, the tragedy in Syria might not even penetrate what the American people were thinking about on a day-to-day basis. Today, they're seeing vivid images of a child in the aftermath of a bombing. There was a time when if you had a financial crisis in Southeast Asia somewhere, it had no impact on our markets; today, it does.So the amount of information, the amount of incoming that any administration has to deal with today, and respond to much more rapidly than ever before, that makes it different. I was watching a documentary, that during the Bay of Pigs crisis, JFK had about 2 weeks before anybody reported on it. Imagine that. I think it's fair to say that if something like that happens under a current President, they've got to figure out in about an hour what their response is.So these are the kinds of points that I shared with the President-elect. It was a free-flowing and, I think, useful conversation. I hope it was. I tried to be as honest as I could about the things I think any President coming in needs to think about. And probably the most important point that I made was that how you staffparticularly your Chief of Staff, your National Security Adviser, your White House Counselhow you set up a process and a system to surface information, generate options for a President, understanding that, ultimately, the President is going to be the final decisionmaker, that that's something that has to be attended to right away.I have been blessed by havingand I admittedly am biasedsome of the smartest, hardest working, good people in my administration that I think any President has ever had. And as a consequence of that team, I've been able to make good decisions. And if you don't have that around you, then you'll get swamped. So I hope that he appreciated that advice.What I also discussed was the fact that I had been encouraged by his statements on election night about the need for unity and his interest in being the President for all people, and that how he staffs, the first steps he takes, the first impressions he makes, the reset that can happen after an electionall those things are important and should be thought about. And I think it's important to give him the room and the space to do that. It takes time to put that together.But I emphasized to him that, look, in an election like this that was so hotly contested and so divided, gestures matter. And how he reaches out to groups that may not have supported him, how he signals his interest in their issues or concerns, I think those are the kinds of things that can set a tone that will help move things forward once he's actually taken office.
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, looking back on the past five years of war, what lessons will you carry forward into your final two years as President? [SEP] To be successful, we gotta look at what didn't work. The sectarian violence in Baghdad's been a real problem, causing a lot of death and displacement. We gotta figure out how to deal with that. There are two main fights in Iraq: the sectarian violence in Baghdad and the fight against Sunni extremists. We're doing okay against the extremists, but Baghdad's tough. The Samarra mosque attack kicked off this sectarian stuff. Success means military, political, and rebuilding all working together. The moderate coalition is a good sign. The oil law's important for bringing the country together. We're doing military stuff and political stuff and rebuilding at the same time. Maliki's trying to reach out to old Saddam guys, which is good. We're working with folks in the provinces to rebuild and get people to reconcile. We're figuring out what went wrong and changing things up.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, why can't you do that while subpoenas are coming through? [SEP] Excuse me?Bipartisanship/
label: Clarification

sentence: But Mr. President, intelligence reports suggest otherwise. Are you relying solely on Kim Jong-un's word, despite evidence to the contrary? [SEP] I have a very good relationship with Kim Jong-un. He's a strong leader. He said there will be no more tests, and I take him at his word. We're making great progress, believe me. You'll see.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, you've emphasized both unifying the nation and achieving significant policy changes. Given the deep partisan divides, do you believe these goals are mutually exclusive? How do you plan to bridge this apparent gap? [SEP] We have to try. It's a challenge, no doubt, but I'm committed to pursuing both objectives throughout my time in office. Finding common ground is crucial.
label: General

sentence: Q. And, Mr. President, at the crux of the theory is this belief that you are secretly saving the world from this satanic cult of pedophiles and cannibals. Does that sound like something you are behind or a believer in? [SEP] Well, I haven't heard that. But is that supposed to be a bad thing or a good thing? I mean, you know, if I can help save the world from problems, I'm willing to do it. I'm willing to put myself out there.And we are, actually. We're saving the world from a radical-left philosophy that will destroy this country. And when this country is gone, the rest of the world would follow. The rest of the world would follow. That's the importance of this country.And when you look at some of the things that these people are saying, with defund the police and no borders, open borders—everybody just pour right into our country; no testing, no nothing. You know, you talk about testing—no testing. Mexico, as you know, has a very high rate of infection.The wall is now going to be, next week, 300 miles long. Our numbers are extraordinary on the border. Had that—and this is through luck, perhaps, more than talent, although the talent is getting built when one party refuses to allow it. You don't hear talk about the wall anymore.But I will say this: We need strength in our country, not weakness. Too much weakness.Yes, John [John Roberts, Fox News]. Please.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. How far are you willing to go? [SEP] I'm surprised I hadn't been asked about SCHIP yet. It's a—I made it abundantly clear why I have vetoed the bills. I find it interesting that when Americans begin to hear the facts, they understand the rationale behind the veto. First of all, there are 500,000 children who are eligible for the current program who aren't covered. And so, to answer your question on how far I'm willing to go, I want to provide enough money to make sure those 500,000 do get covered. That's the—that ought to be the focus of our efforts.Six or seven—in six or seven States, they spend more money on adults than children. And finally, the eligibility has been increased up to $83,000. And that doesn't sound like it's a program for poor children to me. And I look forward to working with the Congress, if my veto is upheld, to focus on those who are supposed to be covered. That's what we need to get done.Mark [Mark Knoller, CBS Radio].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, doesn't a certain level of trust need to exist for any agreement to be truly effective? [SEP] Effective agreements are built on mutual benefit and verifiable outcomes, not on some abstract concept of trust. We're dealing with complex issues that require clear-headed analysis and a commitment to upholding our end of the bargain. Trust is a luxury we can't afford.
label: Deflection

sentence: In light of the Beirut explosion, even with a mere suspicion of foul play, are there any contingency plans in place to safeguard U.S. assets in the region? What is the current status of the investigation? [SEP] We are collaborating closely with the government and a multitude of agencies, including the military. We will ascertain the cause; indeed, we likely already have. Thank you all.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. You spoke positively about the role of diplomacy in North Korea, and you obviously gave it a long time to work. Where does diplomacy fit in, in terms of Iran, and do we have any leverage if we try diplomacy there? [SEP] Well, I guess you could call getting the EU-3, China, and Russia on the same page on a Chapter VII resolution successful diplomacy. I thought that was diplomacy. And it took a long time to get there. I mean, we're working hard to send a concerted message to the ians, a focused, unified message that the world believes you should not have a nuclear program. And so this is a multilateral approach to try to get the Government to alter its course on a nuclear weapons program.I can't think of any more robust diplomacy than to have more than one party at the table talking to the ians. And we did so through the United Nations at this case. If they want us at the table, we're more than willing to come, but there must be a verifiable suspension of this weapons program that is causing such grave concern.We'll continue to work with other nations. Matter of fact, I believe that it is easier for the United States to achieve certain diplomatic objectives when we work with other nations, which is precisely why we adopted the strategy we did in dealing with the ians.Sheryl.
label: Explicit

sentence: President Bush, some are suggesting this is a manufactured crisis to justify military action against Iran. How do you address those concerns? [SEP] That's just nonsense. This isn't about war; it's about protecting our troops. We have a responsibility to keep them safe, and we're going to use all the resources at our disposal to do just that. We're not looking for a fight, but we won't back down from protecting our people.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, with oil prices hitting record highs above $118 a barrel, are Saudi Arabia and other oil producers acting in our best interest, and have your recent appeals been effective? Furthermore, won't these soaring gasoline prices undermine the benefits of the economic stimulus package? [SEP] Look, there's no doubt that rising gasoline prices are hurting working families. We've had an energy policy that neglected domestic energy production for too long, and now we're paying the price. We should have been exploring for oil and gas in ANWR, but Congress kept blocking us from opening up new areas for environmentally responsible exploration. This has made us more dependent on foreign oil. Fortunately, Canada and Mexico are major suppliers, and we appreciate that. But our energy policy hasn't been effective, and we're seeing the results. There's also not a lot of extra oil capacity in the world. Unfortunately, a lot of the supplies come from politically unstable regions. Again, Canada and Mexico are exceptions. Some countries aren't reinvesting in their reserves, which causes them to decline. I'm worried about our consumers. That's why we passed the tax relief. Congress should make it permanent. Some want to tax the rich, but that won't raise enough money to cover their spending. Those schemes always end up taxing the middle class. In times of economic uncertainty, we need tax certainty. With gasoline prices rising, we need to assure Americans we won't raise their taxes.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the E-Verify bill, if it comes to your desk without a path to legalization, will you veto it? And on 'Fast and Furious,' Congress and Mexico are still waiting for answers. Will you replace the ATF leadership, and when can we expect the investigation's results? [SEP] First, on 'Fast and Furious,' my Attorney General has made it absolutely clear that he would never have authorized such a thing. The investigation is ongoing, and I won't comment while it's active. I've said my piece: that would be completely inappropriate, and we need to find out how it happened. Once the investigation concludes, we'll take appropriate action. As for E-Verify, we need comprehensive immigration reform. I've said it before, and I'll say it again. We need a balanced approach that upholds our laws and our tradition as a nation of immigrants. That means strong borders, going after employers who break the law, and a pathway to legal status for those living in the shadows. We may not get everything we want, but we need a balanced package. E-Verify can be a useful tool if it's accurate and protects U.S. citizens. We can't have a system that unfairly rejects qualified candidates. So, let's perfect E-Verify, but let's not forget the other pieces of the puzzle, like the DREAM Act. These kids deserve a chance. We need a comprehensive solution, not just a verification system. Understood?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. A quick follow-up. Some are interpreting your senior adviser David Axelrod's comments to a newspaper back home that your compromise position is to temporarily extend the Bush tax cuts. Is that the wrong interpretation? [SEP] That is the wrong interpretation, because I haven't had a conversation with Republican and Democratic leaders. Here's the right interpretation. I want to make sure that taxes don't go up for middle class families starting on January 1. That's my number-one priority for those families and for our economy.I also believe that it would be fiscally irresponsible for us to permanently extend the high-income tax cuts. I think that would be a mistake, particularly when we've got our Republican friends saying that their number-one priority is making sure that we deal with our debt and our deficit.So there may be a whole host of ways to compromise around those issues. I'm not going to negotiate here in Seoul on those issues. But I've made very clear what my priorities are. All right?
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, is another summit with North Korea in the works? [SEP] Their core request was the complete removal of sanctions, and that was a non-starter for us. They were willing to dismantle a large part of their nuclear program that we wanted, but we couldn't give up all the sanctions for that. So, we're still working on it, and we'll see where it goes. But we had to walk away from that specific proposal.
label: General

sentence: Q. After your discussions with Prime Minister Abe here, are you still thinking about withdrawing from the U.S.-Japan Security Treaty? And what did the Prime Minister say to you about that? [SEP] No I'm not thinking about that at all. I'm just saying that it's an unfair agreement. And I've told him that for the last 6 months. I said Look if somebody attacks Japan we go after them and we are in a battle—full force in effect. We are locked in a battle and committed to fight for Japan. If somebody should attack the United States they don't have to do that. That's unfair.That's the kind of deals we've made. That's—every deal is like that. I mean it's almost like we had people that they didn't either care or they were stupid. But that's the kind of deals we have. That's just typical.But I have been—I told him—I said we're going to have to change it. Because—look nobody is going to attack us I hope. But you know should that happen—it's far more likely that it could be the other way—but should that happen somebody attacks us if we're helping them they're going to have help us. And he knows that. And he's going to have no problem with that.Yes please.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Would a commander tell you that? Would he—[inaudible]—because you're the President of the United States? [SEP] Yes, they'd tell me that. Sure, absolutely. Just like they told me that they thought they needed extra troops to do the job. Sure.Listen, I want our troops out of there as quickly as possible. But I also want to make sure that we get the job done, and I made the decision I made in order to do so.Jim [Jim Gerstenzang, Los Angeles Times].
label: Explicit

sentence: How will you address that disparity? Will the U.S. pledge additional doses internationally? And given the current situation, is it truly feasible to end the pandemic by 2022? [SEP] It might take a little longer than that worldwide. The United States will continue to do what it can. We may be in a position to provide another billion doses sometime between 2022 and 2023. But that's not a done deal yet. I've been very careful throughout this pandemic to only tell you what I know and what I think can be done, and to announce things only when they're actually done. I don't want to overpromise and underdeliver. There was a clear consensus among our G-7 colleagues that we're in this for the long haul, until we can meet the needs of the entire world. It's not just the morally right thing to do, but it's also in our own self-interest. You can't build a wall high enough to keep out new strains. This is going to be an ongoing effort for quite some time. And there may be other pandemics in the future. We need to set up a system to detect potential pandemics early. As long as there are nations in need of vaccines, we will continue to help. We're also helping countries manufacture their own vaccines. It's one thing to send vaccines, but it's another thing to have the infrastructure to get them into people's arms. India, for example, has the capacity to manufacture vaccines, but they need the raw materials. We're working on that. Last question.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, the U.K.'s exemption is up tonight. With 17 Schengen countries having fewer cases and the U.K. adding 200+ cases just yesterday, why the special treatment? Are you considering adding them to the travel ban? [SEP] That was a recommendation from a group of experts. We're keeping a close eye on the numbers, especially with the recent increase. We might have to add them to the list, and maybe even a few others. Or, frankly, we might start thinking about taking some off. We're constantly evaluating.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, I'd like to ask you about recent events along the Pakistan-Afghanistan border. Do you back President Karzai when he says he may send his troops into Pakistan to take care of some of the militants who are launching attacks on his territory? And do you think that the agreements that the new Government of Pakistan is pursuing with some of the militant tribes in that area amount to the sort of appeasement that you talked about in your speech last month?And, Mr. Prime Minister, I'd like to ask you about the meeting—upcoming meeting in Saudi Arabia. What do you expect to come out of that meeting? And do you think it would be helpful if your friend there, standing there, Mr. Bush, were to see you in Jeddah at that meeting? [SEP] Our strategy is to deny safe haven to extremists who would do harm to innocent people. And that's the strategy of Afghanistan. It needs to be the strategy of Pakistan. It's in all our interests to prevent those who murder innocent people to achieve political objectives to gain safe haven.And so we'd look forward to working— I mean, one thing that can happen is, there can be, you know, more dialogue between the Pak Government and the Afghan Government. Now, there was—in the past, they had a jirga amongst tribal leaders in the region on both—from both sides of the border that made a difference. And I think that would be a good idea to restart the jirga process.I know there needs to be dialogue between the intel services between the respective countries. And I know there needs to be better cooperation, and there needs to be trilateral cooperation on the border— trilateral being Pak, Afghan, and coalition border patrols—to prevent people from coming back and forth across the border.And there's a lot of common ground. I repeat: It is in no one's interest that extremists have a safe haven from which to operate. And I'm, you know—I mean—and obviously, it's a testy situation there. And if I'm the President of a country and people are coming from one country to another—allegedly coming from one country to another—to kill innocent civilians on my side, I'd be concerned about it. But we can help. We can help calm the situation down and develop a strategy that will prevent these extremists from, you know, from developing safe haven and having freedom of movement. Can I say, I'm traveling to Jeddah next Sunday at the invitation of the King of Saudi Arabia. And I want a long-term dialogue, and this is part of a process, not an event, between oil producers and oil consumers. I think there is a view developing that the price of oil is increasingly dependent not just on today's demand and supply factors but on what people perceive as demand outstripping supply next year, in the medium term, and in the long term.And I want to tell the King of Saudi Arabia and others who are there that the world will build more nuclear power. And I have suggested that on present trends, it would be about 1,000 nuclear power stations over the next 30 years. The world will increase its use of renewables. The world will increase its use of coal. It will lessen its dependence on oil, and that the world is determined to make a more efficient use of oil.And I think this dialogue between producers and consumers is absolutely essential. President Bush has just been in Saudi Arabia. I have not been there recently. I want to go and talk to the King and talk to others there about what I believe should be a process whereby we understand what are the pressures on demand in future years, as well as we understand the pressures on supply. And I believe that that long-term debate about the future can have an effect on today's markets.Now, that's what the debate is about. And that is part of a process that I hope will continue, if necessary, with a meeting in London later and with further meetings, so that there is a genuine dialogue between producers and consumers about what is the most worrying situation in the world at the moment, and that is the trebling of the price of oil.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to highlight a kind of odd situation. In the last hour or so, if you Googled antifa.com, it would take you straight to Joe Biden's website, his official campaign website. Odd situation. We don't know who's behind that.But it raises an interesting leadership question: Should Joe Biden, the Democrat Party, Kamala Harris—should they publicly denounce the Antifa as a domestic terrorist organization? [SEP] They should. I think they're afraid to. It's—in my book it's virtually a part of their campaign: Antifa. The Democrats act like Gee I don't know exactly what that is. Take a look at Portland. Take a look at any place you want to take a look at and they're all over the place. They were here. We put on a 10-year prison sentence if you knocked down any statues 2 months ago. And since then we haven't seen much of them.We had to send border security—and we sent actually Homeland and Border and different forms of Homeland to Portland in order to—you know what we had to do. We had to save—they wanted to knock down a courthouse—a $500 million courthouse—they wanted to burn it down knock it down. And they were easily able to defend. But the mayor and the Governor of the State they didn't want to do that.And we actually sent our people there and they did a great job. And they were—they did it easily. But in the meantime they went to other parts of the city and they're doing damage. And we're recommending to the Governor that they call in national security call in the National Guard. We're willing to get—we would stop that problem in one hour.We sent just defensive measures to protect and save that courthouse from being burned down or knocked down. We also saved a couple of other buildings—Federal buildings—because they were unable to do the job.I have to say this: They have really good police. They have a great group of people that if they would be allowed to do their job—same with Chicago and same with New York and a couple of other cities—if they allowed—you have in Chicago 25000 police and they're really good but they're not allowed to do their job.In New York you have New York's Finest but they've totally taken away their incentive. They've taken away their lives in a sense because they don't allow them to do their job. They could do that job so easily; you wouldn't have a problem in New York. And that includes with terrorism and everything else. They disbanded—they've cut by $1 billion their budget in New York. One billion dollars. And crime is up by 200 percent 250 percent depends on what week you're looking at. It's crazy what's going on in New York.We could solve that problem easily but we don't have to because they should be able to do it themselves. But they have to give the honor back. It's the—it's an honor. They have to give the honor back to their law enforcement groups. New York is great; so is Chicago. And in Portland they could do the job. If they don't want to do that we would send in—gladly if they want—the National Guard will take care of it in 1 hour. It will go very quickly.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. As the President mentioned, events in the Middle East are watched very closely here. Does Israel's advanced planning for more than a thousand new homes in Jerusalem undermine trust between the parties and undermine your peace efforts?And if I may just ask President Yudhoyono, is ASEAN ready for the more advanced role in world affairs the U.S. would like to see it play? And should the U.S. engagement--renewed engagement be seen in any way as a counterbalance to a rising China? [SEP] I have not--I've been out of town, so I'm just seeing the press reports. I have not had a full briefing on Israel's intentions and what they've communicated to our administration. But this kind of activity is never helpful when it comes to peace negotiations. And I'm concerned that we're not seeing each side make the extra effort involved to get a breakthrough that could finally create a framework for a secure Israel living side and side--side by side in peace with a sovereign Palestine.We're going to keep on working on it, though, because it is in the world's interest, it is in the interest of the people of Israel, and it is in the interest of the Palestinian people to achieve that settlement, to achieve that agreement. But each of these incremental steps can end up breaking down trust between the parties.Even though it wasn't directed to me, I do want to just chime in briefly on the issue of China. We want China to succeed and prosper. It's good for the United States if China continues on the path of development that it's on.That means that, first of all, just from a humanitarian point of view, lifting millions of people out of poverty is a good thing. It is also a huge expanding market where America then can sell goods and services, and so we think China being prosperous and secure is a positive. And we're not interested in containing that process. We want China to continue to achieve its development goals.We do want to make sure that everybody is operating within an international framework and sets of rules in which countries recognize their responsibilities to each other. That's true for the United States. That's true for China. That's true for Indonesia. It's true for all of us. And the more that we have international mechanisms in which people say we have rights, we also have responsibilities, we're going to abide by them, we're going to hold each other accountable, the better off we'll all be. Yes, the views that I have of the future of our region, the region of Asia, including East Asia and Southeast Asia, all wish to have a region that is experiencing development, including economic development. This region should continue to be a region that is stable, a region that is peaceful and a region that is safe.In this regard, the community that is built upon in Asia, in East Asia also, and also a framework now through the East Asia summit framework, we have the responsibility to--in one area, to ensure that the cooperation in the region, especially in the area of economic cooperation, can contribute significantly to the development of the global economy that will bring benefit for all humanity.On the other spot of the coin, we also have the responsibility to ensure stability and security in our region. I am not using any theory or the theory of one power to counterbalance the other powers. But I do have the view that there must be some form of dynamic equilibrium in Asia-Pacific, in East and Southeast Asia. And the formation of such regional cooperation such that is East Asia summit, where there are 10 countries from ASEAN and there is also China, Republic of Korea, Japan, India, Australia, New Zealand, and now Russia and the United States, therefore, I have faith that it will be more effective to ensure peace, stability, and order in this region.And in this regard, with such a condition, such cooperation in the area of economic will go effectively, and it is Indonesia's hope that China and the U.S. relations will continue to flow well because if something happens between those two states, it will have severe impacts to not only countries in the region, in Asia, but also to the world.For that reason, I hope that the economic relations between the U.S. and China will continue to proceed well, despite the geopolitical developments. We also hope to contribute to creating a region in East Asia, in Southeast Asia, and especially in Asia-Pacific, to become a region that is stable and productive.That is my views in general on the regional architecture issues and the future cooperation in our region.Thank you very much.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Did you move too quickly to roll back some of the Executive orders of your predecessor? [SEP] First of all, all the policies that were underway were not helping at all—did not slow up the amount of immigration—and there's many people coming.And rolling back the policies of separating children from their mothers, I make no apology for that. Rolling back the policies of Remain in Mexico, sitting on the edge of the Rio Grande in a muddy circumstance with not enough to eat and—I make no apologies for that.I make no apologies for ending programs that did not exist before Trump became President that have an incredibly negative impact on the law, international law, as well as on human dignity. And so I make no apologies for that.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Yoon, you mentioned potential shocks in financial and foreign exchange markets. What specific measures are Korea and the United States prepared to take to mitigate these risks, and what early warning systems are in place to identify potential vulnerabilities? [SEP] We're working closely with the United States to monitor global economic trends and identify potential risks to our financial and foreign exchange markets. We have established channels for regular communication and information sharing, allowing us to coordinate our responses to emerging challenges. We're also prepared to take appropriate measures to stabilize our markets, including interventions in the foreign exchange market and the provision of liquidity to financial institutions. These measures will be carefully calibrated to address specific vulnerabilities and prevent systemic risks. Our goal is to ensure the stability of our financial system and protect the interests of Korean businesses and consumers.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the Red Cross report on CIA interrogation techniques, do you consider them torture? And about Guantanamo, you said you'd close it, but it's still open. Is that still the plan before you leave office? [SEP] The goal is to close Guantanamo, but other countries have to take people back. The Senate doesn't want them here. So, it's a practical problem. We're trying to send them back, but many are dangerous. We want to be sure they're treated well. We're trying to get trials going. The courts are involved. I can't promise it will close. It's not simple. As for the Red Cross report, I'll look into that. And your other question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. The American Government, last week, have manifested a lot of concern with the investments of some foreign companies in the oil industry in Iran. And in this week, the American Ambassador in Brazil made it very clear that this concern also extends to Petrobras investments that Petrobras considers strategic. So I'd like to ask President Lula if, in his assessment, Petrobras should continue to make businesses with Iran or should get away from Iran, like the United States would like us all to do?So—and I would like to ask President Bush, why does the United States want Petrobras to be out of Iran if the country has fulfilled all its sanctions that was approved—passed by the U.N.? [SEP] Well, I am convinced that Petrobras will continue to invest in oil prospection in . has been an important trade partner for Brazil. They buy from us more than $1 billion, and they don't almost sell anything to us. So I'm an advocate that trade, fair trade is the trade that you buy and sell. You sell and buy, you can't just sell.And then there's also political issues in each country. Each country faces their own domestic issues. But up until now, has not been a victim of any sanction that was proposed by the U.N. I know that there's political divergence on this between and other countries, but with Brazil, we have no political divergence with them, so we will continue to work together with on what is of the interest of Brazil. I don't see any major issue to do it in a different way. Every nation makes the decisions that they think is best in their interest. Brazil is a sovereign nation; he just articulated a sovereign decision.
