And as you mentioned, the trade that you were discussing was not in violation of any U.N.—in any U.N. mandate.Our position is that we would hope that nations would be very careful in dealing with , particularly since is trying to develop a nuclear weapon, and a major threat to world peace is if the ians had a nuclear weapon. And that is why there are sanctions imposed at the United Nations, as a result of collaboration between the United States, EU, China, and Russia, to make it clear to the ian regime that there is a better way forward other than isolation.We have no problems with the ian people. As a matter of fact, the United States highly respects the people of . We respect the history of ; we respect the rich traditions of . We, however, are deeply concerned about an ian Government that is in violation of international accords in their attempt to develop a nuclear weapon. And therefore, whatever comments you hear reflect that concern. And we will continue to work with the international community to say that it is in the world's interest that not develop a weapon. It is in the interest of peace that they not develop a weapon.And I'm hopeful that the people of will be tired of the isolation. I would hope that there would be some rationality amongst their leaders in choosing a better way forward for the people. They're depriving their people of a lot of opportunity.Now, having said that, the United States does believe that it's in our interest that we have people-to-people exchanges. As I say, we have no problem with the ian people. As a matter of fact, we just sent a wrestling team to , all attempting to make it clear to the ian people that we're interested in having a constructive relationship. And it is the decisions of their Government that are preventing that from happening.Thank you. Good job.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Chavez, would you say commentary on his regional influence is exaggerated? [SEP] You're asking my opinion on what, exactly?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, given the recent economic data, are you confident that the current policies are sufficient to prevent a recession? Are you willing to consider alternative strategies if necessary? [SEP] Matt, I—all I can tell you is we grew in the first quarter. I can remember holding a press conference here and that same question came about, assuming that we weren't going to grow. But we showed growth. It's not the growth we'd like; we'd like stronger growth. And there are some things we can do. One is wait for the stimulus package to fully kick in and not raise taxes. If the Democratic leaders had their way in Congress, they would raise taxes, which would be the absolute wrong thing to do. Secondly, they can pass housing legislation that reforms FHA as well as Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. And by the way, a part of that—as I mentioned in my opening statement, a part of that reform will be a strong regulator to help these institutions stay focused on the core mission, which is mortgages.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Duda, following your discussions with President Trump regarding a permanent U.S. military presence in Poland, what was his immediate reaction to your request, and are you presently concerned about the trajectory of U.S.-Russia relations? [SEP] Naturally, I briefed Mr. President on all facets of a potential permanent U.S. military presence in Poland. However, let me emphasize one crucial point: the establishment of such bases should not be interpreted as an escalation that would provoke increased Russian aggression and militarization in the region. It's imperative to recognize that Russia has been systematically militarizing areas like Kaliningrad Oblast for over a decade. This aggressive posture, exemplified by events in Georgia in 2008 and the annexation of Crimea, underscores the need for a strong deterrent. The U.S. presence serves as a guarantee of security and defense for our part of Europe, the free world. We seek the presence of both U.S. and NATO forces to safeguard our interests. While Mr. President and his advisors must consider all factors, the arguments in favor of a U.S. military presence are compelling, particularly in light of the violation of international law and aggressive behaviors we are witnessing. Deterrence is the most effective way to prevent war. President Trump also mentioned Poland's willingness to contribute financially to such a base, aligning with his broader focus on burden-sharing among allies. He emphasized the need for wealthy nations to contribute to their defense, a principle he has consistently advocated within NATO, resulting in increased financial commitments from member states. We are evaluating the proposal from both a military protection and cost perspective.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, could you perhaps illuminate the mechanisms by which this initiative achieves its intended results, as you perceive them? [SEP] The real deal is this: everyone's saying, 'Just strike a bargain!' But they don't have the guts, nor the brains, to realize you can't keep letting a country bleed us dry for $500 billion every year. It's just not feasible. Someone had to take charge. Obama should have done this. Biden, Sleepy Joe, should have done it. Bush, Clinton, all of them! They should have all taken care of it. I'm the one doing it. And another thing: North Korea should have been taken care of a long time ago. I'm doing it. I'm taking care of many things that I shouldn't have to be doing.
label: Deflection

sentence: So, you don't want to say more? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, as you're probably aware, there's a growing hunger strike on Guantanamo Bay among prisoners there. Is it any surprise really that they would prefer death rather than have no end in sight to their confinement? [SEP] Well, it is not a surprise to me that we've got problems in Guantanamo, which is why when I was campaigning in 2007 and 2008, and when I was elected in 2008, I said we need to close Guantanamo. I continue to believe that we've got to close Guantanamo.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. So, they're not being investigated, sir? [SEP] Peter, I'm going to have to decline to comment on that.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, regarding the oil price cap, will this actually lower gasoline prices for Americans, and how long will Americans have to pay a premium due to the war? [SEP] Could you repeat the part about lowering prices?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, given the intelligence reports indicating a civil war in Iraq, your insistence on achieving victory, and the potential threat to our national security, how can you reconcile your commitment to a 'non-open-ended' involvement? [SEP] The notion of 'victory' in Iraq must be understood in a contemporary context, distinct from the total victory of World War II. The challenge lies in articulating a realistic vision of success to the American public. We envision a society characterized by *relative* peace. The complete absence of car bombings is an unrealistic expectation. The fundamental objective is to empower the Iraqi government with the necessary security apparatus to suppress the ethnic cleansing witnessed in certain regions. Furthermore, Iraq faces challenges related to general criminality. Al-Qaeda maintains a presence, responsible for several high-profile attacks. Zarqawi, a foreign terrorist, explicitly sought to incite sectarian conflict through violence, and his efforts were partially successful. Finally, there exists a faction of disaffected Sunnis who believe they should retain power despite their minority status. They are prepared to employ violence to destabilize the country and regain control. Therefore, irrespective of the label applied, the situation is complex and requires internal resolution. While some observers characterize it as a civil war, others disagree. Nevertheless, the situation is sufficiently precarious to warrant intervention. We seek a government founded on constitutional principles, a nation where citizens feel secure, where resources are distributed equitably, where provinces enjoy a degree of autonomy, where non-criminal political actors can participate, and where Iraq serves as an ally in the war on terror – a bastion of moderation rather than a haven for extremism. This constitutes our definition of success.
label: Deflection

sentence: Given your strong rhetoric about Iran and Syria, labeling them as part of the axis of evil and state sponsors of terrorism, respectively, and considering your stated openness to any proposal that aids in achieving victory, would you be willing to collaborate with Iran and Syria if it were determined that their involvement could contribute to success in Iraq? [SEP] The world expects Iran and Syria to assist Iraq, and we've made that clear. Regarding Iran, we have several issues. First, will they help Iraq's young democracy succeed? Second, will they help Lebanon's democracy, specifically the Siniora Government, which is a priority for this administration? The biggest issue is Iran's potential acquisition of nuclear weapons. Our issues with Iran are numerous. Our position is clear: isolation is not the path forward for the Iranian government and people. We will continue to emphasize that their support for terrorism will lead to further isolation. We are actively engaged in diplomatic efforts. The Iranians know our position on Iraq, and more importantly, they know the Iraqis' position. We are supporting a sovereign government. The Iraqis have conveyed to the Iranians: help us succeed by not interfering in our internal affairs. As for Syria, our message remains consistent: do not undermine the Siniora Government in Lebanon; assist Israel in recovering the prisoner captured by Hamas; prevent Hamas and Hizballah from plotting attacks against democracies in the Middle East; and provide assistance within Iraq. They are also aware of our position, Jessica.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, given Rick Ledgett's recent comments, is the administration open to considering amnesty or a plea deal for Edward Snowden, and what's your message to those who believe Snowden acted justly? [SEP] I must be cautious, as Mr. Snowden faces criminal charges, and the matter is before the Attorney General and the courts. Therefore, I cannot comment directly on the specifics. However, I've previously stated that the debate sparked by his actions was important. However, the manner of the disclosures harmed the U.S. and our intelligence operations. There was a better way to have this discussion. The U.S. upholds the rule of law and values privacy and civil liberties. These disclosures have allowed countries that engage in the very actions Snowden criticized to deflect criticism onto the U.S. While the debate was necessary, it's crucial to acknowledge the damage to U.S. intelligence and diplomacy. I will defer to the courts and the Attorney General on Mr. Snowden's case.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Do you feel you need that deal before the election, sir? [SEP] No. I don't think I need it before the election. I think people know that we're doing a great job. I've rebuilt the military. We've—Scott and I were talking about that. We spent 1½ trillion dollars. When I came in our military was depleted. Frankly we didn't have ammunition okay? But our military was in very bad shape. We've rebuilt the military. We've got one of the strongest economies.Mike Pence actually got some—who is right here. Our great Vice President. He was talking yesterday and he called me. He says Boy these numbers—these consumer numbers are incredible. The retail numbers that came out 2 days ago that really weren't reported were really—I mean just incredible numbers. You know that very well. That's your world. And some other numbers.We're doing very well. Our economy is very strong. And China is being affected very badly. We're not; we're not being affected. In fact we're taking in many billions of dollars. And China is eating that. You know China is eating the tariffs because of the devaluation. Now that doesn't happen with all countries. China is China and they know what they're doing as well as anybody.My relationship with President Xi is a very amazing one very good one. But we have right now a little spat. But I think we're doing very well.Our country is doing well. You look at so many different things. Look at all of the regulation cutting that allows us to do what we did. Look at what happens 3 days ago where you have an attack like that and it takes out a big chunk of oil and the prices go up $4 $5 and now it's heading down rapidly. That tells you—that would have happened years ago it would have gone up $50. It would've doubled. And this was a blip.So it's been really amazing what we've been able to do. I think the voters understand that. I don't think it has any impact on the election.Now if something happened I think that would probably be a positive for the election but that's okay. I do think signing USMCA on a bipartisan basis with Nancy Pelosi and Chuck Schumer and everybody else—very bipartisan—I think that's very important for our country. And I would certainly be willing to say that's a bipartisan deal.But I think that's very important for our manufacturers for our farmers. Even for unions they want that deal done. And so hopefully that's going to be put up to a vote very soon. There will be very little cajoling of the Democrats because most Democrats want it too.But the USMCA is ready to be voted on. It's finished. Mexico has taken their final votes. Canada is willing to do that any time we want them too. They're all set to go. And we need that for all of the—we need that for our country. It's a great deal. It's a great deal.Thank you.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, the CIA Director returned from Pyongyang without the three detained Americans and without any obvious concessions from North Korea. Will you still sit down with Kim Jong Un if Americans are still being held? Will you demand concessions for gestures like sending a potential Secretary of State? [SEP] Look, they've got three prisoners, right? We're talking about them, negotiating hard. They've been there a while, treated badly. We fought to get Otto Warmbier back, but he was in terrible shape. A real tragedy. We're working hard to get those three citizens back. I think we've got a good shot. We're having good talks. We'll keep you in the loop. We've come a long way with North Korea. For years, they've talked, but nothing happened. Past administrations should have handled this. We put strong sanctions on. I want to thank President Xi of China, who's done more than anyone else for us. He's tightened the border. He didn't think he'd go this far, and I appreciate it. It's put the squeeze on them. 93% of North Korea's stuff comes from China. Xi knows this is important. He doesn't want a nuclear Korea. He's helping China too. He's been terrific. Can he do more? Always. But he's been good, and it's made a difference. We've never been in this position with that regime. I'm hoping for a successful meeting. If it won't be successful, we won't do it. If it's not working, I'll walk, and we'll keep doing what we're doing. I'm flexible. President Moon said the Olympics would have flopped without me. Our involvement made it a hit. Ticket sales were down before North Korea got involved. We've gotten this far, and I think we'll succeed. But if I don't think we will, we're done.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Here at this meeting and earlier at the G-7, you've said several times that America is back at allies' side, but a lot of those allies are themselves pretty rattled by what happened on January 6—an attempted overturning of your election—and they may still be alarmed by the continued hold that Donald Trump has over the Republican Party and the rise of nationalist figures like him around the world.What do you say to those allies, what have you been saying to them at these meetings about how the next President of the United States can keep any promises you make? [SEP] What I'm saying is them—to them is: Watch me. I mean, I'm not saying anything, quite frankly. I'm just going out—people, as I've said before, don't doubt that I mean what I say, and they believe that I keep my commitments when I say it.I'm not making any promises to anyone that I don't believe are overwhelmingly likely to be kept. I think that we're at a moment where—I mean, let me put it this way: You may have had a different view, but I think an awful lot of people thought that my showing up at the G-7 would not produce any kind of enthusiasm about American leadership and about where America was. I would suggest that it didn't turn out that way.I would suggest that there is a—the leaders I'm dealing with in NATO and the G-7 are leaders who know our recent history; know, generically, the character of the American people; and know where the vast center of the public stands—not Democrat, Republican—but who we are. We're a decent, honorable nation.And I think that they have seen things happen, as we have, that shocked them and surprised them that could have happened. But I think they, like I do, believe the American people are not going to sustain that kind of behavior.And so I—you know, I don't want to get into the statistics, because you know that old phrase of Disraeli's: There's three kinds of lies: lies, damned lies, and statistics. But I think it's appropriate to say that the Republican Party is vastly diminished in numbers; the leadership of the Republican Party is fractured; and the Trump wing of the party is the bulk of the party, but it makes up a significant minority of the American people.Now, we'll see. We'll see. I believe that by us standing up and saying what we believe to be the case, not engaging in the overwhelming hyperbole that gets engaged in by so many today, that we—I guess that old expression, The proof of the pudding is in the eating.When we said—when I said I was going to deal with beating the virus and I was going to focus on that and I was going to get millions of shots in people's arms, it wasn't me—I just knew the American people. I knew the kind of help I'd get from the Defense Department, from police departments, from the hospitals, from retired docs, from—I just knew. And look how rapidly we moved.Now, we have a group of people who were—everything from the political rejection of the notion of taking a vaccine, to people who were simply afraid of a needle and everything in between. And we have a way to go.But I never doubted that we would be able to generate the kind of support we got and get so many millions of people step up and get vaccinated. So I think it is a shock and surprise that what's happened, in terms of the consequence of President Trump's phony populism, has happened. And it is disappointing that so many of my Republican colleagues in the Senate, who I know know better, have been reluctant to take on, for example, an investigation because they're worried about being primaried.But, at the end of the day, we've been through periods like this in American history before where there has been this reluctance to take a chance on your reelection because of the nature of your party's politics at the moment.I think this is passing. I don't mean easily passing. That's why it's so important that I succeed in my agenda—the agenda, whether it's dealing with the vaccine, the economy, infrastructure. It's important that we demonstrate we can make progress and continue to make progress. And I think we're going to be able to do that.So, as I said, the proof will be in where it is, you know, 6 months from now, where we are. But I think you're going to see that there's—that, God willing, we're going to be making progress, and there's going to be a coalescing of a lot of Republicans, particularly younger Republicans who are coming up in the party. The President. And last question, Sebastian Smith of AFP.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, what conditions would need to be met for you to sit down with President Castro in Havana? Are there any red lines for such a meeting? And on the cyber front, while you're keeping your response under wraps, are you looking at more sanctions on North Korea? Can you take military action or a cyber counterstrike off the table? [SEP] I'll stick with what I said before: we've confirmed it was North Korea, and we're working on a bunch of options. I'll see them, and then I'll decide what's fair and makes sense for what they did. As for Cuba, me going there or Castro coming here isn't happening right now. I don't know what'll happen with that relationship down the road. I'm still pretty young, so maybe I'll get to Cuba someday and meet the people. But there's nothing in the works right now.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President—Mr. President, I asked you on Monday if there was anything that you regret in your first 2 years. And you said that, at times, you could have and should have used a, quote, softer tone. Your critics, as you can imagine—your skeptics—they say they're not holding their breath on that happening. Will you indeed have to change your tone if you're to get things passed through Congress after losing the House?And you also said you might extend an olive branch. And what would that look like? [SEP] I would love to have—I'd be very good at a low tone. But when things are done not correctly about you—written about you, said about you on television, on wherever it is—you have to defend yourself.I would love to do very—a very even tone. It's much easier than what I have to do. I have to go around. And going around is much easier than facing somebody and being treated fairly. But when you're not treated fairly, you really have no choice.I would love to have a very even, modest, boring tone. I would be very honored by that. But you know what? When you have to fight—all the time fight—because you're being misrepresented by the media, you really can't do that.
label: Deflection

sentence: Sir, retirement age. Details, please. [SEP] No specifics. We've discussed it all. Seniors pay a little more, millionaires pay too. Fair share.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Mr. Libby's defense strategy, are you concerned that Vice President Cheney's testimony might reveal sensitive information or create further complications in the CIA leak case? Will the White House cooperate fully with the defense's request? [SEP] Well, I saw the reports, just like everyone else. It's certainly a development. But given the ongoing nature of the legal proceedings, I'm going to refrain from commenting any further at this time. I trust the judicial process will run its course.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. If proven true, are you okay with Postmaster General DeJoy and the fact that he asked former employees at his private company to make donations to the GOP and then reimburse them? Are you okay with that? [SEP] Yes, I don't know too much about it. I read something this morning, but I don't—other than that, I'd have to see it. He's a very respected man. He was approved very much by both parties, I guess. It was sort of an approval that took place by both parties. I don't know exactly what the story is. I'll certainly know within a short period of time. I just read it for the first time—I read it this morning, just like you did.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, if that patience were to expire, what then? [SEP] Why are we assuming it will? Let's concentrate on preventing that from happening. That's the goal. That's what optimists do. They say, 'We're going to create a framework, and we'll strive to make it work.' Let's see here, Stephen [Stephen Dinan, Washington Times].
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, looking back, do you stand by your earlier commendation of China's openness about the coronavirus? [SEP] I consistently demonstrate respect for China.
label: General

sentence: So, are you suggesting that your statement directly caused him to back down? [SEP] Look, I'm not saying that directly, but it's interesting, isn't it? Biden's being called an extremist, and suddenly, the press is all over it. I just find the timing rather curious. Draw your own conclusions.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, given the ongoing tensions in the Middle East, what specific diplomatic strategies are you pursuing to de-escalate the situation and prevent further conflict, particularly concerning Iran's nuclear program? [SEP] We are actively engaged in diplomatic efforts with our allies and partners to address the challenges posed by Iran's nuclear program. Our focus remains on achieving a comprehensive and verifiable agreement that ensures Iran does not acquire nuclear weapons. We are also committed to fostering regional stability through dialogue and cooperation.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the unconventional nature of this communication through Twitter, can you provide details about the security measures in place to prevent potential misuse or misinterpretation of these interactions, especially in sensitive diplomatic contexts? [SEP] We have a great team, the best, and they handle everything. They're very smart, very careful. We're not just tweeting out anything, okay? Everything is reviewed, everything is considered. We're using social media to communicate directly with people, to get our message out there. We're not going to let the fake news media control the narrative. We're going to use every tool we have to get the truth out there. And we're going to do it safely and responsibly.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. My question—sir, my question was about Indian Americans. Do you think they are voting for you or are you—are they supporting you—[inaudible]? [SEP] I do. We had a—an event in Houston, as you know, and it was a fantastic event. I was invited by Prime Minister Modi. And this was a massive—this was at the—where they play football—the Houston football team. And it was incredible. It was actually incredible. And the Prime Minister could not have been more generous.We have great support from India. We have great support from Prime Minister Modi. And I would think that the people—Indian people—would be voting for Trump. I also, as you know, went to India, just prior to the pandemic setting in, because India has been hit very hard. Left, really, about a week before that.And we had an incredible time. What— we saw—the people are so incredible. It's really an incredible place, an incredible country, and it's definitely big. It's definitely big.But you've got a great leader, and he's a great, great person.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, given this being your third budget proposal, and your stated willingness to be a one-term president for the sake of doing what's necessary, why not directly engage Republicans now to negotiate? Furthermore, how are you fostering the cooperation you mentioned is needed for bipartisanship? And finally, will the markets remain stable for two more years? [SEP] Wow, that's a lot to unpack! I'm not sure I can keep track of all of that.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, following Mayor Bloomberg's endorsement based on your climate change stance, especially after Hurricane Sandy, what specific actions will you take on climate change in a second term? Furthermore, do you foresee sufficient political consensus in Washington for carbon tax legislation? [SEP] Mark, attributing specific weather events to climate change is problematic. However, global temperatures are escalating at an accelerated pace, and Arctic ice is diminishing rapidly. The frequency of severe weather events is increasing. I am convinced that climate change is genuine and influenced by human activity. We bear a responsibility to future generations. During my initial term, we doubled fuel efficiency standards and clean energy output, thereby curtailing carbon emissions. However, further action is imperative. I intend to engage with scientists, engineers, and elected officials to pinpoint immediate carbon reduction strategies and cultivate a national dialogue on enduring solutions. The level of support from Democrats and Republicans remains uncertain, given regional disparities. Conscientiously addressing climate change necessitates challenging political decisions. Given the public's focus on jobs and economic expansion, we must not neglect these priorities. Should we devise a strategy that simultaneously generates employment, fosters growth, and mitigates climate change, public support will be forthcoming. Expect further pronouncements from me on this matter in the near future.
label: General

sentence: Lesley, regarding Cuba, specifically Fidel Castro's potential involvement in recent talks and the Republican opposition to lifting the embargo, could you address those points directly? [SEP] Lesley, with all due respect, I believe we've exhausted this line of questioning. Let's move on to another topic.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the bank bailout, will you require recipient institutions to increase lending to small businesses and consumers? If not, how do you justify this bailout to the American people, given the failure of the previous one? [SEP] Look, the details are still being finalized, and Secretary Mnuchin will have a full briefing on that tomorrow. But let me be perfectly clear: the success of this package hinges on getting credit flowing again. We need to see capital reaching Main Street, supporting both large and small businesses, and empowering consumers. That's the core principle guiding our approach. But I'll let Steve elaborate on the specifics. Now, where's Major? Always a pleasure to see you, Major.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. If the clinical trials demonstrate the drug's efficacy, will your administration expedite its approval process within the United States? [SEP] Look, I'm not a doctor, okay? It's way too early to jump to conclusions. We need to see the hard data, the real numbers. Until then, any pronouncements would just be speculation. Let's wait and see what the scientists say.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. One more thing. Mr. President, could you tell us about the video that you showed before this? [SEP] Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, you've mentioned being willing to walk away from the North Korea summit. Can you articulate the specific red lines that, if crossed, would trigger your departure from the negotiations? What specific concessions are you seeking from Kim Jong Un, and what are you prepared to offer in return, beyond vague promises of future benefits? [SEP] I'm not going to negotiate in public. I'm going to go into that meeting with a clear understanding of what we want, and I'm going to be firm. But I'm also going to be fair. I believe that Kim Jong Un is a smart guy, and I believe that he wants to do what's best for his country. If we can reach an agreement that's good for both of us, then we'll have a great success. But if not, I'm not afraid to walk away.
label: General

sentence: President Biden, considering Prime Minister Kishida's concerns about China's growing influence and the potential for 'Ukraine in East Asia,' how will this trilateral partnership specifically address economic coercion and maritime disputes in the region? [SEP] Look, we're aware of the concerns. We're working with our allies. This summit was about deepening our cooperation across a range of issues, not just the immediate ones. We want a peaceful and prosperous Indo-Pacific. It's a global issue, folks. A big deal. And we're committed to making it happen. This relationship, it's going to expand. You'll see. It's historic.
label: Dodging

sentence: Can you definitively state whether your Republican nomination acceptance speech will take place in Charlotte, or if an alternative venue is being considered? [SEP] We're exploring all options to ensure the best possible experience for everyone involved. The focus is on delivering a powerful message and uniting the party behind our shared goals.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Some on Wall Street have expressed frustration that it's unclear what more your administration is willing to do to resolve the banking crisis. The markets have remained in turmoil. So how confident are you that the problem is contained? And if it spreads, what measures, such as guaranteeing more deposits, are you willing or not willing to take? [SEP] First of all, have you ever known Wall Street not in consternation? Number one.Look, I think we've done a pretty damn good job. People's savings are secure, and even those beyond the $250,000 the FDIC is guaranteeing them. And the American taxpayer is not going to have to pay a penny. The banks are in pretty good shape. What's going on in Europe isn't a direct consequence of what's happening in the United States.And I—what we would do is, if we find that there's more instability than appears, we'd be in a position to have the FDIC use the power it has to guarantee those loans above 250, like they did already.And so I think it's going to take a little while for things to just calm down. But I don't see anything that's on the horizon that's about to explode. But I do understand there's an unease about this. And these mid-sized banks have to be able to survive, and I think they'll be able to do that.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, the Romanian people are eager to know: when will they be able to travel to the U.S. without a visa, just like other EU citizens? Can you give us a specific timeframe for achieving this goal? [SEP] The President of Romania raised the visa issue, and I appreciate his candor. He's a good friend, and he's not shy about expressing his concerns. I understand the frustration of the Romanian people, especially given their contributions in Iraq. I pushed Congress to update the visa laws, but they didn't go far enough. We're committed to working with Romania to find a solution that respects our laws and their needs. The goal is to facilitate travel for genuine visitors while addressing security concerns. The new law should help, and we'll continue to collaborate. We're doing everything we can to resolve this issue.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Then why aren't you going? [SEP] I couldn't tell you. I'd almost relish the chance to sit in the front row and stare at those corrupt faces. I'd love to do it.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Hadley memo leak prior to the al-Maliki meeting, can you confirm whether you or your Chief of Staff ordered an investigation? And if unauthorized, do you believe someone within your administration sought to undermine your Iraq policy or sabotage that crucial meeting? [SEP] Now, let me think... did I authorize a probe? I can't quite recall issuing a direct order. However, I vividly remember expressing my displeasure with the persistent leaks. While I acknowledge your vital role in uncovering and disseminating information, the unauthorized disclosure of classified documents remains a grave concern. This issue plagues not only this administration but any government striving to implement policies impacting the nation's trajectory. As you know, we've experienced numerous leaks, originating from various unknown sources, precluding me from speculating on their origins. Regrettably, identifying the source of these leaks often proves elusive. Although we may lament this situation, it remains challenging to pinpoint those within the government willing to provide confidential documents to the media. An investigation may indeed be underway; however, I lack definitive knowledge. If such an inquiry exists, it has not been brought to my immediate attention. Nevertheless, I firmly believe that holding individuals accountable for leaking classified information would serve as a powerful deterrent against future breaches.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Obama, your approval ratings have taken a hit, particularly regarding trust and honesty. Do you believe the healthcare rollout has damaged the public's confidence in government? People expect government to work for them, and right now, it's not always doing that.

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the situation in Mexico, and the questions surrounding human rights violations, the drug war, and the Merida Initiative, what are your thoughts? [SEP] I apologize, but the translation was unclear. It sounded like a very insightful question. Could you repeat it?

sentence: Mr. President, how do you view the Pope's recent actions concerning the recognition of a Palestinian state and its potential impact on a two-state solution with Israel? I appreciate the Senators who backed this, and I'll keep working on those who didn't. We must ensure these deals benefit everyone, from large corporations to small businesses, and especially American workers. My priority is creating jobs and opportunities for all Americans. Now, remind me again what the other part of your question was?

sentence: Q. [Inaudible]—put that out in February? [SEP] But read the reports. China came out with a statement that it was an airborne disease. I heard it was an airborne disease. I assumed it early on. The fact is, there has to be a calmness. You don't want me jumping up and down, screaming: There's going to be great death. There is going—and really causing some very, very serious problems for the country.If Bob Woodward thought what I said was bad, then he should have immediately, right after I said it, gone out to the authorities so they can prepare and let them know.

sentence: Mr. President, with your approval ratings declining due to the pandemic response, what specific actions will you take to regain public trust and demonstrate your leadership in combating the virus? The American people know that we're the only ones who can get the economy back on track.

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Turkey's border security, is Turkey doing enough to prevent the flow of foreign fighters into Syria? And what assurances can you give that the U.S. will maintain its climate change commitments even after you leave office? [SEP] Well, let me say first, I'm optimistic a Democrat will succeed me. But even if someone from another party does, the responsibilities of the office change your perspective. American leadership requires considering global concerns. The world takes climate change very seriously. Even if Republicans hesitate to support my policies, the next President will need to address this issue. As for Turkey, I've discussed border security with President Erdogan. We've seen progress, but gaps remain, particularly along a 98-kilometer stretch. Our militaries are collaborating to improve border control. Turkey has also taken on a significant humanitarian effort, hosting millions of Syrian refugees. The U.S. is the largest contributor of humanitarian aid. The EU is also helping Turkey manage refugee flows. We need an orderly process along the Turkish-Greek border to regulate refugee flows and prevent human trafficking.
label: Implicit

sentence: With the rise of extremism, do you think the election represents a shift in people being willing to show more decency? Do you feel like the fever has broken? [SEP] Well, I don't think we're going to break the fever for the super-mega-MAGA Republicans. But I think they're a minority of the Republican Party. The vast majority of the members of the Republican Party, we disagree strongly on issues, but they're decent, honorable people. They're honest, and they're straightforward. They're different than mine, but they're decent folks.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, have you decided on your nominee for Federal Reserve Board Chair? If not, what are your considerations? This is the latest a President has gone without nominating someone. Are you concerned about the timeline, especially if you don't renominate Jay Powell? [SEP] No, no, and no. I'm not discussing it. It's in progress. We'll announce it soon. It's been in the works for a while. We'll have plenty of time to get nominees cleared. I've given it a lot of thought and met with my economic advisors. We have good choices. But I'm not speculating now. Nancy, CBS, did you have a question?

sentence: Q. Mr. President, if Tedros were to be replaced, would you reconsider supporting the WHO? Or do you view his removal as essential for any meaningful reform to occur? [SEP] We're currently conducting an investigation. I don't know the individual, but I'm aware of the issues. The WHO has been unfair to the United States, much like the World Trade Organization, which is now starting to get in line. Why did previous presidents allow China to be classified as a developing nation, allowing them to exploit the United States? I've been addressing this since day one, and we're looking into it very seriously. I have concerns with both the World Health Organization and the World Trade Organization. I'm not sure which is worse, to be honest, but we'll resolve it. Okay?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Can you confirm the suspect's gender? [SEP] I'm not sure at this point. That information will be available in a more detailed briefing later on.

sentence: Mr. President, you've spoken of a return to decency. Do you believe the recent election signals a true turning point, a departure from the divisiveness of the past? [SEP] While I doubt we'll ever win over the most extreme elements, the 'super-mega-MAGA Republicans,' I believe they represent a minority within the Republican Party. The vast majority of Republicans are decent, honorable individuals with whom we may have strong disagreements on policy, but who are fundamentally honest and straightforward. I've worked with many of them for years in the Senate and the House. The world is closely observing the United States. At my first G-7 meeting, I declared, 'America is back.' One leader responded by asking, 'For how long?' Another posed a hypothetical: What would I think if thousands stormed the British Parliament to prevent the confirmation of an election? While the situations are not identical, such an event would undoubtedly signal a crisis of democracy in Great Britain. The world is questioning whether the United States remains stable, whether we adhere to our democratic principles and institutions. They are concerned about our commitment to accepting the decisions of the courts, Congress, and the government.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Biden, is ceding land a possibility for Zelenskyy to achieve a cease-fire with Russia, or is that unacceptable? Also, what's your stance on removing Russia from the G-20? I proposed that if Indonesia and others are opposed, we should consider inviting both as observers. Now, could you please reiterate your first question?

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Speaking of voting rights legislation, if this isn't passed, do you still believe the upcoming election will be fairly conducted and its results will be legitimate? [SEP] Well, it all depends on whether or not we're able to make the case to the American people that some of this is being set up to try to alter the outcome of the election. And it's one thing—look, maybe I'm just being too much of an optimist. Remember how we thought not that many people were going to show up to vote in the middle of a pandemic? We had the highest voter turnout in the history of the United States of America.Well, I think if in fact—no matter how hard they make it for minorities to vote, I think you're going to see them willing to stand in line and defy the attempt to keep them from being able to vote. I think you're going to see the people who they're trying to keep from being able to show up, showing up and making the sacrifice that needs to make in order to change the law back to what it should be.And—but it's going to be difficult. I make no bones about that. It's going to be difficult. But we're not there yet. We've not run out of options yet. And we'll see how this moves.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, you campaigned on canceling $10,000 in student loans. Do you still plan to do so and when? And now that you've clarified the Bull Connor comments, do you plan to reach out to Republicans like Mitt Romney to talk about reforming the Electoral Count Act? [SEP] Yes, I'm happy to speak out. I've—I've met with—I've talked to Mitt on other occasions. And by the way, I reached out to the minority leader as well at the time that he made his speech. And so I have no reluctance to reach out to any Republican and anyone who—and I've made it clear. Look, I've now had the opportunity to travel because of funerals and eulogies I've made and attended—and Congressmen and Senators who have come along with me. I don't—don't hold me to the number, but somewhere between 20 and 25 Senators and Congresspersons have traveled with me. And I find—you should get the list of them and ask what—how we, you know, sat for the 2, 3, 4, 5 hours that we've flown together—sit back in the—in that conference table and talk to them, ask them questions; they ask me questions. I learned a heck of a lot. But as President, you don't quite have that ability to do that as often as I'd like to be able to do it. And one of the things that I do think that has been made clear to me—speaking of polling—is the public doesn't want me to be the President Senator. They want me to be the President and let Senators be Senators. And so, if I've made—and I've made many mistakes, I'm sure. If I made a mistake, I'm used to negotiating to get things done, and I've been, in the past, relatively successful at it in the United States Senate, even as Vice President. But I think that role as President is a different role. Folks, it is now almost 6. With all due respect, I'm going to see you at the next conference. Okay? Thank you.
label: General

sentence: Q. ----sense of pride. In your view, how did reality match up to fantasy in welcoming the world leaders to Chicago? And did the demonstrators in any way on the streets undermine your efforts, Mayor Emanuel's efforts, to project the image of Chicago you would have liked to have seen? [SEP] I have to tell you, I think Chicago performed magnificently. Those of us who were in the summit had a great experience. If you talk to leaders from around the world, they love the city. Michelle took some of the spouses down to the South Side to see the Comer Center, where wonderful stuff is being done with early education. They saw the Art Institute.I was just talking to David Cameron. I think he's sneaking off and doing a little sightseeing before he heads home. I encouraged everybody to shop. I want to boost the hometown economy. We gave each leader a Bean--a small model--for them to remember, as well as a football from Soldier Field. Many of them did not know what to do with it. [] So people had a wonderful time, and I think the Chicagoans that they interacted with couldn't have been more gracious and more hospitable. So I could not have been prouder.Now, I think with respect to the protesters, as I said, this is part of what NATO defends, is free speech and the freedom of assembly. And frankly, to my Chicago press, outside of Chicago, folks really weren't all that stressed about the possibility of having some protesters here, because that's what--part of what America is about. And obviously, Rahm was stressed, but he performed wonderfully, and the Chicago police, Chicago's finest, did a great job under some significant pressure and a lot of scrutiny.The only other thing I'll say about this is thank you to everybody who endured the traffic situation. Obviously, Chicago residents who had difficulties getting home or getting to work or what have you, that's--what can I tell you, that's part of the price of being a world city. But this was a great showcase. And if it makes those folks feel any better, despite being 15 minutes away from my house, nobody would let me go home. I was thinking I would be able to sleep in my own bed tonight. They said I would cause even worse traffic. So I ended up staying in a hotel, which contributes to the Chicago economy. []Thank you, everybody.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, some economists argue that raising the debt ceiling without addressing the underlying drivers of debt is simply kicking the can down the road. Shouldn't you be focusing on long-term fiscal sustainability rather than short-term political expediency? [SEP] We agree that long-term fiscal sustainability is important. That's why we're committed to reducing our deficits and growing our economy. We're also working to reform our tax code and make our government more efficient. We believe that we can achieve both short-term stability and long-term prosperity.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. We, too, have been reporting at the border. And just like Cecilia, we ran into a pair of siblings who came in on Monday, who were detained by CBP—had the phone number for their mother who lives in the U.S. We have contacted the mother. That's the only way they know her kids are here because CBP, today, Thursday, has not contacted that mother. So when can we expect your promise of things getting better with contacting and expediency and processing? [SEP] Well, they're already getting better, but they're going to get real—they'll get a whole hell of lot better real quick, or we're going to hear of some people leaving, okay?We can get this done. We're going to get it done.I had a long meeting with the entire team and several Cabinet-level officers the other night. We're going to be moving, within the next—within the next week, over 100,000—I mean, 1,000 people out of the Border Patrol into safe, secure beds and facilities. We're going to significantly ramp up. We're already out there contacting everyone, from getting some of the employees at HHS—and there's a lot of them doing other things—and move them into making those calls. We're in a—we're in the process of rearranging and providing for the personnel needed to get that done.But I admire the fact that you were down there; you're making the calls yourself. It's real.The next thing that has to happen though—as you well know has to happen—there have to be some certitude that this is the—actually mom, dad, or whomever. And there's ways to do that. There's ways to do that—a little bit like determining whether or not you've got the right code for your credit card, you know? What was your dog's name? kind of a thing. I'm being a bit facetious, but not really. And also seeking harder data, from DNA to birth certificates, which takes longer.So I want to do this as quickly as humanly possible and as safely as possible.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your executive action, how will you ensure its effectiveness against potential Republican obstruction via funding cuts? Also, are you now considering a figure of 2 million or more? [SEP] Well, let's just say that when the details of the executive action are unveiled, I anticipate they will be quite comprehensive. I'm sure there will be ample opportunity for follow-up questions at that time. We'll have plenty to discuss, I assure you.

sentence: Mr. President, a two-part question concerning Canada: First, did you discuss the potential for Canada to boost its stimulus efforts? Second, what's your prediction for the U.S.-Canada relationship in four years, focusing on the automotive sector, border regulations, and carbon market integration? sentence: Mr. President, concerning the U.S. intelligence reports on Russian interference in past elections and cyberattacks, and considering Mr. Putin's denial of responsibility, what specific actions did you secure today to prevent future interference, and what consequences did you articulate? [SEP] Look, he understands that further action will be met with a response, just as it was previously. We made it abundantly clear that these actions would not be tolerated. The result? Diplomatic repercussions, facility closures, and a clear understanding that such behavior carries consequences. Beyond that, and perhaps underestimated by some, is the erosion of global credibility. Imagine the outcry if the U.S. meddled in other nations' elections. It's about upholding international norms and recognizing that no single nation dictates the world's order. There are other major players, including the United States.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, does your recent rhetoric signal a growing openness to doing away with the filibuster? [SEP] I believe I've already answered that./Healthcare Access/Economic Opportunity/The Future of America.

sentence: Q. TV Asahi. My name is Yamamoto. Prime Minister, President Biden, thank you very much.First, to Prime Minister: With the Russian aggression of Ukraine, Prime Minister, you've been saying that security of Europe and security of the Indo-Pacific are inseparable. In today's meeting, did you talk about response to China? How did you analyze the current status of the cross-Straits relations? Did the Japanese side or U.S. side explain how U.S. would respond in times of contingency? What was the request from the U.S. side regarding Japanese response to a contingency in cross-Straits situation? Did you explain the defense budget increase or enemy base strike capability? What did you explain in that context, Prime Minister?Prime Minister Kishida. Well, thank you for your question. First of all, at today's summit meeting, as regards Taiwan Strait issue that you asked, we confirmed that basic stances of two countries on Taiwan remains to be unchanged and underscored the importance of peace and stability of Taiwan Strait, which is an indispensable element for security and prosperity of international community, and called upon peaceful resolution of cross-Strait issues.Well, in the region, security-related environment is getting severer. Unilateral attempt to change the status quo by force, like Russia's aggression against Ukraine this time, should never be tolerated in Indo-Pacific. Above all, in East Asia, it's indispensable to further strengthen Japan-U.S. alliance.Based on this shared awareness, I have said that—fundamentally reinforce Japan's defense capability. And I stated my determination to fundamentally reinforce Japan's defense capabilities and secure substantial increase of its defense budget needed to effect it. And President Biden strongly supported my determination.And also from myself, I have said that includes what is called enemy base strike capability. All the options will be there, not to exclude any one of them. And this is what I said to President in Indo-Pacific region, as well as to ensure the peace and prosperity of the international community, the basis is the cornerstone of which is Japan-U.S. alliance. And toward the further strengthening of the alliance, we would like to remain in close coordination between Japan and the United States.Thank you.Moderator. Thank you very much.U.S. Economy/Foreign Investment in U.S. Manufacturing/Gasoline Prices/Inflation  Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I have a question for Prime Minister Kishida as well. But, Mr. President, I wanted to ask you about the economy. During your trip here to Asia, you've promoted the investments by Samsung and Hyundai. But back home in the United States, Americans are dealing with record-high inflation. The Fed has raised interest rates to try to address those issues. And there are also just enormously high gas prices.Given the cross-currents of the economy right now—the war in Ukraine, the China lockdowns that we've seen—should Americans be prepared for a recession? In your view, is a recession in the United States inevitable? [SEP] No.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. ——that made it very difficult for you in this election cycle, and that it was because they were chairmans, there were chairmanships that were vacated. But Jeff Flake wasn't a chairman of a committee, and Paul Ryan also retired this cycle. So why do you think that is? Whose fault is it that there were so many retirements? [SEP] In Jeff Flake's case, it's me. Pure and simple. I retired him. [] I'm very proud of it. I did the country a great service.Go ahead. Give him that—[]. Give him that—he is retired. I'd like to call it another word, but we're going to treat him with great respect.Go ahead.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, what are your key learnings from the summit with Chairman Kim? And what is your reaction to Michael Cohen's testimony, where he called you a liar, a conman, and a racist? [SEP] Well, it's incorrect. And you know, it's very interesting, because I tried to watch as much as I could. I wasn't able to watch too much because I've been a little bit busy. But I think having a fake hearing like that and having it in the middle of this very important summit is really a terrible thing. They could've made it 2 days later or next week, and it would've been even better. They would've had more time. But having it during this very important summit is sort of incredible. And he lied a lot, but it was very interesting, because he didn't lie about one thing. He said no collusion with the Russian hoax. And I said, I wonder why he didn't just lie about that, too, like he did about everything else? I mean, he lied about so many different things, and I was actually impressed that he didn't say, Well, I think there was collusion for this reason or that. He didn't say that. He said, No collusion. And I was, you know, a little impressed by that, frankly. Could've—he could've gone all out. He only went about 95 percent instead of 100 percent. But the fact is, there is no collusion. And I call it the witch hunt. This should never happen to another President. This is so bad for our country. So bad. You look at this whole hoax, it's a—I call it the Russian witch hunt and now add the word hoax. It's a very, very bad thing for our country. But I was impressed with the fact that he—when—you know, because the most important question up there was the one on collusion. And he said he saw no collusion. So we'll see what happens. But it was pretty shameful, I think.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: ——acquire nuclear capabilities? [SEP] I understand your angle. It's a transparent effort to make me comment, but I decline. Thank you.

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. So if I can ask your response to two items in the news and ask a COVID question. First, do you have any—have you been briefed on the incident off the coast of California, where the marines and the Navy corpsman—hospitalman died in a training accident a couple day—over the weekend? sentence: Mr. President, regarding North Korea's recent cyberattack, what specific actions are you prepared to take, and could you elaborate on the potential economic or military responses under consideration? Also, concerning Cuba, are there any concrete steps being planned to foster engagement with the Cuban people in the near future? A comprehensive set of options is being formulated, and I will carefully assess them to determine the most fitting and commensurate response to this transgression. As for Cuba, while a presidential visit or reciprocal visit isn't currently on the horizon, I remain optimistic that future opportunities will arise to connect with the Cuban populace. We're focused on the present situation, but I anticipate future engagement.

sentence: If Putin were to concede power, would the U.S. consider that a successful outcome? [SEP] The key is for him to cease directing military actions against innocent civilians. His resignation is paramount. He must relinquish his position.

sentence: Q. When will we have that? [SEP] I would say within 2 weeks. And it's being worked on. Deborah, we're working on that very strongly. The CDC—[inaudible]. The President. Okay, CDC is working, but we're getting reports on that. Yes, please, go ahead.

sentence: Mr. President, critics are saying that your failure to prioritize testing, your inconsistent messaging on masks and distancing, and your belief that you know more than the experts are directly responsible for the high COVID-19 death toll. What do you say to that? [SEP] That's probably why she was such a disaster as a candidate and had to drop out – she's just plain wrong. She's terrible with facts. Let's be clear: We've done more testing than anyone else, period. More than India with its 1.5 billion people, more than China, more than everyone. Our testing is the best in the world. Other countries are calling us, begging to know how we do it. But here's the deal: when you test as much as we do – 65 million people and counting – you're going to find more cases, obviously. If you went to Mexico or other countries, you'd see they barely test at all. They only test people who are already sick. We've done the most testing, and we've done the best job overall. We even became the 'ventilator king,' supplying the whole world with these complex and vital machines. And when you look at the numbers, we were impacted less than many other countries. Now, some of those countries are seeing huge spikes, even though they had advantages. So, we've done a great job. She's just wrong on the facts. I think she's going to be a big failure, and I'm looking forward to the debate between her and Mike Pence. He'll destroy her, just like he destroyed Senator Kaine.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, given the gravity of the allegations surrounding Russian interference, shouldn't electors be fully informed before casting their votes? And looking ahead, is it time to revisit the Electoral College system to ensure that every vote counts equally? [SEP] That's a complex issue with many facets.

sentence: President Bush, given your leadership of the world's superpower and your past actions in Iraq concerning UN resolutions, why not apply similar pressure to Israel regarding Palestinian territories? Furthermore, Mr. Abbas, did you ask President Bush to push for a complete settlement freeze to facilitate negotiations? [SEP] I'm sorry, could you repeat the part about the UN resolutions? I didn't quite understand.

sentence: Mr. President, given the immense human and financial cost of the Iraq War, and the criticisms leveled against your initial strategy, how can you justify your continued commitment to a course of action that many believe has been demonstrably unsuccessful? [SEP] With all due respect, that's a simplistic view of a very complex situation. As Mike Hayden himself has said, the situation in Iraq required a change of direction. And we made that change. The surge, for example, was a direct response to the evolving situation on the ground. Furthermore, we've seen significant progress in Anbar Province, where local citizens have turned against Al Qaeda. This bottom-up reconciliation is just as important as any top-down political agreement. So, while the costs have been high, we're seeing positive developments that justify our continued efforts. It's about adapting to the situation and making the best decisions we can with the information we have.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding General Neller's warning to U.S. Marines in Norway about a 'big-ass fight,' could you elaborate on the potential threat and its location? [SEP] This 'big war' you speak of... what are you getting at?

sentence: Mr. President, tomorrow your administration will release a business advisory concerning Hong Kong. Could you elaborate on the reasons behind this decision? Furthermore, regarding your Build Back Better initiative, have you engaged in discussions with Senators Manchin and Sinema regarding the $3.5 trillion framework, and do you anticipate their support at that level? Should they insist on reducing certain elements, will you be able to retain the backing of progressives? [SEP] Hong Kong is a problem. China needs to do better. Build Back Better is a priority. We're talking to everyone. We'll get it done.

sentence: Mr. President, intelligence agencies are reporting that Russia is already interfering in this year's election to undermine Joe Biden, and China is considering meddling to hurt you. Do you believe these assessments? And what actions do you plan to take in response? [SEP] Well, it's possible. Very possible. But I'd say the last person Russia wants in office is Donald Trump, because nobody has been tougher on Russia than I have, ever.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, your opinion, please, on the plan to build a mosque near Ground Zero. They have the constitutional right, but what message would it send if they were pressured to abandon the project? Also, has this Koran-burning threat from Florida endangered American lives? [SEP] Look, on that Koran issue, it's obvious that when someone deliberately tries to provoke a billion Muslims, especially when we have troops in so many Muslim countries, it creates a real problem. It makes things even tougher for our soldiers. As for the mosque in New York, I've been very clear: this country believes everyone is equal, and they have rights, including the right to practice their religion. If you can build a church, a synagogue, a temple, you should be able to build a mosque. I understand the sensitivities around 9/11. I've met with the families, I know their pain. But we are not at war with Islam. We are at war with terrorist groups who distort Islam. We have to be clear about that, because we need allies to fight terrorism. Al Qaeda wants a war between the West and Islam. Most Muslims are peaceful and want the same things we do: good jobs, education for their kids, safety, a better life. They reject this violent ideology. From a national security perspective, we need to identify the enemy: a small group of people committing terrible acts, mostly against Muslims. We also have millions of Muslim Americans, our fellow citizens, our neighbors, our friends, our coworkers. If we start acting like their religion is offensive, what are we saying to them? We have Muslims fighting for us in Afghanistan. They're risking their lives. We have to make sure they know we consider them Americans, just like us. That's a critical principle.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, some are questioning the validity of your Homeland Security Secretary's concerns regarding a potential summer attack, given the lack of hard evidence. Could you elaborate on the reasoning behind these concerns and what specific measures are being taken to address them? [SEP] Look, the key is this: we are constantly evaluating potential threats. The Secretary has access to information that isn't always public. We're not going to telegraph our moves to the enemy. What I can tell you is that we are taking every precaution to protect the American people. We're working with our allies, strengthening our intelligence, and making sure our response capabilities are top-notch. This isn't about 'gut feelings'; it's about being vigilant and proactive in a dangerous world. We've learned from the past, and we won't make the same mistakes again. We are staying ahead of the curve, and that's what the American people expect from us.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, what are your specific goals regarding this impeachment process? [SEP] It's a complete and total sham. A hoax. It's a disaster for our country. The head of the World Trade Organization is here, and he has to listen to this nonsense about a perfect phone call. Nobody mentions the transcript. Nobody talks about the call itself, because there's nothing to see. Just read it! Anyone can read it. And they'll say, 'That's grounds for impeachment?' If that were the case, Lyndon Johnson and Kennedy would have been impeached immediately. It's a hoax. You know it's a hoax better than anyone.
label: Dodging

sentence: About your talks with Kim Jong Un, is there a transcript? [SEP] Huh?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Pakistan's nuclear ambitions, many are concerned about their expanding arsenal and regional instability. Beyond simply stating they should join the NPT, what specific actions is your administration taking to ensure Pakistan's nuclear materials are secure and that they are not contributing to proliferation? [SEP] Look, we're monitoring the situation in Pakistan very closely. We've had some very frank conversations with their leadership. They understand our concerns. We're providing assistance to help them secure their nuclear materials. It's a complex situation, a very complex situation, and we're working on it. We want to see a stable and secure Pakistan, a very stable and secure Pakistan.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Deadline for the Kosovo independence? [SEP] Say that again?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Obama, can you confirm if Chen Guangcheng is under U.S. protection in Beijing? What is the likely resolution? Would the U.S. grant him asylum if requested? Prime Minister Noda, how likely is a North Korean nuclear test? How would Japan respond? What U.S. action would you like? [SEP] I'm aware of the reports, but I won't comment directly on Chen's situation. Human rights are always raised with . We believe openness strengthens . Regarding North Korea, our consultation after the missile launch shows our alliance's importance. We've told North Korea that provocations lead to isolation and sanctions. We insist they abide by international norms. Prime Minister Noda?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Is Mr. Putin likely to abandon his role as a disruptor of NATO and the US? What were the specific penalties you communicated for interfering with US critical infrastructure? [SEP] Allow me to answer your second question first. I emphasized to him that we have considerable cyber capabilities. He is aware of this, although he may not know the exact nature of our capabilities. I made it clear that if they violate these fundamental norms, we will respond with cyber warfare. He is aware of this.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President——Injuries Among U.S. Troops Stationed in Iraq/Iran  Q. Mr. President, a question on Iran: Initially, you said repeatedly to Americans that after Iran retaliated for the Soleimani strike, no Americans were injured. We now know at least 11 U.S. service men were airlifted from Iraq. Can you explain the discrepancy? [SEP] No, I heard that they had headaches, and a couple of other things. But I would say, and I can report it is not very serious. Not very serious.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, reflecting on the impending end of the war in Afghanistan, do you believe the extensive human and economic costs have been justified, particularly given the apparent limitations in achieving the initial visions of reconstruction and democracy? And President Karzai, considering the numerous criticisms regarding corruption and governance in Afghanistan, do you still maintain that foreign influence is primarily responsible, and will you definitively relinquish the presidency after the upcoming elections? [SEP] We went to Afghanistan because of 9/11. We took out Al-Qaeda. That was the goal. We've made progress. Is Afghanistan perfect? No. But we've made progress. And that's what's important. As for Karzai, he's doing the best he can in a tough situation. We're working with him to build a stable and prosperous Afghanistan.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. But just a few hours ago, Russian Foreign Minister is saying that it's not their foreign policy pursuit to return to G-8. What's your reaction to that? [SEP] Well, you know, we'll see. I know one thing: If they were invited back, I think they'd be there. If they weren't, that's okay too. I just think they'd be better inside than outside. I mean, as I said before, I really do; I think they'd be an asset. I think it would be a good thing.You know, some of the things—we were going in the room, and yesterday, in particular, we were discussing four or five matters. And Russia was literally involved in all of those four or five matters. And a few of the people looked up and said, you know, Why aren't they here talking to us about it? And we go: What are we going to do now? Go home? Take it easy for a day? Although, I'm not doing that. I don't take it easy.But what are we going to do? We're going to go home and start calling them at the end of the week and say, Hey, how about this? They could have been in the room.We had numerous things that we were discussing. Right? Numerous. We had a lot of things that we were discussing, and it would've been very easy if Russia was in the room. If he was in the room, we could've solved those things. Now they're just in limbo. But I have to say, with all of that, very little in limbo.But somebody will speak to him about some things, and frankly, they're not very complicated. But it would be easier if they were in the room. Okay?
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Sir, is the election of these two Muslim women a statement against your policies? [SEP] Sorry, what did you say?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Huawei, you mentioned discussing their entity listing. Is there a possibility they might be removed from that list? [SEP] I'm not going to delve into that right now. We're examining the situation very closely. Huawei is a significant factor in our country, particularly concerning intelligence matters. We have considerable information about them. But I don't think it's appropriate to discuss it at this moment. Let's just say we're not making it a primary focus, other than what I've already stated. We'll address it later.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, can you comment on the possibility of direct talks? [SEP] I'd prefer not to delve into that particular area.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the high gas prices affecting Americans, will you directly request increased oil production from Saudi Arabia during your upcoming trip? And how will you reconcile this with holding them accountable for human rights? [SEP] Well, let's be clear, the primary focus of this trip isn't solely about Saudi Arabia or oil production. I'm starting in Israel, at their request. The larger context is a meeting with the G-7—the Gulf States plus three. I anticipate meeting with the King and Crown Prince, but that's not the core purpose. The trip aims to deepen Israel's integration in the region, which benefits peace and Israeli security. We're also addressing the conflict in Yemen, which extends far beyond Saudi Arabia.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, following up on the NATO meeting, would you consider halting military exercises in the Baltic States if President Putin requests it? [SEP] Well, that's something we might discuss. But I want to emphasize that we'll be addressing those three issues and many others. We'll talk about it. Okay? Next question.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, could you clarify whether you personally authorized an investigation into the Hadley memo leak prior to your meeting with Prime Minister al-Maliki? Furthermore, if unauthorized, do you suspect internal sabotage of your Iraq policy or the meeting itself? [SEP] Well, let me see... ordering an investigation... doesn't immediately ring a bell. What I do remember is being rather displeased about the persistent leaks. You reporters are resourceful, I give you that, but the unauthorized disclosure of classified information is a serious issue. It's a problem that plagues every administration, not just mine. We've had a number of leaks, some from unknown sources, so I won't speculate. Finding the source is always the challenge. There might be an ongoing investigation, I honestly can't say for sure at this moment. But I firmly believe that those who leak classified materials, in clear violation of the law, should be held accountable. Establishing consequences for such actions is the best deterrent.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning currency devaluation and China, what's your expectation? Also, any thoughts on whether your party needs new leadership? [SEP] China's growth is welcome, lifting millions from poverty, benefiting the world. But with success comes responsibility. The RMB issue is an irritant, undervalued through intervention. They need a gradual shift to a market-based system. Regarding the Democratic Party, I anticipate talented individuals will emerge, promoting ideas that resonate with the American people. Speaker Pelosi and Harry Reid have been outstanding partners, and I look forward to continued collaboration.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I just want to come back to the debt ceiling, because in the summer of 2011, you said that you wouldn't negotiate on the debt ceiling, and you did. Last year, you said that you wouldn't extend any of the Bush tax cuts for the wealthy, and you did. So as you say now that you're not going to negotiate on the debt ceiling this year, why should House Republicans take that seriously and think that if we get to the 1-minute-to-midnight scenario, that you're not going to back down? [SEP] Well, first of all, Julianna, let's take the example of this year and the fiscal cliff. I didn't say that I would not have any conversations at all about extending the Bush tax cuts. What I said was we weren't going to extend Bush tax cuts for the wealthy, and we didn't. Now, you can argue that during the campaign, I saidI set the criteria for wealthy at 250, and we ended up being at 400. But the fact of the matter is millionaires, billionaires, are paying significantly more in taxes, just as I said. So from the start, my concern was making sure that we had a Tax Code that was fair and that protected the middle class, and my biggest priority was making sure that middle class taxes did not go up.The difference between this year and 2011 is the fact that we've already made $1.2 trillion in cuts. And at the time, I indicated that there were cuts that we could sensibly make that would not damage our economy, would not impede growth. I said at the time I think we should pair it up with revenue in order to have an overall balanced package. But my own budget reflected cuts in discretionary spending. My own budget reflected the cuts that needed to be made, and we've made those cuts.Now, the challenge going forward is that we've now made some big cuts, and if we're going to do further deficit reduction, the only way to do it is in a balanced and responsible way.The alternative is for us to go ahead and cut commitments that we've made on things like Medicare or Social Security or Medicaid and for us to fundamentally change commitments that we've made to make sure that seniors don't go into poverty or that children who are disabled are properly cared for.
