For us to change that contract we've made with the American people rather than look at options like closing loopholes for corporations that they don't need, that points to a long-term trend in which we have fundamentally, I think, undermined what people expect out of this Government, which is, is that parties sit down, they negotiate, they compromise, but they also reflect the will of the American people; that you don't have one narrow faction that is able to simply dictate 100 percent of what they want all the time or otherwise threaten that we destroy the American economy.Another way of putting it is, we've got to break the habit of negotiating through crisis over and over again. And now wenow is as good of a time as any, at the start of my second term, because if we continue down this path, then there's really no stopping the principle. I mean, literallyeven in divided government, even where we've got a Democratic President and a Democratic Senatethat a small group in the House of Representatives could simply say every 2 months, every 3 months, every 6 months, every year, we are going to more and more change the economy in ways that we prefer, despite strong objections of Americans all across the country, or otherwise, we're going to have America not pay its bills. And that is no way for us to do business.And by the way, I would make the same argument if it was a Republican President and a Republican Senate, and you had a handful of Democrats who were suggesting that we are going to hijack the process and make sure that either we get our way 100 percent of the time, or otherwise, we are going to default on America's obligations.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you very much. Mr. President, I've got a question to Mr. Obama. You just mentioned that Afghanistan is still a dangerous place. While it's a dangerous place, is it the right decision to draw down the force level at a time when it's a dangerous place and meanwhile Afghan forces are less equipped and they cannot fight truly?[The reporter and President Ghani spoke in Pashto, and their remarks were translated by an interpreter as follows.] Q. Mr. President, my question is, the peace process—what was your initial—or your request from the United States President? [SEP] The United States has agreed to—with us that the peace process will be led by Afghans, and Afghans will be—will continue this process, and it will be led by Afghans. And this is obvious for us, and we are thankful for the support. . Afghanistan is still a dangerous place. The way it's going to become less dangerous is by Afghan security forces and Afghan police being capable of keeping law and order and security in the country. And that is not going to happen if foreign forces are continually relied upon for the basic security of Afghanistan.So there are going to be specialized areas where we can cooperate, dealing with some of the most vicious terrorist networks. There's going to be intelligence cooperation and counterterrorism cooperation. And there are going to be specialized areas where we can provide logistical support and training and enabling support.But the fact is, is that unless Afghan soldiers and Afghan police are able to maintain security, at some point, someday, the United States and other coalition forces would leave. And the good news is, what we've seen as we've removed ourselves from combat roles is the Afghan security forces have stepped up. And although they're certainly not as well equipped as coalition forces, they're better equipped than the Taliban. They're better equipped than the Haqqani network.And so with the kind of leadership that President Ghani is showing as a Commander in Chief, with the leadership that's being shown by a growing cadre of military officers up and down the military chain, Afghan forces are proving themselves and discovering that, in fact, when they fight, they can be successful. And we want to stand with them in that process because we are very much invested in your success.So, Mr. President, thank you for an outstanding visit. Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, why can't your administration take certain actions while subpoenas are still being processed? [SEP] Excuse me? Bipartisanship?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Good morning, Mr. President. I'd like to ask you about the Justice Department. In the last couple months, we have heard disturbing evidence about senior officials of the Justice Department misleading Congress. We heard disturbing evidence yesterday that a senior official at Justice Department improperly took, by her own admission, political considerations into effect in evaluating career employees of the Justice Department.We've also had evidence from the former Deputy Attorney General of the White House strong-arming a sick man into trying to approve an illegal spying program. I'm curious, Mr. President, if you are concerned about the cumulative picture that's being drawn about your Justice Department? And what assurances can you give the American people that the Department is delivering impartial justice to the American people? [SEP] Yes, thank you, Michael. There is a—an internal investigation taking place at the Justice Department. And this will be an exhaustive investigation. And if there's wrongdoing, it will be taken care of.I thought it was interesting how you started your question, Over the months. I think you said, Over the last months. This investigation is taking a long time; in fact, kind of being drug out. I suspect for political question—for political reasons. In other words, as I mentioned the other day, it's just grand political theater.If—Attorney General Gonzales has testified. He's produced documents. And I would hope the Senate and the Congress would move expeditiously to finish their hearings and get on to the business of passing legislation that is meaningful for the country. But if there had been wrongdoing, that will be addressed, the way we'd hope it would be.
label: General

sentence: Q. And to Chancellor Scholz: Can you outline specific steps that Germany is taking to reduce its energy dependence on Russia? And what do you say to those who suggest that German reliance on Russian gas is limiting Europe's options for how to respond to the crisis in Ukraine?Chancellor Scholz. Thank you very much for raising that question because it gives me the opportunity to address a topic that's important to me. One good news, maybe, within its strategy on fighting manmade climate change, Germany has decided at very short—in a very short period of time to phase out of the use of oil and gas by—very soon. And by 2045, Germany will have a carbon-neutral economy as one of the strongest economies of the world.And with regard to these energies—we often think about heating at home and driving a car, but we're talking about industrial production: producing steel, chemical substances, cement. And changing these industrial processes and reorganizing such systems is what we have planned.So this year, we will continue to take far-reaching decisions that will help us to use more wind energy—offshore wind energy, onshore wind energy—and solar energy; and expand the capacities, expand the grids; and have a strategy for Germany, but also worldwide on the use of hydrogen, which is a central element for us to change our industrial processes that are using oil and gas right now.The industry is willing to be on board. We're doing this together with them, but it will probably be the biggest industrial modernization project in Germany in 100 years, with very good prospects that we will develop new technologies that other partners in the world can use as well, and this will help us fight climate change.And by the way, the energy mix today, we are talking about one-quarter of our energy that is linked to gas. And only part of that gas comes from Russia; a big part comes from Norway or the Netherlands. And of course, it is very important to us that we develop an infrastructure that will give us the opportunity to have all options available and react if needed.So you don't have to be concerned. There are some who should be concerned who see themselves maybe too much as a deliverer of such resources. Because we are focusing on renewable energies, we will go down that path and make sure that this is the profitable future.Mr. Rinke [Andreas Rinke, Reuters].Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG)/U.S. Energy Exports/Russia  Q. Mr. President, I would like to ask you a question about LNG. Germany and Europe are much more dependent on Russian gas than other regions of the world, and you promised European allies to help with LNG. But this resource is more expensive; it's not available in the volumes that might be needed to replace Russian gas. And I would like to know from you how you would help Europeans in case of a conflict with Russia. Is this an empty promise, or what can you really do? What can you offer?And, in addition, the U.S. are buying oil from Russia worth billions of dollars. And I would like to know whether these transfers are also part of the sanctions package against Russia.And, Mr. Chancellor—liquefied natural gas. There is a big controversy in Germany about fracking gas. And how far is LNG even a real replacement, or is it also with a view to the climate club you intend to found? Is it really an alternative to Russian pipeline gas? [SEP] Let me respond. First of all, we are looking at opportunities to make up for lost gas—LNG—from Russia. We're underway of trying to see what we can do to do that and dealing with our friends around the world, as well. We think we could make up a significant portion of it that would be lost.But you know, what everybody forgets here is, Russia needs to be able to sell that gas and sell that oil. Russia relies—a significant part of Russia's budget—it's the only thing they really have to export. And if in fact it's cut off, then they're going to be hurt very badly as well. And it's of consequence to them as well. This is not just a one-way street.And so we are looking at what we could do to help compensate for loss of—immediate loss of gas in Europe if it occurs. And that's what we've been working on for some time now. I can confirm that we work closely with the United States of America, and Joe Biden and I are working closely together as well.We are prepared for all kinds of situation. And that's part of what we do when we say we prepare sanctions. That means we need to be able to react at any time, and this is happening.With regard to the use of LNG, I can say that the biggest volume of LNG used across the world is the gas, and that is part of the debate.Concerning a long-term perspective, I already outlined what this is about. We will modernize our economy. And where gas is being used, we will switch to hydrogen. This will be a process that will happen faster than many might imagine today, and that will create a bright future for all of us. Thank you. Thank you very much. Appreciate it.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Yes.Prime Minister Solberg. Can I call on—[inaudible]—from the Norwegian Broadcasting.U.S. Military Strength/North Korea  Q. Mr. President, Prime Minister, recently, an American general, Robert Neller, told his marines based in Norway, There's a war coming—a big-ass fight. Mr. President, how imminent is that big war? And where will it take place? [SEP] When you say the big war, you're saying what? Say it.
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, concerning foreign influence in our elections, will you commit to refusing any aid from foreign entities? Furthermore, regarding the recent change in the DNI position, with Mr. Grenell's lack of intelligence background, how can you defend this choice to the American public? [SEP] Let me be clear: I want absolutely zero help from any foreign government. Never have, never will. Now, about CNN, your network… weren't they forced to retract certain statements? What was the nature of their apology yesterday, exactly?
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. As President, isn't it your responsibility, since this is your Postal Service, to meet this critical need? [SEP] Well, we have a man in there for 2 months. He's a very talented man. He's a brilliant business person. He's done great. He's a very nice man also. And he—Louis—he is working very hard.But as you know, the Democrats aren't approving the proper funding for Postal, and they're not approving the proper funding for this ridiculous thing that they want to do, which is all mail-in voting. Universal, you could call it, mail-in voting.Again, absentee voting is great. You request—I'm an absentee voter because I requested, I got, and then I sent in my vote. So that works out very well. That's what we've had. But now they want to send in millions and millions of ballots. And you see what's happening. They're being lost, they're being discarded. They're finding them in piles. It's going to be a catastrophe. So—and this is beyond the Post Office.But Louis DeJoy is working very hard. The Post Office has, for decades, lost billions and billions of dollars. I read numbers today that are unthinkable. And what they want to do now is hit the Post Office with millions of ballots from certain States. And if you look at what happened in New York and Virginia and various other places, it's a catastrophe. They're losing 20 percent of the votes. Nobody knows what's happened.So we're going to see what happens. But I do say this: Universal mail-in voting is going to be catastrophic. It's going to make our country a laughingstock all over the world. You can't send out millions of ballots.And look at all of the tests. Look, you've seen them, and there are many. Far more—just look at New York. Look at New Jersey. Look at the catastrophe in New Jersey. And New Jersey had more than just Paterson. Look at what's going on in Virginia. Look at what's happening with this mail-in voting. It's a disgrace. Absentee is good; mail-in, universal, is very, very bad. There's no way they're going to get it accurately. They're off by 20 and 30 percent. And this is beyond Post Office.Now, with that being said, they want money for the universal mail-in ballots, and they're not getting it. You know why? Because of them. We want money to go to people. They want money in order to bail out States that have done very poorly. The States that have done poorly, you know them as well as I do, these are run by Democrats, usually radical-left Democrats.You take a look at what's happening in Portland. And we'll go into Portland—we have to be asked—we'll go into Portland, straighten it out in 1 hour, like happened in Minneapolis. We'll go straighten it out in 1 hour. We will straighten that out so fast, but they have to ask us.So they need money, but they're not willing to approve the money that they need. If they can't get the money that they need for universal mail-in voting, I don't see how they can have it. And that's not only Post Office, it's also for the voting itself./Vote-by-Mail Policies
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. But would you like the U.S. to export more oil and gas? [SEP] The U.S., they are already exporting more. But for that point of view, it's better for to give you the elements. He already informed us in the G-7 meeting and just today that there are licenses already given that, in fact, are equivalent to the supply of gas to Europe, but they are traded in the global market. We certainly don't expect that gas to be earmarked for any kind of specific market. We are believers in free trade. We don't want that to be the case. It's good news, and it's up to the American President to confirm it, but I think I can say it here that there is potential still—that's what the President just told us—even to increase more of these licenses. So this is certainly good news. But we are not relying just on that. We have to do also our homework here in the European Union.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. So, is it a hard Brexit then? [SEP] Is it heartbreaking, you ask?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, following up on the pardon issue, is there any scenario, any circumstance, where you would consider issuing preemptive pardons before leaving office? [SEP] With all due respect, I'm not going to entertain hypotheticals about future pardon decisions at this time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Did either of them talk about Syria without Asad? [SEP] We had an intensive conversation about it. If you're asking me whether they signed on to that proposition, I don't think it would be fair to say that they are there yet. But my--I'm going to keep on making the argument, and my expectation is, is that at some point there's a recognition that it's hard to envision a better future for Syria while Asad is still there.Julianna Goldman [Bloomberg News].
label: Implicit

sentence: Ms. Iglesias from Bloomberg asks about Brazil's position on a potential U.S. military intervention in Venezuela. What's the official stance? [SEP] Well, as you know, certain matters are best left undiscussed for strategic reasons. Revealing our position would be counterproductive. We're handling this with utmost discretion.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, following up on Build Back Better and the pandemic: You're confident about passing significant portions of Build Back Better this year. Does that suggest you're considering breaking the package into separate parts? And regarding the pandemic, now that the Supreme Court has blocked the vaccine-or-test rule for larger businesses, are you rethinking vaccine mandates for domestic flights to increase vaccination rates? [SEP] Okay, first, on the latter part: The Supreme Court's decision, in my view, was a mistake. However, many people working for major corporations are still being tested due to corporate decisions, not my standards. I expect that number to rise, not fall. Now, what was the first part of your question again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, following up on your remarks regarding Governor Romney, can you assure the American people that these discussions will lead to tangible policy changes, and not simply be a symbolic gesture of bipartisanship? [SEP] Look, I'm always looking for good ideas, regardless of where they come from. Governor Romney has a track record, and I respect that. Whether it translates into specific legislation, that remains to be seen. But I'm open to a productive dialogue. That's what leadership is all about.
label: General

sentence: Q. Sir, is a signature required to finalize this agreement? [SEP] Honestly, I'm not sure about the specifics of the signing process. It's not a legally binding agreement, so the protocols might be different. But what I can tell you is that the United States is fully committed to this, and we believe it's very important. Thanks, everyone.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, about the CIA's interrogation program, the Red Cross says it was torture. Your thoughts? And Guantanamo – you said you'd close it, but it's still open. What's the deal? Will it be closed by the time you leave? [SEP] Look, I said we should close Guantanamo. The problem is, nobody wants these guys. We gotta have somewhere to put them. The Senate voted, like, 97-3 against bringing them here. So, it's practical. What do we do with them? You say nothing's happening? That's not true. We're trying to send them back, but nobody wants killers. And we gotta treat them right. We also want to try them. Courts are working on it. Defense is working on it. The sooner we get trials, the better. I can't promise it'll be closed. It's complicated. I set a goal. We'll see. It's not simple. Look at the Senate vote again. Nobody wants them. What else did you want to know?
label: Clarification

sentence: Given the persistent criticism from both sides of the aisle regarding your engagement with Congress, what specific strategies will you employ during your second term to foster stronger, more collaborative relationships? [SEP] Well, I'm always striving for improvement, and I'll be examining ways to better convey my desire to work with everyone, so long as it's in service of strengthening our middle class and bolstering our economy. I've developed good relationships with many members of both the House and the Senate, on both sides of the political divide. However, this hasn't always translated into the kind of agreements between Democrats and Republicans that I'd like to see. We all share a responsibility to identify areas where we can improve, and I certainly include myself in that. I'll be engaging in some self-reflection to determine how I can improve our working relationships. There will likely continue to be some significant disagreements, and as I stated during the campaign, some fights are necessary. But what the American people don't want to see is a constant preoccupation with the next election, rather than a focus on their needs. I don't have another election to contest. Michelle and I were discussing last night what an extraordinary honor and privilege it is to hold this position. Millions of people across the country worked tirelessly to help us get elected, but millions more, who may not have voted for us, are also counting on us. We take that responsibility very seriously. I hope and intend to be an even better President in my second term than I was in my first.
label: General

sentence: So, just to confirm, you're asking if I intend to withdraw the troops? [SEP] Run that by me again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, you've said you would help us with a Brexit trade deal. You said you'd stand by us with NATO, but how can the British Prime Minister believe you, because you have been known in the past to change your position on things? And also, may I ask a question to both of you? People are fascinated to know how you're going to get on with each other. You're so different: the hard-working daughter of a vicar, the brash TV extrovert. Have you found anything in common personally yet? [SEP] Actually, I'm not as brash as you might think. [] And I can tell you that I think we're going to get along very well. You know, I've—interesting because I am a people person. I think you are also, Theresa. And I can often tell how I get along with somebody very early, and I believe we're going to have a fantastic relationship.Brexit—and I really don't change my position very much. If you go back and you look, my position on trade has been solid for many, many years, since I was a very young person talking about how we were getting ripped off by the rest of the world. Now, I never knew I'd be in this position where we can actually do something about it. But we will be talking to your folks about Brexit. Brexit was an example of what was to come, and I happened to be in Scotland at Turnberry cutting a ribbon when Brexit happened. And we had a vast amount of press there. And I said Brexit—this was the day before, you probably remember—I said Brexit is going to happen. And I was scorned in the press for making that prediction. I was scorned. And I said I believe it's going to happen, because people want to know who's coming into their country, and they want to control their own trade and various other things. And lo and behold, the following day, it happened. And the odds weren't looking good for me when I made that statement, because as you know, everybody thought it was not going to happen.I think Brexit's going to be a wonderful thing for your country. I think when it irons out, you're going to have your own identity, and you're going to have the people that you want in your country, and you're going to be able to make free trade deals without having somebody watching you and what you're doing. And I had a very bad experience. I have—I had something when I was in my other world. I have something in another country, and getting the approvals from Europe was very, very tough. Getting the approvals from the country was fast, easy, and efficient. Getting the approvals from the group—I call them the consortium—was very, very tough. But I thought Brexit—I think and I think it'll go down that it will end up being a fantastic thing for the United Kingdom. I think in the end it will be a tremendous asset, not a tremendous liability. Okay. And just on the question you asked me, Tom. I mean, I think as the President himself has said, I think we have already struck up a good relationship. But you asked what we had in common. I think if you look at the approach that we're both taking, I think one of the things that we have in common is that we want to put the interests of ordinary working people right up there, center stage. Those people who, you know, they're working all the hours, they're doing their best for their families, and sometimes, they just feel the odds are stacked against them. And it's that interest in ensuring that what we do, that the economies—our economies and our governments actually work for ordinary working people—work for everyone in our countries. I think we both share that. Thank you very much. Thank you. Thank you very much, everybody.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your financial regulation plan, set to be unveiled tomorrow, and understanding your reluctance to preempt that announcement, could you address concerns about the proliferation of regulatory bodies? With the proposed Consumer Financial Protection Agency joining the Fed, SEC, FDIC, and others, isn't adding another agency exacerbating the existing problem of bureaucratic overlap and inefficiency? [SEP] As you correctly point out, I'm reserving the specifics for tomorrow's announcement. However, let me frame the issue broadly. The core problem we're addressing is the systemic failure of oversight that allowed unchecked risk-taking within financial institutions, both banks and non-banks. This recklessness jeopardized not only those institutions but the entire U.S. and global economies. Our aim is to modernize a regulatory framework largely unchanged since the 1930s to effectively manage the complexities of global capital flows and novel financial instruments. While the complete plan will reveal the details, rest assured that streamlining and consolidation are integral components. We are committed to creating a more integrated system that prevents individuals and institutions from falling through the cracks, whether in consumer protection, investor protection, or systemic risk mitigation. This will undoubtedly be a challenging endeavor, as certain entities will resist any measures that curtail their ability to take excessive risks, relying on taxpayer bailouts when their gambles fail. Despite the inevitable opposition and the predictable calls for deregulation, we must remember the devastating consequences of unchecked recklessness. We intend to implement measures that will prevent a recurrence of the crisis.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Lee, can you detail the specific sanctions South Korea is planning and provide an update on the missile range extension talks with the US? [SEP] We are considering all options in close consultation with our partners. North Korea's actions are unacceptable and will not be tolerated. On the missile range, this is a complex issue that requires careful consideration. We are working towards a solution that strengthens our defense capabilities.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: On the contentious issue of federally mandated busing, you've seen the clashes between Biden and Harris. Where do you stand? Do you believe the federal government should mandate busing to achieve desegregation? [SEP] Well, let's just say that whole debate was a bit overblown, wasn't it? She got way too much credit, and frankly, he took more heat than he deserved. As for my position? We're developing some very interesting policy initiatives, things that will surprise a lot of people, I think. So, stay tuned. We'll be rolling that out in about a month. Next question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: You've described these commutations as being for low-level drug offenders, but many also involved firearms offenses. How do you reconcile that with your views on firearms? [SEP] Well, each case was carefully reviewed on its individual merits.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, following General Pace's widely discussed remarks on homosexuality, your perspective remains unclear. Do you personally consider homosexuality to be immoral? [SEP] I'm not going to comment on the morality of individual choices. I continue to support the 'don't ask, don't tell' policy.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Second to that, do you believe that China is sincere about what it said this morning? [SEP] Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Are you suggesting a face-to-face meeting with representatives from Iran? [SEP] So, the core of your question is whether I intend to sit down with Iranian officials, is that correct?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, in reflecting on the conclusion of this conflict, can you justify the significant human and financial expenditures, considering that Afghanistan has not fully realized the initial reconstruction and democracy objectives? President Karzai, do you maintain your assertion that foreign influence is a primary driver of Afghanistan's corruption and inadequate governance, and are you fully committed to relinquishing your presidency after next year's elections? [SEP] Let us not forget the impetus behind our intervention in Afghanistan. Three thousand Americans were brutally murdered by a terrorist organization operating freely within its borders. It was imperative that we pursue that organization and the government that harbored it. Thanks to the valor of our armed forces and the collaboration of Afghan allies, we have largely achieved our primary objective: to incapacitate Al Qaida and prevent future attacks against us. Our actions have been guided by this aim. We can confidently state that the sacrifices made by our service members have enabled us to achieve this goal. We also recognized the importance of a stable, sovereign Afghanistan that could serve as a responsible partner. This necessitated the development of Afghanistan's own security capabilities and a trajectory toward prosperity and peace. While Afghanistan still faces challenges, the prospects for peace and prosperity are greater now than before our intervention, owing in part to American sacrifices. Did we achieve all of our loftiest aspirations? Perhaps not, as human endeavors often fall short of perfection. However, did we achieve our core objective? Have we forged a strong relationship with a responsible Afghan government willing to cooperate in preventing future attacks against the United States? We are in the process of achieving that goal. We extend our gratitude to our military, intelligence, and diplomatic personnel, as well as the Afghan government and people. Regarding corruption, yes, it exists in Afghanistan, and we are actively combating it. While we have made progress, we are not complacent. On the issue of foreign-sourced corruption, I have been unequivocal: Afghanistan requires the cooperation of its international partners to address the shortcomings in the delivery of assistance. As for elections, my greatest legacy will be a fair and transparent election in which the Afghan people can freely choose their next leader. I will then retire, content in my service.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, does the United States plan to maintain a permanent military footprint in Iraq? Furthermore, would you be willing to explicitly disavow any ambition to establish permanent bases there? [SEP] Jim, the decision regarding any enduring presence in Iraq rests solely with the Iraqi government. Their immediate priority is achieving near-term stability, and they require our assistance to that end. Consequently, our efforts are concentrated on providing that support. It is crucial to remember that we are engaging with a sovereign nation. We have existing agreements with the Karzai government that delineate arrangements for a U.S. presence, contingent upon their continued desire for it. In due course, we will engage in discussions regarding the long-term security of Iraq. However, our present focus is on stabilizing Baghdad and addressing Al Qaeda's violent activities in Al Anbar Province. It is noteworthy that the perception of widespread sectarian conflict throughout Iraq is inaccurate. General Casey reported that 90% of the conflict is localized to 5 of the 18 provinces, primarily within a 30-mile radius of Baghdad. Despite the grim portrayal on television, many Iraqis are leading relatively normal lives. Farmers are cultivating their land, small businesses are expanding, the currency is reasonably stable, and there is a burgeoning entrepreneurial class. General Abizaid recounted his experiences visiting bustling markets in Baghdad. While significant challenges persist, many Iraqis aspire to normalcy, and Prime Minister Maliki bears the responsibility of ensuring their security. Ann, my apologies Rutenberg, your question has been addressed.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, isn't suggesting Ukraine join NATO only after the war essentially rewarding Putin's aggression? Doesn't it risk emboldening him and discouraging meaningful peace talks? [SEP] Look, the reality is, nobody's joining NATO in the middle of a war. That's just common sense. We don't want World War III. The real question is, what does Putin do next? He's already lost. He can end this anytime he wants. But make no mistake, Ukraine will be part of NATO. The timing, that's what we're talking about.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with Netanyahu's recent public acknowledgment of the Israeli airstrike in Syria, can you provide any insight into the target's nature, the U.S.'s stance on the operation, and its potential ramifications for regional stability, particularly concerning Syria, Iran, and Israel, and the possibility of U.S. involvement? [SEP] That's a matter best left to the intelligence community to assess and comment on, not me. Next question, please.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Sir, may I, as a representative of the international media, pose a question? [SEP] Where are you reporting from?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with voting rights legislation stalled, what specific executive orders or other measures are you considering to safeguard voting rights, fulfilling the promise you made months ago? [SEP] I'm not going to detail all the specifics at this moment. But we're not standing still. We've bolstered the Justice Department's ability to combat these Republican attempts to rig the system. We're mobilizing communities, educating the public about the dangers we face. The notion of overturning elections? It's something I never thought I'd see in this country. But we're prepared to fight it. And I remain optimistic that we can pass significant parts of the voting rights legislation, even if it takes time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, have you secured the support of all the Governors for this initiative? [SEP] We recently met with the Governors, and they're all very interested in getting funds for their states. The degree to which we can adjust the 25 percent depends on the specific state. We have the option to eliminate it or keep it, depending on the individual state's needs. So, it will vary from state to state. But the key takeaway is that a significant amount of money will be distributed to a large number of people rapidly. I've instructed the Secretary of the Treasury to expedite this process. Understood? Next question.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the anti-LGBTQ laws in Republican states, the violence, and the families considering leaving, what's your response? Prime Minister Sunak, what are the U.S. and U.K. doing about AI disinformation and election security? How will AI regulation differ from climate change efforts? [SEP] First, get me that family's number; I want to call them. We ended the transgender military ban, signed the Respect for Marriage Act, and strengthened LGBT civil rights. But we're fighting hysteria and prejudice. Firing someone for being gay is wrong, as is the rising violence. These bills targeting transgender children are cruel. They're our kids, and we're announcing new initiatives for protection: physical safety, civil rights, mental health. Congress must pass the Equality Act. LGBTQ Americans, we support you. On AI, it's beneficial but risky. We need guardrails, as discussed with Prime Minister Sunak. We're working with other countries, learning from climate change efforts. Urgency is key.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Can you provide details on the topics discussed during your meeting with [Person]? [SEP] We covered the same ground as the broader conference. We focused on stability and ensuring that developing nations in the Southern Hemisphere had access to change and opportunity. It was a cordial exchange. He approached me and said [inaudible]. Thank you all. The President. Thank you. That concludes the press conference. Thank you, everyone. The President. Thank you. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the Vice President's precautions, how do you reassure Americans about safety and reopening the country? And when will universal coronavirus testing be available? [SEP] The Vice President is doing great. He's tested, he's negative. No problem there. Now, about testing, we're the best in the world. Nobody can touch us. If you want a test, you can get a test. Simple as that. The incident you're talking about, it's a terrible, terrible thing. A beautiful young man. It breaks your heart. They're investigating it. We'll see what happens. It's a very sad situation.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, about the $400, sir. You're saying the States will have to cover some costs. Which Governors have agreed to sign onto that? [SEP] Well, if they don't, they don't. It's their choice. But if they don't, that's their problem. I don't think their people will be happy. They have the money. So, I don't think their people will be too happy. But if they don't, they don't. Again, the States have the money. It's just sitting there.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Concerning the Meng Wanzhou situation, Mr. President, will her case remain unresolved until the very end, or is there a chance the U.S. could withdraw the extradition effort? [SEP] Sorry, what was that about?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, are you saying that any perception of your rhetoric as supportive of white nationalism is simply a misinterpretation by the media? [SEP] Yes. It's a deliberate attempt to smear me and my supporters. We're building a better future for all Americans, and that's what I'm focused on.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: So, is the war in Afghanistan done? Is the Taliban running the show now? And also, why are you putting John Ratcliffe's name in the hat again? [SEP] Well, he's a terrific man. He's been fantastic at everything he's done. He's highly respected. He wanted to wait until after the IG report came in, as you saw originally. I don't think he was officially or formally nominated. His name was thrown out. But he wanted to wait until after the IG report. The IG report has now come, and we've learned a lot of very bad things from the IG report, as you know very well.And I think he'll go through a process, and it will go fairly quickly. He's a very respected man, somebody that I've gotten that like; somebody who really has—he's someone who's really distinguished himself and, I think, over the last year and a half, 2 years, in particular. So we're very happy with that.As far as the Taliban is concerned, everybody wanted this to happen. The Taliban wanted it to happen. President Ghani was very much involved in this, as you know. And he's now dealing with the Taliban.But we're talking about 19 years we've been there. Nineteen years. And other Presidents have tried to do this. The Taliban has given a pledge—and a very strong pledge—and we'll see how that all works out. We hope it's going to work out very well. I think they have big incentives to do it, but they have to take care of the terrorists and kill the terrorists. We'll be working in a different kind of a fashion toward that end.But the job we've done has been fantastic—a fantastic one in terms of terrorists and terrorism, and it's time for our people to start coming home.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. And can you answer the filibuster—[inaudible]? [SEP] Filibuster. Filibuster. You know, with regard to the filibuster, I believe we should go back to a position on the filibuster that existed just when I came to the United States Senate 120 years ago. And that is that—it used to be required for the filibuster—and I had a card on this; I was going to give you the statistics, but you probably know them—that it used to be that the—that from between 1917 to 1971—the filibuster existed—there were a total of 58 motions to break a filibuster that whole time. Last year alone, there were five times that many. So it's being abused in a gigantic way.And, for example, it used to be you had to stand there and talk and talk and talk and talk until you collapsed. And guess what? People got tired of talking and tired of collapsing. Filibusters broke down, and we were able to break the filibuster, get a quorum, and vote.So I strongly support moving in that direction, in addition to having an open mind about dealing with certain things that are—are just elemental to the functioning of our democracy, like the right to vote—like the basic right to vote. We've amended the filibuster in the past.But here's the deal: As you observed, I'm a fairly practical guy. I want to get things done. I want to get them done, consistent with what we promised the American people. And in order to do that in a 50/50 Senate, we've got to get to the place where I get 50 votes so that the Vice President of the United States can break the tie, or I get 51 votes without her.And so I'm going to say something outrageous: I have never been particularly poor at calculating how to get things done in the United States Senate. So the best way to get something done, if you hold near and dear to you that you like to be able to—anyway—I—we're going to get a lot done. And if we have to—if there's complete lockdown and chaos as a consequence of the filibuster, then we'll have to go beyond what I'm talking about.
label: Explicit

sentence: President Bush, could you offer your insights on the projected duration and intensity of the economic downturn in the US, and its potential impact on Mexico? Also, what are your thoughts on President Calderon's proposed reforms in Mexico? And for all of you, what security concerns arise from the situation with NAFTA and the FTA with Colombia, particularly after Colombia's military action in Ecuador? [SEP] Well, let's be clear, we're not in a recession, we're experiencing a slowdown. We saw growth in the last quarter of the previous year. We don't have the figures for the first quarter yet, but there's no doubt, things have slowed down. And yes, people are understandably worried. I'm probably the most concerned of the three of us here, because it's my responsibility to look after the people I represent. That's why we worked with Congress to pass a significant economic stimulus package, which will provide rebates to our citizens starting in May. The package also includes incentives for businesses to invest in 2008. I believe this will have a positive effect on the economy, and experts agree. The key is for Congress not to raise taxes during this time, as that would send the wrong message. As for President Calderon, he's more than capable of handling reform. He's a good, honest man who cares deeply about Mexico, and he'll do what he believes is right for his country. And regarding President Uribe, we have no better friend in South America. He's a strong believer in the rule of law, a reformer, and he's working hard to protect his country from drug traffickers who commit terrible acts. He deserves our support. The United States supports him in many ways, but if we don't approve the free trade agreement we negotiated with Colombia in good faith, it will undermine his efforts and destabilize the region. It would be a mistake for Congress to turn its back on Colombia. Mexico is taking measures to address this economic slowdown in the US, which obviously affects us. Over 82 percent of our exports go to the US, so we're implementing an aggressive public expenditure and infrastructure program. We're increasing infrastructure spending from 3 percent of GDP to over 5.5 percent, which translates to about $500 billion for private-public programs this year. This is already showing up in the figures for the first quarter. We're also working on an anti-cyclical program with tax incentives for investment in the poorest regions of Mexico, offering 100-percent deductions on investments and covering all social security and labor costs for a year and a half. This is a very strong stimulus package. The initial data indicates a 4.25 percent growth rate for Mexico's economic activity. The figures for February and March show that industrial activity continues to grow at about 4 percent. It's a challenging time due to the interconnectedness of our economies, but we're prepared to face the situation and move forward, albeit at a slower pace. We're using all available government resources to accelerate the growth of the Mexican economy. I hope this situation doesn't last long and that the US authorities will be able to overcome it soon. I believe the measures taken by the fiscal and monetary authorities in the US, as well as the Bush administration, have been appropriate and will soon show positive results, leading to a quick recovery for all our economies. In Canada, despite the economic slowdown, our economy remains stable and solid. We've taken steps to ensure continued growth in the future. Regarding Colombia, Canada has negotiated a free trade agreement with them. It's important for the US and Mexico to also benefit from free trade with Colombia. Last year, I said that Colombia can have drug trafficking with our countries without a free trade agreement, but if we want legitimate business for all our economies, we need to pursue free trade agreements with Colombia. I worry that if the US refuses this agreement with Colombia, it could create long-term problems for our countries in South America. We have an important alliance with Colombia, which is fighting against political violence, the FARC, and drug traffickers. Rejecting or turning our backs on such an ally could have long-term security consequences for all of our countries in North America. So, I do worry about that.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, could you elaborate on your perspective regarding the Pope's potential recognition of a Palestinian state and its potential ramifications for the pursuit of a two-state solution? [SEP] Well, first off, let me commend the Senate for their progress on granting me the authority to negotiate and finalize a smart, forward-thinking, and economically stimulating trade agreement with nations in the Asia-Pacific region, and potentially in Europe as well. This authority also equips me with the necessary mechanisms to enforce these agreements, something that has been lacking in the past. I extend my gratitude to all the Senators who supported this initiative, or at least initiated the debate to advance this process. To those who did not vote in favor, I will continue to present the rationale and provide the information needed to instill confidence that, despite past shortcomings in certain trade agreements, the approach we are adopting here is the correct one, not only for large U.S. corporations but also for small and medium-sized businesses, and most importantly, for American workers. I would not endorse any agreement that I did not believe would ultimately generate employment opportunities in the United States and provide increased opportunities for upward mobility, higher incomes, and improved wages for the American populace, as that remains my paramount objective since assuming office. The dynamic between myself and Elizabeth is purely professional. While the press may find amusement in highlighting disagreements on policy matters between close allies, I maintain strong relationships with numerous Senators and Representatives, including some of my earliest supporters, who hold differing views on this issue. I understand their perspective, as they, like myself, have witnessed plant closures and the relocation of jobs overseas. They share concerns regarding the effective enforcement of labor and environmental standards in international agreements, and whether trade practices are genuinely fair rather than merely free. Furthermore, they share a profound concern about global trends and domestic trends that have contributed to increased inequality, and the perceived impact of automation and globalization in enabling those at the upper echelons to thrive while wages and incomes for middle-class families and those striving to enter the middle class stagnate. These individuals share fundamentally aligned values with my own. I observed a recent progressive statement of principles articulated by some of these colleagues, which essentially mirrored my agenda, with the exception of trade. This divergence stems from a policy disagreement and a difference in analysis regarding what is most beneficial for our constituents. I firmly believe that, despite the shortcomings of previous trade agreements, we are better positioned to establish robust, high-standard regulations with stringent, enforceable provisions on matters such as child labor, deforestation, environmental degradation, wildlife trafficking, and intellectual property. We must establish these rules for what is projected to be the largest and fastest-growing market globally. Failure to do so will cede this opportunity to China and other nations, thereby disadvantaging our businesses and ultimately harming our workers. Regarding concerns about job outsourcing, my assessment indicates that companies seeking low-cost labor already have the means to outsource under the existing framework. This agreement presents an opportunity to incentivize companies to relocate manufacturing operations back to the United States. We are already witnessing instances of this trend. My visit to Nike, for example, highlighted their plans to potentially bring back 10,000 jobs due to advancements in manufacturing technologies. However, we must also ensure our ability to sell our products in these markets to fully capitalize on these opportunities. Therefore, my argument to my progressive colleagues is that we should prioritize areas of shared agreement, such as a strong minimum wage, robust job training programs, infrastructure investments to stimulate employment, stronger protections for collective bargaining, rigorous enforcement of overtime pay regulations, guaranteed paid sick leave, and an honest dialogue about our budget priorities to ensure that we are not sacrificing investments in the future to preserve loopholes for corporations that provide no economic benefit. These measures will effectively address the concerns they have raised. Obstructing this trade agreement will not, particularly given their acknowledgment that the current trade rules are detrimental to U.S. workers. If the existing rules are not serving our interests, how does maintaining the status quo benefit American workers? It defies logic. I fully support enforcement and the provisions that have been signed. I have expressed reservations regarding the drafting of the currency language in the bill, and I intend to consult with Senator Schumer and Sherrod Brown to explore potential modifications that would not inadvertently undermine our ability to maintain our own monetary policy. Remind me, what was the other question you asked?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Brexit and the Prime Minister's plan, your stance appears to have evolved since earlier this week, when you implied it could kill a trade deal with the U.K. Given our 'special relationship,' was your public critique of her policy, and even her personally, truly the behavior of a friend? And Prime Minister, how did you feel about the President's criticism of your Brexit plan and its potential impact on future trade agreements? [SEP] Well, let me be clear. I have tremendous respect for the Prime Minister. The media, as usual, took my remarks out of context. They conveniently omitted the positive things I said. Fortunately, we record these interviews now – a useful tool against 'fake news.' The Prime Minister will make her own decision. My only concern is that it doesn't hinder trade. We want to trade with the U.K., and they want to trade with us. We're their biggest partner, by far. Huge potential to expand that. If they choose a different path – and they want independence, which is their right – I simply hope trade with the U.S. remains possible. Some reports suggest it won't be, but after speaking with her representatives, I'm confident it will. So, based on that, and our overall relationship – which will be fine – trade is a bit tricky. We both want to trade, and I believe we'll achieve that. And she's doing a terrific job, I must say.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, the debt increased significantly even before the pandemic. What specific policies, aside from tax cuts, contributed to this rise, and were there any spending cuts implemented to offset the increased debt? [SEP] We renegotiated trade deals. We brought jobs back to America. We did things that nobody else would have done. The swamp was fighting us every step of the way. But we were making America great again. And that required investment.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Russia and Ukraine, after your summit, you suggested Putin didn't want a cold war. Now we see troop deployments, cyber warfare, and demands for a sphere of influence. Do you still hold that view? Has your assessment of Putin evolved? And should he invade, would you revert to a containment strategy? [SEP] My assessment is he still avoids a full-scale war. Yet, he will probe the resolve of the West, the US, and NATO to the fullest extent. He will incur a significant cost, one he underestimates. He is wrestling with the perceived loss of the Soviet empire. He seeks his place between China and the West. I anticipate some form of incursion; he feels compelled to act. He seeks assurances on Ukraine's NATO membership and the placement of strategic weapons. The latter is negotiable, the former less so due to existing agreements. Ukraine's near-term NATO accession is improbable. There is room for diplomacy, but I foresee actions that will ultimately be detrimental to him.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the investigation into Russian interference, can you assure the American public that your campaign will reject any form of foreign assistance in the upcoming election? Furthermore, concerning the recent departure of Acting DNI Joseph Maguire and his replacement with Ambassador Rick Grenell, how do you respond to criticisms about appointing someone with no prior intelligence experience to such a crucial role? [SEP] Look, let me be clear, nobody wants help from foreign countries. And I haven't received any. As for CNN, that failing network, didn't they issue some sort of apology for their inaccurate reporting? What exactly did they say yesterday, huh?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, could you repeat that question? [SEP] I'm sorry, what was that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, do you regret praising China's handling of the coronavirus situation earlier this year? [SEP] My policy is to always show respect to China.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your proposed middle-class tax cuts, what specific strategies are you prepared to employ to overcome anticipated Democratic resistance in Congress? [SEP] You'd have to ask the other side of the aisle about that.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Are you suggesting that a meeting is not guaranteed? [SEP] I'm going to assess things. I just finished these meetings. The issue of combating crime and drug trafficking is a major concern for all of us, and we must address it appropriately.
label: Deflection

sentence: Sir, regarding your tenure, do you acknowledge any instances where your statements to the American people lacked complete veracity? [SEP] I'm sorry, I didn't catch that. What exactly are you referring to?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, your predecessor engaged in a phone conversation with Taiwan's president and subsequently questioned the necessity of adhering to the one-China policy, suggesting it as leverage for trade or North Korea negotiations. Given heightened tensions and China's recent seizure of an underwater drone, do you believe our China policy requires reevaluation? What are your thoughts on direct communication with Taiwan's leader, and are you concerned about potential conflict with China due to such unconventional approaches? [SEP] Well, it's a complex issue. I see both sides. Any administration should re-examine foreign policy. I'm proud of my work, and experience is valuable, but fresh perspectives are beneficial. Democracy benefits from new viewpoints. A new president should assess past actions. That's what I did. Given the US-China relationship's importance to the global economy, national security, and Asia-Pacific presence, it demands careful consideration. Conflict would harm everyone. So, a review is warranted. I've advised the President-elect to approach foreign policy systematically. There's only one president at a time. I suggested assembling a full team, briefing them on past events, potential pitfalls, and opportunities before engaging with foreign governments. This ensures informed decisions and unified government action. Regarding Taiwan, there's a long-standing agreement among China, the US, and Taiwan to maintain the status quo. Taiwan operates differently from mainland China, and China acknowledges this. Taiwan maintains autonomy. This uneasy peace allows Taiwan's economic success and self-determination. But for China, Taiwan is paramount. The one-China policy is central to their national identity. Disrupting this understanding requires careful consideration of consequences. China's reaction would be significant, unlike other issues. This doesn't mean adhering to the past, but thoughtful planning is essential.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Will you engage in direct talks with Iranian officials? [SEP] So, the question is whether I intend to have a face-to-face meeting with representatives from Iran?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with gas prices soaring, will you ask Saudi Arabia to pump more oil? And how do you balance that with their human rights record? [SEP] Look, the trip isn't *just* about Saudi Arabia or gas prices. I'm going to Israel first, because they asked me to. It's a bigger meeting with the Gulf States and others. I might see the King and Crown Prince, but that's not the main thing. We're trying to get Israel more involved in the region, which is good for everyone. Plus, we're working on the Yemen war, which has nothing to do with Saudi Arabia, really.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. The first $350 billion is out the door; it's been spent. Are you satisfied that it's been spent wisely? And for the second 350 that's under consideration, do you think— are you supportive of Congress putting some restrictions on it? [SEP] I'm supportive of the President-elect working out a plan with Congress that best suits him—and Congress. That's what he's going to have to do. He's going to have to go up there, and he's going to have to make his case as to why the 350 [billion] * is necessary. And he knows that. This is nothing new.And in terms of the first 350 [billion], * I am pleased with this aspect of the expenditure, and that is that the financial markets are beginning to thaw. In the fall, I was concerned that the credit freeze would cause us to be headed toward a depression greater than the Great Depression. That's what I was told, if we didn't move. And so therefore, we have moved aggressively.And by the way, it just wasn't with the TARP. If you think about AIG, Fannie and Freddie, a lot of the decisions that were made in this administration are very aggressive decisions, all aiming at preventing the financial system from cratering.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Chancellor Merkel, is this award simply a recognition of her past achievements, or does it also reflect your expectations for her future role? Where do you see opportunities for Germany to contribute more globally? And Madam Chancellor, does Germany's economic strength translate into increased responsibilities on the world stage? [SEP] Well, the Medal of Freedom is certainly a testament to Chancellor Merkel's remarkable career. She's been an exceptional leader of the German economy and a champion of European unity. Her own life story embodies the overcoming of the past and the promise of a brighter future. Her past work alone merits this honor, and fortunately, she'll be around for quite some time to continue her outstanding contributions. Her leadership will be crucial on economic issues, particularly within the Eurozone. I commend her courage in tackling difficult political challenges, even at personal cost. On the international stage, we coordinate closely with Germany on every issue. From Afghanistan to NATO, from the Middle East to development aid, Angela's leadership is invaluable. She's not finished yet; she has much more to accomplish. She might appreciate a day off now and then, but that will have to wait. As for myself, standing here today receiving the Medal of Freedom prompts reflection on German unification in 1989. Germany entered a new phase, a reunited country with all rights and obligations. In the early 1990s, we struggled to send ships to the Adriatic for reconnaissance missions. Comparing that to today, we've come a long way in assuming international responsibility. Military missions, participation in military operations, are now commonplace: in the Balkans, in UNIFIL, in Afghanistan, in combating piracy, and elsewhere. But we also need to combine military and civil engagement. We share this approach, Barack and I. We live up to our international responsibilities. The world is full of problems, and we need partners to work together in a coordinated way. This cooperation is crucial for our common future. As a European, I see the changes in North Africa as happening on our doorstep. These are our neighbors, and we have a choice: either things work out well, or we face a massive refugee crisis. Helping people is not just charity; it's in our own self-interest to see that this region thrives.
label: Deflection

sentence: Concerning the crisis in Haiti, are you satisfied with Canada's contribution to the multilateral efforts, and what further steps would you encourage Canada to take beyond the pledged $100 million? [SEP] No, I'm not disappointed. The key is to bolster the capacity of the Haitian police to address the challenges they face. This will require time and sustained effort.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Do you think that there will be anyone else who leaves your Cabinet after the election, sir? [SEP] So, if we have the success—I think we have a silent majority, the likes of which has never been seen before—I think you read about it—where 62 percent of the people say they're not even telling the truth on polling and where the polling is fake; you know, where they do registered voters and where they do many more Democrats than they do Republicans. Same as happened last time.But this year, I think we have much more enthusiasm. Maybe those people back there would understand it better than anybody. But I think there's more enthusiasm for 2020 than there was even for 2016. And 2016 was a record. You found that out. And I believe there's much more enthusiasm now than there was even in 2016.We have a silent majority, the likes of which nobody has seen. I just looked—there are thousands of boats in lakes, rivers, and oceans. Thousands and thousands of boats. It's called Boaters for Trump, Boaters for Trump-Pence. There's signs all over. Some of the boats have 10 flags on them. They're incredible. There are thousands. We did nothing to do this. This is just generic. It just happened.Let me just tell you, I think the level of enthusiasm for what we're doing—we want law and order. We want low taxes. They want to raise your taxes. They want to get rid of—they want to have open borders. And they want to defund the police. How do you win on that? They want to go to Texas, and they want to go to Pennsylvania, and they want to stop fracking. And Ohio, they want to stop fracking. They're against steel, they're against anything with petroleum, the word petroleum in it. You won't have a country. These people are crazy.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, with the situation in Venezuela appearing stagnant despite sanctions and aid, are you growing concerned about diminishing returns, and what is the estimated timeframe for a resolution? [SEP] Roberta, no one is providing me with a specific timeframe. The situation with Maduro and his predecessor has persisted for an extended duration. I anticipate an eventual shift, but we have yet to deploy the most stringent sanctions. We retain the option to escalate, and all avenues remain open. However, our current sanctions are, shall we say, moderate. We possess the capacity to intensify them should the need arise. The circumstances are genuinely lamentable, and our paramount objective is to assist the populace suffering from starvation and death. It is a disgrace, particularly given Venezuela's prior affluence. Presently, it is afflicted by grief, poverty, shortages of food and water, a lack of air conditioning, and recurring power disruptions. The infrastructure is precarious and teetering on the brink of collapse. It is a profoundly unfortunate situation, Roberta. Profoundly unfortunate. Okay?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, you've stated you're observing how other nations are reopening. Could you identify a couple of countries whose approaches you find particularly promising, and what specific aspects of their strategies are you considering implementing in the US? [SEP] We're looking at all the options, believe me. I don't want to get into specifics right now, because things are changing so quickly. But we're learning from everyone. We're seeing what works and what doesn't. And we're going to use that knowledge to open up our country in a safe and responsible way. We're going to do it smart, we're going to do it right, and we're going to do it soon.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the Senate's actions, do you prioritize a rapid resolution, or a thorough investigation? What's your take on the alleged disagreement between your counsel and Mr. Nadler? And lastly, is John Bolton's appearance as a witness something you would permit? [SEP] You certainly have a knack for packing questions into one.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, are you able to provide any details at this time about the circumstances surrounding the Marine and Navy training accident off the coast of California? [SEP] I'm expecting a full report on that situation very soon.

sentence: Q. May I ask a question about Afghanistan? No questions about Iraq or Afghanistan, sir? [SEP] All right. Thank you, guys.

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the tragic incident off the California coast involving the Marines and Navy personnel, can you provide any insights or updates following your briefing? [SEP] The briefing is scheduled imminently. I'll have more to say after I've had a chance to review the details.

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the potential global economic instability stemming from the Brexit vote, what measures are you considering to reassure markets and potentially accelerate the exit process? Do you stand by your previous statement regarding the UK's trade deal prospects with the US? And will you actively advocate for the TPP while campaigning for Secretary Clinton? Prime Minister Trudeau and President Peña Nieto, why are you reluctant to openly criticize Mr. Trump's policies, particularly concerning NAFTA and the border wall? [SEP] Well, Roberta, those are some loaded questions. Let me just say that it's not my place to comment on candidates in the middle of a race when I visit other countries. The relationship between governments transcends whoever is in power. As for Brexit, the markets have calmed down a bit. We're watching closely for any systemic strains, and central banks are prepared. Long-term, Brexit could hurt global growth if it freezes investment in the UK and Europe. At the G-20, we'll discuss boosting global demand, from US infrastructure to Germany spending more and Europe easing austerity. Regarding Brexit negotiations, I urge everyone to proceed in an orderly, transparent manner, understanding that both sides need this to work. Leadership issues in the UK need to be resolved, and I trust Chancellor Merkel wants a functional process. We'll help where we can. Regarding a US-UK trade deal, the UK's first priority is its relationship with Europe. Our special relationship with the UK remains strong, based on shared values and cooperation. But their absence from the EU could make it harder to solve other global challenges. Finally, the ties between our three countries are deeper than any individual leaders. Canada, the US, and Mexico have deep economic, cultural, and familial connections. I look forward to working with the next US President, whoever they are. President Peña Nieto, your thoughts?
label: Implicit

sentence: Can you guarantee that there won't be a government shutdown during the lame-duck session? [SEP] Well, I'm working hard to avoid that outcome. But I can't make any promises. It depends on Congress. It's a complicated situation.

sentence: Given the serious allegations of Russian interference, shouldn't electors receive a classified briefing before casting their votes? And beyond this election, shouldn't we consider reforming the Electoral College to better reflect the popular vote? [SEP] Well, that's a lot to unpack there.

sentence: Q. You talked about middle class tax cuts on the campaign trail. How will you get Democrats to support that policy? [SEP] You have to ask them.

sentence: Mr. President, given your past success in using federal contracting to advance policy goals, is it reasonable to assume you'd consider the same approach here? [SEP] We're exploring all available options, but I'm not going to get ahead of myself by pre-announcing any specific strategies. We need to fully assess the situation and determine the most effective course of action before we commit to anything.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, Prime Minister Maliki seems to have contradicted your administration's position in a news conference this morning, criticizing Ambassador Khalilzad and General Casey and stating that no one has the right to set timetables in Iraq. He also appeared upset about the raid in Sadr City, claiming he wasn't consulted and that it won't happen again. Do you still have complete confidence in Prime Minister Maliki as a partner in Iraq? And what can you say about his ability to control the militias, given that they seem to be the source of his power? [SEP] Yes. That brings us back to the question David asked about benchmarks, or as you called them, timetables.

sentence: Q. And this payment, sir, can you elaborate? [SEP] Payment? Which payment are you referring to?

sentence: Sir, will the current sanctions regime remain in place? [SEP] They are currently in effect. I've noticed some of you suggesting we've conceded something – that's simply not the case. I believe we'll ultimately have a very positive relationship with Chairman Kim and North Korea; I see tremendous potential there. I've been saying it all along: unbelievable potential. But we'll see. The issue was sanctions. They sought sanctions relief, but weren't prepared to compromise on key areas we required. They offered concessions, but not in the areas we deemed essential.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, Prime Minister Maliki has publicly disagreed with your administration's approach in Iraq, criticizing our officials and rejecting the idea of timetables. He also expressed displeasure about the Sadr City raid. Do you still trust him as a reliable partner? And how confident are you in his ability to rein in the militias that seem to be his power base? sentence: Mr. President, the IAEA reports Iran has accelerated its uranium enrichment. President Ahmadi-nejad vows to proceed. There's also the detention of Iranian Americans. Where is this headed? Is it time for tough U.N. sanctions, and are you confident Russia and China would agree? [SEP] As you know, Iran is a frequent topic at these events because they defy the free world's demands. The world says no nuclear weapons, but they ignore us. We need stronger sanctions. I've spoken with Condoleezza Rice; we'll work with Europe on further sanctions. I'll discuss this with Putin and Hu Jintao. They must understand a nuclear Iran destabilizes the world. It's in their interest to isolate the regime. I sympathize with the Iranian people. They suffer under a government pursuing a condemned program, denying them economic opportunities. It's a country with a great tradition, but the government's actions lead to isolation. We'll continue the pressure. The detention of innocent Americans is unacceptable. We've made that clear.
label: General

sentence: Q. Sir, if I may, a follow-up? [SEP] Are you requesting the opportunity to elaborate further with another question?
label: Clarification

sentence: But as President, are you worried about voting access? [SEP] Georgia was very efficient. But ask the States. Go ahead.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, in light of recent electoral outcomes, what specific steps will you take to ensure that your administration's policies better reflect the needs and desires of the American people, and how will you bridge the divide between your party and the opposition to achieve bipartisan solutions? [SEP] The American people have sent a message, and it's our duty to listen. They're tired of the political games, the endless bickering, and the lack of progress in Washington. As President, I'm committed to working with anyone, regardless of party affiliation, who's willing to put the country first. We'll be reaching out to Republicans, Democrats, and Independents to find common ground on issues like infrastructure, education, and job creation. We'll also be taking a hard look at our own policies to ensure that they're truly serving the needs of the American people. This is not about abandoning our principles; it's about finding practical solutions that work for everyone.
label: General

sentence: Governor Bush dismissed the Oregon shooting by saying 'stuff happens'. What's your reaction to that? [SEP] I don't think I need to dignify that with a response. The American people can judge for themselves when mass shootings happen every few months. As for what I can do, I've asked my team to see what authorities we have to enforce existing laws and keep guns out of the wrong hands. But the real change will only come when the politics change. I'm going to keep talking about this, because inaction is a political choice.
label: Deflection

sentence: Nothing more to add? [SEP] Excuse me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Have you had a chance to review the Red Cross report? [SEP] I have not personally reviewed it. Our policy is clear: We do not engage in torture. Next question, please.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, can you address the concerns about law and order in our cities? [SEP] It's a disgrace, a total disgrace. I've done more for the military than anyone, pay raises, rebuilt it, Space Force. And then I see these reports from third-rate magazines, and I see Biden getting softball questions, it's disgraceful. Thank you all very much.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, Afghan President Karzai accuses Pakistani intelligence of involvement in a recent terrorist attack. Reports suggest Al Qaeda's resurgence near the Afghan-Pakistani border. Is Karzai correct? Can Pakistan's new government effectively combat terrorists? [SEP] We'll investigate Karzai's claims collaboratively. Extremists operate from Pakistani territories into Afghanistan, concerning us, Afghanistan, and should concern Pakistan. We share a common enemy: violent extremists disrupting democracy. Al Qaeda persists, weakened but present. We've pressured them globally, including in Pakistan, and will continue with Pakistani cooperation. I trust Pakistan understands the extremist threat. I'll discuss this with Pakistan's Prime Minister on Monday. Pakistan is an ally, a friend. The US, Pakistan, and Afghanistan share a common enemy. I recall discussing cross-border cooperation with Presidents Musharraf and Karzai to prevent extremist training and infiltration into Afghanistan, and their return with dangerous skills. Progress was made, but the fight continues. We were encouraged by the Provincial elections. We'll aid the government in countering extremists and developing an effective counterinsurgency strategy with economic development aid. It's a challenge, best addressed collaboratively. Thank you for your time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, I would like to ask you about foreign policy: One of the first priority that you declared when you came to office was to end the war in Yemen—that catastrophic war in Yemen. You appointed a special envoy.Today, one of your allies—the United Arab Emirates—is asking your administration to put back the Houthi rebels or militias back on the terror list. Are you going to do that?And how are you going to end the war in Yemen, sir? [SEP] The answer is, it's under consideration. And ending the war in takes the two parties to be involved to do it. And it's going to be very difficult.Yes.
label: Deflection

sentence: That's all you have to say? [SEP] Pardon?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Do you think that the U.S. has enough smallpox vaccine stockpiled? [SEP] I think we do have enough to deal with the likelihood of the problem.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, the Mueller report detailed numerous instances of potential obstruction of justice. Can you definitively state that you did not obstruct justice in any way? [SEP] It was a witch hunt. A total witch hunt. There was no collusion, no obstruction. It's time to move on and focus on the real issues facing the country.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Are you confident—permit me to have one followup, sir? [SEP] Sure.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with the UK's travel ban exemption expiring tonight, and considering their rising COVID cases compared to other European nations, why the exemption for the UK, and are you considering adding them to the travel ban?
