[SEP] Well, that recommendation came from a group of professionals, and we're monitoring the situation closely based on the latest data. Given the recent increase in cases in the UK, we may have to include them on the list of countries facing travel restrictions. Their numbers have risen sharply in the last 24 hours, so we're considering adding them, and potentially others as well. We might also start looking at removing some countries from the list.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. So, Mr. President, why this sudden urgency in making these accusations now? [SEP] Look, the facts speak for themselves. They've practically confessed to targeting our farmers. Anyone paying attention can see that. And since you seem so keen on the topic, let me just clarify something before we move on to your next, undoubtedly earth-shattering, question. Let me just say this...
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, to put it bluntly, are you currently exploring options to oust the President as part of this transition? [SEP] I'm trusting Mitch McConnell's word that the government won't shut down. There's no reason for it. We've been there, done that, and it was bad for everyone. In the end, it was resolved the same way it would have been without the shutdown. So, it's a waste of time, and I think McConnell and Boehner get that. This brings me to a bigger point: Disagreement is part of the game in a democracy. Our system, unlike a parliamentary one, can have a Congress of one party and a President of another, leading to serious disagreements. So how do we handle it? The smart way is to say, 'Here's what we disagree on, we'll fight for our side, and then we'll work together on what we agree on.' That's how it's always been, even with Reagan and a Democratic Congress. They didn't refuse to work with him on Social Security or taxes just because they disagreed on other stuff. They fought on some things, worked together on others, and the country moved forward. I expect the same now. I know some Republicans strongly disagree with me, law enforcement, evangelicals, and even other Republicans on immigration reform. They've made their point, and they have the right to argue and oppose. But shutting down the government over it is as crazy as me shutting down the government if they try to repeal healthcare for the millionth time. I get there's a difference, but let's just get on with doing our jobs.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Jacksonville, some argue you're moving too quickly, particularly with schools and baseball. Doesn't Jacksonville demonstrate the risks of pushing too hard? [SEP] Let's talk baseball – we were just discussing it. You're going to have an empty stadium. Randy Levine, a friend from the Yankees, invited me to throw out the first pitch on August 15th at Yankee Stadium. I asked about the crowd, and he said there won't be one. It'll be interesting for Mariano; he's used to the roar of the crowd. I think it'd be just as good without it. Some people are just born with it.Speaking of baseball players, I've never seen a pitcher break as many bats as Mariano. He holds the record. I asked him how he does it, and he said, 'Parents.' It all comes down to great parents. Right? How do you do that? It's called parents.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, is passing this bill by the August recess absolutely critical? [SEP] I don't like to use the term 'do-or-die.' But I'm strongly committed to getting it done by then. And, hey, is Christi Parsons here? Hometown girl!
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, Nigeria is facing significant challenges, and the Tucano aircraft are crucial. Is it possible to expedite the delivery of at least two before 2020? Also, are there any plans for you to visit Nigeria in the near future? [SEP] I've heard wonderful things about Nigeria. It's a country of immense beauty, and I'd be delighted to visit. As for the first part of your question, I'm afraid I didn't hear it clearly. Could you please repeat it?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, what exactly did you ask President Putin to do regarding Afghanistan and the presence of U.S. forces there? [SEP] Well, he actually brought up Afghanistan. He said he hoped we could keep things stable, and I told him that depended a lot on him. He said he was ready to help with Afghanistan – I won't get into the details now – and with Iran, and some other stuff. We told him what we wanted to do to bring some stability and security to the people in Syria and Libya. So, that's what we talked about. Yamiche [Yamiche Alcindor, PBS News]. Ransomware Attacks on U.S. Companies/
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Iran deal, concerns linger about arms potentially reaching groups like Hezbollah. What measures are in place to prevent this, and what kind of Middle East do you envision leaving behind as your term concludes? [SEP] Well, the arms embargo and ballistic missile issues are indeed a concern. Preventing Iran from arming groups like Hezbollah is vital. We've established mechanisms under international law to intercept Iranian arms shipments, stemming from UN resolutions tied to their nuclear program. While the original resolution's text might suggest lifting these prohibitions upon a nuclear agreement, we negotiated extensions: five years for arms and eight for ballistic missiles. We also have other UN resolutions and agreements allowing us to interdict these shipments. These legal authorities, though, aren't self-enforcing. It requires intelligence and interdiction capacity. We must partner more effectively to improve these capabilities. Beyond legal authorities, we have unilateral sanctions in place. As for the broader Middle East, my goal is to leave behind a region where ISIS is contained, the Syrian civil war is being addressed, Iraq is functioning more effectively, and security partnerships are strengthened, including with Israel. Ultimately, the people of the Middle East must solve their own problems, but we can provide a foundation for progress. We must also address the youth in the region with jobs and opportunities. We can partner with organizations and leaders to achieve this.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac now under government control, are you concerned that this action signals to the market that reckless risk-taking will be rewarded with a bailout, potentially leading to further instability in the financial system? [SEP] Let's clarify something. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are vital to the mortgage markets. People need to have confidence in those markets. Secretary Paulson's plan is designed to provide that confidence. It's about calming nerves and ensuring stability. By laying out a plan for a line of credit and potential capital investment, we actually make it less likely that we'll need to use those authorities. And it's temporary authority, by the way. As for the banks, deposits are insured by the Federal Government up to $100,000. So, depositors are protected. I saw a bank run once, and the guy was yelling, 'Your deposits are good!' People need to take a deep breath and realize that their deposits are protected.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. You are only targeting cities, though, run by Democrats. Is this just a political stunt? [SEP] Yes, the cities, unfortunately, that are in trouble are all run by Democrats. You have radical-left Democrats running cities like Chicago and so many others that we just had a news conference. And unfortunately, that's the way it is. I mean, that's the facts.When you look at Chicago and you look at the job—Mayor Lightfoot sent me a letter yesterday, and I think, in their own way, they want us to go in. There'll be a time when they're going to want us to go in full blast, but right now we're sending extra people to help. We're arresting a lot of people that have been very bad.As far as the coronavirus, as you say, I think we've done some amazing things, and I think you'll probably see that if you compare our statistics to other countries. And if you look at death rates, et cetera, you're going to see—and especially into the future, with what's happening—you're going to see some very, very impressive numbers for the United States.Jon [Jonathan Karl, ABC News], please.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. When you were in Baghdad 6 months ago, you expressed the same kind of confidence in the Prime Minister and his Government that you've expressed today. Yet there have been repeated rounds of disappointments when it comes to the Prime Minister's Baghdad Security Plan, with his plans for reconciliation. I'm wondering, if anything, if you've had any doubts over the last 6 months about the strength of his Government, about the Prime Minister's own abilities. And what gives you such confidence today to think that he can achieve what he hasn't done over the last 6 months? [SEP] Well, as you mentioned, he's been in power for 6 months, and I've been able to watch a leader emerge. The first thing that gives me confidence is that he wants responsibility. A sign of leadership is for somebody to say, I want to be able to have the tools necessary to protect my people. One of his frustrations with me is that he believes we've been slow about giving him the tools necessary to protect the Iraqi people. And today we had a meeting that will accelerate the capacity for the Prime Minister to do the hard work necessary to help stop this violence. No question, it's a violent society right now. He knows that better than anybody. He was explaining to me that occasionally the house in which he lives gets shelled by terrorists who are trying to frighten him.And so the second point I make to you is that I appreciate his courage. You can't lead unless you have courage. And he's got courage, and he's shown courage over the last 6 months.Thirdly, he has expressed a deep desire to unify his country. You hear all kinds of rumors about the politics inside of Iraq. I'm talking to the man face to face, and he says that he understands that a unified government, a pluralistic society, is important for success. And he's making hard decisions to achieve that.No question, it's been tough. It would have been a lot easier had people not tried to destabilize the young democracy. His job would have been more simple had there not been terrorists trying to create sectarian violence.Now, I want everybody to remember that it was Mr. Zarqawi of Al Qaida who said, Let us bomb Shi'a in order to create the conditions necessary for sectarian violence. The Samarra bombing started off this new phase of violence. The Prime Minister comes in about halfway through that phase in order to—he'd been selected, and now he's dealing with a serious situation on the ground. And what I appreciate is his attitude. As opposed to saying, America, you go solve the problem, we have a Prime Minister who's saying, Stop holding me back. I want to solve the problem.And the meeting today was to accelerate his capacity to do so. It's not easy for a military to evolve from ground zero, and I appreciate our forces and I appreciate General Casey, who have worked very hard to train the Iraqis so they become a capable fighting force as well as a unifying element for Iraq. But it's one thing to put people in uniform and another thing to have clear command structure, or the capacity to move troops from point A to point B, or the capacity to make sure that the troop carrier from point A to point B has got the necessary air in its tires or oil in its engine. In other words, this is a sophisticated operation, to get a unifying army stood up.And one of the reasons I appreciate the Prime Minister is that he, on the one hand, sees that it's a sophisticated operation to get a military up from zero, but on the other hand, is frustrated by the pace. And the reason why he's frustrated is because he wants to show the people who elected him that he is willing to take the hard tasks on necessary to provide security for the Iraqi people, such as hunting down those who are killing the innocent. And the reason I came today to be able to sit down with him is to hear the joint plans developed between the Iraqi Government, the sovereign Government of Iraq, and our Government, to make sure that we accelerate the transfer of capacity to the Prime Minister. And I know he's looking forward to more capacity being transferred so he can do his job.Anyway, he's the right guy for Iraq, and we're going to help him, and it's in our interest to help him, for the sake of peace.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, in your meeting with Prime Minister Najib, given the serious allegations of corruption and human rights violations, what specific concerns did you raise regarding the 1MDB scandal and the imprisonment of political opponents? [SEP] First, let's discuss the refugee program. The Paris attacks occurred only a week ago. The news cycle is so rapid that we sometimes lose track of events. The Paris attacks were recent and impactful, and people are understandably concerned given the similarities between Paris and many American cities. That's why the House acted quickly. I hope that now that we have had some time to pause and consider, people will recognize that refugees arriving in the United States undergo the most thorough vetting process. The process, developed over several administrations on a bipartisan basis, is exceptionally thorough and typically takes 18 to 24 months for approval. The House legislation, while seemingly straightforward, could effectively shut down the refugee program if it becomes overly bureaucratic. Adding layers of bureaucracy that don't enhance screening but make processing impossible would be counterproductive. When I spoke of betraying our values, I was referring to suggestions of prioritizing Christian refugees over Muslims, or fearing a 4-year-old orphan. Those of you who visited the refugee center and saw the children understand who we're talking about. If you're a parent and you saw those children, you'd understand that we need to provide them with a home in America. Most people, knowing the screening process, would agree. Regarding Prime Minister Najib, I don't comment on investigations within the United States, and I certainly won't comment on foreign investigations. However, I did emphasize the importance of transparency, accountability, and combating corruption with Prime Minister Najib, as I have with leaders in Southeast Asia, Africa, and Latin America. These are obstacles to development and contribute to poverty and stunted growth. Countries that address these issues will prosper, regardless of resources or geography. I also emphasized the importance of civil society and a free press. Countries are at different stages of development, and we don't expect everyone to follow the same path as the United States. But some fundamental principles are important for us to uphold as friends and partners. Consider Myanmar, which recently held a historic election after 40 years of military rule. They won't become Sweden overnight, but there's a significant shift occurring, and we want to encourage that. Our work through the Open Government Partnership and TPP is designed to raise the bar. Some will advance, some will regress, but the overall direction is towards a world where ordinary people are treated fairly, there's rule of law, transparency, accountable governments, people's voices are heard, women are treated equally, and minorities are not discriminated against. These are American values, but also universal values. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, considering the diverse perspectives on international relations and the complexities of maintaining alliances, what strategies are you employing to ensure that partnerships like the one with Albania remain strong and mutually beneficial in the long term? [SEP] We are actively fostering open communication and dialogue with our allies to address any challenges or concerns that may arise. Our approach is rooted in a commitment to mutual respect, shared values, and a recognition that strong alliances are essential for promoting peace, security, and prosperity in an increasingly interconnected world.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, in the event that the supercommittee fails to reach an agreement, what specific contingency plans are in place to mitigate the impact of the automatic cuts on essential government services? And can you provide any context for your 'hot mic' exchange with President Sarkozy regarding Prime Minister Netanyahu? [SEP] With respect to the supercommittee, we negotiated a trillion dollars in cuts over the next 10 years. The whole idea of the sequester was to make sure that both sides felt obligated to move off rigid positions and do what was required to help the country. Now, I've put forward a very detailed approach that would achieve $3 trillion-plus in savings. It says everything's on the table. I'm not going to comment on whether I'd veto a particular bill until I actually see a bill. With respect to the hot mic in France, I'm not going to comment on conversations that I have with individual leaders.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, do you feel any affinity for him? [SEP] He was a remarkable law student, I understand. I had heard of him, but I didn't truly know him until this entire situation arose. His name has been familiar to me for a decade. Do you know how? Everyone was suggesting that he should be appointed to the Supreme Court. I inquired, 'Who is he?' Brett Kavanaugh. They were discussing him as a potential Supreme Court Justice a decade ago, praising him as the most brilliant legal mind. Nevertheless, I am interested in hearing what she has to say. Is that clear?
label: Deflection

sentence: What about Canada's stimulus plans, and the future of the Canada-U.S. relationship? [SEP] You've managed to cram a whole series of questions into that one. Were you talking to Jonathan? Is that--?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, do you believe you were threatened? [SEP] It's too early to say definitively. The authorities are investigating, and we'll know more once they've completed their work.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. What if you meet President Putin on this trip or would you rule that out? [SEP] I'm sure I'll see him. He's going to be there. Russia—I think it's important for us to acknowledge the role that Russia played during World War II, and that's part of what Normandy is about.All right? Okay. President Komorowski. Well, ladies and gentlemen, it is difficult not to notice that something has changed to the east of the borders of NATO; that, again, we are having to deal with the aggression with the use of armed forces against one's neighbor. A few years ago it was Georgia; now it is Ukraine, with a special focus on the Crimea. President Putin didn't hide it. He didn't hide that these were elements of the Russian Armed Forces, and that—this is something that we have to acknowledge. Just the same way Russia never hid that for the last 4 years it has increased its defense budget twofold. We, ourselves, have to ask a question, why? For what purpose? And what does it have to mean for member states of NATO?All of us are interested in Russia to get modernized so that it was possible to do not only good business modernizing Russia, but also develop relations of good neighborhood and cooperation in many dimensions, in many areas. But today we have to answer to this situation that has come up by supporting independence of Ukraine and its right to choose its pro-Western direction. We have to support the modernization of Ukraine too.I am convinced that this is the right way to develop the mechanism and a source of a very good and suggestive example for the Russian society, just as a great example for them was the development of democracy in Poland—free market, prosperity, security, safety. It acted very well on Ukraine, and I am convinced that it was simply an element of the Ukrainian dreams to follow along the same way, in the direction of the same values.I am also convinced that the success of Ukraine, its democratic and independent nature, combined with overcoming the economic crisis and political crisis on the ground, combined with deep modernization of the Ukrainian society and state, will have a huge influence on the shaping of the attitudes of people within the Russian society. It is difficult not to notice today that the Russian public opinion has fully supported the aggressive behavior of President Putin in Crimea. The point is that a public opinion in Russia should stand on the side of the prospects for the modernization of Russia and not at the reconstitution of any zone of influence and any dreams of empire.Ladies and gentlemen, this press conference is over. Thank you very much.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, in light of China's expulsion of Wall Street Journal reporters, what retaliatory options are currently being evaluated by your administration? Is the restriction of access for Chinese journalists within the United States a viable countermeasure? [SEP] I'm afraid I haven't been fully apprised of the details surrounding that particular incident. We are, of course, examining the situation. It is, needless to say, a development I find rather disagreeable, given the access we routinely provide. Some might argue we provide excessive access. I, personally, do not subscribe to that view. Nevertheless, we shall arrive at a decision on this matter in due course. Next question, please.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, if I may, why should the American people prioritize a global competition when we're still grappling with so much loss and so many cases right here in the United States? [SEP] Well, these losses are occurring worldwide, wouldn't you agree? Maybe instead of asking me, you should be asking China about their role in all of this. Go ahead, ask them. I suspect you'll get a very interesting answer. Next question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding China, you stated yesterday before business leaders your desire for them to adhere to established rules. Subsequently, your staff indicated that you voiced concerns to President Hu about American business leaders' increasing frustration with the slow pace of economic reform in China. Could you clarify which specific rules China is currently violating? What concrete actions do you expect from China, and what punitive measures is your administration prepared to implement if China fails to comply? [SEP] Look, let's be clear, we aren't against China's rise. A prosperous China that lifts its people is good for the world. What we've been doing for the past two years is fostering a candid dialogue. This has brought benefits, like support on the North Korea issue. However, I've consistently told Chinese leaders that their economic practices disadvantage many, not just us. Take their currency, the RMB. Experts say it's undervalued by a significant margin, making our exports pricier and their imports cheaper. While there's been slight improvement due to our pressure, it's not enough. They need to move faster towards a market-based system. This isn't just about us; it's about their economy too. They're too focused on exports and not enough on domestic consumption, making them vulnerable to global shocks. It throws the whole world economy out of balance because they're not buying as much as they could be from other countries. Chinese leadership knows this, but it's politically difficult for them to change. But frankly, enough is enough. Then there's intellectual property. American companies constantly complain about their ideas not being protected in China. This hurts our competitive advantage. If they don't protect intellectual property, they become a low-cost producer without compensating the inventors. These issues aren't secrets. American companies often hesitate to speak up for fear of retaliation. I don't share that concern. We're also enforcing existing trade laws. We've brought cases, like the one on U.S. tires, and won. This benefits U.S. producers and creates jobs. We want to trade with China and maintain a constructive relationship, but we must insist they play by the same rules. We won't let them take advantage of us.
label: Implicit

sentence: So, the election of these two Muslim women, does that represent a rejection of your message? [SEP] I'm not entirely following your line of reasoning. Could you rephrase that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your claim that mail-in voting is rife with fraud, could you provide specific instances or documented evidence to substantiate this assertion, particularly in states like Nevada? [SEP] Look, people are saying it, okay? The media, even the failing New York Times, begrudgingly admits there are problems. You see reports, all over the internet, folks are talking about it. In places like Arizona, they practically let anyone vote, no signature checks! It's a disaster waiting to happen. And they can keep counting for days after the election. Nobody will know what the real result is!
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Looking into it? Do you have a message on that? [SEP] If you tell me that's happening, we will definitely investigate. We don't want that.All right, one more. Go ahead. Go ahead.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, could you comment on the possibility of a future U.S.-North Korea relationship akin to our current relationship with Vietnam? [SEP] Repeat the question.
label: Clarification

sentence: You spoke passionately about human rights during your State of the Union address, even highlighting the defector who escaped North Korea. At the time, you stated that North Korea oppresses its people more brutally than any other regime. After meeting with Kim Jong Un, do you still hold that belief? And does he need to change that? [SEP] Jon, it's definitely a tough situation over there. No doubt about it. We talked about it pretty seriously today. I mean, the main goal of our meeting was denuclearization, but we spent a good amount of time on the human rights issue. We'll be working on it. It's rough. It's rough in a lot of places, by the way, not just there. But it's rough, and we'll keep at it. I think we'll eventually come to an agreement. But it was a major topic outside of the nuclear situation.
label: General

sentence: Could you perhaps provide further details? [SEP] Excuse me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, are you concerned about reports of voter suppression and limited access to polling places in certain states? [SEP] Well, I've heard different things. Some say it was smooth, others not so much. You'd really have to check with the state officials on that one.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, how can you justify what many see as a detrimental example you're setting for the country? [SEP] The premise of your question is flawed. These are standard political practices, and to suggest otherwise is a misrepresentation of the facts.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, to be clear, are you ruling out any changes to the sequester cuts, even if the supercommittee fails to reach an agreement? And can you provide any context for your conversation with President Sarkozy, without revealing specific details? [SEP] I'm committed to finding a solution that avoids the sequester altogether. That requires compromise from both sides. As for President Sarkozy, we discussed a range of issues of mutual concern, including the Middle East peace process.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Are direct talks something you would consider? [SEP] I'm not going to say anything about that right now.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Good morning, Mr. President. Your former Secretary of Defense, Donald Rumsfeld, advocated for a lighter, more agile military force. Have you now concluded that that approach was wrong? [SEP] No, I strongly support a lighter, agile Army that can move quickly to meet the threats of the 21st century. I also supported his force posture review and recommendations to move forces out of previous bases that—you know, they were there for the Soviet threat, for example, in Europe. So he's introduced some substantive changes to the Pentagon, and I support them strongly.However, that doesn't necessarily preclude increasing end strength for the Army and the Marines. And the reason why I'm inclined to believe this is a good idea is because I understand that we're going to be in a long struggle against radicals and extremists, and we must make sure that our military has the capability to stay in the fight for a long period of time. I'm not predicting any particular theater, but I am predicting that it's going to take a while for the ideology of liberty to finally triumph over the ideology of hate.I know you know I feel this strongly, but I see this—we're in the beginning of a conflict between competing ideologies, a conflict that will determine whether or not your children can live in peace. A failure in the Middle East, for example, or failure in Iraq or isolationism will condemn a generation of young Americans to permanent threat from overseas. And therefore, we will succeed in Iraq. And therefore, we will help young democracies when we find them—democracies like Lebanon, hopefully a Palestinian state living side by side in peace with Israel, the young democracy of Iraq.It is in our interest that we combine security with a political process that frees people, that liberates people, that gives people a chance to determine their own futures. I believe most people in the Middle East want just that. They want to be in a position where they can chart their own futures, and it's in our interest that we help them do so.Jim [Jim Axelrod, CBS News].
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, with respect to the Indian American community outreach during the conventions, and the potential for your family to campaign on your behalf, could you share your perspective on the U.S.-India relationship? [SEP] I must confess, I didn't grasp all the nuances of your question. However, I'm familiar with India, and those young individuals you mentioned are quite capable. Their ties to India are strong, as are mine. Prime Minister Modi is a friend, and he's navigating a challenging situation effectively. Speaking of challenges, the border situation between China and India is concerning. We stand ready to assist in any way possible and are in communication with both nations. I appreciate your positive sentiments. My family and I hold India in high regard, and I have great respect for your Prime Minister. Thank you.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Why can't you work together while there are subpoenas or while there are investigations in process? [SEP] I think we will. Look, now that the election is over—the election is over. Now everybody is in love. But then, I see the hostility of questions in the room. I come in here as a nice person wanting to answer questions, and I have people jumping out of their seats, screaming questions at me.No, the election is over. And I'm, you know, very—I am extraordinarily happy. I really am. And by the way, I'd tell you if I wasn't.Look at what happened in Florida. Look at what happened in Georgia. Look at what happened in so many locations with Governorships. Nobody talks about the Governorships. Look at the amount of work that was given to these other candidates against my candidate.And, I mean, I'm extraordinarily happy. And if I wasn't, I'd let you know. There's nothing wrong. I mean, look, you look at midterms and you look at elections—elections generally—you see it's very rare that a party who has the Presidency does well. We did unbelievably well. To win Florida, both the Senate and the Governorship against two very talented people.I'll tell you what: We did incredibly. To win Georgia, where you had some of the biggest stars in the world campaigning endlessly, including President Obama. You know, I'm—I'll tell you what: This was a great victory for us. And again, from a deal-making standpoint, we are all much better off the way it turned out. Because I really believe, if the Democrats want to, we can do a tremendous amount of great legislation.Yes, please. Go ahead.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. And a stimulus question, if you don't mind: You have told me—even before you were President, you always talked about being the ultimate dealmaker. Why not just sit down with Democrats personally and cut a deal? [SEP] Because they want $1 trillion to go to their friends doing a bad job running certain cities and States that are doing very badly. You know, most of our country is running very well. Even in terms of crime, most of our country is setting records in terms of low. But when you look at Chicago, when you look at what's going on in Illinois and New York and other places, both economically and in other ways, it's horrible. It's horrible.Look at Oregon. Look what's going on in Oregon. They have—I don't think they have a clue. We could stop that—if they would request it, we would stop that problem in 1 hour, like we did in Minneapolis. We would stop it in 1 hour. It would be over. It's so easy to do.All right, please, go ahead. In the back, please.
label: Explicit

sentence: President Obama, concerning the Senkaku Islands, does the U.S. commitment to Japan include military intervention? Is this another 'red line' like Syria? Prime Minister Abe, do you trust U.S. security assurances given the Ukraine situation? [SEP] Alright, let's address this. The U.S.-Japan treaty is not a 'red line' I created. It's a longstanding agreement covering territories under Japanese administration. We're simply applying it. We encourage dialogue between Japan and China. Violations of international law, such as chemical attacks or invasions, require a response, but not always military. The removal of most of Syria's chemical weapons demonstrates U.S. leadership without military action. Regarding Russia and Ukraine, a military solution is unlikely. Sanctions are in place, and diplomacy remains an option. Russia hasn't followed the Geneva agreement, while Kiev has. Further sanctions are possible. Difficult issues, but we stand for our values. Now, remind me about North Korea?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, to clarify Bloomberg's question, are you suggesting that a 'minor incursion' by Russia into Ukraine wouldn't trigger the sanctions you've previously threatened? Are you effectively greenlighting a limited invasion? [SEP] That's a complex issue.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with troops serving multiple tours in Iraq, reports of declining morale are increasing. An infantry commander indicated that troops are questioning their purpose. Does this come as a surprise? Are you aware of this sentiment? Is it a minority view or a growing trend, and does it concern you? [SEP] What I'm hearing from commanders is that the primary concern revolves around family members. Our troops volunteered and are willing to serve repeatedly, but their families are worried. That's why I make an effort to thank them. You're speaking with certain individuals, but I'm in contact with commanders who provide me with the situation on the ground. I'm aware of concerns on the home front, but I haven't heard widespread concerns about troop morale in Iraq.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you. A question from Sky News. Mr. Brown's new formulation for what we used to call the special relationship is Britain's single most important bilateral relationship. I wonder if I could ask him what precisely that means, whether it works the other way for the United States, in terms of their bilateral relationships. And also, Mr. President, what you think has actually changed with the arrival of Gordon Brown instead of Tony Blair? [SEP] Besides toothpaste? [] Do you want to—I'll start. Look, I think any time you share values the way we share values, it makes it easy to have strategic conversations; it makes it easy to be able to have common ground on which to deal with these problems. You just listed off a lot of problems. I happen to view them as great opportunities to begin to put conditions in place so that the world looks fundamentally different 50 years from now.But I would say that the relationship between Great Britain and America is our most important bilateral relationship, for a lot of reasons: trade. Great Britain has been attacked; we've been attacked, which caused us to lash up our intelligence services like never before. We have common interests throughout the world.But it's an important relationship primarily because we think the same. We believe in freedom and justice as fundamentals of life. There's no doubt in my mind that freedom is universal, that freedom is a gift to each man, woman, and child on the face of the Earth, and that with freedom comes peace. And there's no doubt in my mind, those of us who live under the free societies have an obligation to work together to promote it.And the man I listened to shares that same sense of morality and that same sense of obligation, not to free others, but to create the conditions so others can realize the blessings of freedom. We can't impose freedom, but we can eliminate roadblocks to freedom and to allow free societies to develop. And it's really hard work, you know? There's a lot of cynics saying, How dare they; how dare they impose U.S. or Great British values. And what I found was a man who understands that these aren't Great British and U.S. values; these are universal values.And so what was your question? []
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, are you going to answer my question? [SEP] I'm addressing the press pool as a whole, and I will call on reporters as I see fit. Next question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Considering your focus on state sovereignty as a key element of the international system, how do you reconcile this with the principle of 'responsibility to protect,' which was once a central tenet for the protection of victims? [SEP] Pardon me, how do I reconcile that with the responsibility to protect, which used to be what?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Russia, the Democratic candidates seemed unfamiliar with Dmitry Medvedev. What's your assessment of him, and his actual power with Putin still involved? Critics claim you misjudged Putin. What advice would you give your successor about Russia and dealing with its new leader? [SEP] I don't know much about Medvedev either. And what will be interesting to see is who comes to the--who represents Russia at the G-8, for example. It will be interesting to see--it will help, I think, give some insight as to how Russia intends to conduct foreign policy over--after Vladimir Putin's Presidency. And I can't answer the question yet. I can say that it's in our interests to continue to have relations with Russia. For example, on proliferation matters, it's in our interest to be able to make sure that materials that could cause great harm aren't proliferated. It's in our interest to work together on Iran. As I said, I think, in this room the last time I was here, I appreciated the fact that Vladimir Putin told the Iranians that they will provide--they, Russia--will provide enriched uranium to run the Bushehr power plant, thereby negating the need for the Iranians to enrich in the first place. I thought that was a constructive suggestion. And we need to be in a position to be able to work with Russia on Iran. There's a lot of areas where--yesterday, for example, with the Prime Minister of the Czech Republic, I talked about a missile defense system in Europe. But I believe it's in our interests to try to figure out a way for the Russians to understand the system is not aimed at them but aimed at the real threats of the 21st century, which could be a launch from a violent regime--a launch of a weapon of mass destruction. So there's areas where--and so it's a--I'm going to try to leave it so whoever my successor is will be able to have a relationship with whoever is running foreign policy in Russia. It's just--it's in the country's interest. That doesn't mean we have to agree all the time. I mean, obviously, we didn't agree on Kosovo. There will be other areas where we don't agree. And yet it is in the interest of the country to have a relationship, leader to leader and, hopefully, beyond that.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, with Russia claiming a full withdrawal from Kherson, do you consider this a potential inflection point, perhaps offering Ukraine the leverage needed to initiate peace negotiations with Moscow? [SEP] The timing of their announcement, just after the election, is certainly curious, isn't it? We've been aware of their intentions for a while now. This underscores the very real difficulties the Russian military is facing. Whether this leads to anything substantial remains to be seen. It will undoubtedly provide an opportunity for all parties to reassess their positions during the winter period. The question remains whether Ukraine will be prepared to compromise with Russia. I'll be attending the G-20, and while President Putin is unlikely to be there, other world leaders will be present. This will be an opportunity to consider potential next steps.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, can you comment on the bribery allegations against you? [SEP] Just a second.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, just to be clear, is the NHS a bargaining chip in these trade discussions? [SEP] Come again? I didn't hear you properly.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, should the clinical trials be successful, will you prioritize the rapid approval of this drug? [SEP] It's premature to speculate. I'm waiting for the facts. We're working hard to find solutions, but I can't say anything definitive until I have more data.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Africa's future, what key steps should African nations prioritize for advancement, and what role should leadership play? How will the U.S. provide support? Furthermore, what are your goals for this African tour, and how will you ensure lasting impact? [SEP] This is my second trip to Africa, and I want to emphasize that it's in our interest to help these countries with diseases, trade, and education. Being in Ghana really shows what we're talking about. Since I've been President, Africa has changed for the better, thanks to its leaders. We've been involved in conflict resolution, like in Liberia, and supported democracy. We're just trying to be a helpful partner. Our aid program now expects good governance in return. I have confidence in the leaders I've met on this trip. That's why I'm here, and I'm happy to be here. And I see John McKinnon from the Wall Street Journal is here.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, can you outline the steps you envision for denuclearization, including treaties and negotiations? [SEP] It's going to be a long haul. We're not the only ones with nukes, remember. It has to be a coordinated effort, with us and other nations moving together. When we set up this meeting – and we both wanted it – I wasn't expecting miracles, but you never know. Nuclear proliferation is a huge problem, the biggest in the world, in my opinion. I know a thing or two about nuclear, my uncle, Dr. John Trump at MIT, taught me a lot. If we can cut down on nukes, or even get rid of them altogether, that would be fantastic. I'll definitely bring it up. It's also a huge expense. We have some political problems here at home that make dealing with Russia tricky. But I want to get along with Russia, China, everyone. I'll also be talking about Syria and Ukraine, of course.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, in your opinion, could a deal have been achieved if Israel hadn't agreed to a temporary suspension of annexation? [SEP] Excuse me, could you please repeat the question?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Obama, is the less-than-enthusiastic reception you've received linked to the failures of your Asia pivot strategy? Also, with Guantanamo still open and your term nearing its end, will you acknowledge your inability to close it? [SEP] My reception has been excellent, as far as I'm aware. The people of Laos seem quite happy. Vietnam was amazing, with millions welcoming us. So, if you think my reception and the rebalance policy depend on the short stairs in China, that's an overstatement. Any reasonable person would find that puzzling. Leaders and ordinary people appreciate our work on economic and development programs, war legacy issues, and civil society. Their concern is whether it will continue. My successor should sustain this engagement, given the dynamic populations and growing economies here. Concerning Guantanamo, I won't concede it will remain open. We're working to reduce the population. It's a recruitment tool for terrorists, hinders counterterrorism cooperation, and is unnecessary and costly. Congress resists, but with only 40 or 50 people left, we should question why we're spending millions when it's not essential for our security.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, to put it plainly, would you sign a budget that keeps the government funded, even if it means sticking with those lower sequester levels, even if it's not your first choice? [SEP] I'm not going to paint myself into a corner here. But the fact is, we made a deal on a budget, agreed on some numbers. There's no need to go back and renegotiate that. Boehner and the leadership were all part of it. So, if the bill I get is in line with those commitments, then yeah, I'd sign it. Gotta keep the government running for the American people. Next question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, I want to talk about Vladimir Putin again. Just to be clear, do you believe Vladimir Putin himself authorized the hack? And do you believe he authorized that to help Donald Trump? And on the intelligence, one of the things Donald Trump cites is Saddam Hussein and the weapons of mass destruction, and that they were never found. Can you say, unequivocally, that this was not China, that this was not a 400-pound guy sitting on his bed, as Donald Trump says? And do these types of tweets and kinds of statements from Donald Trump embolden the Russians? [SEP] When the report comes out, before I leave office, that will have drawn together all the threads. And so I don't want to step on their work ahead of time.What I can tell you is that the intelligence that I have seen gives me great confidence in their assessment that the Russians carried out this hack.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, besides Huawei, could you identify any other Chinese technology companies that are currently under consideration for potential bans within the United States? [SEP] Well, the primary focus is on Huawei, correct? We are not allowing them to operate here. And I have informed various European nations and others that while they are free to utilize Huawei's services, we will not be sharing intelligence with them. And they have all reconsidered. Take the UK, for example, they seemed inclined to go that route, but now they have reversed course.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, one more time, is the NHS under consideration in these discussions? [SEP] Could you repeat the question? I'm having trouble hearing you.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, if a foreign entity proposed aiding your campaign, would you consider their proposition? [SEP] I'm not going to entertain these kinds of questions. My focus is on running a clean, fair campaign, and that's all I have to say on the matter.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: So, why are you not attending? [SEP] I'm not sure. I'd almost relish the opportunity to sit in the front row and glare at their dishonest faces. I would enjoy it.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, you seemed to backtrack on your stance about Brexit impacting U.S.-U.K. trade. Was publicly criticizing the Prime Minister's Brexit plan, considering the 'special relationship,' appropriate? Prime Minister, do you agree with Mr. Trump's assessment that Brexit could limit trade deals, and how did you react to his criticism? [SEP] Look, I have great respect for the Prime Minister. The fake news didn't report all the good things I said about her. We record everything, so we have the real story. She's going to decide what to do with Brexit. I just want to make sure we can trade. We want to trade with the U.K., and they want to trade with us. We're their biggest trading partner. We can make it even bigger. So, if they go a different way, I hope we can still trade. I've heard it might not be possible, but I think it will be. So, we'll see. And she's doing a fantastic job. Thank you. And just to add to what the President said, there will be no limits to our trade deals after Brexit. We can trade with the U.S. and the rest of the world. We're taking back control of our borders, laws, and money. We will be able to make our own trade deals. The U.S. is eager to work with us.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President, regarding the alleged U.S. surveillance of South Korea, what steps are being taken to address this issue, and did President Biden provide any specific commitments during your meeting? [SEP] We are in close contact with the United States regarding this matter, and we are sharing the necessary information. The U.S. government has initiated an investigation, and we must allow that process to unfold. As you know, these situations are often complex and multifaceted. We will continue to communicate with the U.S. on this issue. Thank you, that will be all for today.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, considering your past interactions, did you have any inkling that he might be considering a change in his professional life? [SEP] At that particular juncture, I possessed no such information or awareness.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President Bush, considering your differing philosophy from President-elect Obama, what are your primary concerns about his potential policies? [SEP] Michael, I'm not going to second-guess the next guy. He'll be in the hot seat soon enough, making his own calls. Besides, I'm about to exit stage left. One spotlight at a time, that's my motto. I've had my turn. Sure, I might chime in now and then, but I genuinely wish him well. And that's not just lip service. The stakes are high. There's still an enemy out there itching to strike again. People can dismiss that if they want, but it's the truth. I hope he keeps us safe. And of course, he's inheriting a tough economy. I know how that feels. Using taxpayer money to bail out Wall Street was a gut-wrenching decision, but it was necessary to prevent a collapse. Wall Street got drunk, and we got the hangover. Obama will face similar tough choices, decisions he might not initially be comfortable with. I remember folks back in Midland asking me what I was doing, bailing out those East Coast bankers. I told them, it was to protect them. Anyway, I truly wish him all the best.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, could you elaborate on the reasoning behind including firearm offenses in your commutation decisions, particularly in light of your overall position on gun control? [SEP] Okay.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Senator McCain suggests a tougher stance with Vladimir Putin. Do you agree? And what are the potential implications for Russian democracy if Putin remains in power after your presidency? [SEP] Well, my approach is to build relationships so I can influence people. That means having personal relationships where I can be honest without causing a crisis. That's how I deal with Vladimir Putin. We disagree on many things, but we agree on some, like counterterrorism and nuclear proliferation. Good diplomacy requires good relations at the top. In Slovakia, I told him we were concerned about the press becoming less free. He didn't like it, but it didn't ruin our relationship. He told me going into Iraq was a mistake. That's good diplomacy. I'll keep doing that. As for changing Russia's DNA, that's hard. We've made it clear that good relations with the West are in their interest. That means checks and balances and respecting freedoms. Russia is a complex relationship, but it's important.
label: Deflection

sentence: Considering Cuba's accusations of US meddling, will your administration formally abandon efforts at regime change? And, despite current polling trends, do you maintain that the Democratic primary remains competitive? [SEP] I've run my last campaign, and I won't speculate on future elections. That's your area of expertise. On Cuba, our goal is to empower the Cuban people with freedom and the ability to determine their own future, supporting civil society. Change is inevitable in Cuba, partly due to generational shifts. While we still have serious concerns about the Cuban government's human rights record and regional activities, there are also areas for collaboration, such as healthcare. I told President Castro that we will advocate for our values through persuasion. Cuba is not a direct threat to the US, and our priorities lie elsewhere, including combating ISIL, preventing Iranian nuclear proliferation, addressing conflicts in Yemen and Libya, countering Boko Haram, and addressing Russian aggression in Ukraine. Our approach is to partner with the region, promoting opportunity, prosperity, and security. Overly aggressive intervention often backfires, providing excuses for governance failures. Let's eliminate those excuses and engage constructively. Major Garrett.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the vaccine program, you've made numerous appeals for vaccination, even targeting hesitant Republicans. Yet, the absence of vaccines for young children remains a significant issue. Could you speak directly to concerned parents about the reasons for this ongoing delay and when they can anticipate a resolution? [SEP] The scientists are still evaluating the data and haven't yet determined that it's safe for that age group. Remember, we had similar questions about older kids, those between 7 and 12. After extensive trials, they were confident in its safety. The same rigorous process is being applied here. It's on its way, but as I'm not a medical expert, I can't provide a timeline. But we must prioritize the safety of our youngest citizens.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: On E-Verify, veto if no legalization? And on Fast and Furious, ATF leadership changes and investigation timeline? [SEP] On Fast and Furious, the Attorney General denies authorizing gun running. The investigation is ongoing, so I can't comment further. I condemn such actions and await the results. On E-Verify, comprehensive reform is crucial. We need a system that balances law and immigration traditions, with strong borders, employer accountability, and a path to legal status. E-Verify can be useful if accurate and fair, with safeguards for citizens. We must also consider DREAM Act kids. A balanced solution is needed.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, where are the medical experts? Why aren't Drs. Fauci and Birx at your side during this critical time? [SEP] Those folks are incredibly busy, as you can imagine. They're handling a lot behind the scenes. We have a great team, the best team, and they're all contributing.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the criticism from Mitt Romney's economic advisor, how do you respond to the assertion that your economic policies are flawed and based on a misunderstanding of the European crisis? [SEP] Look, I'm not going to get into a back-and-forth with political pundits. My focus is on creating jobs and growing the American economy. We have a clear plan to invest in infrastructure, education, and innovation. We are cutting taxes for working families and small businesses. We are reducing regulations that stifle growth. We are confident that our policies will lead to a stronger and more prosperous America.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Was he invited, sir? [SEP] I have no idea. I'm not the scheduler of news conferences. I do know they work very closely together, and they've got a very close working relationship, and that's important.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, Turkey's ground offensive in northern Iraq is now a week old with no end in sight. How quickly would you like to see Turkey end its offensive, its incursion? And do you have any concerns about the possibility of protracted presence in northern Iraq causing further destabilization in the region? [SEP] A couple of points on that—one, the Turks, the Americans, and the Iraqis, including the Iraqi Kurds, share a common enemy in the PKK. And secondly, it's in nobody's interests that there be safe haven for people who are—have the willingness to kill innocent people.A second point I want to make to you, Matt [Matt Spetalnick, Reuters], is that there is a Special Forces presence in northern Iraq, in Kurdistan, now, apart from what you're referring to. In other words— so there is a presence, and there has been a presence for a while.Thirdly, I strongly agree with the sentiments of Secretary Gates, who said that the incursion must be limited and must be temporary in nature. In other words, it shouldn't be long lasting. But the Turks need to move, move quickly, achieve their objective, and get out.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, the issue of voting access has become increasingly contentious. As the leader of this nation, do you share concerns about potential barriers to the ballot box? [SEP] I've heard reports that Georgia's voting process was remarkably efficient. However, these matters are primarily under the jurisdiction of the individual states. You'd have to inquire with them directly. Next question, please.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, on the topic of rockets and settlements, what measures should Israel adopt to counter the escalating threat from Gaza? And on settlements, did the Prime Minister provide any new assurances regarding the dismantling of illegal outposts? Do you anticipate any actual progress this time? Is this an issue of importance to you? [SEP] Yes.
label: General

sentence: President Trump, what's your understanding of the duration of Israel's suspension of the West Bank annexation? [SEP] What's your opinion? Share it with me. We're dedicating all our resources to peace. We have an agreement with the Emirates. We're finalizing all the details – embassies, overflights, commerce – and then expanding that to the entire region. I can't provide a specific timeframe. We've prioritized peace over the sovereignty movement, but it remains a possibility. It's simply been deferred until we've explored every avenue for peace.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, to clarify Bloomberg's question, if Russia undertakes a limited incursion into Ukraine, would the sanctions you've promised still be implemented? Or are you signaling to Putin that a small-scale invasion is permissible? [SEP] That's certainly something to consider.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Good afternoon, heads of state. President Obama, there are certain questions about violation of human rights here in Mexico and all these problems of fighting drug trafficking. Are you going to certify Mexico? And how can we move forward with the Merida Initiative? We've also been concerned about any attempt against Felipe Calderon's life. We know about certain threats and insecurity that prevails. This, of course, is certainly related to your country. We're concerned about the visa problem too. But what comments would you have regarding all these questions? [SEP] I didn't get a translation on that one. [] So it sounded like a very good question. [] Here, I think it's coming. Go ahead.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Two very quick questions, one for President Bush and the other for Prime Minister Berlusconi. Now, we know that you are in sound agreement. And, President Bush, I think that you were recently interviewed by my newscast, and you said that you were in favor of Italy being part of the 5-plus-1 group, which is handling the Iranian crisis issue.Now, Stephen Hadley said today that your position is that of waiting to see what might happen. Now, the White House was backing Italy's participation in the 5-plus1 group. So an answer on that.And, Prime Minister Berlusconi, will there be changes in Italy's presence in Afghanistan and other trouble spots after your talks with President Bush this afternoon? [SEP] [Inaudible]—the P-5plus-1. And I told Silvio I'd seriously consider it. I also made it clear, however, that all of us, P-5-plus-1 or not, need to be sending the same message to the Iranians, which is, verifiably suspend your enrichment program or else you will face further sanctions and further isolation. And the sad thing about this issue is that the Iranian people are suffering. They could be doing a lot better. Their lives could be much more hopeful, except their Government has made the decision to defy the demands of the free world, has made the decision to ignore the IAEA, and has continued to enrich in a way that we think is dangerous.And so the choice is theirs to make. Foreign Minister Solana is going to see the Iranianhere very shortly, and his message is one that—is the one I just delivered. And it's—I hope for the sake of the Iranian people that their Government changes course. There is a better way forward.I want to remind you something about this Iranian issue. Vladimir Putin, our mutual friend, went to the Iranians and said, you have a right to have civilian nuclear power. I have said the same thing publicly as well. I mean, I'm a big believer in nuclear power. I think the best way to deal with climate change is the spread of nuclear power. The best way to become less dependent on foreign sources of energy is nuclear power. And I believe Iran should have a civilian nuclear power. I don't believe they can be entrusted to enrich.And therefore, Vladimir Putin went and said—and he believes that—and he said, we'll provide the fuel for you, and we'll not only provide the fuel, we'll gather the spent fuel, so you don't need to enrich. So the argument of the Iranian Government that we have a right to have civilian nuclear power has been undermined by the Russian proposal.And so it will be interesting to see their decision. But what they need to hear is, is that we are firm in our resolve to prevent them from having the capacity to make a nuclear weapon. And with regard to the question addressed to me, we've offered to join the other European countries, plus China, plus Russia, in order to make our contribution to the negotiations which are underway with the Iranian Government. Now, our offer is based on the fact that we know Iran very well from the inside. We have some leading companies that are operating in these countries, and therefore, we think that this would be very useful in helping President Bush and Vladimir Putin to pursue the strategy that they've determined for that country.Now, we obviously need to make sure that nuclear energy is being used for only peaceful reasons. With regard to the sanctions proposed by the United Nations, we have always abided by those. And the presence of our businesses have to do with agreements and contracts which date back several years.Now, with regard to our willingness to remove or lift any caveats with regard to Afghanistan, we discussed that. And we also said that we are willing to keep our troops in other fronts, as it were, in other areas— in Kosovo and Lebanon and wherever it is that our Italian soldiers are today.And I thank President Bush for his appreciation and acknowledgment of the Italian commitment in these international fronts. And in fact, there are 40,000 troops that are currently operating in our foreign missions. And we—there—we obviously have a turnover, and we always manage to keep that very large number of troops there. And we will continue, therefore, to pursue this, because we are fully convinced that it is extremely important to be able to establish democracy in Iraq. This is a very important country in that region, and we'll obviously continue to pursue our other efforts. And we obviously back any agreement that will help us to overcome any divisions in Lebanon.And we're also working on the agreements—on the negotiations for an agreement in Israel and the Middle East. And we are hoping that in all these countries it will be possible to establish peace and that they will certainly be able to become fully established democracies.The second Italian journalist is from ANSA, the leading news agency.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Build Back Better and the pandemic: You expressed confidence in passing major components of Build Back Better this year. Does that imply you're contemplating dividing the package into individual sections? And concerning the pandemic, with the Supreme Court's rejection of the vaccine-or-test mandate for larger companies, are you reevaluating vaccine requirements for domestic flights as a means to boost vaccination numbers? [SEP] Alright, let's address the last point first: I believe the Supreme Court's decision was an error. Nevertheless, numerous employees of major corporations are still subject to testing due to company policies, not my regulations. I anticipate that number will increase, not decrease. Now, remind me of the first part of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Trump, concerning the Washington Post's report that the White House is delaying the GOP coronavirus bill by insisting on including provisions for the FBI building in DC, is this correct? [SEP] I'm not certain if it's being included in *this* particular bill, but the FBI undeniably requires a new facility. The existing structure is antiquated, poorly constructed, and frankly, hazardous! Panels are detaching, and concrete is crumbling. They considered relocating it far from DC, but I emphasized the necessity of proximity to the Justice Department. The present location is optimal. Therefore, I've been advocating for the construction of a new building. A mere renovation simply won't suffice. Envision a cutting-edge building, potentially even with a running track on the roof – FBI agents are known for their fitness! So, regardless of whether it's incorporated into this bill or another, we will secure a new building for the FBI. Rest assured.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, wouldn't your presence demonstrate respect for the institutions you lead? [SEP] Respect is earned, not given. And frankly, the way these proceedings are being conducted, it's hard to see much respect being shown in return. My focus is on delivering results for the American people, and that's where my energy will remain.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. You would tell Congress—you would encourage Congress to pay for testing for school districts? [SEP] I would if they want. Again, we've done 50 million tests. There's nobody even close in the whole world. You look at our mortality rate. You look at our death rate. You look at different statistics. We're doing very well. But one death is too many. This should never have happened. This should never have been allowed to happen—from China.Payroll Tax Cut
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, regarding the NHS, is it under consideration in the trade talks? [SEP] Pardon me? What was that about?
label: Clarification

sentence: Regarding the Israeli-Palestinian issue, you previously stated your willingness to expend political capital. In retrospect, do you feel you've delivered on that commitment? Furthermore, how closely linked are developments in Israel-Palestine to achieving your objectives in Iraq? [SEP] The fundamental objective is for both sides to embrace the vision of two states coexisting peacefully. We are actively investing resources to steer them towards this shared direction, a significant shift considering the historical context of the Middle East.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding our G-7 leadership, what specific initiatives are you hoping to champion? [SEP] Well, we're aiming for something truly remarkable, something that builds upon the already strong foundation we've established. We anticipate a display of unprecedented unity. In fact, unity was the defining characteristic of our recent gathering of these seven crucial nations. Above all, we fostered exceptional rapport.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, could you comment on the recent training accident off the coast of California involving the Marines and Navy corpsman? [SEP] I'm scheduled to receive a briefing on that shortly.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Russia and Ukraine, do you have intelligence suggesting President Putin intends to invade? [SEP] The truth is, only Putin knows what Putin will do. It's his decision, plain and simple. He might wake up one morning and decide to move, or he might not. It's all up to him. We're watching closely, but ultimately, it's his call.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You spoke a moment ago about what you won't do in terms of your negotiations with Republicans. But I'm interested in what you've signaled you already might do. In particular, by conceding in these negotiations to some form of a cap or freezing spending, are you concerned that Mr. McCarthy has already forced you into accepting a policy position that could tip this economy into a recession? [SEP] No, I don't believe that's the case at all. As a matter of fact, I think that we can reach an agreement. As I've told you—and you may be aware or you've seen it—we have provided for a proposal that would cut a trillion dollars off the baseline spent from the year before by just agreeing to deal with what was initially offered.And secondly, we're in a situation where the—let me put it this way: If you all were doing your budget at home, and you said, Okay, we have to make some cuts, would you only look at the spending or would you also look at your income—what was coming in the door—to determine what you could afford?And so part of what I've been arguing from the beginning is a need to consider the tax structure as well as—as well as—cutting spending. I'm willing to cut spending, and I proposed cuts in spending of over a trillion dollars.But I believe we have to also look at the tax revenues. The idea that the—my Republican colleagues want to continue the $2 trillion tax cut that had profound negative impacts on the economy from the Trump administration. The fact that they are—we've provided for the number of—we got a lot of input from serious economists and former administration officials in both parties that we need more people who are qualified to be able to look at the tax returns of the thousand billionaires in America—very complicated stuff.It's estimated that if we had the appropriate number of tax personnel, that we would save somewhere between—we would generate somewhere between $200 billion and $400 billion in tax revenue.And there's a lot of other—for example, the idea that we're—in terms of taxes—that they refuse to—for example, we—I was able to balance the budget and pass everything from the global warming bill—anyway, I was able to cut, by $1.7 billion [trillion; White House correction] in the first 2 years, the deficit that we were accumulating.And—because I was able to say, too, that the 55 corporations in America that made forty—$400 billion—or $40 billion—$400 billion—that they—they pay zero in tax. Zero. And so we said, You've got to pay a minimum of 15 percent taxes. What a horrible thing. You're paying more than 15 percent in taxes, every one of you out there.And so guess what? We not only balanced the budget; we were able to reduce the deficit by $1.7 billion [trillion; White House correction]. And so there's a lot of things that they refuse to look at in terms of tax generation as well as what kind of people we're going to increase taxes for.And like I said, we're now down to—we went from somewhere—roughly 740 billionaires to about 1,000 billionaires in America. They're paying an average tax rate of 8 percent. Raise your hand if you want to pay 8 percent only. I think you'd all be ready to do that.So my point is that there's a lot of things that they refuse to entertain, and they just said revenue is off the table. Well, revenue is not off the table. And so that's what I continue—we continue to have a significant disagreement on, on the revenue side.
label: Explicit

sentence: Do you feel the fever of division has broken after the election? [SEP] Look, there's always going to be some folks who are out there on the fringes, but I think most Republicans are decent people. The world's watching us, you know? They want to know if America's back, if we're stable. After January 6th, they were wondering if our democracy was on the edge. We need to show them we're still the same country, that our institutions matter.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your lunch with Mr. Prodi and your upcoming coffee with Mr. Berlusconi, some perceive this as unusual. Critics suggest it blurs the lines of diplomacy. How do you respond to those concerns, particularly given the ongoing discussions about Afghanistan and Iran? [SEP] Well, let me be clear. Seeing Silvio is about maintaining relationships. He's the opposition leader, yes, but also a long-time friend. I told Romano myself. It's not a big deal. It's not like I'm undermining anything. We've known each other for years, just like I've known Romano. These are important leaders, and we had a frank discussion about Afghanistan and Iran. We share common ground on preventing nuclear proliferation. We'll work together to pressure Iran. We also discussed climate change and how to harmonize our production systems. So, it's about working together for peace and progress.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, considering the delicate balance of power in the Asia-Pacific region, what specific red lines, if any, did you communicate to your successor regarding potential shifts in U.S. policy towards Taiwan, particularly in light of China's increasing assertiveness in the region? [SEP] Look, I emphasized the importance of strategic consistency and a thorough understanding of the potential consequences of any policy changes. The situation in the Asia-Pacific is complex, and any adjustments to our approach must be carefully calibrated to avoid unintended escalation. We need to maintain open lines of communication with all parties involved and ensure that our actions are consistent with our long-term interests and values.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. How do you respond to those who say the election outcome, at least in part, was voters saying that they see you as out of touch with their personal economic pain? And are you willing to make any changes in your leadership style? [SEP] There is a inherent danger in being in the White House and being in the bubble. I mean, folks didn't have any complaints about my leadership style when I was running around Iowa for a year. And they got a pretty good look at me up close and personal, and they were able to lift the hood and kick the tires. And I think they understood that my story was theirs. I might have a funny name, I might have lived in some different places, but the values of hard work and responsibility and honesty and looking out for one another that had been instilled in them by their parents, those were the same values that I took from my mom and my grandparents.And so the track record has been that when I'm out of this place, that's not an issue. When you're in this place, it is hard not to seem removed. And one of the challenges that we've got to think about is how do I meet my responsibilities here in the White House, which require a lot of hours and a lot of work, but still have that opportunity to engage with the American people on a day-to-day basis and know--give them confidence that I'm listening to them.Those letters that I read every night, some of them just break my heart. Some of them provide me encouragement and inspiration. But nobody's filming me reading those letters. And so it's hard, I think, for people to get a sense of, well, how's he taking in all this information?So I think there are more things that we can do to make sure that I'm getting out of here. But, I mean, I think it's important to point out as well that a couple of great communicators, Ronald Reagan and Bill Clinton, were standing at this podium 2 years into their Presidency getting very similar questions because the economy wasn't working the way it needed to be and there were a whole range of factors that made people concerned that maybe the party in power wasn't listening to them.This is something that I think every President needs to go through, because the responsibilities of this office are so enormous and so many people are depending on what we do, and in the rush of activity, sometimes we lose track of the ways that we connected with folks that got us here in the first place.And that's something that--now, I'm not recommending for every future President that they take a shellacking like they--like I did last night. [] I'm sure there are easier ways to learn these lessons. But I do think that this is a growth process and an evolution. And the relationship that I've had with the American people is one that built slowly, peaked at this incredible high, and then during the course of the last 2 years, as we've, together, gone through some very difficult times, has gotten rockier and tougher. And it's going to, I'm sure, have some more ups and downs during the course of me being in this office.But the one thing that I just want to end on is getting out of here is good for me too, because when I travel around the country, even in the toughest of these debates--in the midst of health care last year during summer when there were protesters about, and when I'm meeting families who've lost loved ones in Afghanistan or Iraq--I always come away from those interactions just feeling so much more optimistic about this country.We have such good and decent people who, on a day-to-day basis, are finding all kinds of ways to live together and educate kids and grow their communities and improve their communities and create businesses and work together to create great new products and services. The American people always make me optimistic.And that's why, during the course of the last 2 years, as tough as it's been, as many sometimes scary moments as we've gone through, I've never doubted that we're going to emerge stronger than we were before. And I think that remains true, and I'm just going to be looking forward to playing my part in helping that journey along.All right. Thank you very much, everybody.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. But is the election of two Muslim women—one of them is veiled—to the House, which is making history, is this a rebuke of this message, do you think? [SEP] Could you repeat that?
label: Clarification
