sentence: Which other Chinese technology firms are being considered for bans in the United States? [SEP] The main focus is Huawei, right? Huawei isn't allowed here. And I've communicated this to European nations and others. Australia, for instance, has been exceptional. But Huawei won't be operating here. We've advised certain countries considering Huawei that while they can use them, we won't share intelligence. And they've all stepped back. Take the U.K., they seemed inclined that way, but now they've reversed course—Scotland Yard.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, your answer doesn't address the specific question of whether you believe Crimea should be recognized as Russian territory. Can you clarify your position on that? [SEP] The situation in Crimea is complex and requires careful consideration. We're evaluating all options and will make a decision that is in the best interests of the United States and our allies.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, could you elaborate on the planned actions to resolve this matter? [SEP] This is a challenge that we recognize, and we are dedicated to working towards a resolution.
label: General

sentence: Q. It's the angelic glow of the backlighting, Mr. President, that makes us look so similar. Of course, the denuclearization—nuclear weapons and biological weapons and whatnot—is one problem in North Korea. Another huge problem is the horrible record that they have on human rights. Was that discussed at all? [SEP] Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, in July, your budget office projected a 7.7% unemployment rate for the fourth quarter of 2012. Will this new package reduce that projection? And will it stimulate growth and job creation more effectively than the Recovery Act? [SEP] Well, this package isn't as big of a boost as the Recovery Act, but we're in a different situation now. Back then, we were staring down a potential Great Depression, with unemployment possibly hitting 15 or 20 percent. We don't know. Thanks to our efforts to stabilize the financial system and the Federal Reserve's actions, that's behind us. We're not facing a double-dip recession. Now, the economy is growing, company profits are up, and we're seeing some private sector job growth, but it's not happening fast enough to bring down the unemployment rate, given the 8 million jobs we lost before and as I took office. So, this package provides an extra boost, bigger than most economists expected. Some are already suggesting we might see faster growth and more jobs because of it. The payroll tax holiday will help, and unemployment insurance has a big impact on keeping the recovery going strong. Overall, economists agree this will help economic and job growth in the coming months. That's the main reason I made this decision. We need to remember, especially my fellow Democrats who care deeply about middle-class, working, and low-income families: the best jobs program is a growing economy. The best anti-poverty program is making sure people have jobs and the economy is growing. We can do other things, but if the economy isn't growing and the private sector isn't hiring faster, we'll keep having problems, no matter what programs we put in place. That's why I looked at our options and decided that another 3, 4, or 5 months of uncertainty would hurt people who see their paychecks shrink and those who rely on unemployment insurance to pay their bills. It would also damage the overall health of the economy.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Will you be disappointed if he stays in power after you're gone? [SEP] I have no idea what he's going to do. He—I asked him when I saw him in Australia. I tried to get it out of him, who's going to be his successor, what he intends to do, and he was wily. He wouldn't tip his hand. I'll tip mine: I'm going to finish—I'm going to work hard to the finish. I'm going to sprint to the finish line, and then you'll find me in Crawford.Sheryl [Sheryl Gay Stolberg, New York Times].
label: Deflection

sentence: President Lee, given North Korea's planned rocket launch despite international condemnation, what concrete steps will South Korea take in response? What specific sanctions are on the table, and can you update us on the status of missile range extension negotiations with the US? [SEP] If North Korea goes ahead with this launch, it's a clear violation of UN resolutions and a broken promise to the world. They'll face the consequences, no doubt about it. This action will only isolate them further. The North Korean people will realize their leader prioritizes missiles over their well-being. We urge them to choose a better path, one of responsibility and cooperation. As for extending South Korea's missile range, that wasn't part of our discussion today, though our teams are working on it. It's about strengthening our defenses against the North. We'll handle this calmly and strategically.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, can you guarantee there won't be a shutdown after the midterms? [SEP] Well, you know, the situation is fluid. I'm not going to box myself in with any guarantees. It's possible, sure. But I'm not going to say one way or the other. We'll see how things play out.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Given your history of using federal contracting to achieve policy objectives, is it fair to expect that you'll consider a similar strategy in this case? [SEP] I'm not going to reveal our strategy in piecemeal fashion. We're conducting a comprehensive evaluation, and once we have a clear understanding of our capabilities, we'll share our plans accordingly.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Sir, with respect to the National Health Service, is it on the table for discussion? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, with the election of these two Muslim women, one wearing a veil, does this signal a repudiation of your policies? [SEP] I'm not sure I follow.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, in the wake of an avalanche of allegations made against Harvey Weinstein, your campaign is being subpoenaed for any documents relating to sexual harassment allegations made against you. Do you have any response to that? [SEP] All I can say is it's totally fake news. It's just fake. It's fake. It's made-up stuff, and it's disgraceful what happens. But that's happens in the world of politics.Jon [Jonathan Karl, ABC News].

sentence: Regarding the Marino bill and its alleged contribution to the opioid crisis, Mr. President, can you provide a specific timeline for when your administration will complete its review and announce a decision on whether to seek its repeal or modification? [SEP] We're moving as quickly as possible. It's a very important issue, and we want to make sure we get it right. We're consulting with experts, listening to all sides, and gathering all the facts. We'll have an announcement soon.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, in the event that sanctions against Iran prove ineffective, are there alternative strategies under consideration, short of military action? [SEP] I'm not going to discuss potential future actions. However, I firmly believe the sanctions are having the desired effect. While military intervention remains an option, it's a last resort. Let me assure you, nobody can compete with our military. The investments we've made over the past three years are unprecedented, and all manufactured right here in the United States. Our nuclear capabilities, which had been allowed to deteriorate, are now in top-notch condition. We must pray that we never have to utilize them. Our military is in exceptional shape. We have outstanding individuals like General Milley, who will be assuming the role of Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Secretary of Defense Mark Esper, who brings tremendous energy and expertise to the table. And, of course, Secretary Mnuchin is present; we implemented the most stringent sanctions ever imposed on a nation today. I can assure you, we would never subject Australia to such measures.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, what's your take on Russia's announcement that they're scaling back military operations near Kyiv? Is this a sign the war is ending, or a ploy to regroup? [SEP] Well, we'll just have to wait and see, won't we? I'm not one to jump to conclusions based on announcements. We need to see action. We're talking with our allies, and we'll keep the pressure on with sanctions and military aid.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Sir, regarding the financial transaction, could you clarify its current status? [SEP] Pardon?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Given the economic downturn, how quickly did you feel comfortable leading the nation? [SEP] Comfort wasn't on the menu, not with the economy shedding jobs at an alarming rate. My situation was unique; unlike FDR, who inherited an already established Depression, we were in a free fall. The financial system was seizing up, the auto industry teetering, and housing in ruins. I was too busy making critical decisions to worry about settling in. While the next administration inherits a country with challenges, the economic indicators – low unemployment, rising wages, stable financial systems – are strong. They won't face the immediate crises we did, thanks to my team's hard work.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. It's something interesting, I think, that has not come up. President Obama says that there is footage and records of objects in the skies—these unidentified aerial phenomena—and he says we don't know exactly what they are. What do you think that it is? [SEP] I would ask him again. Thank you. [] Come on, boss, let's go. []
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Sir—[inaudible]—from CNBC TV18 India. American companies have been investing in India for a long, long time. Are you satisfied with the Indian investment rating, especially on issues like multibrand retail and e-commerce on which companies from U.S. have a lot of interest in? [SEP] So I'm very satisfied because they're investing tremendous amounts of money. I met Mr. Patel a little while ago. He's the largest steel person in the world by far. I don't think there's even a contest. And he's going to be building a billion-dollar plant in Alabama.We had the press—I left them in there. Always a risky thing to do. But if you—if you see the—let's say we ask—you know, answered 15 questions, and they were talking about how much better it is to work in the United States now, in terms of their investment. They have done a fantastic job.These are some of the biggest entrepreneurs in the world. I'm not even sure if the media really understood who they were. I knew many of them, certainly heard of all of them. The job they've done is incredible. But Mr. Patel, who's the biggest steel—I think biggest steel company, certainly the biggest steel individual. But I think he's the biggest steel company by a lot. He's investing billions of dollars in the United States, and he's only doing it because of what I've done to bring back the steel industry. The steel industry was dead. Absolutely dead in the United States. And now it's a vibrant industry. It's incredible, and we need it. Again, we need it for defense. It's not just like certain industries that you don't need. We need it for defense.But he was glowing. And one of the reasons he's spending a billion dollars in Alabama, and more money in other places in the United States, is because we brought it back. So we're very proud of that.So I think what we'll do is we're going to see some of you on the plane on the way back. It's been an honor to be here. It's an incredible place with incredible leadership and an unbelievable future.And I just want to thank you all. And I'll see you back in the States. And I think some of you are on the plane, and we can talk a little bit on the plane too. Thank you very much, everybody. Thank you very much.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, regarding General Kelly, are the rumors of his departure accurate? Is he planning to leave the White House? [SEP] Personnel changes are part of any administration. People come and go. We'll make announcements when and if necessary.
label: General

sentence: Following up on President Duda, you mentioned receiving another letter from Kim Jong Un. Given the potential for improved relations between North and South Korea, could you share any details from that letter, and is a third summit being planned? [SEP] He sent me a very gracious letter, quite unexpected. The contents will be revealed in due time. Perhaps in a century, perhaps in a fortnight. Who can say? But it was a most pleasant letter, filled with warmth. I was most appreciative.
label: General

sentence: So, are you being given an ultimatum by Congress regarding the war this fall? [SEP] I value the Members' visit to the White House. We had a productive discussion where I shared my perspectives on the Iraqi issue, emphasizing the potential consequences of failure and the benefits of success. They voiced their concerns about the Iraq war, which are shared by many. I reminded them that polls last fall indicated widespread disapproval of the situation in Iraq. I, too, would have expressed disapproval at that time. That's why I implemented a plan to improve the situation. I explained my decision-making process and emphasized that General Petraeus has a plan that some Members of Congress are hindering. It's illogical to unanimously confirm him and then deny him the resources needed to succeed. We must give General Petraeus a chance. He will report back to the Secretary, the Joint Chiefs, the White House, and Congress on the effectiveness of the strategy. We will then respond accordingly. Decisions about our posture in Iraq must be based on conditions on the ground, and General Petraeus is best suited to assess those conditions. Upon his recommendation, along with the Secretary and the Joint Chiefs, we will respond. Let's wait and see what happens and give this plan a chance to work. Let's avoid playing politics and support our troops. It's one thing to have an honest debate about Iraq, but it's another to involve our troops in that debate. They deserve the necessary funding and flexibility. This cause is necessary and noble, which is why I deployed them in the first place. It's essential for our nation's peace and security. It's noble that these citizens volunteer to serve. Congress must support them. While debating strategies is acceptable, ensuring timely funding is crucial. Funding our troops every two months is inadequate and unacceptable. They need what the military has requested. We can and should debate Iraq, but funding our troops should not be debated. I appreciate your time.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding North Korea, did you and Kim discuss allowing inspectors into their nuclear sites? [SEP] Speak up, please. And what news organization are you with?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, your administration has consistently condemned North Korea's human rights record. After your summit with Kim Jong Un, are you prepared to publicly reiterate your concerns and outline any concrete steps you've discussed to address these abuses? [SEP] We're aware of the situation. It's bad. Very bad. We discussed it. We're working on it. The main thing is getting rid of the nuclear weapons. That's priority number one. But we're not forgetting about the other stuff. We'll see what happens. It's a long process.
label: Dodging

sentence: With the Justice Department IG report highlighting issues with the Carter Page FISA application and earlier warnings about the Surveillance Court, what are your views on Edward Snowden and the possibility of his return without serving time? [SEP] The FISA abuse was staggering, and it's a disgrace it took this long to expose. The altering of documents presented to the FISA Court was reprehensible. We caught Biden, Obama, and the whole gang – Brennan, Comey, Clapper – spying on my campaign. This was an illegal act of unparalleled proportions, nothing short of treason. They used intelligence agencies to spy on my campaign both before and after the election. Now, regarding Kamala, she's a tax-and-spend liberal who wants to gut our military. And let's not forget how nasty she was to Joe Biden during those debates. OAN, please. Thank you very much.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thanks, Mr. President. Two questions for you, if you don't mind. First, the man you met today, Kim Jong Un, as you know, has killed family members, has starved his own people, is responsible for the death of Otto Warmbier. Why are you so comfortable calling him very talented? [SEP] Well, he is very talented. Anybody that takes over a situation like he did, at 26 years of age, and is able to run it and run it tough—I don't say he was nice or I don't say anything about it—he ran it. Very few people, at that age—you can take 1 out of 10,000, probably, couldn't do it.Otto Warmbier is a very special person, and he will be for a long time, in my life. His parents are good friends of mine. I think without Otto this would not have happened. Something happened, from that day. It was a terrible thing. It was brutal. But a lot of people started to focus on what was going on, including North Korea.I really think that Otto is someone who did not die in vain. I told this to his parents. Special young man. And I have to say, special parents, special people. Otto did not die in vain. He had a lot to do with us being here today. Okay? Thank you very much.U.S. Troop Deployment in South Korea/
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. ——President Putin to that meeting? [SEP] I don't know. But we have invited a number of people to the meeting. I certainly would invite him to the meeting; I think he's an important factor. But we will invite certain people that aren't in the G-7. Some people have already accepted.But we're going to be doing it after the election. I think it's a better atmosphere to have a G-7. I think it's a lot—I think it's just a better, calmer atmosphere to have a G-7.Yes, please.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, why the Hong Kong business advisory? And regarding Build Back Better, are Senators Manchin and Sinema on board with the $3.5 trillion framework? If they demand cuts, can you keep progressives on board? Chancellor Merkel, do you believe President Biden now understands your position on China? Is the U.S. contributing enough to global vaccinations, or should American children wait until adults in other countries are vaccinated? [SEP] Did you say all that in one breath? I thought we agreed on two questions each. Anyway, about Hong Kong, the situation there is getting worse. China isn't keeping its promises, so the advisory is just to warn businesses about potential problems. Simple as that. As for Build Back Better, am I confident? Absolutely! It'll all work out perfectly. The media keeps saying my plans are dead, but they're wrong. I still think we'll get the infrastructure deal done. I trust the Republican Senators who made commitments. They're honorable people. And reconciliation is how we get all the Democrats on board. Today, if you make under $150,000 and have kids, you'll get a tax cut, a monthly payment like Social Security. It'll reduce child poverty by 40%. We have ways to pay for it. Maybe a few last-minute adjustments, but we'll get it done. On China, we agree that trade needs to be fair. We need to be technological leaders. We'll cooperate on things like CHIPS. And on the pandemic, we need everyone vaccinated. We're increasing production and encouraging vaccinations. We're investing in COVAX and helping Africa develop its own vaccine production. There's an imbalance, but we're working hard to fix it.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Why are you refusing to release the photos taken by the guards? [SEP] Hold on a minute. That's a completely different subject. It's crucial that we assure the Iranian people that we're paying attention and that they're not alone. However, the most important factor is what transpires in Iran. We've all been moved by the bravery of the people. As I mentioned in a recent statement, and as some of you covering my campaigns know, one of my favorite quotes is Dr. King's statement that the arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends towards justice. We must maintain our faith that justice will ultimately prevail.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, after previously describing the 2010 midterms as a 'shellacking,' how would you characterize the outcome of this election? Moreover, can you provide an update on your planned immigration executive order? Has the election altered your timeline for its release, and is it still expected before the end of the lame-duck session? Has the scope of the order been narrowed? [SEP] Well, as I stated in my opening remarks, there's no denying that the Republicans had a successful election night. Our priority now is to engage with Mitch McConnell and John Boehner, who will be leading both chambers of Congress, to understand their legislative priorities. My hope is that we can identify areas of common ground and work together to address the pressing issues facing the American people. The resounding message from this election, and indeed from recent elections, is that the public wants action. They want us to focus on their concerns, not on partisan politics. They want us to address the challenges facing single mothers, young people burdened with student debt, and construction workers struggling to find employment. If we keep those individuals in mind, I believe we can achieve meaningful progress. Regarding immigration, I've consistently maintained that my preference is for Congress to enact comprehensive immigration reform legislation. Such legislation should strengthen our borders, streamline our legal immigration system, and provide a pathway to legal status for undocumented immigrants who have lived here for many years and have strong ties to our communities. The Senate passed a bipartisan bill that, while not perfect, represented a significant step forward. I urged John Boehner to bring that bill to a vote in the House, but unfortunately, he was unable to do so. Therefore, I feel obligated to use my executive authority to take action to improve our immigration system, while making it clear that any executive actions I take will be superseded by congressional action. That's a commitment I've made to the American people and to Speaker Boehner. Before the end of the year, I intend to take whatever lawful actions I can to enhance the functioning of our immigration system and to allocate additional resources to border security. I'll also be reaching out to Republican and Democratic leaders to explore how we can move forward on this issue. If they're willing to work with me to pass a bill, I'm eager to engage in that process. However, I won't simply wait for Congress to act. I believe I've demonstrated considerable patience and a willingness to work on a bipartisan basis, and I'll continue to do so. But in the meantime, we must do what we can to improve the system through executive action.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, in light of recent events, what advice would you give to those protesting against perceived injustices? Have you counseled your successor on the importance of careful staff selection? And in your final weeks, can you prevent further violence in Aleppo? Chancellor Merkel, given the contrasting views of Trump, what message do you have for Americans? [SEP] Well, a cornerstone of our democracy is the right to protest. I've been the target of protests during my time in office, as have many presidents before me. So, I wouldn't tell people who feel strongly about the issues raised during the campaign to be silent. What I would advise, and have advised, is that elections matter, voting matters, organizing matters, being informed on the issues matters. I consistently tell young people, both in the U.S. and abroad, don't take our systems of government and way of life for granted. Because we've lived in a relatively stable and peaceful era, with improving living standards, there's a tendency to assume it will always be this way. But it's not. Democracy is hard work. In the U.S., if 43 percent of eligible voters don't vote, democracy is weakened. If we're not serious about facts, especially in an age of social media where information is consumed in soundbites, if we can't distinguish between serious arguments and propaganda, we have problems. If people, regardless of their political leanings, are unwilling to compromise and demonize opponents, democracy will break down. So, my advice is to understand the foundations of a healthy democracy and how to engage in citizenship continuously, not just when something upsets us or during an election. It's hard work. The good news is, many young people who were involved in my campaigns continue to be involved in work, both politically and through nonprofits, that can carry this hard work forward. But there's sometimes complacency. Here in Europe, many young people forget the Cold War and the significance of the Berlin Wall. And I'll be honest, I've heard rhetoric in Europe that draws a false equivalence between the U.S. and Russia, and between how our governments operate versus other governments. Those distinctions are important. I've said many times that, like any government, we have flaws, we've operated imperfectly, we've made mistakes. There are times when I've made mistakes or our administration hasn't always aligned with our values. It's a work of constant improvement. But I can say to the German people that the U.S. has been good for Germany, has looked out for Germany, has provided security for Germany, has helped to rebuild Germany and unify Germany. And across Europe, many principles taken for granted here – free speech, civil liberties, an independent judiciary, and fighting corruption – are principles that, not perfectly, but generally, we've tried to apply not just in our own country, but also in our foreign policy. That should be remembered. Because in an age of active misinformation, packaged attractively and appearing the same on Facebook or TV, where overzealousness by a U.S. official is equated with constant and severe repression elsewhere, if everything seems the same and no distinctions are made, we won't know what to protect. We won't know what to fight for. And we can lose so much of what we've gained in terms of democratic freedoms, market-based economies, and prosperity that we've come to take for granted. That was a long answer, wasn't it? I don't remember if there was a second part to it. I got all caught up in that one.
label: Implicit

sentence:
Mr. President, given the current economic climate, are you still confident in achieving your administration's projected GDP growth? [SEP] We have the best unemployment numbers ever, record-breaking. But this virus, it could affect GDP. But safety is the priority, of course.

Boeing and the GM strike haven't helped either. And the Fed, I disagree with them. They're keeping interest rates too high. Obama had it easy with zero rates. We're paying interest, which is good for savers, but it's not helping growth.

We should have the lowest rates, like Germany. The Fed's made a mistake, a terrible mistake. We've still done great, even with the market drop. But we're watching it closely. We've been hurt by GM, Boeing, and the Fed. They've made the dollar too strong, which hurts exports.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, are you still weighing the 14th Amendment, or have you taken those options off the table? Q. How would you respond to criticism that your actions and the G-7 would lead to more instability and division in the world? Q. Sir, is a congressional deal the only option here, or are you still weighing other unilateral or executive actions? [SEP] We have not come up with a unilateral action that could succeed in a matter of 2 weeks or 3 weeks. That's the issue.
label: Implicit

sentence: Are you saying a troop pullout is on the table? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Are you planning any additional sanctions against Russia, besides calling off the summit? [SEP] Let's be clear, the summit cancellation wasn't just about Snowden. It was about a general lack of movement on key issues. So, I wouldn't call it strictly 'punitive.' We're going to keep looking for areas where we can work with Russia to advance our interests and promote peace and prosperity. Where we disagree, we'll say so. Hopefully, Putin will realize that cooperation is better than constant competition, for both our countries.
label: Deflection

sentence: Would you consider Kim Jong Un a peer on the global stage? [SEP] Define 'equal'.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Absolutely. And we know you prize loyalty, so I wonder whether you felt betrayed by Scott McClellan's assessment of the war in Iraq? And moving forward, since there have been positive signs on the ground in Iraq, Senator Obama is about to take a trip there. What would be your advice to him as he tries to assess the situation on the ground? [SEP] I have had no comment on—no comment now on Scott's book.Secondly, I would ask him to listen carefully to Ryan Crocker and General Petraeus. It's—there's a temptation to kind of get—let the politics at home get in the way with the considered judgment of the commanders. That's why I strongly rejected an artificial timetable of withdrawal. It's kind of like an arbitrary thing, you know— We will decide in the Halls of Congress how to conduct our affairs in based upon polls and politics, and we're going to impose this on people—as opposed to listening to our commanders and our diplomats, and listening to the is, for that matter. The is have invited us to be there. But they share a goal with us, which is to get our combat troops out, as conditions permit. Matter of fact, that's what we're doing. Return on success has been the strategy of this administration, and our troops are coming home, but based upon success.And so I would ask whoever goes there—whatever elected official goes there, to listen carefully to what is taking place and understand that the best way to go forward is to listen to the parties who are actually on the ground. And that's hard to do. I understand for some in Washington there's a lot of pressure. You got these groups out there—MoveOn.org, you know—banging away on these candidates, and it's hard to kind of divorce yourself from the politics.And so I'm glad all the—a lot of these elected officials are going over there, because they'll get an interesting insight, something that you don't get from just reading your wonderful newspapers or listening to your TV shows.John [John McKinnon, Wall Street Journal].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, as NATO leaders prepare to gather in Chicago, what's your outlook on securing an agreement regarding the transition strategy in Afghanistan? And how concerned are you that the Koran burning incident and the events that followed might jeopardize your ability to effectively negotiate with our international partners? [SEP] Look, the transition policy was established back in Lisbon, and we've been adhering to that strategy, which dictates a gradual transfer of responsibility to the Afghans, with the ultimate goal of ending our combat mission by the close of 2014. Our coalition partners are aligned with this plan, and it remains our guiding principle. The focus of the upcoming NATO meeting, and indeed the next two years, will be on ensuring a seamless transition, avoiding any abrupt cliff-like scenarios. We'll be establishing clear benchmarks and milestones along the way, mirroring our approach in Iraq, to ensure a measured and effective transfer of authority. Now, the Koran burning incident is undoubtedly a matter of concern. It underscores the inherent challenges within that environment and reinforces the urgency of our transition efforts. The violence directed towards our personnel is, of course, unacceptable, and President Karzai has acknowledged this. However, President Karzai is also eager to assume greater responsibility on the Afghan side. We're committed to identifying a mechanism that respects Afghan sovereignty while empowering them to take on an increasingly significant role in their own security. This aligns with both Afghan and our own interests. While I remain confident in our ability to execute this plan, it's important to acknowledge that the path forward will not be without its obstacles, much like our experience in Iraq.
label: Implicit

sentence: But Mr. President, could you elaborate on the specifics of your plan? [SEP] We'll address that at a later time.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, given the rising casualties and sectarian violence in Iraq, how long can your current policy be sustained without significant progress? And what is your confidence level in finding the missing soldiers? [SEP] We are doing everything possible to find the missing soldiers. General Petraeus and Secretary Gates are fully informed, and we are utilizing all available intelligence and troops. It is a top priority. The loss of life is devastating, but I sent more troops to stabilize the capital. We haven't even fully deployed them yet. General Petraeus presented a plan to Congress aimed at helping the Iraqi government secure its capital and reconcile. All troops will be in place by mid-June. The increased fighting is due to our troops entering new areas with the Iraqis. General Petraeus has requested until September to report back on progress. I want to see a different configuration in Iraq, but that requires securing the capital, which is why I followed General Petraeus's recommendations. I favor the Baker-Hamilton approach of embedding, training, guarding territorial integrity, and using Special Forces against Al Qaida. But we needed to increase troop levels to secure the capital, as I feared violence would spiral out of control. The timing of our actions will be decided by commanders on the ground, not politicians in Washington.
label: Deflection

sentence: By speaking so forcefully against the Iranian regime, aren't you playing into their narrative that the protests are orchestrated by the United States? [SEP] Look, my statements have been consistent: we deplore violence. The Iranian people are concerned with having their voices heard, not with Washington's political squabbles. They're focused on justice in Iran.
label: Deflection

sentence: Can you describe the perpetrator - male or female? And what type of weapon was used? [SEP] Regrettably, those details are currently unknown to me.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Canada's stimulus, the auto industry, border thickness and carbon market, what is your vision for US-Canada relations? [SEP] You're throwing a lot at me there. Can you specify which aspect you'd like me to address first?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, in retrospect, do you stand by Israel's actions in that situation? [SEP] David, I'm not prepared to comment on that specific question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, the COVID-19 mortality data suggests the United States has a disproportionately high death rate compared to other nations. How do you explain this apparent contradiction, considering the actions taken by your administration? [SEP] You know, a large part of those figures are attributed to New York, right? New York and New Jersey experienced severe outbreaks. If we remove them from the equation and examine a state like Florida, for example, our numbers are significantly lower. Not to criticize New York, but it's a densely populated area, very crowded. But even with New York included, I'll have to double-check the exact figures, but we're among the lowest. They've done a remarkable job. Next question, please.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, considering the lack of public discussion regarding Pakistan's role in resolving the conflict, did your discussions with President Zardari yield any progress on reopening supply lines? Furthermore, if the broader tensions with Pakistan remain unresolved, does this jeopardize the NATO coalition's progress in Afghanistan? [SEP] My discussion with President Zardari was brief, but I emphasized the importance of Pakistan's role, both publicly and privately. We share a common enemy in extremists, and we need to address the tensions that have arisen after a decade of military presence. President Zardari believes these issues can be resolved. We knew the supply line issue wouldn't be resolved at this summit, but we're making progress. Ultimately, both countries need to resolve these issues to ensure security, stability, and prosperity and prevent the harboring of extremists. There have been tensions, but they are being worked through. A successful, stable Pakistan is in our interest, and it's in Pakistan's interest to work with us.
label: Deflection

sentence: Regarding the convention, is Charlotte still in the running? [SEP] We're keeping our options open. An announcement is coming shortly.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, what is your administration's projected timeline for the widespread availability of a COVID-19 vaccine to the general public? [SEP] We're working very hard to get a vaccine out as quickly as possible. We're making tremendous progress. We're going to have something very soon, I think. We're pushing very hard. It could be very soon.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, Robert Novak recently claimed that you are the most isolated president he has seen in 50 years of covering Washington. How do you respond to critics like Novak who suggest you are more isolated than Richard Nixon during Watergate? [SEP] What's his definition of 'isolated,' exactly?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, you mentioned a timeline for U.N. action on Kosovo. Could you clarify what that deadline is? Are you concerned about the impact on U.S.-Russia relations? And what's your take on the Russian missile defense proposal? [SEP] Hold on, I don't think I actually said 'deadline.' I think I said 'time.' The real issue is whether we're going to have endless talks about something we've already decided. We think Kosovo should be independent. The G-8 talks were all about trying to get Russia on board. Ideally, Russia would just say, 'Okay, we get it.' But they're not there yet. That's why I said we need to see some movement, because I'm worried about people in Kosovo getting their hopes up. That's what I meant. We're going to push this forward. President Putin had an interesting idea about missile defense for Europe. I also had an idea, and it's all about protecting Europe, not threatening Russia. The real danger is from rogue countries that might have missiles. We need to be able to stop those missiles. President Putin suggested using radar in Azerbaijan together. I said we'd take a look. But he also had some doubts about my idea. So, I said, 'Let's get some people together from both sides to talk about our ideas, share technology, and figure out the best way to position the radar.' I thought his statement was important because he recognized that we could work together. Russia isn't our enemy. The Cold War is over. We're dealing with new threats now. I appreciated him saying we could work together. I thought it was a good sign, and I'm looking forward to talking about it more in July when he comes to Maine.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, intelligence reports suggest Qadhafi's regime is likely to endure. Do you concur with this assessment, and if not, was Director Clapper's public statement an error warranting disciplinary action? [SEP] Director Clapper offered a realistic evaluation of Qadhafi's military strength, a fact few dispute. However, let me reiterate unequivocally: my administration's policy, which I, as President, determine, is that Qadhafi must relinquish power. The Libyan people deserve freedom, and we will collaborate with the opposition and the international community to achieve his removal.
label: Dodging

sentence: So, based on your past actions regarding gay rights and contraception, is it reasonable to assume you'd consider attaching similar conditions to federal contracts? [SEP] I'm not going to discuss specifics at this time. Once we've fully assessed the situation and our legal options, I'll provide an update.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. You mean Helsinki? [SEP] But the fact is that I had a very, very good meeting—a very, very good meeting—with President Putin, and a lot was discussed about security, about Syria, about Ukraine, about the fact that President Obama allowed a very large part of Ukraine to be taken. And right now you have submarines off that particular parcel that we're talking about. You know what I'm talking about.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Are you—were you afraid of offending him on that subject? [SEP] No not at all. I don't really care about offending people. I sort of thought you'd know that. []
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, supposing you conclude a troop surge in Iraq is vital, would you go against your military commanders if they advised otherwise? [SEP] That's a hypothetical, plain and simple. I'm not going to speculate. I'll listen to Bob Gates, the military, the diplomats, and even the Iraqis. Then I'll decide about a surge. So, the answer is, I'm not going to answer.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, how do you plan to reconnect with voters who feel alienated by the Democratic Party's current image? [SEP] Well, the key is presence. We need to be in those communities, showing that Democratic policies are making a real difference. People need to feel heard, not dismissed as out-of-touch elites. That's how I became President. I didn't just rely on Chicago; I went downstate, met with farmers, talked to working people. We have the better argument, but it requires constant engagement. It's something I've done successfully in my own campaigns, but it's harder to transfer that to other candidates, especially in midterms. I wish I could have done more to build a lasting organization, but it's tough when you're also dealing with the White House. But I'm confident that talented progressives will lead the charge in the years to come.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the objectives discussed with Prime Minister Maliki, are there any time constraints for their fulfillment? You continuously mention the US priority as combating Al-Qaeda. Does this mean that managing sectarian violence falls exclusively under Iraqi jurisdiction, precluding US troop engagement? And Prime Minister Maliki, could you clarify the reason for the meeting's cancellation last night? [SEP] Sorry, could you repeat the first part of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: So, is his position secure? [SEP] He's doing a fantastic job, a really great job. We're constantly evaluating personnel, and we'll have a clearer picture soon, probably within the next week.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Biden, regarding the surge in migration and the fentanyl crisis, what specific actions are you taking, and how will Mexico assist in managing these challenges? [SEP] Well, we discussed migration extensively, and we're committed to protecting migrants. President López Obrador's plan to offer humanitarian visas has already shown promise in reducing migration flows. We must address the root causes of migration by investing in development in countries with inequality and poverty. Migration should be an option, not a necessity. Mexico is helping with shelters, healthcare, and food. We celebrate Mexico and Canada's approach to this issue. We're also addressing violence by investing in youth programs, creating jobs, and combating corruption. We've reached agreements to work together to ensure peace and security in all three countries.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, considering your remarks about North Korea, if direct talks are uncertain, would your administration consider escalating sanctions to pressure Pyongyang? [SEP] Sanctions are already in place, and they are substantial. I don't want to telegraph our next move. The people of North Korea are important, and I like Chairman Kim. We're focused on diplomacy, and I've had very good conversations with President Xi about this. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a plane to catch back to Washington.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You suggested that you didn't do anything wrong in the course of your conversations with the Ukrainian President. But can you explain to the American people why it is appropriate for an American President to ask a foreign leader for information about a political rival and what you would have said if you discovered that Barack Obama perhaps had asked a foreign leader for information about you before your campaign for the Presidency? [SEP] Yes. Well, that's what he did, isn't it, really? When you think about it.Look, that whole witch hunt was started, and hopefully, that'll all come out. But there's been some fantastic books written that just came out—whether you will look at Gregg Jarrett, or McCarthy's book that just came out recently, and so many other books. I mean, a lot of books are coming out. When you start reading those books, you see what they did to us. What they've done to this country is a disgrace. They've hurt this country very badly. And no other President should have to go through what I've gone through.The President—the new President of Ukraine is looking to stop corruption. There's a lot of corruption going on, and there was corruption. I just told you about Senators that threatened him with votes and no money coming into Ukraine if they do things. That's really what people are trying to say that I did, but the only difference is, I didn't do it. You take a look at that call; it was perfect. I didn't do it. There was no quid pro quo, but there was with Biden, and there was with these Senators. And they threatened. They said: You do this, you do that. We're not going to give you votes. That's—that's the real deal. So we have an honest group of people that have been maligned. And you know, it's—a lot of people say I'll do even better. I'm very happy. Yesterday, I guess, we had a 53 poll, and a lot of people say add 10 points to anything. Anybody voting for Trump, you can add—anytime you get a poll, you can add 10 points or 7 points or 6 points. Take it any way you want. But I don't know if I consider that to be a compliment, but in one way, it is a compliment.And I guess that's what happened in the last election: Far more people came to vote than anybody thought possible.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, do you agree with the National Intelligence Estimate that Iraq is in a civil war? You emphasize the need for victory, yet state it's not an open-ended commitment. How do you reconcile these seemingly contradictory positions? [SEP] Victory in Iraq won't resemble World War II. My challenge is explaining what success looks like. Iraq will be relatively peaceful. Not perfect, but with a functional government capable of stopping ethnic cleansing. There's criminality, too, and we must help Iraqis build a police force. Al Qaeda is present, responsible for some bombings. Zarqawi fueled sectarian violence. Disaffected Sunnis seek to regain power through violence. It's complex, regardless of what you call it. I had to act to stabilize the situation. Success means a constitutional government, a secure country, equitable resource distribution, federalism, inclusion of non-criminal former political actors, and an ally against terror—a bulwark of moderation.
label: Deflection

sentence: Reports indicate a growing number of troops on repeat deployments to Iraq, coupled with declining morale. An infantry commander has conveyed that troops are increasingly questioning the rationale for their presence. Does this development surprise you? Are you aware of this sentiment? Is it a minority viewpoint or a growing trend, and does it cause you concern? [SEP] The information I am receiving from commanding officers indicates that the primary area of concern lies with the families of our service members. While our troops, who have volunteered to serve, demonstrate a willingness to engage in multiple combat deployments, their families are experiencing significant challenges. I empathize with this situation, and that is why I consistently express my gratitude to them. Your inquiry is based on conversations with specific individuals, perhaps a single individual. My perspective is informed by discussions with commanding officers, whose responsibility it is to provide me with an accurate assessment of the situation on the ground. While I acknowledge the concerns of families back home, I have not received reports of widespread concerns regarding the morale of troops in Iraq.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, Iraq's WMD turned out not to be there, and now Iran halted its nuclear program in 2003. Are you concerned that the United States is losing credibility in the world and now may be seen as the boy who tried—who called wolf? [SEP] Actually, I am—I want to compliment the intelligence community for their good work. Right after the failure of intelligence in Iraq, we reformed the intel community so that there was a lot of serious considerations of NIEs in a way that would give us confidence. And here's a, I think, a very important product that is a result of the reforms we've put in place. As a matter of fact, the American people should have confidence that the reforms are working and that this work on the intel community is important work.People said, Well, why is it that you can't get exact knowledge quicker? Well, the answer is, is because we're dealing with a regime that is not very transparent, and frankly, we haven't had a very good presence in since 1979. And that's why I instructed the intel community to beef up its intelligence on . So we could have a better sense for what they're thinking and what they're doing. And this product is a result of intelligence reform and, more importantly, the good, hard work of our intelligence community.One of the reasons why this is out in the public arena is because I wanted—and our administration believed that, one, it was important for people to know the facts as we see them; secondly, that members of my administration had been very clear about the weapons program earlier this year. And therefore, it's important for the American people to see that there has been a reevaluation of the ian issue.David [David Gregory, NBC News].
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the future of the U.S.-Canada relationship, specifically concerning the auto sector, border security, and environmental regulations, could you elaborate on which aspect requires the most immediate attention and collaborative effort? [SEP] Whoa there, partner. That sounds like about five questions rolled into one. Slow down a bit, will ya?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Biden, you mentioned potentially engaging with President Putin soon. Can you elaborate on your intended approach? Also, considering the Ukrainian conflict appears to be at a crucial juncture, do you believe President Zelenskyy's condition for negotiations—the return of Crimea to Ukraine—is realistic? [SEP] Look, there's one rational way this war ends: Putin withdraws from Ukraine. Plain and simple. But that doesn't seem to be in the cards. He's paying a steep price for his failure, but he's inflicting unspeakable carnage on Ukrainian civilians, bombing nurseries, hospitals, children's homes. It's sickening. That being said, I have no immediate plans to contact Mr. Putin. Let me choose my words carefully: I'm prepared to speak with Mr. Putin if he shows a genuine interest in finding a way to end this war. He hasn't done that yet. If that happens, in consultation with our allies, I'll gladly sit down with him to see what he has in mind. But he hasn't taken that step. In the meantime, it's crucial that we support the Ukrainian people. The idea that Putin can defeat Ukraine is incomprehensible. Imagine trying to occupy that country for years to come. He's miscalculated at every turn. He thought he'd be welcomed by Russian speakers. Go back and read his speech when he invaded. He talked about being another Peter the Great, about Kyiv being the motherload of Russian identity. He's miscalculated across the board. So, the question is, how does he get himself out of this mess? I'm ready, if he's willing to talk, to find out what he's willing to do, but I'll only do it in close consultation with our NATO allies. I won't go it alone.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, in light of the Inter-Continental Hotel attack, what assurances can you provide regarding the Afghan forces' readiness to assume full security responsibilities? [SEP] Well, let's not get ahead of ourselves. The drawdown is only just beginning. We've always recognized the inherent dangers in Afghanistan, and isolated incidents are inevitable. The critical factor is the overall trajectory of Afghan capabilities. Kabul, with a significant portion of the population, is largely under Afghan control, and they've demonstrated considerable improvement. While such events may persist for a while, our work is ongoing. As I've said, we're shifting to a transition phase, mirroring our experience in Iraq. Despite the withdrawal of our troops, Iraq has sustained a democratic government and reduced violence. We believe a similar strategy is viable in Afghanistan. Even in Iraq, sporadic attacks still occur. These nations are grappling with the aftermath of extensive conflict. They won't be entirely secure, even with our presence. However, we can enhance the Afghan people's capacity to defend themselves.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the discussions with Canada, did you explore the potential for increased stimulus spending? Furthermore, looking ahead four years, what is your vision for the Canada-U.S. relationship, particularly concerning the auto industry, border security, and carbon markets? [SEP] That's quite a few topics you've raised. Which aspect of the Canada-U.S. relationship are you most interested in hearing about?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, you stated upon arrival that there was no Plan B and that the Iran deal was to be preserved. Now you're discussing a new deal with Iran. Why the change of heart? Did you adopt President Trump's hard-line stance? And do you believe the other signatories to the agreement will follow suit? [SEP] When I said 'no Plan B,' I was referring to the lack of a 'Planet B' in the context of climate change, not Iran. Regarding Iran, my position has been consistent. As I mentioned at the UN General Assembly in September, the JCPOA is a starting point, but we need to address three additional areas: the post-2025 sunset clauses, ballistic missile development, and regional influence. The future of the JCPOA is uncertain, and that decision rests with others. The JCPOA represents the first pillar of the framework I've outlined. I'm not suggesting a complete overhaul, but rather an expansion. While my criticisms of the JCPOA haven't been as strong as some, I believe we can build upon it. Regardless of the ultimate decision, I want to collaborate on a new agreement with four pillars, encompassing the existing JCPOA provisions related to current nuclear activities, long-term nuclear activities, ballistic missiles, and regional influence. This has been my consistent stance. In recent weeks, we've engaged in detailed discussions on this topic, including the regional situation. I believe we've reached a shared understanding of the situations in Syria, Yemen, and Iraq. We recognize that the nuclear issue is not isolated and that Iran's ballistic missile activities and regional presence are problematic. Our goal is to foster regional stability. By achieving this convergence, the idea of a new agreement that includes a solution for Syria becomes a significant step forward, thanks to our discussions. I hope to collaborate with all our partners. Our Foreign Ministers have already convened a small group and will continue to do so. The aim is for allied powers, including ourselves, and regional powers to work together within this group. We'll also engage in privileged discussions with Russia and Turkey on regional issues, including Syria. Moving forward, we'll use this approach to work towards a comprehensive agreement. I believe we can reconcile our shared views and differences, as we're not operating in a vacuum. I've always maintained that we shouldn't dismantle the JCPOA without a replacement. That would be counterproductive. Instead, we should aim for a broader agreement covering the four areas I mentioned. This approach allows us to address concerns and criticisms of the JCPOA, which, as I've noted, was supported by a previous US administration. We can work together while respecting the sovereignty of the region's states. It's not about interventionism, but about building a stable framework that promotes stability and peace. That's what we've agreed upon today: not tearing up an agreement and having nothing, but building something new that addresses all our concerns.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. In hindsight, could you have taken different actions? [SEP] On which particular matter are you referring to?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, your stance on Iran seems to have shifted from preserving the JCPOA to advocating for a new, broader agreement. Some critics argue that this represents a capitulation to hardliners who seek to dismantle the existing deal. How do you respond to those who accuse you of abandoning your previous commitment to the JCPOA? [SEP] Let me be absolutely clear: my commitment to preventing Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon remains unwavering. The JCPOA was a flawed agreement, but it did achieve some important objectives. However, it failed to address critical issues such as ballistic missile development and Iran's destabilizing activities in the region. We cannot simply ignore these threats. A new, comprehensive agreement is the only way to ensure that Iran is truly prevented from developing a nuclear weapon and that regional stability is maintained. This is not about abandoning the JCPOA; it's about building upon it to create a more effective and sustainable solution.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, your administration imposed sanctions and sent aid to Venezuela, but Maduro remains in power. Are you concerned about losing momentum, and what's the estimated timeline for a resolution? [SEP] No specific timeline. They've been in power for a while. Things will change eventually. We haven't even used the really tough sanctions yet. All options are on the table. We're just trying to help the people who are starving and dying in the streets. It's a disgrace. Venezuela was one of the wealthiest countries, and now it's poverty-stricken, no food, no water, no power. It's very sad.
label: Deflection

sentence: Secretary, numerous reports suggest internal discord regarding the administration's strategy. Can you address these claims and clarify the level of unity within your department? [SEP] Look, every administration has its share of robust debate. What matters is that we are all aligned on the President's core agenda and working tirelessly to execute it.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. So you're willing to negotiate? [SEP] Absolutely.Laura Meckler [Wall Street Journal].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, can you definitively state whether you will sign this particular piece of legislation into law? [SEP] Look, that particular proposal isn't quite there yet, but we're moving in the right direction, believe me. What's important is that we get money to the people who were unfairly harmed by something that could have been prevented. They could have stopped it at the source. They could have stopped it from coming here, to Europe, to the whole world – 188 countries, can you believe it? It's a disaster.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, following your meetings, you mentioned Greece. Do you believe the Europeans are too harsh on Greece? What steps are needed for a deal that avoids financial market harm? Also, French reporters claim you expressed concern about a strong dollar. Is this accurate, and are you worried about the dollar's strength? [SEP] First, ignore unnamed sources. I didn't say that. I avoid commenting on daily currency fluctuations. Regarding Greece, our G-7 partners, the IMF, and others recognize the urgency of a solution. Greece must commit to reforms, not just for creditors, but to foster economic growth. They need tough political choices for the long term. The international community must acknowledge the challenges Greeks face. With flexibility on both sides, we can resolve this. It requires tough decisions, and we'll continue consulting to encourage a positive outcome.
label: General

sentence: You've stated these commutations were for low-level drug offenses, yet many also included firearms charges. How does that fit with your overall philosophy on firearms? [SEP] Uh...
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. You don't see her as a threat? [SEP] As you—as you know, none whatsoever. No, not at all.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You just spoke of the need for banks to start lending, you talked earlier about how creative they can be in chasing profit, and yet earlier in the week, you said that banks don't have some inherent right to just, you know, get a certain amount of profit. You also said in that interview that you can stop them. How do you plan on stopping them from charging this $5 fee or whatever the fee is? And do you think that your Government has a right to dictate how much profits American companies make? [SEP] I absolutely do not think that. I was trying to make a broader point, which is that people have been using financial regulation as an excuse to charge consumers more. Right? I mean, basically the argument they've made is, well, you know what, this hidden fee was prohibited, and so we'll find another fee to make up for it. Now, they have that right, but it's not a good practice. It's not necessarily fair to consumers. And my main goal is to make sure that we've got a consumer watchdog in place who is letting consumers know what fair practices are, making sure that transactions are transparent, and making sure that banks have to compete for customers based on the quality of their service and good prices.Now, the frustrating thing that we have right now is that you've got folks over in Congress, Republicans, who have said that they see their role as eliminating any prohibitions on any practices for financial companies. And I think that's part of the frustration that the American people feel, because they've just gone through a period in which they were seeing a bunch of hidden fees, rate hikes that they didn't know about, fine print that they could not understand. That's true for credit cards. That's true for mortgages. It contributed to overall weakness in the economy.And yes, I think it is entirely appropriate for the Government to have some oversight role to make sure that consumers are protected. So banks--and any business in America--can price their products any way they want. That's how the free market works. As long as there's transparency and accountability and consumers understand what they're getting. And there are going to be instances where a policy judgment is made that, you know what, there are certain practices that just aren't fair. And that's how the market has always operated.
label: Explicit

sentence: President Bush, acknowledging the protectionist barriers in your administration, how flexible will you be in advancing a trade agreement with Uruguay, and what progress has been made today? President Vazquez, did you request President Bush's intervention in the dispute between Uruguay and Argentina regarding the mill plants? [SEP] We discussed Uruguay's concerns about market access. The President mentioned quotas on items like cows and sheep, and I said I'd consider his requests. You might think I'm joking about blueberries, but Uruguay produces fantastic ones. The question is, can their blueberry growers sell to the U.S.? We discussed various produce. I told the President, 'You can't solve problems unless you put them on the table. We'll help where we can, and explain why we can't where we can't.' I'm concerned about protectionism, not just in our country but globally. Free and fair trade helps address poverty. I support completing the Doha round of the WTO. I told President Lula about our strategies. The U.S. is ready to reduce agricultural subsidies, but we need market access. Our trade minister is in Sao Paulo talking to her Brazilian counterpart, aiming for progress on this complex deal. As for your first question, I agree with President Bush. We've created a space for experts and ministers to discuss bilateral issues. Uruguay defends free trade and lower tariffs and subsidies. We've also discussed the GSP. As for the second question, I didn't discuss the Argentina issue with President Bush because we'll be dialoguing with Argentina soon, thanks to the King of Spain. We'll try to find a friendly solution to our differences.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, you pledged to cancel $10,000 in student loans. Is that still on the table, and if so, when can people expect it? And now that the Bull Connor situation is behind us, are you planning to engage with Republicans like Senator Romney on reforming the Electoral Count Act? [SEP] Well, let me say this, I'm always open to dialogue. I've spoken with Mitt on previous occasions. And, incidentally, I also reached out to the minority leader when he delivered his address. Therefore, I have no reservations about reaching out to any Republican, anyone at all, and I've made that abundantly clear. Now, I've had the opportunity to travel recently due to funerals and memorial services, and I've been accompanied by members of Congress. I don't have the precise figure, but I'd estimate that somewhere between 20 and 25 Senators and Representatives have traveled with me. I encourage you to inquire with them about the nature of our conversations during those flights, which often lasted several hours. We engaged in discussions, posed questions, and I gained valuable insights. However, as President, I don't have the opportunity to engage in such interactions as frequently as I would prefer. One thing that has become clear to me, based on polling data, is that the public does not want me to function as a Senator-President. They expect me to fulfill my role as President and allow Senators to perform their duties. So, if I've made errors, and I'm certain I have, it's because I'm accustomed to negotiating to achieve results, a skill at which I've been relatively successful in the Senate, even as Vice President. However, I believe the role of President is distinct. Now, it's almost 6 o'clock. With all due respect, I'll see you at the next press conference. Thank you.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Venezuela, despite the imposition of stringent sanctions and the provision of aid, Maduro's departure seems no closer. Are you concerned about a potential loss of momentum, and what is the projected timeline for resolution? [SEP] Well, Roberta, there's no specific timeline being given to me. This situation with Maduro and his predecessor has been ongoing for quite some time. I anticipate changes eventually, but we haven't fully implemented the most severe sanctions yet. We have the option to escalate, and all possibilities remain on the table. However, our current sanctions are moderate. We can intensify them if necessary. The situation is truly disheartening, and our primary focus is aiding the starving and dying population. It's a disgrace, considering Venezuela's former wealth. Now, it's plagued by grief, poverty, food shortages, water scarcity, lack of air conditioning, and frequent power outages. The infrastructure is fragile and on the verge of collapse. It's a tragic situation, Roberta, a real tragedy. Okay?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, VP Biden referenced a discussion about a 30% failure rate despite best efforts. Could you clarify the subject matter, and whether it involved the stimulus or bank bailout? [SEP] Look, Joe and I talk about a lot of things. I can't recall the exact conversation he's referring to. But the important thing is that we're working together to address the challenges facing this country. We're throwing everything we've got at this problem, and we're confident that we'll get through it.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Isn't—first to President Bush—isn't scaling back demands about what the— North Korea has to declare giving in to a country that has repeatedly demonstrated that it can't be trusted? Former U.N. Ambassador Bolton has called it a complete collapse in the deal, and your critics are saying that you're selling out to get an agreement. Why is it not? [SEP] Look, we're going to make a judgment as to whether has met its obligations to account for its nuclear program and activities, as well as meet its obligations to disable its reactor. In other words, we'll see. The burden of proof is there. We've laid out— they've made some promises, and we'll make a judgment as to whether they met those promises. And then we and our partners will take a look at 's full declaration to determine whether or not the activities they promised they could do could be verified. And then we'll make a judgment of our own as to whether or not—you know, we'll—about our own obligations.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, with the war drawing to a close, can you honestly say the immense human and financial cost was justified, considering Afghanistan's current state falls short of the initial visions of reconstruction and democracy? Also, President Karzai, numerous independent reports cite corruption and poor governance in Afghanistan. Do you stand by your claim that foreign influence is largely to blame, and will you definitively step down after next year's elections? [SEP] Let's not forget why we went to Afghanistan in the first place. A terrorist organization, operating freely under the then-Afghan government, brutally murdered 3,000 Americans. It was our duty to dismantle that organization and prevent future attacks. Our brave service members, along with Afghan allies, largely achieved that primary objective. We aimed to cripple Al Qaeda, and we've come damn close. Everything we've done in the last decade has been geared towards that goal. When this conflict ends, we'll be able to say that the sacrifices made by our troops secured that objective. Now, we also understood early on that a stable, sovereign Afghanistan, a responsible international partner, was in our national interest. That required Afghanistan to build its own security capacity and strive for peace and prosperity. Afghanistan still has work to do, but the possibility of a peaceful and prosperous future is greater now than before we intervened. Did we achieve every pie-in-the-sky dream? Probably not. But did we achieve our core objective and forge a strong relationship with an Afghan government willing to prevent future attacks against the U.S.? Absolutely. We're on our way. And for that, we owe a debt of gratitude to our military, intelligence, and diplomatic teams, as well as the Afghan government and people. As for the corruption question, yes, there is corruption in Afghanistan, including within the Afghan government. We are fighting it. Have we succeeded entirely? No. Regarding foreign-sourced corruption, I've been clear: less corruption will only happen with cooperation between us and our international partners on correcting some of the methods or applications of delivery of assistance to Afghanistan, without cooperation and without recognition of the problems. On elections, my greatest achievement will be a proper, well-organized, interference-free election where the Afghan people can elect their next President. And I will be a retired President, happily so. One last question.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Considering the Inter-Continental Hotel attack, are you confident in the Afghan forces' ability to handle security? [SEP] Let's not forget the drawdown is still ahead. We knew it was a risky area, the Taliban is still around, and these events are going to happen from time to time. The real question is, is Afghan capacity getting better? Kabul, which has a big chunk of the Afghan population, has been policed by Afghan forces for a while now, and they've done a decent job. Kabul is safer and the forces are more capable. That doesn't mean attacks won't happen; they probably will for some time. We're not done yet. But as I said, the war is winding down. We've shifted to a transition, like in Iraq, where we drew down troops, and Iraq kept a democratic government and reduced violence. We think a similar approach makes sense. Even in Iraq, attacks still happen. These countries are digging out of war and conflict; they're dangerous places. They won't be perfectly safe even if we were there. But we can help the Afghan people defend themselves.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Can I ask just one follow-up? [SEP] Maybe. []
label: General

sentence: Q. So none of this is holding out hope that they'll change their behavior? [SEP] No.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, I was talking with a journalist about an hour ago in Baghdad who says, to be a cynic in Iraq is to be naive at this point; that there is discernible progress, undeniable progress on the battlefield, but there is just as discernable and undeniable lack of progress on political reconciliation. Given the premise of the surge is to give the Iraqi Government breathing space to get its business done, given that they're not getting their business done, are the American people entitled to hear from you more than, I've told Prime Minister Maliki he's got to do better? [SEP] As you know, General Petraeus and Ambassador Crocker will be coming back to report on the findings of the success of the surge. The surge success will not only include military successes and military failures but also political successes and political failures. And my own perspective is, is that they have made some progress but not enough. I fully recognize this is a difficult assignment. One of the things that—it's difficult because of years of tyrannical rule that have created a lot of suspicions. And there's a lot of—these folks need to trust each other more.Secondly, from my perspective, we're watching leaders learn how to be leaders. This is a new process for people to be democratic leaders. Now, no question, they haven't passed some of the law we expected them to pass up to now. That's where a lot of people will focus their attention. On the other hand, there is a Presidency Council, with people from different political parties, trying to work through some of these difficult issues, trying to work through the distrust that has caused them not to be able to pass some of the law we expect.And the July 15th report that I submitted to Congress, there were indications that they had met about half the benchmarks and some of the political benchmarks they were falling short. One of the things I found interesting is that the assembly, their elected parliament, has passed about 60 pieces of legislation this year, some of which are directly relevant to reconciliations, like judicial reform, some of which were unwinding Saddam's laws in the past.One of the questions I recently asked about, is there a functioning government? Is there—a lot of Americans look at it and say, There's nothing happening there. There's, like, no government at all, I expect they're saying. So I asked about the budgeting process. In other words, is there a centralized budgeting system that takes the oil revenues? As I understand, about 97 percent of the Iraqi revenues to date come from oil. And do they have a rational way of spending that money for the good of society? Now, most of the money, it turns out, is going into their military operations, operating expenses, and capital expenses.But one of the things I found interesting in my questions was there is revenue sharing. In other words, a central Government revenue sharing to Provincial governments. It surprised me, frankly, because the impression you get from people who are reporting out of Iraq is that it's, like, totally dysfunctional. That's what your—I guess your kind of—your friend or whoever you talked to is implying.In 2006, the central Government allocated $2.3 billion to the Provinces. You know, I'm not exactly sure how the funding formula worked, but a quick analysis: There is no question that Shi'a and Sunni Provinces and Kurdish Provinces were receiving money. Of the 2.3 billion, 1.9 had been obligated or spent. Now, some of that money is being better spent now because of bottom-up reconciliation that's taken place in places like Anbar, particularly with the help of our Provincial Reconstruction Teams. The PRTs are helping. That's not to say what—my point to you there is that there needs still to be work in making sure that the Provincial governments are functioning well, to earn the trust of the people. It's not just the central Government that we're working with; we're also working with Provincial governments to make sure that people have—are inspired to believe that the state is in their interest.The point I'm making to you on this, Jim [Jim Axelrod, CBS News], is that there is a lot of work left to be done; don't get me wrong. If one were to look hard, they could find indications that—more than indications, facts that show the Government is learning how to function. People say we need an oil revenue sharing law. I agree with that; that needs to be codified. However, there is oil revenue sharing taking place, is my point. There's a lot of work to be done, and the fundamental question facing America is, is it worth it? Does it matter whether or not we stay long enough for a ally in this war against radicals and extremists to emerge? And my answer is, it does matter. Long-term consequences will face our country if we leave before the job is done. How the troops are configured, what the deployment looks like will depend upon the recommendations of David Petraeus.David [David Gregory, NBC News].
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, given the headwinds you're facing back home – the AG controversy, the immigration stalemate, the dismal polls – do you honestly believe you still possess the political leverage to get anything done? [SEP] Well, first off, Europe was great. We pushed our freedom agenda and talked shop with our allies. Immigration's a bear, no doubt. Some in my party, some in the Dems, they're just not on board. I was bummed when the bill hit a snag. Frankly, it's weird they're focusing on my AG when it won't change a thing. But I think we can get immigration done. It'll take Dems stepping up, and me working with the Republicans who want a deal. I even called some Senators to figure out how to get back on track, even working with Kennedy.
