We gotta deal with this now. We made progress, hard choices, but it's always two steps forward, one step back. I'm gonna keep pushing for that bill signing.
label: Implicit

sentence: Can you guarantee that this bill will pass within your first year, Mr. President? [SEP] We're pushing forward, full speed ahead on all fronts. Some say I'm doing too much, too fast. I'm committed to moving this process along as quickly as possible during this first year. But, ultimately, the legislative calendar isn't something I control directly. We'll be working closely with legislative leaders to see what's achievable. Andre Showell [Black Entertainment Television]. There you go.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, is there a time limit on meeting any of these goals for Prime Minister Maliki? And you keep mentioning that the U.S. goal is to fight Al Qaida. Does that mean you believe it's up to the Iraqis to stop the sectarian violence and quell the sectarian violence, and this is something you don't want U.S. troops involved in?And, Prime Minister Maliki, can you tell us why you canceled the meeting last night? [SEP] What was the first part of your three-part question? []
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. You're right; I don't.This week, sir, we learned that Scooter Libby's defense team plans to call Vice President Cheney to testify in the ongoing CIA leak case. I wonder, sir, what is your reaction to that? Is that something you'll resist? [SEP] I read it in the newspaper today, and it's an interesting piece of news. And that's all I'm going to comment about an ongoing case. I thought it was interesting.Ann [Ann Compton, ABC News].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, the Pakistani people seem to have rejected President Musharraf's party. Does this signal the end of his influence, and do you still consider him a reliable partner in combating terrorism? [SEP] Let's be clear. Does America believe helping Africa is in our interest? Absolutely. And yes, we can manage both. The elections in Pakistan were a victory for its people – fair elections where their voices were heard. That's a win for the war on terror because those ideologues we're fighting despise free societies. Musharraf kept his word, holding elections and ending emergency law. Now, it's up to the new government to be friends with the U.S. We see Pakistan as a key ally with shared interests, like stopping radicals and preventing attacks on both our nations. As for American and African interests aligning, of course. The U.S. is a melting pot, and African Americans are a significant part of our nation. They should support helping Africa. We're in a global village now. Problems spread easily. If the U.S. isolates itself, it's ignoring reality. Migration is unstoppable. If we don't help Africa's youth, they'll seek opportunities elsewhere, potentially bringing challenges to our shores. Supporting Africa is enlightened self-interest. Terrorism knows no borders, as 9/11 showed. We have common ground. The U.S., as a leading nation, should care about others' struggles.
label: Deflection

sentence: Sir, with respect, can you offer any concrete benchmarks or milestones that would signal progress toward denuclearization, beyond just 'starting the process'? [SEP] We're talking about a total transformation, a complete dismantling. The details are, frankly, confidential at this point, but we're making tremendous progress. It's going to be beautiful. You'll see. It's going to be amazing.
label: General

sentence: Shifting gears, what's the status with John Brennan? And can you provide an update on the Africa Summit and the Ebola outbreak? Mr. President, I believed we were scheduled to discuss your birthday festivities. [SEP] Wait a minute, what about the 'Happy Birthday'?
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Can I also ask you about FISA abuse, President Trump? [SEP] Go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, your predecessor spoke with the President of Taiwan, hinting at using the One China policy as a bargaining chip. Considering China's reaction, including seizing a drone, shouldn't we be more cautious? Do you think this warrants a complete overhaul of our China strategy, and what's your take on these direct calls with Taiwan? [SEP] Look, it's a valid question. I'm in the middle on this one. I think we should always be looking at our foreign policy with fresh eyes. I'm proud of what I've done, but you get stuck in a bubble after eight years. New perspectives are good for democracy. A new President should examine everything. I did that when I came in. The US-China relationship is hugely important. It affects the world economy, our national security, our presence in Asia. If that relationship goes south, everyone suffers. So, taking a look is fine. I told the President-elect to be systematic about foreign policy. Get your team in place, get them briefed, and then make decisions. That way, everyone's on the same page. As for Taiwan, there's a long-standing agreement to keep things as they are. Taiwan's different from mainland China, but China sees it as part of China. The Taiwanese get some autonomy. This keeps the peace. But for China, Taiwan is a big deal. It's central to their identity. So, if you're going to mess with that, you better know what you're doing. The Chinese won't take it lightly.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Huawei and its placement on the entity list: is there any chance of its removal? What are the key considerations guiding your administration's decision? [SEP] I'm not going to get into the weeds on that right now. Huawei is a very important issue, and we're dealing with it very carefully. We're weighing all the factors, and we'll make a decision when we're ready. I don't want to say anything that could compromise our position.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, following up on Russian interference, if I may, what specific assurances can you give the American people that your administration will be more effective in deterring future attacks, beyond simply stating that consequences exist? [SEP] Let me be clear: Putin knows where we stand. We've already demonstrated our willingness to respond decisively. The real question is, what price is he willing to pay for these actions? The world is watching, and his standing diminishes with each transgression. It's about more than just our response; it's about the collective condemnation of nations that respect international law.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. Duda, if you don't mind me asking, how do you see Russia? Are they on our side, or are they the bad guys? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, if chemical weapons are deployed in Ukraine, would that automatically trigger a military response from NATO? [SEP] We're considering all options.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Yes, sir. Mr. President, can you explain the anger and even outrage many Democrats felt when the tax cut bill extended tax cuts not just for the middle class, but also for the wealthy? And is that a divide that you may be contributing to when you and the Vice President talk about morally inappropriate tax cuts for the wealthy? [SEP] Look, the frustration that people felt about that was frustration I share. I've said that before, and I'll probably say it again. I don't think that over the long run we can afford a series of tax breaks for people who are doing very well and don't need it; were doing well when Bill Clinton was in office. They were still rich then, and they will still be rich if those tax cuts went away.And so this is going to be a debate that we're going to be having over the next couple of years. Because I guarantee you, as soon as the new Congress is sworn in, we're going to have to have a conversation about how do we start balancing our budget, or at least getting to a point that's sustainable when it comes to our deficit and our debt.And that's going to require us cutting programs that don't work, but it also requires us to be honest about paying for the things that we think are important. If we think it's important to make sure that our veterans are getting care that they need when they come back home from fighting in Afghanistan or Iraq, we can't just salute and wish them well and have a Veterans Day parade. We got to make sure that there are doctors and nurses and facilities for posttraumatic stress disorder, and that costs money.If we say that education is going to be the single most important determinant for our children's success and this country's success in the 21st century, we can't have schools that are laying off so many teachers that they start going to 4 days a week, as they've done in Hawaii, for example.We've got to make sure that young people can afford to go to college. If we want to keep our competitive edge in innovation, well, we've got to invest in basic research; the same basic research that resulted in the Internet, the same basic research that invited--that resulted in GPS. All those things originated in research funded by the Government.So we are going to have to compare the option of maintaining the tax cuts for the wealthy permanently versus spending on these things that we think are important. And that's a debate that I welcome. But I completely understand why not just Democrats but some Republicans might think that that part of the tax package we could have done without.Having said that, I want to repeat: Compromise, by definition, means taking some things you don't like. And the overall package was the right one to ensure that this economy has the best possible chance to grow and create jobs. And there is no better antipoverty program than an economy that's growing. There is no better deficit-reduction program than an economy that is growing. And if the economy started contracting, as it might have had we not gotten this tax agreement, then the choices that we would have to make would be even tougher.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. On the Kodak deal, sir, the SEC is investigating. Do you have any concerns about how it was handled? [SEP] I wasn't involved in the details, so I couldn't tell you. The concept is solid, but we'll take a look. We'll run a quick study and see what we find.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Is there another way that you should have known? Do you think in hindsight—[inaudible]? [SEP] Well, I mean, Chuck, what I'll say is, is that if—it is also possible that had we been told, then you'd be sitting here asking a question about why were you interfering in a criminal investigation. So I think it's best right now for us to just see how this whole process unfolded.With respect to the tax rates, I just want to emphasize I am open to new ideas. If the Republican counterparts or some Democrats have a great idea for us to raise revenue, maintain progressivity, make sure the middle class isn't getting hit, reduces our deficit, encourages growth, I'm not going to just slam the door in their face. I want to hear ideas from everybody.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. And does it have to have a sunset clause in it? [SEP] It will have a sunset. You have the two sunsets. I mean, you have an ISDS provision and a sunset provision. They've been very heavily negotiated. You have two sunsets, two concepts of sunset. We're pretty close on the sunset division. Okay?
label: General

sentence: You've warned of catastrophic consequences. Could you be more specific? [SEP] I trust they grasp the potential for catastrophe. However, Iraq is a sovereign nation, and we are there at their invitation. We hope the Iraqi government understands that without coalition forces, especially U.S. troops, their survival would be at risk. We work closely with them to ensure they recognize this and wouldn't make such a request. But if they did, we would leave.
label: Implicit

sentence: Does that concern you? [SEP] I think I've said all I need to say on that topic. Mary Bruce, ABC News, you're up.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, reflecting on the strides made in LGBT rights during your tenure – hate crimes protection, the repeal of 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell,' nationwide marriage equality, and greater acceptance of transgender individuals – how significant do you consider LGBT rights to be in your overall legacy? And how optimistic are you that this progress will continue or at least be maintained under the next administration? [SEP] I couldn't be prouder of the transformation our society has undergone in the past decade. While I believe we played a helpful role, the real heroes are the activists, the sons and daughters, and the couples who courageously said, 'This is who I am, and I'm proud.' Their bravery opened hearts and minds, and eventually, the laws caught up. But none of this would have been possible without their activism, whether loud and visible or quiet and personal. Our administration's role was to help society move forward in a way that minimized backlash and respected the fact that these issues were often controversial. Take, for example, our approach to 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell.' By being methodical, working with the Joint Chiefs, and demonstrating that it wouldn't impact the effectiveness of our military, we were able to achieve meaningful change. I am proud of the work of Secretary Gates, Chairman Mullen, and the Joint Chiefs who were open to evidence and ultimately did the right thing. But again, this wouldn't have happened without the incredible transformation happening in society. When I awarded Ellen the Presidential Medal of Freedom, I meant every word. Her kindness and likability, projected into living rooms across the country, changed attitudes. That wasn't easy for her, and it's just one example of what was happening in communities nationwide. I'm proud that we were able to provide some support to help the movement advance. I believe this progress is irreversible because American society has changed, especially the attitudes of young people. While there will still be important battles to fight, particularly regarding legal issues and transgender rights, the younger generation, even those who identify as Republican or conservative, often struggle to understand discrimination based on sexual orientation. It's deeply ingrained in them.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, what assurances do we have that North Korea will actually denuclearize this time, and not simply pay lip service to the idea? [SEP] Can anyone guarantee anything? Can I guarantee the sun will rise tomorrow? No. But I have a feeling. I'm a dealmaker, and I know when someone wants to make a deal. They want to make a deal. Believe me.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. With the flu outbreak spreading and worsening, can you talk about whether you think it's time to close the border with Mexico, and whether--under what conditions you might consider quarantining, when that might be appropriate? [SEP] Well, first of all, as I said, this is a cause for deep concern but not panic. And I think that we have to make sure that we recognize that how we respond--intelligently, systematically, based on science and what public health officials have to say--will determine in large part what happens.I've consulted with our public health officials extensively on a day-to-day basis, in some cases, an hour-to-hour basis. At this point, they have not recommended a border closing. From their perspective it would be akin to closing the barn door after the horses are out, because we already have cases here in the United States. We have ramped up screening efforts as well as made sure that additional supplies are there on the border so that we can prepare in the eventuality that we have to do more than we're doing currently.But the most important thing right now that public health officials have indicated is that we treat this the same way that we would treat other flu outbreaks, just understanding that because this is a new strain we don't yet know how it will respond. So we have to take additional precautions, essentially, take out some additional insurance. Now, that's why I asked for an additional $1.5 billion, so that we can make sure that everything is in place should a worst-case scenario play out.I do want to compliment Democrats and Republicans who worked diligently back in 2005 when the bird flu came up. I was part of a group of legislators who worked with the Bush administration to make sure that we had beefed up our infrastructure and our stockpiles of antiviral drugs like Tamiflu. And I think the Bush administration did a good job of creating the infrastructure so that we can respond. For example, we've got 50 million courses of antiviral drugs in the event that they're needed.So the Government is going to be doing everything that we can. We're coordinating closely with State and local officials. Secretary Napolitano at Department of Homeland Security, newly installed Secretary Sebelius of Health and Human Services, our Acting CDC Director, they are all on the phone on a daily basis with all public health officials across the States to coordinate and make sure that there's timely reporting, that if as new cases come up that we are able to track them effectively, that we're allocating resources so that they're in place.The key now, I think, is to make sure that we are maintaining great vigilance, that everybody responds appropriately when cases do come up, and individual families start taking very sensible precautions that can make a huge difference. So wash your hands when you shake hands. Cover your mouth when you cough. I know it sounds trivial, but it makes a huge difference. If you are sick, stay home. If your child is sick, keep them out of school. If you are feeling certain flu symptoms, don't get on an airplane. Don't get on any system of public transportation where you're confined and you could potentially spread the virus.So those are the steps that I think we need to take right now. But understand that because this is a new strain, we have to be cautious. If this was a strain that we were familiar with, then we might have to--then I think we wouldn't see the kind of alert levels that we're seeing, for example, with the World Health Organization. Okay?Deb Price of Detroit News. Where's Deb? Good to see you.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, turning to Germany's energy security, could you elaborate on the specific measures being undertaken to diminish their dependence on Russian energy sources? And how do you address the concerns of those who suggest that Germany's reliance on Russian gas is restricting Europe's response options regarding the crisis in Ukraine? [SEP] Look, we're exploring every possible avenue to make up for any potential gas shortages stemming from Russia, especially through LNG. We're actively consulting with our friends around the world to figure out how we can collectively address this matter. We believe we can compensate for a significant portion of any losses. However, let's not lose sight of the fact that Russia also needs to sell that gas and oil. It's a major source of their revenue. If that revenue stream is cut off, they'll be significantly impacted as well. This isn't just a one-way street. We're working tirelessly to help Europe mitigate any immediate gas supply disruptions if they happen. We're coordinating closely with our European partners, including Germany, to ensure a unified approach. We are ready for all kinds of situation. And that's part of what we do when we say we prepare sanctions. That means we need to be able to react at any time, and this is happening. With regard to the use of LNG, I can say that the biggest volume of LNG used across the world is the gas, and that is part of the debate.
label: General

sentence: Q. So, about those five Republican Senators, can you name them for the record? [SEP] Look, with all due respect, that's just not something I'm comfortable disclosing. My commitment to confidentiality outweighs any perceived public interest here. It's a matter of principle.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your administration's handling of the debt ceiling crisis has been irresponsible and has damaged America's credibility. How do you respond to these criticisms, and what specific lessons have you learned from this experience? [SEP] That's, by the way, what I said in the meeting 2 days ago. I was very blunt. I said the American people do not want to see a bunch of posturing; they don't want to hear a bunch of sound bites. What they want is for us to solve problems, and we all have to remember that. That's why we were sent here.
label: General

sentence: Sir, intelligence reports suggest both Russia and China are attempting to influence the election. Russia is supposedly trying to hurt Biden, and China is considering moves against you. What's your take on this, and what's your plan to counter it? [SEP] Honestly, it's all a big hoax. They say Russia wants to hurt Biden and China wants to hurt me. But I'm the only one who can fix this mess. We'll see what happens.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Do you have a response to the Governor of Missouri testing positive for coronavirus? [SEP] I didn't know that. No.Yes, John [John Roberts, Fox News], please.
label: Explicit

sentence: Given General Pace's statements, Mr. President, do you believe homosexuality is immoral? [SEP] I'm not in the business of judging people's personal lives. 'Don't ask, don't tell' remains the appropriate policy, in my view.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, can you update us on your overall legislative goals and the challenges you face? [SEP] Schumer and the Democrats are stonewalling every single nomination. It's blatant obstruction. They're not effective politicians, but they're experts at obstruction. Bush, Obama, Clinton—they all had significantly more approvals. Mitch will start pushing these through, especially the judicial nominations.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your $447 billion jobs bill, after two months and countless speeches, the results seem minimal, mainly the veterans jobs bill and some executive actions. Are you resigned to entering the 2012 election with no further jobs legislation, a 9% unemployment rate, and questions about your leadership? [SEP] Well, I reckon folks are more worried 'bout Congress not passin' the jobs bill, even though most Americans, even some Republicans, think it's a good idea. That's why folks ain't too happy with Congress right now. Usually, if most people don't like what you're doin', you change things up. But Congress ain't doin' that, especially the Republicans. They don't seem to think it's urgent to get folks back to work. I'm gonna keep pushin'. I figure we'll get some of it done now, and I'll keep at it 'til we get it all done. Might take 'til November, or maybe a whole new Congress. But the parts of the bill, like cuttin' taxes for middle-class families, cuttin' taxes for small businesses that hire veterans or folks who've been out of work a long time, gettin' teachers back in classrooms, are important. Like in Hawaii, kids are only goin' to school four days a week 'cause of money problems. How we gonna compete in the 21st century when our kids are barely in school? The jobs bill would help with those budget problems. And fixin' up our infrastructure. Every leader I talk to says we gotta have good infrastructure. When you go to Asia, they got better airports and ports than us. That's gonna hurt our business, our trade, our ability to sell American stuff made by American workers to the fastest-growin' market in the world. Plus, we could put a lot of folks back to work doin' it. So, I'm gonna keep on pushin'. I think we'll just keep chippin' away at it. If you're askin' if I think the Republicans in Congress are gonna suddenly say I was right and pass my whole bill, no, I don't think that's gonna happen. But I hope they realize they can't just do nothin'. They should hope that too, 'cause if they don't, we'll have some new faces in Congress.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Kuwaiti Ambassador's concerns about Iran's JCPOA breaches, specifically as it relates to the U.N. sanctions, can you detail the substance of your discussions with the Kuwaiti delegation today on this matter? [SEP] Look, the Kuwaitis are thrilled with the progress we're making in the Middle East. They see the historic deals we've brokered, and they want in. It's a beautiful thing to watch. We touched on Iran, of course, but frankly, it's just one piece of a much larger, more positive picture. We're pulling troops out, securing our interests, and bringing peace to the region. The previous administration made a disastrous deal with Iran, but we are fixing that. The Middle East is straightening out, and everyone is tired of fighting. They want to be part of the deal, and they want security.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. So, you're refusing to comment on whether they are being investigated? [SEP] I'm not going to comment on that matter right now.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Lee, following up on North Korea's potential missile launch, what specific actions will South Korea take, and what sanctions are you considering? Can you also update us on the US-Korea missile range extension talks? [SEP] Regarding North Korea, let me reiterate our firm stance: any launch would be a clear violation of UN resolutions. We are working with the international community to urge them to reconsider. As for our response, North Korea must understand they will face the consequences of their actions. They will deepen their isolation. The people of North Korea will see the cost of this launch, and it will not bring them pride. Regarding the missile range, we are in constant communication with the US, but the focus is on deterring North Korean aggression.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Back to Iran, sir. ABC has been reporting that Iran will be capable of building a nuclear bomb within 2 years. Have you seen evidence that Iran is accelerating its nuclear program? [SEP] I haven't seen the report that you just referred to. I do share concerns about ian intention to have a nuclear weapon. I firmly believe that if were to have a nuclear weapon, it would be a seriously destabilizing influence in the Middle East. And therefore, we have worked to build a international coalition to try to convince the ians to give up their weapon, to make it clear that they have choices to make—whether the choice be isolation or missed opportunity to grow their economies. And so we take your— we take seriously the attempts of the ians to gain a nuclear weapon.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Would you consider a political settlement that involves him as a successful outcome from the American perspective? [SEP] The only acceptable outcome is him stepping down. He needs to relinquish power and cease directing military actions against his own people. He must go.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Sir, given the potential for escalation, can you at least confirm or deny U.S. awareness of the Israeli bombing raid in Syria? [SEP] I'm not at liberty to discuss that matter at this time. Another question?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Mr. Marino and Senator McConnell, do you still endorse them fully despite recent events and criticisms? [SEP] Mitch? We're talking about, what, half a year on healthcare? Others failed for years. He'll deliver, bigly. Tom? Great Pennsylvanian, early supporter. We saw the reports, taking it very seriously. We're going to have a major announcement next week on the drug crisis. It's a massive problem. We're going to look into Tom.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, given the planned troop withdrawals from Afghanistan, how can you assure the Afghan people of a lasting strategic partnership beyond 2017? [SEP] The core of our strategy rests on a robust, long-term commitment to Afghanistan. We envision a future where our cooperation is not just enduring, but transformative. The United States now views Afghanistan as a steadfast and dependable ally. Our financial pledges are substantial, including the significant $4.1 billion earmarked for Afghan security forces by 2017. Furthermore, we've established a new framework for economic collaboration, with $800 million allocated through the Afghan budget. Crucially, the flexibility we've demonstrated in security matters underscores our unwavering support and assures both the Afghan security forces and the region that our partnership is not a fleeting one. Our strategic alliance is rooted in a simple principle: empowering the Afghan people, through their own security forces, to safeguard their nation. We are committed to being a strong partner in building and maintaining effective Afghan security forces.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, looking back at your time in office, do you regret any of the alleged falsehoods you may have told the American people? [SEP] Come again? What was that about?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the leaking of classified information, shouldn't there be consequences for such actions, regardless of the legal outcome? [SEP] The Libby case is done. We are moving on.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. Are you concerned, Mr. President, that commuting Chelsea Manning's sentence will send a message that leaking classified material will not generate a tough sentence to groups like WikiLeaks? How do you reconcile that in light of WikiLeaks' connection to Russia's hacking in last year's election? And related to that, Julian Assange has now offered to come to the United States. Are you seeking that? And would he be charged or arrested if he came here? [SEP] Well, first of all, let's be clear: Chelsea Manning has served a tough prison sentence. So the notion that the average person who was thinking about disclosing vital, classified information would think that it goes unpunished I don't think would get that impression from the sentence that Chelsea Manning has served.It has been my view that given she went to trial, that due process was carried out, that she took responsibility for her crime, that the sentence that she received was very disproportional—disproportionate relative to what other leakers had received, and that she had served a significant amount of time, that it made it sense to commute and not pardon her sentence.And I feel very comfortable that justice has been served and that a message has still been sent that when it comes to our national security, that wherever possible, we need folks who may have legitimate concerns about the actions of Government or their superiors or the agencies in which they work, that they try to work through the established channels and avail themselves of the whistleblower protections that had been put in place.I recognize that there's some folks who think they're not enough, and I think all of us, when we're working in big institutions, may find ourselves at times at odds with policies that are set. But when it comes to national security, we're often dealing with people in the field whose lives may be put at risk or the safety and security and the ability of our military or our intelligence teams or Embassies to function effectively. And that has to be kept in mind.So with respect to WikiLeaks, I don't see a contradiction. First of all, I haven't commented on WikiLeaks, generally. The conclusions of the intelligence community with respect to the Russian hacking were not conclusive as to whether WikiLeaks was witting or not in being the conduit through which we heard about the DNC e-mails that were leaked. I don't pay a lot of attention to Mr. Assange's tweets, so that wasn't a consideration in this instance. And I'd refer you to the Justice Department for any criminal investigations, indictments, extradition issues that may come up with him.What I can say broadly is that, in this new cyber age, we're going to have to make sure that we continually work to find the right balance of accountability and openness and transparency that is the hallmark of our democracy, but also recognize that there are adversaries and bad actors out there who want to use that same openness in ways that hurt us, whether that's in trying to commit financial crimes or trying to commit acts of terrorism or folks who want to interfere with our elections.And we're going to have to continually build the kind of architecture that makes sure our—the best of our democracy is preserved; that our national security and intelligence agencies have the ability to carry out policy without advertising to our adversaries what it is that we're doing, but do so in a way that still keeps citizens up to speed on what their Government is doing on their behalf.But with respect to Chelsea Manning, I looked at the particulars of this case the same way I have for the other commutations and pardons that I've done, and I felt that in light of all the circumstances that commuting her sentence was entirely appropriate.Margaret Brennan [CBS News].
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. I am sorry, can you repeat that question? [SEP] Pardon?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Do you believe—do you still believe that is it is possible that the relations between U.S. and North Korea, in the future, could be like the relations between the U.S. and Vietnam? [SEP] Yea. I think we're going have—yes. I mean, we have very, very good relations. And by the way, speaking of—you mentioned Japan—we have a lot of good things happening Japan. We have trade talks started. For years, Japan has been sending millions and millions of cars in, and as you know, it's not been a very fair situation for the United States. We're starting trade talks with Japan. They actually started about 3 months ago, and I think we'll have a very good deal for the United States. But that's been a very unfair situation. Prime Minister Abe understands that, and that's fine.Yes, sir.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, concerning your library's fundraising, is the $200 million figure accurate? Will you reveal donors? Will you impose contribution limits? [SEP] No, yes, no, yes. Moving on. Good grief, that was a long one. I haven't finalized the budget. Donnie Evans will address disclosure. Some people like to donate privately. And... what was the last part?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. The election of two Muslim women, one veiled, to the House is historic. Do you see this as a rejection of your message? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: So, you're looking into the reports of potential wrongdoing? Can you elaborate on the steps you're taking? [SEP] Absolutely. If there's something to investigate, we will investigate it. We don't condone that kind of activity. Now, I think we have time for one more question.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. What are you going to do about it, sir? [SEP] And it's a problem we want to solve.
label: General

sentence: Sir, with all due respect, the Democrats are saying that your economic policies are failing. They say that the country is headed for a recession. What is your response? [SEP] Matt, I—all I can tell you is we grew in the first quarter. I can remember holding a press conference here and that same question came about, assuming that we weren't going to grow. But we showed growth. It's not the growth we'd like; we'd like stronger growth. And there are some things we can do. One is wait for the stimulus package to fully kick in and not raise taxes. If the Democratic leaders had their way in Congress, they would raise taxes, which would be the absolute wrong thing to do. Secondly, they can pass housing legislation that reforms FHA as well as Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. And by the way, a part of that—as I mentioned in my opening statement, a part of that reform will be a strong regulator to help these institutions stay focused on the core mission, which is mortgages.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, I'm from China. My question is: Do you still believe it is possible that the North Korea and U.S. relations could be like the U.S. and the Vietnam relations in the future? [SEP] You have to go again.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, what would you say to President Moon, who appears limited in his ability to pursue inter-Korean cooperation due to the current sanctions regime? And what can we expect regarding future U.S.-R.O.K. military drills? [SEP] I have a great fondness for President Moon. We have a terrific relationship. In fact, I maintain positive relationships with nearly all world leaders, which some find surprising. However, it's true. Certain countries exploit our generosity to an unbelievable extent. And when they realize that I'm aware of it—which I invariably am—it tends to make them a bit more circumspect. But yes, we enjoy many strong relationships. I plan to call President Moon shortly, as soon as I board the plane. He'll be among the first I contact. I'll also be reaching out to Prime Minister Abe of Japan to provide him with an update. So, I'll be making those calls. President Moon is dedicated to his work. He's very keen on achieving a deal, and he's been a valuable asset. All right? Thank you. Next question, please.
label: General

sentence: Sir, isn't commuting Manning's sentence a green light for future leakers, especially given WikiLeaks' alleged ties to Russian interference? And what about Assange's offer to come here – are you considering it, and what would he face? [SEP] Look, Manning did hard time. Nobody should think leaking secrets is a walk in the park. I looked at her case, she went to court, owned up to it, and the sentence was way out of line. Justice was done. About WikiLeaks, the intel guys weren't sure if they knew what they were doing with the Russian stuff. I don't care about Assange's tweets. Ask Justice about him. We need to find a balance between being open and keeping bad guys from using that against us. Manning's case was just that – her case.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, if you don't mind, could you specify which particular piece of legislation you were alluding to during your remarks? [SEP] Which specific bill are we discussing again?
label: Clarification

sentence: But when will everyday Americans have access to the same level of testing as your staff? [SEP] We're working on it. Tremendous progress has been made. We have the best testing capabilities in the world, frankly. Other countries are envious.
label: General

sentence: President, can you provide a concrete timeline for the completion of the strategic framework agreement with Iraq, and what specific guarantees are in place to protect U.S. troops operating under the 'overwatch' mission? [SEP] The strategic framework agreement with Iraq is a priority, and we're making steady progress. The timeline for completion is dependent on a number of factors, including the ongoing negotiations with the Iraqi government. We're aiming to finalize the agreement as soon as possible, but we want to ensure that it addresses all of our concerns. Now, regarding the safety of our troops, that's always our top priority. We're working to secure the necessary authorities and protections to ensure their well-being. The 'overwatch' mission will focus on training, logistics, and special operations, and we'll continue to work closely with the Iraqi security forces to maintain a stable and secure environment. What's next?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, with the UK experiencing a surge in coronavirus cases, what justifies their exemption from the travel ban imposed on countries with fewer cases? Will you consider including them on the list? [SEP] That decision was based on expert recommendations at the time. We are constantly monitoring the situation, and if the numbers warrant it, we will certainly consider adding the UK to the list. We are also exploring the possibility of lifting restrictions on other countries, so the situation is constantly evolving.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. So will you take action—on the border supplemental, can you act alone? [SEP] Well, I'm going to have to act alone because we don't have enough resources. We've already been very clear: We've run out of money. And we are going to have to reallocate resources in order to just make sure that some of the basic functions that have to take place down there, whether it's making sure that these children are properly housed or making sure we've got enough immigration judges to process their cases, that those things get done. We're going to have to reallocate some resources.But the broader point, Wendell, is that if in fact House Republicans are concerned about me acting independently of Congress—despite the fact that I've taken fewer executive actions than my Republican predecessor or my Democratic predecessor before that or the Republican predecessor before that—then the easiest way to solve it is passing legislation. Get things done.On the supplemental, we agreed on 80 percent of the issues. There were 20 percent of the issues that perhaps there were disagreements between Democrats and Republicans. As I said to one Republican colleague who was down here that I was briefing about some national security issues, why wouldn't we just go ahead and pass the 80 percent that we agree on and we'll try to work to resolve the differences on the other 20 percent? Why wouldn't we do that? And he didn't really have a good answer for it.So there's no doubt that I can always do better on everything, including making additional calls to Speaker Boehner and having more conversations with some of the House Republican leadership. But in the end, the challenge I have right now is that they are not able to act even on what they say their priorities are, and they're not able to work and compromise even with Senate Republicans on certain issues. And they are—they consider what have been traditionally Republican-supported initiatives, they consider those as somehow a betrayal of the cause.Take the example of the Export-Import Bank. This is an interesting thing that's happened. I mean, this is a program in which we help to provide financing to sell American goods and products around the world. Every country does this. It's traditionally been championed by Republicans. For some reason, right now the House Republicans have decided that we shouldn't do this, which means that when American companies go overseas and they're trying to close a sale on selling Boeing planes, for example, or a GE turbine or some other American product that has all kinds of subcontractors behind it and is creating all kinds of jobs and all sorts of small businesses depend on that sale, and that American company is going up against a German company or a Chinese company, and the Chinese and the American—German company are providing financing and the American company isn't, we may lose that sale.Why—when did that become something that Republicans opposed? It would be like me having a car dealership for Ford, and the Toyota dealership offers somebody financing, and I don't. We will lose business and we'll lose jobs if we don't pass it.So there are some big issues where I understand why we have differences. All right? On taxes, Republicans want to maintain some corporate loopholes I think need to be closed because I think that we should be giving tax breaks to families that are struggling with childcare or trying to save for a college education. On health care, obviously, their view is, is that we should not be helping folks get health care, even though it's through the private marketplace. My view is, is that in a country as wealthy as ours, we can afford to make sure that everybody has access to affordable care.Those are legitimate policy arguments. But getting our Ambassadors confirmed? These are career diplomats, not political types. Making sure that we pass legislation to strengthen our borders and put more folks down there? Those shouldn't be controversial. And I think you'd be hard-pressed to find an example of where I wouldn't welcome some reasonable efforts to actually get a bill passed out of Congress that I could sign.Last question, Michelle Kosinski [CNN].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your call for Latin American nations to demonstrate their commitment to democracy, can you point to any tangible results since the Summit of the Americas? [SEP] President Bachelet is a fine leader. Chile's economic management is exemplary. The US can learn from it. There is enormous potential for progress in Latin America. I will be talking about clean energy cooperation with President Bachelet. We're making important progress when it comes to exchanges on cancer research. We continue to have a robust trade regime with Chile. Chile has actually entered into some very interesting partnerships, not just with the Federal Government but also with State governments like California. It's a respectful policy. Chile is an important partner. I think that's the model that we want: partnership. The United States doesn't dictate how Chile should view its own interests, but in fact, we've achieved great cooperation. And I will be looking at President Bachelet giving us further advice in terms of how we can take the kind of relationship we have with Chile and expand that to our relationships throughout Latin America. Okay?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Regarding Crimea, you've criticized the Obama administration. What specific steps will you take to reverse the annexation? [SEP] We're evaluating all options. It's a complex situation, and I'm not going to telegraph my strategy to the world. Let's just say we're looking at it very, very closely. It's a mess, frankly, that I inherited.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, if proven true, do you approve of Postmaster General DeJoy allegedly soliciting GOP donations from former employees and then reimbursing them? [SEP] I don't know much about that situation. I saw something about it this morning, but that's all I know. He's a respected man, approved by both parties, I believe. I'm not sure of the details. I'll look into it shortly. I just read about it myself this morning.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. But in the current scenario, your thinking on that has not changed? [SEP] My thinking has not changed currently.Ed Henry of Fox.
label: Explicit

sentence: You've repeatedly claimed that mail-in voting leads to fraud. Can you cite concrete examples of widespread fraud stemming from mail-in ballots in Nevada or other states? [SEP] The media, even the liberal Washington Post, has reported on it. It's all over the web. Read the articles.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. And just on a different topic, Mr. President. Russia today claimed that it had evacuated the Kherson region and the Kherson city. Do you believe that this is potentially an inflection in that conflict? And do you believe that Ukraine now has the leverage it needs to begin peace negotiations with Moscow? [SEP] First of all, I found it interesting they waited until after the election to make that judgment, which we knew for some time that they were going to be doing. And it's evidence of the fact that they have some real problems—Russian—the Russian military. Number one.Number two, whether or not that leads to, at a minimum, it will lead to time for everyone to recalibrate their positions over the winter's period. And it remains to be seen whether or not there'll be a judgment made as to whether or not Ukraine is prepared to compromise with Russia.I'm going to be going to the G-20. I'm told that President Putin is not likely to be there, but other world leaders are going to be there in Indonesia. And we're going to have an opportunity to see what the next steps may be.Nancy. CBS. Nancy Cordes.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the supercommittee's potential deadlock and the looming sequester, and considering Republican efforts to alter the automatic cuts, are you prepared to veto any such bill? Additionally, could you clarify the substance of your 'hot mic' conversation with President Sarkozy concerning Prime Minister Netanyahu? [SEP] Let's address the supercommittee first. Back in August, we reached an agreement to cut a trillion dollars over the next decade, largely from discretionary spending. We also recognized the need for an additional 1.2 trillion to put us on a more stable fiscal path. The sequester was designed to compel both sides to move beyond their entrenched positions and act in the best interests of the nation. Since then, there have been numerous discussions, but it appears that people are still clinging to their rigid stances rather than seeking solutions. I've presented a comprehensive plan that would achieve over $3 trillion in savings, a balanced approach that the American people favor. It entails putting everything on the table: discretionary spending cuts, non-defense and defense cuts, adjustments to entitlement programs, healthcare cost reductions, and additional revenue. When it comes to revenue, it makes sense to begin by asking the wealthiest among us to contribute a bit more before asking seniors to pay more for their Medicare. This is the same proposal I shared with Speaker Boehner in August, a balanced approach that every independent committee has supported. It seems people are constantly trying to manipulate the numbers to achieve a different outcome. However, the equation remains the same: a balanced approach is crucial to avoid crippling Medicare and Medicaid. I hope the congressional leadership on the supercommittee will rise to the occasion and do what needs to be done, because the math won't change. I'm ready to sign legislation that is balanced and resolves the problem. Regarding the 'hot mic' incident in France, I won't comment on private conversations with other leaders. However, my primary discussion with President Sarkozy centered on my disappointment with France's vote in favor of Palestinian membership in UNESCO, which would require the US to cut funding, undermining direct negotiations between Palestinians and Israelis. I had a very frank conversation with President Sarkozy about that issue, consistent with my previous statements.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Just to be clear, concerning the selection of your Cabinet members? [SEP] Pardon? I didn't catch that.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I have two questions for you and then some for Chancellor Merkel as well. Your administration, tomorrow, is issuing a business advisory for Hong Kong. I was wondering if you can explain why you think that is necessary.And then, secondly, on your Build Back Better agenda, have you spoken to Senators Manchin and Sinema about the $3.5 trillion framework, and are you confident that they'll be on board at that level? And if they demand that you lose some components, will you be able to keep progressives on board?[At this point, the reporter spoke in German, and her remarks were translated by an interpreter as follows.]I wanted to ask you whether you have a feeling that, after the talk with President Biden, he better understands your viewpoint as regards China or whether the situation is still tense, whether there is still decoupling. And secondly, whether you think that the United States has contributed enough to vaccinate the rest of the world, or do you think it's only—is it appropriate for children in the United States being vaccinated—children below the age of 12, while adults in other countries have no chance to get vaccinated? [SEP] That's all? [] I thought I said we'd take two questions, but I guess that translated to, we'd take two questions or more from each person called on.Let me talk about the business advisory. The situation in Hong Kong is deteriorating. And the Chinese Government is not keeping its commitment that it made how it would deal with Hong Kong. And so it is more of an advisory as to what may happen in—on Hong Kong. It's as simple as that and as complicated as that.With regard to am I confident?—I'm supremely confident that everything is going to work out perfectly in terms—[]. Look, I understand why the press, among others, is skeptical that I can actually get this deal done on infrastructure and on human infrastructure. And I've watched and listened, and the press declared my initiative dead at least 10 times so far.I don't think it's dead. I think it's still alive. I still have confidence we're going to be able to get what I proposed and what I've agreed to in the bipartisan agreement on infrastructure. I've gotten—we've each committed—I trust the members of—the Republican Senators who have made the commitments relative to how we should proceed and what would be included in the package for infrastructure. And they're men and women of honor, and I expect they would keep their commitment.With regard to the further issue of what's going on and what will confuse the listening audience—but reconciliation—that is the mechanism by which you have to get every single Democrat to agree to proceed on matters like what I announced today.Today—I don't know whether you have any children; it's none of my business whether you do, but if you do, you're going to get—if you're making less than $150,000—you're going to get a significant stipend that is a tax cut. If you have a child under the age of 7 years old, you're going to get—in your bank account today, you're going to get a payment of one-sixth—12 months divided—$3,600—$3,700 for that child divided by 12 every month, just like a Social Security check. It's expected to reduce poverty—child poverty by over 40 percent. And it could be a significant, significant game changer.We have mechanisms to pay for both these mechanisms. And there may be some last-minute discussion as to who—what mechanism is used to pay for each of these items, both the infrastructure package and the human infrastructure package. But I believe we will get it done.Thank you. We talked about China, and there is a lot of common understanding that China, in many areas, is our competitor; that trade with China needs to rest on the assumption that we have a level playing field so that we all play by the same rules, have the same standards. That, incidentally, was also the driving force behind the EU-China agreement on trade that they abide by the core labor norms of ILO.And we are convinced of ours—needing to be technological leaders for our two countries in many, many areas. Obviously, it's legitimate for China wishing to do this as well, but, forexample, we will cooperate in many technological state-of-the-art technologies, for example, CHIPS. I think the act that the President launched is fundamental in this respect and crucial.And we want to trade together at a time of digitalization where security issues loom very large in our agendas. We ought to have an exchange on this; we ought to talk about this; we ought to talk about norms, standards that govern the internet; whether we can agree on common norms. I think, particularly as regards to the relationship of us with China, we ought to coordinate our efforts. We do that in the European Union, and we should do it with the United States.And then, there are interests, obviously: sometimes divergent interests, but sometimes common interests. But we also have, obviously, areas where American companies compete with European companies, and we have to accept that. But I think, basically, the rules as to how we deal with China ought to rest and do rest on our shared values.And I think, on the pandemic, we are obviously of the opinion that the pandemic—we can only master the pandemic if each and every one is vaccinated. We are trying to boost production. We are trying also to get as many people in our country vaccinated as possible—which obviously opens us up to criticism of those countries who as yet have not had the chance, which is why we invested a lot of money in COVAX, which is why we encourage our companies to increase their production of vaccines.And, in Africa, we are trying to help Africans to upskill people so that they, too, can have their own production sites. We're going to do this, but, de facto, there is an imbalance, I agree. And—but we're overcoming. We're putting our all into that and also together in overcoming that imbalance.I'm sorry. I call on Ms. Schäuble from Der Tagesspiegel newspaper. Thank you.[]
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, can you confirm or deny if they are subjects of an active investigation? [SEP] That's not something I can discuss at this moment.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. [Inaudible]—what about the compromise shift question? [SEP] I have to say that quietly we did some pretty good groundwork during the course of this year, so that our position was relatively clear. I think that the one principle that I brought to this is that whatever commitments we make, I want to be able to be sure that they're actually commitments that we can keep. So we tried to be modest in what we thought we could accomplish. I think there was interest on the part of some to, for example, increase our mitigation targets. Although when you look out in the years 2025 or 2030, our goals are actually entirely comparable with Europe's. On the front end, they appear to be less, because frankly, they've had a head start over the last several years in doing things like energy efficiency that we care about.What I said to the other people in the room is, is that I want to make sure that whatever it is that we promise we can actually deliver on and that it would be unrealistic for us to think that we can turn on a dime and that suddenly a clean energy economy is going to emerge overnight, given the fact that it's going to require significant effort. And companies and industries are going to be wanting to make changes; we're already seeing those changes, but they haven't all borne fruit yet. And we want to make sure that we're not getting too far ahead of ourselves in terms of targets, even as I understand that the science compels us to move as rapidly as we can.All right. Helene Cooper.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Does it require signing? Is it that kind of agreement? [SEP] You know, it raises an interesting question as to whether technically there's actually a signature, since, as I said, it's not a legally binding agreement. I don't know what the protocols are. But I do think that this is a commitment that we, as the United States, are making and that we think is very important.All right. Thanks, guys.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, do you still believe Hillary Clinton will secure the Democratic nomination? [SEP] With all due respect, I'm focused on governing, not speculating about future political contests.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, following General Pace's widely discussed remarks on homosexuality, your perspective remains unclear. Do you personally consider homosexuality to be immoral? [SEP] I'm not going to offer a personal judgment on individual orientations. The 'don't ask, don't tell' policy, in my view, serves us well.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, are you considering cutting off their federal funding? [SEP] I'm not inclined to make such a move. I'm optimistic that we can collaborate effectively. They depend on the federal government for more than just funding; they also need our advice and supplies. We're in a strong position to help. When I assumed office, we faced significant challenges, but we've overcome them. I anticipate the Governors will respect the Presidency. The most effective approach is to empower the States to govern themselves, with federal assistance available upon request.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, to follow up on Afghanistan, some critics are suggesting the current strategy is simply a continuation of past failures. How do you respond to those who say we're just repeating the same mistakes? [SEP] Look, we're not just blindly following the past. We're adapting to the present. The situation on the ground is constantly evolving, and our strategy must evolve with it. We're learning from past experiences, both successes and failures, and applying those lessons to the current challenges. It's a dynamic process, not a static one. And we are committed to ensuring that the Afghan people have the opportunity to build a stable and prosperous future.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the intelligence agencies' claims of Russian and Chinese meddling, do you believe these reports, and what concrete steps will you take to prevent foreign interference in the democratic process? [SEP] It's a thought, isn't it? I mean, the idea that they're meddling. But let's be honest, who knows for sure? We're watching, we're aware. But frankly, I think they're more concerned about someone else winning. We'll see what happens.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Vladimir Putin: Do you possess evidence to suggest that Mr. Putin personally authorized the cyber intrusion? And do you believe the motivation behind this action was to provide assistance to Mr. Trump? Furthermore, Mr. Trump has invoked the specter of Saddam Hussein and the elusive weapons of mass destruction. Can you state unequivocally that this was not the work of China, nor the actions of a solitary individual, as Mr. Trump has posited? And do you believe that Mr. Trump's pronouncements embolden the Russian Federation? [SEP] The forthcoming report, scheduled for release prior to my departure from office, will synthesize all pertinent information. I am hesitant to preempt its findings. However, the intelligence at my disposal engenders a high degree of confidence in the assessment that the Russian Federation perpetrated this cyber intrusion.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Is this just political theater? [SEP] I think this is going to go very rapidly through the courts.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Russia, what's your assessment of Dmitry Medvedev's true influence, considering Putin's continued presence? And what lessons would you impart to your successor concerning the Russian threat and how to engage with this new leader, given past criticisms of your own judgment of Putin? [SEP] Medvedev? Honestly, I couldn't tell you much about the guy. What's more telling is who represents Russia at events like the G-8. That'll give us a clue about Russia's foreign policy direction post-Putin. But I can't give you a definitive answer right now. What I can say is that maintaining relations with Russia is vital. We need their cooperation on issues like nuclear proliferation and Iran. Remember when Putin offered to supply enriched uranium to Iran's Bushehr plant, eliminating their need to enrich it themselves? That was constructive. We need to be able to work with Russia on Iran. There are many areas where we need to cooperate. Take missile defense in Europe, for instance. We need the Russians to understand that the system isn't aimed at them, but at real 21st-century threats like rogue states with weapons of mass destruction. So, I'm going to try to leave my successor with the ability to have a relationship with whoever's calling the shots in Russia. It's in our national interest. Doesn't mean we'll always agree. We didn't on Kosovo, and there will be other disagreements. But a leader-to-leader relationship, and hopefully beyond that, is crucial.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, critics claim your administration's policies have directly benefited your own businesses. How do you respond to these accusations of self-dealing and conflicts of interest regarding Ukraine? [SEP] Let me be perfectly clear: the Bidens are a disaster. Everyone knows it. His son's dealings are shady, plain and simple. They're all crooked, and frankly, it's a disgrace that you're even asking me about it. Now, do you have a real question?
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, who will sign the agreement? Since you're leaving, who here has the power to sign it? [SEP] Well, the—we've got our negotiators who are here. I'm not going to be the only leader who, I think, leaves before it's finally presented, but they are empowered to sign off, given at this point that most of the text has been completely worked out.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, what's your opinion on Australia's potential uranium sales to India, and how much did the U.S. influence that decision? Also, what are your views on a global carbon trading system, especially considering Australia's carbon tax? [SEP] On India, I don't think we had any sway over Australia's decision. I believe your government is savvy enough to appreciate the importance of India and the Australia-India relationship. This is your region, and you'll make your own bilateral calls. The discussions about nuclear energy with India seem in line with international law and the NPT. This is between India and Australia, not the U.S. On carbon emissions, I agree with your Prime Minister and most scientists that climate change is a real problem caused by human activity. Each country is finding its own way to cut emissions. Australia has a bold strategy. In the U.S., we've doubled fuel efficiency standards and invested in clean energy research. We think we can meet our commitments from Copenhagen and Cancun. I hope the U.S. can find more ways to reduce emissions. Advanced economies can't do this alone; emerging economies like China and India need to be part of the solution. We want a mechanism where all countries are making an effort, which will be tough but beneficial in the long run.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, have you discussed the issue of possible inspections to North Korea's nuclear sites during your negotiations? [SEP] Speak up, please. And what news outlet are you with?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, the data from Johns Hopkins shows the U.S. ranking among the highest in deaths per capita. How do you reconcile that with your statement? [SEP] Well, those numbers are constantly changing, and there are different ways to calculate them. We're working hard to bring those numbers down, and I'm confident that we'll continue to make progress. But I'll get you the latest figures as soon as I have them.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, given the divisions within the Republican caucus, do you have faith in Speaker Boehner's ability to secure the necessary votes on key legislation? [SEP] That's really a question for the Speaker, isn't it? He's the one who has to wrangle those votes. I'm focused on working with Congress to get things done. I believe Speaker Boehner is a capable leader, but ultimately, it's up to him to manage his caucus and get the votes. I'm not going to second-guess his leadership.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. ——on the security assurances you talked about in your statement, can you be specific about what assurances you are willing to give to Kim Jong Un? Does that include reducing military capabilities? [SEP] No.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. In 2010, you called the result of the midterm election a shellacking. What do you call this? And can you give us an update on your feelings about the immigration Executive order in the result—in the aftermath of this election? Does the election affect your plans to release it? Will it still—is it likely to come out before the lame duck session is over? And have you reduced its scope to just a couple million people? [SEP] Well, as I said in my opening statement, there's no doubt that Republicans had a good night. And what we're going to make sure that we do is to reach out to Mitch McConnell and John Boehner, who are now running both Chambers in Congress, and find out what their agenda is. And my hope is, is that they've got some specific things they want to do that correspond with some things that we want to get done. What's most important to the American people right now, the resounding message not just of this election, but basically, the last several is: Get stuff done. Don't worry about the next election. Don't worry about party affiliation. Do worry about our concerns. Worry about the fact that I'm a single mom and, at the end of the month, it's really hard for me to pay the bills, in part because I've got these huge childcare costs. Do worry about the fact that I'm a young person who's qualified to go to college, but I'm really worried about taking $50,000 a year out in debt, and I don't know how I'd pay that back. Do worry about the fact that I'm a construction worker who has been working all my life, and I know that there's construction work that should be done, but right now, for some reason, projects are stalled. If we're thinking about those folks, I think we're, hopefully, going to be able to get some stuff done.In terms of immigration, I have consistently said that it is my profound preference and interest to see Congress act on a comprehensive immigration reform bill that would strengthen our borders; would streamline our legal immigration system so that it works better and we're attracting the best and the brightest from around the world; and that we give an opportunity for folks who've lived here, in many cases, for a very long time, may have kids who are U.S. citizens, but aren't properly documented—give them a chance to pay their back taxes, get in the back of the line, but get through a process that allows them to get legal.The Senate, on a bipartisan basis, passed a good bill. It wasn't perfect, it wasn't exactly what I wanted, but it was a sound, smart piece of legislation that really would greatly improve not just our immigration system, but our economy, and would improve business conditions here in the United States and make sure that American-born workers aren't undercut by workers who are undocumented and aren't always paid a fair wage, and as a consequence, employers who are breaking the rules are able to undercut folks who are doing the right thing.So we got a bipartisan bill out of the Senate. I asked John Boehner at that point, can we pass this through the House? There's a majority of votes in the House to get this passed. And Speaker Boehner, I think, was sincere about wanting to pass it, but had difficulty over the last year trying to get it done.So when he finally told me he wasn't going to call it up this year, what I indicated to him is, I feel obliged to do everything I can lawfully with my executive authority to make sure that we don't keep on making the system worse, but that whatever executive actions that I take will be replaced and supplanted by action by Congress. You send me a bill that I can sign, and those executive actions go away.That's a commitment I made not just to the American people and to businesses and the evangelical community and law enforcement folks and everybody who's looked at this issue and thinks that we need immigration reform; that's a commitment that I also made to John Boehner, that I would act in the absence of action by Congress.So before the end of the year, we're going to take whatever lawful actions that I can take that I believe will improve the functioning of our immigration system that will allow us to surge additional resources to the border, where I think the vast majority of Americans have the deepest concern. And at the same time, I'll be reaching out to both Mitch McConnell, John Boehner, and other Republican as well as Democratic leaders to find out how it is that they want to proceed. And if they want to get a bill done, whether it's during the lame duck or next year, I'm eager to see what they have to offer.But what I'm not going to do is just wait. I think it's fair to say that I've shown a lot of patience and have tried to work on a bipartisan basis as much as possible, and I'm going to keep on doing so. But in the meantime, let's figure out what we can do lawfully through executive actions to improve the functioning of the existing system.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with the Seattle City Council voting to defund their police department and Police Chief Carmen Best resigning, what does this signify about the current state of our nation and the 'defund the police' movement? [SEP] Seattle, after all they've been through, with the embarrassment of Antifa and other radical left groups taking over a large part of the city—a major city—that they allowed that to happen is unbelievable. That it took so long to fix is unbelievable. And they only acted because they knew we were going in the next day, and they didn't want to be embarrassed. The people just gave up, they were exhausted from having their city taken over for so long. The police commissioner seems like a very good woman. They were going to slash her salary by 40 or 50 percent. And they cut a tremendous amount from the police department, really, to the point where people are saying it's not sustainable as a good police department. And, again, those police are good also, but they're not allowed to do their job. So I think it's a shame. I hate to see her go, because she did, in her own way, a very good job, but she wasn't effective in convincing the mayor and the city council to give the funds that were needed or just leave the funds the way they are. They've done a big defund, a big part of it. And it will probably get worse before people realize this is a tragic error, before people start dying and getting hurt very badly. So I think Seattle has made a tragic mistake. I think Portland has no clue as to what they're doing. They have no clue. And hopefully, they'll be asking for help, because we can solve their problem very, very quickly.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that the Manning commutation sends the wrong message about leaking classified information, especially given WikiLeaks' role in the 2016 election. Also, with Assange offering to come to the US, what's the plan, and what charges await him? [SEP] The facts are these: Ms. Manning served a substantial sentence. The notion that leaking classified information goes unpunished is simply false. Her sentence was commuted because it was disproportionate. As for WikiLeaks, the intelligence community's findings were inconclusive regarding their knowledge of Russian hacking. I don't concern myself with Mr. Assange's pronouncements. The Justice Department handles any investigations. In general, we must balance transparency with the need to protect national security. The Manning decision was based solely on the merits of her case.
label: Dodging

sentence: Sir, considering the deadlock in the supercommittee negotiations, what specific compromises are you willing to make to avert the automatic cuts to Medicare and defense? And can you address the concerns raised by Prime Minister Netanyahu regarding your private conversations with President Sarkozy? [SEP] With respect to the supercommittee, we negotiated a trillion dollars in cuts over the next 10 years. The whole idea of the sequester was to make sure that both sides felt obligated to move off rigid positions and do what was required to help the country. Now, I've put forward a very detailed approach that would achieve $3 trillion-plus in savings. It says everything's on the table. I'm not going to comment on whether I'd veto a particular bill until I actually see a bill. With respect to the hot mic in France, I'm not going to comment on conversations that I have with individual leaders.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, after 3½ years, do you regret, at all, all the lying you've done to the American people on everything? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Senor Presidente, muchas gracias. Sir, how do you square your position that Colonel Qadhafi has lost legitimacy and must go against the limited objective of this campaign, which does not demand his removal? If Colonel Qadhafi is killing his own people, is it permissible to let him stay in power? And if I may add, do you have any regret, sir, about undertaking this mission while you're on foreign soil? And do you have the support of the Arab people in this yet? [SEP] Okay. First of all, I think I'm going to embarrass Jim by letting everyone know that Jim's mother is Chilean, and so this is a little bit of a homecoming. You were born in Chile, am I right?
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, no threats, you say? What about ultimatums on ransomware? And how do we know if these Russian meddling and cybersecurity groups are working? [SEP] It's simple. On cybersecurity, are they going to crack down on the ransomware guys in their country? They haven't so far. Did they plan the attacks? Probably not. But will they do something now? We'll find out. Will we agree to do something about international norms that hurt us? What can we agree on? There's a chance to make progress. People are starting to get how dangerous this is. Imagine if a ransomware group in Florida hit their oil supply. Boom. Everyone needs to take this seriously. We'll see what happens with these groups.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, beyond a simple congratulatory call, are you prepared to address the broader implications of the recent political developments, and can you provide any specific details regarding anticipated staff departures, especially concerning General Kelly's future in the White House? [SEP] As we make changes, we'll sit down and discuss them with you. There's no great mystery here. Many administrations make adjustments after midterm elections. I will say that, for the most part, I'm very satisfied with this Cabinet. We're accomplishing a lot.
label: Implicit

sentence: Following up on that, what specific measures are being implemented to address the concerns you raised? [SEP] We're taking it very seriously. If it's happening, we'll get to the bottom of it. Next question, please.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, if Tedros were to be replaced, would the U.S. reconsider its support for the WHO? Or is his resignation a prerequisite for reform? [SEP] We're looking into the whole situation at the WHO. I don't know Tedros personally, but there are clearly some serious issues. The WHO, like the WTO, has been very unfair to the United States, especially regarding China. They treat China as a developing nation, which is ridiculous! No other president has addressed this. We're taking a hard look at both the WHO and the WTO. Which is worse? I'm not sure, but we'll get to the bottom of it.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President, to be precise, are you saying Zelenskyy might have to give up territory for a ceasefire, and do you advocate for Russia's expulsion from the G-20? [SEP] Concerning the G-20, my answer is yes, depending on the collective will. This was discussed earlier. I proposed that if agreement proves impossible, we should explore inviting both nations to observe the proceedings. Now, could you please reiterate your initial question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, considering the growing economic influence of China in Latin America, what specific measures will the United States take to maintain its strategic partnerships and promote its interests in the region? [SEP] We're working with our partners in Latin America to create jobs and opportunities. We're promoting free trade and democracy. We're not going to let China take over the region.
