We're going to compete and win.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, the memo from your National Security Adviser has raised the possibility the United States should press Prime Minister Maliki to break with Muqtada Al Sadr. Is this, in fact, your strategy? And did you raise this issue with the Prime Minister this morning?And to the Prime Minister, I'd like to ask, the President's Adviser has said that a central problem in Iraq is your close alliance with Mr. Al Sadr, and did you make any representations to the President that you would break with Al Sadr, and could your Government survive such a break? [SEP] I will let the Prime Minister talk about his relations with Al Sadr. I will tell you that he and I spent a lot of time talking about the security situation inside of Iraq. I expressed my concern about the security situation; he expressed his concern about the security situation. After all, one of his most important jobs is to provide security for the Iraqi people. Part of the Prime Minister's frustration is, is that he doesn't have the tools necessary to take care of those who break the law.I was reassured by his commitment to a pluralistic society that is politically united, and a society in which people are held to account if they break the law, whether those people be criminals, Al Qaida, militia, whoever.He discussed with me his political situation, and I think it is best that he talk to you about the Sadr group or any other group he wants to talk about inside of Iraq. Matter of fact, my coalition is not with only one entity. The national unity Government is a government formed of all the entities that participated in it. Therefore, that coalition basically represent a national responsibility.And Mr. Sadr and the Sadrists are just one component that participate in the Parliament or in the Government. And I think participating in the Government is a responsibility, and it's a mutual commitment, and those who participate in this Government need to bear responsibilities. And foremost upon those responsibilities is the protection of this Government, the protection of the Constitution, the protection of the law, not breaking the law.Therefore, I do not talk about one side at the expense of the other. I'm talking about a state; I'm talking about law; I'm talking about commitments. And this should apply to all the partners in the Government who have chosen to participate in the political process.As to the issues that would pertain to violating the law or breaking the law, we would deal with them the same way, because the most important principle is the sovereignty and the power and the establishment of the state that must be borne by the state, but only our partners should participate in that.
label: General

sentence: President Obama, critics argue that the damage caused by Snowden's disclosures outweighs any potential benefits in terms of increased transparency. How do you respond to that argument, and what specific measures have you taken to mitigate the negative consequences of those disclosures? [SEP] There's no doubt that the disclosures caused damage, real damage, to our intelligence capabilities. We've had to work hard to repair that damage. But I also believe that it's important to have a debate about these issues, about the balance between security and privacy. It's not an easy balance, and we need to keep having that conversation.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, with the security challenges facing Nigeria, would you consider prioritizing the delivery of at least a couple of Tucano aircraft before 2020? And on a lighter note, when might we expect to see you visiting Nigeria? [SEP] I missed the first part of your question. Can you say it again? But Nigeria is fantastic, one of the most beautiful countries. I would really like to visit.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, thank you very much. About Vladimir Putin and your meeting this week: As you're well aware, the U.S. has been slapping sanctions on Russia for years for its malign activities, and Russia has not stopped. So what specifically will you do differently to change Vladimir Putin's behavior? [SEP] Well, first of all, there's no guarantee you can change a person's behavior or the behavior of his country. Autocrats have enormous power, and they don't have to answer to a public. And the fact is that it may very well be, if I respond in kind—which I will—that it doesn't dissuade him; he wants to keep going.But I think that we're going to be moving in a direction where Russia has its own dilemmas, let us say, dealing with its economy, dealing with its—dealing with COVID, and dealing with not only the United States, but Europe writ large and in the Middle East.And so there's a lot going on where we can work together with Russia. For example, in Libya, we should be opening up the passes to be able to go through and provide food assistance and economic—I mean, vital assistance to a population that's in real trouble.I think I'm going to try very much—hard to—it is—and by the way, there's places where—I shouldn't be starting off on negotiating in public here. But let me say it this way: Russia has engaged in activities which are—we believe are contrary to international norms, but they have also bitten off some real problems they're going to have trouble chewing on.And, for example, the rebuilding of Syria, of Libya, of—you know, this is—they're there. And as long as they're there without the ability to bring about some order in the region, and you can't do that very well without providing for the basic economic needs of people.So I'm hopeful that we can find an accommodation that—where we can save the lives of people in—for example, in Libya, that—consistent with the interest of—maybe for different reasons—but reached it for the same reason—the same result.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, following your meeting with Prime Minister Najib, can you provide specific examples of the commitments he made to address the concerns you raised regarding corruption and human rights, particularly concerning the investment funds scandal and the treatment of political opponents? [SEP] The refugee situation is a priority, especially after the Paris attacks. We need to ensure our processes are effective. Regarding Prime Minister Najib, I don't comment on ongoing investigations in other countries. But I consistently raise the importance of transparency, accountability, and rooting out corruption with all leaders. I also emphasize the importance of civil society and a free press. Each country is on its own path, but certain principles are essential. We see progress in places like Myanmar. We use initiatives like the Open Government Partnership and TPP to promote these values. We strive for a world where people are treated fairly, there's rule of law, and governments are accountable. These are American values, but they're also universal.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, concerning the internal dynamics of the White House, are the reports of staff departures, including General Kelly's, accurate? Can you provide any clarity on this matter? [SEP] Well, things change. People leave.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, during your State of the Union, you passionately addressed human rights, even showcasing a North Korean defector. At that time, you asserted that North Korea's oppression was unparalleled. Having now met with Kim Jong Un, do you still maintain that assessment, and does he need to change that? [SEP] Look, Jon, there's no question it's a tough situation over there. We talked about it pretty strongly today. I mean, the main focus was denuking, but we spent a good amount of time on it. We'll be doing something about it. It's rough, it's rough in a lot of places, by the way. Not just there. But it's rough, and we'll keep working on it. I think we'll eventually agree on something. But it was discussed at length, outside of the nuclear situation, one of the primary topics.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, following the ban on TikTok, are there any other Chinese tech companies currently under review for potential restrictions in the United States? What specific criteria are you using to evaluate these companies, and what are the potential national security risks? [SEP] We're looking at everything. We're always evaluating potential threats to our national security. We're going to take whatever action is necessary to protect American interests. We're not going to telegraph our punches, but we're very aware of the situation, and we're taking it very seriously.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. But when it comes to your relationships with Congress, one of the most frequent criticisms we've heard over the past few years from Members on both sides is that you haven't done enough to reach out and build relationships. Are there concrete ways that you plan to approach your relationships with Congress in a second term? [SEP] Look, I think there's no doubt that I can always do better, and so I will examine ways that I can make sure to communicate my desire to work with everybody, so long as it's advancing the cause of strengthening our middle class and improving our economy. I've got a lot of good relationships with folks both in the House and the Senate. I have a lot of relationships on both sides of the aisle. It hasn't always manifested itself in the kind of agreements that I'd like to see between Democrats and Republicans. And so I think all of us have responsibilities to see if there are things that we can improve on. And I don't exempt myself from needing to do some self-reflection and see if I can improve our working relationship.There are probably going to be still some very sharp differences. And as I said during the campaign, there are going to be times where there are fights and I think those are fights that need to be had. But what I think the American people don't want to see is a focus on the next election instead of a focus on them.And I don't have another election. And Michelle and I were talking last night about what an incredible honor and privilege it is to be put in this position. And there are people all across this country, millions of folks, who worked so hard to help us get elected, but there are also millions of people who may not have voted for us, but are also counting on us. And we take that responsibility very seriously. I take that responsibility very seriously. And I hope and intend to be an even better President in the second term than I was in the first.Jonathan Karl [ABC News]
label: General

sentence: President Obama, many are concerned that your proposed solution is too vague. Can you provide concrete examples of the 'prudent cuts' and 'revenue' increases you mentioned, or are you deliberately keeping the details ambiguous to avoid political backlash from specific interest groups? [SEP] The responsible path forward requires shared sacrifice. Details are being worked out, and I won't negotiate in public. My focus is on the big picture, not getting bogged down in the weeds. Regarding the conversation with President Sarkozy, I will not be commenting.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, when you said the shooting—you said the shooting was outside. How far away from the White House? [SEP] Well, they're going to be giving you a full briefing in a little while.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, Social Security reform is a contentious issue, particularly the concept of partial privatization. Given the Democratic Party's strong opposition, are you prepared to modify your proposals in the interest of bipartisan cooperation? [SEP] Well, let's just say that I've directed Hank Paulson to inform the Members that we're willing to sit down and listen to everyone's ideas. I've put forward my own ideas, as you may remember, in the last State of the Union address. We're eager to hear what they have to say. The hope is that by bringing folks together around a table to share their perspectives, we can find common ground and ultimately tell the American people that we've helped solve this problem.But let's be clear, this is a tough nut to crack. I fully understand how challenging it is. Social Security is something that people are generally very risk-averse about. My concern is that the longer we delay, the more difficult the issue is going to become. Some will continue to push for solutions, and hopefully, we can get something done.Richard [Richard Wolffe, Newsweek].
label: General

sentence: Sir, with all due respect, that sounds like a political platitude. What specific measures are you taking to ensure that raising the debt ceiling is accompanied by responsible fiscal policies? [SEP] It's kind of cumulative. The American people aren't paying attention to the details of every aspect of this negotiation, but I think what the American people are paying attention to is who seems to be trying to get something done, and who seems to be just posturing and trying to score political points. And I think it's going to be in the interests of everybody who wants to continue to serve in this town to make sure that they are on the right side of that impression.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, with the Afghanistan war drawing to a close, can you confidently assert that the significant human and financial investments were justified, considering the Afghanistan that remains is not the fully realized vision of reconstruction and democracy? And President Karzai, do you still attribute much of Afghanistan's corruption to foreign influence, and are you unequivocally committed to stepping down from the presidency after the next elections? [SEP] We went to Afghanistan because we were attacked. We had a clear objective: to dismantle Al Qaeda. We've made significant progress towards that goal. Afghanistan still has work to do, but it's on a better path. I'll let President Karzai address the questions directed to him.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Presidential library, reports suggest a fundraising goal of $200 million. Can you confirm this figure? Will you commit to disclosing donor information to the American public? And will there be any limitations on who can contribute and the amount they can donate? [SEP] Look, the budget's still being finalized. As for disclosure, the foundation chairman, Donnie Evans, will assess the requirements and make a determination. Some donors prefer anonymity, which we'll consider. As for the rest, I'll have to get back to you.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: With Ghislaine Maxwell now in jail, many are wondering if she will name names. Considering your previous statements regarding Prince Andrew and Bill Clinton, what are your thoughts on this? [SEP] I haven't been paying much attention to that situation. I just hope things work out for her. I've met her a few times over the years, especially when I was living down in Palm Beach. I don't know anything about Prince Andrew's involvement. Yes, go ahead.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. So, just to button this up, would you endorse that proposal? [SEP] Well, not that proposal, but we're getting closer. We're getting closer.I do like a lot of money getting sent to people that really were—really were hurt unnecessarily by , because they could have stopped it. They stopped it from going into their country. They could have stopped it from coming to our country and from going to Europe and from going to the rest of the world, 188 different countries from all over the world.Please.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, the McKinnon case continues to draw criticism. Is there any room for compromise, given the circumstances? Prime Minister, could you elaborate on your government's position, particularly in light of the strong feelings expressed by your Deputy? [SEP] The Prime Minister and I had a productive discussion on this matter. Of course, discussions are ongoing between our respective governments, and I wouldn't want to jeopardize those. We acknowledge the seriousness of the alleged crime – unauthorized access to critical data. That's undeniable. I know the Prime Minister has raised this with our Ambassador and with me directly, and we're hopeful for a resolution that reflects our close alliance. We also talked about the broader issue of cybersecurity threats in the digital age. While traditional espionage remains a concern, the most significant vulnerabilities now lie in these digital breaches. We take this very seriously, and I know the British government does too. As a matter of policy, I don't typically intervene in extradition matters. My team will follow the legal process, while maintaining close coordination with our invaluable ally. We're confident we can find a solution that balances the gravity of the offense with the strength of our relationship. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding American oil production, specifically offshore drilling, are you satisfied with current output levels? Furthermore, will you finalize a long-term agreement with Iraq concerning U.S. military operations before leaving office, or defer that to your successor? [SEP] Well, let's address Iraq first. We're actively engaged in crafting a strategic framework with the Iraqi government, encompassing diplomatic, economic, and judicial cooperation. A key component is a security agreement, and they aspire to a swift transition to what we term 'overwatch.' This means U.S. forces will transition to a training, logistical support, and special operations role. Naturally, any troop presence requires a formal agreement, outlining operational authorities and troop protections. We're negotiating this concurrently, aiming for completion before year-end, unless the UN mandate is extended. These are distinct but related agreements, often conflated. As for oil...
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the situation in Ukraine and rising tensions in Asia, what specific assurances can you provide that the trilateral relationship between Japan, the U.S., and South Korea will effectively deter further aggression from Russia and China? [SEP] Well, let me be clear. North Korea's missile program, it's a problem. A big problem. And it affects our allies, Japan and South Korea. As for Ukraine, we're providing support, and we expect our allies to do the same. This summit, it wasn't about China, but we did discuss it. Look, this is a historic meeting. A big deal. We're building a structure for a lasting relationship that will have a phenomenal impact, not just in Asia, but around the world. Believe me.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. [Inaudible]—what are the chances, in your opinion, of achieving an agreement at Sochi on missile defense? [SEP] On Sochi, I don't know, but the chances are—advancing my logic is good, since I'll be there talking about it. And we'll see whether or not there's an agreement. But obviously, we've got work to do to convince the President and people around him that the missile defense system is not aimed at Russia. In other words, it's viewed as an anti-Russian device. Well, it's not, and therefore, it requires a lot of time, a lot of discussion. That's what Condi Rice and Bob Gates spent time doing when they were there in Russia, and that is to defuse any notions that this is aiming something at somebody in Europe. This is all aiming to protect people in Europe.Yes, I mean, the truth of the matter is, the Russian system could overwhelm the missile defense systems we have envisioned. I mean, these systems are designed to deal with, you know, limited launch capabilities. And they've got multiple launch capabilities. And so it's just—it requires a lot of work. We're dealing with a lot of history and a lot of suspicion throughout governments. And so the President and I will try to work through these for our common good. And I'm hopeful we can have some breakthroughs. We'll see.The other thing is, is that this will be my last chance to visit with him face to face, as you know, and I've worked with him for 8 years. We've had a very interesting relationship. I like him. He's a person that has been a strong leader for Russia. And my view all along has been that it's in our interest—our interests, Ukrainian interests, European interests—to be able to have a working relationship with Russia. And I've had that. And this will be a chance to say, I appreciate being able to work together, and to be able to try to find some common interests in the waning days of his Presidency.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: To be clear, did Syria's situation come up during these talks? [SEP] The topic of proliferation was a key element of the discussions.
label: Deflection

sentence: Regarding the Khashoggi case, Mr. President, are you prepared to state whether you believe Saudi Arabia is culpable, and what specific actions will the United States take in response? [SEP] This is a complex situation, and we are working diligently with all parties involved – Congress, Turkey, and Saudi Arabia – to gather all the facts. I anticipate having a more definitive assessment within the coming week. Let's move on.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Does anyone else need to go in the chain of command? [SEP] I am confident that we've got a team in place that can execute. Now, I'm paying very close attention to make sure that they execute, and I will be insisting on extraordinary performance moving forward.One last thing I just want to remind everybody, though, that the issues with General McChrystal that culminated in my decision yesterday were not as a result of a difference in policy. I want to be very clear about that. He was executing the policy that I had laid out; that he was executing the orders that I had issued and that were reflective of the review process that took place last year. Okay? I'll try to be even briefer than my colleague, Mr. President. You know, I hope that we have quite friendly relations with President Obama, but I try not to give pieces of advice that cannot be fulfilled. This is a hard topic, a difficult one. I can say only two things. First of all, we believe that, at present, the United States and some other countries are assisting the Afghan people in obtaining the much wanted statehood and restore the basis of the functioning of an effective state, restore their civil society and their economy. And in these terms, we will support and back the efforts of the U.S.As far as our own experience, well-known experiences--[inaudible]--I would very much like to see the Afghan people in near future having an effective state and a modern economy, which requires toiling more than a year. But this is the path to guarantee that the most--the gravest scenarios of the last time will not repeat.Please, ITAR-TASS.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, what do you say to Americans to convince them that they should trust the independence and fairness of the Justice Department when your predecessor, Donald Trump, repeatedly attacks it? [SEP] Because you notice I have never once—not one single time—suggested to the Justice Department what they should do or not do, relative to bringing a charge or not bringing a charge. I'm honest.Thank you.[]
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Nigeria's request for those Tucano aircraft – crucial for their security situation – is there any chance of getting at least a couple of them delivered before 2020? And, on a lighter note, any plans to visit Nigeria in the near future? [SEP] Nigeria, beautiful place. I'd love to go. Heard it's one of the most beautiful countries. Now, remind me about the first question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Number one, do you want to reverse the law that Congressman Marino helped pass that DEA whistleblowers say has contributed to the expansion of the opioid crisis? [SEP] We're going to look at that very closely.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the aid to Puerto Rico, why such a delay? Was there a specific obstacle preventing its earlier approval? [SEP] Look, getting anything through Congress these days is like pulling teeth, especially when the Democrats are playing politics. We've been pushing for this package, and it's a substantial one, believe me. But the real game-changer here isn't just the money; it's revitalizing the pharmaceutical industry on the island. They were driven out by tax changes, and we're bringing them back. That's the real victory, folks.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Russia, some suggest your Democratic opponents lacked knowledge about Dmitry Medvedev. What's your take on him, particularly his power relative to Putin? And what counsel would you give your successor regarding the Russian challenge, given past criticisms of your Putin strategy? [SEP] Medvedev? Can't say I know him well either. The key is seeing who represents Russia at events like the G-8. That'll hint at Russia's foreign policy after Putin. But I can't give you a solid answer right now. What I can tell you is that keeping relations with Russia is crucial. We need their help on things like proliferation and Iran. Remember when Putin offered to give enriched uranium to Iran's Bushehr plant, so they wouldn't need to enrich it themselves? That was a good thing. We need to be able to work with Russia on Iran. There are lots of areas where we need to cooperate. Like missile defense in Europe, which I talked about with the Czech Prime Minister. We need to make the Russians understand that the system isn't aimed at them, but at real threats like rogue states with weapons of mass destruction. So, I'm going to try to make sure my successor can have a relationship with whoever's running foreign policy in Russia. It's in our country's interest. Doesn't mean we'll always agree. We didn't on Kosovo, and there will be other disagreements. But a relationship, leader to leader and beyond, is essential.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: So, Mr. President, to be clear, regardless of the specifics in any debt ceiling legislation, you're standing firm? [SEP] Look, the only thing I'm saying is this: America doesn't negotiate with itself. We're not going to pay a ransom to do what's right. It's a matter of principle. We're talking about the full faith and credit of the United States. This isn't some game we're playing. It's about the economic security of every American. You don't mess around with that. It's like saying you're not going to pay your bills. That's just not acceptable. We need to be responsible, and that means paying our debts. It's that simple.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, in the post-Brexit landscape, will the United States prioritize its relationship with President Macron and France, representing the EU, or with Prime Minister Boris Johnson of the United Kingdom? [SEP] Look, France is a great nation. Macron is trying to do some things, and you know, it's not easy. It's not easy what he's doing. He's changing certain ways. It's a very hard thing to do. I won't get into it. I'm going to let him sell his ideas. But a lot of people don't disagree with his ideas. But it's a very hard thing to do if you're a great citizen of France. You love your country, but you want to do the way you've been doing it for a long time. But maybe that's not working. And maybe they have to do what he has to do. I think he's going to do a fantastic job. But it's very tough for him. I know how tough it is for him. He's been having a hard time. And nobody would have any easy time. But I do believe he is doing the right thing. Boris is different. It's a different kind of a deal. Boris has to try and do something with Brexit. It's very tough. I deal with the EU. The EU is--that's a very, very strong group of people. They have their ideas, and they're not easy to deal with, I will tell you. We've very close to making a deal, by the way, with the EU. I have to say this. We made a great deal with Japan. And we're very close to maybe making a deal with the EU. Because they don't want tariffs; it's very simple. They don't want to tax cars. Mercedes Benz, BMW, they don't need a 20-percent or a 25-percent tax. But we're very close. I think we're going to make a deal with the EU without having to go that route. I may have to go that route, but maybe not. We're going to have a deal, a really fair deal. But the EU is another one. We've been losing $180 billion a year for many years. That's a lot of money. How much can you take out of the piggy bank, right?
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, [inaudible] from the Associated Press. Did you and President Xi discuss the possibility of international observers verifying the dismantling of North Korea's nuclear facilities? [SEP] I'm having a little trouble hearing you. Could you speak up, please? And remind me, which news organization are you with?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, given the failure of cap-and-trade, are you willing to let the EPA regulate carbon emissions, and do you regret any compromises you made to pass the Affordable Care Act, even if it meant a less ideal bill? [SEP] Well, let me say this: Healthcare for families is a top priority. But the process was messy, and I regret that. As for the EPA, we need to find bipartisan solutions on energy and climate. Cap-and-trade wasn't the only way to go. We're looking at all options to address this problem without hurting the economy.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the significant investment already made, what specific metrics will the American people use to determine if your economic recovery initiatives are successful? Should they watch the stock market, housing market stability, or job creation figures, and what timeframe should they expect to see positive outcomes, or will alternative strategies be considered? [SEP] The key to our success is jobs, period. If we can get people back to work, they'll have the confidence to spend, businesses will invest, and the economy will grow. We also need to fix the credit markets so businesses can get the loans they need. And finally, we need to stabilize the housing market, working with the Fed and the FDIC to prevent foreclosures and support housing values. The bottom line is, if we can stop losing jobs and start growing again, we'll know we're on the right track. It's going to be a difficult year, but I'm optimistic that we'll see progress next year. Who's got the next question?
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. So, are you planning a visit anytime soon? [SEP] Pardon me, could you repeat that? I didn't quite catch it.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, are you confident that this legislation will be passed within the first year of your administration? [SEP] We're aiming for progress this year, and I'm pushing as hard as I can. Some say I'm trying to do too much at once. We're moving full steam ahead. Ultimately, I don't control the legislative calendar. We'll be working with congressional leaders to see what we can achieve.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Afghanistan, what are your thoughts on the reported talks between the Taliban and President Karzai, facilitated by Pakistan? Do you see promise, or are you concerned? Also, do you agree with Prime Minister David Cameron that we can be completely out of Afghanistan by 2015? [SEP] Not sure about that Cameron quote, but let's talk about Afghanistan. We've been there for nine years, almost a decade. It's our longest war. We all want a stable Afghanistan, able to handle its own security and not a place for terrorists to attack us. We'll need to help them for a long time, building their government, courts, police, and a fair system. But that's not the same as having troops there. We announced a plan last November to send more troops to give the Afghan government room to build its forces, push back the Taliban, and improve things. General Petraeus is doing that, and our allies and President Karzai are on board. It's tough, given Afghanistan's problems. We hope to see progress by the end of the year. We'll check on things and make changes as needed. Like in Iraq, we need a political solution. As for the talks, it's too soon to say. We need to be careful but open. The Taliban is a mixed bag. President Karzai's efforts and talks between Afghanistan and Pakistan are good steps. We need everyone in the region to see that a stable Afghanistan-Pakistan is good for everyone. Next question?
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. What about the insularity criticism that you hear on the Hill? [SEP] I've got to say I meet with an awful lot of folks, and I talk to an awful lot of folks every day. And I have lunches with CEOs and IT venture capitalists and labor leaders and pretty much folks from all walks of life on a whole bunch of topics. And if you looked at my schedule on any given day, we're interacting with a whole lot of people.And I think it's fair to say that we have a pretty good track record of working with folks on technology and IT from our campaign where, both in 2008 and 2012, we did a pretty darn good job on that. So it's not—the idea that somehow we didn't have access or were interested in people's ideas, I think isn't accurate. What is true is that, as I said before, our IT systems, how we purchase technology in the Federal Government is cumbersome, complicated, and outdated.And so this isn't a situation where—on my campaign, I could simply say, who are the best folks out there? Let's get them around a table. Let's figure out what we're doing, and we're just going to continue to improve it and refine it and work on our goals. If you're doing it at the Federal Government level, you're going through 40 pages of specs and this and that and the other, and there are all kinds of laws involved, and it makes it more difficult. It's part of the reason why, chronically, Federal IT programs are over budget, behind schedule.And one of the—when I do some Monday morning quarterbacking on myself, one of the things that I do recognize is—since I know that the Federal Government has not been good at this stuff in the past—2 years ago, as we were thinking about this, we might have done more to make sure that we were breaking the mold on how we were going to be setting this up. But that doesn't help us now. We've got to move forward.Jeff Mason [Reuters].
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Why do you think it's appropriate to invite Russia to the G-7, given that they've meddled in the 2016 election? And are you worried that if Russia does come to the G-7, that it might hurt you politically, because it's only going to be a couple months before the 2020 election? [SEP] I don't care politically. I really don't. A lot of people don't understand this. I ran one election, and I won. It happened to be for President. I don't care politically. I'm going to run another election. I think I'm winning based on polls that we see. Whether I win or not, I have to do the right thing.So I don't do things for political reasons. Is it good? Probably not. Maybe it is. I mean, a lot of people are smart. A lot of people say having Russia—which is a power—having them inside the room is better than having them outside the room. By the way, there were numerous people during the G-7 that felt that way. And we didn't take a vote or anything, but we did discuss it.My inclination is to say, Yes, they should be in. They were—really, it was a President Obama—I'm not blaming him, but a lot of bad things happened with President Putin and President Obama. One of the things that happened was, as you know, what happened in—with a very big area—a very, very big and important area in the Middle East, where the redline was drawn, and then President Obama decided that he was not going to do anything about it. You can't draw redlines in the sand. You just can't do it.And the other was in Ukraine having to do with a certain section of Ukraine that you know very well, where it was sort of taken away from President Obama. Not taken away from President Trump; taken away from President Obama. President Obama was not happy that this happened, because it was embarrassing to him. Right? It was very embarrassing to him. And he wanted Russia to be out of the—what was called the G-8. And that was his determination. He was outsmarted by Putin. He was outsmarted. President Putin outsmarted President Obama.
label: Explicit

sentence: But, President Bush, looking back, do you believe Israel's actions were justified? [SEP] David, I'm not going to be drawn into commenting on that particular issue.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, you've spoken of changing the tone in Washington, but before the election, you accused Democrats of wanting terrorists to win in Iraq. Has something changed? [SEP] What's changed is the election is over, and the Democrats won. We'll work together for two years to achieve big things for the country. The Democrats need to decide how they'll operate. I haven't spoken with the leadership yet, but we'll start consultations with them soon.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Did you discuss or agree with them on further sanctions? [SEP] The—at this point, the sanctions that we have in place are biting plenty good. We retain the capabilities, and we have our teams constantly looking at mechanisms in which to turn up additional pressure as necessary.With respect to Keystone, I've said consistently—and I think I repeated in Burma, but I guess I've got to answer it one more time—we're going to let the process play itself out. And the determination will be made in the first instance by the Secretary of State. But I won't hide my opinion about this, which is that one major determinant of whether we should approve a pipeline shipping Canadian oil to world markets, not to the United States, is, does it contribute to the greenhouse gases that are causing climate change?
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, less than 2 months ago, at the end of one of the bloodiest months in the war, you said, Absolutely we're winning. Yesterday you said, We're not winning; we're not losing. Why did you drop your confident assertion about winning? [SEP] My comments—the first comment was done in this spirit: I believe that we're going to win. I believe that— and by the way, if I didn't think that, I wouldn't have our troops there. That's what you got to know; we're going to succeed.My comments yesterday reflected the fact that we're not succeeding nearly as fast as I wanted when I said it at the time and that conditions are tough in Iraq, particularly in Baghdad. And so we're conducting a review to make sure that our strategy helps us achieve that which I'm pretty confident we can do, and that is have a country which can govern itself, sustain itself, and defend itself.You know, I—when I speak, like right now, for example—I'm speaking to the American people, of course, and I want them to know that I know how tough it is, but I also want them to know that I'm going to work with the military and the political leaders to develop a plan that will help us achieve the objective. I also want our troops to understand that we support them, that I believe that tough mission I've asked them to do is going to be accomplished, and that they're doing good work and necessary work.I want the Iraqis to understand that we believe that if they stand up—step up and lead—and with our help, we can accomplish the objective. And I want the enemy to understand that this is a tough task, but they can't run us out of the Middle East, that they can't intimidate America. They think they can. They think it's just a matter of time before America grows weary and leaves, abandons the people of Iraq, for example. And that's not going to happen.What is going to happen is we're going to develop a strategy that helps the Iraqis achieve the objective that the 12 million people want them to achieve, which is a government that can—a country that can sustain itself, govern itself, defend itself, a free country that will serve as an ally in this war against extremists and radicals.Caren [Caren Bohan, Reuters].
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. We're seeing judges, most recently in Detroit, limit police ability to use nonlethal force. My first question would be: Should the police be allowed to use nonlethal force to quell the violence in their cities? [SEP] We're talking about where? Nonlethal force?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Sir, considering the evolving dynamics in Russia, what insights can you offer your successor regarding the challenges and opportunities presented by the new leadership? [SEP] That's a question best answered by historians, not me. I'm focused on the present. But I would advise any future president to proceed with caution and always prioritize American security.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, you expressed surprise and disappointment regarding the recent election results. Does this indicate a disconnect between you and the American people after six years in office, considering you didn't anticipate such a significant shift? Furthermore, does Nancy Pelosi remind you of Bob Bullock? [SEP] That's an inside joke; I'm not commenting on it. Secondly, I'm an optimistic person, is what I am. And I knew we were going to lose seats; I just didn't know how many.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, about the NHS, is it up for negotiation? [SEP] Pardon?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the historical context of US-Chile relations, specifically concerning the Pinochet era and potential US involvement, will your administration commit to fully cooperating with Chilean judicial investigations, including the possibility of a formal apology for past actions? [SEP] Look, what's done is done. We can't rewrite history, and frankly, dwelling on the past doesn't serve anyone. We're focused on the future, on building a stronger partnership with Chile based on mutual respect and shared economic goals. Any requests for information will be reviewed, but let's not get bogged down in old grievances when there's so much progress to be made.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Given the evolving dynamics between Russia and the West, particularly concerning figures like Dmitry Medvedev and Vladimir Putin, what specific strategies would you advise your successor to adopt in navigating this complex relationship, especially considering past criticisms of misjudging Putin's intentions? [SEP] Well, to be frank, I'm not deeply familiar with Medvedev's current standing. The real question is who represents Russia on the world stage, at events like the G-8. That will tell you everything. As for advice, I can't give a complete answer yet. However, maintaining a working relationship with Russia is vital, especially on issues like nuclear proliferation and Iran. Putin's past cooperation on Iran's nuclear program was constructive. We also need to work with Russia to address mutual security concerns, such as missile defense in Europe. The goal is to ensure they understand our systems aren't aimed at them, but at genuine threats. Ultimately, my successor needs the flexibility to engage with whoever leads Russia, even when disagreements arise, because it's in our national interest.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President Bush, concerning trade relations with Uruguay, how adaptable is your administration in securing a trade agreement, and what specific agreements were reached today? Furthermore, President Vazquez, did you request President Bush to mediate the dispute between Uruguay and Argentina regarding the paper mill construction? [SEP] We dedicated a significant portion of our discussion to addressing Uruguay's concerns regarding market access for certain goods. The President highlighted various trade-related issues, focusing on the perceived unfairness of quotas on items like beef and lamb. I assured him that I would seriously consider his requests. You might have thought I was joking about blueberries, but I wasn't. Uruguay produces truly exceptional blueberries, and the fundamental question is whether those blueberry growers will have the opportunity to sell their products in the United States. So, we discussed a wide array of agricultural products. I emphasized to the President that problems can only be resolved if they are brought to the table. Where we can offer assistance, we will; where we cannot, I will provide a clear explanation. You raised the issue of protectionist tendencies, which I find concerning both within our own country and on a global scale. I firmly believe that free and fair trade promotes poverty reduction. Therefore, I am a strong advocate for completing the Doha round of the WTO. I shared our strategies for advancing the Doha round with President Lula, who expressed keen interest in our conversations. I did not disclose any confidential information, but I discussed how we can move the Doha round forward. The United States is fully prepared to reduce agricultural subsidies, as I explained to the President, but we require market access for our products. I conveyed this message to President Lula, the Europeans, and President Vazquez. I am optimistic about reaching a deal. Our trade minister, Susan Schwab, remains in Sao Paulo to continue discussions with her Brazilian counterpart, aiming to make progress on this complex but essential agreement. Thank you. In response to your first question, I fully agree with President Bush's remarks. This meeting has established a platform for our experts and ministers to discuss and advance bilateral relations. Regarding the broader multilateral situation, Uruguay advocates for free trade and the reduction of tariffs and subsidies that impede the sale of our cultural products. We have also explored the possibility of advancing the GSP, particularly on issues to be considered in the coming weeks. As for your second question, I did not discuss our issues with Argentina with President Bush, partly because we will be engaging in dialogue with Argentina in a few weeks, thanks to the conciliation efforts of His Majesty, the King of Spain. We will not be negotiating but rather engaging in a dialogue to find a friendly resolution and overcome our unfortunate differences with our Argentine brethren.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Beyond Huawei, are there any other Chinese technology companies that are currently under review for potential operational bans within the United States? [SEP] Well, the big one is Huawei, isn't it? Huawei's not here, and I'm not letting them in. I've told European countries and others – Australia's been great, for example – that Huawei's not coming here. We even told some countries considering Huawei that they could use them, but we wouldn't share intelligence. They all backed away. Look at the UK, they seemed to be going that way, but now they've backed out – Scotland Yard.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, given that the surge troops were largely deployed during the July report's writing, will you maintain the surge even if General Petraeus advises against it, should Iraq fail to show political progress by September? [SEP] Let's hold off on hypotheticals. I'd like to hear General Petraeus's assessment in September before committing to anything. After that briefing, I'll gladly answer your question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. And your views about qualifications, has that changed after meeting with him? [SEP] I think that he successfully mobilized a big chunk of the country to vote for him, and he's going to winhe has won. He's going to be the next President. And regardless of what experience or assumptions he brought to the office, this office has a way of waking you up. And those aspects of his positions or predispositions that don't match up with reality he will find shaken up pretty quick, because reality has a way of asserting itself.And some of his gifts that obviously allowed him to execute one of the biggest political upsets in history, those are ones that, hopefully, he will put to good use on behalf of all the American people.Scott Horsley [NPR].
label: Dodging

sentence: President Park, regarding North Korea's denuclearization, you emphasized international collaboration. Could you elaborate on your discussions with President Obama on this matter, and what are your perspectives on the roles of Russia and China? President Obama, what are your impressions of Kim Jong Un, and what message would you convey to him today? [SEP] On North Korea, our shared objective, along with the global community, is denuclearization and their integration as a responsible member. This promotes peace in the region and supports North Korea's progress. To encourage this, we must collaborate. China's influence is considerable, making their involvement essential. We addressed this. China and Russia, with the international community, share the goal of a denuclearized Korean Peninsula and are working together. China has been active in adopting and enforcing U.N. resolutions on North Korea's missile launches and nuclear tests. Russia also supports denuclearization and has backed U.N. resolutions. They helped include a strong message to North Korea in the G-8 Foreign Ministers' statement. These efforts are crucial to conveying a unified message that their nuclear weapons are unacceptable and urging them to make the right decision. I don't know Kim Jong Un personally and can't judge his character. But his actions have been provocative and futile. We'll maintain a strong deterrent and not reward provocation. However, we're open to North Korea pursuing denuclearization, honoring commitments, rejoining the international community, and achieving security and prosperity. If North Korea's current path hasn't led to a strong, prosperous nation, Kim Jong Un should change course. If he does, we and the world would welcome it. China, Russia, Japan, and others in the six-party talks have made this clear. But behavior must change. As they say, 'Actions speak louder than words.' So far, North Korea hasn't shown a willingness to change.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, about Russia, the Democratic candidates seemed clueless about Dmitry Medvedev. What's your read on him, especially his power compared to Putin? Some say you got Putin wrong. What advice would you give your successor on dealing with Russia and its new leader? [SEP] Truth be told, I don't know much about Medvedev either. Watching who shows up for Russia at the G-8 will be interesting, it'll give us a clue about their foreign policy after Putin. Can't answer fully yet. We need to keep talking to Russia, especially about stopping nukes from spreading and Iran. Putin's idea to give them enriched uranium for Bushehr was good. We need to work with Russia on Iran. Missile defense in Europe, too. We have to make sure Russia knows it's not about them, but about real threats. So, we need to work together. I want whoever comes after me to be able to talk to whoever's running things in Russia. It's good for the country, even if we don't always agree, like on Kosovo. Gotta keep talking.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Hillary Clinton: nominee, yes or no? [SEP] Excuse me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. President Putin, did you want President Trump to win the election? And did you direct any of your officials to help him do that? President Putin. Yes, I did. Yes, I did. Because he talked about bringing the U.S.-Russia relationship back to normal.I think there can be three questions from the Russian pool.Russia Today, you have the floor.Israel/Syria/Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) Terrorist Organization [The reporter spoke in Russian, and his remarks were translated by an interpreter as follows.] Q. Thank you so much. And good evening to everyone. My name is Ilya Petrenko, RT TV Channel.[The reporter spoke in English as follows.] Q. First question for Mr. Trump, in English. Mr. President, would you please go into the details of possibly any specific arrangements for the U.S. to work together with Russia in Syria, if any of these kind of arrangements were made today or discussed?[The reporter spoke in Russian, and his remarks were translated by an interpreter as follows.] Q. And my question to President Putin, in Russian: Since we brought up the issue of football several times, I ask—I use the football language. Mr. Pompeo mentioned that, when we talk about the Syrian cooperation, the ball is in the Syrian court. Mr. Putin—in the Russian court—is it true? And how would you use this fact, the having the ball? [SEP] Well, I guess I'll answer the first part of the question We've worked with Israel long and hard for many years, many decades I think we've never—never has anyone, any country been closer than we are President Putin also is helping Israel And we both spoke with Bibi Netanyahu, and they would like to do certain things with respect to Syria having to do with the safety of Israel So in that respect, we absolutely would like to work in order to help Israel, and Israel will be working with us So both countries would work jointlyAnd I think that, when you look at all of the progress that's been made in certain sections with the eradication of ISIS—we're about 98 percent, 99 percent there—and other things that have taken place that we've done, and that, frankly, Russia has helped us with in certain respects But I think that working with Israel is a great thing, and creating safety for Israel is something that both President Putin and I would like to see very muchOne little thing I might add to that is the helping of people—helping of people Because you have such horrible, if you see—and I've seen reports and I've seen pictures, I've seen just about everything And if we can do something to help the people of Syria get back into some form of shelter and—on a humanitarian basis And that's what the word was, really, a humanitarian basis I think that both of us would be very interested in doing that, and we are We will do thatThank you very muchRussia-US Military Coordination
label: Explicit

sentence: Considering the difficulties of the past year, especially the healthcare rollout, what single decision do you most regret as President? [SEP] Are you asking about healthcare-related missteps, or a broader assessment of my time in office?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, you seemed surprised by the recent election results. Does this suggest you're out of touch with the American people? And, if I may, does Nancy Pelosi remind you of Bob Bullock? [SEP] That's an inside joke. I'm not going there. Look, I'm an optimist. I knew we'd lose some seats, but I didn't know how many.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, isn't it true that your administration relies almost exclusively on public opinion to pressure Congress into action? [SEP] The American system is predicated on the will of the people. Presently, we have a Speaker and a Senate Majority Leader. My responsibility is to articulate our vision and mobilize the public. While support hasn't always been unanimous, as evidenced by the debt ceiling vote, we continue to advocate for our policies. The election is approaching, and I would prefer to focus on governance rather than campaigning. However, I am faced with a legislative body whose primary objective appears to be opposition. Consequently, engaging the public is crucial. Where's David?
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, it sounds like you're offering some way out here, some off-ramp. And it sounds like what it is, is—at least in the informal assurance—that NATO is not going to take in Ukraine anytime in the next few decades. And it sounds like you're saying we would never put nuclear weapons there. He also wants us to move all of our nuclear weapons out of Europe and not have troops rotating through the old Soviet bloc.Do you think there's space for there as well? [SEP] No. No, there's not space for that. We won't permanently station. But the idea we're not going to—we're going to actually increase troop presence in Poland, in Romania, et cetera, if in fact he moves because we have a sacred obligation in article 5 to defend those countries. They are part of NATO. We don't have that obligation relative to Ukraine, although we have great concern about what happens in Ukraine.Thank you.Maureen [Maureen Groppe], USA Today.
label: Explicit

sentence: Ghislaine Maxwell's trial has concluded, and she now faces sentencing. Are you concerned about the potential fallout for prominent individuals who may have been associated with her? [SEP] I haven't been paying much attention to the case. I wish her well. I've met her a few times, especially when I lived in Palm Beach. I'm not aware of the details regarding Prince Andrew.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue your policies disproportionately favor the wealthy. How do you respond to accusations that your administration is enacting a form of plutocracy? [SEP] Look, the beauty of our democracy is that everyone gets a voice, loud and clear, even those who disagree with me. I've heard the complaints, the protests, the whole nine yards. But let's be real, elections have consequences, and the people spoke. Now, I'm not telling anyone to shut up, but I am saying that voting matters, getting involved matters, knowing your stuff matters. And to all those young folks out there, don't take our system for granted. It's not a given. It's hard work. If half the country doesn't even bother to vote, then democracy's in trouble. If we can't tell the difference between facts and fake news, we're in deep trouble. And if everyone's just screaming at each other and refusing to budge, then the whole thing falls apart. So, my advice? Understand how democracy works, and be a citizen, not just when you're mad about something. It's a constant job. And yeah, there's always room for improvement. We've made mistakes, no doubt about it. But this country's been a force for good, a beacon of freedom. Don't forget that. Don't let the noise drown out the truth. It's easy to get caught up in the misinformation, the clickbait, the outrage. But we need to protect what we've built, what we've fought for. Anyway, what was the second part of the question? I got a bit carried away there.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the House immigration bill and the situation in Mexico, how do you see these developments impacting comprehensive immigration reform and U.S.-Mexico relations? [SEP] I commend the Senate's Gang of Eight for their work on immigration reform. While their bill isn't exactly what I would have drafted, it aligns with my core principles: enhanced border security, employer accountability, streamlined legal immigration, and a tough but achievable path to citizenship. I'll review the House proposal with an open mind, assessing whether it meets these same criteria. As for Mexico, I anticipate productive discussions with President Peña Nieto on strengthening our economic partnership while addressing security concerns. Refinements in Mexican law enforcement coordination are primarily internal matters for Mexico.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, if there were no threats made, were there any ultimatums given concerning ransomware? Furthermore, how will we gauge the success of these working groups focused on Russian meddling and cybersecurity? [SEP] The metric is clear. Regarding cybersecurity, will they take action against ransomware criminals operating within their borders? They haven't yet. Did they orchestrate it? Unlikely. But will they act now? Time will tell. Will we commit to actions addressing violations of international norms that negatively impact us? What agreements can we reach? There are opportunities for progress. People are beginning to grasp the potential severity. Imagine a ransomware group in Florida targeting their oil supply. Catastrophic. It's in everyone's interest to act decisively. We'll observe the outcomes of these groups.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Obama, is Chen Guangcheng in U.S. custody in Beijing? How will this end? Asylum on the table? Prime Minister Noda, North Korea nuclear test imminent? Japan's reaction? U.S. role? [SEP] I'm aware of the reports, but I'm not commenting on Chen. We consistently raise human rights with . We believe it's the right thing and makes stronger. On North Korea, our alliance is key. Provocations bring isolation. They must adhere to international norms. Your thoughts, Prime Minister?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, what is the strategy for overcoming this global vaccine access gap? Will the US pledge additional vaccine shipments abroad? And realistically, with the current disparities, is ending the pandemic by 2022 still a viable objective? [SEP] It might require a slightly extended timeline on a global scale. The United States remains steadfast in its commitment. There exists a possibility, stretching from 2022 into 2023, that we could facilitate the provision of an additional billion doses. However, such arrangements are not yet finalized. Throughout this pandemic, I have endeavored to communicate what I know and what I believe can be accomplished. I am wary of making promises that I cannot fulfill. There was a clear consensus among our G-7 counterparts that this endeavor is ongoing; we will persist until we can adequately address the needs of the entire world. This is not only the morally correct course of action, but also the strategically prudent one, in terms of our own health and security. No wall can be erected high enough to prevent the ingress of novel viral strains. Consequently, this will be a sustained project, and the potential for future pandemics remains. We must establish a system capable of detecting, before it spirals out of control, a pandemic or a virus that may be on the horizon. Thus, for as long as there are nations in need of vaccination, we will continue to engage. Moreover, we have been actively involved in assisting, as I have made clear, and as most of my colleagues understood, as they knew from trying it themselves, this is a gargantuan logistical undertaking. It is one thing to dispatch X number of vaccines to nation Y; it is quite another to ensure that there are individuals capable of administering them. Accordingly, we are also providing the means for other countries to manufacture their own vaccines. We have all agreed on this. India possesses the capacity to do so, though they currently lack the requisite material resources. Much is underway to provide not only vaccines, but also the capacity for the countries in question to produce their own vaccines. Last question. Last question. The President. Just kidding. Last question. Peter Alexander, NBC News.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: As you prepare for your final foreign trip, what assurances can you offer world leaders who have expressed concerns about your successor, Donald Trump, and the future of U.S. foreign policy? And, in light of the Democratic Party's recent defeat, what guidance can you provide regarding the party's future direction and leadership? [SEP] Well, one of the great things about the United States is that when it comes to world affairs, the President obviously is the leader of the executive branch, the Commander in Chief, the spokesperson for the Nation, but the influence and the work that we have is the result not just of the President. It is the result of countless interactions and arrangements and relationships between our military and other militaries and our diplomats and other diplomats and intelligence officers and development workers. And there is enormous continuity beneath the day-to-day news that makes us that indispensable nation when it comes to maintaining order and promoting prosperity around the world. That will continue. In my conversation with the President-elect, he expressed a great interest in maintaining our core strategic relationships. And so one of the messages I will be able to deliver is his commitment to NATO and the transatlantic alliance. I think that's one of the most important functions I can serve at this stage, during this trip, is to let them know that there is no weakening of resolve when it comes to America's commitment to maintaining a strong and robust NATO relationship and a recognition that those alliances aren't just good for Europe, they're good for the United States, and they're vital for the world.With respect to the Democratic Party, look, as I said in the Rose Garden right after the election, when your team loses, everybody gets deflated, and it's hard, and it's challenging. And so I think it's a healthy thing for the Democratic Party to go through some reflection. I think it's important for me not to be big-footing that conversation. I think we want to see new voices and new ideas emerge. That's part of the reason why I think term limits are a really useful thing.I think the Democrats should not waver on our core beliefs and principles: the belief that we should have an economy that works for everybody, not just a few; the belief that America, at its best, is inclusive and not exclusive, that we insist on the dignity and God-given potential and worth of every child, regardless of race or gender or sexual orientation or what ZIP Code they were born in. That we are committed to a world in which we keep America safe, but we recognize that our power doesn't just flow from our extraordinary military, it also flows from the strength of our ideals and our principles and our values.So there are going to be a core set of values that shouldn't be up for debate, should be our north star. But how we organize politically I think is something that we should spend some time thinking about. I believe that we have better ideas. But I also believe that good ideas don't matter if people don't hear them. And one of the issues that Democrats have to be clear on is that, given population distribution across the country, we have to compete everywhere. We have to show up everywhere. We have to work at a grassroots level, something that's been a running thread in my career.I won Iowa not because the demographics dictated that I would win Iowa, it was because I spent 87 days going to every small town and fair and fish fry and VFW hall. And there were some counties where I might have lost, but maybe I lost by 20 points instead of 50 points. There are some counties maybe I won that people didn't expect because people had a chance to see you and listen to you and get a sense of who you stood for and who you were fighting for.And the challenge for a national party is, how do you dig in there and create those kinds of structures so that people have a sense of what it is that you stand for? And that increasingly is difficult to do just through a national press strategy. It's increasingly difficult to do because of the splintering of the press.And so I think the discussions that have been taking place about how do you build more grassroots organizing, how do you build up State parties and local parties and schoolboard elections you're paying attention to and State rep races and city council racesthat all, I think, will contribute to stronger outcomes in the future.And I'm optimistic that will happen. And Ifor Democrats who are feeling completely discouraged, I've been trying to remind them everybody remembers my Boston speech in 2004; they may not remember me showing up here in 2005 when John Kerry had lost a close election, Tom Daschle, the leader of the Senate, had been beaten in an upset. Ken Salazar and I were the only two Democrats that won nationally. Republicans controlled the Senate and the House. And 2 years later, Democrats were winning back Congress, and 4 years later, I was President of the United States.Things change pretty rapidly. But it doesn'tthey don't change inevitably. They change because you work for it. Nobody said democracy is supposed to be easy. This is hard. And in a big country like this, it probably should be hard.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Bush, will the US intervene to bolster the dollar if verbal assurances fail? What's your reaction to Saudi Arabia's energy summit proposal? Prime Minister Jansa, how are rising energy costs and the strong euro impacting Eastern and Central Europe, potentially hindering growth? President Barroso, are EU food safety regulations overly restrictive, causing friction with the US? [SEP] Okay, John, interesting idea by the—His Majesty, the King of Saudi Arabia. Secondly, I articulated a policy that I had been articulating ever since I have been the President. It's the same policy, which is, we believe in a strong dollar and that relative value of economies will end up setting the proper valuation of the dollar. Past growth, or growth with little comparison in the his-tory—this is the growth of energy and food prices. And the food prices are going up due to high cost of energy or oil, and this has a significant effect on the economy in Slovenia and throughout Europe. This is one of the key questions being dealt with at the national level and at the level of the European institutions, as has been mentioned by President Barroso. This is a serious problem. It will, on the one hand, make us search long-term solutions. I have mentioned this in part before. And on the other hand, it will make us search short-term solutions, and one of these is energy efficiency.We have also discussed this at today's summit, and this is a strong message. The investment in research and development, the investment into what the economy can do, an economy that is less dependent on carbon, less dependent on fossil fuels, this will have a long-term strategic effect on the price.So the key is the technology. I remember the President of the United States saying 2 years ago at the summit meeting in Vienna that the key thing is investment in the development of new technologies. This is the key strategic reply to these challenge. And as far as the euro is concerned, on the one hand, we are satisfied and happy that euro is a strong currency. And since the 1st of January of last year, Slovenia is also part of the euro zone. And I can say that in the majority, the effects are positive. When calculating the high prices of oil in dollars, this slightly mitigates this jump. And on the other hand, this is also a problem for importers in the European Union. We wouldn't like to see a weak euro and a strong dollar.
label: Deflection

sentence: Regarding the National Health Service, Mr. President, is it negotiable in trade discussions? [SEP] Pardon? I didn't quite hear you.
label: Clarification

sentence: So, are we talking about a 'hard' Brexit? [SEP] Are we talking about a difficult situation?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, given Kuwait's expressed apprehension regarding Iran's JCPOA compliance, and with the U.S. advocating for extended sanctions at the U.N., can you elaborate on the specific assurances you provided to the Kuwaiti delegation during your discussions today? [SEP] The Kuwaitis are fantastic. They understand what we're doing in the Middle East. The deals we've made, the peace we're bringing. They're very excited, believe me. We talked about Iran, briefly. It's part of the bigger picture. We're pulling our troops out, securing the oil, and making deals. The previous administration made a terrible deal with Iran, but we're fixing it. The Middle East is straightening out, and everyone is tired of fighting. They want to be part of the deal, and they want security. It's all coming together beautifully.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. So, if the situation escalates, will you be prepared to make that decision, sir? [SEP] We're monitoring the situation closely. Time will tell what unfolds in the coming weeks.
label: General

sentence: Is Afghanistan wrapped up? Is the Taliban calling the shots? And why Ratcliffe again? [SEP] Well, he's a terrific man. He's been fantastic at everything he's done. He's highly respected. He wanted to wait until after the IG report came in, as you saw originally. I don't think he was officially or formally nominated. His name was thrown out. But he wanted to wait until after the IG report. The IG report has now come, and we've learned a lot of very bad things from the IG report, as you know very well.And I think he'll go through a process, and it will go fairly quickly. He's a very respected man, somebody that I've gotten that like; somebody who really has—he's someone who's really distinguished himself and, I think, over the last year and a half, 2 years, in particular. So we're very happy with that.As far as the Taliban is concerned, everybody wanted this to happen. The Taliban wanted it to happen. President Ghani was very much involved in this, as you know. And he's now dealing with the Taliban.But we're talking about 19 years we've been there. Nineteen years. And other Presidents have tried to do this. The Taliban has given a pledge—and a very strong pledge—and we'll see how that all works out. We hope it's going to work out very well. I think they have big incentives to do it, but they have to take care of the terrorists and kill the terrorists. We'll be working in a different kind of a fashion toward that end.But the job we've done has been fantastic—a fantastic one in terms of terrorists and terrorism, and it's time for our people to start coming home.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. What are your thoughts on the QAnon movement, given its growing popularity during the pandemic? [SEP] I'm not really following that closely. I'm focused on fighting the virus and getting the economy back on track. I've got a lot on my plate.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. Would the U.S. be willing to give up 5 Iranians held in Iraq if it would help persuade Iran to give up the 15 British sailors? [SEP] Steven, I said the other day that—first of all, the seizure of the sailors is indefensible by the ians and that I support the Blair Government's attempts to solve this issue peacefully. So we're in close consultation with the British Government. I also strongly support the Prime Minister's declaration that there should be no quid pro quos when it comes to the hostages.Let's see here—Baker, Baker [Peter Baker, Washington Post]. Are you here? Yes, there you are.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the rise of the QAnon movement, what are your views, and what message do you have for those who follow it? [SEP] I'm not really familiar with QAnon, other than I've heard they're fond of me, which I appreciate. I understand they're gaining popularity. From what I gather, these are individuals who are troubled by the state of affairs in cities like Portland and New York. They are patriots who are concerned about the direction of the country. So, I don't know much beyond that, except that they reportedly support me and want to see these problems in Democrat-controlled areas resolved. If the Democrats are unable to manage these cities, we'll deploy federal resources and rectify the situation promptly. Okay?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Given Stephen Bannon's appointment and the reluctance of some Republicans to join the transition team, how can you assure the world that President Trump will be a reliable partner to Europe and Germany? [SEP] I'm always optimistic. What makes me cautiously optimistic about my successor and the shift from campaign mode to governance is, there is something about the solemn responsibilities of that office, the extraordinary demands that are placed on the United States.
label: General

sentence: Q. But is that nonnegotiable? [SEP] Chip [Chip Reid, CBS News].
label: Dodging

sentence: President Obama, in light of the TPP's stalled progress in Congress, are you considering a different approach to gain its approval, especially after the Boeing and GE deals announced during your Vietnam trip? Should the agreement be modified to address currency manipulation? Also, your comments on the killing of Mullah Mansur and Pakistan's concerns? Does this signal a new offensive in Afghanistan, and are you concerned about a more extreme successor? [SEP] Regarding TPP, trade deals are always difficult. People always want a better deal, especially with multiple parties. And in an election year, some will play politics. But I'm confident we'll get it done because it's the right thing for America and the world. This is a fast-growing region, a huge market for us. They sell to us with low tariffs, but our goods face higher tariffs. This deal eliminates 18,000 taxes on U.S. goods. TPP also requires higher labor and environmental standards. I haven't seen a good reason why TPP will hurt us. American workers and businesses benefit. The politics will be noisy, like with past trade deals. But we got those done, and we'll get this done too. As for currency manipulation, we have transparency provisions in TPP. Some want stronger measures, but it's hard to know why a currency is falling and if it's being manipulated. Binding other countries' monetary policy would mean binding our own Federal Reserve, which we won't do. But we've improved provisions to address competitive devaluations. Finally, Mullah Mansur is dead. He targeted U.S. personnel in Afghanistan. This doesn't change our approach. We're not re-entering combat. We're helping Afghanistan secure itself. But when a leader targets U.S. personnel and resists peace, I must protect our people. That's the message. President Quang.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, can you elaborate on your interactions with the new French President and the objectives of Vice President Cheney's current mission to the Middle East? [SEP] With respect to the new leader of France, it is not my role to 'recruit' presidents. The electorate determines their leadership, and I will collaborate with whomever they choose. I did, in fact, engage in a conversation with President-elect Sarkozy shortly after his electoral victory, at approximately 8:03 Paris time, as I recall. I am appreciative that he accepted my call. Having previously met him, I found him to be an intelligent and dynamic individual. While we will undoubtedly encounter areas of both divergence and convergence, I anticipate a productive working relationship. Regarding Vice President Cheney's mission, his primary message to the Iraqi government is the imperative to accelerate progress, particularly in enacting legislation that fosters reconciliation. There is a sense of urgency in Washington, and they must recognize that. He will also be engaging with regional allies to address the issue of Iran. We are acutely aware of the potential ramifications should Iran acquire nuclear capabilities, and we are committed to forging a unified opposition. We have already secured the diplomatic support of the EU-3, Russia, and China, and we must maintain this solidarity. Furthermore, Vice President Cheney will emphasize the critical link between success in Iraq and the broader strategy for containing Iran. Premature withdrawal would embolden Iran. Therefore, his mission is of paramount importance, and I commend his efforts.
label: Dodging

sentence: Regarding the situation, when can we anticipate an official announcement? Furthermore, what is your assessment of the progress achieved by Asian nations? [SEP] Well, as you are aware, certain nations are demonstrating progress, while others are not. However, some are indeed advancing.
