As they continue to improve and approach the figures deemed appropriate by all parties – figures which are mutually understood and agreed upon – we shall proceed with the opening up process. Certain nations are progressing with considerable rapidity. We remain hopeful that we can expedite this process to the greatest extent possible. Next question, please.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, how are you doing, sir? [SEP] And if you'd like to ask some of the folks up here, it would be fine. Please.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, in light of China's actions against journalists, what steps are you prepared to take to defend the principles of press freedom and ensure that American reporters can operate freely around the world? [SEP] Press freedom is a fundamental value, and we will always stand up for the rights of journalists to report the news without fear of censorship or intimidation. We are engaging with the Chinese government to express our concerns about the expulsion of the Wall Street Journal reporters, and we are exploring all available options to ensure that American journalists can continue to operate freely in China. We are also working with our allies to promote press freedom around the world.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. And since you mentioned the overtime rules, I know it's been about 14 months since you asked the Labor Department to put those together. They went over to OMB last week. How soon might we see those? [SEP] Soon. And with respect to transportation, you're absolutely right that now is the time for us to get something done. I'm practical, and in order for us to get a transportation bill done, I've got to get cooperation from a Republican-controlled Congress. And so I'm in discussions with the majority and minority leaders in both Chambers, as well as the relevant committee chairpersons. We want to hear their ideas. We want to find out what's possible. I think that that's going to be something that we need to explore.But this is not an area where either side should be looking for political points. This did not used to be a partisan issue. Building roads, building bridges, building airports, sewer lines, dams, ports—this is how we grow. This is how America became an economic superpower, was investing in our people, investing in infrastructure, doing it better and faster and bigger than anybody else did. We should be doing the same thing now.The first Republican President, a proud native of my home State named Mr. Lincoln, even in the midst of civil war was looking at how we join the country together through our railways and our canals. We shouldn't be thinking smaller today. We need to be thinking bigger in this global economy.So my hope is, is that we have a chance to have a serious discussion and look at all potential revenue sources. What is absolutely true is, is that the Highway Trust Fund has consistently gotten smaller and smaller and smaller and inadequate for the needs. What's also true is patchwork approaches of 3 months or 6 months at a time don't make any sense. We need some sort of long-term solution.Nobody foresaw that we could actually get a doc fix done and actually solve the long-term problem there in terms of how we were managing Medicare payments for doctors. Who knows? Maybe we might see some intelligent bipartisan outbreaks over the next few months, because I think everybody recognizes this is important. All right?Thank you very much, everybody.
label: General

sentence: Regarding the upcoming bank bailout, will you mandate that banks use the money to ease credit and boost lending? And if not, how do you convince Americans this bailout will work when the previous one didn't? [SEP] Helene, I'm trying not to step on my Treasury Secretary's toes – he's got a press conference tomorrow, and you should all attend; he's going to knock it out of the park. But, like I told Jake, the crucial thing is: is credit flowing to the right places? To businesses, big and small? To consumers? Our plan is designed to make that happen. Tim will elaborate tomorrow. Major Garrett?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the potential for automatic cuts to Medicare and defense, are you prepared to veto any bill that alters the composition of those cuts, as suggested by Mr. Hensarling? And can you clarify your remarks regarding Prime Minister Netanyahu during the 'hot mic' incident with President Sarkozy? [SEP] With respect to the supercommittee, we negotiated a trillion dollars in cuts over the next 10 years. The whole idea of the sequester was to make sure that both sides felt obligated to move off rigid positions and do what was required to help the country. Now, I've put forward a very detailed approach that would achieve $3 trillion-plus in savings. It says everything's on the table. I'm not going to comment on whether I'd veto a particular bill until I actually see a bill. With respect to the hot mic in France, I'm not going to comment on conversations that I have with individual leaders.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. But do you understand when they say, is the President feeling our pain, especially as you were a community organizer? [SEP] I--look, I definitely feel folks' pain. Somebody is doing a book about the 10 letters that I get every day, and they came by to talk to me yesterday. And they said, what's the overwhelming impression that you get when you read these 10 letters a day? And what I told them is, I'm so inspired by the strength and resilience of the American people, but sometimes I'm also just frustrated by the number of people out there who are struggling, and you want to help every single one individually. You almost feel like you want to be a caseworker and just start picking up the phone and advocating for each of these people who are working hard, trying to do right by their families; oftentimes, through no fault of their own, they've had a tough time, particularly over these last couple of years.So yes, it's frustrating. But my job is to make sure that we're focused over the long term: Where is it that we need to go? And the most important thing I can do as President is make sure that we're living within our means, getting a budget that is sustainable, investing in the future, and growing the economy. If I do that, then that's probably the most help I can give to the most number of people.Jake Tapper [ABC News].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, what is your assessment of the potential for an economic recession? [SEP] You know, you need to talk to economists. I think I got a B in Econ 101. I got an A, however, in keeping taxes low—[]—and being fiscally responsible with the people's money. We've submitted a plan that will enable this budget to become balanced by 2012 so long as Congress learns to set priorities. And we can balance the budget without raising taxes.Caren [Caren Bohan, Reuters].
label: Deflection

sentence: Sir, the Attorney General's top aide has testified that Gonzales was more involved in the U.S. attorney firings than he's letting on. How can the American people trust an Attorney General who isn't being fully transparent? What's the timeline for him to repair this damage, and is it even possible? [SEP] Al Gonzales is an honorable man, and he has my full confidence. He's providing documents to Congress to get to the bottom of this. He'll testify and tell the truth. The U.S. attorneys serve at the pleasure of the President. I appointed them to 4-year terms, and they served those terms. I appreciate their service. It's a shame that these hearings have hurt their reputations. That wasn't the intention of anyone in my administration. Let me be clear: there's no credible evidence of any wrongdoing.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, concerning your VA nominee, Dr. Ronny Jackson, he's facing some pretty serious allegations. What's your understanding of the situation, and do you still intend to support his confirmation? [SEP] I'm not personally aware of the specific allegations, but I can tell you he's one of the finest people I know. Melania agrees. He's been the doctor for President Obama, President Bush, and myself. He's a great doctor. It was just a suggestion, and I know there are concerns about his experience. The Veterans Administration is very important to me, and we've accomplished a lot with the Accountability Act and other initiatives. We're also working on choice. We're going to take great care of our veterans. I even said to Admiral Jackson, 'Why do you want this?' It's a tough world. But he's an admiral, a great leader. They'll question everything. Look at Pompeo's confirmation; everyone was surprised. I heard he wouldn't be approved, but Rand Paul came through. Rand is a good man. I knew things others didn't. Rand changed his vote, and he was approved.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, many analysts and some former members of your administration believe that the kind of negotiated political settlement that you say is necessary in Syria will require working directly with Iran and giving Iran an important role. Do you agree? And is that a dialogue you'll be actively seeking? And what about the fight against ISIS? What would it take for there to be explicit cooperation between the U.S. and Iran? [SEP] The reality is, a resolution in Syria necessitates the involvement of all stakeholders – Russia, Iran, Turkey, and our allies in the Gulf. The situation is incredibly complex, with numerous factions, significant financial resources, and a surplus of weaponry. It's become entangled in both sectarian conflicts and geopolitical power plays. To achieve a resolution, the major powers with vested interests in Syria must acknowledge that a military victory is unattainable. Iran is undoubtedly a key player and must be included in these discussions. However, let me reiterate that we have not re-established normal diplomatic relations with Iran, nor do I foresee doing so in the near future. Therefore, I do not anticipate any formal agreements with Iran regarding our counter-ISIS campaign. Nevertheless, Iran wields considerable influence in Iraq, which has a predominantly Shia population. They maintain relationships with Iran, some of which are natural. We anticipate that Prime Minister Abadi will engage with and collaborate with Iran as a neighboring country. However, some relationships are less legitimate, such as Iran's financing of Shia militias that have previously killed American soldiers and may commit atrocities in Sunni regions. Our diplomats and military personnel on the ground are assessing where we can appropriately de-conflict and where we can collaborate with Prime Minister Abadi on an overarching strategy for Iraq to regain its sovereignty. We are also communicating to Abadi when Iran's actions are problematic and that we cannot cooperate in those areas unless those individuals are removed. These discussions are ongoing and will continue. Rest assured that any work undertaken by the U.S. Government or military in Iraq with other partners is predicated on the understanding that they are reporting to and under the command of the Iraqi Government and Iraqi security forces. If we lack confidence that Abadi is ultimately directing those soldiers, it is difficult for us to maintain any direct relationship. Is that understood?
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, a year ago you expressed optimism for bipartisan cooperation. Given the current political climate, how would you evaluate your own effectiveness in working with Democrats, and what specific legislative achievements demonstrate successful compromise? [SEP] Well, we're seeing some common ground on Iraq. Some in Congress disagree with our initial involvement, but Petraeus and Crocker's testimony seems to have made a difference. Funding for our troops is another area where we can hopefully find common ground. FISA is another example. Why change a good law? It works for the security of the country, which is what the American people want. It enables our intelligence experts to understand Al Qaida's intentions. The law needs to be enhanced by providing liability protection to phone companies that helped us. So, we found common ground there. Hopefully, we can find more as Congress moves forward with legislation. The reason I spoke out today is because there's a lot to be done. I'm not a legislator, but as head of the executive branch, I urge Congress to show progress and get results. It's hard to find common ground unless important bills are moving. They're not even moving. Not one appropriations bill has made it to my desk. How can you find common ground when there's no appropriations process? We found common ground on trade bills. Exports helped us overcome the weakness in the housing market last quarter. It makes sense to continue opening up markets to goods and services. Yet, there haven't been any bills moving when it comes to trade. Veterans Affairs is another area where we can find common ground. I asked Bob Dole and Donna Shalala to lead a commission to ensure our veterans get the benefits they deserve. I was concerned about bureaucratic delay and a system that didn't recognize the unique challenges of the current war. I'm concerned about PTSD and want people to focus on it. We sent up a bill, and I hope they move on it quickly. There's a place where we can find common ground.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Yemen conflict, you pledged to end it swiftly. The UAE is now pushing for the Houthis to be re-listed as a terrorist organization. Will you comply, and what's your updated strategy for achieving peace in Yemen? [SEP] Well, the situation is, shall we say, fluid. We're evaluating all options, including the designation you mentioned. Resolving the Yemen crisis requires commitment from all parties involved, which, frankly, has been lacking. It's a complex puzzle, to put it mildly.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, Clinton's camp says the FBI cost her the election. They claim the investigation was weak. Your take? Does this hurt our institutions, like Trump? And will you talk to Trump about his team downplaying the Russia probe? [SEP] Transitions are never easy. People are still emotional. But Trump will soon face the realities of the office. I've spoken to him, offered advice on keeping our institutions strong. He's listened. The FBI? They're dedicated professionals. It's tough when politics gets involved. I've stayed out of investigations, and I'll continue to do so.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Yes, thank you, Mr. President. Why did you lie to the American people? And why should we trust what you have to say now? [SEP] Such a terrible question and the phraseology. I didn't lie. What I said is: We have to be calm; we can't be panicked. I knew that the tapes were there. These were a series of phone calls that we had—mostly phone calls. And Bob Woodward is somebody that I respect, just from hearing the name for many, many years, not knowing too much about his work, not caring about his work.But I thought it would be interesting to talk to him for a period of, you know, calls. So we did that. I don't know if it's good or bad. I don't even know if the book is good or bad, but certainly, if he thought that was a bad statement, he would have reported it, because he thinks that—you know, you don't want to have anybody that is going to suffer medically because of some fact. And he didn't report it because he didn't think it was bad. Nobody thought it was bad.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. But you, sir—Mr. President, you had talked specifically about his temperament. Do you still have any concern about his temperament? [SEP] As I saidbecause, Athena asked the questionwhatever you bring to this office, this office has a habit of magnifying and pointing out, and hopefully, then you correct for it.This may seem like a silly example, but I know myself well enough to know I can't keep track of paper. I am not well organized in that way. And so pretty quickly, after I'm getting stacks of briefing books coming in every night, I say to myself, I've got to figure out a system, because I have bad filing, sorting, and organizing habits. And I've got to find some people who can help me keep track of this stuff. Now, that seems trivial, but actually, it ends up being a pretty big piece of business.I think what will happen with the President-elect is, there are going to be certain elements of his temperament that will not serve him well unless he recognizes them and corrects them. Because when you're a candidate and you say something that is inaccurate or controversial, it has less impact than it does when you're President of the United States. Everybody around the world is paying attention. Markets move. National security issues require a level of precision in order to make sure that you don't make mistakes. And I think he'she recognizes that this is different, and so do the American people.All right, I'm going to take just a couple more questions, and then I get out of here.Nadia Bilbassy [Nadia Bilbassy-Charters, Al Arabiya].
label: Deflection

sentence: So, it's really down to those two locations? No other sites are being considered? [SEP] Those are the two that have captured my attention. They both offer something special. I want to make the right decision, one that honors the occasion.
label: General

sentence: Q. Do you foresee any direct engagement with Iranian counterparts? [SEP] Let me rephrase to ensure I understand correctly: Are you inquiring whether I will personally be involved in discussions with Iranian officials?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, you've often spoken against what you call a 'crude form of nationalism.' Would you advise protesters at home to stop demonstrating against Mr. Trump's rhetoric? And did you advise your successor to be mindful of potentially problematic staff picks? Finally, in your last weeks, can you stop Assad and Putin from bombing Aleppo? [SEP] Protesting is a fundamental expression of our democracy. I've been protested myself. I wouldn't tell people to be silent if they're concerned. However, I advise them to remember that elections, voting, organizing, and being informed matter. To young people, I say: don't take our systems for granted. Democracy is hard work. If a large percentage doesn't vote, democracy is weakened. If we can't discern between facts and propaganda, we have problems. If people are unwilling to compromise, democracy breaks down. Understand the foundations of a healthy democracy and engage continuously. There's complacency. Some forget the Cold War. Sometimes, there's an easy equivalence drawn between the U.S. and Russia, which is inaccurate. We have our flaws, but we've tried to apply principles of free speech and civil liberties. Remember that. Misinformation is packaged well. Don't equate overzealousness with severe repression. If everything seems the same, we won't know what to protect. This was a long answer. I forgot the second part.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. President, clearly the relations between our two countries, politically, have been very good. How could we achieve the same in the area of security, in the context of the antimissile shield, our common—our cooperation in using common sites, and also in respect of the trade investment? [SEP] Do you want me to start on the missiles? The proposed missile shield is aimed at long-range missiles, missiles that would fly over Bulgaria. There are missile systems and defense systems available that would deal with intermediate-range missiles. And so just because Bulgaria is not a part of the longer range missile shield doesn't mean that there won't be equipment and help available for intermediate range. That's how I can answer that question.I know this creates some concerns around Europe, this missile shield, because of Russian objections. And so I had a meeting with President Putin in Germany at the G-8 and explained to him what I've been saying publicly, is, the missile shield would be developed to deal with a rogue regime that would try to hold a free nation hostage, or free nations hostage; that it's not aimed at Russia.I talked to Vladimir Putin a lot about our relations and made it clear that I simply do not view Russia as an enemy. I view Russia as a country with whom we should have and can have good relations to solve common problems.One such problem is Iran. Another problem is proliferation. There are areas we can work together, and he brought an interesting proposal. He said: I have an idea. Why don't we jointly use a radar in Azerbaijan to help deal with a potential threat? And I said: That's a good idea. I don't know how—whether it's technologically feasible; I'm not an expert. I've got experts in my Government, however, who could analyze your proposal, and I'd like for you to maybe—not maybe—I'd like for you to assign some experts in your Government to analyze my proposal.And that's where we left it in Germany. So we're going to have a group of people come together from the State Department, Defense Department, and the military to discuss how to deal with the true threats of the 21st century.And I would hope that would help explain some of the rhetoric that people in your country have seen coming out of the G-8, that there's a process where we can collaborate and share information in a very transparent way, which I think will be beneficial. And I would hope that the Russians would see the meetings as beneficial and out of the meetings realize our true intent, and hopefully, design systems that protect us all. I would like to begin by saying that we welcome the strategic dialog, and it was described as a strategic dialog by both leaders, both by President Bush and by Putin, a dialog which started within the framework of G-8. We Bulgarians would accept any solution that would provide more guarantees, more security guarantees, more guarantees of the indivisibility of the security of the Euro-Atlantic space, any solution that has been achieved, hammered out through dialog and in transparency, and any solution that is not directed against a third country, notably Russia in this case.I would take the liberty of paraphrasing something that was said in Prague—hopefully, my source was reliable; the President would correct me if I'm wrong or imprecise—the Bulgarians mustn't choose between their friendship with the United States and that with Russia. The Bulgarians should and can maintain friendly relations with both countries. Just as I am a friend with George and a friend with Vladimir, we could maintain, within the context of our Euro-Atlantic orientation, friendly relations with both without diluting the things, without losing sight of our strategic priorities. We should maintain relations with everyone who thinks likewise.This means the same approach would apply to the energy, the infrastructure sphere. This is why Bulgaria maintains— has maintained active relations with Russia on the major infrastructure, or rather energy projects.I myself, earlier today, offered to President Bush a clearer, firmer commitment by American companies to the energy project. Chevron, in respect of Bourgas-Alexandroupolis, or AMBO—I'm not going to list them all here—this is an investment in peace and the security of the region. This is a geostrategic contribution. And I'm saying this both as the President of Bulgaria, but also as a citizen of the Balkans, a region for whose fate and future I feel responsible. Thank you.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the supercommittee, if they fail to reach a deal and the sequester is triggered, and Republicans attempt to alter the automatic cuts, will you veto any such bill? Also, could you clarify your 'hot mic' conversation with President Sarkozy concerning Prime Minister Netanyahu? [SEP] Let me address the supercommittee first. We agreed in August to a trillion dollars in cuts over the next decade, mainly from discretionary spending. We also recognized the need for an additional 1.2 trillion to stabilize our fiscal situation. The sequester was intended to push both sides to compromise. Unfortunately, it seems everyone's sticking to their entrenched positions. I've proposed a detailed plan achieving over $3 trillion in savings, a balanced approach favored by the American people. It includes discretionary spending cuts, non-defense and defense cuts, entitlement program adjustments, healthcare cost reductions, and additional revenue, starting with asking the wealthiest to contribute more before burdening seniors. This is the same proposal I presented to Speaker Boehner, echoing the recommendations of independent committees. People are trying to manipulate the math, but the equation remains the same: a balanced approach is necessary to avoid gutting essential programs. I hope the supercommittee will act responsibly. I won't comment on vetoing specific bills until I see them. As for the 'hot mic' incident, I won't discuss private conversations with leaders. However, my primary concern with President Sarkozy was France's vote in favor of Palestinian membership in UNESCO, which would force the US to cut funding, undermining direct negotiations between Palestinians and Israelis. I expressed my disappointment frankly, consistent with my previous statements.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to the Senkaku Islands, for absolute clarity, are you confirming that the US would entertain military intervention if China were to mount a military operation to seize those islands? Does this not constitute yet another 'red line' that you would be compelled to uphold, potentially damaging US credibility, as witnessed with Syria and Russia? Regarding North Korea, you referenced them earlier. Are you conveying a warning against future nuclear tests? And Prime Minister Abe, do you place confidence in President Obama's assurances regarding your security, given the West's inability to prevent Russia's actions in Ukraine? [SEP] Could you remind me of the question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. And Kenneth Starr. How do you feel about him now? [SEP] So Ken Starr is a terrific man. I did make that statement, because, frankly, I didn't think that Bill Clinton should have been impeached. And I thought it was terrible. I didn't know Ken Starr, but I didn't think that Bill Clinton should be impeached—should have been impeached. And I was pretty vocal about that. I didn't know Ken, but what I did know is he was very smart. He was very tough. He was very talented. But in a certain way, I was sticking up for Clinton—for Bill Clinton. And you know, I felt—I sort of still feel that way. I mean, what he did was nothing good. There was a lot of lying going on. There were a lot of things, a lot of bad things.Now, with me, there's no lying. There's no nothing. They have nothing. They don't even have a crime. They say, This is the only one that's ever been impeached, and he didn't commit a crime. I didn't commit a crime. And then, you get into high crimes and misdemeanors. But I didn't commit a crime.So no, I have great respect for Ken. But I didn't think, frankly, that Bill Clinton should have been impeached.
label: Explicit

sentence: Was that conversation recorded? [SEP] No, I don't believe so. I'm almost certain it wasn't. Were any recordings made? I actually wish there were, because the content is quite fascinating.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Sir, assuming the drug demonstrates efficacy, would you advocate for a fast-track approval process? [SEP] Hold your horses. I can't comment on that until I see the results. We're exploring every avenue, but I need concrete evidence before I can make a decision.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. What was it about that first interaction with Chairman Kim this morning that that made you decide not to walk away after you said that you would know within the first minute if he was sincere or not? [SEP] Yes. I've said that about relationships. I've said that about people. You know in the first second. Now, I was generous. I said 5 seconds. But you know in the first second, in some cases. Sometimes, that doesn't work out. But sometimes, it does.From the beginning, we got along. But there's been a lot of groundwork. This wasn't like we went and we started talking about—as you know, right? We didn't just come in and start talking about these very complex subjects that have been going on for 70 years. We've been discussing this for months. And you know, once the rhetoric stopped, once they did a great thing—you know, North Korea did a great thing by going to the Olympics. Because the Olympics—and President Moon will tell you this—the Olympics was not exactly doing great. People didn't feel like being bombed out of the opening ceremonies. You know, they weren't exactly selling tickets. And as soon as the Chairman—Chairman Kim—said, Let's participate in the Olympics, it sold like wildfire and was a great success as an Olympics. It was a great success. He did a great thing.But since that time, pretty much since that time—because, as you know, a delegation came from South Korea who had just met with North Korea. They came to the White House. They told me lots of things, including the fact that they'd be willing to denuke. We have one of their great people here today. That they were willing to denuke. And once that started, we have been really talking about that from the end of the Olympics when the whole delegation came to say various things, including denuking./
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, can you confirm if you received any reports of new COVID-19 infections within the White House staff today? [SEP] Regarding today's reports, specifically?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the situation along the Pakistan-Afghanistan border, do you endorse President Karzai's potential deployment of troops into Pakistan to address militant groups launching attacks from that territory? And do you perceive the agreements being pursued by the Pakistani government with certain militant tribes as a form of appeasement? Prime Minister, what are your expectations for the upcoming meeting in Saudi Arabia? And do you believe President Bush's presence in Jeddah would be beneficial? [SEP] Our paramount objective is to deny safe haven to extremists who seek to inflict harm upon innocent individuals. This is the guiding principle of Afghanistan's strategy, and it must also be the guiding principle of Pakistan's strategy. It is in our collective interest to prevent those who resort to murder to achieve political objectives from gaining sanctuary. To that end, we encourage enhanced dialogue between the governments of Pakistan and Afghanistan. In the past, a jirga, comprised of tribal leaders from both sides of the border, proved effective. Reviving this process would be a positive step. Furthermore, enhanced communication between the intelligence services of both countries is essential, as is improved cooperation, including trilateral border patrols involving Pakistan, Afghanistan, and coalition forces, to prevent the movement of individuals across the border. There is considerable common ground. To reiterate, it is in no one's interest for extremists to possess a safe haven from which to operate. The situation is undeniably delicate. Were I the president of a nation and individuals were crossing from another country to perpetrate violence against my citizens, I would be deeply concerned. We can assist in de-escalating the situation and developing a strategy to prevent extremists from establishing safe havens and enjoying freedom of movement. I shall be traveling to Jeddah next Sunday at the invitation of the King of Saudi Arabia to engage in a long-term dialogue, a process rather than a singular event, between oil producers and oil consumers. There is a growing consensus that the price of oil is increasingly influenced not only by current supply and demand dynamics but also by perceptions of future imbalances. I intend to convey to the King of Saudi Arabia and other participants that the world will expand its reliance on nuclear power, increase its utilization of renewable energy sources, augment its consumption of coal, and reduce its dependence on oil. The world is committed to enhancing the efficiency of oil utilization. This dialogue between producers and consumers is of paramount importance. President Bush recently visited Saudi Arabia. I have not been there recently. I wish to engage with the King and others to discuss what I believe should be an ongoing process of understanding the pressures on future demand and supply. This long-term debate can exert an influence on current markets. This is the essence of the discussion. I hope that this process will continue, if necessary, with a meeting in London and subsequent gatherings, fostering a genuine dialogue between producers and consumers regarding the most pressing issue facing the world today: the tripling of oil prices.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Could you repeat that, please? Focusing on the cabinet. [SEP] Come again? What was that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. But is there anything specific that you feel like you and your administration need to change given this disastrous election for your party and the message that voters sent? [SEP] Julie, I think every single day I'm looking for, how can we do what we need to do better. Whether that is delivering basic services the Government provides to the American people, whether that is our capacity to work with Congress so that they're passing legislation, whether it's how we communicate with the American people about what our priorities and vision is, we are constantly asking ourselves questions about how do we make sure that we're doing a better job. And that's not going to stop. I think that every election is a moment for reflection, and I think that everybody in this White House is going to look and say, all right, what do we need to do differently?But the principles that we're fighting for, the things that motivate me every single day and motivate my staff every day, those things aren't going to change. There's going to be a consistent focus on how do we deliver more opportunity to more people in this country, how do we grow the economy faster, how do we put more people back to work.And I maybe have a naive confidence that if we continue to focus on the American people and not on our own ambitions or image or various concerns like that, that at the end of the day, when I look back, I'm going to be able to say the American people are better off than they were before I was President. And that's my most important goal.So—but the other thing I just want to emphasize is I'm—I've said this before, I want to reiterate it: If there are ideas that the Republicans have that I have confidence will make things better for ordinary Americans, the fact that the Republicans suggesting it as opposed to a Democrat, that will be irrelevant to me. I want to just see what works.And there are some things like rebuilding our infrastructure or early childhood education that we know works. And I'm hoping that the kind of attitude and approach that Mitch McConnell and John Boehner have already expressed, their desire to get things done, allows us to find some common ground.Jeff Mason [Reuters].
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, after your time in office, do you regret the inaccuracies you've told the American people? [SEP] All the what now?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, ABC News is reporting that Iran will be capable of building a nuclear bomb within 2 years. Have you seen any evidence that Iran is accelerating its nuclear program? [SEP] I'm not aware of the ABC report you cite. However, let me be clear: I am deeply concerned about Iran's pursuit of nuclear weapons. A nuclear Iran would be profoundly destabilizing to the entire Middle East region. We are actively working to forge a strong international coalition to dissuade the Iranians from this dangerous path. They face a clear choice: continued isolation or the opportunity for economic growth and integration. We take any and all attempts by Iran to acquire nuclear weapons with the utmost seriousness.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, with the subpoenas still active, what's the obstacle preventing your administration from moving forward on those initiatives? [SEP] Pardon? Bipartisanship
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, many Afghans who supported the U.S. are now at risk under Taliban rule. What is your administration doing to protect these individuals, and what message do you have for those who feel betrayed by the U.S. withdrawal? [SEP] We're working to evacuate those who helped us. We're providing humanitarian assistance to the Afghan people. And we're holding the Taliban accountable for their actions. We stand with the Afghan people. And we will continue to support them in their efforts to build a better future.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. You're about to embark on your final foreign trip. What will you say to other world leaders about your successor? They've expressed many of the same misgivings that you have about Donald Trump. Should they be worried about the future of U.S. foreign policy? And separately, as Democrats scramble to regroup after a pretty shocking upset, what is your advice about where the party goes now? And who should lead your party? [SEP] Good. One of the great things about the United States is that when it comes to world affairs, the President obviously is the leader of the executive branch, the Commander in Chief, the spokesperson for the Nation, but the influence and the work that we have is the result not just of the President. It is the result of countless interactions and arrangements and relationships between our military and other militaries and our diplomats and other diplomats and intelligence officers and development workers. And there is enormous continuity beneath the day-to-day news that makes us that indispensable nation when it comes to maintaining order and promoting prosperity around the world. That will continue. In my conversation with the President-elect, he expressed a great interest in maintaining our core strategic relationships. And so one of the messages I will be able to deliver is his commitment to NATO and the transatlantic alliance. I think that's one of the most important functions I can serve at this stage, during this trip, is to let them know that there is no weakening of resolve when it comes to America's commitment to maintaining a strong and robust NATO relationship and a recognition that those alliances aren't just good for Europe, they're good for the United States, and they're vital for the world.With respect to the Democratic Party, look, as I said in the Rose Garden right after the election, when your team loses, everybody gets deflated, and it's hard, and it's challenging. And so I think it's a healthy thing for the Democratic Party to go through some reflection. I think it's important for me not to be big-footing that conversation. I think we want to see new voices and new ideas emerge. That's part of the reason why I think term limits are a really useful thing.I think the Democrats should not waver on our core beliefs and principles: the belief that we should have an economy that works for everybody, not just a few; the belief that America, at its best, is inclusive and not exclusive, that we insist on the dignity and God-given potential and worth of every child, regardless of race or gender or sexual orientation or what ZIP Code they were born in. That we are committed to a world in which we keep America safe, but we recognize that our power doesn't just flow from our extraordinary military, it also flows from the strength of our ideals and our principles and our values.So there are going to be a core set of values that shouldn't be up for debate, should be our north star. But how we organize politically I think is something that we should spend some time thinking about. I believe that we have better ideas. But I also believe that good ideas don't matter if people don't hear them. And one of the issues that Democrats have to be clear on is that, given population distribution across the country, we have to compete everywhere. We have to show up everywhere. We have to work at a grassroots level, something that's been a running thread in my career.I won Iowa not because the demographics dictated that I would win Iowa, it was because I spent 87 days going to every small town and fair and fish fry and VFW hall. And there were some counties where I might have lost, but maybe I lost by 20 points instead of 50 points. There are some counties maybe I won that people didn't expect because people had a chance to see you and listen to you and get a sense of who you stood for and who you were fighting for.And the challenge for a national party is, how do you dig in there and create those kinds of structures so that people have a sense of what it is that you stand for? And that increasingly is difficult to do just through a national press strategy. It's increasingly difficult to do because of the splintering of the press.And so I think the discussions that have been taking place about how do you build more grassroots organizing, how do you build up State parties and local parties and schoolboard elections you're paying attention to and State rep races and city council racesthat all, I think, will contribute to stronger outcomes in the future.And I'm optimistic that will happen. And Ifor Democrats who are feeling completely discouraged, I've been trying to remind them everybody remembers my Boston speech in 2004; they may not remember me showing up here in 2005 when John Kerry had lost a close election, Tom Daschle, the leader of the Senate, had been beaten in an upset. Ken Salazar and I were the only two Democrats that won nationally. Republicans controlled the Senate and the House. And 2 years later, Democrats were winning back Congress, and 4 years later, I was President of the United States.Things change pretty rapidly. But it doesn'tthey don't change inevitably. They change because you work for it. Nobody said democracy is supposed to be easy. This is hard. And in a big country like this, it probably should be hard.Mark Knoller [ABC News].
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. What was the message you were trying to send with not only your decision not to attend the Sochi Games, but also with the people you named to the delegation to represent the United States at those Games? [SEP] Well, first of all, I haven't attended Olympics in the past, and I suspect that me attending the Olympics, particularly at a time when we've got all the other stuff that people have been talking about, is going to be tough, although I would love to do it. I'll be going to a lot of Olympic Games post-Presidency. [] I think the delegation speaks for itself. You've got outstanding Americans, outstanding athletes, people who will represent us extraordinarily well.And the fact that we've got folks like Billie Jean King or Brian Boitano, who themselves have been world-class athletes that everybody acknowledges for their excellence, but also for their character, who also happen to be members of the LGBT community, you should take that for what it's worth: that when it comes to the Olympics and athletic performance, we don't make distinctions on the basis of sexual orientation. We judge people on how they perform, both on the court and off the court, on the field and off the field. And that's a value that I think is at the heart of not just America, but American sports.I'm going to just roll down these last few, real quickly. Ari Shapiro [National Public Radio]. Last day at the White House. He deserves a question. []
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. [Inaudible]--from Korea's Yonhap News Agency. A question going out to President Lee. North Korea recently said that they will not return to the six-party talks. They have denounced the U.N. Security Council resolution and said they will not give up their nuclear weapons program. Can you, sir, talk about if--whether you talked about how you plan to proceed forward, and did you talk about this with President Obama?And of course, their continuing threat emanating from North Korea--a South Korean worker has been and is still detained by the North Koreans. What are your thoughts about the maintenance of the Kaesong industrial complex, and did you talk about--President Obama--or were there any concerns from the Americans about the Kaesong industrial complex? [SEP] has been resisting, and they've reacted aggressively to the new U.N. Security Council resolution, which is quite expected. And of course, the ns may react by firing another round of missiles or taking actions. We can also expect that from them as well. However, ns must understand that they will not be able to gain compensation by provoking a crisis. This has been a pattern in the past, but this will no longer be. The firm U.S.-Korea cooperation and alliance will not allow that. And the recent Security Council resolution is not simply about words; it is about taking follow-up action and vigorously implementing the U.N. Security Council resolution. And we'll make sure that we fully implement the U.N. Security Council resolution.Like I said, the ns must understand that their past behavior will not stand. And of course, not only the U.S.-Korea close partnership, but Japan, China, and the rest of the international community will take part in this effort. And now the ns will come to understand that this is different, that they will not be able to repeat the past or their past tactics and strategies. I urge the ns to fully give up their nuclear weapons programs and ambitions and to become a responsible member of the international community.With regards to the Kaesong industrial complex, the n authorities are demanding unacceptable demands, and we will not accept such demands being laid out by the ns. Of course, the South Korean Government is very much for maintaining the Kaesong industrial complex because the Kaesong industrial complex is a channel of dialog between the two Koreas. And also, another fact that we must not overlook is the fact that there are 40,000 n workers currently working in Kaesong industrial complex. If the Kaesong industrial complex were to close, these 40,000 n workers will lose their jobs.And therefore, I ask that--I urge the ns not to make any unacceptable demands, because we cannot really know what will happen if they continue on this path. And also the ns have been detaining a South Korean worker. They haven't been giving us any explanation, and also we know that there are two American journalists being currently held by the ns. I urge the ns to release not only the two American journalists, but also the South Korean worker, without any conditions, to release them as soon as possible. The international community is asking the ns to take that path. And once again, I urge in the strongest terms that they release these two American journalists, as well as the Korean worker being held.United Nations Sanctions Against Chip [Chip Reid, CBS News].
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Justice Department's actions concerning the Associated Press, was it an overreach? Do you still trust your Attorney General? Is the media shield law a reaction? And how do you feel about Nixon comparisons? [SEP] I'll leave the comparisons to you. My focus is fixing government problems, like the IRS and diplomatic security. On the Justice Department, I can't comment on ongoing cases. But leaks endanger national security and those serving our country. I won't apologize for protecting them. We also have a free press, and the media shield law tried to balance that. This case has sparked renewed interest, so we should revisit it. I have troops in Afghanistan and intelligence officers in danger. I have to protect them while respecting the need for information.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. But it makes me wonder where you are, sir, at about the 2-year mark on Guantanamo, when closing it was one of your initial priorities, sir? [SEP] Obviously, we haven't gotten it closed. And let me just step back and explain that the reason for wanting to close Guantanamo was because my number-one priority is keeping the American people safe. One of the most powerful tools we have to keep the American people safe is not providing Al Qaida and jihadists recruiting tools for fledgling terrorists.And Guantanamo is probably the number-one recruitment tool that is used by these jihadist organizations. And we see it in the web sites that they put up. We see it in the messages that they're delivering.And so my belief is that we can keep the American people safe, go after those who would engage in terrorism. And my administration has been as aggressive in going after Al Qaida as any administration out there. And we've seen progress, as I noted during the Afghan review.Every intelligence report that we're seeing shows that Al Qaida is more hunkered down than they have been since the original invasion of Afghanistan in 2001, that they have reduced financing capacity, reduced operational capacity. It is much more difficult for their top folks to communicate, and a lot of those top folks can't communicate because they're underground now.But it is important for us, even as we're going aggressively after the bad guys, to make sure that we're also living up to our values and our ideals and our principles. And that's what closing Guantanamo is about, not because I think that the people who are running Guantanamo are doing a bad job, but rather because it's become a symbol. And I think we can do just as good of a job housing them somewhere else.Now, to the issue you had about the review. You're right, I won't comment right now on a review that I have not received yet. I can tell you that over the last 2 years, despite not having closed Guantanamo, we've been trying to put our battle against terrorists within a legal structure that is consistent with our history of rule of law. And we've succeeded on a number of fronts.One of the toughest problems is what to do with people that we know are dangerous, that we know are--have engaged in terrorist activity, are proclaimed enemies of the United States, but because of the manner in which they were originally captured, the circumstances right after 9/11 in which they are interrogated, it becomes difficult to try them, whether in a Article III court or in a military commission.Releasing them at this stage could potentially create greater danger for the American people. And so how do we manage that? And that's what this team has been looking at. Are there ways for us to make sure these folks have lawyers, to make sure that these folks have the opportunity to challenge their detention, but at the same time, making sure that we are not simply releasing folks who could do us grievous harm and have shown a capacity and willingness to engage in brutal attacks in the past?And so when I get that report, I'm sure that I'll have more comments on it. The bottom line is, is that striking this balance between our security and making sure that we are consistent with our values and our Constitution is not an easy task, but ultimately that's what's required for practical reasons.Because the more people are reminded of what makes America special--the fact that we stand for something beyond just our economic power or our military might, but we have these core ideals that we observe even when it's hard--that's one of our most powerful weapons. And I want to make sure that we don't lose that weapon in what is a serious struggle.So with that, everybody, I want to wish you all a merry Christmas. Happy holidays. Happy New Year. See you in 2011.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. And to follow up, what do you want the Palestinians to take away from this deal, since they're not really a party to it? [SEP] Well, but they are supported largely by some of the countries that we're talking to and that have already signed—you know, in the case of the one country. But others will be following. And I think the Palestinians will—without saying it necessarily yet, I think they very much want to be a part of what we're doing. And I see, ultimately, the Palestinians—I see peace between Israel and the Palestinians. I see that happening. I think as these very big, powerful, wealthy countries come in, I think the Palestinians will follow, quite naturally.Yes, please.
label: General

sentence: Q. No, no, I'm—I'm going to take care.Mr. President, thank you. Sebastian Smith from AFP. Another question on Ukraine. Ukraine borders four NATO member countries. How concerned are you? Are you concerned that a real conflagration in Ukraine—if the Russians really go in there—that it could suck in NATO countries that are on the border and you end up with an actual NATO-Russia confrontation of some kind?And secondly, are you entertaining the thought of a summit with Vladimir Putin as a way to perhaps try and put this whole thing to bed, address their concerns, and negotiate a way out of this? [SEP] The last part—to the last question, yes. When we talked about whether or not we'd—the three meetings we talked about. And we talked about: We would go from there, if there was reason to, to go to a summit. We talked about a summit as being before the Ukraine item came up in terms of strategic doctrine and what the strategic relationship would be. So I still think that is a possibility, number one.Number two, I am very concerned. I'm very concerned that this could end up being—look, the only war that's worse than one that's intended is one that's unintended. And what I'm concerned about is, this could get out of hand—very easily get out of hand because of what you said: the borders of the—of Ukraine and what Russia may or may not do.I am hoping that Vladimir Putin understands that he is—short of a full-blown nuclear war, he's not in a very good position to dominate the world. And so I don't think he thinks that, but it is a concern. And that's why we have to be very careful about how we move forward and make it clear to him that there are prices to pay that could, in fact, cost his country an awful lot.But I—of course, you have to be concerned when you have, you know, a nuclear power invade—this has—if he invades—it hasn't happened since World War II. This will be the most consequential thing that's happened in the world, in terms of war and peace, since World War II.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. They expressed concerns though that it could exacerbate tensions and increase violence. Do you give any consideration to that? [SEP] Well, it could also increase enthusiasm, and it could increase love and respect for our country. And that's why I'm going, because they did a fantastic job. As soon as I called and told them, Let's go, the whole problem stopped. That was—what?—6 days ago.Yes, Jeff [Jeff Mason, Reuters].
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Nine years after the September 11th attacks, why do you think it is that we are now seeing such an increase in suspicion and outright resentment of Islam, especially given that it has been one of your priorities to increase--to improve relations with the Muslim world? [SEP] I think that at a time when the country is anxious generally and going through a tough time, then fears can surface, suspicions, divisions can surface in a society. And so I think that plays a role in it.One of the things that I most admired about President Bush was after 9/11, him being crystal clear about the fact that we were not at war with Islam. We were at war with terrorists and murderers who had perverted Islam, had stolen its banner to carry out their outrageous acts. And I was so proud of the country rallying around that idea, that notion that we are not going to be divided by religion, we're not going to be divided by ethnicity. We are all Americans. We stand together against those who would try to do us harm.And that's what we've done over the last 9 years. And we should take great pride in that. And I think it is absolutely important now for the overwhelming majority of the American people to hang on to that thing that is best in us, a belief in religious tolerance, clarity about who our enemies are. Our enemies are Al Qaida and their allies who are trying to kill us, but have killed more Muslims than just about anybody on Earth. We have to make sure that we don't start turning on each other.And I will do everything that I can as long as I am President of the United States to remind the American people that we are one Nation under God, and we may call that God different names, but we remain one Nation. And as somebody who relies heavily on my Christian faith in my job, I understand the passions that religious faith can raise. But I'm also respectful that people of different faiths can practice their religion, even if they don't subscribe to the exact same notions that I do, and that they are still good people and they are my neighbors and they are my friends and they are fighting alongside us in our battles.And I want to make sure that this country retains that sense of purpose. And I think tomorrow is a wonderful day for us to remind ourselves of that.Natasha Mozgovaya of Haaretz. Is she here? Natasha--there you are back there.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you. Thank you, Mr. President. The President. Thank you.Hong Kong/China  Q. I would like to ask your opinion about what recently happened in Hong Kong, the recent attack on press freedom in Hong Kong. And Jimmy Lai was arrested; his newsroom was raided. What—how will the U.S. respond to this? [SEP] Well, I think it's a terrible thing. But one thing that we have done—you know, we gave tremendous incentives to Hong Kong because of freedom. We want freedom. And we were giving tremendous economic incentives to Hong Kong. And we have now withdrawn all of those incentives, and it will be impossible for Hong Kong to compete with the United States with respect to that. It just won't be, because we've taken all of the incentives away.If you look at China—with the World Trade Organization, as an example—they're getting tremendous, because they're considered a developing nation, which is ridiculous. Why should they be a developing nation, but we're not? And they get tremendous incentives.We have—by the way, I told them it's unacceptable, and we've been doing that for a long time. They understand exactly how we feel, and big changes are being made. But with respect to Hong Kong, they get tremendous financial incentives so that they could do business and compete in the world.We've now withdrawn all of those incentives. It's going to be very hard for Hong Kong to compete. And I will tell you that the United States—and I say this from any standpoint you want to hear it—will end up making a lot more money because of it. Because we lost a lot of business to Hong Kong. We made it very convenient for people to go there, for companies to go there. We've withdrawn all of that. And the United States will be a big beneficiary from an economic standpoint, but I hate to see what happened to Hong Kong, because freedom is a great thing.Thank you all very much. Thank you. Thank you.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. With all due respect, Mr. President, are you going to endorse that specific proposal or not? [SEP] We're moving closer, folks, closer. I want to get money to the people who were hurt. Those who were hurt by something that could have been stopped. They could have stopped it from entering their country, from entering our country, from entering Europe, from entering the rest of the world. 188 different countries. It's a disaster.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the imprisoned medics and the ongoing efforts for their release, will you commit to advocating before Congress for the allocation of funds from your HIV/AIDS initiative to support the affected children and families in Libya? [SEP] There's a fund, a joint effort, and we're part of it. The key is that the US is in, along with the EU, providing the necessary resources. We're also pushing for the nurses' release. We're on the same page with your government. We believe in compensation for those children and their families. That's the right thing to do.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the NSA's bulk data collection, a federal judge has questioned its effectiveness. Can you provide concrete examples of its success in preventing attacks and justify its continuation? [SEP] Well, let's step back and look at the big picture. The independent panel I appointed made 46 recommendations, which I'm currently evaluating. I want to thank them for their hard work. They were charged with assessing our security measures to ensure they strike the right balance between security and civil liberties. I'll be making a comprehensive statement in January after consulting with various experts. The 215 program, which involves bulk metadata collection, has been a focus of attention. The NSA believed it was essential for tracking potential terrorist threats. While there haven't been allegations of abuse, public concern remains. We need to explore whether we can achieve the same objectives while enhancing public trust. I'm confident the NSA is not engaged in domestic spying, but we must adapt to evolving technologies. We also need to build greater confidence internationally. We have robust safeguards against spying on Americans, but international constraints are less clear. We need to apply our values more consistently beyond our borders.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, concerning the threat of chemical weapons, do you have any intelligence suggesting Putin is positioning or contemplating their use? And if he does use them, what would be the U.S. or NATO's military response? [SEP] I can't divulge specific intelligence on that matter, for obvious reasons. However, let me state unequivocally that we would respond if he employs chemical weapons. The specifics of our response would depend entirely on the nature and scale of their use. Next question.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, apologies for the background noise. I'm asking if you were informed of any new coronavirus cases within the White House today? [SEP] I'm afraid the audio is quite poor. Could you repeat that, please?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, you called President Xi a dictator. Do you think that hurts our relationship with China? And what about India? Are you ignoring human rights concerns there? [SEP] No, it doesn't hurt the relationship. Look, I'm not gonna tiptoe around what I think is true, especially when talking to our allies like India. This whole 'China collapsing' thing is overblown. We had a little hiccup, but Blinken's trip went well. I'll see Xi soon. No big deal. What was that second question again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the high-profile nature of the Ghislaine Maxwell case, what are your thoughts on the possibility of her testimony leading to further revelations about other influential individuals? [SEP] To be honest, I haven't been following it very closely. I simply wish her the best. I've encountered her on several occasions, particularly during my time in Palm Beach. However, I am not privy to the details of the situation involving Prince Andrew. Next question, please.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, regarding the human rights concerns in Mexico, the drug war, the Merida Initiative, threats against President Calderon, and visa issues, could you address these complex issues? [SEP] I apologize, but I didn't fully catch that. Could you repeat the question, perhaps in a more concise form? I want to ensure I address your concerns accurately.
label: Clarification

sentence: Climate activists are skeptical of the agreements being touted at this conference, feeling that past COPs have led to broken promises. What's your message to those outside who worry that it's all not enough, especially with doubts about your climate legislation and the Supreme Court's potential review of the EPA's regulatory power? [SEP] Anyone focused on the environment should be worried. We've done more than ever, but more needs to be done. No one at the conference questioned my commitment. They're focused on what we've done with deforestation and Build Back Better. World leaders are now prioritizing climate impact in infrastructure projects. There's reason to be worried, but I'm optimistic because populations have a different perspective than at COP25. People are seeing unprecedented climate events. My granddaughters and their generation are having a profound impact. The private sector is now engaged, and corporations are pricing in carbon. Things are changing, and we need the right stewardship.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. The fate of Paul Wolfowitz appears to be hanging in the balance. After all we've heard in recent days, is it still possible for him to provide the kind of leadership needed at the Bank? [SEP] First of all, I believe all parties in this matter have acted in good faith. I regret that it's come to this. I admire Paul Wolfowitz. I admire his heart, and I particularly admired his focus on helping the poor. There is a board meeting going on as we speak. All I can tell you is, I know that Paul Wolfowitz has a interest in what's best for the Bank and—just like he's had an interest in what's best for making sure the Bank focused on things that matter: human suffering, the human condition. I—and so I applaud his vision; I respect him a lot. And as I said, I regret that it's come to this right now. David.
label: Deflection

sentence: What is your best guess as to the percentage of asylum seekers who truly deserve asylum in the United States? [SEP] Look, I'm not a statistician. What I know is that we have a crisis at the border. We need to secure our country, and we need to do it now. The laws are a joke. Catch-and-release is a disaster. We need a wall, and we need Congress to act. It's very simple.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, Clinton and her team are blaming the FBI for her loss, alleging bias and a slow investigation. Your reaction? Does this erode trust in institutions, similar to Trump's rhetoric? And given the incoming administration's potential lack of focus on Russian interference, will you address this with President-elect Trump? [SEP] Look, post-election, everyone's got an opinion. But President-elect Trump will soon have a different perspective. I've had positive conversations with him, offering guidance on preserving the integrity of our institutions. He's been attentive. Regarding the FBI, they are committed professionals. It's always tricky when law enforcement and politics collide. I've consistently avoided interfering in investigations, and I won't change that now.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: So, Mr. President, are you not worried that you are sending the wrong message to the American people? [SEP] You're wrong. Plain and simple. It's a political activity, and the rules make exceptions for that. It's perfectly legal, and it's perfectly appropriate.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the Middle East, your administration's stance on Israel is often questioned due to the lack of a presidential visit. How do you reconcile this absence with your repeated assurances of unwavering support? And on the domestic front, are rising gas prices a deliberate strategy to incentivize a shift towards renewable energy, as some allege? [SEP] Let's be realistic. No president wants to see gas prices go up, especially heading into an election. High gas prices hurt families and the economy. We're tackling this with a comprehensive approach: boosting production, promoting energy efficiency, and investing in clean energy. We're making strides in reducing our dependence on foreign oil. As for Israel, my commitment is unwavering, regardless of whether I've visited as President yet. My administration's actions demonstrate our strong support.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, considering this is your third budget and you've expressed willingness to be a one-term president to achieve difficult goals, why not actively engage Republicans in negotiations now? Furthermore, how are you fostering cooperation, and do you believe the markets will remain patient for two more years? [SEP] Wow, that's a mouthful! I need a stenographer just to keep track of all that.
label: Clarification

sentence: Considering your emphasis on exports and job creation, how will you directly address China's currency practices, which many believe hinder American competitiveness and contribute to unemployment? [SEP] We have to look at the entire economic relationship, not just the currency. When I met President Hu, we were in a crisis. We needed to rebalance the world economy. We need to save more, cut debt, and be more competitive. We need the best education, more engineers, and a better infrastructure. But we also need a level playing field. With China, we need a win-win situation. It's not just about currency. We're making progress on government procurement and intellectual property. Steve Ballmer says only 1 in 10 customers in China pay for Microsoft products. We need better enforcement. China is taking steps, but more needs to be done. The RMB is undervalued. They've spent billions to keep it that way. President Hu says he's committed to a market-based system, but it's not fast enough. It would be good for both countries. They could buy more, and we could export more. He's worried about the transition, but it's the right thing to do.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, looking back at your time in office, do you have any regrets about the falsehoods you've told the American public? [SEP] What was that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, how will you decide who gets the coronavirus vaccine first, and what's your take on Russia's vaccine announcement and any related discussions with Russian counterparts? [SEP] The medical community will determine the vaccine rollout, prioritizing those most vulnerable. As for Russia's vaccine, we're watching closely, but our priority is ensuring the safety and effectiveness of our own vaccines.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Bush, what makes you think Mexicans would believe in migration reform after so many years of it being unattainable? What are the chances of this bill passing Congress? And President Calderon, what was the topic of your lunch with President Fox? [SEP] They discussed... Excuse me, I wasn't present. That's a fair question: why is this possible now? The legislative process in the United States is lengthy. Legislators often debate issues extensively before finding solutions. We haven't had a significant debate on migration until recently. A law was enacted in 1986, but serious discussions began after 2000. As the Governor of Texas, I've always recognized the importance of this issue and have prioritized it. Members of Congress have taken it seriously, but complex legislation is difficult to pass. Many Americans were concerned about the lack of enforcement of our laws. Over the past year, we've demonstrated a strong commitment to the rule of law, making Congress more receptive to my argument: migration reform reduces illegal border crossings, enhancing border security and enabling us to focus on drugs, terrorists, criminals, and weapons. I'm optimistic, though I avoid predicting legislative outcomes. The mood in Congress has shifted from skepticism to recognizing the national interest in a comprehensive bill. Republicans and Democrats in the Senate are collaborating, with the administration's support. I'm not a gambler, but I'm optimistic about achieving comprehensive reform, which benefits both countries. I met with former President Vicente Fox, whom I admire, and we had a productive discussion. He congratulated us on our first 100 days and offered his cooperation. I've met with other former Presidents and will continue to engage with President Fox. Here it comes.
label: Deflection

sentence: You expressed surprise at Republican obstructionism. However, wasn't similar obstruction a hallmark of their strategy during the Obama administration when you were Vice President? What led you to believe they would act differently this time? [SEP] The level of obstruction is far greater now. We had bipartisan cooperation with figures like John McCain and even Lindsey Graham back then. The real question is, what do they stand for now? They had a clear agenda during our administration. Today, it's a mystery. The American people are demanding tax reform. What's their solution? Crickets. They deny climate change. What's their plan? I'm genuinely unsure of the Republican platform. What are their views on taxes, human rights, or the cost of prescription drugs? I'm at a loss. And how can they simply dismiss the events of January 6th?
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. [Laughter] Thank you, Mr. President. Beatriz Bulla from Estadão. The USTR is not supporting the entry of Brazil in the OECD. Is the U.S. Government going to formally support Brazil's entry on the OECD? And what have you asked as a tradeoff? [SEP] We will be supporting. We're going to have a great relationship in so many different ways. That's just a—just something that we're going to be doing in honor of the President and in honor of Brazil. We will be asking for things, but not necessarily having to do with that. I think we're just going to have a very fair relationship. Okay?
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that focusing solely on Russia distracts from the more significant geopolitical and economic challenges posed by China. Why does your administration appear to prioritize inquiries into Russia over addressing China's actions regarding trade, intellectual property, and global health security? [SEP] It's interesting how everyone keeps bringing up Russia. I have no problem discussing Russia, but I believe China is a far more pressing concern at this point. Consider the China virus and their failure to contain it within their borders. They've impacted 188 countries worldwide. Yet, you never inquire about China; it's always about Russia. I would be quite displeased if that's the case, and we'll be examining the data and documents carefully in the coming days.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. You're not bothered at all by the small missiles? [SEP] No, I'm not. I am personally not.
label: Explicit

sentence: Given the current economic climate, are you prepared to consider any compromises with Republicans regarding tax policy for high-income earners? [SEP] The priority, as I see it, is to provide some stability for working families who are struggling. There are areas where bipartisan agreement is possible, and those are the areas we should focus on first. Let's address the immediate needs of the American people.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Very quickly on Russia—I do have a number of domestic policy issues, but I'm—on Russia very quickly: It seemed like you said that you have assessed, you feel as though he will move in. Has this administration, have you determined whether President Putin plans to invade or move into Ukraine, as you've said? [SEP] Look, the only thing I'm confident of is that decision is totally, solely, completely a Putin decision. Nobody else is going to make that decision; no one else is going to impact that decision. He's making that decision.And I suspect it matters which side of the bed he gets up on in the morning as to exactly what he's going to do. And I think it is not irrational, if he wanted to, to talk about dealing with strategic doctrine and dealing with force structures in Europe and in the European parts of Russia.But I don't know if he's decided he wants to do that or not. So far, in the three meetings we've had—OSCE and—anyway—have not produced anything because the impression I get from my Secretary of State, my National Security Adviser, and my other senior officials that are doing these meetings is that there's a question of whether the people they're talking to know what he's going to do.So the answer is—but based on a number of criteria as to what he could do—for example, for him to move in and occupy the whole country, particularly from the north, from Belarus, it's—he's going to have to wait a little bit until the ground is frozen so he can cross.To move in a direction where he wants to talk about what's going—we have—we're continuing to provide for defense capacities to the Ukrainians. We're talking about what's going on in both the Baltic and the Black Sea, et cetera. There's a whole range of things that I'm sure he's trying to calculate how quickly he can do what he wants to do and what does he want to do.But I—he's not—he's an informed individual. And I'm sure—I'm not sure—I believe he's calculating what the immediate, short-term, and the near-term, and the long-term consequences of Russia will be. And I don't think he's made up his mind yet.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue your administration's response to the pandemic was disorganized and slow. How do you address concerns that this lack of preparedness contributed to the high number of cases? [SEP] Look, we had a lot of people working very hard. We inherited a system that was broken, obsolete. We streamlined it, we made it efficient. We had some tremendous people, the best people, working on this. And frankly, the numbers speak for themselves. We did a great job, a really great job.
label: Dodging

sentence: Will you definitively rule out a government shutdown before the new Congress convenes? [SEP] I'm hoping we can avoid it. But I can't predict the future. There are a lot of moving parts. So, I can't give you a definitive answer.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, about Russia, what's your assessment of Medvedev's influence, and what's the one piece of advice you'd give to the next president about navigating the relationship with Russia? [SEP] It's tough to gauge Medvedev's true authority. The G-8 summit will be telling. We need to work with Russia on shared interests like preventing nuclear proliferation and addressing Iran. We'll have disagreements, but communication is vital. My advice is to strive for a stable, if not always friendly, relationship.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, DC Mayor Bowser has issued a mask mandate. Will you encourage federal properties, including the White House and military bases, to follow suit? [SEP] We're evaluating the situation and considering all factors. We'll announce our decision shortly. We're taking this seriously, okay?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Where's the microphone? Here we go. [Laughter] The President. You don't need it. [Laughter]Canada-U.S. Trade  Q. Mr. President, Susan Li from Fox Business. Did you reject a one-on-one meeting with the Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau? [SEP] Yes, I did.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, can you clarify whether the United States and Romania now share a unified perspective on the future of this region, particularly regarding NATO's focus, after your discussions today? [SEP] [Muffled sounds]
label: Dodging
