We are prepared to implement the most stringent economic sanctions ever imposed, and the repercussions would be substantial. Others will also be affected, including ourselves and the European nations, but his economy would bear the brunt of the impact. He currently possesses the capability to invade, assuming the ground freezes near Kiev. He has the capacity, but his ultimate course of action remains uncertain. And I suspect that only he knows the answer.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: While respecting the confidentiality of the selection process, could you outline the key criteria you're using to evaluate potential Fed Chair nominees? [SEP] The nomination process is proceeding as planned, and we anticipate making announcements shortly. We are confident that we will have ample time to secure confirmation for all key nominees. I have been working closely with my economic team to identify the best candidates, and we have several excellent options under consideration. I prefer not to comment further at this stage.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, aside from the summit cancellation, are you planning any other measures to penalize Russia? [SEP] It's important to understand that our decision regarding the summit wasn't solely about Mr. Snowden. It also reflects a broader lack of progress on various issues where we believe cooperation is possible. Therefore, it's not simply a punitive action. We will assess how the relationship can advance U.S. interests and promote peace, stability, and prosperity globally. Where collaboration is possible, we will continue to engage. Where disagreements exist, we will express them clearly. My hope is that Mr. Putin will eventually recognize that cooperation, rather than a zero-sum competition, can ultimately benefit both our nations.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, beyond simply 'maintaining positions,' what concrete steps will you take to advocate for abortion rights in the face of potential Congressional gridlock? [SEP] We will continue to fight for what we believe in.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Considering the historic election of two Muslim women, one veiled, to the House, would you say this represents a public disagreement with your policies? [SEP] I'm afraid I didn't grasp the connection you're making. Could you clarify?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. ——tweet again this morning. What exactly do you mean by invasion? [SEP] What I mean is people are going to become—they are going to be opening up areas of your neighborhood—which they're doing and now they're going to do—they wanted to expand it. And they will expand it. If for any reason—they're going to in my opinion destroy suburbia.And just so you understand 30 percent-plus of the people living in suburbia are minorities. African American Asian American Hispanic American—they're minorities. Thirty percent. The number is even higher it's—they say 35 but I like to cut it a little bit lower. You know why? That way I can never get myself in too much trouble with the fake news. But 30 percent-plus are minorities living in suburbia.And when they go in and they want to change zoning so that you have lots of problems where they want to build low-income housing—you want something where people can aspire to be there not something where it gets hurt badly. And that's what happens.So with suburban women suburban men I think they feel very strongly about what I'm doing. It's a very—I mean it's a very fair question. It's a very important question. But they fought all their lives to be there and then all of a sudden they have—something happened that changes their life and changes what they fought for for so many years.John [John Roberts Fox News] please.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. And secondly, Mr. President, tomorrow you're going to be rolling out your financial regulation plan. And I know you're not going to want to step all over what you're going to say tomorrow. However, we do know from your advisers that you plan to recommend the creation of a new agency, the Consumer Financial Protection Agency. So you'll have the CFPA, you've got the Fed, the SEC, the FDIC, and on and on; it's like alphabet soup. Why did you decide not to consolidate agencies, but instead to add to the agencies? Isn't too many agencies part of the problem? [SEP] You're right; I don't want to step on my announcement tomorrow. So let me just speak in broad principles, and then tomorrow you'll have a chance to ask questions of the administration about exactly what we've proposed.The broad principle is that a lack of oversight, a series of regulatory gaps allowed financial institutions--not just banks, but non-bank institutions--to engage in wild risk-taking that didn't simply imperil those institutions, but imperiled the United States economy and had a profound recessionary effect on the world economy. We have to make sure that we've got a updated regulatory system--that hasn't been significantly changed since the 1930s--to deal with enormous global capital flows and a range of new instruments and risk-taking that has been very dangerous for the American people.We are going to put forward a very strong set of regulatory measures that we think can prevent this kind of crisis from happening again. We expect that Congress will work swiftly to get these laws in place. I want to sign them, and we want to get them up and running.And I think when you see the overall approach that we're taking, you'll see that we have not, in fact, added a whole host of regulatory agencies. In fact, there's going to be streamlining, consolidation, and additional overlap so that you don't find people falling through the gaps, whether it's on the consumer protection side, the investor protection side, the systemic risk that we need to make sure is avoided, on all those issues that's going to be a much more effectively integrated system than previously.But it's going to be, as usual, a heavy lift, because there are going to be people who want to keep on taking these risks, counting on U.S. taxpayers to bail them out if their bets go bad. And you'll hear a lot of chatter about, we don't need more regulation and government needs to get off our backs. There's a short memory, unfortunately, and I think that's what some of the special interests and lobbyists are going to be counting on, that somehow we've forgotten the disaster that arose out of their reckless behavior. And I'm going to keep on reminding them so we make sure that we get something in place that prevents this kind of situation from happening again.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Biden, considering the legislative gridlock surrounding voting rights, what concrete steps, beyond legislative action, will your administration take to safeguard access to the ballot box, and what specific measures are being considered to counter alleged voter suppression efforts? [SEP] Look, the right to vote is sacred, and we're not going to let anyone stand in the way of Americans exercising that right. We're exploring every avenue to protect the franchise, including executive orders, increased enforcement of existing laws, and partnerships with state and local officials. We're also working to educate voters about their rights and to combat misinformation that could discourage them from participating in the democratic process. I'm not going to telegraph our specific strategies, but I can assure you that we're fully committed to ensuring that every eligible American has the opportunity to cast their ballot.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, the UN's economist is sounding alarms about possible disruptions to the food supply chain during this pandemic. What is your administration's plan to mitigate this risk and guarantee food availability for American families? [SEP] Well, let me tell you, our farmers are doing a tremendous job, producing food at levels that are simply unbelievable. We're also focused on ensuring efficient transportation – I'm actually meeting with transportation officials tomorrow to discuss food delivery logistics. So, we're performing exceptionally well in terms of food production. I haven't received any reports of significant issues, and major retailers like Kroger and Walmart appear to be in very good shape. We are committed to maintaining a robust food supply. Now, one final question, please.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, what specific metrics will be used to measure the success of this bank bailout, and what consequences will financial institutions face if they fail to meet these benchmarks? [SEP] We will be closely monitoring the impact of this initiative on lending, job creation, and economic growth. We will hold financial institutions accountable for meeting their targets. If they fail to do so, they will face consequences. We are committed to transparency and accountability. We will provide regular updates to the American people on the progress of this initiative.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, in light of your Nobel Peace Prize and the potential intervention in Syria, how do you reconcile these seemingly opposing forces? Also, can you detail how your discussion with Prime Minister Reinfeldt moved the needle on resolving the climate crisis? [SEP] Regarding the Nobel, I direct you to my acceptance speech, where I openly questioned my worthiness compared to past recipients. I articulated the inherent difficulty of promoting peace in a world plagued by violence and evil. The central question is, what are our responsibilities? I've strived to end the war in Iraq, scale down Afghanistan, and prioritize diplomacy. But the question that confronts us all is: when do we draw the line and confront actions that violate our common humanity? Seeing children gassed, innocent civilians dying senselessly, and having the capacity to take meaningful action, even if incomplete, the moral imperative is to not stand idly by. This is the most difficult aspect of this job. I would much prefer to focus on early childhood education than preventing chemical attacks on young children. Unfortunately, these are the decisions I face as President. And frankly, as President, I cannot sidestep these questions because, despite criticisms, when atrocities occur, the immediate question is: what will the United States do? Libya, Rwanda, Sierra Leone, now Syria. It's part of the job description. And your second question, please remind me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, concerning the G-7 oil price cap, are you certain it will reduce prices at the pump for Americans, and what's the expected timeframe for relief? [SEP] Remind me, the question was about price reduction?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, given the recent meeting in Alaska and ongoing human rights issues, how would you describe your current relationship with China? Are you now more likely to keep tariffs in place, block imports made with forced labor, or limit U.S. investment in China? [SEP] Those are important questions, but they don't fully capture the scope of our relationship with China. I've known Xi Jinping for quite some time, longer than many other world leaders. We've had extensive discussions, going into great detail. He's very direct, but he's not a democrat in the traditional sense. He believes autocracy is the way forward. After my election, we had a lengthy conversation. I emphasized that we're not seeking conflict, but we will engage in strong competition and demand that China adhere to international rules: fair competition, fair practices, fair trade. To compete effectively, we must invest in American workers and scientific innovation. We once dedicated over 2% of our GDP to research; now it's only 0.7%. I intend to reverse that trend. We're also committed to strengthening our alliances. This isn't about being anti-China; it's about democracies working together. I'll be speaking with European leaders shortly, and I recently met with the Quad (Australia, India, Japan, and the US) to ensure China is held accountable. I'm also planning to convene an alliance of democracies to discuss the future. We must hold China accountable for its actions in the South China Sea, regarding Taiwan, and on human rights. No American president should shy away from condemning the treatment of the Uyghurs or the situation in Hong Kong. That's fundamental to our identity. I anticipate robust competition with China. They aspire to global leadership, but that won't happen under my leadership.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, isn't it a bit dismissive to simply disregard polls that show a decline in your approval rating among key demographics? [SEP] I'm not dismissing the concerns of the American people. I'm simply saying that polls are not always an accurate reflection of reality. We are focused on doing what's right for the country, and we believe that the American people will ultimately recognize that.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. What will you do to support them, sir, outside Syria? [SEP] Well, I'm just telling you, we're going to be discussing that situation. We have already started discussing that situation. But we have tremendous support from the Kurds in defeating ISIS. Okay?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, the QAnon movement seems to be attracting a significant following. What are your thoughts on this, and what message do you have for those who are part of it? [SEP] With all due respect, I'm not entirely sure what QAnon is all about. I've been told they're very supportive, which is always a good thing. But I'm focused on the issues that matter most to the American people: jobs, the economy, and national security. What I do know is that there are a lot of people out there who are unhappy with the way things are going, particularly in cities like Portland and Chicago. They see the problems, the crime, the disorder, and they want change. These are people who love this country, and they want to see it succeed. So, while I can't comment on QAnon directly, I understand their frustrations, and we're working to address them.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, in January, when you announced your troop surge, you said that its goal was to get all 18 Iraqi Provinces, the security for those Provinces into Iraqi hands by November of this year. The Pentagon, pardon me, is now telling Congress that's not going to happen until July at the earliest. Have the goalposts shifted once more? [SEP] No, the goals are the same; achieving those goals have been slower than we thought. And the question is, one, whether or not it's worth it to try to achieve the goals. I believe it's worth it for the security of the country. And the reason why I believe it's for the security of the country is that if we were to leave before the job was done, extremist groups like Al Qaida would be able to gain safe haven. That's what they've said they want. They believe we won't have the will to hang in there and help this i Government succeed. And they want us out.And so the goals of helping is provide their own securities remain the same, and the goals are important toward achieving our objective, and our objective is important for the security of the country. I also believe that a democracy in the heart of the Middle East will be a major blow to extremists or radicals wherever they live in the Middle East. And just yesterday we saw an attack on an anti-Syrian/pro-Lebanese democracy advocate. Now, I don't know who did that, but I do know it is typical of this war we're fighting in, when extremists kill innocent people in order to undermine democracies.One of the things I feel passionately about is for the United States to recognize what a Middle East would be like if terrorists and extremists were—would have safe haven and were emboldened by a U.S. defeat. And that's why I'm—one, I believe we can succeed, and two, I know we got to succeed—and therefore, have listened carefully to our commanders and our diplomats as to whether or not they think we can succeed, and if so, what do they need to do it. And that's what I talked to the country about.And so, Mark, yes, the goals are the same. And have we achieved them as fast? No, we haven't. But however, having not achieved them doesn't mean we ought to quit. It means we ought to work hard to achieve the goals, because the end result is the same, whether the goal is done in November or in July, and that is a country that can govern itself, sustain itself, and defend itself and is an ally against these extremists and radicals; a country which will deny safe haven to the folks who have sworn allegiance to the crowd that attacked us on September the 11th.A couple of more, and then I'm going to let Leavitt come up here.Blackwater USA Incident in
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. And he said—well, at least the quote said that. And he also said, quote, he sees no evidence to suggest Iran wants to build a nuclear bomb. Were you disappointed with that message? And does that indicate possibly that international pressure is not as great as you once thought against Iran abandoning its nuclear program? [SEP] I—as I say, I look forward to—if those are, in fact, his comments, I look forward to having him clarify those, because when I visited with him, he understands that it's in the world's interest to make sure that does not have the capacity to make a nuclear weapon. And that's why on—in the first round at the U.N., he joined us, and second round, we joined together to send a message. I mean, if he wasn't concerned about it, Bret, then why did we have such good progress at the United Nations in round one and round two?And so I will visit with him about it. I have not yet been briefed yet by Condi or Bob Gates about, you know, their visit with Vladimir Putin.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, the U.K. travel ban exemption ends tonight. Given that 17 Schengen countries have lower coronavirus rates than the U.K., and the U.K. reported 208 new cases yesterday, why the exemption for the U.K.? Are you considering adding them to the restricted list? [SEP] That decision was based on recommendations from experts, and we're reviewing it in light of the new data. We may need to add them to the list of countries we're, shall we say, restricting travel from during this time. Their numbers have increased significantly in the past 24 hours, so we may add them, and possibly others. We might also consider removing some countries from the list.
label: Implicit

sentence: With respect to Prime Minister Maliki's objectives and the fight against Al Qaeda, are you saying the U.S. will not intervene in the sectarian violence? And Prime Minister Maliki, what was the reason for cancelling last night's meeting? [SEP] Excuse me, could you repeat the initial part of your question? It was rather long.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, to what extent will the U.S. increase its commitment to global vaccine access, and is the 2022 target for ending the pandemic still viable? [SEP] Achieving a global end to the pandemic might take a bit longer than 2022. The U.S. is steadfast in its commitment. We're considering the possibility of providing an additional billion doses in 2022 or 2023, but that's not yet certain. I'm careful to only state what I know and what I believe we can accomplish. I don't want to make unrealistic promises. There was a general agreement at the G-7 that we'll continue our efforts until the entire world is vaccinated. This is not only ethically right but also essential for our own well-being and security. No wall can effectively block new strains. This will be a continuous undertaking. We need a system to detect potential pandemics early on. We're assisting other nations in producing their own vaccines. It's a significant logistical challenge. Final question.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Will this be over before you leave office? And what's your opinion on Israel's conduct? [SEP] That's my sincere hope. I'm in favor of a sustainable ceasefire, which, by definition, means Hamas stops launching rockets into Israel. A ceasefire simply won't hold if they keep firing. I believe the ball is in Hamas's court. We think the best approach is to work with Egypt to cut off the arms supply to Gaza, which fuels Hamas's attacks. Nations providing weapons to Hamas need to stop. The international community needs to keep the pressure on them to cut off the supply. Hamas, naturally, if they want a lasting ceasefire, needs to disarm. And neighboring countries need to cooperate to stop the smuggling. It's a tough job, with tunnels and plenty of chances for those who want to undermine democracy to provide weapons. Now, what was the second part of your question again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Are you saying you'll make your final decision tomorrow? [SEP] I want to observe. I need to see how things unfold. I have meetings scheduled with numerous countries tomorrow, but I'll definitely make time to watch. I'm also trusting in the judgment of some very fair and capable Republican Senators. Let's be honest, if we presented George Washington himself, the Democrats would still vote against him. He probably had some skeletons in his closet, right? Schumer and his cronies would oppose George Washington with 100 percent certainty. So, the FBI's findings are irrelevant. Even if they conducted the most thorough investigation and found him completely innocent, he'd still lose every vote. If the Republicans prevail tomorrow, some Democrats might change their tune. Why? Politics. Alright, next question.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Obama, what specific factors led to the decision to relocate the G-8 summit from Chicago to Camp David? [SEP] The primary reason was logistical. We wanted to align it with the NATO summit to minimize travel for world leaders. The Camp David idea came about later, and it seemed like a great opportunity to host my counterparts in a more relaxed environment. It's a chance for us to have open and honest conversations. And of course, it allows me to meet with President Putin. I have no doubts about Chicago's security capabilities for the NATO summit. They're more than equipped to handle it.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Uribe, given the extensive discussions about Chavez, could you share your assessment of whether his influence in the region is being exaggerated, in your opinion? [SEP] My opinion on what, exactly?

sentence: Q. Regarding the filibuster: At John Lewis's funeral, President Barack Obama said he believed the filibuster was a relic of the Jim Crow era. Do you agree? [SEP] Yes.

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Huawei, is there a possibility, however remote, that the company will be removed from the entity list? Can you give us any insight into the ongoing discussions? [SEP] I'm not gonna telegraph my punches on that one. We're taking a hard look at the whole situation with Huawei. It's a complex issue with serious implications for our national security and intelligence. I'll just leave it at that for now. We'll address it when the time is right.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, given the ongoing economic challenges in Europe, what specific contingency plans are in place to protect the United States from potential spillover effects, such as a recession or financial instability? [SEP] We are closely monitoring the situation in Europe and are prepared to take action if necessary to protect our economy. We have a strong financial system and a resilient economy. We are working with our international partners to address global economic challenges. We are confident that we can weather any storms that may come our way.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: With Speaker Boehner facing considerable pressure from within his own party, particularly from members representing districts where you were not successful, what assurances do you have that he can effectively rally his caucus behind any bipartisan agreement you negotiate? [SEP] The Speaker's got a tightrope to walk, no doubt about it. He's got to balance the needs of his party with the needs of the country. But I believe he's up to the task. He's a seasoned politician, and he understands the importance of compromise. We may not agree on everything, but I believe we share a common goal: to move this country forward. And that's what I'm focused on.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Would you be concerned about doing it before then? [SEP] I think our generals ought to be concerned about making sure there's enough of a presence so that the Provincial elections can be carried off in such a way that democracy advances. But that—I'll wait and hear what they have to say. But yes, I mean, that ought to be a factor in their recommendation to me. I apologize.Do you want to call on somebody? Yup.
label: Implicit

sentence: Following up on busing, do you see it as a feasible method for school integration, and how does it fit into your upcoming policy? [SEP] It's been used for a long time, one way or another. It's how you get kids to school. Sometimes it's been done harshly. But it's been a common method. If Biden had answered differently, it would've gone differently for him. It's a primary way of getting kids to schools.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, concerning Venezuela, even with the sanctions and aid, Maduro hasn't budged. Are you worried about losing steam, and what's the estimated timeframe for a solution there? [SEP] Nobody's telling me how long it's gonna take. They've been there a long time, both of them. Eventually, things gotta change, right? But we haven't even hit 'em with the real sanctions yet. We can go hard. Everything's on the table. We've been playing it cool so far, but we can get a lot tougher if we need to. It's a real shame, what's happening there. We just wanna help those people who are starving. It's a disgrace. Richest country in the world, and now it's just... poverty, no food, no water, no nothing. It's falling apart.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, why should Mexicans believe in immigration reform now after so long? And what are the chances of getting this bill through Congress? [SEP] Good question. Things take time in Congress, you know? We haven't really talked seriously about this until recently. I know it's important, I was Governor of Texas. People were worried we weren't enforcing the laws. I think we've shown them we are, so Congress is more open to fixing things. A good reform bill will mean fewer people sneaking across the border, and we can focus on the real bad guys. I'm feeling good about it because both parties are talking. We're helping them find common ground. I don't bet, but I'm hopeful. It's good for everyone.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, can we expect you to visit the affected area? [SEP] Pardon me?

sentence: Q. Just to be clear, the business sector benefits, and the climate is addressed, but your direct involvement isn't essential? Is that a fair summary? [SEP] I'm afraid I didn't follow that. Could you please rephrase the question?

sentence: Mr. President, a question from China: Do you still think a U.S.-North Korea relationship akin to the U.S.-Vietnam one is a possibility? [SEP] Could you repeat the question? I want to make sure I heard you correctly.

sentence: Mr. President, do you believe Speaker Boehner has the full support of his caucus to pass legislation he agrees to? [SEP] That's really a question for the Speaker himself. I have a good working relationship with John. He's a good man. But the Republican caucus has some, shall we say, strong personalities. It's up to them to sort things out. I'm confident they'll find a way to work together for the good of the country. But it's their internal matter, not mine.

sentence: Q. The election of two Muslim women, one veiled, to the House is historic. Do you see this as a rejection of your message? [SEP] I'm sorry, I didn't catch that. What was the question?

Was the pace of policy reversal perhaps too accelerated? [SEP] Sorry, I missed that. What exactly are you asking about?

sentence: Sir, with all due respect, the lack of a clear timeline is causing concern. Can you offer any assurance that this initiative will be implemented in a timely manner? [SEP] In all candor, I'm unable to provide a definitive date for implementation at this stage.
