sentence: Q. What about David Cameron? [SEP] Never met him. Well, I don't—I mean, I—it's not for me to give advice to the leader of the Conservative Party or a different political party. And that's up to them as to what they do and up to him as to whether he comes here or not.But I do just make this observation to you, and—that what we are trying to do is—never mind these two individual leaders, but the two countries; let's accept for a moment that at least—even if people very strongly disagree with Iraq, for example— that at least people understand that there is a battle that we are fighting around the world today.And let's at least accept, also, that it's a battle about the type of values that govern the world in the early 21st century. You don't win those battles by being a fair-weather friend to your ally. You don't win those battles by being hesitant or withdrawing support for each other when the going gets tough. You don't win those battles by losing the will to fight if your enemy's will to fight is very strong and very powerful.And actually, the values that we represent, as two countries, are shown by what we—what we've been through today. I mean, the President gets tough questions from the American press corps; I get, I like to say, even tougher questions—[]—or at least as tough questions in the British press corps. And—— If you want to define them as tough. [] And we can—here as we speak at this press conference, I mean, I can't make out the words that they're shouting over there, but I bet they're not totally complimentary to either of us. [] Wait a minute. I don't know about that. [] I mean, it could be the supporters we brought in, but I've got a feeling the likelihood is, no. [] And that's what it's about. It's about democracy, and it's about people being free to express their views, and it's about politicians having to face the pressure to justify their decisions, to be punished if the people don't like those decisions. And it's a commonality of values that we have that is so important for the world today.And so you know, yes, of course, it's like—anybody who's sitting there advising a politician in any part of Europe today, if you want to get the easiest round of applause, get up and attack America. You can get a round of applause if you attack the President. You get a—— Standing ovation. [] Yes. And that's fine if everyone wants to do that, but when all of that is cleared away, you're left with something very, very simple, fundamental, and clear, that that battle for values is still going on.And you can debate about the mistakes and the issues, and you can debate about Iraq, whether we should have done this, or we should have done that. But actually, what is happening in Iraq today is that our enemy is fighting us, and, therefore, if what happens when our enemy fights us is that we drift away from our friends, that we kind of make the little accommodations so that we don't escape some of the difficulty and the responsibility and, occasionally, opprobrium of decisionmaking, if we do that, our enemy takes heart from that; they watch that. They watch what we're doing the whole time. They ask, Are these guys standing up for what they believe, or if we carry on, is their will going to diminish and they're going to give up because it's just too difficult, because the public opinion is too difficult, because the opinion polls tell them it's too difficult?Now, that is the decision of leadership. And it's not just a decision for me and him; it's a decision for everybody who's engaged in politics. And people run down politics and say it's all just a series of positions and attitudes and sound bites and, occasionally, even lies and all the rest of it. Actually, what politics is in the end, when it's done in the right way, when people stand up for what they believe, is, it's about public service. And there's nothing to be ashamed of in that. And the fact is, the decisions are difficult; of course, they're difficult.And we took a decision that we thought was very difficult. I thought then and I think now, it was the right decision. History will make a judgment at a particular time. But one thing I know is that what we represent coming here today, speaking in the Rose Garden to you people and getting your questions and being under your pressure, that is a finer and better way of life than either a brutal, secular dictatorship or religious extremism. It's a better way of life, and it's the way of life, actually, people, any time they are given the choice, choose to have. And what we should be about, our two nations, is giving as many people in the world as possible that choice and being proud of it. What I know is, the world needs courage. And what I know is, this good man is a courageous man.Thanks for coming. Appreciate you.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, could you share any developments regarding the trade discussions with China? [SEP] China is doing wonderfully. The talks are proceeding splendidly. Thank you, everyone.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Dilma, how do you respond to the perception that the U.S. sees Brazil as a regional power, while Brazil aspires to be a global leader? How does this affect the relationship between our nations? [SEP] Brazil's role in the world is undeniable. We are a major player in international forums, and our contributions to global issues are significant. While some may see us as a regional power, we are actively engaged in shaping the global agenda. The United States recognizes our importance, and we are committed to a strong partnership based on mutual respect and shared interests.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, may I ask a question on behalf of the foreign press? [SEP] Coming from which outlet, specifically?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, are you aware of the QAnon conspiracy theory which claims you are fighting a secret war against a satanic cult of pedophiles? [SEP] I haven't delved into that particular theory, but if it means saving the world from evil, then I'm all for it. We are fighting a radical-left agenda that threatens our nation and the world. We need strength, not weakness.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Long before today, you've been considered a rights President. Under your watch, people have said that you have expanded the rubberband of inclusion. And with the election and the incoming administration, people are saying that rubberband has recoiled and maybe is even broken. And I'm taking you back to a time on Air Force One going to Selma, Alabama, when you said your job was to close the gaps that remain. And with that, what gaps still remain when it comes to rights issues on the table? And also, what part will you play in fixing those gaps after—in your new life?And lastly, you are the first Black President. Do you expect this country will see this again? [SEP] Well, I'll answer the last question first. I think we're going to see people of merit rise up from every race, faith, corner of this country, because that's America's strength. When we have everybody getting a chance and everybody is on the field, we end up being better.I think I've used this analogy before. We killed it in the Olympics in Brazil. And Michelle and I, we always have our—the Olympic team here. And it's a lot of fun, first of all, just because anytime you're meeting somebody who is the best at anything—[]—it's impressive. And these mostly very young people are all just so healthy looking, and they just beam and exude fitness and health. And so we have a great time talking to them.But they are of all shapes, sizes, colors: the genetic diversity that is on display is remarkable. And if you look at a Simone Biles, and then you look at a Michael Phelps, they're completely different. And it's precisely because of those differences that we've got people here who can excel at any sport.And by the way, more than half of our medals came from women. And the reason is, is because we had the foresight several decades ago, with something called Title IX, to make sure that women got opportunities in sports, which is why our women compete better, because they have more opportunities than folks in other countries.So I use that as a metaphor. And if in fact we continue to keep opportunity open to everybody, then, yes, we're going to have a woman President, we're going to have a Latino President, and we'll have a Jewish President, a Hindu President. Who knows who we're going to have? I suspect we'll have a whole bunch of mixed-up Presidents at some point that nobody really knows what to call them. [] And that's fine.Now, what do I worry about? I obviously spent a lot of time on this, April, at my Farewell Address on Tuesday, so I won't go through the whole list. I worry about inequality, because I think that if we are not investing in making sure everybody plays a role in this economy, the economy will not grow as fast, and I think it will also lead to further and further separation between us as Americans, and I—not just along racial lines. I mean, there are a whole bunch of folks who voted for the President-elect because they feel forgotten and disenfranchised. They feel as if they're being looked down on. They feel as if their kids aren't going to have the same opportunities as they did.And you don't want to have an America in which a handful—a very small sliver of people are doing really well and everybody else is fighting for scraps, as I said last week. Because that's oftentimes when racial divisions get magnified, because people think, well, the only way I'm going to get ahead is if I make sure somebody else gets less, somebody who doesn't look like me or doesn't worship at the same place I do. That's not a good recipe for our democracy.I worry about, as I said in response to a previous question, making sure that the basic machinery of our democracy works better. We are the only country in the advanced world that makes it harder to vote rather than easier. And that dates back; there's an ugly history to that that we should not be shy about talking about.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, on Meng Wanzhou, will the case be delayed until the end, or is it possible the U.S. drops the extradition effort? [SEP] Extradition on what grounds?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, with Russia engaging with both the U.S. and Guaidó, what assurances can you provide? [SEP] Just relax. We've got this. We know everything you're saying, and it's all going to work out. We're very much in the loop. Okay? Thank you all.
label: General

sentence: Thank you, sir. Are you concerned, Mr. President, that commuting Chelsea Manning's sentence will send a message that leaking classified material will not generate a tough sentence to groups like WikiLeaks? How do you reconcile that in light of WikiLeaks' connection to Russia's hacking in last year's election? And related to that, Julian Assange has now offered to come to the United States. Are you seeking that? And would he be charged or arrested if he came here? [SEP] Let's be clear, Chelsea Manning served a substantial prison term. It's not as if there were no consequences. My view is that she went through the trial process, accepted responsibility, and her sentence was disproportionate compared to others. She served significant time, so commuting her sentence was appropriate. I believe justice was served, and a message was sent about national security. Those with concerns should use established channels and whistleblower protections. I recognize some feel those aren't enough, but national security involves people in the field whose lives are at risk. As for WikiLeaks, I haven't commented generally. The intelligence community's conclusions on Russian hacking and WikiLeaks' involvement were inconclusive. I don't follow Assange's tweets. Refer to the Justice Department on criminal investigations. In this cyber age, we must balance accountability, openness, and transparency with the need to protect ourselves from adversaries. We must preserve our democracy while allowing our agencies to function effectively without revealing our strategies. With Chelsea Manning, I considered the specifics and felt commuting her sentence was appropriate.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You addressed—I want to follow up on Jon's questions about the issue that's obviously deeply personal and moving to you—that is the gun issue. Apart from Congress's inaction, apart from the desire for new laws and, beyond that, apart from the gun lobby, as you noted, the pattern is that these perpetrators are angry, aggrieved, oftentimes mentally ill young men. Is there something that you can do with the bully pulpit, with your moral authority, with your remaining time in office to help reach these individuals who believe that gun violence is the way out? [SEP] No I think I can continue to speak to the American people as a whole and, hopefully, model for them basic social norms about rejecting violence and cooperation and caring for other people But there are a lot of young men out there And having been one myself once, I can tell you that us being able to identify or pinpoint who might have problems is extraordinarily difficultSo I think we, as a culture, should continuously think about how we can nurture our kids, protect our kids, talk to them about conflict resolution, discourage violence I think there are poor communities where, rather than mass shootings, you're seeing just normal interactions that used to be settled by a fistfight settled with guns, where maybe intervention programs and mentorship and things like that can work That's the kind of thing that we're trying to encourage through My Brother's KeeperBut when it comes to reaching every disaffected young man, 99 percent of—or 999 percent of whom will, hopefully, grow out of it, I don't think that there's a silver bullet there The way we are going to solve this problem is that when they act out, when they are disturbed, when that particular individual has a problem, that they can't easily access weapons that can perpetrate mass violence on a lot of peopleBecause that's what other countries do Again, I want to emphasize this There's no showing that somehow we are inherently more violent than any other advanced nation or that young men are inherently more violent in our Nation than they are in other nations I will say young men inherently are more violent than the rest of the population, but there's no sense that somehow this is—it's something in the American character that is creating this Levels of violence are on par between the United States and other advanced countries What is different is homicide rates and gun violence rates and mass shooting rates So it's not that the behavior or the impulses are necessarily different as much as it is that they have access to more powerful weaponsJulia Edwards [Reuters]
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. Mr. President, did you or your Chief of Staff order an investigation of the leak of the Hadley memo before your meeting with Prime Minister al-Maliki? And if the leak wasn't authorized, do you suspect someone in your administration is trying to undermine your Iraq policy or sabotage your meeting with Prime Minister al-Maliki a few weeks back? [SEP] I'm trying to think back if I ordered an investigation. I don't recall ordering an investigation. I do recall expressing some angst about ongoing leaks. You all work hard to find information and, of course, put it out for public consumption, and I understand that. But I don't appreciate those who leak classified documents. And it's an ongoing problem here, it really is, not just for this administration, but it will be for any administration that is trying to put policy in place that affects the future of the country.And we've had a lot of leaks, Mark, as you know, some of them out of the—I don't know where they're from, and therefore, I'm not going to speculate. It turns out, you never can find the leaker. It's an advantage you have in doing your job. We can moan about it, but it's hard to find those inside the Government that are willing to give, in this case, Hadley's document to newspapers.You know, there may be an ongoing investigation of this; I just don't know. If there is, if I knew about it, it's not fresh in my mind. But I do think that at some point in time, it would be helpful if we can find somebody inside our Government who is leaking materials, clearly against the law, that they be held to account. Perhaps the best way to make sure people don't leak classified documents is that there be a consequence for doing so.Jim [Jim Gerstenzang, Los Angeles Times].
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Time for one more, Mr. President? [SEP] If you're not asking me a mean one like you usually do. []
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning General Neller's warning to marines in Norway about an impending 'big-ass fight,' how imminent is this war, and where do you anticipate it occurring? [SEP] When you say 'the big war,' you're saying what? Say it again, please.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President——Coronavirus Prevention Efforts in the U.S.  Q. And, sir, if I could follow up, how should Americans prepare for this virus? Should they go on with their daily lives? Change their routine? What should they do? [SEP] Well, I hope they don't change their routine. But maybe, Anthony, I'll let you—I'll let you answer that. Or Bob? Do you want to answer that? Please. Sure, Mr. President. Thank you. I think it's really important that—as I said, the risk at this time is low. The American public needs to go on with their normal lives. Okay?We're continuing to aggressively investigate these new community links. We're going to continue to be transparent in relating that to the American public. But at this stage, again, the risk is low. We need to go on with our normal lives.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. Regarding China, what is your deadline, if you have one, for China to make progress on trade before you impose the tariffs on the other $325 billion in goods? [SEP] Well, we're going to be meeting—President Xi and myself—and you know we have a very good relationship. But, again, he's for China, and I'm for the U.S. It's a big difference. And we thought we had a deal. We didn't have a deal. And I would never make something that would be less than what we already had.We had China opened up to trade. That's a big thing. They've never done that before. We had intellectual property theft taken care of and taken care of beautifully. And all of the sudden, those things started to disappear at the end, after they were fully negotiated.But that's—you know, that's their decision. I think if they had to do again—and in light of the fact that we have 25 percent on $250 billion of goods coming into the United States. And unlike a lot of countries, they subsidize those goods. We haven't had inflation. And you know, they keep saying that the American taxpayer is paying for it. No. No. Very little.And what it really does mean is that a lot of those companies that are in China are going to be moving back to the U.S. You have car companies—General Motors, as an example—that built plants in China. Well, that doesn't work out too well when you have the tariff wall up because now they're going to have to get through that and they can't really get through that. So maybe they'll start building plants in the United States instead.I think that we'll end up making a deal with China. We have a very good relationship, although it's a little bit testy right now, as you would expect. I think they really have to make a deal. A lot of companies are leaving China, as you know. It's in all the reports. And they're going to Vietnam and various other places, and they're also coming to the United States to make their product because they don't want to pay the tariff.And there is no tariff if you do it in the United States. People don't realize that. You know, they say the tariff, but there is no tariff if you don't do it—you know, if you just do exactly as I say: You bring your company back to the United States.And as far as Mexico is concerned, which was a very big topic yesterday—and now people are finding out that the reports that were written were totally false—we would never have had a deal with Mexico without imposing tariffs. Once the tariffs were imposed—and they've been trying to make this deal with Mexico for 20 years, 25 years. The older reporters, those great reporters with the very gray hair in the back—you know who I'm talking about; they know exactly what I'm talking about—you would have never made the deal with Mexico.We have a great deal with Mexico. I actually think we have a much better relationship right now with Mexico because they respect us again. But you would never have had that deal if I didn't impose the tariffs. And those tariffs were ready to go to on Monday morning, and we made the deal on, essentially, Sunday night.And that extra little page of the deal that you saw that brilliantly—I had gained such respect for you people when I held it up to the sunlight and it was closed, and you were able to read it through the sunlight. That was not anticipated. But regardless, I mean, you knew enough of what it said. And I didn't do it on purpose, but we have a lot of strength in 45 days if we decide to use that strength. Maybe we will, and maybe we won't. But there's a lot of power right now in the border.And I will say this: Mexico is, right now, doing more for the United States on illegal immigration and all of the problems of crime and other problems on the border than the Democrats. We can solve our problem on the border in 15 minutes if the Democrats would sit down, straighten out asylum—which is a total mess, but very uncomplicated—straighten out asylum, and get rid of the loopholes. It would take, Jeff, 15 minutes.Okay? Thank you. Please.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, won't commuting Manning's sentence encourage leaks, especially given WikiLeaks' alleged Russian ties? And what about Assange's offer to come here – are you pursuing that, and would he face charges? [SEP] First, Manning did hard time. It wasn't a free pass. She went to trial, took responsibility, and her sentence was way out of line with others. Given the time she served, commutation made sense. Justice was done, and the message is still clear: national security matters. If you have concerns, use the proper channels, the whistleblower protections. I know some think they're not enough, but we're talking about people in danger, our military, our intelligence. As for WikiLeaks, I haven't said much about them. The intel guys weren't sure if WikiLeaks knew they were getting hacked DNC emails from Russia. I don't follow Assange's tweets. Ask the Justice Department about him. In this new world of cyber threats, we need to balance openness with security. Our agencies need to do their jobs without telling everyone what they're doing. But with Manning, I looked at the case, like all the others, and decided it was the right thing to do.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President Obama, your administration faced criticism for its use of drone strikes in foreign countries. How do you reconcile the need for national security with concerns about civilian casualties and the potential for unintended consequences, and what ethical considerations guided your decisions in authorizing these strikes? [SEP] Well, these are incredibly difficult decisions, and they weigh heavily on any president. We always strived to minimize civilian casualties, and we followed the law. But we also had a responsibility to protect the American people from terrorist threats. It's a complex issue, and there are no easy answers. We tried to strike the right balance, but I understand that reasonable people can disagree.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. ——and he would never have invited him to Kennebunkport. And he said it's time we got a little tough with Vladimir Putin. I'm wondering if you think—is Senator McCain right? And what would it mean for Russian democracy if, when you leave power, assuming you do, in January 2009—[laughter]—if Vladimir Putin is still in power? [SEP] Yes. You know, one of the interesting—well, my leadership style has been to try to be in a position where I actually can influence people. And one way to do that is to have personal relationships that enable me to sit down and tell people what's on my mind without fear of rupturing relations. And that's how I've tried to conduct my business with Vladimir Putin. We don't agree on a lot of issues; we do agree on some. is one; nuclear proliferation is another. Reducing our nuclear warheads was an issue that we agreed on early.But I believe good diplomacy requires good relations at the leadership level. That's why, in Slovakia, I was in a position to tell him that we didn't understand why he was altering the relationship between the Russian Government and a free press—in other words, why the free press was becoming less free. And I was able to do— he didn't like it. Nobody likes to be talked to in a way that may point up different flaws in their strategy. But I was able to do so in a way that didn't rupture relations. He was able to tell me going into Iraq wasn't the right thing. And to me that's good diplomacy. And so I'm—and I'll continue to practice that diplomacy.Now, in terms of whether or not it's possible to reprogram the kind of basic Russian DNA, which is a centralized authority, that's hard to do. We've worked hard to make it appear in their interests—or we made it clear to them that it is in their interests to have good relations with the West. And the best way to have good long-term relations with the West is to recognize that checks and balances in government are important or to recognize there are certain freedoms that are inviolate. So Russia's a complex relationship, but it's an important relationship to maintain.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, given the House's likely vote on Iraq, and your Press Secretary's concern about the message sent to the enemy, do you believe a vote of disapproval emboldens them and undermines your policies? Also, what steps are you taking to prevent Congress from restricting your Iraq spending? [SEP] Yes, thanks. A couple of points: One, that I understand the Congress is going to express their opinion, and it's very clear where the Democrats are, and some Republicans; I know that. They didn't like the decision I made. And by the way, that doesn't mean that I think that they're not good, honorable citizens of the country—just have a different opinion. I considered some of their opinions and felt like it would not lead to a country that could govern itself, sustain itself, and be an ally in the war on terror—one.Secondly, my hope, however, is that this nonbinding resolution doesn't try to turn into a binding policy that prevents our troops from doing that which I have asked them to do. That's why I keep reminding people, on the one hand, you vote for David Petraeus in a unanimous way, and then the other hand, you say that you're not going to fund the strategy that he thought was necessary to do his job, a strategy he testified to in front of the Senate. I'm going to make it very clear to the Members of Congress, starting now, that they need to fund our troops, and they need to make sure we have the flexibility necessary to get the job done.Secondly, I find it interesting that there is a declaration about a plan that they have not given a chance to work. Again, I understand; I understand. The other part of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, the latest unemployment figures paint a grim picture. Critics argue you're on track to have the worst job creation record of any post-war president. Doesn't this leave you exceptionally vulnerable to a Republican challenger who can promise economic revitalization? And considering the recent economic headwinds, what's your forecast for the economy when you seek re-election? [SEP] Look, Jim, the political calculus of next year is the furthest thing from my mind right now. My focus is laser-locked on getting Americans back to work. People are hurting, and our economy isn't performing up to its potential. Everything we're doing at the G-20, from boosting growth to responsible deficit reduction, is geared towards that goal. We need to equip our workers with the skills to compete globally. The American Jobs Act isn't just about immediate jobs; it's about building a foundation for future prosperity through infrastructure investments and more. I'm hoping that Congress, when they analyze these job numbers – which, while positive, show sluggish growth – will reconsider their opposition to a plan that independent economists say would actually reduce unemployment. There's no excuse for inaction, whether it's on the global stage or here at home. I'll keep pushing forward, regardless of the political noise.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, critics are saying you're stalling on releasing those guard photos. What's your response? [SEP] Look, with all due respect, we're talking about two separate issues here. The real issue is making sure the Iranian people know we stand with them and that we're paying attention to what's happening. Ultimately, it's their struggle for justice that matters most. As Dr. King said, the arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends towards justice. We need to have faith that justice will prevail.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, concerning the debt negotiations, would you be open to tax cuts to stimulate the economy, even if they add to the deficit? Furthermore, with states like New York embracing same-sex marriage, do you now personally endorse it, irrespective of individual state decisions? [SEP] I'm not prepared to comment on that at this time. Good effort, however.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, supposing this drug demonstrates effectiveness, will you champion its accelerated approval within the United States? [SEP] That's a rather speculative proposition, wouldn't you agree? I'm not prepared to offer an opinion at this juncture, as my understanding is incomplete. The requisite data for a considered judgment is simply not yet available to me. Jon, ABC News, as I recall?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Hadley memo leak, did you personally authorize or direct your Chief of Staff to initiate an investigation prior to your meeting with Prime Minister al-Maliki? Furthermore, if unauthorized, do you suspect internal sabotage aimed at undermining your Iraq policy or disrupting that crucial meeting? [SEP] Well, let me see... an investigation, you say? I honestly don't have a clear recollection of specifically ordering one. What I *do* remember is expressing my displeasure, quite strongly, about these persistent leaks. The press, you all are resourceful, digging up information and, naturally, publishing it. I get it. But the leaking of classified material? That's a different story. It's a constant headache, not just for my administration, but for any administration trying to govern effectively. We've had a flood of leaks, as you know, from... various places. I won't speculate on the source; it's often impossible to pinpoint. You guys have an advantage there. We can complain, but finding the culprit within the government willing to hand over, say, Hadley's document to the newspapers is tough. There *might* be an ongoing investigation; I'm simply not sure. If there is, it's not top of mind. But I do believe that holding those who leak classified information accountable is crucial. A clear consequence might deter future leaks. Next question.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: So, after the call, you mentioned telling him he made a mistake. What was his reaction, and did he acknowledge it? [SEP] No, I didn't actually *tell* him anything. I asked him, 'What happened?' And I got the distinct impression that he wasn't even aware he had said what he supposedly said. I personally didn't witness him saying it.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. When you heard that, since that point, you think of how many hundreds of soldiers have been killed, how much money has been spent. Why shouldn't people conclude that you are either stubborn, in denial, but certainly not realistic about the strategy that you've pursued since then? [SEP] You know, it's interesting; it turns out, Mike Hayden—I think you're quoting Mike Hayden there—was in this morning to give me his weekly briefing, and I asked him about that newspaper article from which you quote. His answer was—his comments to the Iraq Study Group was a little more nuanced than the quotation you read.He said that he made it clear the current strategy in Iraq wasn't working—this is his recollection of the briefing to the Iraq Study Group. He briefed them to the fact it wasn't working and that we needed a change of direction. He also said that those who suggest that we back away and let the Iraqi's Government do it—this is in November 2006—let the Iraqis handle it, don't understand the inability of the Iraq Government at that time to take on that responsibility.He then went on to say—this is what he—his recollection of his conversation— was that our strategy needed to help get the violence down so that there could be political reconciliation from the top down as well as the bottom up.There has been political reconciliation, Martha, from the bottom up. Anbar Province is a place where the experts had— an expert had said that it was impossible for us to achieve our objective. This was the part of the country of Iraq where Al Qaida had made it clear that they would like to establish a safe haven from which to plan, plot further attacks and to spread their ideology throughout the Middle East. Since then, since this November 2006 report and since that statement to the Iraq Study Group, things have changed appreciably on the ground in Anbar Province.And they're beginning to have the same change, because the people on the ground there are sick and tired of violence and being threatened by people like Al Qaida, who have no positive vision for the future. And there's been a significant turn, where now Sunni sheikhs and Sunni citizens are working with the coalition to bring justice to Al Qaida killers. And that same approach is being taken in Diyala.And so there's a lot of focus, and should be frankly on oil laws or elections. But remember, there's another political reconciliation track taking place as well, and that's the one that's taking place at the grassroots level. Mike Hayden talked about that as well.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, can you definitively rule out a government shutdown during this post-election period? [SEP] Look, I'm not going to box myself in with any promises right now. The situation is fluid, and frankly, it's a bit of a gamble. So, while I can't give you a firm 'no,' let's just say anything is on the table.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, Black voters in a recent poll cited inflation as their top concern. What specific, concrete steps can you promise in the next two years to alleviate their financial burdens, especially considering the threat of a recession? [SEP] Well, let's look at the facts. Black unemployment has plummeted under my administration. More Black-owned small businesses are opening than ever before. We're helping people buy homes through the SBA, because homeownership is how most folks build wealth, like my own family. Now, I can't wave a magic wand and eliminate inflation overnight, but we're making progress. Gas prices are down over a dollar a gallon. But these oil companies, they're not helping. They raked in over $100 billion in profits last quarter! In the past, they would've invested in more refineries or passed savings onto gas stations. They're not doing that now. We're also tackling the costs that hit families hardest: prescription drugs. Starting next year, we're driving those prices down. Take insulin, for example. Too many people need it, and they're paying through the nose. We're capping the cost at $35 a month. We're going after all those expenses that families struggle with every month – the mortgage, food, gas, medical bills. We're passing laws to lower those costs, and they're starting to take effect. I'm optimistic because we're growing at a steady pace, not heading into a recession. I believe we can achieve a soft landing, gradually bringing down prices without crashing the economy.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the alleged Russian interference, shouldn't electors receive a classified briefing before they vote? And do you believe it's time to consider reforming the Electoral College? [SEP] That's a multifaceted question.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Yesterday, in a speech before business leaders, you said that you want China to play by the rules. And then your staff later said that, in a bilateral meeting with President Hu, that you expressed that American business leaders are growing frustrated with the pace of change in China's economy. What rules is China not playing by? What specific steps do you need to see from China? And what punitive actions is your administration willing to take, as you said it would yesterday, if China does not play by the rules? [SEP] Well, first of all, I also said yesterday that we welcome the peaceful rise of . It is in America's interests to see succeed in lifting hundreds of millions of people out of poverty. can be a source of stability and help to underwrite international norms and codes of conduct.And so what we've done over the last 2 years is to try to develop a frank, consistent, open relationship and dialogue with , and it's yielded considerable benefits, for example, support for issues like . But what I've also said to Chinese leadership since I came into office is that when it comes to their economic practices, there are a range of things that they have done that disadvantage not just the United States, but a whole host of their trading partners and countries in the region.The most famous example is the issue of 's currency. Most economists estimate that the RMB is devalued by 20 to 25 percent. That means our exports to are that much more expensive and their imports into the United States are that much cheaper. Now, there's been slight improvement over the last year, partly because of U.S. pressure, but it hasn't been enough. And it's time for them to go ahead and move towards a market-based system for their currency.Now, we recognize they may not be able to do it overnight, but they can do it much more quickly than they've done it so far. And by the way, that would not necessarily be a bad thing for the Chinese economy, because they've been so focused on export-driven growth that they've neglected domestic consumption, building up domestic markets. It makes them much more vulnerable to shocks in the global economy. It throws the whole world economy out of balance because they're not buying as much as they could be from other countries.And this is not something that's inconsistent with where Chinese leadership say they want to go. The problem is, is that you've got a bunch of export producers in who like the system as it is and making changes are difficult for them politically. I get it. But the United States and other countries, I think understandably, feel that enough's enough.That's not the only concern we have. Intellectual property rights and protections--companies that do business in consistently report problems in terms of intellectual property not being protected. Now, that's particularly important for an advanced economy like ours, where that's one of our competitive advantages, is we've got great engineers, great entrepreneurs, we're designing extraordinary new products. And if they get no protection, and the next thing you know, 's operating as a low-cost producer and not paying any fees or revenues to folks who invented these products, that's a problem.So those are two examples, but there are a number of others. These practices aren't secret. I think everybody understands that they've been going on for quite some time. Sometimes, American companies are wary about bringing them up because they don't want to be punished in terms of their ability to do business in . But I don't have that same concern, so I bring it up.And in terms of enforcement, the other thing that we've been doing is actually trying to enforce the trade laws that are in place. We've brought a number of cases. One that the U.S. press may be familiar with are the cases involving U.S. tires, where we brought very aggressive actions against and won. And as a consequence, U.S. producers are in a better position, and that means more U.S. jobs.So I think we can benefit from trade with . And I want certainly to continue cultivating a constructive relationship with the Chinese Government, but we're going to continue to be firm in insisting that they operate by the same rules that everybody else operates under. We don't want them taking advantage of the United States or U.S. businesses.Jake Tapper [ABC News].
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Do you think private citizens should be taking guns—[inaudible]? [SEP] I'd like to see law enforcement take care of everything. I think everything should be taken care of—law enforcement.But again, we have to give our cops back, our police back their dignity, their respect. They're very talented people. They're strong. They're tough. They can do the job, but we've taken it away. We don't want to have—when somebody makes a mistake, he chokes, or—in some cases, you have bad cops, and we have to take care of that.In other cases, they choke. They're under—they have a quarter of a second—a quarter of a second to make a decision, and sometimes, they make the wrong decision. If they make the wrong decision—you know, if they make the wrong decision in the other direction, they're probably dead. So they choke sometimes, and that goes on the evening news for weeks.And the thousands and tens of thousands of great things they do, nobody covers that. Nobody writes about that. But if they make a mistake——And again, the bad cops—everybody agrees they have to be very tough on bad cops. But sometimes you have a cop or a police person who is a good—a good police person, right? Good. But they choke. You know, the timing—and they go through this, and they study this, and they work on it all the time. They literally have a quarter of a second to make some of these decisions. And they make a wrong decision, and it's very devastating.But I will say this: I honor law enforcement. We wouldn't be here right now if it wasn't for law enforcement. We have to stop this horrible, left-wing ideology that seems to be permeating our country. And basically, it's weakness. It's weakness on behalf of Democrat politicians.The Republicans, we don't have problems. You take a look at our cities; our cities are doing very well. They're safe. They're secure. I spent a lot of time in Texas, as you know, just a couple of days ago. And I was with the Governor of Texas, Greg Abbott. He was explaining they wouldn't put up with it for a minute. They just don't have the kind of problems that other people have.Thank you very much. I appreciate it.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, anti-LGBTQ legislation is spreading across Republican states, causing families to consider leaving the country. What's your response? [SEP] First, get me the contact information for that family. I want to personally assure them of our support. As President, I proudly ended the ban on transgender individuals serving in the military, signed the Respect for Marriage Act, and strengthened civil rights protections for the LGBT community. However, we face opposition from prejudiced individuals who are spreading fear and division. It is unacceptable for someone to be fired for their sexual orientation or to face violence and hate crimes. We must protect transgender children from hateful bills and ensure their well-being. These are our children, and we must stand by them. I am announcing new initiatives to safeguard the LGBT community, including strengthening physical safety, addressing civil rights violations, and providing mental health support. Congress must pass the Equality Act. To all LGBTQ Americans, especially children, know that you are loved, heard, and supported by this administration. Regarding AI, it presents both opportunities and risks. We must establish safeguards to mitigate potential harms. We are collaborating with other nations on this matter, similar to our efforts on climate change. We need to act urgently. Now, I'd like to call on the BBC.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the ongoing challenges in Iraq, what specific benchmarks are you using to assess the progress of stabilization efforts and the commitment of regional actors to supporting a peaceful and stable Iraq? [SEP] We are closely monitoring a range of indicators to assess progress in Iraq, including security conditions, political reconciliation, economic development, and regional cooperation. We are also engaging with regional actors to encourage them to play a constructive role in supporting Iraq's stability and sovereignty.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Should we be traveling to Washington State?Withdrawal of U.S. Troops From Afghanistan Q. When do you anticipate troops will be returning? You said—how soon do you see them returning in this U.S.-Taliban agreement? How soon do you expect troops to be coming back? [SEP] Like, today. Okay? Today. They'll start immediately.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, if this situation is so detrimental to the country, why not simply put an end to it immediately? [SEP] Next question, please. I believe I've addressed this sufficiently.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. How is that going to be achieved, Mr. President? [SEP] Well, it's going to be achieved by having a lot of people there, and as we develop a certain trust. And we think we have done that. Secretary Pompeo has been really doing a fantastic job—his staff, everybody. As we do that, we're going to have a lot of people there, and we're going to be working with them on a lot of other things. But this is complete denuclearization of North Korea, and it will be verified.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, Vice President Biden spoke of a conversation where even with perfect execution, a 30% failure rate was possible. Can you tell us what you were discussing, and assure us it wasn't the stimulus or bank bailout? [SEP] I honestly can't recall the specifics of what Joe was referring to. But let me put it this way: the problems we're facing are so big that no single thing we do is going to be a silver bullet. As I've said many times, not everything we try is going to work out perfectly. This is new territory. While there's a general agreement among economists on how to move forward, the need for a big recovery package, and a mix of tax cuts and investment, even if we do everything right, we still have to fix the financial system, get banks lending again, deal with housing, and build a new regulatory system to prevent future crises. Those are all huge, complicated tasks. So, I don't know if that's what Joe was talking about, but that's the big picture.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, you've spoken about the need for banks to lend, their creativity in pursuing profit, and your ability to stop them from profiting excessively. How will you prevent them from charging these fees, and does the government have the right to dictate corporate profits? [SEP] I certainly don't believe that. I was trying to illustrate that financial regulation is often used as a pretext to charge consumers more. They claim that if one hidden fee is prohibited, they'll simply invent another to compensate. They're entitled to do that, but it's not a desirable practice and isn't necessarily fair to consumers. My primary objective is to establish a consumer watchdog that informs consumers about fair practices, ensures transparent transactions, and fosters competition among banks based on service quality and reasonable prices. The frustrating aspect is that some members of Congress, particularly Republicans, advocate for the removal of all restrictions on financial companies. This is a source of frustration for the American people, who have experienced hidden fees, unexpected rate increases, and incomprehensible fine print on credit cards and mortgages, contributing to overall economic weakness. Yes, I believe it's entirely appropriate for the government to have some oversight role to ensure consumer protection. Banks, like any business in America, can price their products as they see fit. That's how the free market operates, provided there's transparency and accountability, and consumers understand what they're getting. And there will be instances where a policy judgment is made that certain practices are simply unfair. That's how the market has always functioned.
label: General

sentence: Q. President, Robert Novak argues you're the most isolated president in recent history, worse than Nixon. Your thoughts? [SEP] Can you elaborate on Novak's definition of 'isolated' in this context?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, did you and President Biden discuss the alleged U.S. spying on South Korea? Did he offer any assurances? [SEP] We're in touch with the U.S. about that, sharing information. They're investigating, and it's a complex situation. We need to give them time to finish their investigation. We'll keep communicating.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Biden, you mentioned knowing Donald Trump. Had he not decided to run, would your decision to seek another term be any different? How much did his candidacy factor into your choice? [SEP] The truth is, I'd still be running. Knowing Donald – and he's not exactly hard to figure out – my reasons are about the work that still needs to be done. We have a real chance to lock in economic and political security for the long haul. This isn't about him; it's about the bigger picture, the ongoing struggle between democracies and autocracies. We're the leading democracy, and I'm deeply committed to that role. That commitment doesn't change based on who else decides to run.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. On the debt ceiling, your Treasury Secretary has estimated that the U.S. Government will lose its ability to pay its bills come late February or early March. House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan has said the Republicans are going to decide what it is they can accomplish on this debt limit fight—his words. Will you negotiate with House Republicans on the debt ceiling? [SEP] Oh, Brianna, you know the answer to this question. No, we're not going to negotiate for Congress to pay bills that it has accrued.Here's the good news: I want to emphasize the positive as we enter into this holiday season. I think Congressman Ryan and Senator Murray did a good job in trying to narrow the differences and actually pass a \budget that I can sign. It's not everything that I would like, obviously. It buys back part of these across-the-board cuts, the so-called sequester, but not all of them. So we're still underfunding research, we're still underfunding education, we're still underfunding transportation and other initiatives that would create jobs right now.But it was an honest conversation. They operated in good faith. And given how far apart the parties have been on fiscal issues, they should take pride in what they did. And I actually called them after they struck the deal, and I have said congratulations, and I hope that creates a good pattern for next year, where we work on at least the things we agree to, even if we agree to disagree on some of the other big-ticket items.I think immigration potentially falls in that category, where let's—here's an area where we've got bipartisan agreement. There are a few differences here and there, but the truth of the matter is, is that the Senate bill has the main components of comprehensive immigration reform that would boost our economy, give us an opportunity to attract more investment and high-skilled workers who are doing great things in places like Silicon Valley and around the country. So let's go ahead and get that done.Now, I can't imagine that having seen this possible daylight breaking when it comes to cooperation in Congress that folks are thinking actually about plunging us back into the kinds of brinksmanship and governance by crisis that has done us so much harm over the last couple of years.To repeat: The debt ceiling is raised simply to pay bills that we have already accrued. It is not something that is a negotiating tool. It's not leverage. It's the responsibility of Congress. It's part of doing their job. I expect them to do their job. Although I'm happy to talk to them about any of the issues that they actually want to get done. So if Congressman Ryan is interested in tax reform, let's go. I've got some proposals on it. If he's interested in any issue out there, I'm willing to have a constructive conversation of the sort that we just had in resolving the budget issues. But I've got to assume folks aren't crazy enough to start that thing all over again.
label: Explicit

sentence: President Calderon, critics argue that your response avoids directly addressing the inflammatory nature of the ad and its potential impact on the energy bill debate. Can you clarify whether you believe such comparisons are helpful or harmful to national unity and constructive dialogue in the Mexican Congress? [SEP] My focus remains on encouraging productive dialogue within Congress. The energy bill is crucial for Mexico's future, and we need a serious, fact-based discussion. Getting sidetracked by these kinds of personal attacks and historical comparisons only distracts from the real issues at hand. I trust that the Mexican people are smart enough to see through these tactics and focus on the substance of the debate.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President—— Q. Do you think Cipollone and Sekulow would want you there? [SEP] I think they might have a problem. []
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. So is August 2 a yellow light or a red light? [SEP] I think people should think of--look, I'm the President of the United States, and I want to make sure that I am not engaging in scare tactics. And I've tried to be responsible and somewhat restrained so that folks don't get spooked.August 2 is a very important date. And there's no reason why we can't get this done now. We know what the options are out there. This is not a technical problem any longer. This is a matter of Congress going ahead and biting the bullet and making some tough decisions. Because we know what the decisions are. We've identified what spending cuts are possible. We've identified what defense cuts are possible. We've identified what health care cuts are possible. We've identified what loopholes in the Tax Code can be closed that would also raise revenue. We've identified what the options are. And the question now is are we going to step up and get this done.And you know, Malia and Sasha generally finish their homework a day ahead of time. Malia is 13; Sasha is 10.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Libya, what's the timeline for transferring command, and will NATO assume control? Furthermore, what concrete results do you expect from your "alliance among equals" with the Americas following this trip? And President Pinera, what are the key elements of this partnership to achieve regional objectives? [SEP] Well, in Libya, the situation is very fluid. The timing of the command transfer depends on our commanders' assessment that the initial phase is complete. Our priority is neutralizing Libyan air defenses for the no-fly zone and coalition aircraft safety. We're also focused on humanitarian aid. We anticipate this transition in a matter of days, not weeks. The Pentagon will update the public and press. NATO will play a coordinating role. Admiral Mullen can detail the transfer process. Regarding the partnership, I don't want to spoil my speech. Chile offers valuable insights. Their clean energy efforts are impressive, leading to a partnership. We're strong in alternative energy, but Chile's initiatives could benefit us. On education, we want American students to broaden their horizons, hence the exchange program. Security: We can learn from Colombia's success against drug cartels and apply those lessons to Central America. Collaboration with Chile and Colombia can improve security training. This is a two-way partnership, not just aid. Chile is a rising power collaborating for peace and prosperity. We lag in Americas' integration compared to Europe. Latin America must realize its potential. We share much with the U.S. We aim for a Partnership 2.0, sharing values. It should include democracy, human rights, trade, education, science, and technology. We can learn from U.S. innovation. This alliance addresses energy, crime, terrorism, and climate change. It requires a new international order. Now is the time for collaboration, facing challenges and seizing opportunities. Latin America missed the Industrial Revolution; we can't miss the information age. No country should be left behind.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Sir, is there any indication as to when the next round of discussions with Shanghai Media Group might take place? [SEP] Look, I wish I had a crystal ball. It's up in the air. Could be soon, could be later. We'll see what happens.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Sir, following up on reports of coronavirus cases in the White House, can you confirm if you were informed? [SEP] I apologize, but the connection is breaking up. I didn't catch that.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, in relation to the established red lines, is a military response a potential course of action in the event of a ransomware attack? Additionally, considering President Putin's description of you as 'experienced' and your earlier statement about him having no soul, has your understanding of him changed as a result of this meeting? [SEP] Thanks, everyone. I have to run.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, as you consider ending the war, can you justify the immense human and financial costs, given that Afghanistan is less developed than initially envisioned? President Karzai, do you stand by your claim that foreign influence is largely responsible for Afghanistan's corruption and poor governance, and are you fully committed to stepping down after next year's elections? [SEP] Let's remember why we went to Afghanistan. 3,000 Americans were murdered by terrorists operating openly there. It was right to go after that organization and the government that allowed it. Our troops and Afghan allies achieved our main goal: to weaken Al Qaida so they can't attack us again. Everything we've done has focused on that. We'll be able to say our sacrifices achieved that goal. We also wanted a stable, sovereign Afghanistan, a responsible partner. That required Afghanistan to have its own security and be on a path to prosperity and peace. Afghanistan still has work to do, but the possibility of peace and prosperity is higher now than before we went in. That's partly because of American sacrifices. Did we achieve everything we imagined? Probably not. It's a human endeavor. Did we achieve our main goal? Have we shaped a strong relationship with a responsible Afghan government that will cooperate to prevent future attacks? We're achieving that. We thank our military, intelligence, and diplomatic teams, as well as the Afghan government and people. Sir, on corruption, there is corruption in Afghanistan. We're fighting it. We've succeeded somewhat, but we're not satisfied. On foreign corruption in Afghanistan, I've been clear that Afghanistan needs cooperation from international partners to fix how assistance is delivered. On elections, my greatest achievement will be a proper, interference-free election where Afghans can elect their next president. I'll be a happily retired president.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Concerning India, are you pleased with the existing investment environment, particularly in multi-brand retail and e-commerce, areas of considerable interest to U.S. companies? [SEP] Indeed. They're investing substantial sums of money. I recently met with Mr. Patel, the world's largest steel magnate, who's constructing a billion-dollar facility in Alabama. The press was present, and they were discussing how much more favorable it is to invest in the U.S. now. These are some of the world's leading entrepreneurs. Mr. Patel is investing billions because of my efforts to revitalize the steel industry. It was virtually nonexistent, but now it's thriving, and it's essential for our defense. He was beaming. I anticipate seeing some of you on the plane. It's an incredible nation with exceptional leadership and a promising future. Thank you.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, in terms of the timetable for tax reform, Speaker of the House Paul Ryan has said he wants to get it done by the end of this year. He would make the House stay through the Christmas break in order to get it done. The Senate Majority Leader has said we'll get it done this Congress. Would you be okay if tax reform were not passed until next year as opposed to this year? [SEP] Well, I would like to see it be done this year, John.. I would too. . I would like very much to see it be done this year. So we won't go a step further. If we get it done, that's a great achievement.But don't forget it took years for the Reagan administration to get taxes done. I've been here for 9 months, a little more than 9 months. I can say the same thing for health care. If you look at Obama—first of all, you look at Clinton, they weren't able to get it done. You look at other administrations, they weren't able to get it done. President Obama, after a long period of time, was able to finally push it through, but pushed through something that's now failed—it's really failing badly. But again, we're meeting—Democrat, Republican are meeting right now, and right now they're working on something very special.But I have to tell you, I really believe that we have a very good chance, and I think Mitch feels the same way of getting the——. Yes, let me—— . ——of getting the taxes done, hopefully, fairly long before the end of the year. That's what we'd like to see.Go ahead.. Could I just add? Yes, let me just—let me just add to what the President said. The goal is to get it done this calendar year. But it is important to remember that Obama signed Obamacare in March of year 2. Obama signed Dodd-Frank in July of year 2. We're going to get this job done, and the goal is to get it done by the end of the year. . And just to finish up for Mitch—and we're 9 months, right? So—[].. Yes. . So we could have a long way to go, but that's okay.Yes. /Office of National Drug Control Policy Director-Designate Thomas A. Marino/
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, to be clear, will you endorse the current version of that proposal? [SEP] Not that specific proposal, but we're making progress, believe me. What's important is getting money to those who were unfairly hurt by something that could have been stopped. They could have stopped it from leaving their country. They could have stopped it from coming here, to Europe, to the entire world – 188 countries, can you imagine? Please.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Now that he's openly aiming for Prime Minister, what does that say about the state of democracy in Russia? [SEP] I'm looking forward to seeing him at the 'Person of the Year' reunion. Don't know when that is. I'm guessing they put him on there because he's a big deal. But the question is, what kind of big deal? What will Russia be like in ten years? I hope they get that they need checks and balances, free elections, and a real press. I hope they get that Western values, like human rights, are the way to a better country. That's my hope. As for him being Prime Minister, I haven't talked to him about it. So, we'll just have to wait and see. It'll be interesting to see what the new Russian President does. We'll probably meet a few times, and it'll be interesting to see how things are run and what Putin does. We'll just have to see.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, was the individual carrying a weapon? [SEP] That's my understanding. I can't confirm it. You'd have to direct that question to the appropriate authorities.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, based on your current assessment, do you believe President Putin will authorize a full-scale invasion of Ukraine before winter's end? And what's your advice to the approximately 30,000 Americans currently in Ukraine – should they evacuate? [SEP] Look, I've had numerous conversations with the Russians, especially with Putin. I honestly don't know if he's made up his mind yet. He needs to understand that invading Ukraine would be a colossal error. The consequences for Europe and the world would be devastating, and he'd pay a steep price. I've been very direct with Putin, both on the phone and in person. We're prepared to impose unprecedented economic sanctions, and the repercussions would be severe. Others will feel the impact too, including us and the Europeans, but his economy would suffer immensely. He's in a position to invade, assuming the ground freezes near Kiev. He has the capability, but what he'll actually do, I can't say. And I doubt anyone knows for sure except him.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Last question on humanity. Sir, you can't legislate and you can't Executive order out the issue of empathy or the lack thereof in the midst of this rhetoric—this heated political rhetoric. What's next? [SEP] Part of what I think leadership requires—and I hope I meet this standard—is letting people know you understand their problem. Again, my dad used to have an expression. He said, I don't expect the Government to solve my problems, but I expect them to at least know what they are, understand them.And like a lot of you, we've been very fortunate as a family, but we've also been through a lot of fairly tough times. And it's not—and I've had the great advantage of having a family to get through them.When my first wife and daughter were killed when a tractor trailer broadsided them and killed my wife and—killed my first wife and killed my daughter, and my two boys were expected to die; they were in the—it took the jaws of life 3 hours to get them out. They were on top of their dead mother and dead sister. I understand what that pain is like.And when Jill and I lost Beau after a year in Iraq, winning the Bronze Star and Conspicuous Service Medal, a major in the United States military, came home with stage 4 glioblastoma because he lived about 200—between 2- and 500 yards from burn pit that's 10 feet deep and as big as a football field, burning every toxic waste you could find.You know, I think that we understand what it's like to lose family members, mothers, fathers, to cancer—all of you have been through that kind of thing. We've been fortunate though. We've had each other. We've had strong families—Jill's sisters, my brothers, my sister.And so what we can do to deal with that empathy is make sure there's help available, make sure there's people who are there to help—whether they are a psychologist or whether they're medical doctors or whether they're social workers—to be there to help, to help just hold a hand.And, for example, we can do an awful lot for a lot of families, the families you're talking about, if we—reinstate this child tax credit. It cut child poverty by 40 percent when it was in place. I couldn't get it passed the second time around.So there's a lot we can do. And the empathy is not just talking about it, it's communicating to people you genuinely understand. And I hope a lot of people don't understand, because they—I don't want people having to know the pain.But the second piece of that is, let them know that you are there to help. You're there to help.And one of the things I've talked with Vivek Murthy about—and a lot of you have written about it, and you've written it well about it—is the need for mental health care in America. You know, when we got elected, there were something like, I don't know, 2-, 3-, 5 million people who had gotten their COVID shots.Well, in the meantime—I've got over 220 million people all three shots. But in the meantime, what happened? We lost over a million dead. A million dead.I read one study that for those million people, they had nine people who were—each one of them had, on average, nine people close to them. A relative, someone they're married to, a child—someone close.The impact has been profound. It's been profound. Think of all the people—think of all your children and your grandchildren who didn't have that senior prom, who didn't have that graduation party, who didn't have all the things we had that we took for granted, that impact on their psyche.So there's a lot we have to do. And empathy reflects itself not just on what a person demonstrates they understand—of knowing what people need and helping to make it happen. And we're trying to do that. And a lot of Republicans are trying to do it too. I don't mean this as a partisan thing. A lot of people are trying to do it because they know we've got a problem.Okay, excuse me. These 10 questions are really going quickly. []
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, you indicated last week that Secretary Rumsfeld would remain in his position. What is the rationale behind this timing, and to what extent did the election results factor into this decision? [SEP] Correct. Prior to the election, you and others inquired about Rumsfeld and the Vice President, and I stated that they would remain. I didn't want to inject a significant decision about the war into the final days of the campaign. That was the most straightforward way to answer the question. However, I also hadn't yet had the opportunity to speak with Bob Gates or have my final discussion with Rumsfeld. Rumsfeld and I had been discussing the importance of fresh perspectives. He understood that progress in Iraq wasn't occurring rapidly enough. We were continuously assessing the situation and whether we had the right people and strategy in place. We frequently adapt our tactics, which requires ongoing evaluation. He and I both agreed that it was appropriate for me to accept his resignation. Consequently, the decision was made. I had anticipated a favorable election outcome, but regardless, Bob Gates would have been the nominee.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, could you detail the strategy for distributing resources to minority communities, and outline your plans for improving the lives of African Americans in a second term, considering the current rise in unemployment? [SEP] I appreciate the question. We've achieved a significant reduction in poverty, particularly among African Americans. The employment figures have been the best ever recorded. Of course, the coronavirus has presented challenges. Our focus is on high-risk individuals and frontline workers. We have established thousands of distribution centers, specifically targeting minority and low-income areas. Prioritizing testing at Historically Black Colleges and Universities is also a key objective. It's disheartening to see some individuals attempting to instill fear about the vaccine. It is safe, effective, and essential for everyone, especially those at higher risk, to receive it. This negativity emerged when it appeared we might have a vaccine before the election. It's purely political, driven by disinformation. Similar to the fabricated football ad or the misleading story about me. They are criticizing the vaccine out of fear. However, we are nearing a breakthrough, with massive distribution planned within weeks, prioritizing seniors. We are conducting extensive testing at HBCUs, an initiative I proposed. We will soon surpass one hundred million tests. This allows us to identify problem areas. Other countries, lacking testing, report no cases. We take pride in our testing efforts. So, yes, we are making significant progress. Next question.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, last week you stated that Secretary Rumsfeld would remain in his position. Why is this the right time for that decision, and how much does it relate to the election results? [SEP] Right. Well, you and others asked me about Rumsfeld and the Vice President before the election, and I said they'd stay. I didn't want to make a big decision about the war during the campaign. That was the easiest way to answer the question. But also, I hadn't spoken with Bob Gates or had my final talk with Rumsfeld yet. Rumsfeld and I had been discussing fresh perspectives. He knew Iraq wasn't improving fast enough. We were always assessing the situation and whether we had the right people and strategy. We constantly change tactics, which requires assessment. He and I agreed that I should accept his resignation. So, the decision was made. I thought we'd do well in the election, but win or lose, Bob Gates would have been the nominee.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: In the event that Republicans attempt to undermine your executive action by cutting off its funding, what measures will you take to ensure its success? Furthermore, could you offer some insight into the potential scope of this action, perhaps indicating whether it's expected to impact 2 million individuals or more? [SEP] I imagine that when I announce the executive action, it will be very detailed. And I'm sure there will be a lot of questions afterwards.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Do you think the election of two Muslim women, one veiled, to the House is a rebuke of your message? [SEP] I'm not quite following. Can you elaborate?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, following up on China, considering the complexities you've outlined, how do you balance the need for economic competition with the imperative to address human rights abuses and security concerns in the South China Sea? [SEP] Look, it's a balancing act, no doubt about it. We're not naive. We understand China's ambitions, but we're not going to let them steamroll over international norms or trample on human rights. We'll use every tool at our disposal – economic pressure, diplomatic engagement, strategic alliances – to ensure they play by the rules. We're not looking for a fight, but we won't back down from defending our interests and our values. It's a complex situation, but we're approaching it with clear eyes and a steady hand. We will continue to call out the human rights violations and the actions in the South China Sea, and we will continue to make sure we are investing in our own country, in our own workers, so that we can compete on a level playing field.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, critics suggest your administration's focus on Ukraine and ISIL is a convenient distraction from domestic issues, particularly immigration reform. How do you respond to the perception that you're prioritizing foreign policy to avoid addressing contentious issues at home? [SEP] Look, I'm juggling a lot right now. Ukraine's a powder keg, ISIL's a threat, and NATO needs a serious kick in the pants. These aren't distractions; they're critical challenges to American security. As for immigration, Holder and Johnson are working on recommendations, and I'll get to them. My preference is still for Congress to act, but they've been sitting on their hands. So, yes, I intend to act within my authority to secure the border and streamline the process. It's about responsible governance, not dodging difficult issues.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, the American people deserve clarity. Can you prioritize: expedited conclusion or thorough investigation? And what about Bolton? [SEP] The process is ongoing. Let's not jump to conclusions.
