That's the good news. And that's going to start very, very soon. I believe that's going to start very soon. We will do it as fast as it can mechanically and physically be done, Steve.
label: General

sentence: Q. But if it's that important to you, why wouldn't you bring it—at that level, bring it directly up to King Abdallah? [SEP] We'll have plenty of time. He knows our position loud and clear. McKinnon [John McKinnon, Wall Street Journal].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, the deadline for nominating a Federal Reserve Chair is rapidly approaching. Can you share any insights into your selection process or potential nominees? The markets are getting antsy, and frankly, so is the public. Are you concerned about the potential economic impact of this delay, especially if you choose not to reappoint Chairman Powell? [SEP] Look, the process is well underway. We're considering a range of highly qualified candidates, and I assure you, we'll be making an announcement in due course. We're not going to be rushed by artificial deadlines or market jitters. We're focused on making the right decision for the long-term health of the American economy. I've got the best people working on it, and we're going to get it done. You can be sure of that.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. What's your reaction? Is that enough—that kind of a letter? [SEP] No, I think the Fed has a very important role and especially psychological. I mean, if you look at the—the Fed has a massive impact. Lots of it is psychological, and lots of it is fact.This is something I think they should have done even beyond this and before this, because other countries—that are not as nearly as prime. We're the greatest in the world. It's our currency. Everything—we have everything. We should have the lowest interest rates. We don't have the lowest interest rates. Our Fed rate is higher.You look at Germany. You look at Japan. You look at other countries. They have—many of them have negative rates. And we are not put in that position because of our Fed. And now we have this problem. You saw where Germany is lowering and also infusing a lot of money into their economy, a tremendous amount. I haven't heard our Fed say they should do this.Our Fed should start being a leader, not a follower. Our Fed has been a follower. We need a Fed that's going to be a leader. We should have at least the same rates and ideally lower rates than other countries. We shouldn't be paying more, but we're forced to pay more in interest. And we are the most prime.Think of it: biggest economy in the world, by far. China would have overtaken us in this year; they were expected to for 5 years—2019, they were going to overtake us. They're not even close, and they won't be close as long as somebody smart is right here, they won't be close. But I will say this: The relationship with them is good, but as far as the Fed is concerned, our Fed should be a leader. Our Fed has not been a leader at all.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, will the current sanctions regime against North Korea remain in effect? [SEP] The sanctions are there. A lot of people said we gave up a lot, but we didn't give up anything. We have a great relationship with Chairman Kim, and North Korea has tremendous potential. We'll see what happens.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, to be clear, are you advocating for a boycott, or simply stating that people have the right to choose? [SEP] I'm just pointing out the obvious. People are smart. They see what's going on. They don't like being told what to think or what to wear. And if companies are going to try to control them, well, they might just decide to take their business elsewhere. I'm not telling anyone what to do. I'm just saying, we've built the greatest economy ever, and people have choices. And those companies better remember that. It's a free market, after all. And by the way, those jobs? We're making more all the time. So, if they want to be foolish, that's their problem.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, following the recent election, there's been considerable speculation regarding Secretary Rumsfeld's future. Can you provide insight into the decision-making process that led to his resignation, particularly in light of your previous statements? [SEP] The situation with Rumsfeld is this: I addressed the question before the election specifically to avoid politicizing the war effort. The truth is, I hadn't yet had the chance to fully evaluate all options, including discussions with Bob Gates and a final conversation with Don Rumsfeld. He himself recognized the need for a new approach in Iraq. We are constantly assessing our strategy and personnel needs. The decision for him to resign was mutually agreed upon yesterday. While I anticipated a different outcome in the election, the change in leadership was already in motion. Bob Gates was always the plan.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Given the Republican majority, what steps would you take regarding the Keystone XL pipeline bill? Also, with the drop in oil prices, how does this impact the project's contribution to climate change and its overall viability? [SEP] Well, let's be clear, Keystone is about Canadian oil, not American oil. It benefits Canadian companies. The impact on U.S. gas prices is minimal. Now, regarding the climate, I want to ensure this project doesn't worsen the problem. We need to consider the costs, like increased flooding and wildfires. The State Department will make its decision after the Nebraska judge resolves the path issue. It's not a magic formula for the U.S. economy.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, in light of the changing political landscape in Russia, what guidance would you impart to your successor concerning the approach to this new leadership and the potential threats it poses? [SEP] Look, I'm not going to second-guess the next president. They'll have their own team, their own advisors. But I would urge them to remember that Russia is a complicated player on the world stage, and we need to be smart about how we deal with them.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Sir, you've been talking about state sovereignty, but how does that fit with the 'responsibility to protect' idea that was so important before? [SEP] Could you repeat the last part of your question about the responsibility to protect?
label: Clarification

sentence: After Brexit, Mr. President, who will be the more important relationship for the United States: President Macron and France, representing the EU, or Prime Minister Boris Johnson of the United Kingdom? [SEP] Well, France is a great nation. They have a lot going on. Macron's trying to make changes, which is never easy. I'm not going to get into the specifics, but it's a tough job. A lot of people disagree with his ideas, but he's trying to do what he thinks is right. It's hard to change things when people love their country and the way they've always done things, but sometimes it's necessary. I think he'll do a fantastic job, but it's tough. I know how tough it is for him. Boris has a different situation. He has to deal with Brexit, which is also very tough. The EU is a very strong group, and they're not easy to deal with. We're close to making a deal with the EU, by the way. We made a great deal with Japan, and we're close to a deal with the EU because they don't want tariffs. They don't want to tax Mercedes Benz and BMW. We're going to have a really fair deal. But the EU is another one. We've been losing $180 billion a year for many years. That's a lot of money.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. Yesterday the President of Brazil was talking about the importance not only of growing the economic pie, but making sure that it's divided more equitably. I wonder how you think that applies within the United States, where the idea of spreading the wealth around isn't always warmly greeted, and how, for example, with this free trade agreement, you make sure that the benefits are widely shared. And if I may, sir, on an unrelated topic, if I could get your reaction to the Prime Minister Netanyahu's comments that the P-5-plus-1 had given Iran a freebie with this additional time.And for President Santos, what responsibility do you believe the countries of Latin America, especially those that have become more democratic, have for helping to bring Cuba into the democratic fold? [SEP] The goal of any government should be to create security for its citizens and to give them opportunity to achieve prosperity and to pass that prosperity on to their kids. And I'm a strong believer that the free market is the best tool ever invented to create wealth.But what's true in every country is that we always have to think about whether every single person is getting a fair shot, where they actually have opportunity. Is everybody doing their fair share to support the common efforts that are required to create a platform for growth? Is everybody playing by the same set of rules? And I think the history of the United States, the reason we became an economic superpower is because--not always perfectly, not always consistently, but better than any other country on Earth--we were able to give opportunity to everybody. That's what the American Dream was all about.So when we have debates now about our tax policy, when we have debates now about the Buffett rule that we've been talking about, where we say if you make a million dollars a year or more you shouldn't pay a lower tax rate than your secretary, that is not an argument about redistribution. That is an argument about growth. Because the history of the United States is we grow best when our growth is broad-based. We grow best when our middle class is strong. We grow best when everybody has opportunity. And that means that somebody who has a great idea and is selling a great product or service, we want them to get rich. That's great. But we also want to make sure that we as a society are investing in that young kid who comes from a poor family, who has incredible talent and might be able to get rich as well.And that means we've got to build good schools, and we've got to make sure that that child can go to college. And we also want to make sure that we keep our scientific edge, and that means we've got to invest in basic research. And that means that we've got to have some basic safety net, because people are more willing to take risks that are required for the free market to work if they know that if they fall on hardship, if something happens, that there's still some floor that they can't fall beneath and that they'll be able to retire with some dignity and some respect.And so one of the things that we're going to be talking about over the next several months as we debate the budget and Government spending and the proper role of Government, is just--I want everybody to remember, I'm going to say this repeatedly--this is not an argument about taking from A to give to B. This is not a redistributionist argument that we're making. We're making an argument about how do we grow the economy so that it's going to be prospering in this competitive 21st-century environment. And the only way we're going to do that is if people like me, who have been incredibly blessed, are willing to give a little bit back so that the next generation coming along can succeed as well. And the more people that succeed, the better off the country is going to be.With respect to the Iranian talks, I've been very clear on this. Iran has violated U.N. Security Council resolutions. They're the only country that's a member of the Non-Proliferation Treaty, the NPT, that cannot convince the international community that they are abiding by the rules governing the NPT. And not just the United States, but the world community is now imposing some of the toughest sanctions that we've ever seen, and there are more to come. And it is my view that it would be contrary to the security interests of the United States and destabilizing for the world and the region, if Iran pursues, develops, obtains a nuclear weapon. So I've been very clear, and I've been talking about this quite a bit lately.What I've also been clear about is that the best way to resolve this issue is diplomatically and my belief that we still have a window in which to resolve this conflict diplomatically. That window is closing, and Iran needs to take advantage of it. But it is absolutely the right thing to do for the U.S. Government, working in concert with the other permanent members of the Security Council, with Germany, with the rest of the world community, to pursue this path.Part of the reason we've been able to build a strong international coalition that isolates Iran around the nuclear issue is because the world has confidence that I've been sincere and my administration has been sincere about giving Iran an opportunity to pursue peaceful nuclear energy while foreclosing the pursuit of a nuclear weapon. That strengthens our hand. That's part of the reason why we've been able to execute on these strong sanctions. And we're going to keep on seeing if we make progress.Now, the clock is ticking. And I've been very clear to Iran and to our negotiating partners that we're not going to have these talks just drag out in a stalling process. But so far, at least, we haven't given away anything other than the opportunity for us to negotiate and see if Iran comes to the table in good faith. And the notion that somehow we've given something away or a freebie would indicate that Iran has gotten something. In fact, they've got some of the toughest sanctions that they're going to be facing coming up in just a few months if they don't take advantage of these talks. I hope they do.Was there a--you guys ask too many questions. I start forgetting. Any foreign policy has a formula: Interests plus principles equals a foreign policy. So how do you combine these interests and principles, and how you defend those principles is what makes a foreign policy. In our case and in the case of many countries--countries that believe in freedom and democracy--we have the obligation to make sure that those principles are applied in every form possible and in every place possible.But there are different formulas to defend and apply those principles as well. There are certain paths that are more effective than others. In some cases, sanctions may work. Generally, they don't, but they may work in some cases. In some other cases, it has been proven that sanctions are not the solution, and in these cases, we need to then pursue the defense of those principles through other ways.And in our case, Colombia and other Latin American countries that believe in democracy and believe in freedom, we have the obligation to pursue those principles following the most effective paths. And I believe that that can yield the best results. Thank you very much, everybody. .
label: General

sentence: Q. Were they yesterday at the event? [SEP] But it's a small—it's—last night I heard about it for the first time. And it's a small number of cases. Maybe it's not even cases.Do you know if—do you have any idea if there's—— Yes. . What is it? There—yes, but we're not going to confirm the identities of the individuals. . Yes, that's okay. Yes, but it did not affect the event, and press was not around the individual.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. Bush, regarding missile defense, what steps will you take to ensure transparency with Poland and the Czech Republic? [SEP] We haven't ironed out all the kinks with missile defense yet. But our U.S. partners are listening to our worries and trying to fix them. I'm cautiously optimistic about getting agreements done. It's all about the details; the experts need to agree on how to build trust and how to make it happen. Working together on a global missile defense system is the ideal. If we can cooperate in our region and then globally, that's in our best interest. Russia's worried the system's targeting them, so they'll react. I see it as defense, not offense. We have to show the experts it's not aimed at Russia, but to deal with the threats we all face together. About the Czech Republic and Poland, their leaders need to see Russia as a partner, not an enemy. We'll work through our differences. Transparency means being open, not just giving briefings. I'm happy to share the tech and info to show it's for single/dual-launch threats, not Russia's capabilities. We've come a long way since we started talking. This plan is a win-win for America and Russia.
label: General

sentence: Regarding these provocative activities coinciding with U.S. outreach, what is your understanding of Fidel Castro's role in the talks? Did his name arise during your discussions with Raul Castro? How is he? Given Republican opposition to lifting the embargo and establishing an embassy, will you personally engage them to prevent funding blocks? [SEP] Lesley, with all due respect, I must bring this to a close. We are running short on time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, your administration promotes a 'free and open Indo-Pacific' while you are visiting China, a nation that is not free or open. How do you reconcile this dichotomy, and will this not result in conflict? [SEP] Thank you, Mark. Let me just say, on the Prime Minister's point, that he will be shooting down those missiles very soon, once he completes his purchase of the military equipment from the United States. Just like we shot something down in Saudi Arabia. The Prime Minister of Japan is going to be purchasing massive amounts of military equipment, as he should. We make the best military equipment. He'll be purchasing it from the United States. Whether it's the F-35 fighter, which is the greatest in the world, or missiles, it's a lot of jobs for us and a lot of safety for Japan. As far as China is concerned, my relationship with President Xi is excellent. I like him a lot. I consider him a friend. He represents China; I represent the United States. His views are different on things, but they're similar on trade. The problem we have with China is that for decades it's been a very unfair trade situation. Our trade deficit is massive. It's hundreds of billions of dollars a year, and that doesn't include intellectual property. We've already started discussions with China because it has to come down. That has to do with free trade, fair trade, or reciprocal trade. I like reciprocal the best. It's understandable. We're going to charge the same as they're charging us. Reciprocal trade is very important to me. We have many countries that charge us a hundred-percent tax if we sell things into that country, and yet when they sell the same product into our country, we charge them nothing. You will be seeing that the United States will take very, very strong action. It's already started, but most of the legal foundation has now been done. You're going to see a very big difference, and it's going to happen very soon. Because the United States, by many countries, has been treated very, very unfairly when it comes to trade. Thank you very much. Regarding Japan defense equipment, a lot of them we purchase from the United States. North Korean situation becoming very tough, the Asia-Pacific security situation becoming very tough, we qualitatively and quantitatively, we have to enhance our defense capability. As the President mentioned, F-35A is a case in point. SM-3 Block IIA is another plan for purchase from the United States. Aegis vessels, the quality and the quantity must be enhanced. In that process, we will be buying more from the United States. That is what I am thinking. Now, North Korea: North Korea launched missiles. Immediately after that, we traced them; we were able to grasp and trace where they were going. Missile defense is something which is based upon the cooperation between Japan and the United States. Missile defense system is a cooperation between the two countries. For the intercepting and shooting down, if it is necessary, of course, we will do that—if it is necessary. But in doing so, U.S. and Japan will closely coordinate our actions. Thank you.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, did you discuss Canada's stimulus plans today? And what will the Canada-U.S. relationship look like in 4 years? [SEP] Wow, you managed to pack a whole bunch of questions into one. Were you talking to Jonathan? Is that--?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, given the current political climate, are you concerned that focusing on potential rivals might distract from the pressing issues facing the country? [SEP] My focus remains on the American people and the challenges they face. The political games will play themselves out, but my priority is always going to be serving the best interests of this nation.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Looking back on this difficult year, and acknowledging the healthcare rollout issues, what do you consider your biggest personal misstep? [SEP] Specifically related to healthcare, or in a more general sense?
label: Clarification

sentence: Senator, your critic claims your COVID response – failures in testing, inconsistent messaging on distancing and masks, and a disconnect from expert advice – have led to one American death per minute. How do you respond? [SEP] Well, that's probably why she was such a terrible candidate and had to drop out of the race. Her facts are just plain wrong. She's notoriously bad with facts, you know? We've done more testing than any other country, including India and China. We have the best testing. Everyone wants to know how we do it. And when you test so much, like we have – over 65 million people – you're bound to find more cases. Other countries, like Mexico, barely test at all. They only test people who are sick. We've done more testing than anyone. We've done the best job, even making ventilators that no one else could. We're the ventilator king! We're supplying the whole world. And our numbers are better than other countries. Even countries that supposedly did a good job initially. So, she's wrong on the facts, and I think she's going to fail. I'm looking forward to the debate between her and Mike Pence. He'll wipe the floor with her.
label: Dodging

sentence: Can you confirm the gender of the assailant and the type of weapon employed in the crime? [SEP] I'm afraid I can't. The investigation is ongoing, and I don't want to release any information that could compromise it.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the recent allegations against Judge Kavanaugh, would you be open to having the FBI conduct a supplemental investigation into the matter? [SEP] Well, traditionally, the FBI doesn't engage in such actions. Judge Kavanaugh has undergone six background checks throughout his career. He's an exceptional individual, incredibly intelligent, and an outstanding judge with a flawless record. I empathize with him and his family during this challenging time. These allegations should have been raised earlier. Senator Feinstein possessed the letter for an extended period; why didn't she address it sooner? The Democrats are simply obstructing and resisting. However, we should ensure a thorough process. I hope the accuser will come forward, and Judge Kavanaugh will have the opportunity to present his case before the Senate. Ultimately, they will vote based on his career and the evidence presented. He's a remarkable individual, and I feel deeply for him and his family.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. So when do you want to see it available? What would be a timeline that you would be happy with? [SEP] I would say that—yes, we will start distributing it immediately.

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. On Medicare, there are obviously millions of Americans who depend on Medicare. And when you talk about bending the long-term cost downward, or when you talk about cuts in the current proposal on Capitol Hill, you talk about cuts in Medicare, and they talk about cuts in Medicare, but there are never many specifics. Specifically, what kind of pain, what kind of sacrifice, are you calling on beneficiaries to make? And even if not right away, aren't future beneficiaries going to be getting less generous benefits than today's? [SEP] No. No.

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Africa, what concrete steps will the US take to ensure that aid programs are effective and truly benefit the people, rather than being siphoned off by corruption or mismanagement? [SEP] Look, we're very serious about making sure the money gets to the people who need it. We've changed our approach to aid, demanding accountability and good governance in return for our assistance. We're working with leaders who are committed to fighting corruption and investing in their people. And we're seeing progress, real progress, on the ground. It's not perfect, but we're moving in the right direction.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the UK's exemption from the travel ban despite higher coronavirus cases than many Schengen countries, why do they deserve this exception, especially with their recent surge in cases? Will you reconsider adding them to the list? [SEP] Well, the decision was based on recommendations from experts, but we're constantly reevaluating the situation with the latest data. The numbers out of the UK have been rising sharply, so we might have to include them on the list. We might even add a few other countries, and frankly, we're also considering removing some.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. New York Times? New York Times? [SEP] Oh, okay.

sentence: Q. Mr. President, Netanyahu has publicly acknowledged Israel's bombing raid in Syria. Can you tell us the target, whether you supported the raid, and its impact on regional stability? [SEP] I'm not going to offer any comments on that situation. Do you have another question?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the travel ban affecting individuals from Germany and other EU nations, while Turkey faces significantly higher case numbers, could you elaborate on the scientific rationale underpinning this discrepancy? Chancellor Merkel has voiced concerns about potential business relocations due to this ban. What assurances can you offer to alleviate these concerns? [SEP] Well, the Chancellor and I had a very productive discussion on this very topic. We've tasked our respective COVID teams to expedite a review of the existing travel restrictions. The situation is fluid, and we're constantly evaluating the data. An announcement regarding potential adjustments to the ban should be forthcoming in the days ahead. We want to ensure any decision made is sustainable and reflects the latest scientific understanding of the virus. Dinner awaits, so I must be brief.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Yes. President Niinistö, good to see you again. You had a conversation with President Trump about 5G and how Nokia, Finland's big company, could fill in that space. You also met with Chinese President Xi during the summer, in which you renewed the ties of friendship between the two nations. Do you believe that countries, particularly western countries, that put Huawei equipment in their 5G cores are at risk of national security? [SEP] Thank you. Like I told already: In Europe, the situation is maybe a bit different from that here, because the main company you mentioned is inside Europe, partly, at least.What European Union is now doing is making a risk assessment, asking each country what kind of experience, what kind of—what you have seen and found out. And that will be, well, finished in week two—or 2 weeks' time. And after that, we have to decide together, in European Union, which kind of tools we need to protect ourselves.You referred to my discussions with the President Xi. We didn't talk about 5G while meeting. And we all know Nokia is a major factor in this area. They will answer for themselves. Thank you. You please. Pick somebody who is really nice from Finland. No more Finnish—— Do you have a really nice person? Finnish—– I think they're all nice in Finland. Are there Finnish reporters? Just two. Okay. Uh, oh.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Obama, critics argue that the TPP lacks enforceable provisions to address currency manipulation and protect American jobs. How do you respond to these concerns, and what specific guarantees can you offer to ensure that the TPP will deliver on its promises? [SEP] We have provisions in TPP that advance the transparency and reporting functions that allow us to monitor whether we think that currency manipulation is taking place. One of the debates that took place—and there have been some who argue that we should have enforceable provisions that if you see currency going down too far that we should be able to impose tariffs on that country. The problem is, is that it's very hard to sort out sometimes why currency is going down and whether it's actually being manipulated.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Yesterday you called for a deadline for U.N. action on Kosovo. When would you like that deadline set? And are you at all concerned that taking that type of a stance is going to further inflame U.S. relations with Russia?And is there any chance that you're going to sign on to the Russian missile defense proposal? [SEP] No, thanks. A couple of points on that. First of all, I don't think I called for a deadline. I thought I said, time; I did? What exactly did I say? I said, deadline? Okay, yes, then I meant what I said. [] The question is whether or not there is going to be endless dialog on a subject that we have made up our mind about. We believe Kosovo ought to be independent.The G-8 discussions were all aimed at determining whether or not there is a way to make this acceptable to Russia. The ideal would be for Russia to say: Okay, we understand, and we accept this conclusion as well. And obviously, they're not there yet. And therefore, the reason why I said there needs to be movement is that there just cannot be continued drift, because I'm worried about expectations not being met in Kosovo. That's what I meant. And therefore, we'll push the process. President Putin made an interesting proposal on missile defense for Europe. I suggested—and I've made an interesting proposal for missile defense in Europe, by the way, all aimed at protecting Europe, not aimed at Russia. The reason I did is because the true threats we'll be facing will be from rogue nations that may end up with a deliverable weapon. So, I thought it was in the interest of peace that we have the capacity to intercept such a missile, and, therefore, need to proceed.And President Putin said, Well, I think I've got an idea that makes sense. And this is the joint use of radar in Azerbaijan. I said, Well, why don't we look at it? But during the discussions, it became apparent that he also had doubts about the proposal I made, as to its effectiveness or necessity. And I said: Well, you put out an idea, and I put an idea. Why don't we both get a group together to discuss our relative ideas in a transparent fashion; so put—get people from your Foreign Ministry, and we'll get people from the State Department and our respective defense departments and militaries to sit at the table and to share different ideas, to share ideas about technologies on how to intercept a missile and radar positioning to make sure that there's effective coverage?I thought his statement was an important statement to make. In other words, he recognized that there's an opportunity to work together. That's what friends do, by the way. Russia is not our enemy. As I said repeatedly, the cold war is over, and now we're dealing with threats in the 21st century. And I appreciated his recognition that there could be an opportunity to work together to deal with those threats. I viewed it as a very positive gesture, and looking forward to continuing discussions on this very subject in July when he comes to Maine. I would like to add for the citizens of Kosovo and its leadership, in my discussions, I found out consciousness and awareness of President Bush for the consequences of prolongation on— unacceptable prolongation around justifiable—prolongation of the process. And in this context, they should be clear that the President is aware of these consequences and is not willing them to be.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Kodak deal, the SEC is investigating potential irregularities. Given your administration's involvement, do you have any insight into the concerns being raised about the arrangements? [SEP] Look, I'm aware of the situation, but the specifics are handled by other departments. The core idea was solid, but we're reviewing the details. We'll get back to you once we've looked into it.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, with the ongoing tunnel operations, is a ceasefire truly viable at this point, or should we consider a different strategy? [SEP] Well, the proposed ceasefire allowed Israel to continue dismantling those tunnel networks, and they can do so without leveling Gaza's population centers. Dismantling those tunnels is absolutely necessary. There's a way to do it while minimizing bloodshed. Past conflicts have shown the devastating costs. The images we've seen – children, defenseless women, Israelis living in fear – are heartbreaking. A ceasefire that safeguards Israel's security, ensures they aren't constantly threatened by rockets, and acknowledges the Palestinian need for a decent life is crucial. It's a tough challenge, filled with anger and despair, but we must persevere. American leadership means stepping up when others won't. While these crises may pose tangential risks to the US, like ISIS, they aren't direct attacks. We intervene because of our unique responsibilities. We must be humble about our limitations, recognizing our finite resources after a decade of war. But we try. When John Kerry works to broker peace, we should support him, not criticize his efforts prematurely. No other nation is making such efforts. Our involvement usually leads to better outcomes, not perfect or immediate, but better. This applies to the Middle East, Ukraine, and Iraq. I'll conclude by reminding everyone that during my first term, the focus was on the economy and job creation. Our actions worked, and the economy improved. Six consecutive months of over 200,000 jobs created – a 17-year milestone – demonstrate the power of persistence.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with the midterm elections looming, is the Puerto Rico aid package intended to sway voters? [SEP] This is about doing what's right for the people of Puerto Rico, period. We fought hard to get this passed, despite the Democrats' best efforts to block it. The money is important, sure, but the real story is how we're going to rebuild the island's pharmaceutical industry. They were unfairly targeted, and we're going to bring those jobs back. It's a win-win for everyone.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the interconnectedness of these conflicts, are you concerned that instability in Yemen could spill over into other countries in the region, potentially exacerbating the threat of terrorism? [SEP] Regional stability is a top priority. We're working with our allies to contain the conflict in Yemen and prevent it from spreading. We're also providing support to neighboring countries to help them strengthen their borders and counterterrorism capabilities. It's a challenging situation, but we're determined to protect our interests and promote peace and security in the region.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, you've stressed over and over in recent days particularly the importance of FISA reform to help keep America safe, and yet you have not yet filled a key national security post. Fran Townsend announced her resignation months ago, in November. What is the delay there, and what are Americans to make of that delay? Is America less safe because of it? [SEP] We got a fine man named Joel Bagnal working that office right now. He's a professional. I trust his judgment. He's a real good guy. And no, they shouldn't worry about Joel. He knows what he's doing.John [John McKinnon, Wall Street Journal].
label: Explicit

sentence: You previously stated that the Taliban posed no threat to the Afghan people. Who do you believe is now supporting the Taliban's actions of kidnapping and attacking government officials, and what are their motivations? [SEP] Four years ago, I made that statement, and I stand by it. The Taliban pose dangers to our innocent people, including children attending school, our clergy, teachers, engineers, and international aid workers. However, they do not pose a threat to the Government of Afghanistan, its institutions, or the development of those institutions. They are a defeated and frustrated force resorting to cowardly acts such as killing schoolchildren. The question of who is supporting them is one we have been actively investigating. I hope the jirga between us and Pakistan will offer some solutions. One thing is clear: we know their vision of governance. They have held power and demonstrated their beliefs and actions to the world. It would be beneficial to speak with a mother of a young girl about her experiences under Taliban rule. These individuals are brutal and cold-blooded killers. That is their nature. The fundamental question for those of us who believe in freedom is whether we confront them and whether the effort to promote an alternative to their hateful ideology is worthwhile. We have determined that it is. That is why President Karzai is here at Camp David, discussing shared concerns and opportunities to defeat this vision of darkness. They do not believe in freedom and do not believe in a society where individuals can freely express themselves. This is an ongoing challenge for the free world. The real question is whether those of us who are fortunate enough to enjoy liberty will continue to pursue policies that protect our homeland and create conditions for lasting peace.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, following today's discussions, have the United States and Romania reached a consensus on the strategic direction for this region, particularly regarding NATO's role? [SEP] [Unintelligible mumbling]
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, Kevin McCarthy confidently predicts a Republican takeover of the House. Based on current data, do you concur with his assessment? [SEP] Well, the situation is fluid. As of now, we've lost a minimal number of seats. The possibility of retaining the House remains, albeit narrowly. For instance, we secured all three contested seats in Nevada, where I actively campaigned. However, this information was unavailable last night. So, it's a dynamic situation, but the outcome will be close.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. So, Mr. President, are you saying that your demands to Congress on immigration are completely non-negotiable, even if it means jeopardizing a DACA fix for 1.7 million people? [SEP] Look, DACA is something we could have fixed a long time ago. We were making progress, but then a judge had to get involved. Now it's in the hands of the Supreme Court. We'll see what they decide.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. I don't want to give anything away, but we saw your wife, the First Lady, drink a glass of French wine yesterday. So can you perhaps give up on your threat to put sanctions on French wine? Because if we've understood correctly, you have arrived at an agreement on taxing digital firms. Could you confirm that there has been an agreement between you and France on taxing digital firms? [SEP] I can confirm that the First Lady loved your French wine, okay? [] All right? She loved your French wine. So thank you very much. That's fine. You go ahead. Thank you. I will wait for the end of this press conference to have the press conference of the Presidency. I will leave that to the floor. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Good job.[] She's worse than you are! [] I can't believe it! Jonathan [Jonathan Karl, ABC News]. Come on up. Let's go.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. That was me.Coronavirus Prevention Efforts The President. Please. Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Tonight you're minimizing the risk of danger of the virus. Are you telling the Americans, except for the ones who are sick, not to change any of their behaviors? [SEP] No, I think you have to always—look, I do it a lot anyway, as you've probably heard. Wash your hands, stay clean. [] You don't have to necessarily grab every handrail unless you have to. You know, you do certain things that you do when you have the flu.I mean, view this the same as the flu. When somebody sneezes—I mean, I try and bail out as much as possible when they're sneezing. [] I had a man come up to me a week ago. I hadn't seen him in a long time, and I said, How you doing? He said, Fine, fine. And he hugs me, kiss. I said, Are you well? He says, No. [] He said, I have the worst fever and the worst flu. And he's hugging and kissing me. So I said, Excuse me. I went, and I started washing my hands. [] So you have to do that.You know, this is—I really think, Doctor, you ought to treat this like you treat the flu, right? And, you know, it's going to be—it's going to be fine.
label: Explicit

sentence: Can you understand why he held the position he did? And then on the other hand, is it intellectually consistent to say that gay and lesbians should be able to fight and die for this country but they should not be able to marry the people they love? [SEP] I don't want to go into detail about conversations in the Oval Office with my service chiefs. Jim Amos expressed the same concerns to me privately that he expressed publicly during his testimony. He said that there could be disruptions as a consequence of this. And what I said to him was that I was confident, looking at the history of the military with respect to racial integration, with respect to the inclusion of women in our Armed Forces, that that could be managed. And that was confirmed by the attitudinal studies that was done prior to this vote.And what he assured me of, and what all the service chiefs have assured me of, is that regardless of their concerns about disruptions, they were confident that they could implement this policy without it affecting our military cohesion and good discipline and readiness. And I take them at their word. And I've spoken to them since the vote took place and they have all said that we are going to implement this smartly and swiftly, and they are confident that it will not have an effect on our military effectiveness.So I'm very heartened by that. And I want to again give Bob Gates and Admiral Mullen enormous credit for having guided this process through in a way that preserves our primary responsibility to keep America safe and at the same time allows us to live up to our values.With respect to the issue of whether gays and lesbians should be able to get married, I've spoken about this recently. As I've said, my feelings about this are constantly evolving. I struggle with this. I have friends, I have people who work for me, who are in powerful, strong, long-lasting gay or lesbian unions. And they are extraordinary people, and this is something that means a lot to them and they care deeply about.At this point, what I've said is, is that my baseline is a strong civil union that provides them the protections and the legal rights that married couples have. And I think that's the right thing to do. But I recognize that from their perspective it is not enough, and I think this is something that we're going to continue to debate and I personally am going to continue to wrestle with going forward.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, you've stated that Iran sanctions aim to change their actions. Why hasn't this strategy succeeded with North Korea, a nuclear-armed nation? [SEP] I'm not about to give you a comprehensive overview of North Korean behavior. However, it's clear that they've pursued a course of severe isolation, which has had devastating consequences for their citizens. We remain hopeful that mounting pressure will encourage them to enhance their economic performance, break free from isolation, and return to multilateral discussions, leading to a shift in their behavior. While sanctions are not a magical solution, they do increase the probability of them modifying their behavior compared to a situation where they face no consequences for nuclear weapons testing. Next question, please.
label: Dodging

sentence: President Biden, regarding the recent announcement about accepting citizens from Venezuela, Haiti, Cuba, and Nicaragua, what is the specific timeline for this initiative, and are there plans to increase the number of individuals accepted or include additional nations? Furthermore, concerning fentanyl, what concrete steps are being taken, and what impact has the detention of Ovidio Guzmán had on fentanyl production, given the Cartel of the Pacific's involvement? [SEP] We're addressing migration comprehensively, cooperating closely with Mexico. Migrants face immense dangers on their journey north, exploited by smugglers and vulnerable to criminal elements. We aim for a long-term solution, tackling the root causes of migration by investing in development and opportunity in their home countries. While Mexico isn't establishing migration centers, we're providing essential support like shelters and healthcare. The Venezuelan humanitarian visa program has shown promising results, reducing migration flows. We're exploring similar approaches for other nations. Canada's efforts are commendable. We're also committed to combating violence by addressing its root causes and providing opportunities for young people, steering them away from criminal activity. My administration is dedicated to fighting corruption and ensuring security for our citizens. These are complex issues, but we're working diligently towards effective solutions.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Russia and Ukraine, you mentioned Putin might 'move in.' Has your administration definitively determined whether President Putin intends to invade or otherwise intervene in Ukraine? [SEP] The long and short of it is, Putin's the only one who knows what he's going to do. Nobody else is calling the shots. What's he thinking? It's anyone's guess. Maybe it depends on his mood that day. He could be thinking about the big picture, strategic deployments, the whole shebang. But has he decided to act? I honestly don't know. Our meetings haven't achieved much because my team is getting the sense that even his own people don't know his plans. He's got options on the table, like a major offensive from Belarus, but he needs the ground to freeze first. We're supporting Ukraine's defenses and monitoring the situation in the Baltic and Black Seas. He's weighing the potential consequences for Russia. My feeling is he's still undecided.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. But, sir, on that point, what evidence can you present to the American people that the people who attacked the United States on September the 11th are, in fact, the same people who are responsible for the bombings taking place in Iraq? What evidence can you present? And also, are you saying, sir, that Al Qaida in Iraq is the same organization being run by Usama bin Laden himself? [SEP] has sworn allegiance to Usama bin Laden. And the guys who had perpetuated the attacks on America—obviously, the guys on the airplane are dead, and the commanders, many of those are either dead or in captivity, like Khalid Sheikh Mohammed. But the people in Iraq, , has sworn allegiance to Usama bin Laden. And we need to take seriously, just like we need to take Al Qaida anywhere in the world seriously.Let's see here. Working my way around here. Sheryl [Sheryl Gay Stolberg, New York Times].
label: Explicit

sentence: Given Republican Leader McCarthy's prediction of a House takeover, what is your assessment of the current political landscape and the likelihood of maintaining Democratic control? [SEP] The situation remains fluid. While some seats have been lost, the possibility of retaining the House still exists, albeit narrowly. Victories in key races, such as those in Nevada, demonstrate the ongoing competitiveness. The final outcome remains uncertain.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. But my question is: Why not wear it more often or have the White House staff wear it more often to set an example for the country? [SEP] Well, I'm tested, and I'm sometimes surprised when I see somebody sitting and—like, with Joe. Joe feels very safe in a mask. I don't know, maybe he doesn't want to expose his face. I don't know what's going on. He'll be way away from people, nowhere near people—there will be nobody with him. He doesn't draw any crowds. He'll have circles. These big circles. They'll be way far away. There's no reason for him to have masks on.We get tested—I'm tested; I have people tested. When people come into the Oval Office, it's like a big deal. No matter who they are—if they're heads of countries, they all get tested. So I'm in sort of a different position. And maybe if I wasn't in that position, I'd be wearing it more. But I've worn masks. And especially I like to wear them when I'm in hospital. Not for me so much as for other people. Okay? Thanks. Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Secretary Yellen recently said that some of the tariffs on Chinese imports hurt consumers and businesses and aren't very strategic. Do you agree? And are you considering taking down some of those tariffs? [SEP] I'm talking with the Secretary when I get home. I am considering it. We did not impose any of those tariffs. They were imposed by the last administration, and they're under consideration.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, Donald Trump's repeated claims of a rigged election are a direct assault on our democratic foundations. Can you unequivocally assure the American public of a fair and impartial election process? And are you concerned that such pronouncements could erode public trust in the electoral outcome? Furthermore, should he prevail, despite your stated reservations, what message will you convey to the American people? [SEP] The ultimate arbiter is the American people. I possess a single vote, equivalent to every citizen. While I have expressed my perspective, the collective decision rests with them. Should an individual secure victory, my constitutional imperative mandates a seamless transfer of authority and a commitment to facilitating their success. The assertion of a rigged election is, frankly, preposterous. The federal government does not administer elections; that responsibility lies with states and local jurisdictions. Mr. Trump's propagation of conspiracy theories is baseless, even in states such as Texas. We are steadfast in our commitment to safeguarding election integrity, diligently monitoring for vulnerabilities and addressing any infringements upon federal law. This election will proceed as any other. It is not uncommon for those who face defeat to allege foul play, but rarely do such accusations precede the conclusion of the contest. My counsel to Mr. Trump is to concentrate on securing victory. Should he suffer defeat despite a significant lead, then perhaps he may have grounds for inquiry. However, that is not the current reality.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding China, you've expressed optimism despite General Mattis's concerns about China's revisionist tendencies. Do you believe a new Cold War can be avoided? And on Taiwan, what is your assessment of China's intentions, and what specific warnings did you convey to President Xi about potential military action? [SEP] Well, to address the first part of your question, I absolutely believe that a new Cold War is not inevitable. I have met with Xi Jinping on numerous occasions, and we have engaged in frank and open discussions across the board. I do not believe that China is currently planning an imminent invasion of Taiwan.I made it clear that our policy on Taiwan remains consistent and unchanged. We want to see cross-strait issues resolved peacefully, ensuring that military action never becomes necessary. I am confident that he understood my message, and I understood his.I believe that the United States is uniquely positioned, both economically and politically, to navigate the evolving global landscape.Furthermore, I believe that Xi Jinping and I have agreed to establish a mechanism whereby our respective chiefs of staff, relevant Cabinet members, and other officials will meet to discuss the specifics of the issues we raised, and we raised a significant number of issues.Seung Kim, Associated Press.
label: General
